HEADLINE: NATO's Cousin Organization Will Meet on Crisis

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Aug. 20

 BODY:
Amid criticism that they have not yet developed a coherent response to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, key Western European governments are to meet here Tuesday under the auspices of a little-known defense organization that has long been overshadowed by NATO.
The Western European Union, as it is known, comprises nine countries that are members of both the European Community and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. But unlike NATO, which can operate only in Europe and North America, the Western European Union has no geographical restrictions on its activities. 
''This is our main appeal today,'' an official of the organization said. ''Our charter says we can respond to threats to peace 'in whatever area this threat should arise' as well as to threats to our economic stability. It's tailor-made for the current crisis.''
With both foreign and defense ministers expected to attend Tuesday's session, experts said the organization aimed to coordinate European naval activities in the Persian Gulf and to provide a political umbrella for governments wary of becoming involved militarily in the crisis.
After the meeting, foreign ministers of the 12-nation European Community - the nine nations of the Western European Union plus Greece, Ireland and Denmark - are also to meet here to discuss the fate of some 7,700 Community citizens who are trapped in Iraq and Kuwait.
While working together diplomatically, however, Western European nations have so far failed to develop a common military strategy, with Britain alone in joining the United States in an international force protecting Saudi Arabia and only France also sending naval reinforcements to the gulf.
Several governments nonetheless now seem willing to act more forcefully. The Netherlands today ordered two frigates to the gulf. Warships sent by Italy and Belgium to the eastern Mediterranean may also move into the gulf if given the green light by the Western European Union.
Belgium said any decision to send its three minesweepers into the gulf would depend on the Western European Union's stand.
Spain, which is allowing American aircraft to use United States bases in its territory to refuel on their way to Saudi Arabia, has already alerted several warships in expectation of the Paris meeting. Portugal and Luxembourg, the remaining members of the organization, have so far not disclosed their plans.
 
Bonn Won't Send Warships
BONN, West Germany, Aug. 20 (Reuters) - West Germany will not send any warships to the Persian Gulf because such action would violate its Constitution, Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher said today.
He told reporters that Chancellor Helmut Kohl and Government and party leaders had agreed unanimously that a military operation in the gulf region would be contrary to the Constitution, which bars West Germany from sending warships on combat missions outside NATO's area.
But he said the meeting, which included the opposition's candidate for chancellor, Oskar Lafontaine, favored a constitutional amendment to allow West German forces to go to the gulf as part of a United Nations force.

HEADLINE: Looking for Better Life, They Found Welfare

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NASHUA, N.H., Aug. 20

 BODY:
Cecelia D. Fernandes and her husband moved to New Hampshire 10 months ago, seeking a better place to raise their two children. They left a second-floor apartment in Lowell, Mass., looking for a backyard and lower rents.
Ms. Fernandes found the backyard, but she found something else she was not looking for: New Hampshire's economy had declined so much that she was unable to keep her family above the poverty line after she and her husband separated in January.
She is just one of many New Hampshire residents who have entered the halls of welfare offices for the first time in the past year. A Federal Agriculture Department report recently found that applications for welfare have risen 38 percent in New Hampshire, while food stamp applications have jumped 54 percent, the highest rise of any state in the country. 
 
A Regional Slowdown
New Hampshire's plight has been a direct consequence of a regional economic slowdown that has touched all the New England states, pushing up unemployment, slowing wage growth and depressing real estate prices after years of spectacular growth. But state officials say the economic decline has been particularly hard and fast in New Hampshire, and that people who migrated to the state only a year ago are discovering a chilly job market.
Officials at the state's Division of Human Services recently concluded a six month study to discover the roots of the state's sharp increase in welfare applicants. The three most typical situations, the study found, involved families who were splitting up, people who had been laid off or had lost income such as child support, and those who had moved to the state but had been unable to find a good job.
Ms. Fernandes qualifies in the first category. She and her husband are getting a divorce. She gave birth to her third son 12 days ago, but has managed to hold down an $8,500-a-year job as a preschool aide in Lowell, a 20-minute trip away. She is not looking for a better-paying job because one of her children will attend the preschool with her beginning in September, off-setting her child-care costs.
When her husband recently started sending child support payments of $112 a week, she went off welfare but still relies on $70 a week in food stamps. And she has moved into a two-bedroom apartment in Nashua that has a backyard. ''There's room for the children to play outside, so it's nice,'' she said.
 
Named Best Place to Live
Ms. Fernandes's story is a common one in Nashua, where state officials report that applications for welfare and food stamps have jumped more than 50 percent in the past year. Only a few years ago, Nashua was bursting with civic pride when Money magazine ranked it as the best place to live in the country, citing its strong economy, low crime rate and arts and leisure attractions. Today, the city's unemployment stands at 7.1 percent, up from 2.9 percent in 1989.
Madeline Avilus, a 37-year-old mother of two who is separated from her husband, applied for welfare benefits for the first time a year ago when she lost her job working for a temporary-employment agency. Ms. Avilus, who had moved from Massachusetts to New Hampshire three years ago, had been working through the agency for Lockheed Sanders, a defense electronics subsidiary of the Lockheed Corporation that relies almost entirely on federal contracts. ''I was hoping that it would lead to a full-time job at Sanders, but then the company started laying people off,'' Ms. Avilus said.
''A year ago, this place was supposed to be the best place to get a job. People told me there were lots of jobs and career opportunities. But now there are no jobs,'' said Ms. Avilus, who is applying for financial assistance at a local technical college where she wants to study to be a paralegal.
 
Looking for Work
Jessica Creekmore moved from Massachusetts to New Hampshire four months ago because she had heard that the cost of living was lower. But as a 21-year-old mother of two children who is pregnant with her third child, Ms. Creekmore is applying for welfare and food stamps because her husband, from whom she is separated, has stopped sending child-support payments.
Unable to find a job, Ms. Creekmore said she needs to find work that pays enough to cover her child care costs, which she estimates at $170 a week. ''I wouldn't apply for welfare if I could get a job and do day care, too, but I can't do both at the same time,'' she said.
Ms. Creekmore, who estimates that she is about one month pregnant, has not seen a doctor yet about her pregnancy because of the expense, but she is applying for Medicaid so that she can seek medical care. She has gotten clothes for her family at the Salvation Army in Nashua.
Except for a three-month period a year ago, this is Ms. Creekmore's first experience with welfare and food stamps. ''It's my own fault,'' she said. ''I got married too young. I had kids too young. I'm pregnant again, and I don't believe in abortion. It's all my own fault.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: New Hampshire's economic decline has pushed some families into unexpected poverty. Applicants for welfare have increased by 38 percent in the state, while food stamp applications have jumped 54 percent, the highest rise of any state in the country. After separating from her husband, Cecelia D. Fernandes found herself applying for welfare. She shopped at a supermarket in Nashua. (Rick Friedman for The New York Times)

LENGTH: 489 words

HEADLINE: Time Squeezes Iraq

 BODY:
A frustrated and besieged Saddam Hussein now makes a liar of his Foreign Minister and affronts law and Islamic custom by interning ''foreign guests'' in Iraq and Kuwait. In fact, as President Bush said yesterday, thousands of innocent citizens are now hostages. Small wonder that some Americans respond viscerally, urging armed reprisals or even a declaration of war. 
A less heated reading is that Iraq's latest outrage is more desperate than menacing. It affords no reason suddenly to deviate from the strong, sound policies that Mr. Bush and the world are still arraying against this outlaw regime. Once military forces are in place opposing Iraq, the strength that will free hostages and end the crisis is the strength to be patient.
Pessimists fear that time is on President Hussein's side, that leaks will spring in the oil embargo against Iraq and that Americans won't support a prolonged siege in the Persian Gulf. These assumptions are highly debatable. Iraq's economy and morale are already being squeezed, its ports closed by a growing international armada that will soon total more than 100 ships.
Baghdad has yet to gain a single major ally. On the contrary, the massive deployment of planes, ships and troops to Saudi Arabia seems already to have achieved its purpose, of deterring wider Iraqi adventurism. The United Arab Emirates now joins in asking American military help.
The policy intended to force Saddam Hussein to disgorge Kuwait is not an American but an international effort, and that policy has already won the support of an impressively united United Nations. It has condemned Iraq's use of foreigners as human shields, an affront that has helped nudge France closer to the American view on the need for multinational enforcement of a U.N. embargo. And as Mr. Bush noted yesterday, for the first time since World War II the Soviet Union and the United States are again allies against aggression.
Its pipelines closed and its supply routes through Jordan in doubt, Iraq turned to Iran for trade and aid. But the humiliating gift to Teheran of disputed territory gained little for President Hussein except the ability to shift 140,000 Iraqi soldiers to the southern frontier.
And now he maneuvers in ways that suggest he is groping to try to undo a monumental miscalculation. Dispersing hostages as human shields to scattered bases bespeaks fear of attack, not lust for vengeance. He implies that, if pressed solely by Arabs, he just might leave Kuwait. And he abruptly offers to free all hostages and accept U.N. peacekeepers if the U.S. withdraws forces from Saudi Arabia.
These quick shifts argue that Saddam Hussein does not believe time is on Iraq's side. Mr. Bush, and the world, can draw encouragement from these gyrations. The once-unthinkable idea that Iraq would yield up Kuwait with little to show for its conquest now seems conceivable, if the world maintains its strength - and patience.

HEADLINE: Try International Law in Dealing With Iraq

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It might be useful to consider Iraqi behavior from three different points of view: legal, moral and political.
Legally, there is no doubt that the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait violated the United Nations Charter, which forbids the threat or use of force against the territorial integrity or political independence of any state. However Iraq might have viewed Kuwait, to the other members of the United Nations it was a member and a state.
But the United States must have peculiar problems in applying these provisions in light of our actions in Grenada, Panama and Nicaragua. To imagine that the countries of the Middle East are not familiar with this recent history is naive. 
The responses to this violation of law by Iraq are being made by the United Nations itself, whose Security Council has decided to institute an embargo. There are legal problems regarding the Council's authority, shown by our own violation of the equivalent sanctions imposed by the Council against Southern Rhodesia before it became Zimbabwe. Again, it would be naive to imagine the people in the Middle East and elsewhere are unaware of the hypocrisy apparent in our righteous rhetoric.
Morally, there is an even more muddled situation. Kuwait is not morally entitled to independence or the continuation of its preinvasion Constitution any more than Iraq is morally entitled to take the country over. The wealth of the Middle East results primarily from nature's distribution of oil, regardless of the moral stature of the elites controlling territory.
Nor were the British and others impelled by moral imperatives when supporting clan leaders as ''sovereigns'' of territories detached from the Ottoman Empire. It is hard to understand why the happiness of the greatest number of people in the advanced industrial states, and their thirst for cheap oil, is a better guide to moral righteousness than the ambitions of Arab leaders or the Arab people as a whole. In my opinion, the moral analysis leads to no clear result at this time.
Politically, the picture is, if anything, even more muddled. No doubt short-term American political interest would be served by the elimination of Saddam Hussein from Middle Eastern politics, but whether that would serve our long-term interests will not be clear, unless we know who would succeed him, what the impact of the methods used to displace him would be on the area's other political actors and other factors.
In any case, that elimination is probably not feasible except by luck or an intrigue that would be more likely to fail than succeed and would be almost certain to fail in the long run, even if it succeeds in the short. The Iranian lessons of Mohammed Mossadegh and the Shah, with the ultimate rise of fundamentalism and the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini as its result, must not be forgotten.
Nor is it clear that destroying Saddam Hussein will destroy his poison gas stocks and nuclear facilities or that his successor will care less for those tools than he. Do we plan to conquer Iraq and occupy it? Really?
Finally, the economic, social and other implications of our re-entering the Middle East as a military presence seem in danger of being underestimated. We withdrew in some disarray from Lebanon when the oversimplifications that guided military policy became clear, and Lebanon is now bordering on anarchy; the Palestine Liberation Organization is back. It is not clear what air and naval power will do to the play of politics, and the strategist Karl von Clausewitz showed more than a century and a half ago how military activity not coordinated with a rational political program is self-destructive. Have our leaders in mind a realistic plan for our withdrawal and for the future of Iraq under Saddam Hussein? Or are we once again engaging in short-term wishful thinking?
I suggest that America's clearest advantage now lies in the international law we have disparaged for 10 years and more, and in the legal institutions that remove these questions from national discretion and place them on the international agenda, however frustrating the process may be.
 
ALFRED P. RUBIN
Medford, Mass., Aug. 9, 1990
 The writer is professor of international law at Tufts University.

SECTION: Section A; Page 27, Column 5; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 749 words

HEADLINE: FOREIGN AFFAIRS;
Steady Against Saddam

BYLINE: By Flora Lewis

DATELINE: MINORCA, Spain

 BODY:
Early in the Persian Gulf crisis, Secretary of State James Baker retorted to the suggestion that the invasion of Kuwait was an Arab issue, for the Arab states to settle. ''No,'' he said, ''it is a world issue.'' So it remains.
It is about power and domination. It isn't essentially about the legitimacy of Kuwaiti emirs nor their country's right to independence. Nor is it about the price of oil. The price of oil was going up anyway, because of OPEC's agreement and mostly because the U.S. and others have grown sloppy about applying the 1970's lessons of excessive dependence. 
True, there would probably have been little world reaction had it not been for the oil and wealth at stake. But it is straightforward realism, not hypocrisy, to see that the oil and wealth concerned make the difference between another nasty aggression in an unstable region and the future of the world.
No country would be unaffected, no economy would be reliable, no development plans sustainable if President Saddam Hussein of Iraq could achieve his ambition of becoming master of the gulf. The Arab regimes in the area are in imminent danger, which is why they welcome Western protective force. But the U.S. would lose not only its world power status but its ability to govern its own destiny if it were unwilling to confront the menace.
This central issue must be clearly understood before the temptation grows to bog down in arguments about cost, strategic options and Arab history. The choice is not whether to confront President Hussein or to seek a tolerable compromise; it is whether to accept the challenge now or later, in much worse circumstances.
The enormous military buildup being established against him is not an extravagance. In strictly military terms, it is sound. The Soviets displayed in their invasions of Czechoslovakia in 1968 and Afghanistan in 1979 the military truism that force has the best chance of rapid success if it's overwhelming. That still holds. The opposite approach of sidling into battle, as the U.S. did in Vietnam, is the most dangerous.
But the Soviet campaigns also showed that brilliant military operations aren't enough. The political objectives must be evident and widely acceptable. This is the case in the gulf as long as the United States keeps its cool resolve and its determination to rally international support.
Saddam Hussein's craven use of hostages does not change the stakes. It is right to denounce him for that and to do all possible to extricate the hapless foreigners caught in his adventure.
But we must not repeat the grave mistake of the American Embassy hostage crisis in Teheran. The hostages' ordeal was enormously prolonged by the frenzied American reaction, proving to hostage-takers that they had stumbled on a much more potent weapon against the U.S. than they had imagined.
The hostages' value to President Hussein should not be enhanced by public wailing and media hysterics.
This is not to say that the United States can only counterattack. America and the rest of the world do not want to go to war. President Bush should continue to make that very clear, despite the shouts of Rambos like the editorialist of The Orange County Daily Pilot, in California, who wrote: ''America has spent $300 billion a year to build up its military. Let's put it to use.'' The limit on the capacity of firmly enforced sanctions and international isolation to wear Saddam Hussein down and prove his mistake depends on us, not on him. It is already a form of surrender to say that democracies haven't the stamina to keep up the pressure and must strike or quit.
Steadfastness is also the answer to emotional Arab populations that are cheering the Iraqi dictator. They are applauding him for bravura, for giving vent to their frustrations, but they don't applaud losers. He can only count on them as long as they think he will win.
The turmoil of the Arab world is deep and intricate. Saving kings and sheiks won't stabilize it. In any case, their era is hastening to a close. But the Arab dreams of renewing past glory can only be approached now by working with others for mutual benefit. It was the culture of Islamic civilization when Europe was backward that brought it pre-eminence. Arab intellectuals should remind their people of the real strength of their roots.
It isn't too early for the West to start thinking of post-Saddam relations with the Arabs on a higher, less cynical plane. Meanwhile, it must make sure Saddam fails.

HEADLINE: Subway Improvements Will Be Delayed

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW

 BODY:
Repairs to subway stations and tunnels, train yards and other New York mass-transit centers will be delayed for at least a year, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced yesterday.
About $500 million in capital projects planned for the next two years will be postponed, and $335 million of those projects may be eliminated if the city is unable to sell the New York Coliseum by the end of 1991, said Mortimer L. Downey, the agency's executive director.
Under a 1985 agreement between the city and the transportation authority, which jointly own the Coliseum, money from the sale of the four-acre Coliseum site was to be used for transit system improvements in the city and the region. Most of the money was to have gone to the New York City Transit Authority; the rest to suburban commuter railroads. 
The Metropolitan Transportation Authority oversees the Transit Authority, the Long Island Rail Road, the Metro-North Commuter Railroad, the Metropolitan Suburban Bus Authority and the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority.
 
Service Will Be Affected
''There will be impacts on service because of these delays,'' Mr. Downey said. ''Delaying the station projects is contrary to our goals of improving the stations and increasing ridership. But there's no other way to raise the money at this time.
''We'd expected this deal to close years ago,'' he added. ''We'll have to defer $170 million in projects that would have started in 1990 to 1991, and pay for them with money we know will be available next year. If the Coliseum doesn't close in 1991, we'll have to cancel the $335 million in projects permanently or from this five-year capital program. If it does close next year, we would have the funding in 1991 for all $500 million.''
The reduction in capital programs for the Transit Authority would be $299 million and for the suburban railroads, $36 million. As a result of the delay, the agency's 1990 capital spending will be cut from $1.5 billion to $1.2 billion.
The delays in capital improvements will cause additional problems for the Transit Authority, which announced last week that its operating-budget deficits were rapidly increasing.
 
Fares Could Increase
The deficits, which the agency estimated would be $109 million this year and more than $200 million in 1991, are likely to mean service cuts and fare increases, agency officials said. The growing deficits are a result of the New York area's weak economy; a sharp rise in subway fare-beaters, estimated at 6 percent of riders, and a 3.4 percent decline in ridership in the first half of 1990.
The Coliseum was put up for sale in February 1985, but litigation over various development proposals for the site have delayed the sale. If pending lawsuits are resolved and the site is sold by next spring, the capital program could move ahead, Mr. Downey said. ''If it's not sold by then, we have to assume it won't happen,'' he said.
The projects that are affected are part of an $8.6 billion, five-year capital program that began in 1987. In addition to the delay announced yesterday, the agency has had ''a small shortfall in Federal funds,'' Mr. Downey said. It had expected to receive $2 billion from the Federal Government for the five-year program, but will get only $1.9 billion, he said.
''Every other piece of the plan has fallen into place,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Board of Estimate Approves Rockaway Housing Complex

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
A proposed housing complex with 7,500 condominium apartments on a two-mile stretch of beachfront in the Arverne section of Rockaway in Queens was approved last night by the New York City Board of Estimate.
The site, which was cleared of run-down beach bungalows more than 20 years ago through urban renewal, is the largest vacant property available for development in the city.
The developer, Oceanview Associates, bid $90 million last year to buy the 308 acres of city-owned land. It also agreed to provide as much as $300 million to create streets, sewers, playgrounds, garage space, parks, a firehouse and other public works. 
In its last meeting before its demise under the new City Charter, the board voted 9 to 2 to approve the project. Before the vote, city officials said the city had agreed to pay a substantial portion of the cost of the public works, including building two schools, and some of the cost of new roads and sewers. In all, the city's share would come to about $138 million and the developer's share would be about $180 million, said Felice Michetti, the Commissioner of Housing Preservation and Development.
 
Holtzman Votes No
City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman cast the only votes against the proposal. Ms. Holtzman said she was concerned because the financial arrangements had shifted significantly recently, with the city picking up more of the burden. Ms. Holtzman also cited criticisms of the proposal from state environmental officials, who said that not enough attention had been paid to the potential effects of beach erosion and water pollution.
Ms. Holtzman said she favored redeveloping the vast stretch of land at Arverne, ''but I'm not prepared to write a blank check.''
Borough President Claire Shulman of Queens, a longtime proponent of the plan, said she was more concerned ''about the environment of the people who live in the Rockaways.''
Mrs. Shulman said the complex would help revitalize the area, one of the poorest in the city, and would give the Rockaways ''a shot in the arm.'' #3- and 4-Story Town Houses Most of the apartments would be in three- and four-story town houses, with the remainder in mid-rise buildings. When the plan was announced last year, city officials said the apartments would sell at market rates, at prices ranging from $155,000 to $180,000, and would be affordable to families with annual incomes of at least $60,000.
Ms. Michetti said yesterday that plans now call for apartments near the beach to sell for an average of $177,000 and for those farther from the beach to sell for an average of $135,000. To buy the more expensive apartments, a family would need an annual income of about $65,000, and to buy the less expensive ones a family would need an annual income of about $52,000, city officials said.
Some civic groups, particularly those involved with the Nehemiah program in Brooklyn, which produces low-cost subsidized row houses for families with incomes of about $33,000, had sought city support last year to build about 3,200 low-income town houses at Arverne.
But the Koch and Dinkins administrations, along with Mrs. Shulman and many residents of the Rockaways, supported market-rate housing. They contended that the Rockaway peninsula already contained more than its fair share of city housing projects and other low-income housing.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Reinstates Funds to Bolster Tourism

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins announced yesterday that he was reinstating city funds for the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau in an effort to halt the downturn in tourism.
''I realize how vital your efforts are to this city's economy,'' he said in a speech to the group's board yesterday. ''That's why I have reversed the decision of the previous administration to eliminate city funding of the C.V.B., and I have insured that your organization gets a share of the revenue generated by the increase in the hotel tax.''
During the Koch administration, the bureau's budget was cut by nearly one-third in the city's budget squeeze.
''We were getting about $1.2 million the last year,'' said Marshall E. Murdaugh, the president of the bureau. ''This was at a time when cities like Miami, Los Angeles and San Francisco had identified tourism as a growth industry that needed to be nurtured.''
Earlier this year, the Dinkins administration helped win passage of state legislation that permits one-quarter of 1 percent of the 21.5 percent hotel tax to go for tourism. City officials said the bureau was to get three-quarters of the money from that share of the tax, while the city would get the rest.
The bureau is to receive about $3 million a year, which with other funds will give it an annual budget of $7 million to $9 million, Mr. Murdaugh said. He said tourism, which the United States Travel Data Center estimates generates about $10 billion a year for the city, was ''generally down or flat.''
He said the funds would allow the bureau to double its sales staff to 10 people, reopen the visitors center in Times Square and open a Washington office to attract more conventions to New York.

HEADLINE: Richard Strout, 'TRB' Columnist And Capital Reporter, Dies at 92

BYLINE: By JOAN COOK

 BODY:
Richard L. Strout, the acerbic nonconformist who wrote the ''TRB From Washington'' political column in The New Republic for 40 years and was Washington correspondent for The Christian Science Monitor for more than 60 years, died Sunday at the Georgetown University Medical Center in Washington. He was 92 years old and lived in Washington.
Mr. Strout had been in the hospital since Aug. 8, when he suffered a fall, said Richard J. Cattani, editor of The Monitor.
As the pseudonymous TRB from 1943 to 1983, Mr. Strout was one of the country's most widely followed liberal columnists. He once compared Senator Joseph R. McCarthy to ''a mist that carries lethal contagion,'' and in 1958 he wrote of Vice President Richard M. Nixon, ''He is out for the kill and the scalp at any cost.'' 
''When I took the job, I was advised that the column was easy to write,'' he said in 1968. ''Just get mad at someone once a week and spit in his eye.''
 
A Passionate Liberal
But Mr. Strout's voice was seldom merely angry. His liberalism was passionate and his outlook broad. In his first column, at the height of World War II, he called for a national statement of postwar aims, saying, ''When a man dies, he wants to die for something important.''
''The rich stay rich in the U.S., and the poor, poor, and the gulf between them hardly changes,'' another column began. ''America's disparity of income is the single most significant and sinister social fact in the nation. Everything comes back to that.''
Mr. Strout succeeded Kenneth Crawford as the column's writer. The name TRB, the initials of the Brooklyn Rapid Transit system in reverse, was coined by Bruce Bliven, the magazine's onetime editor, who used to rush copy to the printer by subway in the days when it was published in New York.
Mr. Strout shunned entangling alliances with Washington politicians and avoided the round of Georgetown cocktail parties. He covered 12 Presidents, from Warren G. Harding to Ronald Reagan, and national scandals from Teapot Dome to Watergate. He characterized Calvin Coolidge as ''a sharp, unimaginative Yankee who took lots of naps'' and Herbert Hoover as ''a towering figure in many ways, caught in a Greek tragedy he never understood.'' The greatest President, he wrote, was Franklin D. Roosevelt, ''a superb combination of Machiavelli's lion and fox.''
 
To Washington in a Model T
Richard Lee Strout was born in Cohoes, N.Y., on March 14, 1898, and raised in Brooklyn. After graduating from Harvard University in 1919, he worked his way across the Atlantic on a grain ship and began his career as a confidential assistant to the editor of The Sheffield Independent in England. He returned to the United States in 1921 and worked briefly for The Boston Post, then moved to The Monitor.
In 1923, after receiving a master's degree in economics from Harvard, he drove his Model T Ford to The Monitor's Washington bureau, where he remained until his retirement in 1984.
He won many awards, including a Pulitzer Prize for lifetime achievement in 1978 and the George Polk Memorial Award for national reporting in 1958.
In his last TRB column, on the crisis in Soviet-American relations in April 1983, he wrote: ''Presidents come and Presidents go. You can measure passage of time, I think, by counting the things we knew couldn't happen.'' After listing events like school desegregation and the election of a Catholic President, he added, ''And there was another absolute: America couldn't lose a war.''
Mr. Strout's first wife, Edith Mayne, died in 1932.
He is survived by his wife, the former Ernestine Wilke; four daughters, Elizabeth Zimmmerman of Minneapolis, Mary Rubeiz of Geneva, Phyllis Norris of Santa Cruz, Calif., and Nancy Dulaney of Washington; a son, Alan M. of Weston, Mass., 11 grandchildren and 2 great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: New Direction in Physics: Back in Time

BYLINE: By MALCOLM W. BROWNE

 BODY:
THE possibility of traveling through time, of creating something out of nothing and even of spawning a new universe in a laboratory are notions ordinarily reserved to fiction rather than science. But a rash of articles in some of the most prestigious scientific publications suggests that theoretical physicists have begun to take such outlandish ideas seriously.
Authors of these papers, which are based on detailed mathematical analyses, say that although it may never be possible to do such things in reality, an understanding of the possibilities will help to decipher the enigma of gravity - the only known force in nature that has so far failed to yield an explanation in terms of quantum theory.
Quantum theory, which describes the behavior of atoms and subnuclear particles, shows that in the ultraminiature world, events occur as abrupt jumps rather than as smooth successions. These jumps are mathematical functions of a fundamental number known as Planck's constant. 
Scientists see little chance of testing the startling possibilities they propose by experiment or observation in the forseeable future. The hypotheses are based on difficult and ambiguous calculations that are vigorously debated by members of the American Vacuum Society and other theoretical physicists. Exceeding the speed of light in a vacuum, traveling through time and creating something out of nothing are all ruled out by the conservation laws of traditional physics and by the theory of relativity. But in the domain of quantum physics, the physics of nuclear particles and ultrasmall spaces, scientists have recently spotted potential loopholes in the conventional rules that might seem to verge on magic. Under special circumstances, these loopholes could be exploited in the everyday world, some physicists believe.
Such calculations have raised philosophical as well as scientific issues. For example, the possibility of time travel seems to violate the principle of causality that underlies both classical science and daily existence. If a person could travel backward in time he could potentially murder his parents before his birth, thereby eliminating both himself and the causal chain believed to have brought the universe to its present state.
Three years ago Dr. Kip S. Thorne, a theoretical physicist at the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena, caused a stir among theoretical astrophysicists by suggesting the possibility of building a time machine. Dr. Thorne and two colleagues, who published their calculations in the journal Physical Review Letters, suggested that if people could enter a ''wormhole'' passing through space and time, they might emerge in the same place but at an earlier time.
In Dr. Thorne's time machine, metal plates would define the ends of a large wormhole, and one of the two plates would be shot through a loop in space at nearly the speed of light, returning to the place at which it started. Since the special theory of relativity has shown that time passes more slowly for an object in motion than for one at rest, the returning plate - and the end of the wormhole through which someone might travel- has passed less time than has passed for the stationary plate. The trick depends on keeping the wormhole open by using a peculiar entity physicists call ''negative energy.''
Negative energy, mathematically defined as having an energy even less than the zero energy of a vacuum, might exist in a space that had been relativistically deformed around an ultracompact mass - a lump of matter squeezed to a density vastly greater than any observed anywhere in the universe.
One of the difficulties raised by Dr. Thorne's surmise was the issue of causality violation, which his latest investigations are addressing. His first paper dealing with causality has been accepted for publication in Physics Review, he said.
''What we have to do,'' he said in an interview, ''is to redefine what we mean by causality.'' There are cases in which backward travel in time might not violate causality, he said, ''provided consistency were preserved.''
Analysis on Changing History Dr. Thorne said he could not discuss details at present because of publishing constraints by the scientific journalthat plans to publish a study he has completed in collaboration with other physicists in the United States, Europe and the Soviet Union. But a former student of Dr. Thorne, Dr. Ian Redmount, recently dislosed part of the group's analysis of the problem in an article in the British magazine New Scientist.
Dr. Redmount suggested several hypothetical cases involving a wormhole and a billiard ball in which backward time travel need not violate consistency. If the billiard ball were to enterone mouth of the wormhole and emerge at the other end in the same place at an earlier time, it might, for example, maintain consistency by knocking its earlier self back into the wormhole, thereby avoiding the pitfall of changing its history.
The negative energy Dr. Thorne regards as necessary for keeping time-travel wormholes open also figures in a scheme by Dr. Alan H. Guth of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology for creating new universes in the laboratory.
Dr. Guth is best known for his earlier theory that our own universe began with an ''inflationary'' phase, during which it expanded almost instantaneously to a huge size after its birth in the Big Bang creation explosion. During the inflationary phase, Dr. Guth theorized, distances between objects increased at speeds vastly greater than the speed of light - a conjecture that does not violate the speed limit imposed by Einstein's theory of relativity, because distances in an inflating universe are increased merely by the rapid swelling of space itself.
In their recent investigation, Dr. Guth and his colleagues at M.I.T. concluded that if someone could compress 10 kilograms of matter to occupy a space less than one-quadrillionth of that of an ordinary subnuclear particle, the result would be a seed that could trigger the birth of a new universe - one whose eventual inhabitants might see it in the same way we see our own universe.
A 'False Vacuum' The seed, Dr. Guth says, would consist of a spatial region of ''false vacuum'' - a region charged with the negative energy essential to driving the inflation of the infant universe. Starting from virtually nothing, the expanding space in such a universe would create for itself all the particles of matter and energy that make up a universe like our own.
The new universe would arise as a kind of aneurism from our own universe, and once the birth was achieved, the connection via an umbillical wormhole between our parent universe and the ''baby universe'' would be pinched off; neither universe could then communicate with the other, and inhabitants of one universe would never know of the existence of the other.
Dr. Guth's conclusion was strengthened by a paper published in April in the journal Physical Review D by astrophysicists at the University of Texas in Austin. Dr. Willy Fischler, Dr. Joseph Polchinski and a student, Dr. Daniel Morgan, investigated Dr. Guth's ''baby universe'' theory using an different approach.
Dr. Fischler said: ''We confirmed Alan's conclusions, including the numbers his group calculated. Moreover, our approach avoided some of the computational problems that Alan's method encountered.
''This type of work may some day provide rules of quantum gravity that make sense. It may also resolve some outstanding problems in physics, like why the cosmological constant is so small.''
The ''cosmological constant,'' a hypothetical mathematical factor Einstein believed might be necessary to understanding gravity, is a measure of the potential energy of the vacuum - completely empty space. Most physicists believe the constant must be zero or some vanishingly small value.
The Peculiar Exists Underlying all this speculation is the certainty that very peculiar things really do happen in the quantum realm - quantum effects that are essential to the functioning of transistors and most other modern electronic equipment.
Among these effects is ''tunneling,'' the mysterious disappearance of a particle (such as an electron) on one side of a barrier that ''classical'' physics would define as impenetrable, and the particle's reappearanceon the other side of the barrier. Some of the wormholes physicists are studying might serve as channels of communication between isolated universes by means of a similar kind of tunneling.
The renowned British astrophysicist Stephen W. Hawking of Cambridge University and Dr. Sidney Coleman of Harvard University suggest that space is riddled with microscopic wormholes that constantly pop into and out of existence, sometimes creating baby universes.
''The sea of baby universes in which our universe moves,'' Dr. Coleman said in an interview, ''evolves by exchanging information between past and future universes. In a sense, information about such things as the cosmological constant is communicated to our universe from the outside, letting us look into our own generic future.''
Controversy Acknowledged ''Stephen Hawking and I have perhaps worked this out correctly, or perhaps we've made fools of ourselves. I won't tell you this subject isn't controversial,'' he added.
Among the physicists who sharply disagree with this interpretation is Dr. Fischler of the University of Texas.
But there seems to be little disagreement about some of the factors in their calculations, including that of negative energy.
According to quantum theory, the vacuum contains neither matter nor energy, but it does contain ''fluctuations,'' transitions between something and nothing in which potential existence can be transformed into real existence by the addition of energy.(Energy and matter are equivalent, since all matter ultimately consists of packets of energy.) Thus, the vacuum's totally empty space is actually a seething turmoil of creation and annihilation, which to the ordinary world appears calm because the scale of fluctuations in the vacuum is tiny and the fluctuations tend to cancel each other out. But experiments using giant particle accelerators have shown that every conceivable kind of subnuclear particle (along with its antimatter equivalent particle) is constantly popping into existence in the vacuum only to be immediately reunited with its antiparticle in mutual annihilation.
These short-lived ''virtual'' particles can be converted into a real particle by supplying it with the needed energy a task made possible by modern particle accelerators.
Fluctuations Observed In 1948 a Dutch physicist, Hendrick B. G. Casimir, theorized that if two electrically conductive metal plates are held close enough together in a vacuum, they distort the normal quantum fluctuations in the vacuum between them, and the result is a measurable attraction between the plates. Experiments in the 1950's confirmed the Casimir prediction. Theorists have since concluded that because of the distortion in fluctuations, the vacuum between the conducting plates contains negative energy.
Two of the most surprising new studies were reported in separate papers published this spring in Physics Letters B by Klaus Scharnhorst of Humboldt University in East Berlin and Gabriel Barton of the University of Sussex in Brighton, England. Using different approaches, the two physicists concluded that Casimir plates would exhibit another strange property: light passing through the vacuum between them would travel very slightly faster than does light in an ordinary vacuum.
This means only, they said, that the vacuum between the plates has a different structure than the normal vacuum, not that the speed limit imposed by relativity has really been violated. Some theorists have noted that the theory of relativity has not been violated because the new work merely suggests that the speed limit for light must be slightly raised in special circumstances. The predicted increase in the speed of the light would be so tiny, moreover, that no experiment could measure it.
Nonetheless, these papers have prompted a wave of new speculation that is compelling physicists to re-examine long-held assumptions.
In a comment on the work published by the British journal Nature, Dr. Stephen M. Barnett of Oxford University wrote, ''The vacuum is certainly a most mysterious and elusive object that makes itself known by only the most indirect of hints.''

HEADLINE: A Treat for Night Owls in Poland

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WARSAW

 BODY:
It is midnight on a Wednesday and the line is forming for lemon-flavored Perrier, imported muesli, German beer and even Arab cheese. The counters gleam, the blue-frocked saleswomen beam, and business is transacted at a pace that startles people in this service-starved city.
Welcome to Michel Badre, Warsaw's first 24-hour convenience store. There are no Slurpees or Big Gulp beverage containers here. Yet in a city where they roll up the sidewalks by 10 P.M., the late-night, premium-priced impulse purchase has become the latest consumer phenomenon.
The business is the brainchild of Michel Badre, a French businessman from Strasbourg who hopes to become Poland's first national franchiser. Mr. Badre said he had never heard of America's ubiquitous 7-Eleven stores. But he knows that franchise arrangements like those pioneered by McDonald's translate in any language into billions of dollars - for the franchiser. 
Even so, turning Western ideas into reality in Poland will not be easy. Simple activities in the Western world, like making change, can be complicated for Polish store owners. And training sales help in the fine art of service has already proved tricky for Mr. Badre.
Yet he and his two Polish partners have come up with imaginative ways to cope with these and other obstacles. They hope to open 12 Michel Badre stores in Poland within a year.
Just as McDonald's strives to create a french fry that tastes the same in the capital of the Soviet Union and in Moscow, Idaho, Mr. Badre is prepared to offer the same consistently enticing brand of pate de foie gras throughout Poland.
''What we're trying to do is import a different method, a different image of commerce, another way of looking at things,'' said Mr. Badre, who was interviewed during one of his recent visits to Warsaw.
 
A Problem With Change
Mr. Badre's concepts are novel in food retailing in post-Communist Poland. Although private shops are taking hold in some of the major cities, the majority of stores in Warsaw are still Government-owned enterprises where the floors are dirty and the attitude of employees toward customers ranges from indifference to resentment.
Want a plastic bag? It's an extra cost. And most purchases cannot be concluded without that quintessential Polish ritual: the requirement that customers fish through every pocket to provide the necessary change.
Mr. Badre's formula seems to be working. Although Government statistics show Poland in a deep recession, the crowds are flocking to his store, opened this summer on one of Warsaw's major thoroughfares.
 
'A Tremendous Difference'
''There is a tremendous difference here,'' said Zbigniew Komon, a technician at the Warsaw phone company who says he is a regular customer. ''The sales assistants are very nice, there is a wide selection of goods, and everyone who works here is trying to help you. It's especially good that they are open on Saturdays and Sundays. Before, it was hardly possible to buy anything on the weekends.''
Mr. Badre said that 30 Polish investors had made offers for the chance to display the Michel Badre name and tricolor emblem, but Mr. Badre has not signed any agreements yet. Franchisers have to agree to buy 75 percent of their merchandise from Mr. Badre and would be subject to regular inspections to assure that they are meeting the standards set by the prototype store in Warsaw.
The venture was begun in July 1989, when a restaurateur in Strasbourg who bought wine from Mr. Badre, a food and beverage executive, introduced him to Slawomir Rudnicki, who was exporting flowers from Poland to Finland.
Mr. Badre had the notion that the collapsing Communist system in Poland offered opportunities for Western investors. Mr. Rudnicki was eager to participate in a food retailing venture and he brought in a friend, Dariusz Robicki, who helped the company obtain its choice location in Warsaw. The Frenchman and the two Polish partners together initially invested more than $700,000.
 
Imported Even the Paint
Although Mr. Badre professes to be pleased with the results so far, he said it had not been easy to turn his ideas about business into reality in Poland. Renovation of the first location in Warsaw, for example, turned into a nightmare of delays and shoddy workmanship and the company ended up importing building supplies and even paint from France.
Instilling the Western ideal of service with a smile has also presented problems. Juliusz Baranowski, the store's manager, said he had to dismiss three salespeople on the staff of 36 for rudeness to customers. He said several more dismissals were imminent for the same reason.
Mr. Baranowski, who worked previously at Warsaw's state-run radio factory, said it had taken time to convince his employees that it was not appropriate to smoke at the counter or to continue personal conversations when a customer walked in.
Still, Mr. Baranowski has come up with some innovative strategies for overcoming this country's obstacles to service-oriented retailing.
 
New Policy on Making Change
The Michel Badre store has a policy, which is not always observed, that the cashier, not the customer, will provide the change for each purchase. That is not as easy as it sounds. The present exchange rate for the Polish zloty is 9,500 to the dollar, and each customer spends tens of thousands of zlotys in 100- and 500-zloty denominations.
That makes it difficult for shopkeepers to make change. Mr. Baranowski says his store uses more 100-zloty notes daily than the central bank has available for all the stores in Warsaw. To avoid shortages, he said, he has an arrangement with nearby restaurants to buy up their small bills at the end of each evening's business.
 
Seeking Local Suppliers
Lining up local suppliers is also potentially nettlesome, one reason the chain imports nearly all its products. Mr. Baranowski says he is prepared to sell Polish goods, ''but only of quality.''
His first attempt to do business with Poland's state-run dairy monopoly proved disappointing. High-quality milk is hard to find in Poland and Michel Badre has been doing a brisk business selling far more expensive milk imported from France. Still, Mr. Baranowski thought he could make a better profit by signing a contract with a local dairy that could consistently deliver milk that was not spoiled or contaminated.
After a brief search, Mr. Baranowski found such a supplier, but he has failed to strike a deal despite negotiations that included a guaranteed 10 percent premium for the dairy above the payments made by its other customers. The reason: Mr. Baranowski said the dairy cooperative just did not want to bother to change its delivery schedule.
 
'He's Very Critical'
The Polish partners say the store's success stems, in part, from Mr. Badre's discerning eye for detail.
''It's only natural that because Mr. Badre lives in the West, he can organize a store better than we do in Poland,'' Mr. Rudnicki said. ''He's very critical and he spots a lot of things that you can change right away. When there are two saleswomen talking and they don't stop their conversation when a customer comes in; when a salesperson can't explain one of the products in the store, this is important. We see it, too, but it doesn't strike us as much.''
Still, Mr. Rudnicki says it will be a few years before capitalism makes inroads in Poland.
''If it's difficult to change the way of behavior for politicians, it's all the more difficult to change the behavior of the people,'' he said. ''If people behaved in one way for 45 years, it's going to take at least half that time again to reverse it. In the West it is simple: You give people a lot of money and they work better. Here, it's not the same. One in a hundred reacts to such an incentive. You have to have patience.''

HEADLINE: U.S.-Russian Shoemaking Venture Set

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
In a major consumer goods venture with the Soviet Union, a Long Island company has a preliminary agreement to help Russians produce 50 million pairs of shoes over the next decade.
The M.A.L. Sales Corporation of North Merrick, L.I., said it hoped to sign a final agreement in Moscow next month with Kimray, a Soviet shoemaker, and the Ministry of Light Industry of the Republic of Russia, to convert a factory to produce shoes for sale in both Russia and the West.
M.A.L., which specializes in making arrangements between American shoe retailers and domestic and foreign suppliers, will arrange for the Russians to buy American shoe manufacturing equipment, for the transportation and setting up of the equipment and for training some 600 Russian workers to use it. 
 
A Decade of Shoemaking
The 50 million pairs of leisure and work shoes to be produced over the next 10 years are expected to have a wholesale value of about $5 billion, according to Steve Wald, an M.A.L. consultant. But, he said, M.A.L. could not estimate now how much the deal might eventually be worth. The company expects to make money from the equipment sale and training contract and later to share in the revenue from the shoe sales.
M.A.L. expects to be paid in Russia with rubles and hard currency and to get additional hard currency from the shoes to be sold to the West, Mr. Wald added. ''Eventually, if all goes well, we hope to be hard-currency self-sufficient, but that may take some time,'' he said.
''The shoes will be in the economy price range,'' Mr. Wald said. ''That means that a canvas-and-leather jogger shoe will sell for the equivalent of $20. Later, we will also be making work shoes.'' Both the leisure shoe and the work shoe are said to be the types of footwear most in demand in Russia.
Initial goals are for production of 25,000 pairs of shoes daily and after two years this will be raised 100,000 a day, said Bert Cunningham, assistant to Stephen Latham, the Nassau County Commerce Commissioner.
 
'A Unique Deal'
''We think that this is a unique deal,'' Mr. Wald said. ''It all began when Martin Lorber, M.A.L.'s president, attended a seminar last April in Moscow jointly sponsored by the Harvard University Graduate School of Business and a Soviet Government institute. Both Mr. Lorber and I went back to Moscow in July for more discussions. And now a committee of seven Russian officials, Mr. Lorber and other M.A.L. executives are visiting American shoe-import facilities, retail stores and manufacturing plants to get an idea of what they might need for this project.''
Russia may also make arrangements to import shoes from other countries later, Mr. Cunningham said. But the raw materials for the Russian-made shoes, particularly leather, will not be imported, for Russian supplies are said to be ample.

HEADLINE: Talking Business with Lipsky of Salomon Brothers;
Help for Dollar Called Unlikely

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
The dollar has reached a new low against the German mark and it is close to touching its record low against the Swiss franc.
John Lipsky, the director of international research for Salomon Brothers in London, says he expects the dollar will continue to fall, but he does not foresee a dramatic decline. Mr. Lipsky says, however, that the Federal Reserve Board has little policy leeway on the dollar because help for the currency, through higher interest rates, is unlikely with the economy so near a recession.
 
Q. Will the dollar continue to fall?
 
A. We expect to see the dollar continue to weaken somewhat further in the coming weeks. It's likely that monetary policy shifts will continue to drain support from the U.S. currency. Specifically, we think that additional modest easing of U.S. short-term interest rates is likely while, in contrast, higher interest rates are expected in both Japan and Germany. 
 
Q. Do you expect the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates when the Federal Open Market Committee meets today?
 
A. No, we wouldn't expect to see an immediate move because of the uncertainty surrounding the Middle East situation. But once that is clarified, we would expect to see the Federal Reserve move cautiously.
 
Q. Why will the Fed wait?
 
A. There is the possibility that some more serious disruption of oil supplies could result in much more significant rises in prices. Significantly higher oil prices would have inflationary consequences and in those circumstances one would think the Federal Reserve would want to proceed cautiously.
 
Q. Do you mean that if oil prices rise much further, the Federal Reserve might not ease interest rates even if the economy is near a recession?
 
A. Certainly that could temper monetary policy. During the previous oil shocks, monetary policy was tightened considerably. However, we don't consider that the current situation is directly comparable and we don't expect to see price rises of the magnitude that we saw then.
One of the factors that has weakened the dollar is the perception that the Fed is caught in a dilemma that significantly limits its room for maneuver.
The threat of higher prices and the weakening dollar points to caution or even a tightening of monetary policy. But the significant weakness of the economy and the increasing likelihood of a recession points in the other direction.
 
Q. How much further will the dollar fall?
 
A. We don't think that we're going to see dramatic additional declines. We think it's likely that the dollar will eventually test the Deutsche mark's 1.5 level. And we think that eventually we'll move to the low 140's against the yen. [The dollar closed yesterday in New York at 1.5641 marks, just above its new record low of 1.5495. Against the yen, the dollar closed at 146.51.] If a deterioration in the Middle Eastern situation does lead to much more serious problems on oil, the dollar could well benefit. The United States is still significantly more self-sufficient in energy than Japan and most Continental European countries. And, further, we think the recent weakness of the dollar certainly already reflects much of the anticipated shifts in interest rate differentials.
 
Q. Why hasn't the dollar weakened as much against the yen as it has against European currencies?
 
A. The yen has lagged for two principal reasons. First, with the risk of a more serious disruption of energy supplies, Japan is by far the most exposed of the major industrial economies because Japan relies by far most heavily on imported energy sources.
Second, with the renewed weakness of the Japanese equity markets, there is some concern on the part of investors that the Bank of Japan may not follow through in tightening policy despite the bank's own justification for doing so. In the German case, there seems to be much less doubt that the Bundesbank will act, if and when it sees fit, to tighten policy.
Now, eventually we think that it is very likely that the Bank of Japan will move to tighten rates. And that will ultimately lead to a strengthening of the yen.

GRAPHIC: Photo: John Lipsky (Salomon Brothers)

HEADLINE: Bush's Warning to Iraq Spurs Gain by Dow

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
President Bush's warning yesterday that he would hold the Iraqi Government responsible for the safety of American hostages being held in Kuwait and Iraq helped give the stock market its first lift since Wednesday.
But in a sign that investors remained cautious, trading volume continued sluggish and buying turned selective.
The Dow Jones industrial average of 30 blue-chip issues climbed by 11.64 points, to 2,656.44.
But Peter G. Grennan, senior vice president of Lehman Brothers Inc., pointed out that only four stocks -I.B.M., Exxon, Texaco and Chevron -accounted for about 75 percent of the gain, with the three oil issues accounting for most of that. 
Stocks opened higher in Tokyo today, but drifted down in slow trading, and the initial gain was wiped out by late afternoon. The Nikkei average of 225 stocks closed at 26,297.84, down 192.63 points, or 0.73 percent.
 
Volume Declines by 39%
In the United States, trading activity sank to 129.6 million shares, down sharply from the abnormally high 212.6 million shares in Friday's ''double witching hour,'' when stock options, index options and index futures all expired. Declining issues outran advancing ones yesterday, 920 to 629, with 203 stocks falling to new lows.
''Three hundred more stocks were down than up,'' Mr. Grennan remarked. ''It was a selective, blue-chip energy rally.''
Commenting on the President's strong remarks, Mr. Grennan said, ''The firmer he is, the better the market will like it.''
Asked why the market was up, Michael Metz, chief market analyst for Oppenheimer & Company, said: ''Is it up? Far more stocks are down than up.''
With many issues selling at depressed levels because of strong declines on Thursday and Friday, yesterday brought ''selective bargain hunting,'' Mr. Metz said, but ''an obvious low level of conviction.''
He pointed to the low trading volume and that ''few stocks participated in the advance - oils and a few leaders, like Wal-Mart, Bristol-Myers Squibb and I.B.M.
''Investors and traders didn't have the courage to go for the secondary names,'' Mr. Metz continued. ''They chose to stick with the high-visibility brand-name companies.''
I.B.M., benefiting from a favorable mention in Barron's, rose by 7/8 in heavy trading, to 102 1/4, representing at least 10 percent of yesterday's rise in the Dow.
Chevron surged by 1 3/8, to 80, its high point for the day. Texaco climbed by 1 3/4, to 65 5/8, its high point yesterday. And Exxon gained 5/8, to 52 3/4, only slightly off its high for the day. Together, the three accounted for about 65 percent of the Dow's rise.
The rest of the Dow industrial stocks changed only slightly. USX, which has a large oil component, rose by 5/8, to 33 1/8, while Du Pont, which also owns a huge oil company, increased 1/4, to 37 5/8.
Oil stocks may be rising, but prices in general may not follow. H. Erich Heinemann, chief economist at Ladenburg, Thalmann & Company, said, ''Some institutional investors are beginning to speculate that the impact of the 1990 oil shock on the general price level may be a lot smaller than many people originally assumed.''
The Federal Open Market Committee, which sets monetary policy, meets today amid speculation that the Federal Reserve will take little action to pump more money into the steadily weakening economy.
''I think very little will happen,'' Mr. Heinemann said. ''The Fed will continue to hold short-term interest rates at approximately the present level. The result of this will be a further tightening of money supply.''
On a more positive note, he argued that ''you have the potential for a very large reduction in interest rates once the Middle East crisis is settled - assuming it's settled.''
 
Wal-Mart Rises to $28.25
Bristol-Myers Squibb, a market favorite that fell by 1 5/8 last week, gained 3/8, to 60. Wal-Mart, another market stalwart, which dropped by 1 7/8 last week, rose by 1/4, to 28 1/4.
Fannie Mae, a quasi-Government agency that buys mortgages and then resells them and the only one among the 10 most active stocks to change as much as a point, fell by 1 1/8 yesterday, to 29 3/4, after sliding by 3 points last week. Freddie Mac, a Fannie Mae competitor, fell 3 1/8, to 59 1/4, after falling by 5 5/8 last week. Their weakness was thought to be related partly to Congressional sentiment to reduce their Government ties.
Gitano, the apparel manufacturer, plunged by 4 7/8, to 19 3/8, also hitting a new low of 19 after Goldman, Sachs & Company downgraded the stock.
In a broad decline among the high-technology issues, Compaq Computer fell by 2 3/8, to 47 3/4; Hewlett-Packard by 1/4, to 34 3/8; Digital Equipment by 5/8, to 66 3/8, and on the Nasdaq, Microsoft, the software producer, by 4 3/4, to 55 1/2.
Despite the oil crisis, the Dow transportation index rose by 6.38, to 930.29, with most transportation stocks showing strength. UAL rose by 3, to 104 1/2, after The American Banker reported that Gerald Greenwald, head of a union effort to buy the airline company, would meet in Tokyo this week with several Japanese bankers. Union Pacific, which has important oil interests, also rose, by 2 7/8, to 73 3/8.
Among other market averages, the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose by 0.68 point, to 328.51. The Nasdaq composite index fell 4.90, to 388.59 after hitting a new low for the year of 388.31. The American Stock Exchange's market-value index fell by 2.32, to 331.29, after also reaching a new low for the year of 330.82.

HEADLINE: Eli Lilly's Spending Plans

 BODY:
Eli Lilly & Company said yesterday that it would spend $540 million over the next five years to build drug laboratories and plants near the company headquarters in Indianapolis.
Lilly, which has said that its earnings will grow 22 percent this year from $939.5 million in 1989, expects to add 500 employees at the new site in the first phase and 500 more by the end of the 1990's. It currently has 3,000 employees in Indianapolis.
The pharmaceutical company said the expansion, which will eventually cost $1 billion, will include $120 million for a new biotechnology laboratory, $145 million in other projects to be completed by 1994, and $90 million in site improvements and utilities.
The technology center will also house Lilly's previously announced $150 million synthetic human insulin plant and a $35 million administration building already under construction.
Analysts said Lilly's plans reflected the relative strength in the pharmaceutical industry at a time of weakening in the overall economy. ''Lilly's products are not sensitive to economic downturns; they are not discretionary spending for consumers,'' said Robert H. Uhl at Salomon Brothers. Ronald Nordmann at Paine Webber Securities said other large pharmaceutical companies like Merck & Company and the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company had also made significant investments in biotechnology.
Eli Lilly's shares fell 37.5 cents yesterday, to $72.625, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Fall in Quiet Trading

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities dipped in very light trading yesterday, as dealers awaited further developments in the Middle East.
''There is a lot of talk about what might happen in the Middle East, but people are too tired of getting whipped around to trade on talk,'' one Government bond trader said.
Worries about the Persian Gulf crisis were especially evident during overnight trading in Tokyo, where traders pushed yields on the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent benchmark bonds of 2020 up close to 9 percent.
 
Mark Helps U.S. Rates
But as activity shifted to Europe and then to the United States, prices stabilized and then turned up slightly, aided by a rise in the value of the dollar against the West German mark. Comments from President Bush indicating that he was remaining firm on the need to curb the Federal budget deficit and a very small drop in oil prices also helped. 
''Everybody is pleased that the market more or less held its own,'' said William V. Sullivan, Jr., a senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.
''But let's not blow what happened out of proportion,'' Mr. Sullivan cautioned. ''Activity was very light, and the Fed is likely to leave monetary policy on hold for the next few weeks. As a consequence, we don't expect any major breakout now.''
Members of the Federal Reserve Board's policy-making Open Market Committee will meet in Washington today to discuss monetary policy.
Despite widespread economic weakness, most analysts expect the Fed will delay any reduction in short-term interest rates until conditions in the Middle East stabilize or improve.
 
'Overwhelmed' Traders
While the central bank might like to ease policy, the threats of war and an oil-related jump in inflation have effectively tied the Fed's hands for now, the analysts said.
In addition, the traders said, the continuing huge supply of Treasury issues is weighing on market participants.
''We are just overwhelmed with paper,'' another trader said. ''And until the Street gets some of this supply off its books and we get a clear sign what the Fed will do next, the market is going to stay under pressure, even though it held up pretty well today.''
The Treasury sold $18.4 billion worth of three-month and six-month bills at its weekly auction yesterday.
Three-month bills were auctioned at an average discount rate of 7.55 percent, up from an average rate of 7.41 percent at last week's sale.
Meanwhile, bids on the six-month bills produced an average discount rate of 7.45 percent, compared with a rate of 7.31 percent a week ago. 30-Year Bonds Down In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds were offered at a price of 98 3/32 late yesterday, down by 1/32, to yield 8.93 percent, unchanged from late Friday.
Among note issues, the 8 3/4 percent 10-year notes were offered at 99 19/32 in late trading, down by 5/32, to yield 8.81 percent. The 8 percent two-year notes were offered at 99 3/4, down by 3/ 32, to yield 8.13 percent.
Activity in the secondary markets for investment-grade corporate bonds and for tax-exempt securities was also very light, the participants said, with little price movement.
Following are the results of yesterday's auction of three-month and six-month Treasury bills:

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Higher After Many Days of Decline

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar closed mostly higher against the world's major currencies in moderate trading yesterday, recovering ground after many days of decline.
Gold prices also rose. On the New York Commodity Exchange, an ounce of gold closed at $410.10, up 50 cents from Friday. Later, the Republic National Bank quoted an after-hours bid of $409.25, up 75 cents, as of 4 P.M. 
Traders said much of the dollar's advance was attributed to investors who were selling positions in other currencies in exchange for the United States currency to take profits.
''The market was stretched to the point of a need for a correction,'' said Lorenzo Troni, vice president of foreign exchange at Paine Webber International in New York. ''There is always a point of profit taking.''
The dollar was also helped by President Bush's strong statements to President Saddam Hussein of Iraq about the fate of foreigners held in Iraq and Kuwait.
''People are a little bit concerned we could be approaching a flash point in this issue,'' said John McCarthy, chief dealer at Amsterdam Rotterdam Bank in New York. The dollar is traditionally viewed as a haven in times of international turmoil, but that has not been the case so far in the Middle East crisis.
Another factor helping the dollar was a slight weakness in the German mark because of trouble in the Social Democratic coalition Government in East Germany, Mr. McCarthy said.
But Mr. McCarthy did not expect the dollar's rebound to last. He said the currency remained weak against other major currencies because of rising interest rates abroad, which tend to support those foreign currencies, and sluggishness in the United States economy.
The dollar closed at 1.5641 marks in New York, up from Friday's close of 1.5500 marks. Friday's close was an all-time low for the dollar against the Germany currency. Earlier, in Europe, the dollar closed at 1.5625 marks, up from 1.5485 Friday.
The dollar also strengthened against the British pound. One pound cost $1.9135 in New York, cheaper than $1.9230 late Friday. In London, the pound fell to $1.9185, from $1.9195 late Friday.
But the dollar lost ground against the Japanese yen. Mr. Troni said the yen had been lifted by weekend reports that Iran would supply oil to Japan, whose economy is almost entirely dependent on imported oil.
In New York, the dollar bought 146.51 yen, down from 147.60 yen late Friday. Earlier, in Tokyo, the dollar had risen to a closing 147.47 yen, from 147.35 yen Friday. But in London, it fell to 146.90 yen.
Other dollar rates as of 4 P.M. in New York, compared with late rates Friday, included: 1.2955 Swiss francs, up from 1.2820; 5.2565 French francs, up from 5.1975; 1,157.25 Italian lire, up from 1,142.25, and 1.1427 Canadian dollars, down from 1.14365.
Gold rose in London to $409.75 an ounce, from $409.25 on late Friday. In Zurich, gold rose to a closing bid of $409.75 an ounce, up from $408.25 on late Friday. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold fell 11 cents an ounce, to $409.77.
Silver bullion in New York cost $5.129 an ounce on the Comex, down from $5.179 on late Friday. In London, silver fell to $5.14 an ounce, from $5.20 on late Friday.

HEADLINE: Careers;
Better Times Expected for Southwest

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
ARE Southwestern states like Texas, Arizona and New Mexico, long in the economic doldrums, about to come alive again?
James Challenger, head of Challenger, Gray & Christmas Inc., a Chicago outplacement firm, has a theory that change for the better is on the way, and with it more job opportunities.
He points out that some economists have said that the savings and loan crisis will bring money into the Southwest. Many of the nation's failed institutions are in this region and their depositors can receive up to $100,000 in Government insurance on their accounts. At the same time new groups are buying up the assets of these institutions at fire sale prices. 
All of this activity, Mr. Challenger said, can create jobs in the area.
The Southwest is receiving a boost from another direction. There is a growing trend at many large companies to move their headquarters or parts of their businesses to the Southwest, where labor and energy costs as well as the cost of living tend to be much lower than in the Northeast and Midwest. State taxes also tend to be lower in this region than in states like New York, New Jersey and Massachusetts.
Mr. Challenger noted that the Exxon Corporation and J. C. Penney both recently moved out of Manhattan skyscrapers to relocate in the Dallas region. A subsidiary of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, AT&T Microelectronics, has moved to the area from New Jersey.
The GTE Corporation, a major electronics company, has moved its market services operation from Florida to the Dallas area, and the Mobil Corporation moved its training operations from Chicago to Dallas. NEC America, a large Japanese-owned concern, has moved staff members to Dallas from both New York and California.
In Houston, the Compaq Computer Corporation expects to expand its operations and create 4,000 jobs, and McDonnell Douglas Aerospace plans to relocate from California to the Houston area, he said.
In addition, the crisis over Iraq's invasion of Kuwait could help the oil industry in Texas. Some analysts say that if oil prices are sustained at around $25 a barrel for a year, the state should realize a marked benefit to its economy.
Outplacement firms like Mr. Challenger's help dismissed employees, mainly middle managers, to deal with job loss trauma. Their fees are usually paid by the employee's former company.
Sometimes an unemployed person has to relocate to get a job he or she wants, which can be painful financially because working spouses often have difficulty finding new jobs.
In fact, the effect on spouses of relocations shows little change for the better, according to Atlas Van Lines, one of the major household movers of families. It found in a recent survey that 84 percent of corporate relocation administrators with whom the company deals provide virtually no help for spouses who want to find jobs after their husbands or wives relocate.
''It is surprising that these percentages have not changed one iota when compared to five years ago,'' J. Stephen Mumma, senior vice president of marketing for the moving company, said recently.
Yet, when employees refuse to relocate, their careers can be hurt. Atlas found that 40 percent of the respondents in its survey said that rejecting a move probably hurt their careers. When they do refuse, these employees cite their spouses' employment, family ties, cost of living considerations, and mortgage and housing worries.
Runzheimer International, a management consulting firm in Rochester, Wis., keeps an eye on the reasons for relocation and the statistics of such moves.
Recently Nancy Brinkerhoff, a consultant who specializes in group moving and employee relocation for Runzheimer, said: ''The No. 1 reason companies move is cost. When salaries are high, rents are moving up and transportation costs going up, top management often says, 'Why do I need to be here?' ''
Often it is hard to recruit some employees for work in a high-cost area like New York.
Ms. Brinkerhoff added: ''A skilled productive work force is the first consideration when choosing a new work site. Increasingly the work ethic is a big concern because companies want a work force that is not only educated but also motivated.''

HEADLINE: U.S. Export Rise Forecast

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20

 BODY:
Regardless of the impact of events in the Middle East on the cost of oil, Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher believes United States exports will continue to grow and keep the nation's economy out of recession this year.
But he acknowledged in an interview that rising oil costs could ruin his prediction that the nation's merchandise trade deficit will come in under $100 billion this year for the first time since 1983. 
Mr. Mosbacher commented following his department's announcement Friday that exports in June reached a record $34.3 billion and helped drive the trade deficit that month to just $5.07 billion.
So far this year, Mr. Mosbacher said, the deficit has tumbled to $45.8 billion, the lowest six-month imbalance since the second half of 1983.
But he acknowleged that continued high oil prices could add to the cost of imports, which dropped to $39.37 billion in June and helped narrow the deficit. The price of oil on Friday was nearly twice the $14.64 a barrel that it averaged during June.
