HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Envoys at U.N. Say Soviets Block Endorsement of Force Against Iraq

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 21

 BODY:
Soviet objections have so far been the main cause of the United States' inability to win Security Council backing for the use of force to uphold the embargo of Iraq, diplomats here say.
Representatives of the Security Council's five permanent members held another inconclusive meeting today on a United States draft of a proposed resolution allowing military action to enforce the mandatory economic boycott of Iraq adopted by the Security Council on Aug. 6.
For more than a week, diplomats from Security Council members have been discussing the resolution without being able to achieve a consensus of the five permament members. Without such a consensus, any of the five - in this case, the Russians - could veto the resolution, and this would embarrass the United States, diplomats said. 
Although there is said to be more than one reason for the difficulty found in getting approval of a use-of-force resolution, the major cause has been the difference in United States and Soviet views. As one diplomat from a Western country put it today, ''What we're looking at is bridging the differences between the United States and the Soviet Union.''
The differences are largely about the timing of such a resolution but also about the role of the United Nations in military force.
These differences have surfaced, diplomats say, despite the vast thaw in Soviet-American relations in recent years. But they say that as far as they know, the United States Government has not tried to use diplomatic channels other than the United Nations to try to do the bridging.
That is, as one put it, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d has not picked up the phone to discuss the subject with his Soviet counterpart, Eduard A. Shevardnadze.
Monday night and today, the United States presented to other Security Council members a succession of proposals of wording for such a resolution, in a continuing effort to generate broader acceptance within the Council. These proposals were said to include at least one change of wording to meet a Soviet objection.
 
Hope Goes Unfulfilled
After the heads of the permanent members' missions conferred for about two hours today, the British chief delegate, Sir Crispin Tickell, said cheerfully to reporters: ''Everyone reaffirmed the importance of the five and the Council as the mechanism to see that sanctions are enforced.''
But as the afternoon wore on, the only further contacts to be reported about the resolution were bilateral talks between the United States and other Security Council nations.
As the hours passed, earlier suggestions that the Security Council might go so far as to hold a formal meeting, beginning this evening, to vote on such a resolution, went unfulfilled.
One Western diplomat said his understanding was that the Soviets' chief objection was ''a question of timing: the Soviet Union wants a clear instance of sanction-busting'' - that is, a clear violation of the embargo to take place - before the resolution is adopted.
The United States and other members of the Council would like the ''U.N. blessing,'' that is, the resolution, in advance of such a violation.
Widespread doubt was expressed here today about a news report from Yemen that an embargo violation had taken place: the reported unloading of an Iraqi tanker at a coastal oil installation. The United States has taken the position that it can neither confirm nor deny the report.
In pressing for such a resolution, the United States believes that it would be good to have a United Nations endorsement for military action.
This has been referred to here by one American diplomat as ''a U.N. umbrella.'' It has also been described as ''a wink and a nod'' of approval.
But what the United States envisages is that these countries' military action remain ''unilateral'' - that is, not subject to command by a United Nations group.
Some days ago, the Soviet Foreign Ministry stated that Soviet forces would be engaged in the Persian Gulf area only in the context of an authorization from the United Nations. And the Soviet Union has been emphasizing in the recent discussions here that it wants a role to be played by a little-known United Nations panel, the Military Staff Committee of the Security Council, in overseeing military action.
 
Officers From Five Nations
The committee, which has been in existence for decades, consists of high military officers from the five permanent member nations of the Security Council - Britain, China, France, the Soviet Union and the United States. The officers customarily meet briefly here every two months.
It is widely said that the United States felt a sense of urgency Monday - and called for informal consultations among all Council members that went on late in the night - because Washington thought that it might have to order military action against another Iraqi tanker that was approaching Yemen.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: BEHIND BUSH'S HARD LINE;
Washington Considers a Clear Iraqi Defeat To Be Necessary to Bolster Its Arab Allies

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21

 BODY:
Iraq called today for negotiations on ending the Persian Gulf crisis, but did not offer to pull its troops out of Kuwait. The White House quickly responded that no talks were possible until Iraq unconditionally carried out the United Nations demand that it withdraw its forces from Kuwait.
The Administration's rapid rejection of the Iraqi proposal for opening a diplomatic track grows out of Washington's concern that should it become involved in negotiations about the terms of an Iraqi withdrawal, America's Arab allies might feel under pressure to give the Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein, a few token gains in Kuwait to roll back his invasion and defuse the crisis.
Also underlying the Administration's tough stance is a growing feeling that Washington and its allies have the advantage over the Iraqi leader, that their international quarantine and military buildup are just beginning to pinch Baghdad and that there is no reason to settle for anything less than an unconditional Iraqi pullout. 
True, officials say, the United States faces the theoretical problem of holding its international boycott of Iraq together over the long run. But the Iraqi leader faces a real and immediate problem - he is almost totally isolated and his economy is being strangled.
 
Withdrawal and Its Perception
Bush Administration officials insist that for the United States and its allies to achieve their objectives in the Persian Gulf, President Hussein must not only retreat from Kuwait, but he must do so in a manner that leaves no suggestion that Iraq gained from its invasion. Officials say he must not only be defeated, he must also be seen as defeated by everyone in the Arab world and beyond.
If Mr. Hussein walks away from his Kuwaiti invasion with even a scintilla of profit - a Kuwaiti island or minor border adjustments - American officials fear the Arab world will regard his crime as having paid dividends, and he will remain a threat. This would have profoundly negative implications in the Arab world for years to come.
For now, American officials say their closest Arab allies, Egypt and Saudi Arabia, are no more interested in negotiations with Mr. Hussein than Washington is. Administration officials contend that the Iraqi leader has lied to his Arab neighbors so many times that they simply do not believe any of his assurances and they want him deflated, if not militarily defeated, once and for all.
Nevertheless, Bush Administration officials say they are keenly aware that just beneath the surface of Arab support for the isolation of Iraq, there is anxiety about the mood on the Arab street. The Egyptians, Saudis and other gulf Arabs have to be concerned that pro-Iraqi elements will try to punish them for siding with the United States against an Arab power.
 
Pressure for a Compromise
These governments are already being pressed by King Hussein of Jordan and Yasir Arafat of the Palestine Liberation Organization to allow them to mediate between Baghdad and the other Arabs. For King Hussein and Mr. Arafat, being able to play the role of mediators is the only way to justify their support for President Hussein's invasion. Because that support has put them in politically difficult positions, they will do everything possible to escape from their predicament by trying to play this role and then telling the world that the only reason they kept ties with Baghdad open was to be peacemakers.
Between these pressures and those from the Arab street, Administration officials fear that in the context of a negotiation, the Arab world might be inclined to grant President Hussein some minor face-saving concessions to get him out of Kuwait and remove the threat of a full-scale war in the oilfields of the Persian Gulf.
''If Saddam Hussein is left looking like a winner he will be treated like a hero, and if he is left looking like a loser he will be treated like a zero,'' said Martin Indyk, director of the Washington Institute for Near East Policy Studies. ''Even if the United States succeeds in getting Saddam to withdraw from Kuwait, he will still have a formidable force at his disposal. The only way that we can hope that he won't use it again is if he pays a significant, clear price for his aggression.''
 
Concern for Hostages
But the reason Washington rebuffed the Iraqi overtures today in a low-key, muted manner was concern for American and other Western hostages. American officials were worried that if they had simply told the Iraqi leader to ''go jump in the lake,'' he might have done something irrational with his hostages and might have closed off all discussions with American diplomats in Baghdad about their fate.
From the start of this crisis, one fear of the Bush Administration has been that Saddam Hussein's Arab nationalist appeal would resonate throughout the Arab world and undermine the resolve of America's Arab allies to resist Iraq. Officials are of two minds about this danger.
One school argues that the threat of the Arab street and the real support for Saddam Hussein in the Arab world have been vastly exaggerated. This is in part because so many American television and newspaper reporters have congregated in Amman, Jordan, where they have been widely exposed to a Palestinian interpretation of events, which is very sympathetic to the Iraqi leader. Elsewhere, in Cairo, the gulf and Syria, there is much less sympathy for the Iraqi leader.
It would also be dangerous to underestimate the resources of the Arab gulf states to manipulate public opinion in their favor. Last week the Muslim Brotherhood, a Muslim fundamentalist organization in Egypt, issued a statement supporting President Hussein. But the Muslim Brotherhood receives its main income from Saudi Arabia.
''The Saudis pulled their purse strings,'' said one American official, ''and suddenly they were singing a different tune.''
 
Funding for Palestinians
In the Israeli-occupied West Bank, Palestinian hospitals and relief organizations are beginning to complain that their funding from the gulf is disappearing.
''There is a saying in Arabic that 'after the bout of drink comes the moment of awareness,' '' said Fouad Ajami, a Middle East expert at Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies. ''After they let off all their steam, even the Palestinians will understand what a great economic catastrophe has befallen them as a result of events in Kuwait. People will still have to work, and the gulf states provided more work for Palestinians and other Arabs than anyone else.''
In addition, Mr. Ajami said: ''The Arab street is much smarter than it is often given credit for. It knows a thief. It knows plunderer when it sees one. It knows that there is enormous blood on the hands of Saddam Hussein.''
But there are some equally strong arguments for reading the Arab street as more dangerous. Not only is the pro-Iraqi sentiment clearly in evidence in Jordan, the West Bank and North Africa, but more important, what matters in the crunch is not what the Arab silent majority feels, but what the activist minority does. The Administration may be right that millions of Arabs stand with Washington, but through terrorism they could easily be intimidated by the few who do not.

HEADLINE: Hartford, Its Boom Over, Sees Downtown Decaying

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Aug. 21

 BODY:
The hundreds of millions of dollars that poured into Hartford in the 1980's changed the skyline and tripled the amount of office space downtown, but the makeover appears now to have only masked a continuing decline in the heart of Connecticut's capital.
As the commercial real-estate boom abruptly ended across the Northeast, all the problems of an aging urban core have reemerged intact, shattering the idea that Hartford's glittering new facades and office towers enabled it to transcend the isolation, poverty and downtown blight that afflict so many old industrial cities.
To many people here, this city of 137,000 remains divided into a small island of safety crowned by the gold dome of the Capitol and the towers of insurance companies, surrounded by poor, devastated neighborhoods untouched and unreclaimed by the prosperity of the 80's.
 
Empty Swaths Downtown
In the last nine months, Hartford has lost more than 40 percent of its downtown hotel rooms, including the 410-room Hilton and a 36-year-old landmark, the Summit, which closed this month with only three days' notice. This week, one of the city's two downtown department stores, Sage-Allen & Company, which has done business on Main Street for 101 years, is expected to close as well. 
Some restaurants have closed and others are limping badly. Business bankruptcy filings are running double what they were a year ago, according to Federal bankruptcy court officials.
 
'Turned Off the Lights'
Worse still, large swaths of this compact city, including a whole block of stores on Main Street opposite Sage-Allen, lie empty, having been intentionally vacated by developers over the last few years in preparation for office towers that are now stalled on the drawing board. A nonprofit group has volunteered to put decorations in the windows of Sage-Allen and the other stores this Christmas to provide at least the illusion of life.
''It's like someone turned off the lights for some of these companies,'' said John A. Green, vice president of Lux Bond & Green, a downtown jewelry store.
Business people and economists - some of whom expressed relative optimism in for-the-record interviews but deep gloom in com-ments that they insisted not be attributed to them - said that Hartford's claim as a center of insurance and banking had been bolstered by the commercial real-estate boom of the 1980's.
But in many of the things that make a city more than an office park, Hartford's downtown lost ground as people found fewer and fewer reasons to come here except to work. For downtown businesses, the shock came when the number of 9-to-5'ers declined as banks and insurance companies reduced employment and construction came to a sharp halt last year.
Retailers estimate that the number of people working or visiting downtown on any given weekday is two-thirds to one-half what it was three years ago.
''It started before the current economic downturn, but the economic downturn can only make it worse,'' said James O. Rogers, president of the Connecticut Retail Merchants Association, referring to Hartford's long-term problems. Mr. Rogers said he believed things would get worse for downtown and that the city would face at least another 18 months of stress before there would a letup.
''And that's just the economy,'' Mr. Rogers added. ''The bigger question is how long can people hold on until we revitalize the urban areas?''
In Hartford's poorest sections, especially the largely black North End, unemployment is already running well above 30 percent, according to city officials.
Among Hartford's hidden losses during an otherwise booming decade of growth, one of the most bitterly missed has been the business-convention trade.
Convention agents said that while the city continued to draw smaller groups, the large lucrative conventions that can fill a city with shoppers and people on expense accounts increasingly went to competitors like Springfield, Mass., and Mystic, Conn., both of which built new hotel-convention complexes.
Hartford, with its aging hotels, traffic congestion, expensive parking and higher crime rate, could not compete.
In 1986, for example, the city was host to 139 convention meetings with 87,000 guests. By 1989, the number had fallen to 114 meetings and 46,000 guests. In Springfield, just 45 minutes north, the number of conventions rose from 4 to 48 in the same period, while convention visitors increased sevenfold, according to figures from the Greater Hartford Convention and Visitors Bureau.
 
Missing the Rolling Stones
''A year ago, I said things couldn't get much worse, and they did,'' said Claire Hue, co-owner of Monsieur Hue, an upscale men's clothing store that she said would either close or move next month. Mrs. Hue opened the store in 1987 in a downtown mini-mall called the Pavillion, which was built for 20 stores and now has less than half that number. Her store's sales this summer are 40 percent below those in the summer of 1989, which was in turn down from 1988, Mrs. Hue said.
Even for one-night events, like concerts, newer concert halls elsewhere attracted shows that only a few years ago would very likely have gone to the Civic Center Coliseum, which has been empty through most of this summer.
''In 1981 we had the Rolling Stones at the Civic Center because it was the largest arena in New England,'' said Jim Koplik, a concert promoter based in New York. ''But 16,000 seats is not as big as it used to be.''
Hartford's allure as a summer concert setting has further declined in the last two years, Mr. Koplik said, since the owners of Lake Compounce, an amusement park in nearby Bristol, began an ambitious program of outdoor shows.
 
Darker and Emptier Streets
A decline in visitors, especially at night, has in turn made Hartford's streets seem darker and emptier and more frightening, many restaurant owners say, especially to suburban residents on whom the delicate economy of the city depends. And Hartford's businesses can clearly not survive on the resources of city residents alone: In the 1980 census, Hartford was ranked one of the poorest cities in the United States in per capita income.
''It's a very fragile balance,'' said Warren L. Trafton, president of the Convention and Visitors Bureau. ''A whole series of things have conspired against us.''
Many of Hartford's hopes are pinned once again on the traditional savior, office construction, which is expected to rebound faster here than in some other cities where buildings went up faster than the demand.
According to the Farley Company, a leading commercial real-estate firm here, the amount of vacant office space peaked in January at 15 percent and has since fallen to 12.7 percent. The firm expects the rate - a key measure of economic health - to continue to decline to between 7 and 8 percent by 1993, when large-scale office projects could again become economically viable.
By contrast, Stamford, Connecticut's other major corporate office market, has 26.9 percent of its office space vacant, down from 29.6 percent in January, when it had the highest vacancy rate in the United States. In both New York City and Boston, the vacancy rate has hovered near 15 percent.
The United Technologies Corporation, based in Hartford, is also expected to provide at least something of a boost to the local economy this fall when it announces which of 10 empty sites it is selecting for a new corporate headquarters. The project, intended to consolidate the company's Hartford offices, is expected to be the only active construction job downtown through at least the early part of the decade.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
With Embargo, Cheaper Tea

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: LONDON, Aug. 21

 BODY:
The price of tea has been hit by the Persian Gulf crisis. The United Nations trade embargo against tea-drinking Iraq has helped push it down to two-year lows. 
Other factors behind the fall include rising world output, reduced purchases by the Soviet Union and hot weather in Britain, where people have forsaken tea for cold drinks. Iced tea, while popular in America, has never taken hold in Britain.
The average price at last week's London auction fell to 77.7 cents a pound from $1.38 at the beginning of the year.
The figures make bad reading for India, Sri Lanka and Kenya, the world's major sources of tea.
International Tea Committee figures show that Iraq imported around 80.5 million pounds of tea in 1989. World production for all of 1989 was 11.64 billion pounds, and world tea output in the first six months of this year is believed to be 187 million pounds ahead of the same period in 1989.

HEADLINE: MORE EUROPEANS TO JOIN GULF FORCE

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Aug. 21

 BODY:
Anxious to demonstrate full support for American moves to isolate Iraq, Western European governments decided today to increase and coordinate their naval activities in the Persian Gulf and to reject Baghdad's demands that they close their embassies in Kuwait.
At a meeting of the nine-nation Western European Union, a regional organization, Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands and Spain said their warships would soon join naval vessels from Britain, France and the United States that are already enforcing the trade embargo against Iraq in the gulf.
West Germany said its Constitution prohibited it from sending five minehunters and minesweepers beyond the Eastern Mediterranean, but it announced plans to propose a constitutional amendment allowing it to participate in any military operation backed by the United Nations. The other two members of the organization, Portugal and Luxembourg, have not offered naval support so far. 
 
Coordinating Effort
Both foreign and defense ministers attended the meeting, which included an agreement to set up an ad hoc group to coordinate members' naval activities in the gulf in areas like logistical support, zones of operation, task-sharing and exchange of intelligence.
The ministers said that, while naval forces would for the moment remain under national commands, the chiefs of defense staff of the participating countries would meet here on Friday to harmonize strategies. They added that this European initiative should enormously ease cooperation with the United States.
''It's very important that this should not just be a United States operation,'' Britain's Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, said, referring to enforcement of United Nations sanctions against Iraq. ''It is very important that it should be seen that the European allies are vigorously helping.''
The Secretary-General of the Western European Union, Willem van Eekelen, said, ''It seems essential that we do not leave this as an American affair, because Europe is even more interested than the United States in the supply of oil.''
Later, at a meeting of foreign ministers of the 12-nation European Community, there was also agreement that Western European embassies in Kuwait should remain open ''as long as practically and physically possible'' despite Iraq's order that they be shut down by Friday.
 
Paring Staff in Kuwait
The foreign ministers reiterated demands for the release of all hostages and further warned individual Iraqis that they would be held personally responsible under international law for any illegal acts committed against foreign nationals. Some 7,700 Community citizens are not being allowed to leave Kuwait and Iraq.
Mr. Hurd said that while diplomats from Community governments would remain in Kuwait, families and nonessential staff would be withdrawn in the coming days. In Britain's case, he added, ''three or four'' diplomats would stay in Kuwait to assist British citizens trapped there.
The actions today in both the Western European Union and the European Community seemed intended not only to dispel doubts about Europe's willingness to take part fully in the United States-led response to the Iraqi aggression, but also to demonstrate that Western Europe can work together both politically and militarily.
The Western European Union, which has been overshadowed by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization since it was created in 1955, was last used by its members in 1987 to coordinate the activities of five countries that sent warships to the gulf to protect oil tankers threatened during the Iran-Iraq war.
On this occasion, however, the Union has also provided a multilateral framework for several European governments that were reluctant to be seen either acting unilaterally or simply following the United States. Spain, for example, waited until today to announce it was sending one frigate, two corvettes and an auxiliary ship to the gulf.
France, which over the past two weeks has sought to emphasize its independent posture in the Iraqi crisis, also stressed today that it now shared the position of its Western allies. French officials said President Francois Mitterrand held a long telephone conversation with President Bush on Monday evening.
 
Action From Paris
Today, Mr. Mitterrand said at a news conference that France had responded positively to a request for personnel and materiel from ''different countries of the region'' and would be sending ''reconnaissance squadrons from the ground forces'' to the United Arab Emirates. He did not disclose how many troops would be involved.
Barely one week after France criticized American and British threats to stop ships suspected of trading with Iraq, Mr. Mitterrand also noted that ''an embargo without sanctions would be a sham.'' He added that only he could order French warships to fire on foreign vessels, although he acknowledged that the crisis had now entered ''a logic of war.''
With 8 French and 3 British warships, a total of 32 naval vessels have now been mobilized by European countries as a result of the Iraqi crisis. Among Community countries, excluding Ireland, which is neutral, only Portugal, Denmark and Luxembourg have not offered naval support.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK;
A Base With No Name: U.S. Puts It on the Map

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

 BODY:
The following report was filed under the ground rules that govern American correspondents accredited to the Pentagon who are working in Saudi Arabia. The ground rules prohibit the reporting of exact numbers of troops or weapons, their exact locations or the names of enlisted personnel.
The most famous spot in Saudi Arabia these days has become a base without a name.
Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, wearing blue jeans, a work shirt and dark-red Western boots, came here the other day to meet the troops under the glare of the television cameras. And nearby hotels are jammed with reporters and television technicians discussing satellite hookups and the troops that they are trying to ''book'' for the next day's broadcast. 
Taxicabs are doing so much business that a hotel guest here was advised to make a reservation for a cab.
But the official ''Ground Rules for Coverage of U.S. Military Activities'' distributed to correspondents here prohibits naming even the most obvious military installation, even though they are no secret to the Iraqis.
The rule appears to reflect the American military's zealousness about operational security, as well as Saudi Arabia's continued unease about its decision to open the kingdom's borders to large numbers of foreign correspondents. [Reports from correspondents not accredited to the United States military in Saudi Arabia have said that the air base is in Dhahran in eastern Saudi Arabia.] The base without a name is hardly the only paradox that reporters traveling with Mr. Cheney encountered this week during his hurried swing through the Persian Gulf.
In Bahrain, American reporters were urged by an American Embassy official to attend a news conference where, it was said, Bahrain would issue its first public statement explicitly endorsing the large deployment of American forces in the region.
But once the news conference began, a senior Bahrain official insisted that his endorsement be reported on a ''not for attribution'' basis and forbade the correspondents to tape-record his remarks.
Even with 200,000 Iraqi troops deployed in Kuwait and southern Iraq, the open embrace of the American military does not come easily for many gulf officials.
 
The Skeptical and Edgy
Despite the increased tensions near the base with no name, some here do not appear to believe that war will break out - at least in the short run.
A foreign mining consultant with long experience in the Middle East said he had been warned by his colleagues against coming here a week ago, but was told that it was safe to return now. His business: building underground command posts for the Saudi military.
But many American servicemen in the region are edgy.
A 28-year-old electronics technician on the La Salle, the command ship for the American fleet in the Persian Gulf, which is docked in Bahrain, said the vessel keeps its generators running and its crew on alert so that it can sail on two hours' notice.
The La Salle's crew held several emergency drills recently, including one called Circle William, where the sailors practice defending against a poison-gas attack by closing all outside and inside air vents. The spare parts that used to take months to reach the La Salle have all of a sudden started being delivered over the course of a week or two.
For some service personnel, the crisis in the gulf appears to present a dilemma. They don't want war, and yet find it difficult to imagine staying on a war footing in the region for months, or even years, as Mr. Cheney has suggested is possible. ''Hopefully we can take care of Saddam Hussein without force,'' said a sailor from Louisiana on the La Salle. ''But I'd rather see us do something now than drag it out for a long period of time.''
 
A Longer Stay, and Why
On the Eisenhower, the nuclear-powered aircraft carrier in the Red Sea that Mr. Cheney visited on Saturday, the sailors waited on Mr. Cheney's every word when he suggested that they would have to extend their time at sea.
The Eisenhower has been deployed since March, and under a normal operating procedure is due to be relieved. Many sailors in the Eisenhower battle group said they wished they could return home soon. But the prevailing feeling appeared to be that the sailors were prepared to stay on station in the Red Sea if needed.
The last few weeks have been an intense period of activity for the battle group, and sailors loaded fuel and transferred missiles at sea in the Mediterranean before sailing through the Suez Canal.
Mr. Cheney told the crew on the Eisenhower that their contribution was essential over the next couple of weeks and that they would be relieved as soon as possible. As he did with other American forces in the gulf, the Secretary spent much of the time telling the servicemen why they were here.
Mr. Cheney warned that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq could gain control of half of the world's oil if he conquered Saudi Arabia, giving Baghdad a hold on the economies of the West.
''When the President makes a decision to send folks halfway around the world to engage in what may be a dangerous enterprise, it is important that they hear from the President and his representative why that decision was made,'' Mr. Cheney told reporters after meeting with Air Force personnel in the United Arab Emirates.
By and large, the message appeared to go over well with the troops.
''At least he is not trying to run the war from behind a desk at the Pentagon,'' said a soldier at the air base here.
Another soldier, who was sitting under a camouflage net at the air base, indicated that he was persuaded by Mr. Cheney's explanation. The soldier's unit was an army battalion armed with Patriot antiaircraft missiles from Fort Bliss, Tex.
''We had kind of been in the dark,'' about why American forces were being sent to Saudi Arabia, a soldier said.
For all of the fanfare that surrounded Mr. Cheney's visit here, which ended with his return to Washington today, not everyone greeted the Secretary's visit with great expectation.
Mr. Cheney approached several soldiers here who were sleeping under a hastily-constructed shelter, a piece of wood bridging two light Sheridan tanks, a thin barrier against the sun and 104-degree heat.
''I did not mean to get you guys out of bed,'' Mr. Cheney said.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Yemen Agrees to Block Iraqi Oil; Missile Flow to Kuwait Reported

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21

 BODY:
The mounting confrontation between American warships and two loaded Iraqi oil tankers in waters near the Persian Gulf was at least temporarily defused today when Yemen said it would not allow the tankers to unload their cargo in its port of Aden.
As Yemen acted, Pentagon officials said they had information on ''the likelihood'' that Iraq had moved long-range ballistic missiles into occupied Kuwait that could strike the Saudi Arabian capital of Riyadh.
 
Missiles 'Not Surprising'
A Pentagon official who spoke on the condition of anonymity said that intelligence reports showing that Soviet-made Scud B missiles had been moved into Kuwait were of concern but ''not surprising,'' given the buildup on both sides of the Saudi border.
The missiles typically carry conventional high-explosive warheads, but Western military experts say they believe Iraq is trying to develop chemical warheads containing mustard or nerve gas. The Scuds, with a range of more than 350 miles, have dubious accuracy but could still inflict heavy casualties if launched at cities. 
Iraq has also deployed shore-to-ship missiles in occupied Kuwait, where they could be aimed at Western naval forces in the Persian Gulf, said an article in Britain's Financial Times newspaper quoted by Reuters.
The two Iraqi tankers that sought to unload in Aden had ignored warning shots across their bows from the American ships on Saturday, in the first challenge to the United States use of military power to enforce the international trade sanctions against Iraq.
But early today, in a session of the United Nations Security Council at which the United States sought approval for use of military power to enforce the sanctions, the Yemeni delegate said his Government would not unload the tankers headed for Aden.
 
Abstained in U.N. Vote
Reuters reported, however, that a third Iraqi tanker might have slipped through the naval blockade and unloaded its cargo before the Yemeni promise took effect. Yemen had abstained in an earlier Security Council vote to impose an international embargo on all commerce with Iraq.
Yemen's representative at the United Nations denied reports the tanker had unloaded at the oil refinery in Aden.
The Bush Administration had said it would order the Navy to disable the two tankers still at sea whether or not the United States won the United Nations blessing, but Administration officials were clearly seeking the added degree of international consent. The Pentagon said the two tankers were sailing slowly off the coast of Yemen today, shadowed by American warships.
The White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said one of the tankers might be allowed to dock in Aden, but that the Yemenis had given assurances that the oil would not be unloaded or used. ''We intend to follow up and make sure that they comply with the sanctions as they said they would,'' Mr. Fitzwater said.
Defense Department officials were uncertain where the second loaded tanker would go.
 
A Selective 'Interception'
The two Iraqi vessels apparently loaded several days ago at Mina al-Bakr, an Iraqi off-shore oil platform in the northern part of the Persian Gulf. The American warships intercepted one tanker in the Persian Gulf and the other in the Gulf of Oman. A Pentagon official who spoke on the condition of anonymity sought to explain in the gaps in the economic net around Iraq, saying ''the operative term here isn't 'blockade,' it's 'interception.' ''
The official said that United States' intention was not to stop every single vessel, but to selectively intercept the ships most important to Baghdad's economy: oil tankers.
In Washington, the Pentagon's chief transportation commander, Gen. Hansford T. Johnson, said that more than 1 billion pounds of equipment was being sent by ship and by plane to Saudi Arabia in the ''largest sustained airlift ever'' over a short time period.
Virtually all American troops now in Saudi Arabia got there on civilian planes, General Johnson said. At first the troops were moved on chartered commercial jets and, more lately, they have been flying on planes commandeered by the military. More than 35,000 troops are now in Saudi Arabia.
Eight fast sealift cargo ships and 38 slower transport vessels have been activated and are carrying the bulk of the equipment to the Middle East, including tanks, helicopters, armored personnel carriers and ammunition.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Bush Regains Record Rating in Crisis

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES

 BODY:
The Persian Gulf crisis has propelled public approval of President Bush back to its highest level, with support for his stand against Iraq's invasion of Kuwait overwhelming misgivings about his handling of domestic problems, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll has found.
Seventy-six percent of the respondents said they approved of the job Mr. Bush was doing as President, the same figure he reached after the invasion of Panama last December. Only 15 percent of the 1,422 Americans reached by telephone Thursday through Sunday disapproved of Mr. Bush's job performance. The margin of sampling error was plus or minus three percentage points.
While Presidents Lyndon B. Johnson and Jimmy Carter had similar levels of support soon after taking office, the last President to attain this level of popularity so far into his term was John F. Kennedy, who won approval from 76 percent of the public in a Gallup Poll after the Cuban missile crisis in 1962. 
 
Sharp Climb in Rating
This upsurge in support for Mr. Bush, with its beginnings visible in a New York Times Poll on Aug. 9 and 10, came just in time, from the perspective of Republican Party officials, to reverse a precipitous decline in the President's standing since Panama, just as Kennedy's showdown with the Soviets pulled Kennedy and the Democrats out of a tailspin as the midterm election approached in 1962.
In less than three weeks, Mr. Bush's public approval has climbed nearly 20 percentage points. In a poll completed almost entirely before Iraq seized Kuwait, 58 percent of the public approved of Mr. Bush's handling of his job and 33 percent expressed disapproval.
That poll, conducted by Market Opinion Research, a firm with many Republican clients, said Mr. Bush was being dragged down by doubts about his handling of the economy and the savings and loan scandal. These doubts made Republicans increasingly nervous, and Democrats increasingly hopeful about the fall campaign, when Iraqi forces suddenly crashed across the Kuwaiti border.
 
Misgivings Persist
Those doubts persist, acccording to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll. The public is evenly divided over Mr. Bush's handling of the economy. and majorities give him poor marks on the savings and loan scandal and taxes.
But after another week of images of American troops crossing the desert sands, attention has shifted from domestic problems and the public, as it usually does at the outset of a foriegn crisis, has thrown its support to the President.
Misgivings and reservations about the American commitment in Saudi Arabia, apparent in the New York Times Poll 10 days ago, persisted at significant levels even as Americans learned more about the reasons for the United States deployment and the extent of it.
Three-quarters of the public expressed overall approval for Mr. Bush's handling of the Persian Gulf situation, equal to the level he reached in the earlier New York Times Poll immediately after he addressed the nation to announce the deployment of forces to Saudia Arabia.
Yet 4 out of 10 also said he was too quick to involve the military. That is the same number who felt that way when the troops were first sent 10 days ago, and none of the events since seems to have shaken their view.
This seeming contradiction illustrates a phenomenon so well documented by students of public opinion that it has a name: ''the rally round the flag effect.''
This is the tendency of the public to set aside doubts in a foreign crisis, particularly the early stages of one, and support the nation and its leader, the President.
 
Support for Deployment
Now that American troops, planes and ships have been deployed in Saudi Arabia and the gulf, 77 percent of the public says they support the decision to send them, a level of support far higher than was ever given to military deployments during the fighting in Vietnam.
Of those who support troop deployment in the gulf, half do so with the expectation that the conflict will be resolved peacefully. That is one example of how the public is divided in its readiness, or willingness, to shoulder the sacrifices that President Bush said on Monday would be required.
In another example, 43 percent of the respondents said they would be willing to pay higher taxes to protect Saudia Arabia, while 53 percent said they would not.
That division could be seen as evidence of resolve only when compared with the willingness to pay taxes to reduce the deficit. Only 31 percent of the public said in the same poll that they approved of tax increases to reduce the deficit, while 65 percent said they disapproved.
Richard Sobel, a Princeton University expert on public opinion about foreign policy, said that based on the history of the conflicts in Vietnam and Korea, support for American military action in the gulf would weaken in direct relation to expense and casualties.
In the early months of American involvement in Korea, 75 to 80 percent of the public in various polls said they supported President Harry S. Truman's decision to send troops. But as casualties mounted and Chinese forces overwhelmed American positions, support weakened. A year after the United States intervened in Korea, several national polls showed declines of 20 percentage points in the view that it had been the right thing to do.
The latest New York Times/CBS News survey was conducted just as President Saddam Hussein of Iraq was announcing that Americans and other Westerners would be held and moved to potential military targets as a shield against attack.
Most foreign policy experts have painted America's intervention in the Persian Gulf as a 20th-century spice war, motivated by the need to protect access to vital resources, in this case oil. But the more familiar justification for use of American power - deterring aggression and protecting friends -has greater political potency and is the one President Bush stressed in his speech to the Veterans of Foriegn Wars on Monday.
Just short of half the public, 46 percent, says American troops have been sent mainly because the price of oil will increase too much if Iraqis control the oil fields, while some 30 percent say the United States is there mainly to protect our friends. Both explanations were offered by 16 percent.
All three groups overwhelmingly support the decision to deploy American military forces, but among those who say the forces are there primarily to protect oilfields, 24 percent oppose the use of military forces. Among those who say they are there primarily to protect America's friends, only 11 percent are opposed.
In Washington, critics say Mr. Bush has not given an adequate explanation of the American purpose in the gulf. But 6 out of 10 Americans in the latest survey, completed before his speech on Monday, said they thought he had clearly explained why the United States sent troops. One in three said he had not.
Mr. Bush's decision to go ahead with a vacation despite the gulf conflict split the public, as it has divided his staff. Half the public thinks the President should have stayed in Washington, but 44 percent approve of his decision to go. Higher-income and better-educated people, who most strongly support American intervention in the gulf, are also most supportive of Mr. Bush's taking his vacation.
 
How the Survey Was Conducted
The New York Times/CBS News Poll was based on telephone interviews conducted Aug. 16 to 19 with 1,422 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the country. The exchanges were chosen so as to assure that each region of the country was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. The numbers were then screened to limit calls to residences.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of residential telephone lines and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to region, race, sex, age and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
The percentages reported are the particular results most likely to match what would be obtained by seeking out all adult Americans. Other possible percentages are progressively less likely the more they differ from the reported results.
The potential sampling error for smaller subgroups is larger. For example, for either Republicans or Democrats or independents it is plus or minus five percentage points.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll.

HEADLINE: Pakistanis Race to Save Indus Valley Ruins

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KARACHI, Pakistan

 BODY:
The Pakistani Government, racing against time to save the Indus Valley ruins of Mohenjo-Daro, the site of one of the world's oldest but most mysterious civilizations, is planning an international appeal for help.
Scholars and tourists alike are being invited to tour the site. A small airstrip near the ruins, which rise above a barren plain, has been designated an international airport. A international symposium on Mohenjo-Daro and its unsolved mysteries is being planned for early in 1991, and an application has been made to the United Nations Development Program for a loan to set up an international fund-raising campaign. 
Mohenjo-Daro, about 240 miles north of Karachi, was the center of one or more ancient civilizations, the earliest possibly 5,000 years ago, with an extraordinary level of human development. Wells and private bathrooms, drainage systems and a variety of children's toys were found at the site, which was not discovered until 1922.
Why Mohenjo-Daro died or was destroyed - there is some evidence that a sudden human or natural calamity occurred - is still a matter of debate. Although pictographs have been found, no one has been able to decipher them. There is no known equivalent of Egypt's Rosetta Stone to provide a key, and the language is sufficiently unrelated to others of its age to make decoding difficult.
While the puzzles await solutions, the partly uncovered ruins are suffering from exposure and need restoration and preservation, said Abdul Kadir Shaikh, a justice of the Pakistan Supreme Court, who has been chairman since 1978 of a national commission named by President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq to look after the site.
Justice Shaikh is also head of an international consultative committee on the site, supported by Unesco. The seven-member panel has two American experts: Paul Perrot, director of the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts in Richmond, and Frank Preusser of the Getty Conservation Institute in Marina del Rey, Calif.
Shahid Hosain, head of Pakistan's Department of Culture and Tourism in Islamabad, said that about $15 million would be needed found for work at the site. ''We have learned that all cultural projects have to be marketed like soap,'' he said.
Prince Mikasa, an art scholar and brother of the late Japanese Emperor Hirohito, has been active in bringing international attention to Mohenjo-Daro.
Alexander the Great fought battles in this country, and early Buddhist learning centers flourished long before the advent of Mogul armies.
The most serious threat to Mohenjo-Daro, Justice Shaikh said, has been the Indus, whose changing course and seeping irrigation canals raised water levels sharply, soaking part of the unexplored ruins.
Justice Shaikh said drainage spurs and the installation of 26 pumps to remove ground water had eliminated immediate catastrophe.
Justice Shaikh, hopes to lure Prince Charles of Britain and the Aga Khan -two leading patrons of architecture -to the site to lend support for restoration efforts.
''These sun-baked bricks of Mohenjo-Daro are part of the oldest civilization in the world,'' he said. ''If you are talking of the first known civilized way of life and society, then it has to be Mohenjo-Daro.''

HEADLINE: Philadelphia Mayor Seeks Taxes to Avoid Deficit

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 21

 BODY:
Mayor W. Wilson Goode says Philadelphia is not bankrupt and can avoid a $206.4 million deficit if the state and City Council work with him to raise taxes and cut spending.
''These actions may be painful,'' he said Monday. ''But had they been taken in the past, as I recommended, they would not be necessary now. To avoid tough times ahead, we cannot avoid tough choices today.'' 
Mr. Goode urged the Legislature to give the city power to raise taxes by $150 million, to be spread among consumers, homeowners and businesses. He also called for a freeze on hiring and a cut in all nonessential services. He did not specify the services. Under its charter, the city cannot raise taxes after the start of the fiscal year, which began July 1, without the Legislature's approval. The Legislature will reconvene Sept. 24.
Mr. Goode also proposed the lease or sale of Veterans Stadium, home of Philadelphia's professional baseball and football teams, and other city assets, including the Water Department.
Mr. Goode's call for action came as his administration announced plans to borrow $400 million in temporary loan notes within the next two weeks.
Without the notes, the city would be out of cash by late September, according to a report by the City Finance Director, Betsy Reveal.
Even with the notes, the city will be out of cash by May unless measures are taken to cut spending or raise taxes in the short term and over a longer period, the report said.
Mayor Goode accused previous administrations of taking stopgap measures to avoid financial crises. But he reserved the largest share of blame for the state.
''The root of our dilemma is that Philadelphia's fiscal problems are primarily structural,'' he said. ''They are built into the state system.''
Gov. Robert P. Casey defended his administration, saying he has ''substantially increased the state's financial contribution to the city.'' Both the Governor and the Mayor are Democrats.
Mr. Goode also assailed the City Council, which he said had repeatedly thwarted his attempts to raise taxes.

HEADLINE: Incumbent Senator And Governor Win In Wyoming Voting

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: CHEYENNE, Wyo. Aug. 21

 BODY:
Senator Alan K. Simpson, an incumbent Republican, and Gov. Mike Sullivan, an incumbent Democrat, handily won their primary races today.
In the Republican primary to face Mr. Sullivan in November, Mary Mead, a ranch owner, defeated State Representative Nyla Murphy. With about 60 percent of the vote counted, Mrs. Mead's margin was 68 percent to 32 percent. 
Mr. Simpson, the Senate minority whip, won nomination to a third term, with about 85 percent of the vote.
Six little-known Democrats were contending for the right to challenge Mr, Simpson. Kathy Helling, a 32-year-old college student, and Al Hamburg, who was convicted last year of forging names on a campaign petition, were ahead in early returns.
As he did four years ago, Mr. Sullivan walked away with the nomination today. He received 88 percent of the early vote in his primary contest with a motorcycle mechanic, Ron Clingman.
The Governor said he would have preferred to face stiffer competition.
''I have to say that when you watch people debating the issues on the other side, you wish you had some primary opposition so you could talk about the issues,'' Mr. Sullivan said.
In the campaign for the Republican nomination to face Mr. Sullivan in November, Mrs. Mead faced Mrs. Murphy, a 59-year-old Casper woman who has served for 12 years in the state House of Representatives.
Mrs. Mead, 55 years old, is the daughter of former United States Senator Cliff Hansen. Mrs. Mead's campaign stressed her skills as a rancher and businesswoman and attacked Mr. Sullivan's economic development efforts.
Mrs. Murphy accused Mrs. Mead of having a negative attitude toward Wyoming and of failing to propose solutions to the shortcomings she perceived.
The state's only member of the House of Representatives, Craig Thomas, had no opponent in the primary. Elected last year to fill Dick Cheney's unexpired term in office, Mr. Thomas is seeking his first full term this fall. Also unopposed was the Democratic challenger, Pete Maxfield, a law professor at the University of Wyoming.

HEADLINE: The President and the Hasty Hawks

 BODY:
A cynical theory making the rounds in Washington holds that Americans will soon tire of President Bush's intervention in the Persian Gulf. Therefore, the theory goes, Mr. Bush should quickly exploit his high standing at home and abroad by undertaking, in Henry Kissinger's words, the ''surgical and progressive destruction of Iraq's military assets.'' Yet there's no evidence that Americans are as fickle as the Hasty Hawks contend. 
That could change, if casualties occur or Saddam Hussein seeks to ransom the hostages. But so far, in growing numbers, Americans support a strategy based on strength, patience and a carefully woven international consensus.
A New York Times/CBS News Poll shows that support for Mr. Bush is high, and climbing. His popularity has now reached 76 percent, equaling his previous high, after the Panama invasion. Fully 75 percent approve his handling of the crisis, a jump from 64 percent in early August.
Those findings reflect patriotism; Americans always rally around the Commander in Chief early in a crisis. But there's no reason to presume that this resolve is as fragile as the hawks seem to believe. Mr. Bush has explained the stakes, and most people appear to understand them.
Mr. Bush also profits handsomely from a resurgence of American pride. Having been told repeatedly that their country is in decline, many Americans are probably pleased to find that the U.S. alone possesses the global reach and the political mechanisms to offer prompt leadership.
Mr. Bush has made one big misstep - moving unilaterally to block shipping to Iraq without waiting for U.N. consent. And his oratory has been anything but Churchillian. Otherwise he has faultlessly positioned his pieces, orchestrating almost overnight two formidable policies - a military force to protect Saudi Arabia, and economic sanctions to force Iraq from Kuwait. Indeed, so smoothly has his strategy fallen into place that it's easy to underestimate how much he's accomplished.
Immediately after Iraq's invasion, for example, it could not be taken for granted that the cautious Saudis would risk inviting American protection. Or that Turkey would close Iraq's pipeline. Or that the U.N. Security Council would unanimously approve sanctions. Adroit diplomacy has since enlisted allies, neutrals and the moderate Arabs in a common cause.
Support for President Bush sends an important signal to Saddam Hussein. So, too, does Mr. Bush's willingness to spend his popularity by mobilizing reservists - the first such call-up since the Tet offensive in 1968 - and, on a less dramatic level, by commandeering 38 jets from 16 domestic airlines. His almost comical insistence on finishing out his vacation in Maine bothers many people; half the poll's respondents think he should have stayed in Washington. But even that stubbornness sends a calculated message to Baghdad: He will not allow foreign tyranny to imprison him in the White House.
The crisis is still in its early stages; much could happen to test and even weaken public resolve. But for now, Americans in great numbers accept Mr. Bush's definition of the stakes and his goals. Having worked so hard to build a global consensus against Iraq, one that includes even Arab states, the President would be foolish to risk its destruction by heeding the Hasty Hawks.

HEADLINE: OBSERVER;
Slaves to Oil

BYLINE: By Russell Baker

 BODY:
We are all hostages now, and by our own consent. It is our addiction to imported oil that has undone us. ''Just say no,'' Nancy Reagan used to advise the young tempted by drugs. Neither her husband nor anyone else of public consequence dared issue the same good advice to a vast public of all ages that was hopelessly hooked on oil.
Jimmy Carter had tried something like it during his own Presidency and Reagan had flattened him for it in the election of 1980. The Reagan people had recognized that Americans had a bad, bad oil habit, so bad that they were ready to kill for it, and certainly ready to shuck off any President who tried to ease them toward a cure. The Reagan people chose to get ahead by going along. 
To be sure, even Carter's medicine had been feeble stuff. He asked everybody to set the thermostat lower, leaned on Detroit to make the cars a little more efficient, persuaded Congress to put up a little money for research on solar energy. He appeared on television sitting in the White House wearing a heavy wool sweater.
A lot of us joked or winced at that. Next thing you knew he'd be urging us to put on long johns for the winter, as though we were farmers or, worse, Britishers.
Americans were delighted by the chance to put him away in 1980. When they did, the one feeble attempt to stop the big oil binge ended. After the Reagan landslide, research on solar energy was closed down. The ancient American lust for big cars was permitted to rage again.
The Japanese had successfully invaded America by offering low-cost, low-weight, fuel-efficient cars Detroit couldn't match. But as the oil spree got bigger in the 80's, so did Japanese cars. Bigger, heavier, more expensive, more like the old Detroit guzzlers and more profitable to both dealers and Japan.
By the late 1980's, Cadillac and Lincoln were running television commercials in which uptown swells engaged in boasting competitions about whose car was bigger, longer, heavier, more mastodonic and, therefore, more appropriate for the very finest Americans to drive to the country club.
The policy was: It's morning in America; live it up.
Thus we made the entire country available to hostage-takers like Saddam Hussein whose threat to our oil supply now enables him to force us to choose among options in matters of war, diplomacy and economic stability, all of them decidedly nasty.
If Saddam had not taken advantage of us, sooner or later someone else surely would have, and may yet, if the Saddam business ends happily. When you are as vulnerable as we have made ourselves because of our oil habit, it is only a matter of time before dangerous or foolish adventurers will dare have a go at you.
The big men say, of course, that oil is not the only explanation for our war footing. Saddam is said to be another Adolf Hitler (sure, and John Dillinger was another Attila the Hun), and his theft of Kuwait is said to be the sort of brutal aggression against which we must be prepared to use all our might if necessary to avert bloody chaos.
This call to serve principle and international morality is ennobling, but if no oil were at risk would we really be putting armies and navies into Arabia?
Drop the oil from the equation and the thuggish Saddam's seizure of Kuwait would be, to the United States, just another uninteresting incident in the tiresome tribal quarrels that divided the Arabs of the old Ottoman Empire before the British made such a mess of it in the First World War.
Of course, without the oil - all that money! - Kuwait might not have attracted Saddam. Certainly nothing in the Middle East attracted the United States until there was oil. It is hard to believe that before the Middle East and oil became synonymous, the United States would have wasted even a note of reprimand on a small-bore chieftain like Saddam for brutalizing one of the weaker tribes.
President Bush says the American way of life is threatened. He apparently means our ability to pick up the carry-out fried chicken in the drive-by lane at the fast-food shop, as well as our power to sit one-commuter-per-car for 45 minutes every day on the way home from work.
Hooked as we are on such joys, we may end by finding ourselves at war to preserve them. If not this time, then maybe next time. When you've got to have oil or die, you put your destiny in the hands of the oil dealers, just as surely as the drug addicts make themselves hostages to the people Nancy Reagan wants you to just say no to.

HEADLINE: Rinfret, Stalking Governor, Gets Lecture but No Debate

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUFFALO, Aug. 21

 BODY:
For the second time in five days, Pierre A. Rinfret, the Republican gubernatorial candidate, ambushed Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today by making a surprise appearance at one of the Governor's public events.
Mr. Rinfret beat Mr. Cuomo to a General Mills factory here and, when Mr. Cuomo arrived for a plant tour, confronted the Governor on the subject of debates. Mr. Rinfret, a New York City economist running his first political race, staged a similar ambush on Thursday at a Manhattan park where Mr. Cuomo was scheduled to speak.
Mr. Cuomo approached Mr. Rinfret today after being told his opponent was outside the factory gate. He spoke to him in calm, if stern, tones, but he later mocked Mr. Rinfret's tactics. 
''Politics is a little bit silly here,'' Mr. Cuomo said. ''It's obvious that if he were the major candidate he says he is, he wouldn't be popping up from the bushes to get his face on television, right?
 
'He Could Buy Television'
''He'd go to the people of the state and talk to them. Or, he has $15 million. He could buy television. He says he's very wealthy. He said the President's with him. Why he has to sneak around and jump up in your face I don't know.''
Just as in last week's encounter, Mr. Rinfret devoted his entire confrontation with Mr. Cuomo to challenging the Governor to a one-on-one debate that would not include the nominees of the Conservative Party and the Right to Life Party.
''Hello Mario, how are you,'' Mr. Rinfret began, as a ring of reporters and photographers tightened around the candidates.
''You're good at getting cameras,'' Mr. Cuomo said. ''How can I help you?''
''Well, I want to debate you one-on-one, as you know, as we've talked about,'' Mr. Rinfret said.
 
'Mario, Will You Debate Me?'
''Let me make it as clear as I can,'' said Mr. Cuomo. ''We agreed four ways. I've said over and over and I've said to you personally, as you know, I'd be delighted to debate you. They want to be part of the debate and they're entitled to be part of the debate and that's it.''
That was not quite it, but the discussion did not get much more substantive. Mr. Cuomo eventually broke it off as Mr. Rinfret yelled after him: ''Will you debate me one-on-one? Mario, will you debate me one-on-one?''
Despite Mr. Rinfret's challenge, the Republican candidate's true position on debates seemed unclear.
Mr. Rinfret said today he would debate only Mr. Cuomo. That stance contradicted Mr. Rinfret's position last week, in a news release, that Mr. Rinfret preferred a two-way debate but would participate in a four-way affair.
 
Rinfret Demands One-on-One
''Changed my mind,'' said Mr. Rinfret, who has also changed his mind on releasing his income-tax returns. ''I'm entitled to that.''
Mr. Cuomo has maintained that Herbert London, the Conservative Party candidate, and Louis P. Wein, the Right to Life Party candidate, have a legal right to participate in any debates.
Mr. Rinfret has said that those candidates are ''peripheral'' and that they will join Mr. Cuomo in attacking him during a debate.
While the Republican candidate was taking out his lonely position, representatives of the three other candidates agreed today to hold two debates this fall. Mr. Rinfret's aides were invited to the meeting but did not attend.
One debate would be held in upstate New York in mid-October and the other would be held in New York City in late October or early November. Election Day is Nov. 6.

HEADLINE: For Gay Travelers, More Places to Go

BYLINE: By Trish Hall

DATELINE: EAST STROUDSBURG, Pa.

 BODY:
ON a blistering August day the lounge chairs around the swimming pool at the Rainbow Mountain Resort here are overflowing with bare arms and legs. The smell of coconut oil and the sounds of ''I Got You Babe'' fill the air. Everything about this middle-class enclave seems typical of life in a Pocono Mountain resort except for one thing: nearly all the guests are gay.
John R., who lives and works in New York City, has been spending every weekend here because it is the only place where he and his companion feel they can relax, holding hands when the mood strikes without looking around nervously. ''It's like paradise,'' he said. ''Nobody bothers you.'' Like others, he spoke only on condition that his full name not be used.
Resorts, guest houses, tour operators and travel agents are increasingly finding that it pays to cater to gay customers by providing environments where they will feel comfortable and able to relax without engaging in the pretenses that are so often required in their day-to-day lives, where they often feel obliged to hide their sexual orientation. 
There have always been some resort areas, like Provincetown on Cape Cod and Key West in Florida, that attracted gay people, but the range and quality of services has vastly increased in the last few years. Seedy guest houses, once the norm, have been supplanted by elegant Victorian inns. Travelers can join gay-only tours through Machu Picchu or cruises of the Caribbean.
The International Gay Travel Association, a trade group that started with 20 members five years ago, now has 450 members. Member agencies seek gay business, either because they are gay-owned or see the market as appealing. Most travel companies, however, do not seek gay business as a special niche. ''We provide travel services for everyone,'' said Henry Blinder, a spokesman for Thomas Cook Travel in New York.
Specialists in gay travel say several factors account for the surging business, which is occurring even as the travel business in general is in a slump. The market for gay travel seems less affected by economic uncertainty because so many gay travelers live in households with two incomes and no children.
Although there are no figures showing the size of the gay market, a survey answered by 4,100 readers of eight large gay newspapers found that they took twice as many domestic trips as the national average, were more likely to fly and had incomes three times the national average. The study was done in 1988 by Simmons Market Research Bureau in New York for the Rivendell Marketing Company in New York, an advertising representative for gay newspapers and magazines.
Travel agents who specialize in the gay market say the lure of gay-only trips seems to be growing in part because those who came of age during the gay liberation movement tend to be more open about their sexuality and less afraid to patronize gay establishments. The advent of AIDS has also made travel more alluring to gay men than socializing in bars and bathhouses. ''It's an activity that doesn't involve any danger,'' said Hanns Ebensten, a tour operator with his own company in Key West. ''You don't get AIDS from looking at the Taj Mahal.''
Gay-only tours and cruises also spare gay travelers the need to participate in tiny but wearing compromises. ''On a tour,'' Mr. Ebensten said, ''you have to contribute and socialize and be pleasant and dance with the ladies. When someone says, 'Look at that pretty girl selling oranges,' you have to agree.''
The lure of all-gay trips, he said, is not what some people might think. ''It's not a great sex jaunt,'' Mr. Ebensten said. ''It's just that they're seeing the wonderful places they want to see in congenial company.''
At Rainbow Mountain, begun nine years ago by Laura Irish and Georgeann Moses on 85 acres of land here, all the amenities that typify a mountain vacation are available: tennis court, swimming pool, restaurant, pond, little red cabins with white trim. ''People come here to rest and relax,'' Ms. Irish said. ''It's not a cruisy, pickup atmosphere.''
Most visitors are couples who like to vacation in a place where they do not have to hide their homosexuality. ''I can be how I want without wondering if anyone is talking about me,'' said Jeanne L., who was spending the weekend with her companion and two of their friends. On Monday she would return to work, where she never can talk about her companion or her personal feelings because her friends and co-workers do not know she is gay. ''It's very difficult to go back into the real world,'' she said. ''You have to reprogram your brain.''
For a weekend, though, the women are spared the necessity of pretending. Homosexual couples say that when staying in most hotels, they sometimes mess up the other bed so the maid won't suspect they are gay.
An all-gay resort offers the chance to make friendships based on honesty. Some gay people say that is a rare opportunity for gay people. ''The life style can be a very lonely one,'' Jeanne said. Travel agents say their gay customers want what all travelers want: good accommodations and a felicitous environment. Agents will make sure that travelers don't end up in meccas for families with children or heterosexual honeymooners.
Not all gay travelers want to stay in gay-only hotels, but they tend to prefer adult-oriented places or resorts not biased against gay patrons. Derek G., who is homosexual and lives in Boston, recently stayed at a Holiday Inn in San Antonio and wandered down to the hot tub at 8 one night, thinking it would be frequented by other adults. ''There were 15 children diving head first into the Jacuzzi,'' he said. ''That's not my idea of relaxation.'' Travel agents make sure accommodations are suitable. ''A gay couple would be embarrassed to go to a regular agency and ask for a double bed,'' said George Wilson, president of the gay-oriented Islanders' Club Travel Company in New York.
Agents, too, can warn clients not to behave publicly in ways that might create problems for them in some locations. ''When you land in Madrid, you don't wear four earrings in each ear,'' said Aldis Alexander, an agent whose company, Aldis the Travel Planner in Brookfield, Conn., caters to a gay clientele.
Patronizing gay resorts makes problems less likely. James Fisher, a transportation consultant in New York, said he once checked into a hotel in Key West and received the worst room in the house. ''I think it was because I was with my lover,'' he said. ''I did complain, and they did upgrade my room, but it took a lot of fighting,'' he said. At gay-owned places, he said, he has not encountered such slights.
Information on travel can be found in the growing number of travel books put out by small publishers and sold at gay bookstores, and in gay-oriented newspapers and magazines. Our World, an international gay travel magazine based in Daytona Beach, Fla., started publishing 18 months ago and broke even after five issues. ''We have six filing cabinets full of gay accommodations, and we get new stuff in every day,'' said Wayne Whiston, the editor.
There are more luxurious places to stay than in the past, perhaps because of the recognition that the gay market is relatively affluent.
Kay Tsenin, a lawyer in San Francisco, opened the Langtry, a bed and breakfast in an old Victorian house that offers rooms ranging from $75 to $200 a night. ''I was tired of going to places that were downwardly mobile,'' she said, ''places that had signs in the kitchen like, 'Your mother doesn't live here anymore, so clean up after yourself.' ''
Cruises have also become popular among homosexuals. RSVP in Minneapolis has offered them for men since 1986. And early this year Olivia Records in Oakland, Calif., a producer of women's music, held its first two cruises in the Bahamas for 600 women each time. They sold out so quickly that Olivia is now planning three more cruises in the next year. ''Women are making more money,'' said Judy Dlugacz, the president of Olivia. ''There's such a desire to go away and not be defending yourself the whole time.''
Specialists in gay travel say they rarely encounter resistance to booking their clients, but it does happen. Robin Tyler, a music promoter in Los Angeles, decided earlier this year to organize a cruise for women. ''A lot of the cruise lines wouldn't do it,'' she said. One finally agreed, and the cruise is scheduled for this winter.
Most gay-oriented trips and agents publicize their services only in gay publications, to avoid mix-ups. They do occur, however. Ms. Tsenin, general partner in the Langtry, said a man checked in shortly after it opened about five years ago. She said that when he looked out on the deck and saw it filled with women, ''He said, 'I think I've died and gone to heaven.' '' He caught on, though, and ''ended up being a good friend,'' Ms. Tsenin said.
