HEADLINE: Oil and Gas Prices Rise Slightly

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Prices for oil and gasoline rose slightly yesterday after swinging sharply during the day. They surged early in the day but then fell back after a statement by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq that traders said was less aggressive than expected.
Crude oil for October delivery closed up by 12 cents a barrel, at $28.71, having bounced from $28 to $29.45. But that was placid compared with gasoline, which traded over a broad 11-cent-a-gallon range, equivalent to $4.62 a barrel. It closed at $1.0125 a gallon, up 1.01 cents, after reaching $1.065 and dipping to 95.5 cents. 
Heating oil for September delivery closed at 83.71 cents a gallon, up three-quarters of a cent.
 
Bigger Losses in Europe
Stock prices also gyrated, with the Dow Jones industrial average dropping 52.48 points, or nearly 2 percent, to 2,603.96, after being down more than 77 points early in the day. The selloff continued in Tokyo today, with the Nikkei index at midday off 3.9 percent. Earlier yesterday, in Europe, with tensions heightened by a rumor, quickly denied, of a downed American fighter plane, stocks took even bigger losses. [Pages D8 and D2.] Crude oil moved mostly because the Iraqi statement was ''somewhat conciliatory, comparatively speaking,'' one trader in New York said.
The market's mood is making it more volatile even if price differences from one day's close to the next is not large, some experts said.
 
Move by OPEC Expected
Officials of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries indicated last night that there was a ''strong likelihood'' that by today a majority of 7 of the 13 OPEC members would agree to call a meeting.
A senior official of the group, who spoke on the condition that he not be identified, said that the last holdout was Ecuador and that it would decide today whether to join in a call for a meeting of all 13 members. Officials said, however, that even if a meeting were called, there was little chance that it would produce a unanimous decision on raising the group's total production but that enough of the members would agree to increase their output to make up for the Iraq and Kuwait shortfall.
The senior OPEC official said that these members would certainly include Saudi Arabia, which will increase its output by 2 million barrels a day; Venezuela, which is expected to raise its production by 500,000 to 600,000, and the United Arab Emirates, which would participate with an increase of about 500,000 barrels.
Peter C. Beutel, a trader at Merrill Lynch Futures, said the market in the United States ''acted like a gorilla on a trampoline.'' He added that in the current atmosphere of uncertainty, speculators were afraid to sell oil short, which means to promise delivery of oil they do not have. As a result, when others who are ''long'' decide to take a profit by selling contracts for oil they do not need, there are no ready buyers. ''So you get these quick whooshes down,'' he said.
After trading ended yesterday, the American Petroleum Institute, the industry's main trade association, released inventory figures that will add to the cues from which the market can choose today. 271,000-Barrel Drop In ordinary times, the new inventory numbers would be bearish. For the week ended Friday, crude oil fell by 271,000 barrels, a barely significant amount, and remained 40.4 million barrels higher than this time last year.
But with all eyes on the Middle East, market analysts said they did not know what effect the institute's numbers would have. ''If you do a supply-demand analysis for the fourth quarter,'' said Philip K. Verleger Jr., a commodity economist, ''even with an increase by Saudi Arabia of two million barrels a day and even if the other OPEC members go to full capacity, there is still a difference between production and consumption of two million barrels a day.''
The gasoline market, meanwhile, seems driven by demons of its own. Specialists suspect that at least part of the price run-up of the last few days is because large purchasers, from fuel distributors to service station chains, were buying supplies earlier than usual, because they thought prices would keep rising. That may have ended, with the inventories of refiners rising last week, by the petroleum institute's count.
But the market for refined products is also driven by the availability of refineries, and specialists are beginning to consider more seriously the fact that nearly half of Kuwait's exports of 1.5 million barrels a day were not crude oil, but refined products, which went to Europe and the Far East.
''Imports of gasoline into Europe must be down significantly,'' said John H. Lichtblau of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation in New York. That cuts European exports to the United States. American refineries meet only 94 or 95 percent of domestic demand, with the balance coming from Europe and South America.
Mr. Lichtblau said that to a small extent, the military deployment in the Persian Gulf was consuming oil from Saudi refineries that would otherwise be available for export.
While the crude market may be calmed by increased production from Saudi Arabia or Venezuela, and crude prices would be lowered if Western governments decide to release reserves from strategic stocks, none of that would make more gasoline available, analysts point out.
Others say there is no justification for the price increases. ''I find it difficult to understand,'' said Nicholas A. Fedoruk, an energy specialist at Citizen Action, a nonprofit group in Washington. ''Clearly the price of oil has leveled out; there just doesn't seem to be a reason for the price of gasoline to be increasing.''
He suggested that the oil companies felt freer to increase the price of gasoline now because Congress was out of session. ''Maybe they think the chance of a 'windfall profits' tax is less now,'' he added.
Whatever the reason for the rising price of gasoline in the futures market, oil experts say that the last 20 to 30 cents of increases have not been reflected in the pump price, but will be in coming weeks unless futures prices turn around sharply.

HEADLINE: A Bank Expert's Plan for Change

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
When Lowell L. Bryan, head of the banking group at McKinsey & Company, the management consulting firm, ponders the future of the banking system, he recalls his father's explanation of how the failure of four banks in Oklahoma during the early 1930's carried away the family fortune.
''It was dust bowl Oklahoma and the fortune was not that big,'' Mr. Bryan said, ''but I remember my father telling me at an early age that bank failures were not good.''
That bit of family lore, plus the evidence from the Great Depression, when a loss of deposits contributed to the downward economic spiral, has made the 44-year-old Mr. Bryan a believer in the Government safety net for depositors. But he has warned of serious problems with the way the safety net is used in the American banking system.
 
An Influential Voice
At a time when Congress and bank regulators are intent on preventing a repeat of the savings and loan debacle among banks, Mr. Bryan has emerged as an influential voice on regulatory issues. He has an insider's knowledge of banking, without the vested interests of a banker. His recommendations - particularly that banks should not be able to use Government-insured deposits for risky loans and that the Government should not pay the costs when those loans go bad and the bank fails - are part of the dialogue whenever regulators and legislators discuss reform of the banking system. 
''Even if you see problems with his proposals, as I do, he is a thinker, and that is something you don't see enough of in banking,'' said H. Rodgin Cohen, a lawyer specializing in banks at the law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell..
While Mr. Bryan does not expect a rapid collapse of the banking industry, he warned the Senate Banking Committee recently that the problems of banks ''are distressingly similar'' to those of the savings and loans. The banks' $200 billion capital cushion for absorbing losses may allow the industry ''to muddle through'' for several years, he said. But unless the system is changed, he added, the capital cushion could be eroded, increasing the chances that banks would eventually need the same kind of taxpayer support now being provided to the savings and loans.
Bankers' problems stem from their increasing losses from the kinds of risky loans that were rare a decade ago. As banks tried to replace the profits lost to competitors like money market mutual funds and securities firms, Mr. Bryan said, risky lending by banks for commercial real estate and corporate takeovers grew until, by 1989, it accounted for nearly half of the industry's pretax profits.
With riskier loans has come a rise in loan losses and a fear that if the economy slides into a recession, bank losses would rise sharply on a wider variety of loans. ''We have a greatly weakened banking system,'' Mr. Bryan said, noting that history shows that in a recession most of the loan losses are concentrated at 20 percent of the banks, making those banks more vulnerable to failure, which in turn could drain the Government's bank insurance fund.
The son of a Washington lobbyist for the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, Mr. Bryan has seen enough of Washington to recognize that taxpayers' outrage at the cost of the savings and loan collapse ''makes this the right time for banking reform.''
His efforts, which include four appearances before Congressional committees, take about a quarter of his working hours. Other partners at the firm are sympathetic, leaving him enough leisure time to coach the basketball and baseball teams of his 12-year- old son, the only one of his three children still young enough to live at home in New Canaan, Conn., with him and his wife, Deborah.
The essence of Mr. Bryan's program is to divide the banking system into two types of firms.
One type, which he calls a core bank, would accept Government-insured deposits, much as banks do today. But its activities would be limited to what he calls low-risk businesses like investments in Government securities, consumer loans and loans to small- and medium-sized businesses. ''These are not the customers that are putting banks out of business,'' he said. ''They don't have access to the securities markets and banks are still the best way of delivering service to them.''
 
Consumer Banking Risks
While some analysts, like Mr. Cohen, warn that even consumer banking can be made risky by poor management, Mr. Bryan notes that regulators would still have a role in making sure that core banks follow sound business procedures.
A second type of firm, called a wholesale or commercial finance bank, would be financed by investors whose funds would not be insured. It could do as much risky trading and lending, like loans for corporate takeovers and commercial real estate, as its financial performance and investors would allow.
''Protect the depositors and let investors take their chances,'' is Mr. Bryan's theme.
But for his system to work, depositors and investors would have to accept changes in the benefits and risks of the current system.
''Depositors in the core bank, in return for eliminating the risk of loss, would have to accept lower interest rates than they now earn,'' he said. And investors in the commercial finance company must accept the risk that ''if the company gets in trouble, the Government will prevent a panic, but will allow the company to go down, just as they did with Drexel Burnham.''
The success of companies like American Express and General Electric Financial Services Inc. is proof, he said, that a deposit guarantee is not needed to operate a financial company. Large financial companies would probably own a core bank and a commercial finance company, he said, adding that there should be strict controls on money transfers between them, but no limits on the sharing of information.
Mr. Bryan is modest enough to acknowledge that many others, including Robert Litan at the Brookings Institution, have proposals similar to his. But he does not shirk from criticism of other proposals that he sees ''as too narrow to solve the problem.''
 
Fed Proposal Criticized
For example, the Federal Reserve's recent suggestion that banks be required to increase the capital they have available to absorb losses might temporarily protect the Government insurance fund from loss but is not a long-term solution to the industry's problems, Mr Bryan said. In his 1988 book, ''Breaking Up the Bank,'' he said that higher capital requirements would encourage banks to make high-risk loans because ''only these will yield spreads high enough to generate a satisfactory return'' on the increased capital required by regulators. The alternative for banks - to cut back lending until their size is reduced to a level considered more appropriate for their capital - would starve many businesses of needed financing and hurt the economy.
Suggestions that the Government limit its risk of loss by sharply reducing the amount of deposit insurance available to bank customers ''are a lot riskier than people realize,'' Mr. Bryan said. ''There could be a real flight of capital'' from banks if large depositors are told they face a loss in the event of failure.
Backers of the ''universal bank'' structure, which is used in Europe and allows a wide range of insurance, securities, lending and deposit taking under the roof of a single banking company, should beware of weaknesses that will be disclosed as European countries drop trade barriers in 1992, Mr. Bryan warned.
''Competitors will emerge who will go after the most profitable parts of the universal banks' business,'' he said. ''If a Swiss company can successfully offer money market funds in Germany, they will take some market share and the German banks will lose some of their ability to cross-subsidize other activities,'' Mr. Bryan said. In the past, he noted, universal banks have used their large share of their home country's retail banking business to subsidize other activities and keep competitors out.
 
Research in Vietnam
Mr. Bryan's interest in the banking system started long before the savings and loan crisis. After graduating in 1970 from the Harvard Business School, ''where I got my Eastern Establishment credentials,'' he went to Vietnam and completed a research report on how banks set prices for different services.
He described the job of training Vietnamese to operate the country's communications system after American forces left as ''one of the safest positions over there, because the North Vietnamese did not want to destroy the system they knew they would be taking over.''
Now, with the once unthinkable collapse of the banking system becoming at least a possibility, Mr. Bryan is again in a position to observe the fray. Whatever measures for change are supported by Government regulators, it seems certain that the services of management consultants will be in strong demand.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Baby Boomers' Free Lunch?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
EVERYONE knows that America's rapidly aging baby boomers are burning the candle at both ends, consuming when they should be saving for retirement. Everyone also knows the boomers are depending on the rapid accumulation of cash in the Social Security trust fund to save their bacon.
But according to some heavyweight economists from Harvard (Louise Sheiner, Lawrence Summers) and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (David Cutler, James Poterba) everyone has it wrong. While it may indeed pay Americans to consume less, they argue, the graying of the baby boom generation is not in itself a good reason to save more. 
In ordinary times their paradoxical defense of profligacy, just published in the Brookings Institution's Papers on Economic Activity, might be written off as the sort of game that academics love to play. But with state taxes on the rise and Federal tax increases high on the political agenda, it could - and probably should - increase the intellectual respectability of the crusade by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, to reduce the Social Security payroll tax.
On first glance the case for increasing savings to cover the needs of a rapidly growing non-working population seems airtight. One way or another, those who are productive must pay for those who are not. And if America does not save and invest heavily today, the smaller number of workers laboring in tomorrow's shops and factories will not be productive enough to support the larger number of pensioners in the style to which they have grown accustomed.
But as the four economists point out, demographics can cut both ways. The baby boom of the 1950's and 60's has been mirrored by the baby bust of more recent decades. Between 1960 and 1990 the labor force grew at an average of 1.6 percent annually. Between the years 2010 and 2060, however, it is unlikely to grow at all. And as the growth of the labor force slows, so, too, will the economy's need to run merely to stay in place.
During the 1980's, for example, the labor force increased by one-fifth. And to maintain the same amount of productive capital equipment per worker, the economy had to increase the stock of capital one-fifth - an effort that absorbed hundreds of billions of dollars. By early in the next century, however, the number of workers will have peaked. Any investment, beyond the amount needed to cover depreciation, will increase capital ''intensity.''
The dependency effect and the labor scarcity effect thus work in opposition. The former accentuates the tie between high savings and high growth rates, while the latter diminishes the linkage. And miracle of miracles, say the researchers, mathematical simulations suggest that today's high-living consumers need never pay a price for their profligacy. In spite of rising dependency, America could sustain gradually rising living standards -what economists call an ''optimal growth path'' -without increasing savings.
Were America to adopt pay-as-you-go Social Security, taxes would, of course, have to be raised later on to cover the baby boomers' pension and medical bills. And the spike in taxes, the authors acknowledge, could act as disincentives to work and invest. Indeed, if the economic distortions associated with this future tax increase were large enough, it would sink the whole logic of playing now and paying later.
But once again Pollyanna prevails. The researchers estimate that demographic changes will increase the portion of national income spent by the Government between 2010 and 2060 by a full five percentage points. But the failure to pay the rising bill with an unvarying tax rate would create economic losses of a mere 1 percent of a single year's national income.
Economists are bound to be attracted by the researchers' tight reasoning, as well as by their mathematical razzle-dazzle. But as Lawrence Summers readily acknowledges, it is all too easy to misread the conclusion. The research does not say that Americans would be foolish to save more. What it does say is that the rapid aging of the population does not mean it is necessary to raise the savings rate to maintain stable growth in living standards.
But there is no need to misread the research to see its political significance. Senator Moynihan maintains that it would be fairer to pass on the cost of the baby boomers' retirement to future generations than to take it out of the hides of today's hard-pressed workers, many of whom are baby boomers. Mr. Summers and his colleagues conclude that the looming cost of the boomers' retirement is in itself a poor excuse to save more now. Congress, always on the lookout for ways to please the voters, may need no sturdier rationale.

HEADLINE: Tokyo Stocks Plunge Over Crisis in Mideast

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The Tokyo stock market plummeted today in reaction to the continued tensions in the Middle East and the tumbling prices on Wall Street.
Once again, program trading played a leading role in the decline. The value of stock index futures fell sharply this morning, followed by stock prices, traders said. Volume was very thin, which allowed the selling pressure to have an even larger impact. 
''The futures had an exaggerated effect on the market,'' said Jeffery Guy, an analyst at Yamaichi Securities. ''But the market is very shaky anyway.''
The Nikkei 225-stock average closed down 1,086.93 points, or 4.13 percent, to 25,210.91. At one point in the afternoon, the Nikkei dropped below 25,000, the first time it went below that level since Feb. 24, 1988.
Another factor pushing the market lower, analysts said, was higher interest rates. As short-term rates edged higher in the money market, reports came out saying that Japanese banks were likely to raise their long-term prime rate soon. Banking sources were quoted as saying the prime rate would rise from 7.9 percent to 8.3 percent in the next several weeks.
In Europe yesterday, stock markets also fell sharply as the uncertainty of the Middle East crisis, fears of inflation and higher interest rates continued to undermine confidence.
The West German market dropped 5.2 percent, the French market 4 percent and the British market 2 percent. In Germany and France, the markets closed at their lowest levels of the year.
With the crisis finishing its third week, news or rumors from the Persian Gulf have sent markets up or down quickly. But most of the news has been negative and most quick reactions have been down.
Some selling in Europe was set off by a rumor, quickly denied, that an American fighter plane had been shot down over the Persian Gulf. The rumor caused concern that war could break out. But by the end of trading in New York those fears may have eased a little, with the Dow Jones industrial average coming back from a 77-point decline to close down 52.48.
Stock market analysts have given up trying to guess when the decline will stop. In many markets ''trusty'' support levels in the main indexes have already given way several times.
But Alistair Ross Goobey, the chief international strategist at James Capel Ltd. in London, said, ''At some stage you reach levels where people say, 'Even if I do this and war breaks out I will be happy in six months' time.' ''
He said he thinks that France and Britain are close to these levels. But West Germany and the United States, where the Dow's 1.98 percent fall left it at 2,603.96 yesterday, still have a way to go.
Even with the growth of bargains in many markets people are not ready to take advantage of them. ''We are not recommending buying,'' Mr. Ross Goobey said yesterday, ''because, as we saw today, the threat of war sends the market down.''
Forces outside the Middle East and the economic shock of the oil price increase were also contributing to the declines in some markets.
In France, the end of the monthly accounting period is tomorrow, which is adding to the sales rush, analysts said. If stock is sold in the new account period after tomorrow, the trade is not settled and the money does not change hands until the end of the account period in September.
Yesterday, the Paris bourse's blue-chip index, the CAC-40, fell 65.41 points, to 1,546.51, its lowest level since the beginning of 1989.
Also adding to the market's problems is the fact that some half-year earnings reports that have been released have been disappointing and the others still due soon are not expected to be any better. The weak dollar is hurting French exporters and the rise in oil prices is hurting chemical firms.
Michael Diehl, an analyst for Kleinwort Benson Securities in London, said that the selling in France had been by foreigners who helped drive the market up this spring. He said that most domestic investors had been staying out of the market.
In West Germany, the problems with the unification of the two Germanys is also weighing on the market. In Frankfurt, the blue-chip index, the DAX, dropped 85.73 points, to 1,549.96, its low for the year.
The faster than expected collapse of the East Germany economy means the cost of unification will be higher for West Germany. On Monday, the head of the East German agency in change of selling off state-owned businesses resigned after only a month on the job.
In Britain, The Financial Times stock exchange index was down 48.5 points, or 2 percent, to 2,108.1, its lowest level since April of this year and its sharpest one-day decline since Oct. 16, 1989.

HEADLINE: 'Junk Bonds' Post Sharp Price Decline

BYLINE: By ANISE C. WALLACE

 BODY:
Prices of some high-yield ''junk bonds'' fell sharply yesterday as investors reacted to the uncertainty in the Mideast and to concerns about a possible recession. Some mutual fund portfolio managers sold these speculative bonds to meet an increase in redemptions by nervous individual investors, traders said.
Indeed, in contrast to recent days when Wall Street dealers marked these bonds lower on very little selling, yesterday's trading was characterized as moderately heavy, traders said, and they expect the selloff to continue. 
Prices of RJR Nabisco bonds plunged more than two points, or $20 for every $1,000 of face amount. Bonds of the R.H. Macy & Company fell more than four points on continuing worries that the heavily indebted retailer would be unable to meet its obligations.
 
'Everything Was Down'
Even junk bonds of companies that investors consider recession-proof like the Kroger Company, the food chain, fell more than one point. ''Everything was down,'' said David Feinman, a junk bond trader at Jefferies & Company in Beverly Hills.
Many of the more speculative junk bonds, like zero-coupon bonds that pay no interest, or so-called pay-in-kind bonds that pay interest not in cash but in more junk bonds, were hit the hardest, and bonds of casino companies continued to drop sharply.
Nevertheless, traders said that late in the afternoon portfolio managers at some insurance companies and investment management firms stepped in and began buying some of the suddenly cheaper bonds. $230 Billion Market Junk bonds are securities of companies that are too young or have too much debt to earn an investment grade rating from the rating agencies like Moody's Investors Services. Many of the bonds in this $230 billion market were issued to finance leveraged buyouts and other corporate reorganizations in the late 1980's. Many investors are now worried that these companies will be unable to meet all of their debt payments.
Traders said yesterday that some Wall Street dealers, nervous about the possibility of war in the Mideast, were selling bonds to lighten their inventories of these risky securities. Also portfolio managers at junk bond mutual funds were trying to raise cash as nervous shareholders moved out, many switching their assets into safer investments like money market funds.
''There had been good cash flow into our high-yield fund all year, but clearly the trend has reversed,'' said Brian Mattes, a spokesman at the Vanguard Group, a large mutual fund organization in Valley Forge, Pa. Investors began withdrawing their cash from the company's $865 million junk bond fund in early August, and redemptions have picked up substantially since then, he said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Japan Trade Group Fills Top Post in New York

 BODY:
The Japan External Trade Organization has named Tetsuo Matsufuji president of its New York office. Jetro is one of the leading Japanese Government agencies that promote trade relations between Japan and other countries.
Mr. Matsufuji, who is 47, has spent the last 25 years working in various countries for the Japanese Ministry of International Trade and Industry, which oversees Jetro. 
He was president of the trade organization's office in Dusseldorf in the 1970's, for instance, where he developed policies to help reduce the trade imbalance between Japan and West Germany. His most recent position was as director of the policy division in the organization's Economic Planning Agency in Tokyo.
Mr. Matsufuji said he would work to increase United States exports to Japan in an effort to reduce the $49 billion trade imbalance between the two countries.
''This is not an easy job because the situation is too big,'' he said. ''You can't change it in a year or two.''
Since arriving in New York last month, Mr. Matsufuji has been walking a great deal around the city to get to know it and to window-shop with his 22-year-old son. He said they looked primarily for luggage, baby clothes and furniture because those were items manufactured in the United States that appealed to the Japanese. Nevertheless, he said American manufacturers would have to reshape some products for the Japanese market.
''The furniture sizes are just too big,'' Mr. Matsufuji said with a slight laugh. ''And in America, all the baby products are pink and blue. But in Japan the color is white.''
He had no complaints about the quality or cost of American products.
Mr. Matsufuji said his next project was to send Japanese businessmen to 15 Southern and Midwestern states in search of export products from small and medium-sized companies.
Jetro organizes buying and selling missions in which representatives of Japanese companies come to the United States and buy products that are then sold as samples at trade shows in Japan. Textiles, furniture and pharmaceuticals make up most of the 1,000 samples tested annually, he said.
The agency's annual budget for import promotion this year is $100 million, distributed among seven offices in the United States and 77 offices in other countries.
Mr. Matsufuji graduated from the law department of Tokyo University. His wife, Ayako, and two daughters plan to join him in New York in February. His son will return to Japan to finish his university education there. The family has a home near Tokyo, in the city of Nagareyama.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Tetsuo Matsufuji, Japan External Trade Organization

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
State Dept. Contract Gives Wang a Boost

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
In its most positive news in more than two years, Wang Laboratories Inc. said yesterday that the State Department had awarded the company a five-year, $841.3 million contract to supply and service a range of desk-top and midrange computers.
Under the agreement, Wang, based in Lowell, Mass., said that it would supply the State Department with personal computers, computer networks, midrange systems, communications gear and technical support and training.
Wang, once a leader in the computer industry, has struggled for the last four years with a series of reorganizations and layoffs. The contract announcement yesterday was described as the largest in the company's history. 
''This is important because it sends a signal,'' said Richard W. Miller, Wang's chairman and chief executive. ''It's an important confidence builder and a testimony from a sophisticated customer that is betting on us.''
He said he expected that the company, which reported a $424.3 million loss in 1989, will return to profitability in 1991.
Mr. Miller said the company had begun the bidding process for the State Department contract three years ago, but that it had been particularly intense in the last 12 months.
Frederick A. Wang, son of Wang's founder, An Wang, resigned in August 1989 as president of the company and Mr. Miller was appointed to take over as president and chief executive. An Wang died of cancer at age 70 this past March.
The office automation equipment in the contract will be used by the State Department, the United States Agency for International Development, the United States Information Agency, the Foreign Agricultural Service of the United States Department of Agriculture and the Foreign Commercial Service of the Commerce Department.
''It's a very pleasant surprise,'' said Shao Wang, a computer industry analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. ''It follows by less than a month a relatively positive earnings report. I won't say that the tide is turning, but things are coming in the right direction.''
Wang Laboratories rose to prominence in the 1970's as a word processor and minicomputer manufacturer, but the company has not been able to make the transition to the personal computer industry because it was late in bringing compatible products to the market.
Wang shares rose $1.125 yesterday, to $4.50, on the American Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
USAir to Drop More Workers

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
USAir, which said last week that it would lay off 200 pilots, reported yesterday that it was cutting another 1,500 workers, or 2.7 percent of its work force, as it pares back expansion plans.
The nation's seventh-largest airline, based in Arlington, Va., said most of the 1,500 employees have been hired recently as part of an expansion program that is being rolled back. 
''We are going to terminate about 1,500 probationary employees,'' a USAir spokesman said. Union and nonunion workers, most of them on the payroll less than six months, will be affected.
''We deeply regret that this action is necessary, but these employees were hired in anticipation of an expansion program that has since been reduced in light of current economic projections,'' USAir's president, Seth Schofield, said in a statement.
Last week, USAir said it planned to furlough 211 pilots on Jan. 1. At the time, it also said it was looking for areas to make further cuts.
USAir now has about 55,000 employees. It has large hubs in Pittsburgh, Philadelphia and Charlotte, N.C.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of U.S. Securities Lower

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved lower in thin, volatile trading yesterday, as dealers used movements in oil prices as their major indicator to buy or sell securities.
A sharp run-up in oil prices early in the day sent out a clear sell signal, pushing bond prices down by more than a point. But oil later came down from its daily highs, and that helped erase most of the decline in bond prices.
Comments from Tariq Aziz, Iraq's Foreign Minister, calling for a negotiated settlement to the crisis in the Persian Gulf also helped buttress prices, even though Mr. Aziz did not offer to withdraw Iraqi troops from Kuwait and restore its monarchy. 
Traders said that the drop in stock prices had little influence on activity in the credit markets. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 52.48 points, to 2,603.96.
''We are not seeing the move into Treasury bills that a drop in stock prices caused in the past,'' one government bond trader said.
Even though price movements were very erratic, market participants attached little significance to the shifts because volume was so low.
''People don't want to get headlined,'' another bond trader said, referring to the strong chance that a wire service report about the latest development in the Middle East could send prices plunging or soaring.
 
Investors Seen Afraid
''That means the Street is afraid to take positions, and retail investors are afraid to buy the market.''
For the most part, traders did not react when late yesterday morning the Federal Reserve added reserves to the banking system at a time when the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market was trading at just under 8 percent, the level widely believed to be the Fed's target for the closely watched rate.
Under other circumstances, the Fed's move would probably have attracted more attention, since it occurred on a day when members of the central bank's policy-making Open Market Committee were meeting in Washington.
But analysts said that the move was more to clean up after the chaos caused by the Aug. 13 blackout in lower Manhattan than it was to ease policy.
''Normally, when they add reserves after an Open Market Committee meeting you might think they are easing policy,'' said David Wyss, chief financial economist at Data Resources Inc., the economic forecasting firm.
''But in this case, they are disentangling the system after the problems created a week ago Monday. As a result, I wouldn't read too much into this.''
The funds rate traded as low as 7 3/4 percent yesterday, and Mr. Wyss and others said that it would probably not move back to its target level until after the end of the two-week reserve reporting period for banks ends on Wednesday.
For all of their volatility, Treasury issues were little changed at the end of the session.
By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 98 1/32, down 2/32, to yield 8.93 percent, unchanged from late Monday.
Among note issues, the 8 3/4 percent 10-year notes were offered at 99 15/ 32, down 6/32, to yield 8.83 percent. And the 8 1/2 percent five-year notes were offered at 99 26/32, down 2/32, to yield 8.52 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates rose slightly.
In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.56 percent, up three basis points, or hundredths of a point. Six-month bill rates rose by four basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.46 percent.
 
'Junk Bond' Prices Fall
While the sharp drop in stock prices had little effect in the secondary market for Treasury securities, the selloff in equities rattled investors in the high-yield ''junk bond'' market. Market participants said that prices of most issues fell by 1 to 1 1/2 points, with some bonds falling by much more than that. Trading was very light, however.
Reaction to the day's developments in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds was more subdued. Traders said that prices of most actively quoted issues were unchanged on the day.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, market participants said that prices of most issues fell by 1/2 point to 5/8 point.
Among the new municipal issues priced yesterday was a negotiated sale of $185 million worth of general obligation bonds for the District of Columbia.
The issue, which is insured by Financial Security Assurance, consists of serial bonds with maturities from 1991 to 2001 and two term bonds.
Coupons on the serial bonds range from 6.20 percent in 1991 to 7.20 percent in 2001.
The 7.40 percent term bonds that mature June 1, 2005, were initially offered at a price to yield 7.497 percent. And the 7 1/2 percent bonds that mature June 1, 2010, were offered at a price to yield 7.585 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Closes Mixed In U.S. After Drop Abroad

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished mixed after falling overseas yesterday in a volatile session that saw the currency buffeted by conflicting reports about the prospects for stability in the Middle East.
Traders sold the dollar after a report that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq was willing to negotiate a peace settlement. But later reports that the Iraqis were mining Kuwaiti ports and refineries pushed the dollar higher. 
The dollar ''got whipsawed by these conflicting reports,'' said Marc Chandler, an analyst with MMS International in Chicago. ''The dollar put in its lows on the idea that there would be peace,'' he added, but when that seemed to fade, it was pushed back up.
But another round of bearish economic data put further pressure on the dollar, as the Government reported that the Federal budget deficit jumped $25.9 billion in July. That pushed the fiscal year's imbalance so far to $189.1 billion, compared with $123.7 billion at the end of July 1989.
The report induced traders to sell dollars because it appears the United States economy may be headed into a recession. Lower interest rates, which typically follow in an economic slowdown, would make dollar-denominated securities less appealing to foreign investors.
Still, investors are ''a little afraid to get a little too short of dollars,'' said Gilbert Cisneros, a trader at the Bank of Boston's New York office. ''If something does spark'' in the Middle East, he said, ''it's expensive to get the dollars back.''
Against the Japanese currency, the dollar rose in New York to 146.80 yen from 146.51. Earlier, the dollar fell in Tokyo to a closing 146.55 yen, from 147.47 yen late Monday, and in London, it fell to 146.35 yen.
Against the German currency, the dollar rose slightly, to 1.5645 marks from 1.5642.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.9215, from $1.9185 late Monday. In New York, it cost $1.9113 to buy one pound, less expensive than Monday's $1.9135.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday, included: 1.2900 Swiss francs, down from 1.2955; 5.2635 French francs, up from 5.2565; 1,161.75 Italian lire, up from 1,157.25, and 1.1399 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1427.

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
Building Plan In Detroit Starts Debate

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
COMERICA INC., one of Detroit's largest banks, has won approval for a controversial plan to tear down a riverfront auditorium that was donated by the Ford family to the city and put a new corporate headquarters on the site.
After a series of heated public debates, Detroit's City Council voted 6 to 3 last month to approve the plan by Comerica and the developer, Gerald Hines Interests Inc. of Houston, to buy the Ford Auditorium, demolish it and build a 28-story headquarters. The design, by the architect Cesar Pelli will be made public next month. Comerica will start razing the auditorium, now rarely used but once the home of the Detroit Symphony, this fall, and construction will begin next summer. 
The controversy centers not only on the location of the proposed 750,000-square-foot building but also on the economic incentives given by the city. Under an agreement with Mayor Coleman A. Young's office, the bank will be allowed to buy the site for $7.5 million, with payments delayed 28 years, and receive an $18 million, 28-year interest-free loan for construction.
Downtown Detroit has been the site of relatively little major office construction since the Renaissance Center was built in the late 1970's. The Comerica project comes just a few months after Gerald Hines began construction of a 50-story office building nearby, and many local real estate people fear a glut of offices in the downtown market.
Opponents, among them an array of business and civic leaders and some members of the Ford family, say the site next to Hart Plaza, a large public space with a huge fountain and an amphitheater, is inappropriate for a high-rise office structure. Woodward Avenue, Detroit's main commercial thoroughfare, leads into the plaza, making it the core of the city's riverfront. They also assert that the auditorium should not be torn down. It was built in 1956 to house the city's symphony orchestra and abandoned last year because of poor acoustics. The orchestra now performs in its original home, Orchestra Hall, which was refurbished in 1989.
Comerica's supporters say the project will be an important investment by the bank that will keep approximately 1,200 jobs downtown and put a new, world-class office building on the riverfront. The bank defends its plans, saying it could not find another site downtown appropriate for its headquarters that would attract investors to help build it.
Critics say Comerica blackmailed the city by hinting that it would move to the suburbs if the project was not approved. William Clay Ford, grandson of Henry Ford and the largest single shareholder of the Ford Motor Company, criticized the bank's proposal in a letter to the city and said his family would no longer make donations to the city as long as the Young administration was in office.
Mel Ravitz, one of three City Council members who voted against the proposal, is a party to a lawsuit to stop the project. He said he opposed the plan because the city would be selling an asset to a private company that had been donated for public use.
''This seems to be a violation of the public trust,'' Mr. Ravitz said. ''My primary concern now is that other developers will be looking to the city to bargain for other public lands.''
The controversy started in May when Comerica and the city announced the project. The bank said then that it had spent several months looking for a site because the lease in its current headquarters would expire in mid-1993.
''The Ford Auditorium site was the one that best guaranteed that we could attract the financing and tenants to make the building an economic success,'' said David Taylor, a Comerica spokesman.

HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
Japan Offering Billions to Arabs To Help Offset Gulf Crisis Losses

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Thursday, Aug. 23

 BODY:
Japan is offering what may amount to billions of dollars in financial aid as well as communications and transportation support to Middle East nations that would suffer by cutting off trade with Iraq and Kuwait, the Foreign Ministry has said.
Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama is on a tour of the Middle East that will take him to Saudi Arabia, Oman, Jordan, Egypt and Turkey.
Japan is still debating whether it should send personnel to the Persian Gulf to support the United Nations embargo against Iraq.
 
Unable to Send Personnel
Mr. Nakayama has not been able to offer the ''concrete measures'' of noncombat personnel that the Government has said Japan is contemplating. But Foreign Ministry officials said he has been receiving requests for other forms of aid and that the Government has moved closer to agreeing to them. But officials said that the aid plans have not been completed. 
These requests range from large amounts of financial support to more practical logistical aid, including desalinization equipment for Saudi Arabia to medical teams. Such aid would be a new step for Japan, which is constrained by its post-World War II Constitution from involvement in possible military conflicts.
The offer of aid is an exceptionally sensitive issue for the Japanese. The Government is eager to demonstrate that it is prepared to take a more active role in international affairs commensurate with its economic influence.
Mr. Nakayama has told the potential recipients that Japan could offer some inducement to help countries financially if they agreed to support the embargo against Iraq.
The results of the Japanese initiative have been mixed so far. President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, who has backed the embargo, reportedly told Mr. Nakayama on Wednesday that his country, already facing financial difficulties, might lose $2 billion a year or more from lower foreign exchange remittances by Egyptians working outside the country, a decline in fees from the Suez Canal and a reduction in tourism.
Turkey, which shut off an Iraqi pipeline through its territory to the Mediterranean, may suffer even greater losses and be even more eager for aid.
 
At Washington's Urging
But Jordan, which has been less willing to oppose its powerful neighbor, earlier this week rebuffed Japan's urgings that it take a strong stand on the embargo, according to Japanese press reports.
Japan's offer of money comes in part in response to American urgings. President Bush reportedly telephoned Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu last week and proposed that Tokyo provide such assistance.
In addition, he was said to have suggested that Japan help finance the international forces in the Persian Gulf, cover more of the annual costs of stationing American troops in Japan and that the Japanese Self-Defense Forces buy more American military equipment.
The Japanese Government has been playing down discussions of financial assistance out of fear that it would be seen as checkbook diplomacy - sending money when other countries, particularly the United States, are shouldering a heavier burden by risking lives in an effort to force Iraq out of Kuwait.
Japan has joined the trade embargo, cutting off nearly 12 percent of its regular oil supply. Also, 509 Japanese citizens are trapped in Iraq and Kuwait. But Japan is finding it far more difficult to arrive at a consensus on what other support it can offer.
Government officials have expressed some urgency in making it clear to the United States and other countries that Japan is willing to play a more prominent role in resolving the crisis - particularly since Japan is more reliant on Middle Eastern oil than any other industrialized nation.
Japan buys slightly more than 70 percent of its oil supplies from the Middle East.
On Friday, a Foreign Ministry spokesman, Taizo Watanabe, emphasized in a briefing here for foreign reporters, ''Please don't think we are only considering sending money.'' He added, without being specific, ''We are considering everything.''
But any discussion of military matters can elicit strong emotional reactions in Japan, particularly from opposition parties. To overcome this resistance, it has been reported that Mr. Kaifu has been contacting opposition leaders to seek their understanding for what would be the most active steps Japan has taken since World War II into a possible military situation.
Japanese newspapers have said that this included a possibility of sending teams of medical, transportation or communications specialists, and perhaps minesweepers as well.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 5; Financial Desk

HEADLINE: The Shaken Financial Markets

 BODY:
The world's financial markets have been reeling as fears mount of war in the Middle East and oil prices soar.
In the United States, the jolts come on top of fears of imminent recession, and the stock market tells the story clearly. With a 43.81-point drop yesterday, to 2,560.15, the Dow Jones industrial average has now lost almost 440 points, or nearly 15 percent, since its peak in mid-July. 
In the three weeks since Iraq invaded Kuwait, the Dow has lost 300 points, fully 10 percent of its value.
The stocks of smaller companies have been hit even harder, with over-the-counter issues off by more than 20 percent since mid-July.
The Tokyo stock market, a powerhouse in recent years, is taking the biggest beating after reaching a record high at the end of the year. As measured by the Nikkei index, prices have fallen by 39 percent this year, with a 4 percent drop yesterday and a sharp selloff of nearly 6 percent in in Tokyo today.
European stocks have also suffered. On Tuesday, the West German market lost 5.2 percent and the French 4 percent, both hitting lows for the year, as British stocks lost 2 percent. In Frankfurt and Paris, the indexes regained some ground yesterday, while the London market stabilized.
In the American credit markets, fears of oil-ignited inflation and higher budget deficits piled on top of war worries, sending long-term interest rates to their highest levels in nearly four months. The yield on the Treasury's closely watched 30-year bond now stands at 9.04 percent.
In foreign exchange markets, the invasion would normally have sent the dollar higher as investors sought a haven, but instead it continued to weaken.Just last week, the dollar slid to its lowest level against the mark since the German currency was created in 1948.

LENGTH: 1024 words

HEADLINE: PRICE OF OIL JUMPS BY 9% IN ONE DAY

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
The price of oil topped $31 a barrel yesterday, the highest price since November 1985, when the oil markets were still recovering from the Iranian revolution of five years earlier. The current Middle East crisis has raised prices to a level higher than they were when Iran and Iraq were trying to sink each others' tankers.
Many traders said yesterday's surge, close to 9 percent, came because market participants feared further war in the Middle East, eliminating even more production than the four million to five million barrels a day that Kuwait and Iraq once exported. Prices of refined petroleum products also continued to rise. 
 
A Case of War Jitters
''I think the market is getting more and more fearful that the shooting's going to start sometime soon,'' said Daniel Yergin, an energy analyst, ''and when that happens, it may be a lot more than four million barrels a day that doesn't get out of the gulf.''
Indeed, Saudi Arabia notified many customers yesterday that it would not be able to deliver large quantities of refined products because in the event of military action against Iraq the fuel would be needed for its own armed forces and the American forces in Saudi Arabia. The announcement came as the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries found itself deeply divided after a group led by Algeria, Libya and Iran blocked a renewed attempt by Saudi Arabia and Venezuela to convene an emergency meeting to try to stabilize oil prices. [Page D6.] A few oil traders said yesterday's price action was also influenced by the delay in the often-expressed plan of Saudi Arabia and Venezuela to increase production by a combined total of 2.5 million barrels a day.
The futures market, where producers, refiners, wholesalers and speculators come together and strike a price for oil to be delivered at a specified date that may be many months away, has a mixed record as a predicter and interpreter of events. Dozens of times in the past, sometimes more than once a day, prices surged on reports of the death of the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini in Iran. The market has reacted to snaps of cold weather, aberrations in inventory figures and announcements about OPEC in ways that bore little relationship to long-term meaning of the events. But its instinct at the moment is that it is better to buy at today's price than to risk having to buy at a higher price later.
The market's rise is likely to hit consumers harder in the next few weeks than they have been so far in the crisis. For example, gasoline has risen about 16 cents since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, but at the American Automobile Association, Jerry Cheske, a spokesman, predicted a rise of at least that much again in coming weeks.
Some experts, pointing to futures prices, say bigger retail increases are ahead. The price of unleaded regular gasoline for delivery next month surged 2.85 cents, to just over $1.04 a gallon yesterday. That plus the average tax of 25 cents a gallon exceeds the average pump price of $1.24 that prevailed at the beginning of this week. That leaves less than nothing for distributors and retailers, whose combined markup in normal times is about 20 cents. Thus, the futures price is pointing to a retail price of $1.50 a gallon.
At Mobil Oil, John Lord, a spokesman, said corporate policy forbade him to make price predictions. But he said the decreasing margin between the price on the New York Merc and the average retail price ''once again shows that there's been no rip-off of the American driving consumer.''
Refining analysts say that the loss of output from refineries in Kuwait, plus increased demand for refined products from nervous gasoline middlemen and users and from the armed forces in the Middle East have all contributed to the price run-up.
None of this assuages a popular mood of suspicion, however. Yesterday the New York City Consumer Affairs Commissioner, Mark Green, complained, ''This isn't a price hike but a price heist.''
Heating oil prices will also rise sharply, and the effect of higher prices will continue to ripple through the economy, experts said. In trading yesterday, the contract for September delivery of heating oil closed at 91.35 cents a gallon, up 7.64 cents.
In the crude market, the closing price for oil for October delivery on the New York Mercantile Exchange was $31.22, up $2.51. That was the highest since futures prices were at $31.72 on Nov. 20, 1985. Contracts for delivery in later months moved up yesterday by their allowable daily limit, $1. Under the exchange's rules, the limits will rise to $1.50 today. In 1985, when the Iran-Iraq tanker war began, the average cost to refiners was $26.75, but by 1986 a price war among producers had cut the figure to $14.55.
Much of yesterday's gain came late in the trading day, after Gen. Colin Powell, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said on television that the United States' goal in the Middle East extended beyond simply defending Saudi Arabia.
At Cargill Investor Services, Bradford H. Hughes, a futures broker, said that the message the market got from that remark was that ''Saddam Hussein can't be another little Hitler; he's going to have to be taken out early.''
Not everyone has war jitters. At Purvin & Gertz, a Houston-based consulting firm, Robert A. Hermes, the president, said the market was reacting to delays by Saudi Arabia and Venezuela in increasing their production. ''The market thinks the additional production just isn't coming on on schedule, and the clock keeps ticking away,'' he said.
Without news of new production, he said, he would not be surprised to see the price of crude oil go to $35 a barrel.
Some experts said the sharp rise in prices might induce the Bush Administration to rethink its position on the use of the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. The Administration has said it would tap the reserve only in the event of a shortage and not in response to price moves. Phil Kief, a spokesman for the Energy Department, said after the market closed yesterday that no re-evaluation was under way. ''We're not driven by price,'' he said. ''We're driven by supplies.''

PUB-DATE: August 23, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 14, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1074 words

HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
Saudis Plan to Supply U.S. With Fuel for Military Use

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22

 BODY:
Saudi Arabian oil officials moved today to suspend their nation's daily export of hundreds of thousands of barrels of jet and diesel fuel, diverting much of it to the American military as a down payment on reimbursement for United States aid in the Persian Gulf crisis, Saudi officials say.
The precise size of the Saudis' fuel contributions was not known today, but Ken Miller, an expert with OPEC Listener, a New York-based oil analysis concern, said the suspended exports could total 200,000 to 300,000 barrels a day, worth $5 million or more.
The fuel is probably the largest single Saudi compensation to date for the United States military effort, one American official said today, although the Saudis are expected to provide oil or cash to other nations assisting in its defense against Iraqi troops.
At the same time, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said the Pentagon would dip into its own inventories to supply the Saudis with additional jets and other weaponry quickly, and promised later to sell the Saudis the most advanced fighter jet in the United States Air Force fleet, the F-15E. 
 
A Close Relationship
The two actions dramatize the increasingly close relationship between Washington and Riyadh, a political and military alliance that American officials say has long been warm, but has been cloaked to meet the necessities of Middle East diplomacy and economics.
Now the threat of war has forced King Fahd openly to declare himself in league with President Bush and the Western world. Although the move could save the Saudi kingdom in the short run, it poses both great and small risks as the American presence in the Saudi desert increases.
''Over the long term, it creates some big problems for the Saudis,'' said Yahya Sadowski, a research associate and Middle East expert at the Brookings Institution in Washington. ''The American presence is a lightning rod. Already, every Islamic movement in the Middle East is now depicting the Saudi Arabians as American puppets, rich sheiks sitting on barrels of oil while the poor suffer.
''If the Saudis can get out of this quickly and peacefully, they can still say they invited the Americans in strictly for defense purposes, and they don't totally rupture the relationship with the Arab world,'' he said. But Mr. Sadowski said he now believes the chances of that are slim.
 
A Free-Fuel Policy
The move today to restrict fuel exports by the Government-owned Saudi Arabian Marketing and Refining Company, commonly called Samarec, formally takes effect on Sept. 1. As a practical matter, however, it extends a free-fuel policy toward the American military and other foreign forces that has existed since Aug. 8, when the first United States troops arrived in Saudi Arabia.
One American official who spoke on condition of anonymity said the Saudis also provided fuel to the United States Navy when it escorted oil tankers through the mined waters of the Persian Gulf in 1987 and 1988.
Because the troops and military hardware are already paid for, fuel is one of the larger incremental costs of the American operation in the Persian Gulf, and the Saudi contribution therefore is substantial, that official said. Riyadh is also expected to foot some other costs of the American military, like building quarters for troops that now live in tents, should the United States' stay in Saudi Arabia become lengthy.
But by far the most important Saudi assistance, American officials say, is King Fahd's pledge this month to make up much of the shortfall in world oil supplies that has been triggered by the United Nations embargo on trade with Iraq and on Kuwaiti oil.
 
Close to Nation's Capacity
The Saudis are widely believed to have pledged to increase their oil exports from their current level of 5.38 million barrels a day, a figure set by the OPEC cartel, to nearly 7.4 million barrels. That is close to the nation's production capacity, and more than the Saudis have produced for a sustained time since 1982.
King Fahd has sought OPEC approval for the increase, but it is opposed by cartel members like Libya, which cannot easily increase its own production, and so would benefit by selling its existing stock of oil at higher prices.
''An OPEC agreement would kind of legitimize their position, but if none of that works, I think they'll go it alone,'' Mr. Miller said. ''But it's quite a big decision for them - bigger in their eyes than ours, because they have to live with these people.''
The prospect of an additional two million barrels from Saudi Arabia, and more from other oil-producing nations, so far has helped keep the price of oil low enough to limit the threat of a worldwide economic recession.
 
Close Ties Increasing
While the huge United States force in the Persian Gulf cannot be hidden, American officials have taken pains to play down other aspects of the increasingly close ties to the Saudis.
The State Department said today that the American Embassy had added only a handful of officers to its embassy in Riyadh to assist during the gulf crisis. The Pentagon has also shied away from describing the politically touchy nature of its authority on Saudi territory, with Mr. Cheney saying today only that the Americans and the Saudis had made ''parallel arrangements'' to govern the actions of desert troops and pilots.
Similarly, the Bush Administration declined to discuss Saudi payment for American military aid today. An official said only that ''in previous times when the Saudis have asked for our assistance we have worked out means of compensation, and we expect that will happen this time as well.''
The Saudi willingness to risk OPEC disapproval and the scorn of some Arab neighbors, American officials and observers like Mr. Sadowski say, underscores both the seriousness of their plight and the increasing depth of their ties to the United States.
Saudi kings have quietly supported American causes for decades, giving billions of dollars to secret American-backed wars in places like Afghanistan and Nicaragua, and providing cash support for United States diplomacy in nether regions like Somalia. In return, they have won the right to buy advanced Pentagon weapons and the White House's promise of on-the-scene aid in a genuine crisis.
American military advisers have been in Saudi Arabia almost constantly since 1949, training the nation's military elite and helping maintain planes and weapons systems.
