PUB-DATE: August 23, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 16, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 5951 words

HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
Transcript of News Session by Bush and 2 Officials on Mideast

 BODY:
Following is the transcript of the news conference by President Bush, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin L. Powell yesterday in Kennebunkport, Me., as recorded by The New York Times:
 
OPENING STATEMENT
PRESIDENT BUSH: First, Secretary Cheney and General Powell have just given me a very full and, I would say, encouraging briefing on the status of our deployment to the Persian Gulf. This has been a very complicated mission, calling for precision, calling for maximum coordination with Saudi Arabia and the other nations providing forces.
The process is going smoothly. And we've now moved what amounts to a medium-size American city completely capable of defending itself all the way over to the Middle East. And the Secretary reports that the men and women in the armed forces have performed with extraordinary ability. Their morale is high, and they've accepted the challenge of their mission with extraordinary dedication to duty. And I'm very proud of each and every single one of them. 
Now I want them to know that the American people are behind them 100 percent, supporting them strongly. And it's also crucial that everyone understand we are not in this alone. We stand shoulder to shoulder right there in the Middle East with the armed forces of 22 other nations from the Middle East, from Europe and around the world.
Secretary Dick Cheney reports an impressive alliance of multinational forces that stands behind the United Nations' resolve that Iraq completely and unconditionally withdraw from Kuwait, with the restoration of the legitimate government in that country. The United Nations has provided enormous leadership to the whole world community in pursuing this objective and voting the sanctions necessary to carrying it out.
And let's be clear as the deployment of the forces of the many nations shows and that the votes in the United Nations show, this is not a matter between Iraq and the United States of America. It is between Iraq and the entire world community, Arab and non-Arab alike, all the nations of the world lined up to oppose aggression.
And as our forces continue to arrive, they can look forward to the support of the finest reserve components in the world. We are activating those special categories of reservists that are essential to completing our mission.
The United States considers its reserve forces to be an integral part of the total military command. These essential personnel will soon be joining the cohesive organization required to support the military operation in and around the Arabian Peninsula. And I have the highest confidence in their ability to augment the active forces in this operation.
 
Pledge Not to Waver
We continue to pursue our objective with absolute determination. And I might add that I talked to the four leaders of Congress today, and I am very pleased that they are giving us the strong support they have been, the Speaker, Senator Mitchell, Senator Dole, Congressman Michel.
And the world simply cannot waver in its opposition to the threat that Iraq has placed on the doorstep of all nations who cherish freedom and the rule of law.
Now what I plan to do is take some questions, and then I know you'll have more questions for Secretary Cheney and General Powell. And then the discussions that we've had with these two gentlemen and Secretary Eagleberger, General Scowcroft, the Chief of Staff, Bob Gates, will continue for a little while this afternoon before they return to Washington.
So, Dick, I am very grateful to you for your mission, successful mission, and, both to you and Colin, my sincere thanks for the superb leadership you are giving the United States military, the superb leadership you are showing in working with other countries as we pursue these moral, high moral, objectives.
 
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
 
Cooperation With Soviets
Q. Mr. President, the Soviets had voted with us in the Security Council for the economic sanctions, but we learned today that they have 193 military advisers still advising the Iraqi army on how to use Soviet-built weapons against the allied forces. Do you call upon them to pull those people out?
A. Well, I think that frankly I'd like to see Iraq do what is civilized and permit foreigners who want to leave, leave. But I'm not going to comment on that because I don't have this information that you're telling me about. Maybe Dick Cheney can comment on it later.
Q. Can I just follow, sir? You've talked to at least a dozen world leaders right from here in the past week and a half. Have you called Secretary, President Gorbachev? And will you call President Gorbachev for his help in the crisis?
A. Secretary Baker talked to Foreign Minister Shevardnadze less than two hours ago, and we are in close touch with the Soviets. At this point, I can say we are getting superb cooperation from the Soviets. There may be some differences. In fact, I think it's fair to say we've been discussing some of them regarding the timing of certain further U.N. action. But I have no argument with the way in which they have cooperated, and I would expect that Secretary Cheney would agree on that point.
 
U.S. Interception of Ships
Q. Could I follow up to that, sir, talking about the action that you would hope to have? The U.S. forces fired across the bow of a ship that then was allowed to continue on and is now in Yemen. Why did they not pursue that further? Do you want to wait until you now have that U.N. authority?
A. Well, you know we feel we have all the authority we need. And the world leaders I've talked to, particularly Francois Mitterrand and Margaret Thatcher, agree that we have all the authority we need. We have been trying, and I think prudently so, to work with other countries around the world. And the more unanimity we get out of the United Nations, for example, the better.
So we're prepared to intercept shipping, but where I stand now is I'm talking to my top advisers here and been on the phone to Secretary Baker a couple of times in the last two hours talking about should the United Nations, should we give the United Nations more time to take more productive action.
And it has taken productive action, obviously. The Chapter 7 was a significant step. So, I think we've made clear to the shipping that they can be stopped and that we have the forces to stop them right now. And I believe that General Powell would back me up on what I've just said. So my question is, how much more United Nations action is required?
And so I'm going to continue the discussion, asking for the advice of my officials here, but at this juncture I'm not prepared to say whether we're going to insist on U.N. action before we go further. But I think the record, the signal, must go out to the world that many countries are prepared to fully enforce these sanctions, and if there's some U.N. action that will help, so much the better.
Q. How long will you wait for that U.N. action?
A. We haven't made a determination. I think the signal is out there as we pursue certain vessels and clearly have superior, have the demonstrated ability to board these vessels that we can do it. So now the question is, how much more U.N. action is, benefits this idea of the world staying more closely together? And I might be prepared to give a little time - speaking just for the U.S. - we're only one country there, important one though it may be - in order to get more collective action.
But, on the other hand, I need more advice in terms of the logistics, where the ships are, what the signal would be if we go ahead and take action to stop them, which we could confidently do.
 
Likelihood of Closing Embassy
Q. Mr. President, despite demands from the Iraqis that the U.S. and other countries close their embassies in Kuwait and remove all their diplomatic personnel, the State Department announced today that the U.S. would not do that. Why have you decided to take that course of action? And how can you possibly enforce that?
A. Because the occupation of Kuwait is illegal under international law and other countries agree totally that we must not take the position that this illegal regime can shut down legitimate embassies as a result of their aggression, that's why.
Q. But with Iraq in military control of Kuwait, how can you possibly hope to enforce that?
A. Well, my view is let's wait and see what happens. I don't go into these hypothetical questions. I'd like to explain this because I know there's a lot of them out there, as to what I might not or might do under certain circumstances. But here I think most countries that I'm aware of, and I defer to Secretary Eagleburger, would agree that they will not go along with the, with agreeing to this kind of affirmation of Iraq aggression, aggression that has been thoroughly condemned by the United Nations.
 
Policy on American Hostages
Q. I'd like to ask please about your hostage policy. You were very firm the other day in warning Saddam not to harm the Americans, but I wonder --
A. Consider what?
Q. -- has been provoked? Has the United States been provoked now?
A. I don't think it's a question of the United States. I think it's a question of the whole world is being provoked by this illegal action, outrageous action.
Q. Do you have a plan for getting --
A. I don't discuss hypothetical contingencies. But I would reiterate, it is a grave concern to all the countries whose leaders I've talked to.
Q. Will the United States give safe haven to our citizens in Kuwait and Iraq if, in the embassies --
A. If citizens came to the embassy seeking support and help, clearly we would do that.
Q. Mr. President, do you have plans to --
A. Let me just work right down the line here, if that's agreeable.
Q. Do have plans to draw down the number of Americans in our embassy in Kuwait?
A. I'd like to defer that question to Secretary Eagleberger when I continue this. There has been talk of it. Indeed, I think we're talking about taking down some personnel, but I'd like to ask him to be a little more definitive.
Q. Mr. President, how constrained do you feel by the Americans trapped in Kuwait as you make your decisions by the plight of the Americans?
A. I think any decision maker in the United States or in any of these countries is concerned about the lives of innocent civilians, innocent people. And so you weigh that very thoroughly against your actions. Having said that, international law in this case, the Chapter 7 sanctions, must be enforced.
 
Call to Conserve Resources
Q. Mr. President, you said last Wednesday at the Pentagon that part of what we're fighting for, standing for, in the desert is our way of life. Part of our way of life is heavy uses of energy, much more so than any other industrialized country. We haven't really heard you call upon Americans to conserve as part of this crisis.
A. I call upon Americans to conserve.
Q. Will you elaborate?
A. No. I think we ought to conserve in times like this. On the other hand, we are doing everything we can to guarantee that we don't panic Americans and that there will be an adequate supply of hydrocarbons. But I think it is a good time to conserve, so I'm glad you reminded me of that and I would call upon Americans to conserve.
And I think that doesn't mean that life screeches to a halt, and, therefore, I would say that. But I also think we're going to be able to guarantee an adequate supply of petroleum.
Q. How many reserves are going to be called up as a first step?
A. I will defer that question to Secretary Cheney.
Q. Do you sense any frustration or even desperation in the recent statements we've been hearing out of Iraq?
A. I certainly sense a sense of isolation. I sense, I think, the urgency in these statements and the high immoderate tone is due to worldwide isolation. And I think that's very clear, and I think he's trying to whip up support and make his Iraq versus the United States. Indeed it is Iraq versus the rest of the world. And I talked to leader after leader, talked at length to Helmut Kohl today, and he's been making just that point and will continue to make that point.
But yes, I think there is some of that feeling that as they become isolated from their Arab brothers - and they are - and as they become isolated from traditional trading partners - and they are - there is a sense of irrational urgency there.
Q. How seriously do you take his public threats?
A. The United States won't be threatened.
Q. Mr. President, the other day you called on Americans for personal sacrifice, but you didn't really elaborate. Are you talking about economic deprivation or were you --
A. No, I was not particularly talking about economic deprivation. I'm thinking of families whose plans have been severely altered by this. I'm thinking of more of that kind of thing when I made the statement.
 
Role of King Hussein
Q. Are you preparing Americans for the possibility of war and American deaths?
A. I think any time you move American forces and any time you are up against what most of the world now considers to be an outrageous violator of international law, the best thing is to be prepared.
Q. King Hussein today in Jordan suggested that perhaps you moved too percipitously, in his words that if there had not been this buildup that we might not be in the situation we're in and that Saddam Hussein might have withdrawn. Were there ever any signals, anything that would suggest that that might have been the case?
A. No, and the King, regrettably, did not have much support in the Arab world for that position. You recall the vote at the Arab summit. He certainly had no support for that position in the United Nations and as the United Nations moved towards Chapter 7. And I would simply remind people who hear that allegation that it isn't just the United States, it's the rest of the world.
But when we are invited by a friend to help defend it against aggression that has recently taken place and that it threatens to take place again, we're going to respond. And that's a good signal to send to friends around the world.
And I might say the request for support was not taken without reason. The Saudis were very much concerned, and let me just recite the history for the American people here.
He had said, Saddam Hussein had said, we're withdrawing. I believe it was on a Sunday. And they had a picture of one truck, people frantically waving goodbye to the beloved brothers in Kuwait as they went north. And at the same time, there was truckload after truckload of armor and mechanized equipment moving south.
Now we're not dumb when we see that. Nor are the Saudis. Nor are the other countries that are rejoicing, as Dick Cheney will tell you, in the fact that we moved. But I think it's important to keep reminding people of why the Saudis felt threatened and probably today still feel threatened.
 
Equipment for the Saudis
Q. Another sense of the enormity of this buildup, the reports have come during the Secretary's visit that the Saudis wanted -preparing to send them the most advanced fighters, the F-15E's. Is that, in fact, the case? And isn't there a political problem with that?
A. I will let Secretary Cheney address it himself to it. But the Saudis have been threatened. A neighboring country has been aggressed against. International law has condemned it. We should do all we can to help the Saudis arm themselves against aggression, and so he can talk 15E's or some other weapon system. I want to do everything I can, and I hope there would be no political problem because the world clearly sees that the Saudis have been strongly threatened, Charles.
Q. Prince Bandar is on his way into Moscow. King Hussein says he's going back to Baghdad. Is there a new stage of diplomacy that's beginning now?
A. There's a lot of activity, Ann, going on, a lot of diplomatic activity. I am continuing to conduct a good deal of it. Secretary Baker is. I mentioned his recent call with Shevardnadze. Other countries are reaching out to friends, trying to be sure that we all stay together on this. And indeed the Japanese, I might say, have a very big diplomatic initiative going now, and I must say once again that I think Prime Minister's Kaifu's willingness to help some of these countries that might be victimized by full enactment of the sanctions is very good. The Turks, as I've told you, have been heavily involved. I talked to Mr. Mitsotakis in Greece today, who's been cooperative. So there's an awful lot of diplomatic activity behind the scenes.
Q. And is it helping that King Hussein's going back to Baghdad?
A. I have no feelings about, I, no, there was no message or anything of that nature. As you remember there was a lot of speculation that the King was coming here bearing a message, and I can tell you unequivocally there was no request on my part for a message to go back other than one: our determination to stay joined up with others to see that this aggression is reversed and that the rightful rulers of Kuwait are returned.
 
Media Coverage in Saudi Arabia
Q. Mr. President, you mentioned return for the families here in the United States a few minutes ago. Traditionally, those families have been able to rely on open press coverage of young men and women who are sent into the breach, such as they've been now. Despite their earlier hospitality, the Saudis are now restricting press coverage and are saying that they will probably order foreign press out of the country, perhaps by the end of this week. Is there anything you can do to assure that Americans will have free, complete and open press coverage of their young men and women abroad?
A. We are the guests of Saudi Arabia in their country. I think Dick addressed himself to that question, because it has been discussed, and the more coverage the better as far as we're concerned. However, when people travel to countries like Iraq and countries of that nature, I hope the press coverage will be totally objective, just as it right here in this marvelous setting.
Q. Are you saying that we're at the total mercy of Saudi Arabia? That there's nothing we can do to insure -- A. No, I'm not saying that. I'm saying I'll let the Secretary address himself to this question. And I'm saying I hope the same tough questions are asked in every country as they are in this county. And I'm speaking of Iraq particularly.
 
Iraqi Use of Jordan's Port
Q. Is that criticism of press coverage, Mr. President?
A. Well, that's no criticism, Jim. I've learned long ago that you've got the loudest mike, and I just am standing here. So I'm not criticizing. Don't be so sensitive about it. American people know what the American people see. And so all I'm simply saying is, don't be sensitive. It's not a criticism; it is an objective statement. Yeah.
Q. Mr. President, why is Iraq still being allowed to receive supplies through Jordan?
A. I'm not sure they are. And I hope they're not. And very little is going into the Gulf of Aqaba these days. And so it is a question though, that if it is going in, it clearly violates not only the sanctions but what King Hussein told me.
Q. Mr. President, is it your understanding that it's been stopped? I mean, many of our colleagues at the border say -- A. Yeah, there's a difference of view on it, and I'm not sure I know the total facts on that, because we were discussing it a few minutes ago.
 
Possibility of Using Force
Q. Mr. President, when you made the announcement that you were sending U.S. troops to Saudi Arabia, you said their mission was not to kick the Iraqis out of Kuwait. Do you still rule out the use of U.S. military force to evict -- A. I don't rule in or rule out the use of military force. And I learned long ago not to tie one's self down by stating what I will or will not do in that regard.
These two last, and then I'll go peacefully, Marlin. One and two.
Q. Mr. President, we asked you last week if you saw any hope of a diplomatic solution. You said, ''I don't see it right now.'' Do these statements from Baghdad that they are willing to put their cards on the table increase the hopes there will be a diplomatic solution?
A. If they're willing to put all their cards on the table, that's good. I didn't hear that, but if they're willing to put them all out there, including complying with international law, that would be good. And in terms of readiness to talk, we've got a very able person there in Baghdad who is prepared to talk, and they came in the other day and said they'd like to talk. Well, here he is available to talk.
But please don't tell us that they're going to talk with conditions that are unacceptable under international law, because that is not, that's not the way it would work. The world community has made a strong statement, a very strong statement, and I don't sense any view in the world community that it is going to back away from that statement. And that statement included removal of Iraqi forces from Kuwait and the restoration of the rulers.
Yeah, Charles, last one.
 
Vacations and Prudence
Q. Mr. President, somebody's got to ask the tough question. You talked about conservation. Does that include Fidelity?
A. I'm going to keep using my boat. And I hope the rest of America will prudently recreate. I don't think we've reached the point where I want to call on everybody in the recreation industry to shut it down or everybody that's taking a vacation in America to shut it down.
It's not a tough question; it's a very fair question. And I would simply say that there's a lot of industry, a lot of people that have been looking forward to vacations in this country, and I would not suggest that the situation at home requires they stay at home now, or that they don't use their recreational facilities. Yeah? Q. We're not in any energy -- A. No, not now. We are not.
Q. In what condition are those 54 missing Americans? Have you been told? And is the number still 54?
A. I can't answer the question about the condition. And I, maybe Larry can expand on this later on. He says we don't know.
Thank you all very much. And now I will turn it over again with a vote of thanks to Dick Cheney and to Colin, who are doing a superb job and to both of whom the American people owe a strong vote of thanks, and people around the world, too. CHENEY. Thank you sir. A. All yours.
 
Saudis and F-15 Fighters
CHENEY: We'd be happy to entertain a question.
Q. Would you answer the F-15E question? What are the Saudis going to get? CHENEY: The instructions of the President have been asked to sort of do three things, defense. One is to deploy forces to deter aggression; secondly, be prepared to defend if deterrent should fail, and third is to look at how we can best enhance the indigenous defense capabilities of the forces in the region so that they can do more in the future for themselves. Part of that is to see that we deal with their emergency requirements, given the crisis they're now faced with and the large number of Iraqi forces on their border.
There has been a report that we plan to provide F-15E aircraft - for the uninitiated, that's the latest model of the F-15. It's basically, it's got both air-to-air and air-to-ground capability long range. We have not yet completed the buy for our own forces on the F-15E. So what's currently coming off the line will come to U.S. forces. What we have talked with the Saudis about is really a two-stage process. Stage one would be meeting their emergency requirements. Stage two would be a more comprehensive plan that dealt with the long term.
In terms of emergency requirements, we are looking at transferring to the Saudis from our own forces, our own inventory, a number of existing F-15's. They would not be the E model; they would be the C or D model basically designed for air-to-air combat, although they have some ground-attack capability as well.
The report that we're going to provide F-15E's immediately simply is invalid. That's the kind of thing we'd work in the longer-term package.
Q. Do they even need them? And don't you run into a problem with the Israelis if you give them?
CHENEY: Well, I think first of all that the situation in the Middle East and in the gulf region has changed dramatically. And the argument over the years has been that we wanted to help our friends in the region, including the Saudis, satisfy their legitimate security requirements. I would argue that a million-man Iraqi army, 160,000 to 200,000 Iraqi soldiers, a thousand Iraqi tanks poised on the northern border of Saudi Arabia is a legitimate security need. And that in light of that, it is appropriate for us to work with the Saudis within the confines of existing authority that the President has to see to it that we help meet their most urgent requirements, and then we will also work long term.
But I don't think this is a situation that presents any threat whatsoever to Israel, and I would not expect there to be any opposition in the quarter to our efforts to help the Saudis and our other friends in the region deal with what is a threat to their very existence.
 
Calling Up the Reserves
Q. Mr. Cheney, the order the President signed on the reserves was open-ended: it vests you with the authority to call them up. We're told that there'll be 40,000 called up by the end of August. Is that correct, and how many more will there be after that?
CHENEY: Well, the services are looking at, and working right now preparing their proposals. I've, working with the chairmen, asked them to scrub those proposals, and they'll be presented to me in detail tomorrow in a briefing scheduled at the Pentagon on a service-by-service basis by the service chiefs and the service secretaries. I expect that we will not use the full 200,000 authority that's in the statute that the President's authorized to call up. It will be considerably short of that, but it is important for us to move forward because many of these key requirements in special areas have for years been built into the reserves. We've always assumed the reserves would perform those missions, and we need to have those missions performed now in light of the deployment to the Middle East. Q. Is 40,000 the right ball park figure? CHENEY: I wouldn't want to put a figure on it at this point because I haven't reviewed the plans in detail. I would expect that the number will obviously increase the longer period of time goes by. But, again, I think the ultimate call-up will be significantly below the 200,000 that's there. And as soon as we've got some specific plans approved and we know which units are involved and we know how many people will be asked to come back for service, we'll be happy to make that public. It's just that we have not yet finalized the plans, and I'm reluctant to speculate on what the exact number is until I've personally reviewed and approved those plans.
Q. Mr. Secretary, on the F-15C's and D's, you said 'transfer.' Do you mean we're going to give those jets to the Saudis?
CHENEY: The Saudis would pay for them. But the point is, we take them out of existing inventories, not future procurement.
Q. But they will remain in Saudi Arabia once this operation is finished?
CHENEY: That's correct.
 
Limits on Flow of Information
Q. And on the press question, the President asked me to refer this question to you. CHENEY: I noticed that. Q. Will the American people be able to rely on free, open and complete press coverage of their American men and women deployed overseas, or are we going to be restricted?
CHENEY: Well, I suppose you get into a debate here over definition of terms and what you mean by free and unrestricted might be different than what the Saudis think is free and unrestricted. The fact of the matter is we are in their country at their request. They've asked us to come help defend their nation, as have many other countries.
They are a very traditional society. They've got certain standards and norms, certain ways of doing business. They're very private in their personal lives, and I think we have to respect their culture, just as they respect ours.
By the same token, I think it is important that we have an adequate flow of information to the American people about what our young men and women are doing in Saudi Arabia, and I'm hoping that we'll be able to arrange that.
I do not have the final authority over what kind of access the government of Saudi Arabia grants to our press. We have to date, I think, been able, working under difficult circumstances, to provide pretty good coverage. I think the pool system at the Pentagon worked to initiate that process. I know having been there the last few days myself that there are a lot of stories being filed out of Saudi Arabia. I think we'll work with the Government of Saudi Arabia to provide as much access as we can.
In the final analysis, they'll make the decision, but obviously we will be advocates for the concept that there should be significant coverage of U.S. forces in Saudi Arabia available to the American people.
Q. You can understand the American people - if the Saudis asked us to come over there and help - and have the U.S. help protect them, and we're expending our blood, sweat and tears, that the American people would think that we should have open access to what is going on.
CHENEY: I'm, there may be a little bit of a difference, Jim, between what the American people think qualifies as open access and what the press thinks qualifies as open access. I don't want to get into that kind of debate, but the fact is that - I'll come back again to the proposition - we think that a good, steady flow of information about U.S. forces operations over there is an important part of the existing arrangement. We also think that we have to recognize and honor the request and the desires of the Saudi Government. And we'll do the best we can.
This affects not only the press. I mean there are other areas where our presence there forces, if you will, debate over different ways our two societies do business. Women play a very prominent role in our society; they play a very prominent role in our military. In Saudi society, a very different role. And having the two societies come together raises questions that have to be addressed, and we've done that successfully in a number of areas, and I'm confident we can do it with respect to the press as well.
 
Standard Chain of Command
Q. -- control or command of the American forces over there, would that also be the Saudis?
CHENEY: No. The way the process works is that under our constitutional principles the chain of command runs from the President to myself to General Powell to General Schwartzkopf is our sync in the area. And that constitutional principle is honored in our current arrangements.
It's also true though that we work very closely with the Saudis and that we coordinate very closely with them in terms of overall strategic guidance. We have parallel arrangements worked out between our forces and Saudi forces that our people on the ground have arrived at, and it seems to be working very smoothly. And this is not unusual. We do this in nations all over the world.
Q. On that point the President said there are armed forces from 22 countries involved in this operation. Has the issue been resolved in terms of command of this multinational force, particularly if combat were to occur?
CHENEY: I don't really have anything to add to what I've already offered: that is, to say that the Saudis obviously are the host for the operation. They've asked the rest of us to participate. And I'm confident that we will have adequate command arrangements to deal with whatever situation might arise.
Q. -- command at some point or are we going to have to waste a lot of time with units negotiated back and forth over who moves where.
CHENEY: We've not wasted a lot time now. We've moved very rapidly and very aggressively, and I'm satisfied with the current arrangements that we can do whatever we're called upon to do.
 
Reports of Missile Buildup
Q. General Powell, can you tell us anything about reports that there's a large buildup of missiles - SCUD missiles and the like -along the border of Saudi Arabia?
POWELL. I've seen those reports but I can't verify them or confirm that those large buildups are taking place.
Q. We well have, I would suspect, adequate intelligence to tell us that.
POWELL. I have adequate intelligence, and I think we have an extremely good picture of what the situation looks like on the ground north of the Kuwaiti-Saudi border, and without telling you how good that picture is, let me just say that I cannot confirm the reports you refer to.
Q. General, the President said we have sent a medium-size American city over there. The Pentagon talked about forces the size of Jefferson City. Without looking in our atlases, how many people do we have over there now?
POWELL. About the size of a medium-size American city. I'm not going to give the exact number of troops who are in-country. I think I will just rest on what we have been saying: that it's an adequate force that's being moved over there to accomplish the mission given to us by the President. And it has been a very impressive performance on the part of all the branches of the armed services for them to have delivered this force some 8,000 miles to the Saudi desert over a period of two weeks.
 
Size of American Buildup
Q. Are we no longer undermanned by the 160,000 or so Iraqis in Kuwait?
POWELL. I'm not trying to match them man for man.
Q. Are you satisfied, then, that the current force is sufficient to handle any contingency?
POWELL. Any contingency is a very broad statement, Jim, not - let me just say that the mission given to us was to deter initially and then be prepared to defend. And with each passing day I'm more and more confident of our ability to accomplish that mission.
Q. -- shadowing some of the tankers and freighters in the area under orders not just shadow and no longer fire across the bow?
POWELL. They are performing a mission given to them by the President, which was to perform those monitoring functions you described and we're just, we're tracking.
Q. General, how would you characterize the Iraqi deployment now? Offensive? Defensive?
POWELL. It's ambiguous, frankly. As the Secretary pointed out, there are 160,000 or more Iraqi soldiers north of the Saudi-Kuwait border. There's a large number of tanks. There are artillery formations there. There is some buildup. And when you see that kind of a force, you have to give it the capability of either defending or attacking.
And so I'm not prepared to say which one they are going to do. I always assume the worst in our planning. But I really can't ascribe an intent to Mr. Saddam Hussein, but it is a very capable force that does have the capability to go on the offense.
Q. Presumably ours has the same dual capability? POWELL. Excuse me. Q. What happens now?
POWELL. Half of the service secretaries and service chiefs brief Secretary of Defense tomorrow morning and get approval of their plans. Then the callups will begin. Selected units will be called up as they are needed and when they are needed. So you will not see a sudden rush, but individual units will be called up and told at what time to report to their mobilization station and whether or not they are going overseas or whether they will be used just to backfill for units who have left the United States.
Q. General, what about the mission? Are we clearly offensive now?
POWELL. Our mission there is to defend.

HEADLINE: Washington at Work;
Religion and Politics Become Fused In Congressman's District, and Heart

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22

 BODY:
Boston is one of those places where religion and politics sometimes merge to the point of being indistinguishable. Such was the case during one of Representative Joe Moakley's visits to the streets of the South Boston district that has been his base since he entered politics 37 years ago.
''Don't let those guys murder the priests and get away with it!'' one constituent shouted. ''Get those Jesuit killers!'' cried another. The reference was to Mr. Moakley's investigation into the killings of six Roman Catholic priests in El Salvador last November.
''It made me feel good,'' remembered Mr. Moakley, chairman of the House Rules Committee and a proud product of old-fashioned Democratic machine politics. ''It used to be there wasn't half a vote in the El Salvador issue. Then they killed the Jesuits.'' 
 
His Personal Crusade
The slayings are a personal crusade for Mr. Moakley. After criticizing the Bush Administration as not pushing the case, he turned up evidence strongly suggesting that top officers in the Salvadoran Army covered up the crime, and may even have ordered it. The Congressman then pushed through the House an amendment cutting United States military assistance to El Salvador in half. The Senate will take up the matter soon after the August recess.
In 10 years of Congressional protests to the policy of supporting the Salvadoran Government, no member has come closer to cutting aid to the country, which has received more than $4 billion in military and economic assistance over the last decade. To contain the damage, the Administration is scurrying to negotiate with Mr. Moakley, privately promising to accept cuts of 30 percent and to cooperate with his investigation.
Mr. Moakley's success is all the more remarkable because it is the work of a lawmaker who has never before taken a leadership role on any major foreign policy issue. Mr. Moakley's prior concentrations have been on issues like health care and labor causes.
Conservatives are not happy. Worried that Mr. Moakley's efforts could give a lift to the struggling guerrillas of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, they express concern that Mr. Moakley is letting his strongly felt Roman Catholicism get in the way of a sensible anti-Communist policy. Similar criticism was directed at former House Speaker Thomas P. (Tip) O'Neill, Mr. Moakley's close friend and golf partner, who said he took advice on policy toward El Salvador and Nicaragua from Maryknoll nuns who had worked in the region. A 'Sentimental' Approach? ''I think Joe, as Tip, is a good man who is somewhat sentimental in his approach to the clergy,'' said Representative Henry J. Hyde, Republican of Illinois.
Mr. Hyde commended Mr. Moakley for honesty and statesmanship but criticized him for embracing ''liberation theology,'' a leftist doctrine that says the church should side with the poor, which Mr. Hyde believes fails ''to draw the line at Marxist interpretation.''
Mr. Hyde added: ''The church has a myopic view of El Salvador. Ever since the murder of Archbishop Romero, they have not been friendly to the elected governments down there.''
Mr. Moakley does not disagree that religion drives his politics. He has long opposed abortion. In his office hangs a portrait of Archbishop Oscar Arnulfo Romero, who was assassinated in 1980 in the San Salvador cathedral.
''When I was a kid growing up in parochial school,'' Mr. Moakley said, ''the current wisdom was: Hey, you're poor because God made you poor, and God loves poor people, and the poor shall inherit the Earth. That's no longer true.
''Today, they teach you you're only poor because you've got to pull yourself up by your bootstraps, you've got to educate yourself, you've got to unionize to get better wages, all the money shouldn't be in the hands of the few. I don't see anything wrong with that, to be honest with you.''
 
Stayed Close to Home
''I am a product of my environment,'' he said, as he toyed with a gold baseball ring given to him by the former Boston Red Sox star Carl Yastrzemski. ''I live in the same ward that I was born in 63 years ago. I grew up in South Boston politics, where the politician was the guy who put turkey on the table at Christmas if the husband was not working.''
His father was a truck driver. His two brothers became police officers. As a youth, Mr. Moakley dreamed of becoming a longshoreman, but while a sailor in the Navy during World War II he decided he needed a college education. He attended the University of Miami but did not graduate because ''I got sick of it.''
He returned to South Boston to become a state insurance auditor. He got sick of that, too, went into local politics and earned a law degree at night. He says his wife, Evelyn, the daughter of a Cambridge city public workers laborer, ''is just a housewife,'' adding, ''She tells me what we are going to eat and where we are going to go.'' He has few hobbies, aside from the statehouse politics he lives and breathes.
For 17 years, Mr. Moakley worked in the shadow of party leaders. He shied from publicity, and even refused to hire a press spokesman for his first 12 years in the House. ''There probably aren't many bills with my name on it,'' he acknowledged.
 
Affected by Suffering
Mr. Moakley first discovered the El Salvador issue in 1983, when during a meeting with constituents a group of Salvadoran refugees talked about the suffering in their country. ''They told me that some 50,000 to 60,000 noncombatants had been killed, how children were blown up by stepping on mines,'' he said. ''I just couldn't believe this was going on and this country had anything to do with it.''
He began working to allow Central American refugees to remain in the United States, and during Congressional hearings on the issue met two of the Jesuits who would later be slain, Dr. Ignacio Ellacuria and Dr. Segundo Montes. He concluded that the Reagan Administration had based its policies in Central America on all the wrong premises. ''The Salvadoran Army,'' he said, ''is only in place to save the country from their own people.''
Others had taken the lead in opposing United States policy toward El Salvador, but that all changed last November, when the guerrillas launched a large offensive. In response, a death squad invaded a college campus and executed the priests, their housekeeper and her daughter with high-powered rifles.
''I felt terrible,'' Mr. Moakley said. ''I figured here's a guy whose going right to hell, whoever did this thing. How can anybody in their right mind attack people representing God and do that to them?''
 
'Not Looking for Headlines'
Speaker Thomas S. Foley of Washington called Mr. Moakley to ask him to head a committee to investigate the killings. Mr. Moakley demurred. ''Why me?'' he recalled saying to Mr. Foley. ''If you put out an application list, you'd have 434 names on it, but not mine. He said, 'I know, that's why I chose you.' He knew I was not looking for headlines.''
John Sasso, manager of the 1988 Presidential campaign of Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, put it another way: ''The reason why Joe Moakley is so effective is because his efforts are not coming from the left but from Mr. Lunch Bucket Democrat. When his blue-collar Irish and Italian constituency gets behind a move like this, you know it is going to be successful.''
In February, Mr. Moakley traveled to El Salvador, where he operated with the same plucky style he brings to the cloakrooms of the House. At first, the United States State Department wanted to put one of its own officials on his plane to supervise his activities, he said, but ''I said, 'No way.' I didn't want to look like Mickey the Dunce.''
 
Striking a Deal
He finally made a deal: He let a department representive come along but only after the department released answers to a list of questions Mr. Moakley had submitted two months before.
When the United States Embassy in San Salvador refused to release polygraph evidence taken from suspects in the killings and a letter written by an American major regarding a Salvadoran military cover-up, Mr. Moakley wangled them from sources he had cultivated within the Salvadoran Army.
In its preliminary report, released in April, Mr. Moakley's task force documented that the Salvadoran investigation was at a ''virtual standstill.'' The committee's findings included a report of a radio call from a meeting of the high command to a commander of the Salvadoran soldiers who allegedly killed the priests. Mr. Moakley concluded that the Army's high command was implicated in the case, and he has instructed his staff to keep investigating the radio call.
The task force returned to El Salvador in August, after which Mr. Moakley released a stinging indictment of the military. ''Salvadoran military officers,'' he said, ''have withheld evidence, destroyed evidence, falsified evidence and repeatedly perjured themselves in testimony before the judge.''
''You know what really bothers me?'' Mr. Moakley said in an interview. ''If some Speaker had organized a task force when Archbishop Romero was killed to challenge the Administration, the aid could have been cut a long time ago.''
 
Joe Moakley
 
Born: April 27, 1927.
 
Hometown: Boston.
 
Education: Attended University of Miami; J.D. Suffolk University Law School.
 
Career: Member Massachusetts House of Representatives, 1953-64; practicing lawyer, 1957-72; member Massachusetts State Senate, 1965-70; member Boston city Coundil, 1971-73; member House of Representatives 1973-present.
 
Interests: Golf, going to the movies.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 27, 1990, Monday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday headed Washington at Work, about Representative Joe Moakley, referred incorrectly in some copies to the late Archbishop Oscar Arnulfo Romero of San Salvador. The Archbishop was not a leader of the Arena Party; the party was organized after he was assassinated in 1980 by a gunman who was later linked to a current party leader.

HEADLINE: 3 INCUMBENTS WIN IN WYOMING RACES

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: CHEYENNE, Wyo., Aug. 22

 BODY:
Former Gov. Clifford P. Hansen's daughter won the Republican nomination for his old job in a primary on Tuesday. In November, she will face the Democratic incumbent, Mike Sullivan, who easily defeated his opponent, a motorcycle mechanic. 
With 96 percent of the votes counted today, Mr. Hansen's daughter, Mary Mead, a rancher, received more than twice as many as her opponent, State Representative Nyla Murphy.
Referring in her victory remarks to the Democrats' 16-year hold on the governor's office, she said, ''The people in Wyoming that I've talked to think it's time for a change.''
Mrs. Mead, who is 55 years old, had stressed her skills as a rancher and businesswoman and attacked Mr. Sullivan's economic development efforts.
Her father, also a Republican, was governor from 1963 to 1967 before moving on to the United States Senate. He retired in 1978.
Mr. Sullivan easily won nomination for a second term, receiving 88 percent of the vote against Ron Clingman, who had called for lowering the drinking age to 18 from 21.
 
Student Nominated for Senate
Senator Alan K. Simpson, the Republican whip, handily won nomination for a third term, receiving 84 percent of the vote. He will face Kathy Helling in the general election.
Ms. Helling, a 32-year-old college student who received 34 percent of the vote in a six-way Democratic race, said a strong grass-roots campaign and her stand against abortion would make her a formidable opponent.
Representative Craig Thomas, a Republican, had no opposition in his primary campaign for re-election. His Democratic opponent in November is Pete Maxfield, a law professor at the University of Wyoming. Like Mr. Thomas, Mr. Maxfield was unopposed in Tuesday's primary.

LENGTH: 502 words

HEADLINE: Found: A New Treasure in the Gulf

 BODY:
President Bush's main goal in the Persian Gulf is to protect moderate Arab states threatened by attack or intimidation from Iraq. His policy has already achieved a brilliant success: A broad front of Arab states are standing up to Saddam Hussein's renegade regime.
That's a revolutionary development. But this brave new coalition remains tentative. If the U.S. were to heed the advice of those now urging pre-emptive military strikes against Iraq, the coalition could shatter, and with it America's standing among moderate Arabs for a generation. 
Wise American policy would build on the new Arab alliance. It offers a way to isolate and contain President Hussein with minimal bloodshed. And it also offers the best long-term approach to defending American interests in the gulf.
For decades, no Arab leader dared challenge the dogma that Arab unity meant unity against the West, especially against the United States. Cold war divisions once made it possible for Arab leaders like Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt to play off East against West. But the old doctrines make little sense in the world of the 1990's. And Iraq's brazen assault on an Arab neighbor buries the old ideology under the urgent need for self-defense.
Urged on by Mr. Bush's energetic diplomacy, Hosni Mubarak, Egypt's President, has rallied other Arabs around a new proposition: They must unite against any aggressor in their region, Arab or foreign, and cooperate with outside powers in a framework of collective security. The results have been astonishing. Twelve Arab League states have backed a resolution to defend Saudi Arabia with Arab troops. Egyptian and Moroccan contingents already stand beside Saudi Arabia's 65,000-member army. Syrian forces are pledged as well. The United Arab Emirates this week joined Saudi Arabia in giving the United States base rights.
Meanwhile, Baghdad grows ever more isolated. Even radical regimes like Libya now denounce Iraqi aggression and hostage-taking. Yemen, which had abstained in the original Security Council votes on sanctions, now says it will cooperate in their enforcement.
Saddam Hussein revealed himself as a clear threat to vital American interests only when he turned his might against the oil-producing Arab states of the Persian Gulf. His invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 raised the prospect of an Iraqi stranglehold on oil that could feed his growing appetite for advanced weapons and economic warfare.
The best defense against such threats is to give the gulf oil states political reinforcement. That means giving the highest priority to consolidating the new Arab alignment and reinforcing it with a broad international consensus on collective security operating through the United Nations.
Unilateral American military action may ultimately prove necessary, and President Bush was surely right in his news conference yesterday in refusing to rule it out. But for much of the Arab world to join the rest of the world in facing down Iraq is a political treasure to protect.

HEADLINE: South African Equality Begins With Education

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your upbeat editorial ''In South Africa: The Nightmare Ebbs'' (Aug. 8) is most encouraging. May I contribute to a dialogue by emphasizing that the nightmare in South Africa is not over. The phased release of political prisoners and the return of anti-Government exiles are part of the first easy steps. The hard bargaining on the hard questions of equal rights is still to come.
As you so rightly say, Nelson Mandela should press for, among other things, more jobs, better pay and opportunities in a country where 88 percent of the wealth is controlled by only 5 percent of the people.
To his credit, Mr. Mandela has consistently spoken out about the need to improve education for blacks.
Last March I led a group of 14 United States citizens to South Africa to survey the potential for Outward Bound programs in South Africa. One colleague participated in a protest march of more than 100,000 students from the townships of Alexandra and Soweto, outside Johannesburg. Fortunately, it was a peaceful march, although the police put up blockades at several intersections of the roadway.
The teachers were out on strike, but the students had grievances of their own: There are more than 100 students to each class. Ninety percent of the teachers are underqualified, and there was only one textbook for every five students. For every 100 rand the Government spends on each white student, it spends about 20 rand on each black student.
Jobs and economic opportunity begin with education. One of the most urgent needs in South Africa is a major effort to give blacks equal educational opportunity. When this happens, there will be cause for some celebration.
 
CHARLES P. STETSON
President, U.S. Fund for the Southern
Africa Outward Bound School
Southport, Conn., Aug. 8, 1990

HEADLINE: Board of Estimate, Headed for Demise, Approves Flurry of Projects

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE

 BODY:
The New York City Board of Estimate approved a flurry of disputed proposals early yesterday morning, including a plan by Columbia University to build a commercial biomedical laboratory at the site of the ballroom where Malcolm X was assassinated in 1965.
The unanimous vote came shortly after 1 A.M., almost a week after the board began its final meeting last Thursday. As in the past, the board hammered out its agreements in a series of private meetings, which began after noon on Tuesday, when the board reconvened after a weekend break. The public portion of the meeting resumed just before midnight Tuesday. 
Early yesterday, the board also approved extension of city streets into the site of the proposed $2.3 billion Hunters Point redevelopment, a complex of up to 6,000 apartments and 2 million square feet of commercial space planned for the East River waterfront in Long Island City, Queens. The board also approved zoning changes sought by developer Harry Macklowe that would allow him to build a 28-story office tower on West 33d Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues.
After voting on the Audubon Ballroom project, the board recessed until Monday morning, when it is to vote on the last item on its final agenda, a proposal for special permits for the United Parcel Service for a sorting center on Washington Street in SoHo. Under the new city charter approved last November, the board is to be dissolved on Aug. 31. Its powers are to be divided among the City Council, the mayor and various new agencies and boards.
 
A Test for Dinkins
The Audubon Ballroom was the most emotional issue taken up by the board as it went about the business of putting itself out of business. For different constituencies, the controversy had become a test for Mayor David N. Dinkins on everything from his policy on development to his racial loyalty.
In the compromise agreement on the ballroom at 165th Street and Broadway, the Manhattan Borough President, Ruth W. Messinger, won a number of concessions from the Dinkins administration and the university, including more extensive preservation of the 1912 building's terra-cotta facade, the creation of a community health facility within the building and the establishment of community-based job-placement and training programs.
In return, Ms. Messinger agreed to drop her veto of $8.1 million in Port Authority funds that had been designated for the project.
''Malcolm X is widely remembered as a powerful leader of the African-American community throughout the world,'' Mr. Dinkins said of the agreement. ''The compromise we have reached will further his dream of economic justice while also creating a fitting memorial in his honor.''
The Dinkins administration and the university had contended that the proposed lab would help revitalize Washington Heights and would enable New York to remain competitive in high-technology medical research.
But opponents, including landmark preservationists, some local residents and members of a black nationalist group called Black Consciousness, had argued during a lengthy and passionate public hearing late Monday night and early Tuesday morning that the entire ballroom should be preserved.
Under the agreement, about 55 percent of the building will be preserved, including the ballroom, compared with 40 percent under the original proposal.
The $37.5 million project is the city's first foray into the field of biotechnology. It is expected to create 250 jobs during construction and 300 permanent jobs during the project's first phase.
Those involved in the negotiations said yesterday that the talks had not been about the relative merits of economic development versus historic preservation. Rather, they said, it was a matter of balancing those needs by quantifying the issues and fine-tuning some language.
''There was no one last issue,'' said Deputy Mayor Sally B. Hernandez-Pinero. ''It all sort of crystallized at the same time.''
 
'The Same Goals'
''The hardest issue for all of us was what to do with the money we have here,'' said Carl Weisbrod, the president of the city's Public Development Corporation, which is a partner in the project. ''We all had the same goals.''
Ms. Messinger said that while the center could not be viewed as solving all the problems in the neighborhood, it was a start.
In other action, the board on Tuesday cleared the way for the developer Peter S. Kalikow to demolish part of a tenement complex designated a landmark and then build a luxury tower. The site is the City and Suburban York Avenue Estates, on East 79th Street. Late Monday, the board voted to approve a condominium complex with 7,500 apartments on a two-mile stretch of beachfront in the Arverne section of Rockaway in Queens.

HEADLINE: 2 Held in Extortion of Paper Delivery Service

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Two key employees of a wholesale newspaper distributor were arrested yesterday on charges that they extorted $30,000 to assure speedy shipments of The New York Times to a newspaper home and business delivery service.
Federal prosecutors said the defendants stalled newspaper shipments to a company known as Mitchell's, the World's Finest Newspaper Delivery Service, to force the company to make the payoffs. 
The defendants, Leo D'Angelo and James McCreay, are named in a two-count indictment charging they conspired to extort money from the company through ''force, violence and fear, including fear of economic injury to Mitchell's.''
Both men pleaded not guilty at an arraignment before Judge Arthur D. Spatt of Federal District Court in Brooklyn. Judge Spatt set bail at $500,000 for Mr. D'Angelo and $250,000 for Mr. McCreay.
Both defendants are employed by Metropolitan News Company, a newspaper wholesale distributor located in Long Island City, Queens. Mr. D'Angelo, 57 years old, of East Northport, is a general foreman for Metropolitan and Mr. McCreay, 43, of Staten Island, is a driver and union shop steward.
Metropolitan, one of the largest newspaper distributors in the city, was not accused of any wrongdoing.
''The New York Times was aware of the investigation and supported it,'' said United States Attorney Andrew J. Maloney. Most copies of the newspaper in the metropolitan area reach dealers through independent wholesalers.
The owner of Mitchell's ''was threatened with physical harm, if he didn't agree to pay,'' said Assistant United States Attorney Leo Laufer.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

THE OIL JOLT
 
The price of oil topped $31 a barrel, the highest price since November 1985, when the oil markets were still recovering from the Iranian revolution five years earlier. The current Middle East crisis has now raised prices higher than they were when Iran and Iraq were trying to sink each other's tankers. [Page A1.] 
 
A militant group of oil producers led by Algeria, Libya and Iran has blocked a renewed attempt by Saudi Arabia and Venezuela to convene an emergency OPEC meeting to try to stabilize soaring oil prices. The move creates a deep rift within OPEC as it faces its most severe crisis in 30 years. [D6.]
 
MARKETS
 
Stock prices tumbled late in the day in the wake of the surprising rise in crude oil futures. For much of the day, the market treaded water, but by the close, the Dow had slid 43.81 points, to 2,560.15, its lowest level in nine months. [D1.]
 
The Japanese stock market plunged again early today. And as the Tokyo stock market goes through its second major downturn this year, the seemingly invulnerable Japanese commercial banks and securities brokers appear likely to suffer their steepest profit declines in years and a possible slowdown in their headlong overseas expansion, analysts and economists say. [D1.] In Tokyo today, continued concerns about the Middle East caused the Nikkei stock index to fall nearly 6 percent by midafternoon today, to a point about 39 percent below its high for the year. Meanwhile, in Europe yesterday, stock markets stabilized after suffering heavy losses on Tuesday, and in some cases posted big gains. [D8.]
 
Long-term interest rates rose to their highest levels in nearly four months and Treasury bond prices fell sharply. In addition to worrying about inflation and possible war, the prospect of sharply higher Federal budget deficits weighed on the credit market. [D17.]
 
The dollar continued to weaken as the foreign exchange markets remained nervous. Gold prices were mixed. [D18.]
 
A growing supply of pork and a break in cash market prices combined to send hog futures prices skidding. [D18.]
 
THE ECONOMY
 
The storm at New England banks is growing more ominous. Problems with loans to real estate developers that emerged about a year ago have mounted, causing losses that threaten insolvency for many banks and savings institutions. [D1.]
 
COMPANIES
 
The U.S. is allowing Control Data to sell the Soviet Union six mainframe computers. The move is a significant policy relaxation. The machines will be used for analyzing safety factors in civilian nuclear power reactors. [D1.]
 
Crossland Savings said Federal regulators had turned down its plan for a financial revamping and had imposed limits on its lending in the future. Crossland has been hard hit by the downturn in the New York real estate market. [D1.]
 
Disciplinary charges against Stotler have been filed by the S.E.C. and the C.F.T.C. The collapsed futures trading firm is charged with hiding its financial difficulties. [D2.]
 
National Intergroup said it would entertain proposals for the sale of its Foxmeyer drug distribution subsidiary. [D4.]
 
TODAY'S COLUMNS
 
Chrysler's 1987 acquisition of American Motors gave Chrysler the Jeep line and A.M.C.'s share of the U.S. vehicle market. But Chrysler bought some headaches as well. Talking Deals. [D2.]
 
In stocks, the real carnage is in the over-the-counter market. Investors describe the activity of recent weeks as the worst since the October 1987 crash. Market Place. [D8.]

HEADLINE: Control Data Allowed to Sell 6 Computers to Soviet Union

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
In a significant policy relaxation, the United States Government is allowing the Control Data Corporation to sell six mainframe computers to the Soviet Union. The machines, which are considered mid-size mainframes and not supercomputers, will be used for analyzing safety factors in civilian nuclear power reactors. They would be the fastest yet sold to the Soviets.
The export license, which was announced yesterday by Control Data, was approved by the Commerce Department on Monday. The machines will cost the Soviets $32 million, the company said. 
The deal is the first large sale of high-performance computers to the Soviet Union by an American corporation since a June agreement that ended most trade restrictions with the former Soviet bloc. The accord was reached by the 17 nations of the technology watchdog group known as the Coordinating Committee on Multilateral Export Controls, or Cocom.
The license is likely to be the first in a range of new agreements between American companies and the Soviet Union, aimed at supporting issues that are of importance to the United States Government.
On his visit to the United States in June, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union visited the Minneapolis-based computer maker and was given a demonstration of the machine, the Cyber 960.
''This is the first approval of a significant level of computing power to the Soviet Union,'' said Jim O'Connell, Control Data's director of international trade policy. ''There's an important symbol here. The U.S. Government is indicating in this approval that it is going to support U.S.-Soviet high-tech cooperation in certain areas that are deemed to be of global concern.''
He said other technology agreements could be expected in areas like environmental protection, petroleum exploration and industrial modernization.
''The American establishment has realized that this technology already exists in the Soviet Union,'' said Esther Dyson, a computer industry analyst in New York who publishes Release 1.0, an industry newsletter. ''It has become a financial question instead of a political one.''
People who have argued for strict controls on technology sales to the Soviets said yesterday that the sale was a reasonable one for the purposes involved.
''These computers don't pose any threat,'' said Steven D. Bryen, a former Pentagon official who was responsible for export control policy. ''But before we do any broad release of technology, we ought to make certain that the Soviets have made the changes that they have promised.''
Mr. O'Connell said Control Data had begun the process of attempting to gain an export license in November 1989. In June, restrictions were lifted dramatically after the Cocom countries met in Paris and dropped most technology export limits.
 
Machine Restrictions
Before the June meeting, computers with a performance figure above 75 were restricted. The figure means that the machine would be able to transfer data at 75 million bits of information a second - or the equivalent of about eight large novels.
This level of restriction led to the control of most computers, including most personal computers.
Since June, the 75 figure has been replaced by a three-tier structure. Computers with a performance rating of up to 275 can be freely sold under general-export licenses. The sale of machines rated up to 550 can be sold based on national discretion. Machines rated 550 to 1,000 still require Cocom export approval.
Mr. O'Connell said Control Data's Cyber 960 computer, which the Soviets are buying, has a rating of 435, but since the licensing process had begun before the June Cocom meeting, the application had gone through the United States Government interagency approval process.
The sale required a special agreement between the American and Soviet Governments, he said. The agreement creates a special safeguard program to regulate the use of the computers. The program, known as the nuclear safety technology cooperation agreement, was completed at the end of June.

HEADLINE: Bank Woes Climbing in Northeast

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The storm at New England banks is growing more ominous.
Problems with loans to real estate developers that emerged about a year ago have mounted, causing losses that threaten insolvency for many banks and savings institutions in the region. Nonperforming loans at New England banks nearly doubled, to 4.3 percent of their assets on June 30 from 2.23 percent a year ago, according to SNL Securities, a financial data firm of Charlottesville, Va.
New England now has a far higher percentage of nonperforming loans than any other region; the national average is 2.49 percent. The increases in problem loans are similar at savings institutions in the region. 
 
New Office to Address Problems
The recent failures of four banks in Massachusetts and the prospect of more have led the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation to make plans to open a new office outside Boston. The office, with a staff of 450, will handle the myriad problems that emerge once bank examiners determine that a bank should be closed.
''There is clearly the potential for many more bank failures in New England over the next 12 to 18 months,'' said Gerard S. Cassidy, an analyst specializing in the region's banks at Tucker, Anthony & R. L. Day, a securities firm in New York.
New England relies heavily on oil for home heating and electricity generation, and recent increases in oil prices caused by turmoil in the Middle East will reduce the amount of money available for other kinds of spending and limit the region's economic growth, analysts expect.
 
Effect of Higher Oil Prices
''Given the region's real estate problems, the potential for failure was here without price increases in oil,'' Mr. Cassidy said. ''With higher oil prices, the outlook for the New England economy becomes more grim.''
Many of the troubled loans are to developers who have too many vacancies in their office buildings, condominiums and other projects because of the weakening New England economy. As higher oil prices hurt the economy further, it will take even longer for the region to absorb the glut of real estate projects.
''Things are still very bad and are probably going to stay that way for the foreseeable future,'' said Charles A. Shorter, senior vice president in the New York office of the Real Estate Research Corporation, a Chicago firm. Mr. Shorter estimated that as more projects were completed, vacancy rates would rise for residential properties and office buildings.
The rate of bank failures in New England has been low for the last few years. Two banks failed in 1988, four in 1989 and four so far this year.
But there are strong signals that the financial condition of many other banks is precarious, according to data compiled by Veribanc Inc., a Wakefield, Mass., bank-rating firm.
In Connecticut, Massachusetts, Maine and New Hampshire, there were 23 banks whose losses in the first quarter, if continued at the same pace, could wipe out capital in less than a year, or whose capital was less than 3 percent of assets.
 
Capital Is a Cushion
The level of the capital of a bank and its earnings are critical guides to its financial strength and are used by Veribanc to predict which banks are most likely to fail. A bank's capital serves as a cushion to absorb losses and many healthy banks have capital of 5 percent or more.
A rise in failures among New England banks was foreshadowed earlier this month by L. William Seidman, the F.D.I.C. chairman, who said the Bank Insurance Fund was likely to lose $2 billion in 1990, not break even as he had predicted earlier this year. To rebuild the fund, which exceeded $13 billion at the end of 1989, Mr. Seidman has proposed a 30 percent increase in the premiums banks pay for deposit insurance.
Although Mr. Seidman did not say where additional bank failures would occur, many analysts have been expecting a rise in New England.
They noted that the collapse of many Texas banks did not take place until more than two years after their real estate problems emerged.
 
'Many More Problems'
A staff of 450 at the new Boston office of the F.D.I.C. ''suggests they know of many more problems to come among smaller firms, or else they are anticipating the collapse of a very large institution,'' said Warren Heller, Veribanc's research director.
''Up till now, liquidations in that area had been handled out of the New York or South Brunswick offices,'' said Joseph Palladino, head of the liquidation division in the F.D.I.C.'s New York office. The agency has 16 liquidation offices around the country to sell the loans, real estate and other assets of the more than 500 banks that have failed since the end of 1987.
Recent announcements from many of the largest banks in New England have shown that the problems that began coming to the surface in late 1988 and caused large losses in 1989 are worsening.
At the Bank of New England Corporation, which reported a second-quarter loss of $33.3 million, troubles with bad real estate loans continue to grow. Even a large increase in reserves for loan losses that caused the company to lose $1.1 billion in 1989 and wiped out most of its capital has not proved enough to cover the company's bad loans.
In the second quarter, the Bank of New England added $28 million to its reserve for loan losses and increased by $31 million the real estate it holds from defaulted loans. It also shifted $110 million in loans to ''nonperforming'' status, meaning they are delinquent or face such serious trouble that the bank can not rely on continued payments.
Lawrence K. Fish, the chairman of the Bank of New England, said the deterioration was ''not unexpected because of the continued sluggishness in the region's economy'' and the ''softness of the real estate market.''
 
Failure Is Feared
The Bank of New England is a candidate for failure because of its losses and the low level of capital available to absorb additional losses, Mr. Heller said.
The Fleet/Norstar Financial Group of Providence, R.I., a financially healthy banking company and the second largest in New England, returned to profitability in the second quarter after a first-quarter loss, but nevertheless reported increases in its problem loans. Nonperforming loans rose by nearly 16 percent, to $756 million, on June 30, from $653 million at the end of March, and holdings of foreclosed real estate rose by $16 million, to $291 million.
Many of the banks hit hardest in New England are savings banks that have historically concentrated on home loans, much like the separately regulated savings and loan associations more common in the South and West. Deposits at many savings banks are insured by the F.D.I.C., meaning that the cost of their failure is borne by the bank insurance fund, which remains solvent.
Savings banks that have failed or been taken over by regulators this year include the Home Owners Savings Bank of Burlington, Mass., with $2.8 billion in deposits, and the Eliot Savings Bank of Boston, with $420 million in deposits.
The closing of savings institions whose deposits were previously insured by the insolvent Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, now the Savings Association Insurance Fund, is the job of the Resolution Trust Corporation. So far this year that agency has taken over five savings institutions in New England.
