HEADLINE: Japan Stocks Plunge; Finance Sector Ailing

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Thursday, Aug. 23

 BODY:
The sharp slide in the Tokyo stock market accelerated today after a heavy selloff yesterday.
With this continuation of the second major downturn in the market here this year, the seemingly invulnerable Japanese commercial banks and securities brokers appear likely to suffer their steepest profit declines in years and a possible slowdown in their headlong overseas expansion, analysts and economists here are saying.
In Tokyo today, the closely watched Nikkei index, which fell 4.1 percent yesterday, plunged an additional 1,473.28 points, or nearly 6 percent, to close at 23,737.63. [Page D8.] The ripples that the tumbling market has sent through the financial system in response to the Persian Gulf crisis - and that it could continue to send for months - are demonstrating anew the dependence of Japanese banks, which hold huge stock portfolios, and brokerage houses, which rely on commissions from trading, on rising share prices for their financial health. 
When the market was raging ahead in recent years, it was a locomotive for the whole financial system. But as it tumbles, the market is turning into a millstone around these institutions' necks.
At least initially, the market's troubles will affect Japan's financial concerns much more than they will affect the country's industry. Japanese industrial companies have grown so wealthy over the last few years that they have generally not needed to raise large sums of capital from the market to finance expansion of their plants or moves into new businesses.
In time, however, a prolonged slide would cut into the assets of these companies and make it more difficult for them to get bank loans, raise capital or even make overseas acquisitions.
Likewise, the decline of the stock market is unlikely to have a direct impact on the purchases of United States Treasury securities by the Japanese, who have been principal underwriters of the United States budget deficit. But analysts say that if the decline persists it could eventually give the Japanese less fire power for acquiring assets in the United States or elsewhere.
''Nobody wants to believe this will continue for a year, or two or three years, but in my opinion it will be very hard to get confidence back after being hit twice in just a few months,'' said Toshio Mori, executive vice president of the Tokyo Securities Company. ''I'm afraid 1988 and 1989 were too good to be true.''
At one time, some in the financial community here would have expected the powerful Finance Ministry to step in and, behind the scenes, take steps to stabilize the market. But with the advent of deregulation, the ministry has fewer tools for doing so and has given no indications that it intends to intervene.
 
Calls for Program Trading Halt
There have been calls from some Japanese securities houses, however, to limit or halt program trading, which some blame for the volatility. There are no signs yet that action will be taken, but the issue could be particularly divisive, since American securities firms here are the principal practitioners of this trading technique, which involves using stock index futures.
For the securities industry, what is worse than the market's slide is the drop-off in the volume of trading. Every trade, even in a falling market, generates commissions for brokers. But volume has withered to less than 300 million shares on many recent days, a third of last year's daily average, as investors sat on the sidelines amid the uncertainties.
''In Japan, brokerage houses are much more dependent on commissions than Wall Street firms,'' Mr. Mori added. ''Thus, the magnitude of the problems when the market falls like this is much greater for us.'' 63% Drop in Profits Forecast Robert Zielinski, a financial analyst at Jardine Fleming Securities here, has forecast a stunning 63 percent decline in the operating profit this year for the 25 Japanese securities houses whose shares are listed.
The Nomura Securities Company, the largest brokerage in the world and this country's most profitable company two years ago, is expected to post a steep 45 percent decline in operating profits this year, Mr. Zielinski estimated.
Nonetheless, the damage to the nation's banks will be greater, he and others said.
''The Japanese banks live off the stock market and share price levels more than some people realize,'' Mr. Zielinski said. ''They were the biggest beneficiaries of the price rises before, and now that has all ended.''
 
Less Dependence on Oil
Economists say that Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and the subsequent embargo on oil imports from the two countries have not hit Japan's powerfully expanding economy hard because Japan has spent the last decade easing its heavy dependence on Middle Eastern oil.
But the attack could not have come at a worse time for the financial system. The market had plunged in February, March and April after interest rates here spurted upward. But in early July, it started to emerge from a long convalescence.
The fragile confidence in the market was therefore shattered when the tanks rolled across Kuwait's borders earlier this month, creating worries about inflation here and a possible recession in the United States.
Interest rates spiked upward, stock prices tumbled and stock-related business evaporated. The market for new issues of securities, the source of immense sums of new capital over the last few years, has been all but closed down. During the second quarter of this year, new issues of securities totaled about $275 million a month, compared with about $3.7 billion a month the year earlier. Now, there will be even less.
 
Effect on Psychology
''Frankly speaking, I don't think we can expect a return to the kind of trading volumes that we had in previous years,'' said Takatoshi Okuyama, an investment executive at Daiwa Securities. ''The psychology of investors has really been affected.''
There are no signs of huge insolvencies, like those that hit America's savings and loans, or other serious problems. Indeed, analysts say profits will still be relatively high even after the big declines that are expected. But the recent difficulties are a sign that Japanese institutions are not impervious to the kinds of jolts that have afflicted their American competitors.
Some of the fallout seems frivolous at first glance. Fortune magazine estimates that the market's slide has decreased the number of paper billionaires in Japan to 8, from 12 a year ago. But that is a telling omen, pointing to how deeply all Japanese institutions sitting on huge portfolios of paper wealth have been hurt.
 
Banks Have Huge Portfolios
Among the largest of these institutions are commercial banks. Japanese banks are permitted to own up to 5 percent of the stock in industrial companies, and the largest banks have portfolios worth tens of billions of dollars.
Analysts estimate that nearly half of the earnings of Japan's largest dozen banks over the last several years have come from sales of this stock. In addition, the banks have been able to count a portion of the value of these vast holdings as capital.
That system gave the Japanese banks huge and fast-growing capital bases when the market was rocketing higher. In turn, it permitted them to expand their lending at home and overseas at a break-neck pace, giving them a huge competitive advantage over American and European banks.
Stuart Matthews, an analyst at Barclays de Zoette Wedd, a brokerage house here, has forecast that the so-called city banks, the 13 leading commercial banks, will suffer a 20 percent decline in what he called their underlying operating profits, to 1.285 trillion yen, from 1.595 trillion yen in fiscal 1989, which ended on March 31 of this year.
 
Fall in Capital Positions
''Securities companies are generally in a better position to withstand a collapse in profits because their expenses naturally decline faster,'' Mr. Matthews said. ''They don't have the same expense problems.''
Under international banking guidelines, commercial banks as of 1993 will have to maintain capital equal to 8 percent or more of their total assets. Japanese banks were already well over the minimum last year. But the market slide has sliced billions of dollars off the value of their stock holdings, and that drop has sent their capital ratios tumbling.
Jardine Fleming estimates that of Japan's 15 largest banks, only 3 are above the 8 percent limit now, compared with 11 at the beginning of this year. Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank, the largest in the world; Mitsubishi Bank; Bank of Tokyo, and the Industrial Bank of Japan, to name a few, all fall below the minimum now, according to these estimates.
 
Cuts in U.S. Seen as Likely
The answer for these banks would normally be to raise capital by selling securities - an avenue that has been shut off. As a result, they must consider slowing growth in their least-profitable businesses. And in the last few years, that has been their international operations, in particular the United States. Japanese banks were heavy lenders to a number of large leveraged buyouts, many of which have run into trouble.
A recent article in a financial newspaper here estimated that Japanese banks might have to write off as much as $4 billion of such American loans. The article went on to make a subtle comparison between lending in the United States with lending in troubled developing nations.
''It's true; given their capital restraints they will have to think about cutting back on their less profitable businesses,'' a senior Finance Ministry official said. ''And that is most likely on the international side. They might consider slowing or even curtailing those businesses.''

HEADLINE: Stocks Fall Again as Oil Surges

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stock prices tumbled late yesterday in the wake of a surprising $2.51-a-barrel rise in crude oil futures.
For much of the day, the market treaded water, as no major new developments had emerged in the Persian Gulf crisis. At 2 P.M., the Dow Jones industrial average had fallen barely 19 points.
But by the 4 P.M. close, the Dow had slid 43.81 points, to 2,560.15 - its lowest level in nine months - after sinking 52 points the day before. 
 
Sharp Two-Day Loss
As a result, the blue-chip market indicator has lost nearly 100 points in just two days.
While the Dow has been making headlines, even more damage has taken place in the over-the-counter market. The Dow has lost 14.7 percent since July 16, but the Nasdaq composite index has fallen 20.2 percent. Yesterday, the Nasdaq index fell 4.84 points, to 374.84, its lowest level in 20 months. [Market Place, page D8.] In yesterday's market selloff, ''crude oil was the culprit,'' said Peter G. Grennan, head of stock-index futures trading for Shearson Lehman Brothers.
Until close to 2:30, he said, the price of crude was around $30.15 a barrel, up $1.44, and ''trending lower.''
But almost immediately after President Bush's news conference ended, he said, the price jumped an additional $1.07, to $31.22.
 
Behind Bush's Remarks
Traders said they had interpreted remarks by the President as meaning that he would not rule out the use of force to settle the crisis.
''Bush came across as very firm, in control of the situation, and doesn't want to back down,'' Mr. Grennan said.
But what is good for oil prices is bad for the stock market.
''Any escalation would move it down,'' said Kenneth P. Ducey, senior vice president of the investment house of S. G. Warburg & Company.
With the deadly combination of a weakening economy and a deepening crisis weighing ominously on the market, investors continued to be troubled by the preponderance of new lows and declining issues over new highs and advancing issues.
Declines outnumbered advances yesterday, 1,190 to 379, with 328 stocks setting new lows and only 7 hitting new highs.
For the second day, the nation's most widely held stock - A.T.& T. -touched a new low of 32, subsequently closing at 32 1/8, down 3/4. Others setting new lows included Hewlett-Packard, the technology company; AMR, the owner of American Airlines, and Fannie Mae, which buys and then resells mortages.
Trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange totaled a strong 175.6 million shares, down from 194.6 million the day before. Activity was buoyed by heavy program trading, investors seeking bargains and speculators scrambling early in the day to buy back stock they had sold short.
 
Pessimistic Mood
Mr. Grennan described the market's mood as pessimistic.
He said that early in the day traders had thought the market would rally because it was ''oversold,'' that prices had sunk too low.
''The market stabilized for a few hours in the middle of the day,'' he said, ''then began to move higher, but the rally was aborted by the oil rise. When it crossed $2, that was it. Then the market started selling off.''
During the President's news conference at Kennebunkport, Me., a reporter asked in part of the Iraqis, ''Do you still rule out the use of U.S. military forces to evict . . .?''
Not waiting to hear the rest of the sentence, President Bush responded: ''I don't rule in or rule out the use of military force. And I learned long ago not to tie one's self down by stating what I will or will not do in that regard.''
Oil prices jumped immediately, Mr. Grennan said. He added that cash prices subsequently rose an additional 50 cents a barrel after the futures market had closed for the day.
 
Program Traders Are Active
Professional stock traders again dominated most of the day's activity.
Program traders - who use computers to spot price differences between, say, the 500 stocks in the Standard & Poor's index and futures on the S.&P. index - clipped nearly 50 points off the Dow, Birinyi Associates said. A 14-minute selling program starting at 3:02, or 30 minutes after the President's news conference ended, toppled the Dow almost 19 points by itself.
Mr. Ducey of Warburg said investors who had sold stock short, hoping to buy it back later for less money, had given up by the middle of the day when prices failed to break and bought back the stock anyway. Bargain hunters were also heavily in the market, he said.
''When they got through,'' he said, ''the market came down again.''
Trading on Monday had been marked by wild rumors, later denied, that an American plane had been shot down, touching off sentiment that a shooting war could break out soon. With Wall Street prepared for the worst, some even thought that war might come in 48 hours. The spiraling rise in oil prices in the wake of President Bush's tough talk seemed to give stock traders little comfort.
With one eye on the crisis and the other on the economy, traders said nothing new had emerged from the Federal Open Market Committee, which reviewed monetary policy over the last two days. Many traders argued that lower interest rates might be a big help right now, although the deepening Middle East situation made that prospect much more difficult to assess.
 
Declines Among the Blue Chips
Many blue-chip stocks fell yesterday. 3M fell 2 1/8, to 79 1/8; Procter & Gamble 1 7/8, to 74 1/8; Eastman Kodak 1 1/4, to 39; Coca-Cola 1 7/8, to 39 1/2; Boeing 1 1/8, to 45, and Merck 2 3/4, to 78 1/2.
Oil stocks, which have already had a strong run-up, were mixed. ARCO rose 1, to 138 3/8. Gold shares, always a recession haven, rose slightly. ASA gained 1 1/4, to 54 1/2.
Paramount Communications rose 2 3/4, to 36 5/8, on renewed takeover talk. And Raytheon, the military supplier, rose 1 3/8, to 63 7/8.
In over-the-counter trading, Nike, the athletic shoe producer, slid 5 3/8, to 62. Alice Ruth of Montgomery Securities in San Francisco downgraded the stock because of recessionary trends that could hurt sales. Fred Anschel of Dean Witter Reynolds in New York recommended the stock as ''quite cheap.''
The S.& P. 500-stock index fell 5.31 points, to 316.55, while the New York Stock Exchange index dropped 2.72 points, to 174.22. And the American Stock Exchange's market-value index slipped 2.95 points, to 324.39.

HEADLINE: Merc May Trade in Rubles

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Aug. 22

 BODY:
The Chicago Mercantile Exchange said today that it was working with Soviet officials and economists to develop futures and options markets for the ruble.
''As the Soviets dismantle their past economic system of rigid controls and move toward a market driven economy, it is imperative that their monetary unit become an accepted world currency,'' said Leo Melamed, executive committee chairman of the Merc, where trading of foreign currency futures had its inception in 1972. 
Mr. Melamed, considered a pioneer in currency futures, said he expected the exchange to begin trading in the ruble late in 1991.
''The big question is how fast the Russians move to convertibility,'' he said. ''It hinges on that.''
Western economists say the ruble cannot become truly convertible to other currencies until the Soviet Union establishes a market pricing system for all its goods and allows free cross-border trade.
They also say it is not possible to have a convertible currency in a controlled market.
Also, the currency does not circulate outside the Soviet Union. Over the years, Soviet businesses wanting to trade with Western companies have had to trade rubles with the Soviet Government for Western currencies. While the situation has loosened somewhat in recent years, the rate of exchange is still set by Soviet officials.

HEADLINE: Attempt to Set OPEC Meeting Fails

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, Aug. 22

 BODY:
A militant group of oil producers led by Algeria, Libya and Iran has blocked a renewed attempt by Saudi Arabia and Venezuela to convene an emergency meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to try to stablize soaring oil prices.
The move creates a deep rift within OPEC as it faces its most severe crisis in 30 years. The Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 interrupted the flow of four million barrels of oil a day from the two countries, and prices for OPEC crude have since surged to around $28 a barrel here, the highest level in at least five years.
This latest OPEC disagreement comes as oil markets are beginning to experience serious shortages of some refined products. Many oil experts expect the situation to worsen and prices to rise further over the next two months. 
 
Saudis to Curtail Shipments
Saudi Arabia notified many customers today that it would not be able to deliver large quantities of jet kerosene, gasoline and gas oil, because in the event of military action against Iraq the fuels would be needed by its own armed forces and the American forces in Saudi Arabia.
The OPEC dispute splits the organization into two camps: price hawks who argue for higher oil prices and the Saudi-Venezuelan group, which insists that OPEC must raise output immediately to push down prices and ease the strains that short supplies are causing for both third would countries and the industrialized nations.
Trying to ease the friction, Sadek Boussena, Algeria's oil minister and the OPEC conference president, suggested today that all 13 members of OPEC meet informally in Vienna on Sunday without a mandate to make a decision, OPEC officials said.
Saudi Arabian and Venezuelan officials indicated, however, that they would hold a separate meeting by Sunday with the other OPEC members who favor immediate increases in output.
 
Saudi Official's Reaction
''The unwillingness of some OPEC members to meet just to look into what we should do to alleviate the shortage of oil and the pressure on prices is incomprehensible, given the fact that we have called many emergency meetings over situations that were far less serious,'' said the Saudi oil minister, Hisham M. Nazer, in an interview here.
Saudi and Venezuelan officials said they had hoped that a decision to increase production could be arrived at under ''an OPEC umbrella'' to preserve the organization's cohesiveness, but the failure to do so will not delay an increase in output for more than a few days.
''We wanted to avoid triggering a free-for-all because this is not going to be a matter of short duration,'' said a senior Venezuelan OPEC delegate who spoke on condition that he not be identified. He added that ''now we will coordinate our action with Saudi Arabia and those others who want to join us because it would be irresponsible not to step in now and dampen the price rise in such a crucial time.''
The official noted that failure to act now ''will affect OPEC's credibility as a reliable supplier of oil and as a responsible economic organization.''
 
Shortages Are Dobuted
But Iranian and Algerian oil industry sources maintain that there is no real shortage of oil and that the Western oil companies should use up the large stocks of oil they have on hand to ease the crisis.
These officials also say that the Saudis and the Venezuelans made no move to restrict output when oil prices sank to $14 a barrel in May and they maintain that the present increase is compensation for the revenue lost then.
''If the Saudis are once again undertaking to check the increase in oil prices, the oil-producing countries will stand against such plans and neutralize them,'' the Iranian press agency, Irna, quoted the daily Joumhouri Islami newspaper of Teheran as having said in an editorial today.
There are six OPEC members favoring a meeting, but that is one short of a majority of the 13-member organization. The six nations are Saudi Arabia, Venezuela, the United Arab Emirates, Qatar, Ecuador and Kuwait. (Representatives of the pre-invasion Government of Kuwait are still recognized by all the OPEC members, except Iraq.) Iraq, Iran and Libya have staunchly opposed a meeting that would try to raise output. Indonesia, Algeria, Nigeria and Gabon have said they see no need for a meeting now but want consultations to continue.
Oil experts said OPEC's procrastination in agreeing on a course of action, coupled with the certainty that some OPEC members will raise output anyway, had made the group's deliberations irrelevant to world oil markets.
Over the weekend, Mr. Nazer of Saudi Arabia served notice that his country would raise production by two million barrels a day ''very, very soon,'' with or without OPEC approval. On Monday the President of Venezuela issued a similar statement.
Today Mr. Nazer said: ''We are not going to let bureaucratic maneuvering delay a decision. We are talking about three or four days at the most.''
 
Pressures for Conservation
Oil experts said the actions by the OPEC faction that favors higher prices might push industrialized nations to step up efforts for energy conservation and to intensify the search for alternative energy sources.
John H. Lichtblau, president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation of New York, said that OPEC had already damaged its image as a reliable partner in world economic development. ''After four years of projecting the image of moderation, a number of OPEC members are clearly adopting a pro-Iraqi stand, opposing a meeting and favoring much higher prices,'' Mr. Lichtblau said. ''This will be remembered.'' One senior Arab oil executive commented that even if OPEC did meet now it would project an image of political conflict that is overwhelming economic common sense.
''You will have a country like Iraq, which invaded Iran 10 years ago, sitting there days after it gobbled up Kuwait, another major OPEC producer,'' the executive said. ''It will be a mess.''
Evidence is mounting that a production free-for-all has already begun among OPEC members.
 
Iran Output Said to Rise
Oil industry sources here and in London said Iran was pumping some 3.3 million to 3.5 million barrels of oil a day - significantly above its OPEC quota of 3.1 million barrels a day -and that Iran was signing contracts with Japanese clients to supply additional oil starting in September to replace Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil.
The United Arab Emirates has begun to produce more than its quota of 1.5 million barrels a day, oil industry sources say. And, Nigeria, which has expressed opposition to higher output by others, is itself producing at least 100,000 barrels a day above its quota of 1.6 million barrels a day.
Saudi oil executives said that while they were intent on increasing output, the consuming nations must also act.
''Everyone should help out in this crisis, including the Americans with their strategic reserves and the Japanese and the Europeans with theirs,'' said a Saudi oil executive who insisted on not being identified. ''It is important that the crisis be eliminated, so consumers do not suffer. With proper administration the shortage can be handled.''

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Long-Term Rates Climb Sharply

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Long-term interest rates rose to their highest levels in nearly four months yesterday and Treasury bond prices fell sharply, pushed by a sharp rise in oil prices and heightened fears that war may soon break out in the Persian Gulf.
''The market is trading on raw nerves,'' said John P. Costas, director of the taxable fixed-income department at the First Boston Corporation. ''People are very skittish.'' In addition to worrying about the inflationary implications of higher oil prices and the possible outbreak of fighting in the Middle East - a development many traders said could happen this week - the prospect of sharply higher Federal budget deficits also weighed on the credit market yesterday. 
''There is a growing consensus in the market that there will be an utter disregard for the Gramm-Rudman budget targets,'' said Richard L. Sandor, president of IndoSuez International Capital Markets, a subsidiary of Banque IndoSuez.
Through the first 10 months of the 1990 fiscal year the deficit stands at just under $190 billion, and seems certain to rise above $200 billion for the first time since 1986.
Earlier this week the White House projected that the shortfall in the coming 1991 fiscal year, which begins Oct. 1, will rise to $232 billion unless an agreement on a deficit reduction plan is reached.
 
Gramm-Rudman Targets
Before the Persian Gulf crisis, representatives from Congress and the Bush Administration had been talking about a $50 billion package of budget cuts and tax increases to bring the deficit in line with Gramm-Rudman targets.
But with the economy apparently on the verge of recession and the cost of financing military operations in the Middle East rising daily, far bigger cuts may be necessary. As a result, resolve to deal with the deficit is probably melting, private analysts said.
All of those factors helped to push the price of Treasury securities down sharply, but the drop ''didn't feel like a blowout,'' Mr. Sandor said, ''because it was so orderly.''
By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 96 30/32, down a full point, or $10 for each $1,000 face amount of securities, to yield 9.04 percent, up from 8.93 percent late Tuesday. It is the highest yield on the benchmark issue since late April.
Treasury note issues also got pounded, as it became increasingly apparent to traders that the Federal Reserve Board is not likely to ease short-term interest rates soon.
In late trading, the 10-year 8 3/4 percent notes were offered at 98 26/32, down 21/32, to yield 8.93 percent. And the 8 1/2 percent five-year notes were offered at 99 15/32, down 13/32, to yield 8.79 percent.
Late in the afternoon the Treasury announced that next Tuesday it will sell $11.5 billion of new two-year notes and $8.5 billion of five-year, two-month notes on Aug. 29.
In when-issued trading following the announcement, the two-year notes were offered at a price to yield 8.24 percent. The five-year notes were offered at a price to yield 8.60 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates rose modestly.
By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.57 percent, up one basis point, or hundreth of a point. Six-month bill rates rose by four basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.50 percent.
Since Aug. 2, when Iraq invaded Kuwait, long-term bond yields have risen by 56 basis points. Analysts said that while a 9 percent yield could attract retail investors into the market, interest rates could easily go higher.
''If we don't get a speedy conclusion to the crisis, there is no upper limit on where bond yields could go,'' said Nancy J. Kimelman, chief economist at Technical Data, a Boston-based bond market advisory service.
 
Fixed-Income Market Prices
Prices in other fixed-income markets also fell sharply yesterday, largely in sympathy with the decline in Treasuries.
Traders in the investment-grade corporate bond market said that prices of most actively quoted issues fell by 3/4 point. Meanwhile, municipal bond participants said that prices of most tax-exempt issues fell by 1 point to 1 1/4 points.
Among the tax-exempt issues priced yesterday was a $205 million offering from the New York City Transit Authority.
The issue, which is insured by Financial Security Assurance, consists of two term bonds maturing in 2020 and 2021 and serial bonds with maturities from 1993 to 2004.
Yields on the serial bonds range from 6.40 percent in 1993 to 7.35 percent in 2004.
Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. acted as lead manager for the negotiated underwriting, which is rated AAA by both Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Weakens Further And Gold Prices Are Mixed

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar continued to weaken yesterday as the foreign exchange markets remained nervous about events in the Persian Gulf. Gold prices were mixed.
Analysts said the United States currency fluctuated in a narrow range as traders awaited new developments from the Middle East. 
Earl Johnson, an assistant vice president at the Harris Trust and Company in Chicago, said the dollar had some support from fears that war would break out, but lost ground on continuing concerns about the slowing United States economy.
''It's basically a nervous market,'' he said.
Investors were reluctant to make major moves in any direction, Mr. Johnson said.
Overseas dealers said traders continued to buy currencies of nations where interest rates were expected to remain high. The markets believed United States rates would be eased to prevent a recession, analysts said.
The British pound, one of the currencies supported by high rates, continued to climb against the dollar. Sterling rose to $1.9235 in New York from late Tuesday's $1.9113. In earlier London trading, the pound rose to $1.9275 from $1.9215.
The dollar fell to 146.15 Japanese yen in New York, from 146.80 yen late Tuesday. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar closed at 146.92 yen, up 0.37 yen from Tuesday, and the dollar was quoted at 145.85 yen in late London trading.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.5575 German marks, down from 1.5645; 1.2775 Swiss francs, down from 1.2900; 5.2390 French francs, down from 5.2635, and 1.13535 Canadian dollars, down from 1.13985.
The dollar did manage to post a slight gain against the Italian lira, rising to 1,162.25 lire in New York, from 1,161.75 late Tuesday. In Europe earlier, the dollar rose to 1,159.00 lire from 1,155.75.
Gold prices were higher in New York after falling in Europe.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, a troy ounce of gold rose $3.60, to $411, while the Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $412.50, up $5.60 from Tuesday.
Overseas dealers said fluctuations in the price of gold reflected the market's nervousness over the gulf.
Gold fell in London to a late bid price of $410.25 a troy ounce, from $413.25 late Tuesday. In Zurich, gold fell to a closing bid of $410.25, from $414.75 late Tuesday.
Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.24 to close at a bid of $408.69.
Silver rose on the Commodity Exchange, picking up 3.8 cents to close at $5.129 a troy ounce. In London earlier, silver fell to a late bid price of $5.15 a troy ounce from late Tuesday's $5.20.

HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
BAGHDAD WARNS DIPLOMATS AGAINST 'ACT OF AGGRESSION'; HUSSEIN SHOWS OFF HOSTAGES

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., Friday, Aug. 24

 BODY:
Iraq warned the United States and more than two dozen other nations Thursday that if they challenged a deadline today and tried to keep their embassies in Iraq-occupied Kuwait open, as they have vowed to do, Baghdad would take it as an ''act of aggression.''
Ambassador W. Nathaniel Howell 3d and fewer than a dozen aides remained in the American Embassy early today. Indications here Thursday night were that any Iraqi effort to shut down the United States Embassy or those of other nations would not trigger an immediate response by the American military, as long as no attempt was made to harm or kill the American citizens who remain inside.
The Bush Administration appears to have concluded that the Iraqis are preparing to cut off water, power and telephone lines to the embassies. But the Iraqis are seen as unlikely to take any other overt military action to invade the buildings, which are considered sovereign territory of the nations involved. 
 
Uncertainty on Deadline
American officials said they were uncertain about the exact deadline imposed by the Iraqis for closing embassies in Kuwait. Some accounts gave it as noon today (5 A.M. Eastern standard time), while others gave it as 8 P.M. today, or 1 P.M. EST.
But the impression here Thursday night was that the United States and other countries believed that diplomats in Kuwait could only hold out for a matter of days under such circumstances.
The ''red lines'' set by the Bush Administration as intolerable Iraqi action that could prompt a military response were more extreme: the killing of American citizens, an Iraqi military attack on Saudi Arabia or its oilfields, or an attack by Iraqi forces on Israel - a possibility that may be the one most feared by Mr. Bush, according to indications here Thursday night.
There were also indications that the Administration was moving toward a decision in the next day or two to start boarding or disabling Iraqi oil tankers.
 
Soviet Influence
The Administration is said to have been delaying such action primarily at the urging of the Soviet Union, which is concerned about the fate of 5,000 to 8,000 of its citizens living in Iraq. Moscow also is said to have argued that there is a glimmer of hope that Iraq might back down in the face of international sanctions, basing that contention on a visit to the Soviet Union this week by the Deputy Prime Minister of Iraq, Sadun Hammadi.
While the Administration has not addressed the issue of how Mr. Bush intends to weigh the lives of American hostages against the potential need for military action, the impression here is that Mr. Bush would use force if he believes it is unavoidable - even if that might endanger the lives of Americans and other foreigners.
Mr. Bush has almost said as much himself, declaring that while American lives are important to him, the United Nations sanctions imposed against Iraq after the invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 must be enforced.
''I think any decision maker in the United States or in any of these countries is concerned about the lives of innocent civilians, innocent people,'' Mr. Bush said Wednesday at a news conference here. ''And so, you weigh that very thoroughly against your actions. Having said that, international law in this case, the Chapter 7 sanctions, must be enforced.''
A convoy carrying more than 100 people from the United States Embassy - diplomats, dependents and the entire Marine guard detachment -crossed from Kuwait into Iraq on Thursday, leaving behind Ambassador Howell and fewer than a dozen aides. A senior White House official said, ''A few Marine guards aren't going to fight off the entire Iraqi Army.''
The diplomats who stayed behind risked being taken hostage, for Baghdad has said that envoys who remain in Kuwait after the deadline will lose diplomatic status.
Only India and Lebanon, among major nations, acceded to Iraqi orders to close their embassies. There were unofficial reports that the Philippines would also do so. But like the United States, most countries evacuated most of their staffs; Britain left only four diplomats in place, including Ambassador Michael Weston.
Suggesting that a showdown could be near, European officials said they had been told that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq would surround the embassies with troops. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney warned that this would be a mistake. A Belgian official said all of the European Community ambassadors might assemble in one place ''to make their expulsion as dramatic as possible.''
The Pentagon said Thursday that as many as 49,703 servicemen and women could be involved in the first two rounds of a limited reserve callup, 10,000 more than officials had said on Wednesday. Britain announced the dispatch of a second 12-plane squadron of Tornado attack aircraft, American minesweepers were dispatched to join the Persian Gulf flotilla and a United States military unit, the 7th Medical Command, was sent from Germany to Saudi Arabia. No Breakthrough at U.N. In another military development, officials said that American sailors had already boarded about a half-dozen merchant ships suspected of violating the United Nations embargo on Iraqi commerce.
Washington's effort to win explicit United Nations support for the naval blockade it has been leading yielded some progress as representatives of the five permanent members of the Security Council - the United States, France, Britain, China and the Soviet Union - sent a draft resolution to their Governments for review. Diplomats said France and Britain had accepted the wording of the proposal, but that Soviet objections had not yet been resolved.
Mr. Bush said in the news conference on Wednesday that he was willing to wait only a little longer for United Nations action before ordering American ships to use force to halt vessels that violate the sanctions.
As the Middle East crisis entered its fourth week, Iraq continued to move foreigners from Kuwait to Baghdad and its environs. Poles returning home reported that about three dozen Americans were taken last Friday to the Chemadex chemical plant at Al Qaim in western Iraq, where the Eastern Europeans had been working. American experts said the plant produces phosphorus fertilizers, not chemical weapons.
 
Outrage at Iraqi Broadcast
American officials, reportedly including Mr. Bush, were outraged by an Iraqi television broadcast on Thursday in which an avuncular President Hussein met with a number of hostages, playfully ruffling a small boy's hair. Most of the captives seemed to be British.
The broadcast seemed to be an attempt by Mr. Hussein, who has been denounced in the West as a bully, to demonstrate his benevolence toward individuals while signaling that an American attack on Iraq would inevitably cost the lives of Western women and children.
Richard A. Boucher, a State Department spokesman, denounced the broadcast as ''shameful theatrics.'' The British Foreign Office assailed it as a ''repulsive charade.''
Baghdad radio reported Thursday night that the Iraqi leader had authorized the release of a 15-year-old British youth who was separated from his family during the crisis. The broadcast gave his name as Alex Cameron Farni, but The Associated Press said that officials at the British Foreign Office in London later identified him as Alex Barnett. A spokesman for British Airways quoted by the news agency said the boy was traveling to the Gulf region from London without his family when his plane was stranded in Kuwait.
 
Elite Iraqi Troop Movements
The State Department said it had counted 56 Americans who were in the hands of the Iraqis - 41 seized in Iraq and 15 in Kuwait. Mr. Bush declared earlier this week that the 2,500 non-official Americans in Kuwait and the 530 in Iraq must now be considered hostages.
In Tokyo, the Japanese Foreign Ministry said that 178 Japanese had been flown in three groups to Baghdad from the Japanese Embassy in Kuwait, where they had taken refuge. Another group of 62 was reportedly following. Shortly before the movements, Japan announced its intention to help reimburse countries that supported United Nations sanctions against Iraq at considerable cost to their own domestic economies.
Two Under Secretaries of the United Nations met on Thursday with nine hostages at an undisclosed location about an hour's drive from Baghdad, a spokesman for the organization said.
The nationalities of the nine captives, men between the ages of 17 and 63, were not given. The United Nations Under Secretaries, Virenda Dayal and Kofi Annan, arrived in Iraq on Tuesday to seek the release of some of the thousands of foreigners, including 21,000 Westerners estimated to be trapped by the conflict.
A Pentagon official said Thursday night that there were signs that Iraq was pulling back elements of the elite Presidential Guard, the vanguard of the force that invaded Kuwait, from the Saudi border and replacing them with ''second stringers.''
 
Concern Over Soviet Advisers
The official said it was unclear why the guard units were pulling back. He suggested that Mr. Hussein may not want to entrench his elite fighters along the front lines, or that the Iraqi President fears coup attempts from within his ranks and needs the guard's help.
Jordan, which announced on Wednesday that it was closing its border with Iraq to all refugees, left it open for another day Thursday. At least 30,000 more refugees poured through the Ruweishid border crossing as King Hussein of Jordan embarked on another peace-seeking mission to Arab capitals, starting with a trip to the Sudan.
Although Mr. Bush praised Soviet cooperation in American efforts as ''superb'' on Wednesday, United States officials said they were troubled by the presence of almost 200 Soviet military advisers in Iraq. Mr. Boucher said the Administration strongly believed ''that it is inappropriate to provide any form of military assistance to Iraq.''
The Soviet Union's reluctance to have the United Nations promptly endorse a blockade also irritated policy makers here.
 
'Mounting Toward a Peak'
Still, the Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman, Yuri Gremitskykh, pleased Washington with his comment Thursday that ''Iraq should change drastically the policy which it is pursuing now.'' He added, ''Baghdad has lost much, politically and morally, in the eyes of world public opinion by its illegal and inhumane actions against citizens of third countries.''
In Israel, which is separated from Iraq by an increasingly shaky Jordan, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir warned that the crisis was ''mounting toward a peak,'' and a civil-defense official urged citizens to stock up on food, tape their windows shut and mix a homemade antidote in anticipation of Iraqi use of poison gas.
But in Washington, military officers said the Bush Administration had canceled an earlier alert issued to two United States-based Ranger battalions, in the belief that their involvement would feed speculation about a commando-type thrust by American forces into Iraq or Kuwait.
Representative Dante B. Fascell, the Florida Democrat who heads the House Foreign Affairs Committee, called on the President to tell Congress in a joint session when lawmakers return in two weeks exactly what his intentions are in the Persian Gulf. Among other things, he said he wanted to know how the enormous military undertaking would be financed and whether other countries were ready to pay a share of costs.

HEADLINE: U.S. STOCKS PLUNGE ON HEAVY SELLING OVER CRISIS IN GULF

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stock prices plunged yesterday for the third day, falling to their lowest level in 13 months on growing concern over the crisis in the Persian Gulf.
The market, as measured by the Dow Jones industrial average, fell 76.73 points, or 3 percent, to 2,483.42. It has now lost 173 points, or more than 6 percent of its value, since Monday.
In Tokyo today, though, stocks turned up after taking a beating recently. The Nikkei index, which had lost 10 percent in the last two days, rose 428.13, or 1.8 percent, to close at 24,165.76. 
The plunge in the United States came as oil prices continued to rise amid bellicose talk in the Iraq-United States standoff. Crude oil for October delivery rose 71 cents, to $31.93 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. [Page D1.] Pace of Selling Picks Up An added disturbing note is that until yesterday the sharp fall in stock prices had taken place on relatively low volume, as many institutional investors shied away from trading. But that seems to be changing. Stanley Shopkorn, chief stock trader for Salomon Brothers, said, ''We're seeing an increase in institutional sell orders today for the first time.''
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange rose to more than 250 million shares, the heaviest since the day after the 190-point plunge in October 1989.
''There's a lot of panic out there,'' a leading money manager remarked. ''It may be over, but there's still a lot that could happen.''
Speaking of the day-after-day drop in the market, one trader said: ''This is like water torture, You can live through it, but it's certainly not pleasant. When you're in the midst of a bear trend, it can be excruciating. It wears you down.''
The Dow is now at its lowest level since July 6, 1989. Just over a month ago, on July 16, the average stood just shy of the 3,000 level, but has plummeted 17 percent since then. It has fallen 13 percent just in the three weeks since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.
Smaller stocks performed even worse yesterday. The Nasdaq composite index of over-the-counter issues fell 14.62 points, or 3.9 percent, to 360.22, its lowest level since Feb. 22, 1988.
Some traders said the situation in the Persian Gulf seemed far too fluid to do much more than to pull money out of the market. In addition, some said a growing number of individual investors were facing margin calls, which meant they were being asked to put up more cash for the stocks they had bought on credit.
''Everybody seems to be anticipating that war is going to break out by Monday,'' said E. E. Geduld, president of Herzog, Heine, Geduld, a brokerage firm dealing in over-the-counter stocks.
 
'Ultimate Pessimism'
In Boston, Robert G. Freedman, the chief portfolio manager for the John Hancock mutual funds, described the mood of the market as ''ultimate pessimism, extreme nervousness.''
''It seems like people are throwing out money just to get into cash,'' he said. ''It's panic selling.''
Since the Dow peaked in July, worries over corporate profits and a possible recession have been intensified by the Middle East crisis and the soaring price of oil.
Shares of oil companies had been strong, but even they fell yesterday. Texaco dropped $3.625, to $60.125, with more than a million shares changing hands. Chevron fell $3, to $75.625, and Exxon was off $1.75, to $49.625.
Expressing an opinion that seemed to be fairly widespread, Mr. Freedman said that while a lot of stocks had fallen to levels that were attractive, ''We're not doing anything.''
 
Keeping Their Cash
Noting that Hancock's mutual funds ordinarily would have all of their money in the market, Mr. Freedman said that the funds currently have $42 million, or 14 percent of their money, in cash. ''We're not panicking,'' he added. ''We're holding cash and starting to look at opportunities to buy some extremely discounted stock.''
He said he would ''probably start buying'' stock again when the Dow falls to around 2,450, which would mean that it would have to drop another 33 points. If the current trend continues, that might be very soon.
The selling began at the opening bell yesterday, following selloffs in other stock markets around the world. In Japan, the Nikkei average fell 5.8 percent yesterday.
By 9:54 A.M., less than 30 minutes after trading began, the Dow had tumbled more than 50 points, prompting the New York Stock Exchange to invoke a rule that makes index arbitrage trading virtually impossible. In such trades, investors sell stocks and buy stock index futures. With the Dow down more than 50 points all day, the rule stayed in effect throughout the session.
Index arbitrage is a form of program trading, which has been severely criticized for past market declines. But it seems to have played only a minor role in this week's drop. Birinyi Associates, a research firm, concluded that program trading probably had a net effect yesterday of raising prices slightly from where they otherwise would have been.
 
Losses Were Widespread
Every stock market indicator fell to the lowest level in at least a year. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 9.49 points, or 3 percent, to 307.06, its lowest since May 11, 1989. The New York Stock Exchange index fell 5.34 points, or 3.07 percent, to 168.88, its lowest mark since April 13, 1989. The American Stock Exchange market-value index was off 8.54 points, or 2.63 percent, to 315.85, the lowest close since Jan. 12, 1989.
Showing the bearish mood that investors were in, 1,640 stocks declined and only 157 advanced in Big Board trading. No common stock on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday rose as much as $1, with the largest gain being 87.5 cents for Nuevo Energy, which finished at $9.625.
While only one issue hit a new high - an Alabama Power preferred stock - 707 hit new lows, including General Electric, American Telephone and Telegraph, General Motors, Citicorp and Toys ''R'' Us. That was the highest number of new lows for any session since the 1987 stock market crash. The number of stocks falling in price was also the highest for any session since then.
Many stocks are now so low that companies are beginning to think about buying back some of their own shares. The latest to announce repurchases were Intel, the high-technology company, and Fannie Mae, which buys and sells mortgages. Intel, which is traded in the over-the-counter market, rose $1.125, to $33.25, but Fannie Mae, traded on the Big Board, fell to a new low of $24.875 before rising to $26.625, down 12.5 cents. Southern Companyd(Alabama Power)A.T.&T.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 27, 1990, Monday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Friday about the performance of the stock market misstated the ranking of the New York Stock Exchange volume on Thursday.
The total of 250.4 million shares traded was the third-heaviest volume, not the heaviest, since the day after the 190-point plunge in October 1989.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

HEADLINE: In Europe, Ambiance Costs $10

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Aug. 23

 BODY:
It's one thing to hand over an unfamiliar bill or a few strange coins after a pleasant hour at a Paris sidewalk cafe. It's quite a different thing to find that you've just spent $10 for a Coke and sandwich and a touch of ambiance.
''Don't think in dollars if you want to enjoy yourself,'' wily world travelers advise. But that is just what American tourists have been doing throughout Western Europe this summer. And the results have insured that their vacations will never be forgotten. 
''People used to talk about the rich Americans coming to Europe and buying everything in sight,'' said Brent Morris of Boulder, Colo., as he and his wife looked at shop windows in Vienna. ''Now we can't buy a thing. Everything is more expensive, even McDonald's.''
The explanation is quite simple. The dollar is considerably weaker against Western European currencies than it was last year. In fact, the dollar has fallen to its lowest level against the West German mark since the currency was created in 1948, setting a new low today.
Nonetheless, many American tourists come psychologically unprepared. ''Eight years ago, prices were just the opposite,'' recalled George Lamartiniere, who was visiting Paris from Alabama. ''This time we had to give up going to Rome and Florence and stayed with friends in Grenoble to economize.''
 
Sneakers for $65 in London
Marcia Burros, who is from Washington, said she was going about London on foot to save money. But then she looked down at her toes sticking out of her sneakers. ''Do you know sneakers cost $65 here?'' she said. ''How do the Britishers do it?''
From clothes to gasoline, meals to hotels, prices are now higher in Western Europe than in the United States. And often the little things hurt most. ''I had to listen to my wife complaining all morning about the price of one coffee, one orange juice and one croissant,'' Charles Reilly from McLean, Va., lamented as he wandered around Paris.
Some tourists, caught short of cash or traveler's checks, lean on their credit cards, determined not to ruin their vacations. But many admit to taking buses rather than taxis, to skipping lunch in favor of a good dinner and even to forgoing presents for the family. ''I can buy the same thing cheaper back home,'' a New Yorker in Vienna said.
 
Despite Costs, They Keep Coming
Surprisingly, though, Americans have not stopped coming. During the first three months of 1990, the number of Americans entering Italy rose by 4 percent over last year. Swiss officials anticipate a 5 percent increase in American visitors this year. France's tourist promotion agency also reported 10 percent more Americans with Paris as their destination this year. Yet much of the increase may have happened before the dollar really began to fall in June.
With rare exceptions, Americans have been replaced by Japanese - although the yen is also weak in Europe - and Italians as the big spenders in many European capitals. But whether in search of culture, good food or family roots, millions of Americans continue to be drawn to Europe, principally Britain, France and Italy.
Once here, though, many this year are spending as much time looking at price tags as at the sights. And those who visit more than one country become experts: taxis are cheaper in Madrid than in Rome;, meals are cheaper in Brussels than in Oslo, and the sales tax in Paris is one to watch out for.
 
Eastern Europe Is a Bargain
Those who travel first in Eastern Europe and then come here are in for a bigger shock than if they had come directly from New York. ''We came in from Czechoslovakia and the price of everything more than doubled,'' Mark Gallagher, a teacher from Manheim, Pa., noted after arriving in West Berlin. ''There a soft drink cost 15 cents. Here it costs $1.20.'' Since the economic unification of the two Germanys last month, however, East Germany is no longer a bargain. Scott Gordon from Boston paid the equivalent of $17 for a night at a youth hostel in East Berlin, and he thought the rate a bit high. At the other end of the scale, a double room at the legendary Ritz in Paris costs $590 a night.
In theory, with most major European currencies except the British pound following each other, prices should not vary much within the region. But frequently they do. A Coca-Cola costs the equivalent of $1.25 in Berlin and $3 in Rome, a medium-priced dinner for two without drinks costs $70 in Geneva and $130 in Rome, a medium-priced hotel costs $80 in Vienna and $160 in Rome.
 
'We're All Feeling the Pinch'
Indeed, By most accounts, Rome prices are hard to top. Sherri McFarran, from Lexington, Ky., said Italians had not heard that Americans are no longer rich. ''I was insulted by a taxi driver because I turned down his service for a bus,'' she said. ''Shopkeepers insist on hyping prices, not realizing that, with the dollar so low, we're all feeling the pinch.''
Mexite Begiri, visiting Rome from Worcester, Mass., said she found Italy much more expensive than Germany and the Netherlands. ''Food is twice as high as back home,'' she said. ''Take pizza. For $3 or $4, you get a full 10-inch pan in the States. Here you get a strip and it isn't as tasty.''
Her husband, Agim, added his experience. ''Gasoline must be five times higher here than in the U.S., and highway tolls are outrageous,'' he said. ''The trip from Bari to Rome cost me $33 when it would have cost me $18 to go from Boston to Toronto.'' The latter trip is nearly twice as long.
If not five times more, gasoline prices in Europe are more than triple what Americans pay at home. Recent averages in the United States for a gallon of unleaded was $1.21 for self-service and $1.42 for unleaded, according to Runzheimer International, a Chicago-based company that tracks travel costs.
In London last Friday, gasoline was about $4.89 for an American gallon. In Paris, it cost $4.03; in Rome, $4.98.
 
Spain No Longer a Bargain
Spain, which for many years was a penny pincher's paradise, is rapidly catching up with the prices elsewhere in Europe, and the dollar has done its bit. Five years ago, one dollar produced twice as many pesetas as today. ''I bought a pair of Levi's in New York for $20,'' said Patricia Lopez-Calleja, a young Spaniard who now lives in New York. ''Here it would cost me four times as much.''
Young people backpacking with crumpled copies of ''Europe on $25 a Day'' find they have to improvise to make ends meet. ''We had to sleep on radiator vents on the streets because the hotels in Paris are so expensive,'' recounted Brian Pagnella, a 19-year-old from Bowling Green, Miss. ''At least those vents have hot air blowing out.''

HEADLINE: Kohl Hails 'Day of Joy' for Reuniting Germans

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: BONN, Aug. 23

 BODY:
Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany, a champion of German unification, basked in his triumph today with East Germany's decision to accede to the West on Oct. 3.
''Today is a day of joy for all Germans,'' he said in an address to a special session of the Parliament.
''Wednesday, Oct. 3, will be the day of reunification,'' said a beaming Mr. Kohl, who was often interrupted by applause from the parliamentarians and a delegation from the East German Parliament. ''It will be a great day in the history of our people.'' 
East Berlin's Parliament had voted in the early hours today to join West Germany in six weeks, less than a year after the breaching in November of the Berlin wall that symbolized the collapse of the Communist regime in East Berlin.
 
Week of Political Upheaval
The rush to decide on a date for formal reunification followed a week of political upheaval in East Germany's ruling coalition.
Unity was first planned to coincide with all-German elections Dec. 2. But East Germany's economy deteriorated so rapidly after it fused with West Germany's on July 1 that calls grew for Bonn to take full control through quick political union.
In his address to the West German Parliament, which later ratified a treaty setting the rules for December's election, Mr. Kohl said the unification was without precedent in recent European history.
''It is happening without war, without bloody revolution or violence and with the full agreement of our friends, partners and neighbors in West and East,'' he said.
Mr. Kohl thanked a long list of Germany's friends for helping make the dream of unity a reality after 40 years of division. First came the three Western World War II powers - the United States, Britain and France - ''who for decades have insured our security.''
''I name in particular our American friends and foremost President Bush who has proved himself to be a true friend of the Germans in the past months,'' Mr. Kohl said.
The French President, Francois Mitterrand, also came in for praise for supporting unification, which Mr. Kohl also said would have been impossible without the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
''Through his reform policies and the new thinking in Soviet foreign policy the fundamental change in Germany and in Europe has been made possible,'' Mr. Kohl said.
He also thanked the people and leaders of other Eastern European countries, especially Hungary, whose decision to let East Germans cross its borders to the West last summer led to an exodus and sparked East Germany's peaceful revolution.
 
The 'Inhuman Border'
Turning to the dark days of the cold war, when the superpowers stared at each other across the German divide, Mr. Kohl said unification had been achieved through blood and suffering.
Thousands of Germans died in the immediate post-war years and an estimated 75,000 were imprisoned by East Germany's former Stalinist leaders for political reasons, he said.
He also remembered the nearly 200 East Germans killed for trying to flee to the West across what he called the ''inhuman border'' that divided the two Germanys. Mr. Kohl's opponent for chancellor in December's election, Oskar Lafontaine, said the decision on the date for unification ended an unbearable tug-of-war over the timetable for the event.
''Now we must do all we can to steady the situation in East Germany and fight the ever-worsening economic crisis,'' said the Social Democratic leader in a statement.

HEADLINE: Confrontation in the Gulf;
Shrinking Supplies of Food Evident in Iraq, Reports Say

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
While the American-led military buildup in Saudi Arabia continues, another weapon, the withholding of food for Iraq under the United Nations trade embargo, is beginning to cause hardship, a variety of reports from officials of Western governments and food experts say.
The Iraqi leadership is struggling to cope with shrinking supplies and an abrupt cutoff of imported food that, until the crisis, was fulfilling three-quarters of the country's nutritional needs. Eggs, sugar, cooking oil, fruits and vegetables have disappeared from store shelves in Baghdad or are in short supply, according to reports from the Iraqi capital that were confirmed by American Government officials.
Food imports from Jordan, the only neighboring state not to have fully committed to barring trade with Iraq, have not kept up with Iraqi consumption. And even these supplies may be dwindling as ships with Iraqi-bound cargos are being discouraged by United States Navy vessels from entering the Jordanian port of Aqaba, said a State Department official who spoke on condition that he not be identified. ''The clear impression is that they are running down their food supplies,'' he said. 
One possible source of food for Iraq is Iran, which President Saddam Hussein of Iraq is wooing by returning lands occupied in their eight-year war and by releasing Iranian prisoners. But Iran has so far shown no interest in actively helping Iraq, and in any case, routes between the countries are not adequate to support the large food shipments Iraq needs, grain industry experts say.
Mr. Hussein has exhorted his people to eat less, threatening to limit the food that foreign residents receive and announcing that merchants who hoard supplies will be sentenced to death.
 
'I Think They Can Make It'
But it remains unclear how quickly the pressure of the embargo will mount and at what point it might induce the Iraqi government to come to terms with those blocking its supplies. ''I don't think hunger is going to make the regime capitulate,'' said Daniel Pipes, the director of the Foreign Policy Research Institute in Philadelphia. ''Unless we start bombing bridges and factories, there will be hardship but I think they can make it.''
Iraq's people are among the better fed in the Middle East, and their food supplies could last months with rationing, Mr. Pipes said. Farmers could also plant more grain for human consumption and less for animal feed next spring. Iraq has indicated that its soldiers may be fed before civilians.
President Hussein does not appear to have anticipated an embargo on food before his Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, said John P. Parker, a Department of Agriculture economist who studies Middle Eastern food supplies. While Iraq dramatically increased its food stockpiles on the eve of its 1980 invasion of Iran, these stockpiles fell every year from 1984 to 1990 and had reached unusually low levels by July 25, he said.
Because Iraq's population was growing in this period, the food supply for each person fell and the country was left with only a two-month supply of wheat as of July, Mr. Parker said.
Reports by people who fled from Kuwait after the country was overrun say Iraqi soldiers began asking local residents for food. ''It was like the old method of sending armies foraging for food on the ground they occupy,'' said a Kuwaiti businessman in a telephone conversation from Saudi Arabia, where he arrived four days after the invasion.
 
Some Stores Looted in Kuwait
The average Iraqi may notice shortages of sugar and tea first, he said. ''They drink a lot of tea, and heavy tea. It's like triple the amount of tea Westerners use, and that, of course, means you need a lot of sugar.''
An executive of a multinational corporation with employees trapped in Baghdad said yesterday that ''there is a shortage of certain food items,'' including eggs. The executive spoke only on the condition that neither he nor his company be identified.
Many stores in Kuwait were looted immediately after the invasion but others kept their shelves stocked, said Katherine C. Baker, an American store manager who escaped from Kuwait on Aug. 12. She said the banks were closed, she had little money and lived on potatoes, rice and pasta.
The amount of food seized by Iraq from Kuwait is unclear but may prove important, the State Department official said. The Kuwaiti businessman said his country had enough canned goods stored in warehouses to feed its population for four to six months, and Iraqi soldiers took over these warehouses and sent Kuwaiti employees home soon after the invasion.
But the canned goods may not feed Iraq for long. In 1987, Kuwait had 1.87 million people; Iraq's population was 16.1 million in 1986.
 
U.S. Supplies Had Been Cut
The United States cut subsidized food shipments to Iraq in half last year because of a financial scandal involving Government credit guarantees and an Italian bank, and Iraq had not found alternative suppliers.
The United Nations sanctions allow food shipments to Iraq and Kuwait to relieve famine only. The United States and the world's other major grain producers have said famine is not yet a problem. The American naval blockade includes food.
President Hussein's current predicament has been compounded by the failure of Iraqi agriculture to surmount problems like infertile land and inadequate irrigation.
 
Effects of Fabled Rivers
Two large rivers flow through Iraq, the Tigris and Euphrates, and their banks were the breadbasket of the Middle East in ancient times. Nearly five thousand years ago, the Sumerians built one of the world's first great civilizations there, while the wealth of the court of Harun ar-Rashid, an eighth-century caliph of Baghdad, was described in the famous work of Arab literature, ''Thousand and One Nights.''
But in the 12th century, the fields of Iraq became dry and less fertile after the Tigris began flowing faster and dug itself a deep channel instead of periodically flooding and distributing rich silt over the fields, said Engin D. Akarli, an associate professor of Middle Eastern history at Washington University in St. Louis.
Most of Kuwait is desert, and with the exception of some vegetables grown in greenhouses and limited shrimp fishing, the nation depends on imported food, Mr. Parker said.

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
How Old Votes Become New Political Liabilities

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23

 BODY:
Recorded votes in Congress have a habit of becoming campaign nightmares. To avoid them, lawmakers often jockey for voice votes on controversial legislation, so as not to have to risk going on the record.
But the legislative process is not always accommodating.
This year, a series of votes in April 1987 is among those coming back to haunt incumbents. The subject was the Government's first savings-and-loan rescue; the issue, a Reagan Administration plan that would have forced the industry to spend $15 billion of its own money to shut down and liquidate its sick members. 
The Administration's argument was that since industry lobbying was largely responsible for the loose regulatory policies leading the burgeoning S.& L. crisis, it should be responsible for cleaning up its own mess.
The United States League of Savings Institutions, the industry's lobbying dynamo, countered that no more than $5 billion was needed. Let Congress revisit the issue in a couple of years, the lobbyists argued. In the meantime, the economy of Texas could easily turn around.
The league prevailed, in the House Banking Committee and on the floor of the full House. Most industry experts now say those votes delayed a comprehensive clean-up of the largest financial scandal in the nation's history, and so drastically increased its cost.
One politician particularly feeling the aftereffects is Representative Stephen L. Neal, the North Carolina Democrat who sponsored the amendment to cut the Reagan Adminstration bailout proposal.
''The S.& L. fiasco is the No. 1 issue, and the $5 billion amendment is the major issue within the major issue,'' said Ken Bell, a former assistant United State Attorney for the Western Disrtrict of North Carolina, who faces Mr. Neal in the fall election.
Mr. Bell points to Mr. Neal's comments at the time on the House floor. ''People have said that if we do not agree to the larger amount, there will be a taxpayer bailout,'' Mr. Neal was recorded as saying three years ago. ''There is nothing in the bill or in anyone's reasonable expectation that that would be the case.''
Today, Mr. Neal is far from eager to discuss his amendment. But through a spokesman, he defends the measure this way: Even if the Reagan Administration's $15 billion plan had passed, it would have been woefully inadequate. The spokesman added that from Mr. Neal's perspective, Mr. Bell had not been able to make the issue a major concern.
Among the 23 members of the House Banking Committee who voted for the Neal amendment in 1987 and are still on panel, only three are Republicans. Two, Norman Shumway and David Drier, are from California, and one, Bill McCollum, is from Florida. Both states have very large savings and loan interests, and all three Representatives have received contributions from those interests.
''This plan is more than adequate for the needs of both the industry and the nation,'' Mr. Shumway declared when the issue was debated on the House floor.
''Why should we risk the solvency of the healthy institutions?'' asked Mr. Drier. ''If there are still problems we can revisit the issue in two years,''
Mr. Shumway is retiring from Congress this year. Mr. Drier and Mr. McCollum have very little opposition in their districts.
That is not the case for one of the most senior Democrats on the Banking Committee, Doug Barnard of Georgia. The eight-term incumbent is under heavy attack by his opponent, Sam Jones, for his involvment with the savings and loan industry, and especially for a $20,000 contribution from Charles H. Keating Jr., owner of the failed Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif., and a focus of the savings and loan affair.
As for the Neal amendment, Mr. Jones takes issue with Mr. Barnard - for not voting on it. He was the only member of the House Banking Committee to abstain, and the amendment carried by only one vote. His vote against it would have meant a tie and a defeat for the amendment.
''Doug Barnard took a walk away from the American people that day,'' Mr. Jones said recently. Mr. Barnard will not say exactly why he abstained but said ''we were being pulled by a lot of forces,'' including pressure by the House leadership to support the $5 billion number. ''I probably should have voted for the $15 billion,'' he said.

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%); 

STATE: NORTH CAROLINA, USA (92%); CALIFORNIA, USA (79%);
