HEADLINE: U.S. Already in a Recession, More Than 60 Percent Say

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23

 BODY:
Americans have turned decidedly sour about the state of the economy, with the perception that the country is in a recession now shared by 6 out of 10 of them, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.
This negative mood has been developing for months, various polls indicate, but it has increased significantly since Iraqi tanks rolled into Kuwait three weeks ago and set off a continuing wave of bad economic news: rising oil prices, stumbling stocks and climbing interest rates.
About 55 percent of the public says the economy is growing worse, according to the Times/CBS News Poll. The last time the poll found so large a proportion of Americans dour about the economy was in 1981 and 1982, as the country tumbled into the worst recession since World War II.
 
Prospects for Economy
About 40 percent of the respondents in the current survey said the economy was staying the same. Only 4 percent said they thought it was getting better. 
The survey was conducted in telephone interviews with 1,422 Americans from Aug. 16 to Aug. 19. The margin of sampling error was plus or minus three percentage points.
Attitudes about the economy can have a powerful influence both on actual economic conditions and on politics.
Politically, a weak economy generally spells trouble for the party in control of the White House, although at the moment acclaim for his handling of foreign policy is carrying President Bush above troubles on the home front and may even be protecting his party from defections that might otherwise be spurred by bad economic times.
Then there is the effect that public attitudes have on the actual economy.
 
Various Definitions of Decline
Academics generally define a recession as two consecutive quarters of declining national output. Although there has not been even a single quarter of declining output in years, many economists say the definition fails to capture fully the varieties of hard times, like rolling regional recessions, that can develop at the bottom of the modern business cycle.
In any case, consumers' pessimism about the economy discourages them from making purchases - particularly high-price items like homes, cars and major appliances - and can thus help produce, or deepen, the very recession Americans are convinced is already here. The Federal Government, in fact, uses consumer confidence, as measured in a monthly report by the University of Michigan, as part of its index of leading economic indicators, which is designed to presage future movement in the economy.
Richard T. Curtin, who directs the Michigan survey, said there was an unusually sharp downturn in consumer confidence immediately after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. ''The mood of consumers was quite bleak,'' he said. It has rebounded somewhat since then but will still be down over all for August, he said.
In the latest New York Times/CBS News survey, attitudes about the economy varied considerably from region to region, just as conditions have varied. Nearly two-thirds of the respondents in the Northeast, where actual economic conditions have been poorest, said the economy was getting worse, while only about half of those in the South and the Central States said so. About 6 of 10 Westerners saw worsening economic conditions.
 
Rise in Pessimism
But pessimism increased across the country in August, and more than half the respondents in each of the four regions now say the country is in a recession.
The jolt that Iraq dealt to American economic confidence is clearly visible in a series of polls conducted before and after Aug. 2, the date of the invasion.
In a poll conducted by The Wall Street Journal and NBC News in May, only 30 percent of the respondents said they thought there would be a recession this year, and 57 percent said not. In a poll by CBS News six days after the invasion, 49 percent of Americans said they thought the country was in a recession, and 42 percent said not. In a poll by The New York Times eight days after the invasion, 52 percent said the country was in a recession, and 35 percent said not. In the latest survey, 61 percent said the country was in a recession, and 32 percent said not.
Mr. Curtin and other analysts said that so sharp a turn in so brief a period was unusual and was almost always associated with major events. For example, consumer confidence took a sharp slide after the stock market crash of 1987. The extent of the impact that such events have on consumer purchasing, and thus on the economy, depends largely on whether attitudes continue to deteriorate or begin to improve, Mr. Curtin said.
Analysts attributed the current dive in confidence to a combination of actual effects on Americans' pocketbooks - like higher gasoline prices - and the intensity with which television and newspapers have focused on the damage that the turmoil in the Persian Gulf could do to the American economy.
 
Talk of Spending's Benefits
There has been very little discussion in the news media of the possible economic benefits that various regions might derive from the military spending associated with the Persian Gulf buildup.
The latest survey comes in the wake of evidence that economic confidence among Americans was already deteriorating before the invasion of Kuwait. Indeed, that deterioration was the biggest concern of Republican strategists, and one of the unspoken hopes of Democratic strategists, as the Congressional elections approached.
Market Opinion Research, a polling concern that has many Republican clients, has found a steady increase since March in the percentage of Americans who say they believe the economy has worsened. In March, 32 percent of registered voters said they thought the economy had grown worse, Market Opinion Research said. In May the figure was 41 percent, and in a poll conducted in late July and early August, just as Iraq invaded Kuwait, the figure climbed to 52 percent.
In the latest Times/CBS News Poll, blacks were more likely to view the state of the economy as ''very bad,'' with 25 percent of blacks and 14 percent of whites saying so. Blacks and other economically disadvantaged groups are often more vulnerable to economic downturns. But there was no difference between the opinions of blacks and whites when they were asked in which direction the economy was going: more than half of both groups said it was getting worse.
Women were more pessimistic than men were, with 60 percent of women and 49 percent of men saying the economy was getting worse.
 
Joblessness vs. Inflation
Americans were about evenly divided over whether the biggest economic problem facing the country was unemployment or inflation. Forty-one percent picked unemployment, which was at 5.5 percent in July, and 45 percent picked inflation, which was running at an annual rate of about 5 percent before the latest round of gasoline price increases. During the high inflation of the late 1970's and early 1980's, Americans overwhelmingly picked inflation when asked this question, and during the 1982 recession, a majority picked unemployment.
Stanley Greenburg, a Democratic poll taker, said he believed Americans were expressing their economic worries largely by complaining about higher costs, even when the problem might be lagging income rather than serious inflation. He said this attitude was underlying political sentiments as diverse as the resistance to taxes and the objection to soaring auto insurance premiums. In the Times/CBS News survey, 43 percent of respondents said they were finding it more difficult today than a year ago to make ends meet; 47 percent said they were finding it about the same, and 10 percent said they were finding it easier.
Some 26 percent said the chances were high that an adult in their family would be out of work and looking for a job in the next year, and 4 percent said someone was already out of work in their family.
As for inflation, 37 percent said they expected prices to go up a lot in the next year. Virtually everyone, 89 percent of the respondents, said they expected prices to go up at least a little in the next year.
Economic conditions are thought of by politicians and political analysts alike as one of the most powerful influences on elections - particularly midterm elections, in which issues of foreign policy are generally secondary. In forming a judgment about the economy, voters go beyond the immediate condition of their own pocketbooks to an assessment of general conditions, said Michael S. Lewis-Beck, a professor of political science at the University of Iowa.
 
A Number of Influences
Everything from layoffs in the community to reports on the nightly news about interest rates can influence that judgment, said Mr. Curtin, who directs the University of Michigan's Survey of Consumers.
The decline in the public's assessment of the economy has not been followed by a decline in public approval for Mr. Bush's handling of the economy. Such a decline would otherwise have been expected were it not for the boost Mr. Bush is getting from his handling of the Persian Gulf crisis.
In the Times/CBS News survey, 45 percent of Americans said they approved of Mr. Bush's handling of the economy and 44 percent expressed disapproval. These results were virtually unchanged from a survey in June.
A similar effect may be occurring in the important question of party identification. One of the few forces that rivals economics in influencing how voters cast their ballots is the party with which they identify. But in the latest survey, deterioration in attitudes about the economy did not shake loose any support for the Republican party.
In fact, the percentage of Americans identifying themselves as Republicans or leaning toward the Republicans edged up, to 47 percent from 44 percent in a Times/CBS survey in June; and the percentage saying they considered themselves Democrats or closer to the Democrats slipped, to 43 percent from 44 in the June survey.
Although this could be a statistical blip, it is sure to be watched closely by political strategists in both parties.
 
How the Survey Was Conducted
The New York Times/CBS News Poll was based on telephone interviews conducted with 1,422 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii, from Aug. 16 to 19.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the country. The exchanges were chosen to assure that each region of the country was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. The numbers were then screened to limit calls to residences.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and the number of residential telephone lines and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to region, race, sex, age and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20, the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points, in either direction, from what would have been obtained by interviewing all American adults.
The percentages reported are the particular results most likely to match what would be obtained by seeking out all adult Americans. Other possible percentages are progressively less likely the more they differ from the reported results.
The potential sampling error for smaller subgroups is larger. For example, for those in the northeast region of the country, it is plus or minus six percentage points.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll.

HEADLINE: Water Under A-Plant Is Found to Be Tainted

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: GORE, Okla., Aug. 23

 BODY:
Workers excavating storage tanks at a plant that processes uranium found levels of radioactive uranium in underground water that were as much as 35,000 times higher than Federal safety standards allow, officials said today.
Ron Adkisson, an official of Sequoyah Fuels Corporation, the plant's operator, said that the contamination had been contained in the plant's restricted area and that there was no danger to the public. 
The United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission is investigating.
Mr. Adkisson said workers discovered the contaminated water on Wednesday, while the plant was closed for annual maintenance.
Plant officials said they believed that the uranium had leaked years ago from a building where pure uranium is dissolved using an acid.
None of the company's 243 workers were exposed to radiation, he said, and no evacuations were ordered at the plant, 60 miles southeast of Tulsa.
Mr. Adkisson said he did not know when the factory, including a uranium conversion plant and a uranium hexafluoride reduction plant, would be reopened.
Sequoyah is a unit of General Atomics of San Diego.

HEADLINE: F.D.A. Defends Milk-Producing Drug in Study

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23

 BODY:
The Food and Drug Administration said in a study to be published on Friday that a genetically engineered growth hormone that increases milk production in dairy cows was harmless to human health.
With the nine-page article in the journal Science, the 84-year-old agency is for the first time opening for public review the full array of confidential safety studies on which decisions to approve or disapprove a new drug are based. The agency took the unusual step, an official said, to explain and defend itself against critics of the hormone's safety and of the F.D.A.'s review process.
In 1985, the agency approved the experimental use of the drug, bovine growth hormone, in dairy herds around the country and said the milk produced by test animals was safe to market. Final approval of the drug is expected next year after the agency finishes evaluating the drug's effect on cows. 
But the drug has been criticized as an economic threat to small farmers and a hazard to health by a coalition of farm and environmental groups that are campaigning to outlaw its use.
''It had become well-known that this drug was being developed and questions about its safety and the impact on family farms came up,'' Dr. Gerald B. Guest, the director of the F.D.A.'s Center for Veterinary Medicine, said in a telephone interview. ''People were casting doubt on our review. There was a credibility question involved that we felt needed a response.'' #4 Companies in Campaign The agency's extraordinary action to explain why it concluded that the hormone is harmless is part of a campaign by the four companies developing the drug and portions of the dairy industry to calm the public's concern about bovine growth hormone. One reason for the F.D.A. review was a request last year by the National Milk Producers Federation, the industry's principal trade group. The review could not have been conducted without the permission of the manufacturers to disclose their own confidential studies on the safety of the drug.
The $1 million campaign, begun on July 11, has been planned since 1986 by the National Dairy Promotion and Research Board, a farmer-supported public relations and advertising group. The campaign includes consumer surveys, advertising, public relations efforts and attempts to convince physicians and pediatricians that the hormone is safe, according to the board's internal documents obtained by the Foundation on Economic Trends, a Washington-based group that opposes the hormone. $500 Million in Development This week, The Journal of the American Medical Association published an article and an editorial asserting that all available scientific evidence showed that the genetically engineered drug was safe. The articles were written by scientists from the Washington University School of Medicine in St. Louis, and Cornell University in Ithaca, N.Y., who have received research grants from the Monsanto Chemical Company, one of the drug's manufacturers.
More than $500 million has been invested in research and development of the drug by the manufacturers - Monsanto, the American Cyanamid Company, Eli Lilly & Company and the Upjohn Company - who say it will make dairy farming easier, keep milk prices down, and do so without any harm to health. The hormone's success or failure in the marketplace is seen by most industry analysts as pivotal to the future development of other products of genetic engineering intended for use on farms.
 
Some Farmers Opposed
Opposing the hormone's use is a coalition of farm groups and environmental organizations in the Middle West, New York, and New England led by Jeremy Rifkin, president of the Foundation on Economic Trends, a public research group. Mr. Rifkin began his campaign against bovine growth hormone four years ago in Wisconsin by asserting that it would drive up milk production, lower prices and cause thousands of dairy farmers to go out of business. Since last year, he has focused his criticism on the drug's effects on health, which he says have not been adequately evaluated by the F.D.A.
The article in Science, by two scientists in the Center for Veterinary Medicine, Judith C. Juskevitch and C. Greg Guyer, summarizes more than 120 safety studies submitted by the manufacturers.
The authors said that genetically engineered bovine growth hormone, which is produced by altered bacteria, is nearly identical in chemical structure to natural bovine growth hormone, which appears in minute concentrations in milk.
 
Insulin-Like Growth Factor
The article said the F.D.A. has paid particular attention to concentrations of another protein, insulin-like growth factor, that are higher in milk from cows treated with the hormone than in untreated cows. Insulin-like growth factor, a protein produced by the liver, helps to regulate production of growth hormone in warm-blooded animals, including man.
Some scientists believe that higher levels of insulin-like growth factor in the blood could effect development in babies and small children. But the authors said the concentrations of the growth factor in milk from cows treated with bovine growth hormone are roughly the same as the concentrations in human breast milk.
 
Drug Temporarily Banned
Last spring, Wisconsin and Minnesota temporarily banned the sale or commercial use of bovine growth hormone, the first time in American history a farm product has been banned before it was approved for commercial sales.
Among those joining Mr. Rifkin in questioning the F.D.A. review of bovine growth hormone were two lawmakers from dairy states, Senator Patrick J. Leahy, a Democrat of Vermont, the chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, and Representative John Conyers Jr., a Democrat of Michigan, the chairman of the House Government Operations Committee.
Both lawmakers requested separate investigations of the agency's review. One inquiry is being conducted by the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, and the other is being conducted by the Inspector General of the Department of Health and Human Services.

HEADLINE: FOOTBALL: The Making of a Quarterback;
U.S.C.'s Marinovich Was Raised According to a Game Plan

BYLINE: By MALCOLM MORAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
The man is sitting in his office at a fitness center, looking at the figure on the television screen. The television is on a chair, resting upon the book ''Secrets of Soviet Sports Fitness and Training.'' The figure on the screen is throwing footballs, viewed from the side and the front in normal and slow motion.
As the balls are thrown, an impassive voice on the tape provides an analysis:
''Notice first the position of your body as your front foot lands. The body is leaning back a little bit more than we'd like to see. We'd like to have your weight balanced between your feet, the body more straight upright. This is going to help you to transfer your weight over your front foot as you throw. . . . By transferring your weight forward, it's going to help you throw harder with better energy transfer . . . .''
''Interesting, huh?'' said Marv Marinovich, captain of the 1962 University of Southern California Trojans, a former lineman with the Oakland Raiders, a onetime assistant pro coach, an expert on fitness and nutrition and the father of the image on the screen. 
Todd Marinovich, starting his sophomore season at the age of 21, has already exceeded the expectations surrounding the most highly anticipated U.S.C. football player since O. J. Simpson brought impressive junior-college credentials here more than two decades ago.
 
Already N.F.L. Material
After a freshman season in which Marinovich threw for 2,578 yards and completed 62.2 percent of his passes, the U.S.C. coach, Larry Smith, has already grown apprehensive that the willingness of the National Football League to accept underclassmen could end the college career of Marinovich after just two seasons.
That possibility is just one aspect of the economic options and competitive pressures that have been reflected in abrupt and radical changes for high-profile college quarterbacks this season.
Andre Ware, now with the Detroit Lions, became the second consecutive Heisman Trophy winner to leave for the N.F.L. with a year of college eligibility remaining. Chris Weinke, who chose Florida State over approximately 70 other schools, recently signed a baseball contract with the Toronto Blue Jays before playing a game for the Seminoles. And Bret Johnson of U.C.L.A., whose progress had been compared closely with that of Marinovich since high school, left the team this week after losing the starting position. But for now, the presence of Marinovich raises a larger question: As a career is guided by computerized analysis and carefully planned direction, by the exercises at a young age, the diet, the punishment and discipline, would it be an overstatement to say Todd Marinovich has become a prototype for the elite football player of the 1990's?
''I don't think so,'' Marv Marinovich said, ''and the people I have dealt with all believe that. In East Germany, that's how they've gotten to the top, with attention to detail and focusing on biomechanics.''
 
A Star is Conceived
The father sits in his office in Anaheim, and smiles as he tries to remember the earliest plans for his son, the vitamins and minerals that were taken before the child was conceived.
''A lot of minerals,'' he said. ''Potassium. Magnesium. Vitamin E. Vitamin C. Zinc. Of course, all your B-complex vitamins.'' Marv Marinovich chuckled. ''We used to eat a lot of sprouts,'' he said.
On the wall behind his desk, not far from seven of his son's trophies, is the magazine cover that established the image that identified a high school student as ''ROBO QB.''
''To me, the Robo quarterback means the guy has all the equipment,'' the father said. ''Everything in sync. Everything balanced. The perfect machine. From a training standpoint, not that Todd is that, but the appearance of that is a positive situation.
''You could never be too good with your mechanics of throwing. You can never be too focused, mentally. You can never have too good a vision. You strive for those things. The idea of Robo, the ultimate decision-making trigger machine.''
A freeway drive away, the ultimate football prodigy sits in the sun outside the cafeteria. He is asked about the label. ''I don't know what that really means,'' he said. ''I think people can get the false idea of what I'm all about.''
The quarterback of the 90's is a child of the 60's, born on the fourth of July, 1969. His light red hair creeps down his neck toward his shoulders. His earth-shoe sandals appear as if they were borrowed from another college generation. When Todd Marinovich was asked once for his favorite musicians, his response was Neil Young and Led Zeppelin. His ambition, after an N.F.L. career, is to open an art gallery and be able to paint in seclusion near the ocean.
 
'Total Control'
The quarterback talks about bringing his sense of creativity to the field. ''There's nothing like it,'' he said. ''You have total control on the field. You're the guy, and everyone in the stands is looking at you. Even the players are looking for you to make things happen.''
Last Sept. 30, just over a month after a knee injury to Pat O'Hara suddenly made Marinovich the starter, he produced a stirring finish in his fourth college game. He not only pulled out a 1-point victory over Washington State with 4 seconds to play, but also elicited a telephone call two days later from an excited fan named Ronald Reagan.
Marinovich is a fine-arts major who aspires to have an exhibition of his paintings and drawings on campus. ''So many times, at school, at home, it was my biggest release,'' he said. ''I'd go out and I'd just lose myself. I was so engrossed in starting something from scratch and watching it turn into something.'' The father said that was planned, too. ''I always thought, when I have a child, I hope I'll be able to provide a near-perfect environment for him,'' Marv Marinovich said. ''We didn't start out to produce a quarterback, or a football player. We didn't want to do it the way everybody else did it. We wanted to try to do our best to do a better job.
''And I'm not just talking about fitness,'' he went on. ''I'm talking about enriched mental capabilities, music and art. The ex-wife, every day, would go to museums, would plan park excursions, classical music, artistic expression. And it just happened that Todd showed an ability in sports, and it was something he wanted to do.''
From the time he was a young athlete, Marv Marinovich had searched for answers to questions about how the body works.
''I can remember asking my dad: 'What can I do to improve my performance? What would be the plan?' ''
His career became an endless search. He studied the biomechanics of running, metabolism, and nutrition at a time when many football coaches clung to the belief that water breaks were harmful to an athlete's sense of purpose.
He researched philosophies of athletic development in Eastern Europe. He investigated the concepts of visualization and mental rehearsal. The father made the same demands of his son that he had made of himself.
Before Todd fully committed himself to this regimen, he began to rebel. The father remembered: ''I thought, 'He has put all this time in. I've put the time in. We've researched everything. He's got everything in order. Why isn't he good all the time?' ''
 
Long-Distance Punishment
The son remembered being punished after barely going through the motions during an all-star basketball game. He had to run home alongside the car, from Huntington Beach to Balboa, a distance of nine miles. Todd Marinovich said it was not a big deal for him to run nine miles as a second grader.
''Usually with my dad, when we had confrontations it always blew over the next day, and he explained why he did it,'' he said. ''There were days I didn't want to, but always in the back of my mind I loved playing sports. There was no way I would have thrown it away.''
Marv Marinovich acknowledged that there had been family disagreements over Todd's development, but feels that the issue was not responsible for his divorce. He is remarried with a 2-year-old son named Mikhail.
''If he plays football, he's definitely going to be a linebacker,'' Todd Marinovich said with a smile. ''He's got that mentality, that look in his eyes. He's crazy.''
This summer, Todd lived with his mother, Trudi, and went to his father's club to work out. At school, he is a student developing a sense of independence.
''The separation from me going to college brought us closer,'' the son said of his father. ''We're still working out. It's just summers now. I like that. I have my life over here now, and Dad has his little boy now.''
Now and then, the father returns to the campus where he played to watch his son wear the colors he wore. Marv Marinovich stands back in the baseball grandstand next to the football practice field, and watches quietly. ''I'm just enjoying it,'' he said. ''But I'll always have a few comments for him, of course. I kind of think he expects it.''

LENGTH: 499 words

HEADLINE: The Soviets: Steady, if Slow

 BODY:
Differences between the Soviet Union and the United States on when to use force to uphold economic sanctions against Iraq are troublesome. But they scarcely threaten the remarkable international consensus that increasingly isolates Saddam Hussein.
On all the big questions, Moscow has joined with Washington to counter Iraq's aggression. This counts more than Moscow's hesitations about using naval force to assure compliance with sanctions. Working to overcome Soviet doubts makes more sense than letting a difference on timing turn into a serious rift over larger goals. 
Moscow has joined in condemning Iraq's grab of Kuwait. It has also joined in imposing an arms embargo on the Baghdad regime and in voting mandatory economic sanctions. But so far, the Soviet Union has held back from fully approving a Security Council resolution authorizing a ''minimum use of force'' to prevent evasion of the sanctions. That could delay naval challenges to ships bound to and from Iraqi ports.
Meanwhile, the collective effort to contain Saddam Hussein grows stronger by the hour. Japan offers what could amount to billions in compensation to countries hurt by sanctions. Saudi Arabia is providing oil to reimburse costs of U.S. military aid. Western Europe is moving ships and troops to the gulf; France is joining as a full partner.
And global resolve can only be stiffened by Iraq's latest affront: the grotesque television charade in which Saddam Hussein appears as kindly godfather to the children of British hostages.
Soviet anxieties about moving too fast on the military track seem neither alarming nor unreasonable. Mikhail Gorbachev is not alone in his aversion to using force; others also worry that a massive U.S. buildup in the gulf could result in war by miscalculation or overreaction. And Moscow is understandably reluctant to turn forcibly against a radical Arab state with which it has had close ties for two decades. That may be why Mr. Gorbachev prefers deferring naval action until sanction-busting has been clearly demonstrated.
The debate has already whetted cold-war suspicions. Some fear that the Soviet Union is playing for time to protect its client and reap the benefits of higher prices for its own substantial oil and gas exports. And Soviet ''specialists'' remain in Iraq. Moscow says the advisers are only fulfilling contracts to train Iraqis in using Soviet military equipment.
None of this diminishes the crucial importance of Soviet support in helping to unite the United Nations. Sanctions are already reckoned as 90 percent effective. Their bite has provoked Iraq into denouncing the U.N. as an American tool, thus slandering all its members.
Given the tumult in the gulf, Mr. Gorbachev's hesitation about going further matters less than the unity of purpose already achieved. The first post-cold-war crisis has carried nations everywhere into new terrain. It is premature to read sinister motives into uncertain and even contradictory Soviet signals.

HEADLINE: Adding Police Won't Hold Back New York's Crime Tidal Wave

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I am disturbed that public outcry over the recent shootings of children and innocent citizens in New York City has brought the tried and ineffective answer of more police. I have heard knowledgeable public officials and others who should know better say the additional police presence will ''suppress'' crime. How can you suppress a tidal wave? The murders, rapes and assaults that make headlines are only the crest of the wave of crime washing over this city.
The only true means of tackling the crime problem is to prevent young people from becoming criminals. You start by educating them and providing them with the means to compete successfully for jobs. You provide supervised activities to keep them off the streets and under the watchful eye of trained counselors, after school and during the summer. Most of all, you give them opportunities to work while they are young. Let them taste early a piece of the American dream the legal way.
The problem with adding additional police is that for every criminal arrested, there are plenty of unemployed, and unemployable, teen-agers and young adults waiting to take his place. The cost is more than just for the police. It costs approximately $58,000 a year to keep an inmate locked up in a New York City jail.
If we are forced to spend more on police, let us recognize that we must spend as much extra on preventive services (youth employment, after-school services, counseling) for children and their families. To spend money in one area and not in the other wastes public dollars and precious time.
 
GEOFFREY CANADA
Exec. Director, Rheedlen Centers
for Children and Families
New York, Aug. 10, 1990

HEADLINE: Persian Gulf States Use Wealth Wisely

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As an American born and raised in the Middle East, with 20-odd years of recent close experience with native business and government leaders in the Arab world, I believe the news media owe Americans more accurate representation about Kuwait, Abu Dhabi and the Persian Gulf states.
Great wealth from oil revenues is a fact, but not the only significant one. Perhaps as important, this wealth is used in many respects wisely and responsibly: to change ancient tribal societies into well-intentioned progressive 20th-century ones with preservation of family and religious values benefiting the whole social spectrum; and not only to spread the benefits of great wealth to every citizen by providing universal free education, medical services, home ownership, telephone and water services, but also to make hundreds of millions of dollars available to impoverished third world countries through the huge Kuwaiti and Abu Dhabi social and economic funds.
That these wealthy countries are in large measure acting responsibly with their resources deserves recognition.
 
LACHLAN REED
Palm Beach, Fla., Aug. 13, 1990
 The writer heads the Physicians for Peace Foundation.

HEADLINE: Price of Being No. 1 Is Nothing to Cheer About;
Japan Gains on Us

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Selected statistics can make the financial and industrial health of our country look better than it is, as Alfred Balk shows (Op-Ed, July 31). For example, he talks of our ''reindustrialization,'' our gross national product and population as more than double Japan's, without recognizing that statistics from 1980 to 1989 indicate that Japan is likely to exceed our real per capita gross domestic product by the year 2004 or that Japan invested more in new factories in 1989 than we did - $549 billion versus $513 billion (see Leonard Silk's July 27 Economic Scene column, ''Who Is No. 1? It's Hard to Say''). 
There is an intangible asset that favors other industrial nations in their effort to capture more of our share of the world's industrial market. This is the quality of the work force. Beyond question, our work force is beset by social, economic, psychological and education problems that have led to warnings from industrial leaders that there will not be enough well-qualified workers for our industry by 2000.
Honest evaluation in Washington of our shrinking share of the world high-tech industrial market would force the conclusion that we need to change the distribution of wealth and our priorities to shore up the American family, and make the salaries and conditions in our schools attractive to potential science and math teachers. Instead, we will continue to spend close to $300 billion a year for ''defense,'' including weapons that have no proven purpose and don't function as prescribed.
Looking through rose-colored glasses is comforting, but dangerous. Not long ago, it encouraged the belief that multiplying high-tech factories would compensate for our lost smokestack industry. Events proved otherwise.
 
FREDERICK S. LIGHTFOOT
Greenport, L.I., Aug. 9, 1990

HEADLINE: Price of Being No. 1 Is Nothing to Cheer About

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''America Is No. 1. It'll Stay No. 1,'' Alfred Balk tells us (Op-Ed, July 31). He fails to mention our most serious problems, for instance, our national debt, which is more than $3.2 trillion and getting larger each day. 
He stresses the size of our gross national product but fails to tell us that $300 billion of this is due to our military spending, which has come close to bankrupting our nation. Since the cold war started, we have spent for the military an amount greater than the value of everything in the United States except for the land.
Neither does he mention what the cost of the savings and loan association bailout will do to the country. And in telling us how important our large G.N.P. is, Mr. Balk does not tell us that 65 percent of the G.N.P. is made up of consumption expenditures and that consumers are drowning in debt.
For the last seven years we have avoided a recession only because of our deficit spending. We have fluctuated between fear of inflation and fear of a recession. Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, has constantly changed from tight money and high interest rates to control inflation, to low interest rates and an easing of credit to avoid a recession.
Sixteen states are already in a recession or on the edge of having one. A recession seems almost inevitable. The only way we have of recovering from a recession is deficit financing, but we are already doing that at the present level of $150 billion annually. This is the bad news. The good news is that if we act in time, it is possible to avoid the chaos that a recession brings.
 
JOHN C. DAVIS
Santa Fe, N.M., Aug. 10, 1990
 The writer was formerly chief economist of the President's Council of Economic Advisers.

HEADLINE: Price of Being No. 1 Is Nothing to Cheer About;
Tomorrow's Hope

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Alfred Balk (Op-Ed, July 31), tells us that we're No. 1 and will stay that way - in fact, that we've ''Americanized the world.'' Such notables as Vice President Dan Quayle have recently voiced similar notions. 
Mr. Balk's inventory of the many categories of human endeavor and enterprise in which we ''lead the world by far'' is impressive, but he seems to forget our crisis in education, our students' poor performance compared with their foreign peers, especially in science, mathematics, geography, other languages and knowledge of other cultures. Can he believe that the deficient performance of many American students will have little or no effect on our national future, especially in the science and technology he extols?
Finally, it is sad that Mr. Balk stresses material accomplishments almost exclusively. Surely our American dream is an inseparable fusion of the material and the spiritual, and surely this, not solely our material attainments, explains its attraction for the people of other countries. We all need to remember, Mr. Balk included, an ancient but always valid question: What profits it a man (or country) if he gains the world but loses his soul?
 
ROBERT G. MEAD JR.
Storrs, Conn., Aug. 8, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 29, Column 2; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: DIALOGUE: Next Step in the Gulf
Should the U.S. Attack Iraq?;
Yes, Hussein Must Be Ousted

BYLINE: By Alfonse D'Amato; Alfonse D'Amato, Republican of New York, is a member of the Senate Intelligence Committee.

 BODY:
Imagine the Middle East with Saddam Hussein in command of a multimillion-man army, equipped with chemical, biological and nuclear weapons, and intercontinental missiles to deliver them.
Unless Mr. Hussein is destroyed now, that is what we will face in the future.
The United States' response to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait has been correct. We are now confronting tough choices. With every passing hour, Mr. Hussein rounds up more innocent Americans and other foreign citizens to be part of his ''human shield.'' We must act decisively against Iraq before we are presented with the unacceptable moral choice of tolerating his naked aggression in Kuwait or facing a protracted hostage crisis. 
We must realize that if Mr. Hussein is permitted to remain in power in Iraq, he will present a constant and growing threat to the security of the region and, in particular, to Israel. For that reason, we cannot settle for anything less than his removal from power.
Even apart from the hostage issue, the case for immediate action is compelling. Had Israel not undertaken its 1981 pre-emptive strike against Iraq's nuclear reactor, we would now face an enemy armed with nuclear-tipped Scud missiles. If we don't act decisively now, Saddam Hussein will have looked into the barrel of the gun and survived. He inevitably will seek the power to destroy any country that opposes him. Be assured that he will seek nuclear weapons to provide him with that power.
We cannot wait until President Hussein is able to back his grandiose ambitions with nuclear arms. If we now settle for a negotiated solution without destroying Iraq's capacity for future aggression, the cost of stopping him in five years will be more than the United States - and indeed the world - can or should pay.
Before World War II the world tolerated Hitler, erroneously believing that he was an enemy of Communism. We have made much the same mistake in tolerating President Hussein because he was the enemy of Iran and the Ayatollah Khomeini. Just as the world closed its eyes to Hitler's atrocities, we have ignored President Hussein's unconscionable use of poison gas against his own people.
We cannot accept a deal that would allow Mr. Hussein to retreat to his lair with his army - and his ambitions - intact. Nor can we trust him to abide by the terms of any negotiated agreement. Recall that when Iran confronted Iraq with superior force in 1975, President Hussein kissed the Shah and agreed to a treaty settling Iraq's boundary with Iran. He broke that treaty when it suited his plans, with a massive military attack on Iran in September 1980.
We now stand on Kuwait's border, face-to-face with him. We should learn from Israel's 1981 example and act pre-emptively. It is simply naive to believe that an economic embargo will starve Mr. Hussein into capitulating to our demands. With his bold rhetoric, he is fanning popular Arab unrest in Jordan, Egypt and even Syria. Time is not on our side.
Only a pre-emptive strike will save us from the nightmare of facing a regional nuclear war within the decade. Mr. Hussein's insatiable ambition and animosity toward Israel is well documented. If we walk away from the present crisis leaving intact his ambitions and Iraq's offensive military capability, then Iraq will surely strive to acquire the nuclear capability to destroy all of Israel and dominate the entire Arab world.
In any future confrontation involving an Iraq armed with nuclear arms, Israel may well be compelled to resort to nuclear weapons to insure its survival. The consequences could be a nuclear conflagration drawing in the entire world.
Striking now avoids the wrenching moral dilemma we will face if President Hussein is allowed to put his ''human shield'' in place. As we wait, the situation worsens and the cost of inaction mounts.
Appeasement and negotiations are no more the road to peace now than they were before World War II. We must show strength now.

SECTION: Section A; Page 29, Column 5; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 652 words

HEADLINE: DIALOGUE: Next Step in the Gulf
Should the U.S. Attack Iraq?;
No, U.N. Pressure Will Work Best

BYLINE: By Terry Sanford; Terry Sanford, Democrat of North Carolina, is a member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The U.S. has accomplished its original military objective in the Middle East: We stepped in with a strong presence in Saudi Arabia and stopped Saddam Hussein's march south to control the Middle East oilfields. That was a bold and proper action. It was a brilliant performance.
Now, however, there is a real danger that we will be tempted to go on the offensive. Success is heady stuff. My fear is that commitments or threats will lead us into a war that would be bloody, costly and hard to conclude. 
By continuing to add troops and planes, and by threatening to act in advance of the United Nations to enforce a shipping blockade, the Bush Administration is playing into Mr. Hussein's desperate effort to depict his naked aggression as a confrontation between Iraq and the ''imperialist'' U.S.
We do not want the nations of the world to feel that they are helping the U.S. against Iraq. We want the rest of the world to see this confrontation as an obligation of the United Nations, of which the U.S. is a strong supporter.
Thus, we must rapidly shift the primary burden to the U.N. It will take the civilized world's concerted and sustained efforts to enforce an effective embargo of Iraq. It will take the U.N. to protect thousands of foreign nationals held as hostages. These are U.N. responsibilities.
I understand patriotic fervor, the urge to back the President when we are confronting a foreign foe. But I also remember the plunge toward combat involvement in Vietnam.
That is why there is an urgent need to calm down and remind ourselves that our presence in the Persian Gulf cannot become America's war. Although we may, and should, seek to guide and shape international consensus through the U.N., we cannot dictate it. Nor should we march ahead unilaterally, arrogantly assuming that the world will follow. If there is to be war, it is to be Iraq's war against the entire world community.
The U.N. charter was signed in the hope that a new international system might ''save succeeding generations from the scourge of war.'' That hope was frustrated by the cold war. Now, 45 years after the charter was adopted, the U.N. is in a position to unite and act. The international community appears ready to cooperate to enforce the law of nations.
The Security Council enacted economic sanctions against Iraq without a dissenting vote. If it finds that sanctions have ''proved to be inadequate,'' it may order other operations, including a military blockade. We must give the U.N. time to lead.
Such a multilateral effort is needed to make sanctions effective, and to deprive Saddam Hussein of the propaganda claim that he is simply standing up to American imperialism. His trump card is in turning the ordinary Arab against the royal families and against their protectors. The United Nations can take that card out of his hand.
Washington simply must, through the United Nations, exercise leadership among the community of nations to convey, forcefully and collectively, the message that blatant aggression will not be tolerated. Our greatest weapon is the embargo that will cut off Iraq's revenue.
The U.S. must also shift to the United Nations the responsibility for the American and other foreign families being detained in Iraq and Kuwait. There are indications that the continued buildup of U.S. forces in the region - by raising Iraqi fears of invasion - may expose them to even greater danger. The U.N. can best liberate these people.
We must not allow Iraq to transform an international crime into an offense against the United States - as Iran did so successfully in the hostage crisis in Teheran. Mr. Hussein's offense is against the world.
Those who suggest that Mr. Hussein is a brutal dictator are correct. But those who argue that we should take back Kuwait and take over Iraq in order to liquidate him are not thinking clearly. There are safer ways to bring him under control.

SECTION: Section B; Page 1, Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1093 words

HEADLINE: At Stewart Airport, a Whiff of Success

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO

DATELINE: NEWBURGH, N.Y.

 BODY:
Amid the military cargo planes and private jets that have long rolled along the runways at Stewart International Airport is a new addition these days: Boeing 727's.
After years of trying to interest airlines in this former Air Force base on the fringe of the New York metropolitan area, and years of opposition from environmentalists, state officials have finally succeeded in attracting scheduled passenger service.
Arrivals and departures have nearly tripled since the first flights were begun four months ago by American Airlines to its Chicago and Raleigh-Durham hubs.
American Airlines now plans to start service to Dallas in September, while two feeder lines, United Express and American Eagle, have begun flying to Washington and to New York, 60 miles to the south. ''In truth, I didn't think we would see all of these markets quite as soon as we're seeing them,'' said Russell B. Vachon, Director of Aviation for the State Department of Transportation. 
Stewart's auspicious debut has pleased passengers from Orange County and beyond and also state officials - the passengers because they were tired of fighting traffic to reach La Guardia, Kennedy International and Newark International Airports and the state officials because they see the Hudson Valley as New York State's next frontier for economic development.
But the early success at the airport has also heightened concerns among local residents and environmental organizations who have long feared its development into a fourth major airport for the New York City region.
 
Environmentalists Suing State
A coalition of groups, including the Stewart Park and Reserve Coalition, the Sierra Club, and Scenic Hudson, is suing the state, demanding a comprehensive environmental review of both the new air service and plans by the state to develop over the next 20 years up to 2,000 acres that it owns around the airport.
Last spring the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court ruled in the state's favor, and the coalition is now appealing to the Court of Appeals.
''Rockland County was overwhelmed by development in the wink of an eye,'' Sandra Kissam, president of the Stewart Park and Reserve Coalition, said of Orange County's southern neighbor. ''What's going to happen to our open space?''
State planners, however, argue that they will be better able to preserve open space and sensitive environmental areas by concentrating development in and around the airport, which is near both Interstate 84 and the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway and is bordered by an 8,000-acre ''buffer zone.'' That zone includes the 2,000 acres that officials have marked for industrial and commercial development.
 
Control of Development Stressed
''Over the long term, there will continually be development pressures coming out of the New York metropolitan area, and we ought to be in a position to handle it and control it, rather than let it happen haphazardly,'' said Stephen M. Finkle, the Urban Development Corporation's director of economic development at the airport.
The Federal Aviation Administration and the state's Department of Transportation are overseeing an environmental review of proposed commercial development on the buffer land. A review of the airport expansion in 1977 found there would be no significant impact on the environment.
As the debate continues over the merits of development and expansion, Stewart is making progress within the airline industry. The State Commissioner of Transportation, Franklin E. White, said in a recent news conference that the airport was ''the talk of the aviation industry,'' adding that it had the potential to relieve ''airport congestion that has reached crisis proportions.''
 
Airline Expansion Considered
A spokesman for American Airlines, Ed Stewart, said, ''Because Stewart is doing so well, it's one of the places we're constantly looking at for possible expansion.''
A number of airlines are now considering moving to Stewart, transportation officials said, with Boston and Miami the two new destinations talked about most.
The Department of Transportation has estimated that Stewart could one day accommodate about a fifth of the more than 200,000 passengers now using Kennedy, La Guardia and Newark each day. It sees the airport drawing on residents and employees from the Hudson Valley, northern New Jersey, parts of Connecticut and eastern Pennsylvania.
Among Stewart's airline and feeder services there are now 31 arrivals and departures daily. In June about 17,000 passengers passed through the single gate at the 34,000-square-foot terminal. The parking spaces, which are free until 1991, initially numbered 850 but have more than doubled.
The possibilities for expansion are great. A site at the northern end of the airport has already been set aside for a second terminal that would be 10 times the size of the existing one, subject to environmental review, and long-term plans call for an extension of an alternate runway to 8,000 feet from 6,000. But state officials say the current terminal could be expanded to handle any new airlines during the next five years.
 
Biggest Jets Can Land
In area the 10,000-acre airport is the second largest in the nation, behind Dallas-Fort Worth. Its 11,818-foot main runway - 2,518 feet longer than Newark's top runway but 2,754 feet shorter than Kennedy's - can accommodate the largest jetliners, as well as the supersonic Concorde and the Space Shuttle - as opponents like to make known.
On a recent day several travelers suggested they were willing to accept some development for the sake of convenience.
''The impact is somewhat of a concern, but unfortunately you've got to give a little to get a little,'' said Antoinette Rudzinski, a 39-year-old legal assistant from Beacon, N.Y., who was picking up her father-in-law on a flight from Florida.
''I don't have to go to the city, which is four hours there and back, every time a friend or relative comes to visit,'' she said.
Perhaps most concerned about the budding airport are the people whose houses are directly beneath the new flight paths. Gordon Rauer of Rock Tavern, an economist and real-estate broker who lives five miles from the airport in a farmhouse on three and a half acres, said he was now wakened every morning at 7:18, 12 minutes before his alarm clock was set to go off.
''The windows shake, and it feels like the plane is going through my living room,'' said Mr. Rauer, who is active in the Stewart Park and Reserve Coalition. ''I can practically see the pilot's lapels.''

HEADLINE: Tourism in New York City Is Down After 80's Boom

BYLINE: By KAREN De WITT

 BODY:
After the boom years of the 1980's, New York City tourism is down slightly this summer, a dip that is being closely monitored by the local tourist industry.
Hotel occupancy, convention bookings and domestic airline arrivals have decreased, but industry experts are saying they are not unduly concerned.
''What we're seeing in New York City is a dip from the sky, from cosmic levels of tourism,'' said Bern Rotman, a spokesman for the New York State Department of Economic Development. ''If it's a long-term trend, then of course it's dangerous. But tourism has been an absolutely growing industry, so if it seems that there is a slowdown, people get nervous.'' 
Even in the decline, there are bright spots. Theater attendance and visits to major New York City attractions are up. And New York appears to be less affected by a general dip in tourism than other parts of the country.
 
Tourism Peaks in the Fall
Earlier this year, travel experts feared that changing tourism patterns and a sluggish economy marked a flattening of the industry. But industry spokesmen are taking a wait-and-see attitude because tourism in New York peaks not in the summer months but in October and November.
''In the summer you get strictly visitors on vacation, and while New York is wonderful, it has its drawbacks if you have children,'' said Christine Godek of Berman-Godek Communications Inc., a hotel-industry public relations firm.
Though almost everyone acknowledges a softening in the domestic market, John D. Harding, vice president of marketing and advertising for Restaurant Associates Inc., which operates Mama Leone's Restaurant and restaurants at Rockefeller Center and other tourist destinations, said the company's New York proprieties have held better than those in Miami or Boston.
''Even though there's clearly a downturn, we think New York isn't as as badly affected as most other places in the rest of the country,'' he said.
 
'Stuff They Read in the Media'
What seems to be affecting New York City tourism, a $10 billion industry, is partly psychological, some travel experts say. An image of New York as crime ridden and racially strained are not selling points.
At Lincoln Center, Andryola Kye, a New York City jewelry designer, was showing off the city to a friend from Munich, Ann Pawlowski. ''You want to know why tourism is down in New York?'' Ms. Kye asked. ''I'll tell you. It's the image of the city. It's crime. It's the stuff they read in the media.'' Earlier this week, Mayor David N. Dinkins announced that he was reinstating city money for the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau in an effort to promote tourism. City officials say the money was more an effort to ensure continued tourism than an attempt to stanch a decline.
''There are areas of business I'm panicked about, but the tourism industry is not one,'' said Sally B. Hernandez-Pinero, Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development. #5 Percent State Tax on Hotels Hotel occupancy rates and the number of conventions is down to 73 percent for 1989, compared with 76.7 percent for 1988. In other major cities like Los Angeles, Atlanta and Miami, the figures are down as well.
Mrs. Godek said that travel industry officials were still waiting to see what effect the New York State tax increase of 5 percent on hotel rooms would have on the market. ''Everyone is a little worried about the tax, because along with stories generated in the media worldwide, the problem of Kennedy Airport no longer being the only gateway into the country - and Kennedy is not a user-friendly airport - those kind of things make all New York hotel people nervous,'' she said.
According to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, domestic airline passenger arrivals showed a slight increase over the first six months of last year, from 12,979,741 in 1989 to 13,012,101 this year. But since 1986, the figure has been declining.
The number of foreign visitors to New York continued to increase, from 5,157,774 in the first six months of 1989 to 5,334,856 this year.
 
Attraction of the Lower Dollar
''The relatively depressed value of the dollar is helping things for the overseas tourists,'' said Greg Bohan of Pannell Kerr Forster, an accounting and consulting firm that specializes in the hotel and restaurant industry.
At Rockefeller Center, Shirley Emery, 26 years old, and Avril Nicolson, 27, of Scotland, said that bargain prices brought them to the city.
''We're spending about a thousand dollars each for the two weeks here,'' said Miss Emery, a nurse.
American tourists like Sungbok Lee, 19, and Sang Jee, 20, both Michigan State University students, are cutting their costs by staying with friends.
 
Cutting Vacation Costs
''And we drove from Lansing,'' said Mr. Lee, as he and Mr. Jee waited for a friend at St. Patrick's Cathedral. ''There's no question that we'd come to visit New York - this is the world's metropolis - it was just how to keep it from being really expensive.''
The students said that at some point during their stay they were going to have to pay for a hotel and had calculated $40 a night apiece, a far cry from the $133.75 average daily room rate.
While hotel occupancy and the number of conventions are down slightly, visits to the city's tourist attractions and theaters are up. For fiscal year 1988-89, there were 7.97 million theatergoers; in fiscal 1989-90, 8.03 million.
''Generally there has been an upturn reflecting more and better shows playing, with about 40 percent of our business from out of town and about a quarter of that from foreigners,'' said George Wachtel, director of research for the Theater League.
At the Empire State Building, Laura Fries, manager of the observation decks, said: ''While last year was a flat year, this year we're seeing an increase. One of the reasons is that the Empire State building is internationally known.''

HEADLINE: Reviews/Art;
In Westchester, Fantasies of Odilon Redon

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN

 BODY:
Odilon Redon's name does not often appear near the top of lists of 19th-century artists who influenced 20th-century art, but before the Surrealists - before many of the Surrealists were born, in fact - he was exploring the dark side of the subconscious.
In the prints and drawings he made beginning in the 1860's, Redon created macabre and cryptic images inspired in some cases by the writings of Poe and Baudelaire, in others by the paintings of Goya. His renditions of flowers sprouting skulls and of skeletons with antlers, and his references to Hindu symbols for death and to mythical creatures like Pegasus and the Sphinx, prompted the Parisian critics to label him as a purveyor of ''le fantastique reel,'' ''that desolate region which exists on the borders of the real and the fantastic - a realm populated by formidable phantoms, monsters, monads and other creatures born of human perversity,'' explained the critic Emile Hennequin in an 1882 review of Redon's lithographs.
''Le Fantastique Reel: Graphic Works by Odilon Redon'' is also the title of a concise and handsome exhibition at the Katonah (N.Y.) Museum of Art, organized by Stephen F. Eisenman, a professor at Occidental College in Los Angeles. Bringing together about 30 drawings and prints from six public and private collections, the show focuses on the first decades of the artist's career, when he was working almost exclusively in black and white and was known only to a coterie of enthusiasts. 
Redon was 41 years old in 1881 when he was finally given his first exhibition of drawings, and only in the 1890's did he achieve a measure of the fame he had sought for so many years. By 1913, three years before his death, Redon was thought significant enough to the development of modern art to merit a prominent place in the Armory Show in New York.
Yet for much of his career, he worked in obscurity. Born in the Medoc, in the Bordeaux region of France, Redon maintained a fascination with supernatural stories he had heard as a child, and in his early work he sought to illustrate those tales of demons, enchanted forests and witches' sabbaths. Like others in the French avant-garde, he wanted to create a kind of populist art, one based on a repertory of folk images that would seem in opposition to the classical themes promoted by the academy. This goal also led him in the mid-1870's to printmaking, which he believed would ensure that his works were widely available. Redon told his teacher, Rodolphe Bresdin, that he wanted to become ''a man of the people.''
In retrospect, as Mr. Eisenman points out in his catalogue essay: ''Redon's ambition was contradictory and utopian. . . . The 'supernatural tales' that Redon heard were, to some extent, the creation of metropolitan folklorists who felt comforted by the idea of a timeless, simple and superstitious peasantry. Indeed, though Redon's own championing of the 'ragged and sad' people of his native Medoc was first motivated by respect and a desire for social justice, it gradually changed into a belief that poverty was itself ennobling.''
But the salient point remains that, for Redon, depictions of the grotesque and otherworldly represented not an escape from reality, but an attempt to create a visual language at least as true to life as the landscapes depicted by the Impressionists - in his case, true to the inner life of the imagination. Like photographers, the Impressionists were concerned only with re-creating the surface of nature, he believed. Redon aimed for a representation of nature based on the unseen.
The prints and drawings in this exhibition underscore how diverse his sources were. He seems to have found precedents in the works of not only Goya and Bresdin, but also Corot, Rembrandt and Leonardo. Although Poe, Baudelaire and Flaubert supplied him with ideas, he derived help, as well, by reading about the latest developments in anatomy and botany. (He sent a copy of his 1879 set of lithographs, ''Dans le Reve,'' to Louis Pasteur, who declared Redon's monsters ''fit to live.'') The results can be judged in his 1888 suite of prints based on Flaubert's ''Temptation of St. Anthony,'' in which it becomes clear why Mallarme praised Redon's blacks for being ''as royal as purple.'' In ''The Chimera With Green Eyes Turns, Bays,'' from this series, the artist creates a realm so shadowy and unfathomable as to seem abstract. It is a work like ''The Chimera'' that links Redon most strongly with the avant-garde of the early 20th century.
Evocative uses of light and dark are also what make prints like ''Evil Glory'' of 1886 and the frontispiece for ''The Chimeras'' by Jules Destree of 1889 stand out among the finest of Redon's achievements. Few artists could make black serve so many purposes.
When, in the 1890's, he began to create scenes more explicit in their imagery and less dependent on mysterious effects of shadow, he was responding to charges of obscurantism from critics unaccustomed to ambiguity. But the works suffered as a result. His third ''Temptation of St. Anthony'' series, from 1896, is a prime example of the problem, with its descriptive, almost cartoonish style.
By the mid-1890's, Redon had become widely known, and his change of fortunes corresponded with a turn from black and white to pastel, oil and watercolor. He became an artist in the modernist mainstream. It is on the basis of these later, more contrived compositions that his reputation has understandably suffered. It has suffered, as well, from association with imitations by countless lesser artists. Still, as this exhibition makes clear, Redon left behind, with his early prints and drawings, works that have lost none of their mystery and elegance, and that establish him clearly as a father to the art of the 20th century.
 
In Purchase
''First Impressions'' at the Neuberger Museum in Purchase, N.Y., is ultimately too big and too diffuse, but it serves an important function in documenting the growth of the art of printmaking in the United States in the last 30 years. Organized by Elizabeth Armstrong of the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis, where the show was first seen, it brings together early attempts at printmaking by 46 contemporary artists, beginning in the late 50's with the collaboration between Larry Rivers and Frank O'Hara on a series of lithographs, and concluding with works from the 80's by such artists as Carroll Dunham, Eric Fischl, Robert Longo and Elizabeth Murray.
What transpired during the interim was a complete transformation of attitude among artists. Where Robert Rauschenberg had felt justified in responding to an invitation in the early 60's to make prints by saying that ''the second half of the 20th century was no time to start writing on rocks,'' two decades later it had become evident to young artists that the reputations of many of America's leading artists, including Rauschenberg, were considerably enhanced by their prints.
What had also become clear is that almost anything was possible in printmaking. The great merit of ''First Impressions'' is to demonstrate how freewheeling and inventive contemporary artists have been - partly, as with Vito Acconci or Bruce Nauman, in an attempt to translate radically different kinds of artistic practices into the medium of prints; partly, as in the case of Edward Kienholz or Lynda Benglis, in an attempt to stretch the definition of printmaking.
There are outstanding works in the show, including familiar ones like Jasper Johns's ''0-9'' and Chuck Close's ''Keith,'' and there are many other prints, like Richard Bosman's ''Man Overboard'' and Bruce Conner's ''Thumb Print,'' that would have seemed more impressive under less sprawling circumstances. The once-over-lightly quality of the exhibition tends to make the display seem more a survey of contemporary art than a study of the evolution of a particular medium. As for the very important part that economics has played in the flourishing of prints, little is said. Still, ''First Impressions'' will leave no doubt in a viewer's mind of the major contribution of publishing houses like Universal Limited Art Editions, Tamarind Lithography Workshop, Crown Point Press and Gemini G.E.L. to the progress of American postwar art.

GRAPHIC: Photo: ''The Wing,'' 1893, by Odilon Redon, at the Katonah Museum of Art. (Yale University Art Gallery)

HEADLINE: Review/Art;
Parallels in American and Soviet Post-Modernism

BYLINE: By ANDY GRUNDBERG

 BODY:
To American eyes, contemporary Soviet art is endlessly fascinating. It comes from a culture that for most of this century has been closed to the West. It dispenses with the approved style of Socialist Realism and contradicts our preconceived ideas about the creative conditions of Communist life. Moreover, it bears a disconcerting resemblance to recent American art.
The new Soviet art has only recently begun attracting the attention of American museums, however, so the process of sorting out what its meanings and potentials are is in its infancy. But judging from ''Adaptation and Negation of Socialist Realism: Contemporary Soviet Art,'' an exhibition organized by the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art in Ridgefield, Conn. (where it can be seen through Oct. 7), today's Soviet artists are as fully post-modern as those in New York.
What popular culture is for New York artists, Socialist Realism apparently is for the Soviets - an omnipresent, oppressive realm that symbolically represents an elusive but all-pervasive authority. Thus much of the work in the exhibition - a total of 46 pieces by 14 artists, selected by Jamey Gambrell, an art critic in New York - attempts to unmask or pervert the erstwhile ''official'' style. 
Yevgeny Barabanov, a Soviet art critic who has contributed an essay to the show's catalogue, calls it ''post-underground'' work. That is, it is neither the detested art of officialdom nor an absolute rejection of it. Instead, the artists in ''Adaptation and Negation'' toy with the ideological system from which an earlier avant-garde tried to flee. Part of a loose, Moscow-based movement referred to as conceptualism, they employ illustration, text, graphic design and a realm of other non-painterly techniques to comment on the contradictions of Soviet life. This is what makes their work look so similar to that of their American post-modernist peers. But however much their purposefully ambiguous and sometimes playful work resembles the kind of contemporary American art one finds in SoHo galleries these days (and much of it has already been seen there, primarily at the Phyllis Kind Gallery), its reasons for being are not the same. These artists have little of the world-weary cynicism that results from a fashion-conscious marketplace. Their theoretical basis is formed not so much by the notion of the disappearance of reality as by the all-too-real reality of their immediate artistic and political situation.
Some of the best-known figures in today's Soviet art are included in the show. Ilya Kabakov, for example, who has been a member of the Soviet Artist's Union since Nikita S. Khrushchev's time, is represented by paintings and a room-sized work called ''He Lost His Mind, Undressed, Ran Away Naked.'' The wordy, debris-filled installation has a narrative that concerns the fate of an obsessed, paranoid Moscow apartment dweller.
The paintings of Ivan Chuikov, Eric Bulatov and Eduard Gorokhovsky - all veterans of the New York gallery scene - are here as well. Each, in his own way, makes use of the Socialist Realist style, turning it into a form of a bad joke. The most vivid demonstration of this adaptive urge is Mr. Gorokhovsky's ''Two Thousand Four Hundred and Eighty Eight Portraits of Lenin'' (1988), a photo-silk-screen in which the thousands of tiny Lenin heads form a single, monumental portrait of Stalin.
However, the show's main energy comes from a slightly younger generation of artists. Igor Kopystiansky's ''Construction'' (1990) employs a traditional style of painting, but his 19th-century genre scenes are brushed on walls, floor and several free-standing pylons. Svetlana Kopystiansky's installation in the same room, ''Library,'' is gorgeous in an equally polished but more Minimalist way. Consisting of a wall of more than 100 open books displayed in individual wooden boxes, the work creates a tension between the autonomy of each volume and the sculptural mass of the whole.
Ms. Kopystiansky's interest in combining verbal and visual experience is echoed elsewhere in the show, by the inked-over newspapers painted by Dmitri Prigov and the lettered oil paintings of Igor Makarevich. For others, painting is about symbolism. Simon Faibisovich fashions photo-realist conundrums like ''Das Ist die Frage,'' an interior shaped by sunlight in the form of a question mark. In Oleg Vassilyev's ''Landscape and Space'' paintings, bright floodlights bleach out the center of an empty vista. Natalya Nesterova's ''Recollection of Germany'' shows three men looking back at a distant yacht.
Few of these artists are represented in the recently organized touring exhibition of contemporary Soviet Conceptual art ''Between Spring and Summer,'' currently at the Tacoma (Wash.) Art Museum and bound for Boston and Des Moines. This is at once a sign of the breadth and depth of Soviet cultural life today and a symptom of how much of it remains unexamined and unsorted in America.
 
Longo in Hartford
As the mid-career retrospective of some 50 drawings, sculptures, videos and mixed-media works at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford confirms, Robert Longo is an ambitious artist who is at his best when he treads the borderline of hyperbole and arrogance. Prone to firing major artillery at small targets, he nevertheless is capable of expressing emotions beyond the reach of many of his contemporaries.
The line between success and failure in Mr. Longo's work is always subject to redefinition. At the beginning of his career, in the late 1970's, it was a matter of finish: his ideas - about the ambiguities of masculinity, gesture and photographic representation - often overspilled their containers. More recently, now that he employs assistants to help in fabricating his drawings and sculptures - the situation is often reversed, and the containers threaten to become self-sufficient spectacles.
But there is a great deal of pleasure to be had in seeing the artist's efforts to walk the line, which he manages to do remarkably often in this show, which was organized by Howard N. Fox of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art. His themes of faceless power, male dominance and urban anomie are familiar, but his stylistic decision to mimic their rhetoric without obvious irony gives the work its frightening charge.
In ''All You Zombies: Truth Before God,'' a bronze science-fiction figure turns slowly in front of a semi-circular painting of an opera house. The figure sports two sets of bared teeth, a bandolier of bullets, football shoulder pads and chain mail; as if this were not enough, a pair of lightning bolts issues from his backside. Invisible motors make an unholy din in ''Running Dumb: The Theory of the Brake,'' a 10-foot-long stack of steel rollers covered in gold leaf.
Compared to these hybrid works - Mr. Longo calls them ''combines,'' using Robert Rauschenberg's term - ''Corporate Wars: Wall of Influence'' seems a model of restraint. ''Corporate Wars'' epitomizes the artist at his best: an aluminum frieze of warring, punching businessmen and women, modeled after Michelangelo's ''Battle of the Centaurs,'' is flanked by two lacquered black forms that suggest modernist skyscrapers. The piece suggests the fraught emotions of corporate life symbolically and, for Mr. Longo, economically.
Indeed, some of the show's best moments come when Mr. Longo is at his most abstract. ''Joker: Force of Choice,'' a steel wall sculpture that forms the shape of a cross, verges on being a spiritual logotype. ''Black Planet (for A. Z.),'' with its trail of rubbery cords falling from a steel disk, evokes a damaged and weeping Earth.
But even at his most restrained, the artist has been hard put to make sculpture that can match the force of his ''Men in the Cities'' drawings of the early 1980's. Done with the aid of a commercial illustrator and larger than life, these show single figures mysteriously engaged in what seems to be a particularly animated dance. Tall and iconic, the drawings provide a space of reflection in a show that begins with the whine of electric motors and ends with the chug of the hyperactive, hyperfashionable rock videos that Mr. Longo has directed in recent years.
 
Photos in Stamford
''American Photography, 1839-1900,'' the survey at the Whitney Museum of American Art's branch in Stamford, has two major virtues. One is that it includes many of the acknowledged masterworks of the medium, pictures that are often seen in reproduction but seldom in the flesh. The second is that it traces the evolution of photography from its most primitive beginnings to a state of elaboration and diversity of means, styles and social functions.
The show was organized by Janet Burger of the International Museum of Photography at George Eastman House in Rochester. Any exhibition that numbers among its 50 daguerreotypes portraits of Henry Clay, Stephen Douglas and Daniel Webster, as well as John Whipple's 1852 portrait of the moon, is not to be missed. Add to these weathered splendors such paper pictures as Carleton Watkins's 1861 view of Yosemite Falls, Alexander Gardner's grisly image of the execution of the Lincoln assassination conspirators, A. J. Russell's staged tableau of the joining of the transcontinental railroad, and two intimate, domestic scenes by Oliver Wendell Holmes, and one has an exhibition of unsurpassed accomplishment.
What is missing among all the masterpieces, however, is much evidence of photography's pedestrian presence in 19th-century life. There are no tintypes, ambrotypes or other common coinage from portraiture's mammoth mint; instead, there are ''imperial size'' portraits by Mathew Brady of the nation's social cream. The dawning of the age of the snapshot at the century's end is barely hinted at in Frederick Fargo Church's 1890 image of George Eastman photographing aboard ship with an early Kodak camera. Instead, ''American Photography'' ends with a flurry of Pictorialism, photography's most refined and artistically self-conscious moment.
