HEADLINE: Books of the Times;
Seeing the Landscape At Its Best and Worst

BYLINE: By RICHARD SEVERO

 BODY:

The Experience of Place
By Tony Hiss
233 pages. Illustrated. Alfred A. Knopf.
$19.95.
Its subtitle to the contrary, ''The Experience of Place'' is not really ''a completely new way of looking at and dealing with our radically changing cities and countryside.'' It is a way that has been used for years wherever people have been piled up in cities, here and abroad. (The Japanese are very good at it.) It is the sort of adjustment that may well occur whenever condos rise above the fruited plain and wherever the majesty of purple mountains overlooks acres and acres of free parking. 
For when developers march on meadows and fields, and only the well-to-do dare aspire to the privacy of a bosky garden, or to live within an easy walk of a working farm, what else is there to do but concentrate very hard on the shards of beauty that remain? To do it as Tony Hiss wants, we must embrace the illusion of countryside if there is no countryside, and think about the city lovingly so that in the mind's eye it always remains as we want to remember it: civilizing, comforting and offering its own special kind of privacy.
The only question is whether most have the will to engage in a kind of observation that would bring out the best in the physical reality of America. Mr. Hiss, a writer for The New Yorker, does this very well indeed. He can look through the enormous damage that has been done to American cities and countryside since World War II and fix upon the good that has survived; he acknowledges the sins of the past, which continue even now, but he does not dwell on them. He uses his estimable powers as an observer to take us to some familiar places, and he challenges us to regard them as he does.
Times Square, for example. Yes, he says, there are crime and sleaze there, but there are also the ingredients that originally made the place work, and aren't these the things we should at least try to look at? He describes the square in detail and talks about the activities in it that continue to serve the interests of the legitimate theater. He reveals the places where, he assures us, he can still get a feeling of privacy, and he recalls the way sunlight used to fall into the square before some of its most recent skyscrapers were built, ''reflecting off the dust in the air, making the air seem to be charged with light and showing it as a three-dimensional form.'' He later concedes, though, that ''what used to be a bowl automatically brimming over with light now feels increasingly isolated from its sources and more like an oddly shaped bucket that's starting to drop down a well and sink away from the reach of the sun.''
And then there is Grand Central Terminal. Again, he gives an extended description of what it is like to walk through one of its passageways: ''I felt hurried along. My breathing was shallow and slightly constricted; my neck and shoulders were tight. I could smell cookies and pizza baking in the shops around me, but it seemed difficult to look to either side.''
Later, entering the Main Concourse: ''I could no longer distinguish the sounds of my own footsteps. All the sounds that reached me seemed to have been fused into a single sound. Vast and quiet, it seemed to be evenly distributed throughout the great room. This sound, pleasant in all its parts, regular in all its rhythms, and humorous and good-natured, seemed also to have buttoned me into some small, silent bubble of space. I felt that I wasn't quite walking but was paddling - or somehow propelling - this bubble across the floor.'' ''The Experience of Place'' is filled with such etherealness, as well as hard reporting on what advocates for environmental and urban health are thinking these days.
But before one begins to appreciate what Mr. Hiss has created, it would seem mandatory to remember some of the other observers, famous and not so famous, who have come before him, especially in the last 30 years: Lewis Mumford, whose ''City in History'' made it clear that there were parallels between downsliding Rome of yore and New York City of 1961; and Jane Jacobs, who celebrated humanist values and diversity in her ''Death and Life of Great American Cities,'' also published in 1961. Richard J. Whalen's anger seemed justified when, in 1964, he attacked New York's greed and short-sightedness in ''A City Destroying Itself.'' By 1985, there was wistfulness and a tightly controlled ire in Lorraine B. Diehl's ''Late, Great Penn Station,'' which meticulously detailed the ignominy and economic folly that attended the destruction of one of New York's most impressive public places.
There is much to enjoy in Mr. Hiss's book. But his message is disturbing, too, because it shows that the nation did not hear Mr. Mumford and the others who tried to instruct Americans in what it means to be true stewards of the land. Even worse, some of the alarms that were sounded by an older generation of environmentalists and urbanologists are yet to be responded to.
Mr. Hiss suggests that if the land is developed carefully, people ''can build on a landscape, that is, without eating away it.'' But he also acknowledges that New York State lost nearly a million acres of farmland between 1982 and 1987, and that 372 of the most productive farming counties in the nation, representing more than half of the best such counties we have, are ''either already within or directly adjacent to metropolitan areas.'' Americans still do not have a very good track record in protecting such places.
Mr. Hiss tells of a research program in England intended to ''investigate how schools can restructure a number of paved and windswept schoolyards to give them a country look and so provide 'a complete environment for learning.' '' His readers may be glad to know it, but many of them will think that America could have had so much more.

Markets
Stock prices plunged for the third day, falling to their lowest level in 13 months on growing concern over the crisis in the Persian Gulf. Volume rose to more han 250 million shares, the heaviest since the day after the 190-point plunge in October 1989. [Page A1.]

HEADLINE: Judge Rejects Keating Suit; Sees 'Looting' of Lincoln

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23

 BODY:
In a blistering opinion, a Federal judge today dismissed the lawsuit brought by Charles H. Keating Jr. to regain control of the failed Lincoln Savings and Loan Association. The judge said that the Government seizure of Lincoln was ''fully justified'' and that the actions of Mr. Keating and his associates amounted to a ''looting'' of the institution.
In handing the Government an across-the-board victory, Federal District Judge Stanley Sporkin found that Mr. Keating and other Lincoln directors engaged in ''unsafe and unsound practices'' that warranted the seizure last year by regulators. The judge said Mr. Keating and other executives had executed a series of improper transactions to funnel money from Lincoln to its parent company, the American Continental Corporation. 
The ruling, the first significant court decision to examine Mr. Keating's management of Lincoln and its takeover, came in a much-publicized lawsuit that Mr. Keating had filed to regain control of the institution, which was seized on April 14, 1989.
At more than $2 billion, the bailout is one of the costliest on record, and Mr. Keating's campaign contributions to lawmakers and his flamboyant personal style have made him a symbol of the savings and loan excesses leading to the nation's worst financial crisis. Mr. Keating has attributed Lincoln's demise to the Government, saying that regulators engaged in a vendetta against him.
 
'Not a Pretty Picture'
''What has emerged is not a pretty picture,'' Judge Sporkin said in his opinion. ''It is abundantly clear that A.C.C.'s officials abused their positions. Bluntly speaking, their actions amounted to a looting of Lincoln.''
''This was not done crudely,'' the judge wrote. ''Indeed, it was done with a great deal of sophistication. The transactions were all made to have an aura of legality.''
The judge's only criticism of the Government appeared in a footnote in which he said it was ''inexplicable and clearly inappropriate'' for the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, in the face of threats of lawsuits, to have agreed to transfer the investigation of Lincoln and ignored an earlier critical report of the institution by its San Francisco branch.
''This is an extremely important victory in a very significant case,'' said T. Timothy Ryan Jr., director of the Office of Thrift Supervision, the successor agency to the bank board. Harris Weinstein, the agency's chief counsel, said the ruling reinforced the view that Mr. Keating and the senior management operated Lincoln ''primarily for their own benefit at the expense of the institution and its depositors.''
One of Mr. Keating's lawyers, Robert K. Huffman, declined to comment on the opinion or say whether an appeal would be made.
 
Directors Criticized
Moving broadly beyond the Keating claims, Judge Sporkin also questioned why lawyers and accountants at Lincoln and American Continental had failed to stop or at least disassociate themselves from the improper transactions.
Judge Sporkin said the Government's evidence proved ''beyond question'' that the main purpose of many transactions ''was to create paper profits to 'window dress' the financial statements of Lincoln and its parent.''
''The entire board of directors, in addition to Keating and the others that controlled and operated Lincoln, must be held strictly accountable.''
Exploring a tax agreement plan in which Lincoln transferred more than $94 million to American Continental purportedly to take advantage of loss carry-forwards at the parent, the judge called it a ''dishonest scheme.'' He said it was ''nothing more than a clever but impermissible way of looting Lincoln by upstreaming funds from Lincoln to A.C.C.''
''Plaintiffs used the concept of tax sharing as a way of dipping into Lincoln's coffers,'' he added.
 
Land Sale Criticized
The judge said that another transaction involving the sale of 20,000 acres of land outside Phoenix by a Lincoln subsidiary was engineered solely to enable Lincoln to transfer $4.4 million to American Continental.
While Mr. Keating appeared confident throughout much of the proceedings that led to today's decision, few lawyers had said they thought he would be handed a favorable ruling from Judge Sporkin, who earlier in his legal career had vigorously prosecuted corporations as director of enforcement at the Securities and Exchange Commission. His decision today represents a small piece of the enormous legal battle between the Government and Mr. Keating.
Mr. Keating is under parallel investigations that are being conducted by a grand jury in Los Angeles, the S.E.C. and the Internal Revenue Service. A civil lawsuit was filed two weeks ago by the Office of Thrift Supervision against Mr. Keating and others seeking $40.9 million. Earlier, a racketeering case was brought by regulators naming Mr. Keating as a defendant and asking for $1.1 billion.
 
Bondholders Suing
He is also the target of lawsuits brought by bondholders of American Continental, many of whom are elderly and say they were defrauded by sales made to them in the lobbies of Lincoln branches. The company is in Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings.
Mr. Keating has struck back at regulators in other lawsuits, but the Sporkin proceeding stands out, not only because it addressed many legal questions for the first time, but also because it served as a critical turning point in the public relations battle between Mr. Keating and regulators.
Mr. Keating's lawsuit provided him with a powerful forum to strike back at the Government, putting regulators on the defensive and introducing important pieces of evidence that at the least raised questions about how officials had handled the affair.
 
Took the Spotlight
At the same time, Judge Sporkin's willingness to question both the Government and Mr. Keating at great length over more than six months emboldened the Phoenix developer to move into the public spotlight. Only a month before the Sporkin hearings began last December, the normally loquacious Mr. Keating sought to maintain a low profile. He declined to answer any questions before a Congressional committee examining his campaign contributions to five senators who regulators say intervened on his behalf, and instead invoked his Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination.
Once the hearings were under way and it became clear that Judge Sporkin would permit Mr. Keating wide latitude, he radically changed his tack, appearing on television and arranging interviews with virtually anyone who would listen.
For hours, Mr. Keating would engage in a casual colloquy with Judge Sporkin, who seemed to be enjoying the event, often asking questions as he leaned back in his chair, almost supine, and stared at the ceiling, his glasses perched atop his head. The judge questioned, interrogated, debated and chatted with Mr. Keating during several days of testimony from January to May.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Why the Broad Selloff in Oil Stocks?

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Aug. 23

 BODY:
Even as commodity traders extended the upward march of oil prices in the futures market, investors continued to unload their holdings in oil companies and oilfield service companies, for the third consecutive day.
Among the oil stocks, Texaco fell $3.625 a share today, to $60.125; Chevron lost $3, to $75.625; Mobil declined $2.375, to $62.875, and Occidental Petroleum fell $1.75, to $22.375. In the oilfield service sector, Halliburton lost $2.875, to $50.625; Schlumberger fell $2.125, to $61.125, and Baker Hughes slipped $1.875, to $29.125.
This broad and unexpected selling wave began Tuesday with Wall Street's growing conviction that a shooting war along the Saudi-Iraqi border was imminent. Price declines have been especially deep in the oilfield service sector, with one mutual fund specializing in oilfield stocks, the Fidelity Select Energy Service fund, falling by 8 percent in the last three days, to $14.07. 
 
Rise in Prices of Oil Futures
Most of the attention on oil prices has been focused on the futures market. The contract for September delivery on the New York Mercantile Exchange closed at $31.93 today, up 71 cents. But the posted price for oil bought by Texas refineries has also soared. Producers are getting $29 a barrel this week, compared with $15.50 as recently as July 13. Analysts said those prices are certain to translate into higher third-quarter revenues for most of the industry.
So why are investors shedding energy stocks with crude oil prices at their highest level in nearly five years?
Anthony Banham, managing director of Simmons & Company International, an investment firm in Houston, said the selling was a logical response after the large price gains posted this year by many energy issues. ''My guess is you are seeing a correction to a knee-jerk runup in oil prices,'' he said. ''There really is no reason for us to be trading for some extended period of time in the $30-a-barrel range.''
 
Nervousness Over Profits
Other analysts and investment bankers attributed the selloff to nervous money managers. As the collapse of the broader market gathered momentum, these analysts said, the money managers came under pressure to take profits where they could to offset mounting losses in other issues. Profits in the energy sectors were among the fattest on their books this year.
Another reason is mounting uncertainty within the oil industry itself about demand and pricing in the coming months. Many oil executives are concerned that prices may retreat just as quickly, possibly below $20 a barrel, after such a rapid rise.
''When $18 oil becomes $25 oil, it's a good thing for oil stocks,'' said Thomas A. Petrie, chairman of Petrie, Parkman & Company, an investment firm in Denver. ''But somewhere between $32 and $60 it becomes too much of a good thing, and major imponderables loom on the investment horizon.''
Some important issues include how much demand for oil and gasoline would be dampened by high oil prices and a severe recession, whether Congress would agree to a guaranteed, minimum price to encourage higher spending for drilling and, most critically, how soon a price collapse would follow a price spike.
Bryan Jacoboski, an oil analyst at Paine Webber Inc. in New York, said money managers wrestling with these issues should be betting on energy stocks. Instead, many have not accepted the view that oil prices could average or exceed $25 a barrel or more in 1991 because that would require them to reshape their stock portfolios drastically, he said. ''If crude prices do no more than stay where they are now, people should be buying oil stocks with both hands,'' he said.
He recommended the purchase of Unocal, Murphy Oil, Texaco and Amerada Hess. ''A lot of scenarios could lead to lower prices than where we are today, but prices will still be higher than where we were before the invasion,'' he said.
With worldwide oil demand rising and production capacity in OPEC strained, Iran, Iraq, Saudi Arabia and Kuwait had planned to expand production from their oilfields in coming years. But one consequence of the Iraqi invasion in Kuwait, Mr. Jacoboski said, was that ''about the only thing one can say with 100 percent confidence is that capacity expansions will be delayed.''
Suzanne L. Cook, an oilfield service analyst at Merrill Lynch in Dallas, issued a buy recommendation this morning for several big companies in the oilfield service sector. In an interview, she said investors had a chance to buy into the sector before stock values of oil service companies resumed an upward climb that had begun last year.
''In this already somewhat tight market,'' she said, speaking of oilfield services, ''we are now introducing higher oil prices and stimulus for higher levels of activity for drilling.'' She added that Merrill Lynch would soon raise its earnings estimates in the industry by 20 percent for 1991. Her recommendations included Dresser Industries, Schlumberger, Halliburton and Baker Hughes.

HEADLINE: 'Parking' Spaces for Jittery Dollars

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
In the midst of the Persian Gulf oil crisis, much of the world's money is fleeing to safe harbors in Britain, Australia and Canada.
These three currencies have become the haven for millions of dollars from worried investors and, as a result, have rocketed to recent highs against the American dollar. The reason is energy. These countries have it. 
Normally, one would not expect sterling or the Australian dollar or the Canadian dollar to provide protection for the troubled money of the world.
Traditionally, sterling and the Australian dollar have both been volatile, burning many investors who put their trust in them. The Canadian dollar is less volatile, but, like the other two, is a high-yield currency, supported by high local interest rates that attract foreign investors. Such high-yield currencies have traditionally meant more risk, something investors would not normally look for during a confrontation like that between Iraq and most of the rest of the world.
But in this situation, these countries and currencies have something else. They have energy at home - oil, coal and natural gas - and are net sellers of energy abroad. This gives them a cushion in the current crisis from the negative economic impact of higher oil prices and the threat of supply disruptions. And that gives investors some measure of the extra comfort sought when financial markets are in turmoil.
 
'Best of Both Worlds'
''You are getting the best of both worlds,'' said Robert A. White, vice president of First Interstate Bank in Los Angeles. ''You are getting a high yield, and you are putting your money into a country that will benefit from the higher oil prices.''
''People are parking cash,'' said Francoise Soares-Kemp, vice president at Credit Suisse in New York. ''Its a real non-brainer reaction,'' she added. ''People are just chasing yields, and on top of that these countries are long on the resources.''
The flight to these currencies has been swift. Since the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, sterling is up 5.3 percent, the Australian dollar is up 5 percent and the Canadian dollar is up 2 percent.
This invasion rally has pushed the British pound, which closed at $1.9555 in New York yesterday, to its highest level since November 1981. And the Canadian dollar, which reached 88.55 cents late yesterday, touched its highest point since July 1978. And for the Australian dollar, its 83.51 cents to the dollar was the best it has done since February 1989.
All three currencies jumped sharply yesterday with the pound up more than three cents from $1.9239 Wednesday, the Australian dollar up almost a penny and a half from 82.04 cents, and the Canadian dollar gaining almost half a penny, from 88.08 cents.
 
Swiss Stability
The dollar also continued to fall against other currences yesterday, passing its all-time low against the Swiss franc and falling to a new low against the German mark. In late trading in New York, the dollar was at 1.2560 Swiss francs, down sharply from 1.2780 Wednesday and its lowest level since World War II. The previous closing low in New York was 1.2690 on Dec. 31, 1987.
The Swiss franc is helped by its traditional status as a stable currency, which has long attracted investors, and, now, its generally lower dependence on imported energy than other Continental countries, especially West Germany. While not in the interest-rate class of the high-yielders, the Swiss franc, with three-month interest rates at 8.75 percent, is even yielding a little more than a dollar investment.
Against the mark yesterday, the dollar fell to 1.5444, down from 1.5589 on Wednesday and below the record low set last Friday of 1.5495. Before that, the lowest level since 1948, when the mark was created, was 1.5700 on Dec. 31, 1987. Against the Japanese yen, the dollar was basically unchanged, ending at 146.19 against 146.15 Wednesday.
The U.S. Dollar Index, which is an average of the dollar against a basket of 10 major foreign currencies, fell yesterday to 84.98, its lowest level since July 28, 1980. The index is used as the basis for a futures contract traded on the Financial Instrument Exchange in New York.
In the current Persian Gulf crisis, the Canadian dollar and the Australian dollar have gotten stronger, although their central banks have eased interest rates a little recently. This is in part because the jump in oil prices and the expected increase in inflation at home mean there is little chance that rates will be eased again soon. Canadian short-term rates are about 12.85 percent, and Australian rates are about 13.75 percent.
 
'Comfortable in London'
In England, where short-term rates are around 14.88 percent, there is also no immediate expectation of lower rates.
John W. Baker, senior vice president at Bank Julius Baer & Company in London, said much of the money that is going into these currencies appears to be coming from Japan and the Middle East. ''A lot of investors from the Middle East feel comfortable in London,'' he said, referring to the buying of pounds.
Britain, Canada and Australia are all net exporters of energy. Based on 1989 data, Australia, which has significant coal resources and also produces oil, has net energy exports equal to abvout 65 percent of its consumption. Canada, a big producer of natural gas and oil, has net exports of about 18 percent. Britain, a major oil and coal producer, is a bigger energy consumer, but still had net energy exports equal to about 1.5 percent of consumption.
This run to the British pound is similar to the lift it got in the last oil crisis of 1979-80. Then the pound, which averaged $1.92 in 1978, moved up to an average of $2.12 in 1979 and $2.33 in 1980. But neither the Canadian dollar nor the Australian dollar moved higher then. The Canadian dollar actually declined from an average of 88 cents in 1978 to 86 cents in 1980 and the Australian dollar held relatively steady, averaging $1.12 in 1978 and $1.12 in 1980.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Trade Obstacles Among Africans

BYLINE: By Jane Perlez

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya

 BODY:
On the edge of Nairobi's industrial park sits one of the most visible manufacturing ventures in Kenya. Founded after independence in 1963 by the Jumas, an Asian family who came to Kenya from Uganda, the company, Orbitsports, makes soccer balls, rugby balls - indeed, all kinds of balls - dart boards, boxing gloves, and a wide range of sports clothing and leisure wear. Its soccer balls were used in the recent World Cup matches in Rome.
''From here we send to France, Italy, the United States,'' said Nizar Juma, the managing director. 
Orbitsports is an African success story. But it is also a telling example of why trade among African countries is extremely difficult. Orbitsports has grown because of its exports outside the continent.
High-minded economists from the West stream into Africa suggesting ways that countries could not only export to the lucrative markets of Europe and the United States but also trade with each other. The experience of Orbitsports, which is also the only Adidas franchise in sub-Saharan Africa, might show the economists some of the obstacles.
In the beginning, Mr. Juma said, Orbitsports did well on African business alone. Now, 23 years later, more than half the company's trade is with Europe, where it was recently able to outprice and outsell the Adidas franchise in Hungary.
Mr. Juma's hand-stitched, top-of-the-line soccer balls command a lower price in Europe than in Africa. But a multitude of political and economic problems gave him the incentive to search for business away from Africa.
First, the company had protracted problems getting its bills paid in Africa. A few years ago Libya, then one of the company's biggest customers, owed more than $1 million. It took diplomatic efforts to get the bill paid.
Second, even though a number of East African nations have a preferential trade agreement, jealousies are pervasive. Thus, neighboring Tanzania prefers to buy its sports equipment in Europe rather than to ''make Kenya rich,'' Mr. Juma said. ''They pay 45 percent more for Adidas in Europe, and then the freight back, even though the products are made next door,'' he added.
Also the idea of doing business across the continent - from Kenya in the east to the Ivory Coast in the west - makes Mr. Juma laugh. ''If I want to export to the Ivory Coast, it's often easier out of Paris,'' he said. There is no direct flight to the Ivory Coast from Kenya.
The goods must pass through Lagos, Nigeria, perhaps Africa's most corrupt airport, where Mr. Juma reckons about 75 percent of any shipment is likely to be stolen. Even from one East African country to another, transport is a headache.
Mr. Juma's soccer balls do well in Europe because the quality is high - thanks largely to the stitching by the 500 Kenyan workers - and the price is right. The workers receive a basic 2,200 Kenyan shillings a month, or about $100 at the current exchange rate of 22 shillings to the dollar, for a five-day, 40-hour week with three weeks of paid vacation a year.
But where his product does well on quality and price, the efficiency is poor in comparison with Adidas's Asian franchises. Part of the reason is a tradition that workers go home to their rural villages the day after payday. On that day, there is 30 percent absenteeism.
The market within Kenya is good for Orbitsports. The company provides 90 percent of the country's sporting equipment, and the brand name is a household word, at least in Nairobi, where the company has invested in extensive newspaper and radio advertising to convince consumers that Orbitsports products, particularly track suits, are as smart as any imported brand.
Snob appeal among Kenyans is on the rise, Mr. Juma said. So with a bit of marketing inventiveness, Orbitsports came out with another label, L'Equipe - which has a foreign sound. ''Friends come up to me in their track suits with L'Equipe written on the front and apologize for not having bought Orbitsports,'' Mr. Juma said. ''I just smile and say, 'That's O. K.' ''
Nevertheless, Mr. Juma sees future growth more and more in exports, especially as American importers look for replacements for Asian products that are subject to quotas. The Kenyan Government is beginning to offer incentives to exporters. An export processing zone is being established in the industrial park not far from the Orbitsports factory, where manufacturers will be able to import raw materials duty free as long as the finished product is exported.
''We've had inquiries from American companies,'' Mr. Juma said, as he headed for a trip to the United States. ''I think we can fill a gap on the clothing side.''

HEADLINE: 'Junk Bond' Prices Plunge In Reaction to Stocks' Fall

BYLINE: By ANISE C. WALLACE

 BODY:
Heavy selling sent prices of high-risk, high-yield ''junk bonds'' sharply lower yesterday as traders reacted to the uncertainty in the Middle East and the sharp decline in the stock market.
''It's a nightmare,'' the head trader at one Wall Street firm said. ''The market was very, very illiquid.'' 
Prices of many junk bonds were down at least a point, or $10 for every $1,000 face amount. Some zero-coupon bonds, which pay no current interest, fell by much greater amounts. For instance, Burlington Industries bonds fell 3 points, to $35.50, and Fort Howard bonds dropped 3 points, to $43, traders said.
 
Effect on RJR Nabisco Issues
Bonds of RJR Nabisco Inc. were hit hard, as were the company's warrants, which are traded on the New York Stock Exchange. The RJR junk bonds due in 2009 dropped 2.125 points, to $106.25, down 12 points from the high in July. The company's bonds due in 2007 fell 3.75 points, to $80.75, down 16 points from the July high. The warrants, which can be exchanged for common shares of the company's stock, fell to $4.75, down one-half point.
Since the beginning of August, the First Boston High Yield Index has declined about 4 percent, compared with a 10 percent decline in the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index and a 5 percent drop in the price of 30-year Treasury bonds, said Sam DeRosa-Farag, an analyst at the firm. The price of the average bond in the index is 75 cents on the dollar, compared with 98 cents a year ago, he said.
Wall Street traders said the junk bond market was acting in concert with the stock market as investors worried about a recession. Additionally, Wall Street dealers were marking prices of bonds down on selling, or anticipated selling, by mutual funds that must raise cash to meet shareholder redemptions.
 
'Junk' Funds Lose Investors
A number of organizations that operate junk bond funds, including T. Rowe Price Associates, Fidelity Investments and the Vanguard Group, said this week that investors have been switching their cash out of the funds in recent weeks.
Professionals at investment management firms that own junk bonds complain that Wall Street dealers are not willing to provide capital for their trades, making prices of these thinly traded securities more volatile.
''It looks like dealers have thrown in the towel and repriced the market,'' said David A. Briggs, senior trader at Federated Securities in Pittsburgh.

HEADLINE: Venezuela to Increase Oil Production by 25%

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 23

 BODY:
Venezuela, the largest oil producer in Latin America, has announced it will raise production by 25 percent to offset oil lost because of the embargo on Iraq and Kuwait.
Venezuela will increase production by 350,000 barrels a day in September, the nation's Minister of Energy and Mines, Celestino Armas, told a Venezuelan congressional committee here Wednesday night. By December, production is scheduled to rise by a total of 500,000 barrels a day, to 2.5 million barrels, he said. 
 
A Big Windfall
Speaking hours after world oil prices rose above $30 a barrel, Mr. Armas calculated that Venezuela stands to gain an extra $1.2 billion to $2.4 billion in oil revenues this year. Last year, Venezuela earned $9 billion, largely from selling crude oil at an average price of $14.62 a barrel.
The windfall is expected to wipe out the financially troubled nation's 1990 budget deficit of $1 billion.
The minister's statement appears to end three weeks of indecision here on energy policy. Venezuela's President, Carlos Andres Perez, reportedly promised the United States on Aug. 7 that Venezuela would increase oil production by 500,000 barrels. But he has said his country, a founding member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, needed the group's permission to exceed an OPEC quota of 1.945 million barrels of crude oil.
In recent days, it has become clear that a full OPEC meeting has been blocked by a militant group of oil producers led by Algeria, Libya and Iran, which oppose higher production.
On Monday, Mr. Perez, long a spokesman for the third world, expressed concern that the soaring price of oil could hurt the world economy.
''It is not our plan to allow this crisis to skyrocket oil prices and to cause serious damage to the international economy,'' the President said. ''Venezuela feels it is her obligation to look after our clients and to safeguard the equilibrium of the world oil market.''
 
Big Supplier for the United States
Venezuela's production increase is good news for the United States. In recent years, the South American country has alternated with Saudi Arabia as the largest source of crude oil for the United States. In 1989, Venezuela sold the United States about a million barrels of crude oil a day - about 18 percent of America's total crude-oil imports.
During the 1973 Arab oil embargo, Venezuela sharply increased oil production and exports to the United States. This time, Venezuelan public opinion is again heavily in favor of increasing production.
Frustration over a prolonged recession in Venezuela, a country recently accustomed to the highest standard of living in Latin America, is bolstering the push for more production. Low oil prices forced Mr. Perez to adopt unpopular austerity measures shortly after he took office in February 1989. About 300 people were killed in ensuing riots.
Last year, Venezuela's gross national product collapsed by 8 percent, partly because of the austerity measures and partly because of adjustment to new free-market policies. Until the recent jump in oil prices, economic growth was expected to be flat this year.
''This little war is a bonanza for us,'' Teodoro Petkoff, a socialist politician, said in an interview, echoing the sentiments of many Venezuelans. ''We are doing better off the misfortune of others.''

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Bonds Decline Further

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The selloff in the credit markets continued yesterday and interest rates rose, as dealers reacted to a further rise in oil prices by marking down the price of most Treasury securities.
''The market has one eye on oil and the other on wire reports coming out of the Middle East,'' said Daniel Callahan, director at Deutschebank Government Securities Inc. ''But there is very little liquidity in the market.''
Despite the continued pessimism in the market, Mr. Callahan and others said that at this juncture it would be unwise to make big bets that the rise in interest rates would continue unabated.
 
'You Have to Behave'
Given recent events, traders were forced to cast an extremely practical eye on prospects of war and the impact on credit markets. 
''At these levels you have to behave yourself,'' one government bond trader said. ''The Street expects this whole Middle East thing will come to a solution pretty soon. And while war would be negative initially, how the market moves after that would depend on news of how it is going.''
The price decline was recorded in issues with maturities of more than two years. The continued sharp slide in stock prices supported prices of short-term securities, as investors appeared to move some money out of equities and into short-term notes and bills.
The short end of the maturity spectrum was firm despite the fact that the Treasury auctioned $10.5 billion worth of one-year bills yesterday. Given the market's extreme nervousness, injecting that much new supply in the market could have pushed up short-term interest rates.
At the auction, the one-year bills were sold at an average discount rate of 7.40 percent, up from the average rate of 7.34 percent at the last one-year bill sale on July 26.
''The fact that we had a bill auction and that prices are firm is a positive sign,'' another bond trader said. ''But everybody is afraid of what might happen Friday and over the weekend.''
 
'Impossible to Trade'
Dana Johnson, chief money market economist at the First National Bank of Chicago, said: ''In these circumstances it is impossible to trade the fixed-income markets. They are subject to the latest rumor or headline coming out of the Middle East or any movement in oil prices.''
By late yesterday, the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 96 9/32, down 21/32, to yield 9.11 percent, compared with 9.04 percent late Wednesday.
Among note issues, the 8 3/4 percent 10-year notes were offered at 98 1/2 in late trading, down 10/32, to yield 8.98 percent. The 8 1/2 percent five-year notes were offered at 99 9/32, down 6/ 32, to yield 8.66 percent. But the 8 percent two-year notes rose by 1/32, to a late offered rate of 99 19/32, to yield 8.22 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates fell slightly.
In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.51 percent, down 6 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. And six-month bill rates fell by a basis point, to a late offered rate of 7.49 percent.
The sense among market participants that the Persian Gulf crisis would break out into war very soon was heightened yesterday when Iraq said that a failure by foreign governments to abandon their embassies in Kuwait would be regarded as ''an act of aggression.''
Scores of diplomats and their families left Kuwait yesterday, but the United States and a number of other Western nations have made it clear that they have no intention of completely abandoning their embassies.
Although an outbreak of war would almost certainly feed inflation fears by pushing oil prices well above the level of $32 a barrel that they reached yesterday, some analysts said the Federal Reserve might react to the start of a war by easing monetary policy.
 
Unpleasant Alternatives
''If war breaks out, the least worst alternative for the Fed is to loosen up,'' said Robert Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International.
''It would not work miracles,'' he said, ''but in a war you need more liquidity, and the evil the Fed must absolutely avoid is recession. Compared to increased inflation, that is the greatest risk.''
Activity in the secondary markets for investment-grade corporate bonds and tax-exempt municipal bonds was light again yesterday as prices continued to decline. And the continued slide in stock prices also pushed down the prices of high-yield ''junk bonds.''
Corporate bond traders said that prices of most actively quoted issues fell by about 1/2 point.
The decline in the tax-exempt market was more severe: market participants said that prices of most issues fell by a range of 1 1/4 points to 1 1/2 points.
In the new-issue market, the Rohm & Haas Company offered $100 million of 10-year notes through an underwriting group led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.
The 9 7/8 percent notes, which mature Sept. 1, 2000, were priced at 99.53 to yield 9.95 percent, 95 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve reported yesterday that all three measures of the nation's money supply rose during the week ended Aug. 13. The report had no effect on prices in the credit markets.
Following are the results of yesterday's auction of one-year Treasury bills:

HEADLINE: Vehicle Sales Drop By 4.7%

BYLINE: By PAUL C. JUDGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 23

 BODY:
Sales of domestically built cars and light trucks fell 4.7 percent in mid-August, a decline that analysts attributed to record high sales a year ago.
While analysts noted that overall demand for vehicles has been sluggish this year, they said that consumers appeared to be shrugging off the crisis in the Middle East.
''So far there seems to be no visible effect on car sales from gasoline problems or fears about the Middle East,'' said David Healey, an automotive analysts with Barclays de Zoete Weld in New York.
The nine manufacturers with American operations sold 160,633 domestically built cars in the Aug. 11-20 period, a decline of 10 percent from a year ago. Sales of vehicles classified as light trucks, which account for about a one-third of all vehicles sold, rose 5.1 percent. 
Cars sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 6.9 million, compared with 8.4 million in the comparable period of last year. Through July of this year, the seasonally adjusted sales rate was 6.6 million.
 
Japanese Auto Makers Gain
Overall sales of cars and light trucks by the Big Three domestic auto makers declined 9 percent in mid-August. The Japanese auto makers that produce cars in the United States posted a 38.8 percent increase in sales.
The General Motors Corporation reported that its car sales fell 10.1 percent, the smallest decline of the Big Three. The Ford Motor Company's car sales dropped 22.9 percent. The Chrysler Corporation reported a decline of 27.3 percent of its cars.
The major manufacturers said August sales were consistent with their forecasts in spite of the tension in the Persian Gulf. Analysts cautioned, however, that sales of cars could plummet if the price of gasoline continued to rise and the economy worsened.
Michael M. Luckey, president of the Luckey Consulting Group, said he was ''very cautious about the prospects for vehicle sales over the next 12 months.''
Mr. Luckey said he had reduced his forecast of 1991 light-vehicle sales to 13.5 million cars and trucks from his previous estimate of 14.2 million, because of the anticipated jolt to the economy of higher oil prices.
The auto industry is bracing for a drop in sales and executives said they are scrutinizing daily sales reports from dealers for signs that the car-buying public is holding back from making purchases.
Some auto executives expressed surprise that the threat of war in the Middle East had not caused auto sales to fall even further in August.
Joel Pitcoff, manager of research and analysis for Ford, said higher gasoline prices had not had a discernible effect on customers' choices of vehicles.
''There does not seem to be any massive stampede toward fuel-efficient vehicles,'' he said.
One measure that the Persian Gulf crisis has had little effect so far on auto sales was the strong sales performance of mini-vans, pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles in mid-August. Higher gasoline prices are expected to affect sales of these vehicles first, because of their generally large engines and relatively inefficient designs.
Ford's light-truck sales jumped 19.3 percent, led by the strong sales gains of the company's Explorer sport-utility vehicle. G.M.'s light-truck sales also rose 1.3 percent while Chrysler reported a 9.5 percent decline.
Car and truck sales soared a year ago when manufacturers offered huge cash rebates and dealers slashed prices in an effort to sell a large backlog of unsold 1989 models to make room for 1990 models.
Dealers' inventories are lower this year, so there has not been as much pressure to offer discounts on unsold models.
The Toyota Motor Corporation sold 10,444 cars manufactured at its plant in Georgetown, Ky., a gain of 65.8 percent. The Honda Motor Company, which manufactures cars in Marysville, Ohio, posted car sales of 12,323 units, an increase of 26.6 percent. The Nissan Motor Company sold 3,129, up 3.9 percent, and 3,696 light trucks, a decline of 3.5 percent. Both vehicle lines are produced at Nissan's plant in Smyrna, Tenn.

HEADLINE: Even as Profits Fall, Home Builder Plans to Gain

 BODY:
The Ryland Group, the nation's second-largest home builder, took analysts by surprise earlier this summer when it said it would earn less in the second quarter than it had expected.
''Some people couldn't believe that what was happening to everybody else was happening to Ryland,'' said Melissa Cook, a New York-based analyst for Barclays de Zoete Wedd Ltd.
The Columbia, Md., builder of moderately priced houses has indeed started to smart from the real estate downturn that is already consolidating its rivals. With housing starts at their lowest level since the early 1980's, Ryland's net earnings declined 46 percent in the second quarter, to $5.7 million, from the corresponding period last year. 
 
Low-Risk, Conservative Strategy
But Ryland is showing the same resilience in the low point of this cycle as it has shown in previous slumps. Its success arises from a low-risk, conservative approach that limits the 23-year-old company's profits in boom times, but cushions it from losses during the downturns.
''They have a tremendous record of long-term performance and will come out ahead,'' said Kenneth Campbell of Audit Investments, a money management company in Montvale, N.J. ''You cannot kick them in the teeth now simply because they aren't going to perform this year.''
While hundreds of home builders have gone bankrupt since early 1989, Ryland, one of the few that are publicly traded, earned $170 million on revenues of $1.4 billion last year. Today, it is one of the least leveraged companies in the business, allowing it to borrow and expand at a time when competitors are retrenching.
 
Aiming to Gain Market Share
In fact, Charles E. (Ted) Peck, Ryland's chairman and chief executive, said the company aims to double shareholders' equity in each of the next five years - just as it has in every year for the last 17. It hopes to pick up market share as rivals weaken, luring home buyers with financing plans that few in the industry can afford to offer.
At the heart of its strategy is the fact that Ryland, unlike many home builders, rarely ties up its money in raw land. It buys finished lots already equipped with roads, sewage, water and utility systems. This method enables the company to get its money out of properties more quickly and reduces its borrowing costs and the risks of having an inventory of undeveloped lots when demand for new houses is slack, as it is today.
In the rare instance when it buys raw land - as it does in California because developed lots are scarce -Ryland minimizes its risk by buying the properties in joint ventures with financial institutions.
 
Debt-to-Equity Ratio: 0.5 to 1
''By using financial partners, they get only half the profits, but they can keep capital in lines they prefer,'' said Barbara K. Allen, an analyst at Kidder, Peabody & Company. As a result, Ryland's debt-to-equity ratio is only 0.5 to 1, Ms. Allen said. By contrast, the top 100 builders had an average ratio of 8.4 to 1 last year, according to Builder magazine.
''Ryland may have missed out in some markets, but they are not suffering the catastrophic losses from borrowing that other builders are,'' Ms. Cook said. In fact, at a time when bank regulators are tightening commercial lending standards and developers of all stripes are finding it difficult to obtain financing, Ryland recently managed to complete a three-year revolving credit agreement with about a dozen banks for $265 million.
''I think our conservative practices offer them some reassurance,'' Mr. Peck said.
 
Cautious Top Executives
Ryland's conservative approach is in keeping with the backgrounds of its top executives, analysts say. While most home builders are headed by risk-taking entrepreneurs, Mr. Peck, who is 64 years old, worked for the Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation for 32 years before joining Ryland in 1981, where he considered himself ''an organizational man.'' He was most recently an executive vice president and director of Owens-Corning.
Before becoming president of Ryland in May, Roger W. Schipke, who is 53, was a senior vice president of the General Electric Company's $5.6 billion-a-year appliance division.
Mr. Schipke is scheduled to become chief executive in January and may become chairman later next year when Mr. Peck retires, analysts say. He is expected to carry on in the company's cautious tradition.
''He seems very much like Mr. Peck and takes a very analytical, well-thought-out approach to strategy,'' Ms. Allen said. ''Mr. Schipke is expected to continue the positive leadership left under Mr. Peck.''
 
Orders Down 21% in First Half
Yet, Ryland recently started to skid. The company booked 4,207 orders for homes (their average sale price last year was $116,000) during the first six months of this year, a 21 percent decline from the corresponding period in 1989.
And times are getting tougher. Housing starts have slipped to their lowest level since the recession of nearly a decade ago. Based on July's figures, new houses and apartments are being built at a seasonably adjusted annual rate of 1.15 million, the lowest level since September 1982.
And with Iraq's invasion of Kuwait earlier this month have come renewed fears of inflation and the prospect of higher interest rates, which would further hurt housing sales.
 
More Bankruptcies Expected
Analysts expect bankrupcties among home builders this year to top those in 1989, when 1,840 builders of single-family homes went under, according to statistics compiled by Dun & Bradstreet. That figure is scarcely 1 percent of the approximately 200,000 home builders nationwide, most of which build fewer than 10 houses a year.
Indeed, Ryland's stock has been trading at its lowest level in two years. Trading as high as $25.50 a share in 1989, it closed yesterday at $11.50 on the New York Stock Exchange, down 25 cents.
Yet Ryland says it is less vulnerable to the vagaries of regional economies than many of its rivals, most of which operate locally, because it builds houses in 17 states.
 
Shift of Regional Profits
While most builders began feeling the slowdown in demand in 1987, Ryland thrived until about a year ago because of its business in Washington, D.C., and California, where real estate values continued to increase until recently. Ryland is now likely to pin its hopes on regions experiencing slight rebounds like Phoenix, Houston and Denver.
Ryland says its ability to provide financing also gives it an edge. It is one of only about two dozen home builders to provide financing to its buyers. Ryland's mortgage unit has accounted for about 17 percent of the company's earnings for the last five years.
''The mortgage company is not a big-income item, but it definitely gives them an edge in times when credit is tight,'' said Michael Mead, vice president of research at Legg Mason Wood Walker Inc. in Baltimore.

HEADLINE: Durables Orders Up 2.9% in July

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23

 BODY:
Factory orders for durable goods rebounded 2.9 percent in July, the Government reported today.
The orders had declined 3.2 percent in June, and analysts said the zigzag performance this year indicates a listless manufacturing economy that could worsen because of the Middle East crisis.
''Orders have been bouncing up and down, and the net effect is a very weak upward trend,'' said Cynthia Latta, an economist with DRI/McGraw-Hill, an economic research firm in Lexington, Mass. ''I don't actually see the industrial sector in decline, but there's not much stimulus for expansion there.'' 
 
'A Little Tougher'
Thomas Runiewicz, an economist with the WEFA Group in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., agreed, but added: ''Since the Middle Eastern crisis, we're in a different ball game. It makes things a little tougher than what we were experiencing before, and that was fairly flat.''
The Commerce Department reported that orders for durable goods - relatively expensive items expected to last more than three years - totaled a seasonally adjusted $128.3 billion in July.
In the first half of the year, orders rose during three months and fell in the other three, with January posting a record drop of 10.5 percent. Over all, orders for the six months fell to $744.7 billion, down 1.5 percent from the comparable 1989 period.
The sluggishness in the manufacturing economy has cost 350,000 factory jobs since that sector peaked in March 1989, and 7,000 of those job losses occurred in July, according to Labor Department figures. Drops in orders normally result in production cutbacks and job layoffs.
Ms. Latta noted that the July rise in orders included a 5 percent increase in transportation orders, to $34.9 billion, which she said would not result in any immediate economic stimulus.
''A lot of that is aircraft, and that's production three, four, five years down the road, given the big backlogs that aircraft manufacturers have,'' she said.
Excluding transportation, orders would have risen 2.2 percent.
 
Military Orders Are Down
Military orders slipped 3.1 percent, to $7.6 billion, after a 21.9 percent decline in June, but Ms. Latta suggested this category would pick up because of the Middle East crisis.
''There have been a lot of things shipped over to Saudi Arabia'' to support American forces there, she said. ''There are a lot of stockpiles that will have to be replenished.''
Orders for nonmilitary capital goods jumped 10.7 percent, to $40.1 billion. This category is often a barometer of business investment plans, but analysts were hesitant to read anything into the July number because of the Mideast uncertainty.
Orders in all major durable categories rose in July: nonelectrical machinery was up 2.7 percent, to $22.4 billion; electrical machinery, 1.9 percent, to $20.4 billion, and primary metals, 1.5 percent, to $11.6 billion.
Shipments of durable goods slipped 2 percent, to $124.7 billion, after an increase of six-tenths of 1 percent in June. Unfilled orders rose seven-tenths of 1 percent, to $501.6 billion, more than offsetting a decline of five-tenths of 1 percent in June.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Cattle Prices Fall the Limit; Hogs and Pork Bellies Drop

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Cattle futures prices plunged the daily limit on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange yesterday, as concern grew about the implications of the Middle East crisis.
Pork futures also suffered a setback, particularly bellies, which were down the limit for the third consecutive day.
Beef is more expensive than pork at the meat counter now, making cattle much more vulnerable to outside price swings, said Phil Stanley, a trader at the Merc and consultant to ADM Investor Services. 
''Economic worries had as much to do with the break in cattle prices as anything,'' he said.
Inflation or recession would turn shoppers away from high-priced beef cuts.
Pork futures have been under pressure from the skidding cash hog market, and trading yesterday was no exception.
''It's been kind of a free fall for cash hogs,'' Mr. Stanley said, noting that they have lost nearly $3.50 a hundredweight this week. A large increase in the number of animals being brought to slaughter has severely weakened the cash market.
Pork prices were at record highs earlier this summer but have been in a fairly steady decline. Meanwhile, cattle prices have remained fairly level for half a year.
While the relatively high price of beef makes cattle more vulnerable, pork is not immune, Mr. Stanley said.
''If the stock market falls on its face,'' he said, ''we can expect another deep plunge for cattle and hogs.''
Live cattle settled 0.75 cent to the limit of 1.50 cents lower, with the contract for delivery in October at 76.72 cents a pound; feeder cattle were 0.57 cent to the limit of 1.50 cents lower, with August at 88.95 cents a pound; live hogs were 0.30 cent lower to 0.20 cent higher, with October at 48.42 cents a pound, and frozen pork bellies were 1.58 cents to the limit of 2 cents lower, with August at 43.72 cents a pound.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
GORBACHEV WARNS BAGHDAD TO BACK OFF OR U.N. WILL ACT; IRAQIS RING KUWAIT MISSIONS

BYLINE: By R.W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24

 BODY:
President Bush made a big gain today in his effort to isolate President Saddam Hussein of Iraq when President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union warned Baghdad that he was ready to back additional measures to toughen the United Nations embargo against Iraqi commerce.
Ranking American officials said Mr. Gorbachev's action made it likely that the Security Council would soon allow United States warships and those of Britain and France, as a last resort, to stop Iraqi tankers trying to evade sanctions. One official said he expected to ''see Iraqi rudders shot off,'' disabling the ships, if oil-bearing tankers tried to make port this weekend.
 
Security Council Gathers
The 15-member Council gathered tonight and began informal discussions on a proposed resolution after the five permanent members - the United States, Britain, France, the Soviet Union and China - circulated a draft with new wording.
Unlike previous drafts, the latest version does not specifically call for the use of ''force,'' but it would nonetheless authorize countries to halt ships suspected of violating the embargo. Removing a major stumbling block, the Soviet representative to the United Nations said he was in agreement with the text. 
As the three-week Middle East crisis continued, Iraqi troops surrounded the embassies of the United States and a number of other countries in Kuwait, preventing people from entering or leaving and trying to force diplomats to close the missions.
A West German spokesman said the Iraqis had cut off electricity and water to most of the operating embassies tonight after first notifying the Norwegian Ambassador, the senior Western diplomat still in Kuwait. But the State Department said the United States Embassy had not been affected.
 
No Intrusion on Embassy
''They have not made any moves against the embassy or intruded in any fashion,'' Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said at a briefing earlier in Kennebunkport, Me. ''But they are nonetheless present.''
President Bush, vacationing there, was said to be withholding any retaliatory action unless the United States Ambassador, W. Nathaniel Howell 3d, and the handful of aides who remained with him were harmed.
The Bush Administration reacted much more angrily to news that 100 or more American diplomats, dependents and Marine guards, who had been evacuated from the embassy in Kuwait in a caravan of 33 automobiles on Wednesday, had been held up in Baghdad despite Iraqi promises to let them leave the country.
A State Department spokesman, Richard A. Boucher, called their detention ''another stark example of Iraqi duplicity.'' The 100 refugees were reported to be safe at the United States Embassy in Baghdad, but they seemed to be stuck there at least until the impasse at the embassies in Kuwait was resolved.
The Soviet Union vacated its embassy in Kuwait, the only major power to do so, but said it remained open in legal terms, even if shuttered.
President Gorbachev sent President Hussein a sternly worded message warning him that failure to heed a United Nations resolution ordering him to pull out of Kuwait would ''inevitably compel the Security Council to take corresponding additional measures.''
American officials said Mr. Gorbachev was referring to the possibility that the Security Council would authorize military action to back up economic sanctions. The United States, Britain and France have been seeking Soviet support for their naval blockade of Iraqi commerce.
About 12 Iraqi ships are currently under allied surveillance in or near the Persian Gulf and Red Sea, Pentagon aides reported tonight.
The British Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, said one Iraqi ship had unloaded oil at Aden, in Yemen, and that one other Iraqi tanker was in the Aden port and three others were en route there.
 
Arms Linked to Libya
Before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, Iraq regularly sent its crude oil to the Aden refinery for processing, and the resulting products were sold on the world market by Iraq, according to David T. Mizrahi, editor of the Mid East Report.
Mr. Fitzwater said that despite the sanctions, which have been in force for three weeks, Baghdad was still receiving shipments of arms, aircraft parts and some of the raw materials used in the manufacture of chemical weapons. He would not say where the supplies had come from or how they had entered Iraq, except to indicate that some had arrived by air.
Intelligence officials said Libya was one source of the arms. They said that fewer than 10 planeloads of weapons had been sent this week from Tripoli to Baghdad.
The flights are believed to have carried Polish-made tank engines and other military supplies loaded earlier this summer aboard the Iraqi-flag vessel Balqees when it docked in the Polish port of Gdynia.
 
Battleship Enters Gulf
The Balqees was bound for an undetermined Middle East port when American warships began shadowing it in mid-August. An Administration official who insisted on not being identified said the ship later changed course and unloaded its cargo in Libya.
Increasing the military pressure on Iraq, the United States moved the battleship Wisconsin, with its Tomahawk cruise missiles and its 16-inch guns, through the Strait of Hormuz and into the Persian Gulf. From there Kuwait, Baghdad and all of Iraq are well within its range.
Six Air Force reserve units were mobilized, all with C-5A and C-141 cargo planes to bolster the massive airlift of troops and weapons from the United States to Saudi Arabia. The squadrons are in Mississippi, Texas, New Jersey, New York, Maryland and Massachusetts.
This weekend, military officials said, the Central Command, which oversees all United States military operations in the Middle East, will move from MacDill Air Force Base in Tampa, Fla., to Saudi Arabia.
President Hussein's next step is unclear. Having set several deadlines Friday for the embassies to close down, he allowed each to pass without definitive action, a State Department official noted, adding, ''The big crunch at noon did not materialize.''
The Japanese Foreign Ministry said its two remaining diplomats in Kuwait had been told that their diplomatic immunity had been revoked but that no attempt had been made to remove them from the embassy. Spain's Ambassador to Jordan said the diplomats had been told to leave their embassies by Saturday morning or be forced out, increasing fears that the stranded envoys would be taken hostage.
There was no confirmation from Baghdad of a report by Britain's Independent Television News quoting the Iraqi Information Minister, Latif Nassif al-Jassem, as warning of dire consequences if Britain invaded Iraq. He was quoted as saying of the 230 British hostages, ''If Iraqis die, so will the British civilians.''
About 10 other American diplomats were reported to have stayed behind in Kuwait with Ambassador Howell, who is a 50-year-old Virginian. Most of them are thought to be consular officers.
 
Symbol of U.S. Protest
Asked what the Ambassador's standing orders were, Mr. Fitzwater said: ''Force has not been applied. Should he be subject to that, he will have to act accordingly, but those are judgments that he is authorized to make in many cases. Beyond that, I couldn't go into specific discussions that we have had with him.''
The State Department said its communications links with the embassy via satellite were intact.
Mr. Fitzwater insisted that the United States intended to keep the embassy open ''to look after the American community'' and to serve as a symbol of continuing protest against Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. But officials said privately that they did not expect Mr. Howell to resist a direct order from the Iraqis, delivered at gunpoint, to close down.
The Bush Administration appears to have concluded that the Iraqis are unlikely to take overt military action like invading the embassies, which are considered the sovereign territory of the nations involved. But it takes very seriously the prospect that Mr. Howell and his colleagues may be made hostages, as the 100 evacuees from the American Embassy appear to be.
''In any event,'' an adviser to the President said, ''we doubt any of the embassies can hold out for more than three or four days at best.''
Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, describing President Hussein as a dictator, warned him against harming British diplomats or British hostages.
In addition to the British, West German, Norwegian and American Embassies, those of France, Japan, Sweden, Hungary and Romania were surrounded by troops this morning.
Jordan officially reopened its border to refugees, who in fact have never stopped crossing it, and Asians and Arabs continued to pour out of Iraq by the thousands. The Interior Ministry said that it would limit the flow to 20,000 people a day.

LENGTH: 962 words

HEADLINE: FEDERAL RESERVE SAID TO RULE OUT A RATE SHIFT NOW

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo., Aug. 24

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve apparently decided at a policy meeting this week to make no changes in interest rates until the Middle East crisis quieted down and a clearer picture emerged of its effect on the economy.
Such a decision suggests that the Federal Reserve, for the time being, remains more concerned about controlling inflation than quickly trying to offset any potential recessionary effect of the Middle East crisis.
Perhaps more important, some officials said that if oil prices, after the crisis, were to settle at, say, $8 a barrel above their pre-crisis levels, or at about $26 a barrel, then the long-term effect on the economy would be minimal - perhaps shaving one-quarter or one-half a percentage point off economic growth.
 
Growth Rate Is Weak
The Commerce Department reported today that growth in the second quarter was at an anemic annual rate of 1.2 percent, after an also-weak 1.7 percent in the first quarter. That means the gross national product has grown at an annual rate of 1.5 percent so far this year. [Page 31.] The minutes of the closed-door meeting in Washington on Tuesday will not be released for six weeks. But some Federal Reserve officials, here for a conference, indicated in off-the-record conversations that a change in policy when no one knows what might happen in the Middle East could inject new uncertainty into the jittery bond and stock markets. 
 
Annual Two-Day Event
The gathering here in Grand Teton National Park, at a lodge deep in the mountains and woods, is an annual two-day event that brings together Federal Reserve officials and economists from universities and from Wall Street.
The aim is to socialize, to exchange views and to attend five hours of conference sessions each morning, leaving the afternoons free for white-water rafting and hiking. The conference sessions today and Saturday center on controlling inflation in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe; a half-dozen central bank presidents and finance ministers from these countries traveled here to participate.
But the Middle East was clearly a distraction for the Federal Reserve delegation, led by Alan Greenspan, the chairman. There was much coffee-break talk about the latest reports from Wall Street and the Persian Gulf. And some Fed officials suggested that as long as the crisis continued and future oil supplies were uncertain, there was nothing that the Federal Reserve could or should do.
''It is fairly well accepted that monetary policy, reacting to supply shocks, is not appropriate,'' a Federal Reserve official said.
Largely as a result of war fears and oil-supply disruptions, the Dow Jones industrial average has lost nearly 13 percent of its value since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, and long-term bond yields have climbed more than half a percentage point.
 
Regularly Scheduled Meeting
The Tuesday policy meeting in Washington was one that is held every six weeks. The presidents of the Federal Reserve's 12 regional banks gathered in the capital with Mr. Greenspan and the five Federal Reserve governors to review the state of the economy and decide whether to use their power to lower interest rates, thus stimulating buying and investing, or push up rates and thus reduce the odds of a higher inflation rate.
The Federal Reserve has been slowly pushing down interest rates for nearly a year, out of concern that the economy was weakening. The last drop came on July 13. Although Mr. Greenspan has not commented on the economy since Iraq invaded Kuwait, he maintained until then that while the economy was weak, the odds of a recession were low.
A day after the Washington meeting this week, Mr. Greenspan and two Federal Reserve governors, Wayne D. Angell and Edward W. Kelley Jr., traveled to Jackson Hole and were joined by 6 of the 12 presidents of the Federal Reserve regional banks.
 
Two Unwelcome Developments
In informal interviews, several Federal Reserve officials said the Iraq crisis had brought on two developments that the central bank had hoped to avoid. One was a fall in the value of the dollar, a potentially inflationary development because it makes imports more expensive. The other was the sharp rise in interest rates for long-term Government bonds to offset any erosion in the value of bonds from future inflation.
The rise in bond rates reflected in part a concern on Wall Street that the Middle East crisis might cause the Federal Reserve to reduce interest rates in an effort to avoid a recession. In the Wall Street view, rather than warding off a recession, such action by the Federal Reserve might fuel inflation. ''People perceive that the Fed might be ready to cave in on interest rates, so the Fed has to maintain them longer than it might otherwise have wanted to do,'' said Jerry Jordan, chief economist at First Interstate Bancorp in San Francisco.
 
Decisions Not Disclosed
None of the five or six officials who discussed informally the Middle East crisis and the American economy would disclose specific decisions made at the Tuesday meeting. But they said the nation would not know for a month or more what might happen in the Middle East: whether war would break out; whether oil shipments would be further disrupted, or how high oil prices might rise. In such an uncertain situation, the officials said, adjusting interest rate policy would be inappropriate.
But some said that if the price of crude oil was to stabilize at about $26 a barrel - it fell in trading today to about $31 a barrel - that would be a $25 billion to $50 billion ''tax'' on consumption. Economic growth would slow a bit, in this view, but not to the point of a national recession, which is defined as two consecutive quarters of negative growth in the gross national product.
