HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Amid Crisis, West Meets Mideast in Saudi Arabia

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, Aug. 24

 BODY:
The arrival of American and foreign troops in Saudi Arabia and the flood of Kuwaiti refugees here are helping to pry open Saudi society, which has been hermetically sealed.
This deeply conservative Muslim country of about 16 million people is being exposed to the glare of international news reporting, and Saudis are being drawn into a social enterprise that is radically different from their retiring ways and conspicuous traditions.
So far, the Saudi Government has done its best to insulate its people from the effect of this crisis, keeping foreign troops well out of sight in all civilian regions - several hundred miles from this port city and from the inland capital of Riyadh - and maintaining a business-as-usual facade in its news reports and daily economic activities.
Saudi newspapers and television news talk of the ''Islamic, Arab and other multinational forces,'' arriving here to stand up to Iraq - practically ignoring that the bulk of these troops are American soldiers that include women, Christians and Jews, in a country that is almost 100 percent Muslim.
In Dhahran, Al Khobar and Dammam, the heart of the Saudi oil industry and its vital pipelines, pumping stations and oilfields, barely 200 miles from where Iraq's missiles and troops are stationed, shops are open late into the night, hotels are full of guests, and military vehicles are only rarely seen. The American troops are out of sight, 15 to 20 miles away in the desert. 
Oil has made the Saudis one of the world's most prosperous nations, with an economic growth rate of 5 percent and virtually no unemployment. In Jidda, where the Saudi Government has been for the summer, the pulse of life is untouched. Cars linger over the long seaside corniche, and Egyptian soap-operas fill television programming.
On the nightly news Saudi soldiers are paraded and senior Saudi officials review troops endlessly and listen to patriotic poems. But there is little discussion of the huge American buildup under way and virtually no mention of Iraqi troop movements close to the Saudi borders.
''We don't feel a thing,'' said a senior oil executive in Dhahran as he drove his car up and down the main avenues of the oil town that is the headquarters of the Aramco oil company. ''If it weren't for foreign radio stations you would not suspect we are on the verge of war.''
 
A Xenophobic Grip
Yet, a deep and fundamental debate has started in Saudi circles about the impact of this crisis on the future of the country.
Saudi intellectuals and liberals are thrilled by the notion that the presence of American troops, and the immense good will the world is showing Saudi Arabia, will loosen the hold of the fundamentalist Muslim religious leaders, who have opposed every step of modernization in this country, from the education of girls to the introduction of television.
But the purpose of the foreign presence does not escape Saudi officials. They are concluding that this country can absorb a first strike by Iraq, but fervently hoping that the United States would hit first, with a devastating attack on Iraqi forces.
''We think that there is a 3 percent chance of missiles getting through to our vital oil facilities,'' said one Saudi official, who expressed confidence that the combined American-Saudi airpower can handle any such atack with a ''knockout'' blow to Iraq's air force and missile launchers.
Saudi intelligence officials estimate that Iraq's rate of production of land-to-land missiles is two per day, and a Saudi defense offical said it is believed that Iraq has not perfected the technique of mounting chemical warheads on its missiles.
''The greatest probability is that they have to deliver chemical payloads by airplanes or artillery, which gives them a limited range of operation,'' said the defense official, who like many Saudis and foreigners interviewed here about the current crisis, asked for anonymity.
In the streets of this desert country, the burning topic of conversation is the threat of war, and foreigners fret over whether they should stay or leave, while Saudis are content to bask in the notion that with American troops here and the whole world standing against Iraq, there is little doubt that President Saddam Hussein's days are numbered.
''He is finished,'' said Khalid Ali Alturki, a successful businessman who lives in Al Khobar, speaking of President Hussein. ''The only question is how much it will cost - not whether it will happen. I think Kuwait will pay a heavy price, but no matter how much it costs, it is worth it to have back the country and rid us of Saddam.''
Saudi officials and senior members of the ruling Kuwaiti al-Sabah family who live here in the summer capital of Taif, said that Kuwait is indeed putting its formidable economic muscle behind the military effort against Iraq.
It is understood from these officials that Kuwait, which holds foreign assets estimated at over $100 billion under the control of its Government-in-exile in Taif, is increasingly footing a growing part of the enormous costs of the deployment here of the American, Egyptian and other forces, which is running at some $25 million a day.
''We are willing to sacrifice everything,'' said the Kuwaiti Crown Prince, Sheik Saad al-Abdullah al-Sabah, in a meeting with the foreign press on Thrusday in Taif.
 
Kuwaitis Underwriting
Kuwait and Saudi Arabia are also believed to have advanced financial aid to Egypt to compensate for the rising costs of moving back tens of thousands of Egyptians fleeing Iraq and Iraqi-occupied Kuwait from Jordan.
And, Saudi Arabia has been carrying the cost of housing, feeding and giving refuge to some 100,000 Kuwaitis who are refugees here.
But Saudis in decision-making positions are rethinking the country's financial aid to the Palestine Liberation Organization. They make it clear that they will no longer deal with the current leadership of the P.L.O. and that they expect Yasir Arafat to be replaced as its chairman if the organization expects to resume normal ties and continue to receive financial aid.
In Saudi Arabia, hardly a single Saudi misses the opportunity to vilify Mr. Arafat, who is seen as having betrayed this country and other gulf Emirates by siding with Iraq in the conflict.
''From now on, we will support causes not people,'' said one well-placed Saudi in an extensive interview today. ''We are making the point that Yasir Arafat is finished here but that other Palestinian leaders who appreciate all the financial help we have extended to the Palestinian movement over the years and who have not turned against us will be welcome.''
Officially, the Saudi Government denies that there has been any break with the P.L.O. Saudi officials said that a request by Mr. Arafat to come here a few days ago was politely turned down, but on Thursday King Fahd received Hani al-Hassan, a senior P.L.O. leader who is widely seen as sympathetic to the gulf monarchies within the Palestinian movement.
In conversations with many Saudis, including ordinary citizens, there appears to be a firm conviction that Iraq, the P.L.O., Yemen and Jordan have conspired to subdue the gulf emirates and Saudi Arabia in the hope of each getting rewards out of what is described as an obvious plot.
''When Saddam attacked Kuwait, he really calculated that we will back down,'' said a Cabinet minister. ''Eventually they thought the P.L.O. would dominate Kuwait using the 400,000 Palestinians living there to govern and that Yemen would get a territorial adjustment in the South taking some land from us there. Jordan and Iraq would reap substantial financial aid from a subdued Saudi Arabia and Kuwait.''
The talk of the future in this region now envisages a whole different scenario. ''This is the beginning of what I think is going to be a rollback of the excessive influence of the Saudi religious establishment,'' a liberal Saudi official said.
Faced with the immense good will the world has shown Saudi Arabia, the most conservative religious leaders, led by Sheik al-Baaz, the most senior religious figure in the kingdom, conceded in television interviews over the past few days that even though those who came here to ''defend Islam'' include ''atheists and Christians,'' not to mention women, they will be ''rewarded by God for their good deed,'' thus putting the seals of approval on the American presence here.
 
American Habits
Even though they deny it, American troops here are believed to have access to alcoholic drinks, including beer, and as their numbers rise to an anticipated 200,000, their influence is bound to be felt more strongly.
Already in the Eastern province of Saudi Arabia, where the bulk of Kuwaiti refugees and American troops are, Kuwaiti women and American women soldiers have been seen driving their cars and jeeps in a country where women are strictly forbidden from driving.
There is a story that has circulated widely in Saudi Arabia over the past few days: that an American woman soldier in uniform drove her car into Al Khobar to shop. Her behavior was viewed as nothing less than scandalous in a society where women virtually never appear alone in public.
The soldier was approached by a Mutawaa, one of the Islamic fundamentalists who enforce laws of proper behavior. The Mutawaa raised his cane warning the soldier to get back into her car and go away. Whereupon, the story goes, the American pulled her gun and pointed it at his face sending him scrambling for cover.
''It does not matter that the story is true or not,'' said a Cabinet minister who was among 14 people recounting it over a lunch recently. ''What matters is that everyone wants to believe that it is true,'' he said.

PUB-DATE: August 25, 1990

SECTION: Section 1; Page 4, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1006 words

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Gorbachev Sends a Signal Ending Hesitation at U.N.

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Aug. 24

 BODY:
President Mikhail S. Gorbachev warned President Saddam Hussein of Iraq today that the Iraqi leader will face additional international sanctions if he does not withdraw his troops from Kuwait and release foreign nationals under his control.
Mr. Gorbachev's message to the Iraqi leader, reported by the Tass press agency, was a clear sign that Moscow was prepared to support a United Nations resolution authorizing limited military measures to enforce the embargo against Iraq. Members of the 15-member Security Council gathered tonight to begin debating a draft resolution.
Arab diplomats and Soviet journalists here said that despite the Soviets' hesitation to back the use of force, there was now little doubt that Moscow would withdraw its objections to the United States-sponsored resolution in the United Nations Security Council aimed at increasing naval pressure on Iraqi cargo vessels. 
''I am 100 percent sure the Soviet Union will either vote for the measure or abstain,'' said Maksim A. Yusin, the diplomatic correspondent for the Government newspaper Izvestia. ''A veto can be ruled out.''
 
'Losing Patience With Iraqis'
''It seems to me they are losing patience with the Iraqis,'' a senior Arab diplomat said.
In what Tass described as ''an urgent personal message,'' Mr. Gorbachev called on President Hussein to begin immediately honoring United Nations resolutions demanding that Iraqis leave Kuwait, restore the ousted Government and assure the safety of foreigners.
''Evading these resolutions will inevitably compel the Security Council to adopt appropriate additional measures,'' Tass quoted Mr. Gorbachev as saying.
The news agency itself added, ''It now depends on the Iraqi side how the Security Council will act.''
Moscow has not wavered from its condemnation of Iraq and its endorsement of economic sanctions, but Soviet leaders have consistently pleaded for more time to let the sanctions work before applying new pressures.
 
A Crossroads of Diplomacy
During the last week, Moscow has become a crossroads of international diplomacy, with senior diplomats from Iraq and Saudi Arabia visiting this week to compete for the Kremlin's support, and the Foreign Ministers of Kuwait and Egypt expected within days.
Arab diplomats said one clear signal of Moscow's loyalties in the crisis was the brusque official treatment of Iraq's emissary, Deputy Prime Minister Saddun Hammadi, compared with the warm welcome given the special emissary of the Saudi royal family, Prince Bandar Bin Sultan al-Saud.
Although Moscow has no diplomatic relations with Saudi Arabia, the Prince spent hours with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze and other senior officials, and told fellow Arab diplomats afterward that he was satisfied with the Soviet position.
''We have no reason to think they are not serious,'' said a Persian Gulf diplomat who sat in on some of the talks. ''We will give them the time.'' Soviets Argue for Delay In meetings with Prince Bandar and other Arab diplomats, the Soviets argued for delay so that Mr. Hammadi could pass along the Kremlin's mounting impatience to his superiors in Baghdad.
In the meantime, they argued, a few leaks in the embargo would not seriously reduce the pressure on President Hussein.
''They still hope they can influence Iraq, because they feel Iraq has nowhere to go,'' an Arab diplomat said.
Arab diplomats said Soviet officials also argued for caution because they see a serious risk of a catastrophic war, including the use of chemical weapons.
''There is still a lot of anxiety in this country,'' Mr. Yusin, the Izvestia correspondent, said in an interview. ''The memory of Afghanistan is fresh, and when the coffins start coming from the gulf not everyone will think the goal of stopping the aggressor is noble.''
 
Concern About Its Nationals
Diplomats and Soviet journalists said another factor in the more moderate Soviet approach was concern about the fate of Soviet nationals in the region, and a desire to evacuate as many as possible before increasing the pressure on Baghdad.
The Foreign Ministry said today that it had completed its evacuation of all 882 Soviet nationals from Kuwait, and was scheduled to begin removing Soviet women and children from Iraq this weekend.
''Soviet citizens in Iraq are not regarded as hostages, unlike citizens of Western countries, but we cannot take risks,'' Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov said on television tonight.
Yuri Gremitskikh, a Foreign Ministry spokesman, said that although the Soviet Embassy in Kuwait was empty, this did not mean that Moscow was complying with Iraq's demand that all embassies be closed, or that it recognized Iraq's annexation of the emirate.
''We said in advance that we were not closing the embassy in international legal terms,'' Mr. Gremitskikh said. ''In international legal terms we have not ended our diplomatic representation.''
Arab diplomats said the Soviet decision to abandon its embassy in Kuwait when Western embassies are defying Iraq's order to leave was typical of Moscow's more low-key approach.
 
Military Specialists Stay
Another example was the decision not to withdraw 193 Soviet military specialists from Iraq. Moscow says they are weapons technicians and have not taken part in the seizure of Kuwait. The Kremlin seems to feel that pulling them out might endanger the other Soviet citizens still in Iraq.
Still another reason for the greater moderation among the Soviets, diplomats said, is a reluctance to be seen as slavishly following the American lead.
''I think that they don't want to appear in this whole crisis to be trailing the United States,'' an Arab diplomat said. ''Maybe the United States has not been attentive enough to this factor.''
Offsetting the Soviet reluctance to move too quickly against Iraq is a feeling that the gulf crisis is a test of Moscow's commitment to new principles of international conduct, and the desire for the potential economic benefits that would flow from acceptance in the West.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Reserves' Quick Shift: Civvies to Olive Drab

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWBURGH, N.Y., Aug. 24

 BODY:
He spent Thursday night in Greenwich Village, shopping for clothes - just another 19-year-old. He got the call at 11:30 P.M. By this afternoon he was in an olive drab flight suit with an American flag insignia on one arm, checking in at the Air National Guard base here, 60 miles north of New York City.
His unit, the 137th Military Airlift Squadron of the 105th Group, had been called to active duty. 
Standing in a line, in front of a window, waiting to begin a slew of paper work, the second-year student at the Fashion Institute of Technology in Manhattan still seemed dazed.
 
'Excited and Apprehensive'
''I'm excited and apprehensive,'' he said. ''I'm backing this 100 percent.''
All day long, the 150 members of his unit, based at Stewart International Airport, arrived from New York, Connecticut, New Jersey, Philadelphia, Washington and as far away as Texas.
They were mostly men, mostly in their 20's, with a few in their 40's who had fought in Vietnam. There was a computer analyst from Texas, an unemployed Eastern Airlines pilot, a lawyer, a switching technician for New York Telephone Company and a 26-year-old New York City detective.
At least in front of reporters, the talk was not of war or hot desert sands or chemical gas but of the mundane details of tying up loose ends at home: powers of attorney, W-4 forms, checking accounts, life insurance and wills. They were told not to give their names to reporters.
 
Patriotic but Not Gung-Ho
What they actually felt as they left their families and entered the cauldron of the Mideast they kept to themselves. The base was not the place for them to spill emotions. They seemed proud but not gung-ho.
''We're not a bunch of Tom Cruises,'' said the commander of the 137th, a lieutenant colonel who identified himself only as Tom.
The narcotics detective said he was not worried at all. ''It's probably worse in New York than it is over there,'' he said.
 
World's Largest Aircraft
This is an elite unit. Its members fly and operate 12 C-5A Galaxies, 221-foot-long cargo planes that are among the largest aircraft in the world. The transports cost $130 million each and hold 246,000 pounds. The members fly the planes, maintain them and handle the cargo.
The guardsmen have been called up for 90 days and will be shuttling the planes forth across the ocean. Volunteer guardsmen have been operating the planes since Aug. 7.
 
Long Preparations
Colonel Tom, as the unit's commander was called all day, is a 43-year-old former Air Force pilot in Vietnam. He said this unit had prepared long and hard for today.
There had, he said, even been simulated calls to active duty. ''This is a simulated recall,'' the phone caller used to say.
After 9:30 P.M. Thursday, as Colonel Tom and other full-time personnel telephoned the unit members, they repeated the words: ''This is an actual recall. This is an actual recall.''
A unit member named Valerie, checked in late Thursday night. A 22-year-old assembly line worker at the General Motors plant in Tarrytown, N.Y., she had worked her usual 8 A.M. to 4 P.M. shift, putting together gas tanks on 400 cars. Then she drove to the air base.
Her father, who served in Korea and also works at the plant, gave her advice: ''He told me, 'Just be brave.' You'll feel better about yourself when you get back,'' she said.

HEADLINE: Southwest Boomed in 80's, Census Finds

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24

 BODY:
The five states whose deserts and canyons form the vast expanse of the American Southwest have seen some of the nation's sharpest increases in population in the last decade, preliminary 1990 census figures show. A boom in the Las Vegas area raised Nevada's population by nearly 50 percent.
While the growth in Arizona, New Mexico, Colorado and Utah was also strong, it was still slightly below the bureau's earlier estimates. Nevada grew by more than expected, rising to 1.2 million from 800,000 in 1980. The total population for the five states rose from 9 million to more than 11 million, or more than 20 percent; that was twice the estimated growth rate for the nation as a whole. 
The Census Bureau, which began distributing its preliminary estimates last week, has now issued figures on 40 states and the District of Columbia, a group making up just under half of the estimated national population. The figures on Arizona, Colorado and Nevada were in the most recent group; the New Mexico and Utah results were issued earlier. Data on most of the largest states, including California and New York, are still to come.
 
Growth Around, but Not in, Capital
The tentative figures, which are being distributed to 39,000 state, county and local governments for review, also show double-digit growth in Delaware, Maryland and Virginia, at the southern end of the sea of suburbs that run down the East Coast from Boston to Richmond. Those three states now have a population of 11.5 milion, after a steady 10 years of growth that reached almost 14 percent.
But the the city of Washington itself lost almost 10 percent of its population, or more than 60,000 people, and now may have as few as 575,000 people, the early data show. A slow downturn in population apparently accelerated at the end of the decade, when the homicide rate soared and crack markets blossomed on Washington street corners.
In the Northwest, a late-decade spurt that followed five years of sluggish growth pushed Oregon's population above earlier estimates, said Kimball Brace, a demographer and political analyst who is tracking the emerging figures. Alaska grew by 36 percent, but much of that increase came in the early 1980's, as the oil pipeline was completed.
Contrary to predictions that economic problems would slow its growth, Washington State grew by more than a sixth in the decade. That increase, nourished by the state's Pacific Rim export industry and an expanding cluster of high-technology concerns, may have garnered it an extra Congressional seat, redistricting experts say. In the South, a Surprise Loser? By contrast, Louisiana's loss of 0.6 percent of its population during the decade may cost it one of eight Congressional seats.
But Mr. Brace and other experts caution that few predictions about winners and losers can be made until the preliminary total for the entire country, the essential element in the redistricting equation, is available next week.
Census Bureau officials also note that procedures still going on may add three million or more people to the count. Among those procedures are a check of housing stock and the reviews by the state, county and local governments that are now receiving the data.
Demographers say the 1990 tally is still running well behind earlier estimates, though it has closed the gap somewhat since the first figures were distributed last week.
Mr. Brace, president of Election Data Services, who first identified the consistent discrepancy between the unchecked 1990 figures and the Census Bureau's earlier estimates, said the discrepancy was now running slightly below 2 percent. If that figure holds for the nation as a whole, it will mean that the census found about five million fewer people than the bureau had expected. In 1980, the bureau found 5.1 million more people than its earlier estimates had led it to expect.
But it is not clear whether the discrepancy is a result of a faulty 1990 tally, inaccurate earlier estimates or both. In addition, preliminary population counts are still not in for California, Texas and Florida, where much of the decade's population growth was concentrated.
Preliminary population estimates for those three states and seven others - Massachusetts, New York, Pennsylvania, Illinois, Indiana, Georgia and Alabama - are expected next week.

HEADLINE: Religion Notes

BYLINE: By Peter Steinfels

 BODY:
Woman to Head Alliance An American Presbyterian scholar has become the first woman to head a worldwide communion of churches. Dr. Jane Dempsey Douglass was elected president of the World Alliance of Reformed Churches, an association of churches rooted in the 16th-century Reformation theology of John Calvin.
The alliance includes 178 Presbyterian, Reformed and Congregational denominations with 50 million members in over 80 countries. Two-thirds of the denominations are in the third world. Recently, the alliance, which has a small staff in Geneva, has been most visible for its advocacy of human rights in South Africa and Rumania. 
Dr. Douglass, a 57-year-old professor of historical theology at Princeton Theological Seminary in New Jersey, had been a leader in the alliance for more than a decade. She will replace the Rev. Allen Boesak of South Africa, who resigned after revelations of an extra-marital affair.
Interviewed by telephone, Dr. Douglass linked her election this month to a decision last August by the alliance's General Council to emphasize the ''full freedom of women in the church.''
Almost half the alliance's member denominations do not ordain women as ministers, she said, and the General Council, the group's highest decision-making group, asked them to reconsider that position.
 
Reactions on Invasion
Religious groups that have recently been among the most outspoken critics of American military interventions and armaments are generally supporting the nation's position in the Persian Gulf crisis.
The National Council of Churches, the president of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops and the World Council of Churches, all of which have questioned previous military actions, have strongly condemned Iraq's seizure of Kuwait and supported resistance to it.
Most of the statements stressed the need for international cooperation, and they are wary about directly endorsing any specific military action by the United States.
The American Jewish Committee went a bit further, commending President Bush's ''forceful leadership'' and urging a ''firm and collective response.''
Mohammed T. Mehdi, Secretary General of the National Council on Islamic Affairs, condemned the Iraqi invasion immediately after it took place.
Last week, he criticized both President Bush and President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, saying they had ''cornered themselves'' by their ''action and hyperbole.'' He called on King Fahd of Saudi Arabia to prevent a confrontation.
 
Bishops Back Unions
In a statement of strong support for labor unions, the Committee on Domestic Social Policy of the United States Roman Catholic bishops has condemned the hiring of permanent replacements for striking workers.
Federal labor laws should ''outlaw the permanent replacement of workers involved in a legitimate strike,'' the committee said in its annual Labor Day statement.
''When replacements are permanent, they represent a major stumbling block to settlements,'' the statement said. ''When the issues are settled, agreeing what to do with two sets of workers - strikers and strikebreakers - is usually more difficult than settling the strike in the first place.''
 
Wages With the Church
All is not well on the Catholic bishops' own labor front. A study overseen by 15 Catholic groups, including the National Conference of Catholic Bishops, has found that the median annual salary of nonordained professional workers in the church is $22,258, 17.5 percent below the median income in the general population.
The study covered lay and religious staff members in Catholic schools, parishes and diocesan agencies but not professionals in Catholic hospitals. Over half the workers, whose median age was 42, had master's degrees.
Over 20 percent of the married workers surveyed had no family health benefits. Forty percent of the married workers reported needing second jobs, family gifts or other forms of outside income to make ends meet. Almost 70 percent had considered leaving their church jobs, primarily for economic reasons.
 
Torah Among Soviets
Several years ago, when Sidney Kwestel, president of the Union of Orthodox Congregations, decided to commission the writing of a Torah scroll in honor of Soviet Jews, he did not imagine that the task would be completed in the Soviet Union itself.
But two weeks ago in Leningrad, he watched a scribe ink in the last letter of the handwritten Sefer Torah, the first five books of the Bible that every synagogue treasures as its most sacred ritual object.
Thousands of Soviet Jews in attendance fell into line and came forward to kiss the scroll, said Eliezer Edelman, administrative director of the Orthodox Union.
Although the scroll was written in Israel according to the exacting requirements of Jewish law, 1,000 letters of the approximately 300,000 letters in the Torah had been left blank. These were filled in during a series of dedication ceremonies from Aug. 5 to Aug. 10 in Moscow, Berdichev, Kiev and Leningrad. The scroll will be kept by the Jewish communty in Kiev.
Mr. Edelman estimated that at least 25,000 Soviet Jews attended these events. The Torah scroll was accompanied by a 120-member delegation of American Jews.
While Mr. Edelman affirmed the seriousness of anti-Semitism in the Soviet Union, he also said: ''Wherever I went, I always wore a yarmulke. Not only did nobody bother me, but many young Soviet Jewish men also seemed to be wearing yarmulkes without fear.''

HEADLINE: The World v. Saddam Hussein

 BODY:
Cornered and desperate, Saddam Hussein now lashes out against diplomacy itself. His troops lawlessly threaten foreign embassies in Kuwait while his regime detains U.S. diplomats and dependents who were promised a safe exit from Baghdad. The most telling condemnation comes from Moscow, Iraq's longtime ally. An outraged Mikhail Gorbachev warns that an Iraqi failure to heed United Nations resolutions would ''inevitably compel the Security Council to adopt appropriate additional measures.'' 
Those measures need no spelling out. The Soviet Union is now weighing a Security Council resolution that would authorize use of force to secure compliance with economic sanctions. Americans who have been struggling to win Soviet approval have gained unexpected support from Saddam Hussein.
Each fresh breach of law solidifies the global consensus against him. Cumulatively, he and his associates are becoming war criminals in the classic Nuremberg sense.
In a decade, Iraq has managed to violate most of the Nuremberg Principles as formulated in 1945 by the Allies in World War II and reaffirmed unanimously by the U.N. in 1950. In law if not yet in fact, the Baghdad leadership could be held criminally accountable for Iraq's offenses. The Nuremberg Principles assert that a crime against world law is liable to punishment, that heads of state can be held responsible and that obeying orders does not exempt subordinates when a moral choice is possible. These are punishable crimes:
Crimes against peace, like initiating a war of aggression in violation of international treaties. Iraq initiated war against Iran in 1980, and against Kuwait 23 days ago.
War crimes, like the ill treatment of civilian populations in occupied territories, killing of hostages, plunder of private property or wanton destruction of cities. Iraq plundered Kuwait, stripped its people of their citizenship, abused innocent civilians and now makes hostages even of diplomats whose special status is protected by the Vienna Convention.
Crimes against humanity, like murder, deportation and inhuman acts or persecutions on political, racial or religious grounds. It is a capital offense in Iraq to insult the President, espouse Zionism, leave the ruling Baath Party or persuade someone else to do so. Using these laws, Iraq has executed thousands. It has waged genocidal war against its own Kurdish minority, using poison gas in contravention of a Geneva protocol to which it is a party. There is hardly a human rights convention that Iraq has not violated.
The chief defense of war criminals tried at Nuremberg in 1945-46 was that no precedent existed for their punishment. It does now.

HEADLINE: Letter: On Energy;
A Tax Would Make Oil Shock Worse

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''America's Neck and a New Noose'' (editorial, Aug. 2) is wide of the mark when it comes to crafting workable energy policies for this country's future. If the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has indeed put a noose on the United States economy, there's no need for Congress to be the one to pull open the trap door by jacking up prices even more with a new energy tax.
You say the United States ''can't do much'' about declining domestic production. It was that same attitude that led OPEC to think it could raise the cost of oil through the roof in the 1970's. The result was that, spurred by higher prices, producers in the United States increased their output by about 10 percent between 1976 and 1985. At least when OPEC is the one raising prices, American oilmen can reap some of the benefits and use the profits to strengthen the industry at home, reduce our need for foreign oil and help put supply and demand back into balance. 
An energy tax would bring most of the negative effects of an oil shock to the economy, including inflation, unemployment and a diminished quality of life, while weakening our energy industry by cutting the demand for products that aren't in short supply. The declining United States production that you rightly identify as a threat to our national security and our economic well-being would actually be accelerated.
As to the supposed conservation incentives provided by an energy tax, not all business leaders agree that more expensive energy will lead to great gains in efficiency. Last month, Red Cavancy, president of the American Paper Institute, observed that the proposed new energy taxes would shrink the pool of money available for such capital improvements. Similarly, a report issued by Congress's Office of Technology Assessment last June found that economic slowdowns tend to create conditions that impede energy-efficiency gains.
It wasn't just OPEC's greed that caused oil prices to collapse in the 1980's. The unexpected flexibility of producers in this country to find more oil and consumers to use less, aided by Federal policy changes that let the law of supply and demand bring the market into balance, played key roles in taking the bull by the horns.
As oil markets in the 1990's suddenly turn volatile, it's important that we remember a lesson of the 1970's and 80's, and keep the Government out of the business of setting energy prices.
 
VIRGINIA HINCS
Senior Editor, Energy User News
 Washington, Aug. 10, 1990

HEADLINE: Mexican Democracy Means Brokered Elections

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It is unfortunate that Javier Trevino, Minister of Press and Public Affairs at the Mexican Embassy (letter, Aug. 11), has chosen to misrepresent when he rhetorically asks, ''If no 'honest elections' have been held in Mexico, why do 237 out of the 500-member Chamber of Deputies belong to opposition parties?''
That opposition members occupy political offices in Mexico is not proof of democracy. Rather, it demonstrates the success of his party, the Institutional Revolutionary Party, or P.R.I., in manipulating elections. What Mr. Trevino did not say is that Mexican opposition parties began to ''win'' elections only after 1968. It was that year the Mexican Army, on orders of Luis Echeverria, the next President, opened fire on unarmed student demonstrators in the Plaza de Tlateloco, killing 500 while the world press, in Mexico City for the 1968 Olympics, watched in horror. 
Mr. Echeverria, scrambling to repair Mexico's image, established quotas for opposition party ''victories'' in the Chamber of Deputies, a rubber-stamping body. His successors merely expanded the quotas.
Opposition victories have thus been the result of brokered deals orchestrated by the P.R.I., not of actual ballots cast by Mexican voters.
That Mexico is not democratic is evident. The Organization of American States warned Mexico last June that it ''must comply exactly with the obligation to guarantee the free and full exercise of political rights.''
Unarmed citizens, protesting election fraud in municipal elections throughout the state of Michoacan, were forcefully dislodged in 19 towns by the army in a wave of unprecedented violence last spring.
As I walk to and from my office every day, I see the tired faces of the Mexican people, faces that have had to endure the ravages of a decade of inflation and an austerity program that has cut real wages by 70 percent. Mexico does not need lectures on democracy. But it certainly needs democracy.
 
LOUIS E.V. NEVAER
 Merida, Mexico, Aug. 12, 1990

HEADLINE: Man Suffocates As Intruders Hold a Party

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
Four people, three of them teen-agers, were charged yesterday with murdering a mentally retarded man who suffocated inside a closet while they caroused in his Bronx apartment for nearly six days and sold his belongings, the police said.
The victim, Freddie Thomas, 32 years old, was found dead inside a plastic garbage bag in his apartment at 665 Burke Avenue in the Williamsbridge section at 6:15 P.M. on Wednesday. His girlfriend, Opah Sanders, 34, also mentally retarded, was imprisoned in another closet for six days but survived. She was set free on Wednesday evening just before the group left. 
Both Mr. Thomas and Ms. Sanders were unemployed and received Social Security payments for their disabilities, the police said. They met more than a year ago in a program for mentally disabled people, called the Bridge, that teaches them to live independently. The couple had lived in the apartment together since October. ''They were harmless, slightly mentally retarded people,'' said a detective. ''They kept to themselves, getting by on Social Security.''
An autopsy revealed that Mr. Thomas was smothered by tape his attackers had put over his nose and mouth, said Ellen Borakove, a spokeswoman for the Medical Examiner. The police said he is believed to have died sometime Aug. 17 or Aug. 18. Acting on information from Ms. Sanders, the police arrested four people on charges of second-degree murder, robbery and unlawful imprisonment on Wednesday night. They were identified as Ms. Sanders's sister, Hope Kelly, 16; William Fennell, 21, of 2302 Andrews Avenue; Samuel Rivera, 17, of 8 Fordham Hill Oval, and Barbara Redding, 17, of 380 East 143d Street. A fifth suspect was being sought.
The couple's ordeal began at 9 P.M. on August 16 when Mr. Thomas answered a knock at the door and let in Hope Kelly, Ms. Sanders's sister, who had lived off-and-on at the apartment, Lieut. Anthony Vitaliano of the 47th Precinct detective squad said.
Minutes later, Lieutenant Vitaliano said, Miss Kelly let in a woman and three men, one of them armed with a shotgun. One of the men hit Mr. Thomas over the head with the gun, taped his face with duct tape, bound his wrists with telephone wire and locked him in a closet, the police said. In the living room, another man hit Ms. Sanders from behind, bound her with tape and put her in a second closet.
 
Parties in Apartment
For the next two days, the group held parties, Lieutenant Vitaliano said. They also sold Mr. Thomas's television, a videocassette recorder and stereo equipment on the street.
The group also bought a padlock and sealed the closet where Mr. Thomas was imprisoned, the police said.
On Saturday, when Mr. Thomas's body began to decompose, the group wrapped it in a shower curtain and a garbage bag and placed it in a bedroom with a fan blowing, the lieutenant said.
On Tuesday about 6 P.M., the five untied Ms. Sanders, who had been given only cigarettes and fruit juice, and fled the apartment, the police said.
None of the suspects showed any remorse for the crime, investigators said. The four arrested made videotaped statements to investigators.
''It seems senseless,'' said Lieutenant Vitaliano. ''These were two harmless people who didn't bother anyone.''

HEADLINE: Quiet Race Worries Connecticut Democrats

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Aug. 24

 BODY:
In two weeks Democrats will choose in a primary for governor between a challenger whose strategy for victory counts on as few voters as possible going to the polls and a convention-endorsed candidate who rarely acknowledges there is a race at all.
The result is a nearly silent campaign of murmurs and glancing blows that has done little to light the partisan fires that many Democrats say will be needed if the state's largest political party is to remain in power.
Based on the candidates' backgrounds and campaign pledges, Democrats face a clear choice in the Sept. 11 contest between United States Representative Bruce A. Morrison of Hamden and State Representative William J. Cibes Jr. of New London, especially on the major question of how the state will deal with its troubled finances next year.
But because Mr. Cibes (pronounced SEA-bus), the challenger, has little money to trumpet his views, and Mr. Morrison, the party front-runner, has chosen almost to ignore Mr. Cibes's challenge, voters have had to be in the right place at the right time to know that there is a race or to be inspired to take any interest in it. Recent world events have not helped. 
''With the Mideast thing and a lot of other issues, my sense is that there are not a lot of people excited about it,'' said Carmella M. Lattizori, who, as First Selectman, is the top Democratic elected official in the town of Barkhamsted, and who is a volunteer worker for Mr. Cibes. ''The primary has kind of gotten back-burnered, if that's a word.''
Strategy has played a part as well. Mr. Cibes's campaign manager, Jonathan Pelto, said this week that because Mr. Cibes is largely unknown, a big turnout would not be good because it would probably swamp the polls with Morrison supporters. Only if less than 20 percent of all Democrats vote will Mr. Cibes's supporters have much hope of being in the majority, Mr. Pelto said.
In the last Democratic gubernatorial primary, in 1978, about 33 percent of the voters turned out. But Mr. Pelto said the low level of interest in this year's race makes it more like the last statewide primary, in 1982, for the office of secretary of the state. Only 18 percent of the 661,000 Democrats registered in that year bothered to vote.
For Mr. Morrison, who has raised more than 10 times the $90,000 collected by Mr. Cibes, the primary has seemed almost incidental. The real opponent, as Mr. Morrison made clear in campaign appearances this week, is former Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., a Republican who is running as an independent and leading by a large margin in the polls over all other candidates. The Republican candidate is Representative John G. Rowland of Waterbury.
Voters will decide in the primary which Democrat has the best chance against Mr. Weicker, Mr. Morrison said, and only by going toe to toe with Mr. Weicker now can Mr. Morrison demonstrate that he is that man.
''I'm focused on winning the election in November,'' Mr. Morrison said in an interview about the primary in which the name ''Cibes'' crossed his lips only once. ''That's my goal. That's why I'm running,'' he said. ''In order to win in November I have to win the primary.''
On many issues Mr. Morrison and Mr. Cibes do not differ significantly. Both have made protecting the environment a theme in their speeches, both are for abortion rights and both have presented plans to reinvigorate the state's moribund economy.
 
The Question of an Income Tax
The major difference between them is the question of taxation. Mr. Cibes, who is the chairman of the General Assembly committee on Finance Revenue and Bonding, says that Connecticut's tax system has reached a crisis and must be changed next year. Mr. Morrison says there is still room to maneuver.
Mr. Cibes has said he would propose a sweeping package of tax changes that would lower the sales tax to 5 percent, from 8 percent, cut corporate taxes and impose a progressive income tax for the first time. The new engine of an income tax could then be used for property tax relief, environmental protection and education, he has said.
Mr. Morrison argues that residents are too strained by taxes and a souring economy to risk what he says would be a major tax increase under Mr. Cibes.
Spending must be controlled before taxes are considered, and voters must be consulted through a referendum before an income tax is imposed, Mr. Morrison said.
 
Democrats Less Popular
Both candidates agree that their stands on the tax question are proper measures of their character and philosophies of government. Mr. Morrison said his position reflects a view that people do not want anything ''stuffed down their throats.'' Mr. Cibes said his stance reflects the courage and leadership to say what he believes is needed, however unpopular it may be.
Opinion polls show that Democrats have become less popular in Connecticut in the last year, and some poll-takers say that this race simply reflects that disaffection.
Of 500 residents questioned late last month by the Institute for Social Inquiry at the University of Connecticut, for example, 34 percent said the state would be ''better off'' with a Republican governor. Only 23 percent said they preferred a Democratic governor, while most of the rest either favored Mr. Weicker or said it would depend on the candidate. The poll has margin of error of plus or minus 5 percent.
A recent Gallup poll said that both Mr. Morrison and Mr. Cibes were the least-favored candidates in any of the possible three-way races that voters could decide in November.
Democrats have controlled the governor's office for all but four years since 1955, including the last nine years under William A. O'Neill, who decided in March not to run again as his popularity wilted with the state's economy.
''People are ready for a change without a doubt; they say we need something else,'' said Mrs. Lattizori. ''But I'm not sure at all what that something else is going to be.''

HEADLINE: S.I. Port's Fate Is Muddled by the Mideast Crisis

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA

 BODY:
Before the Persian Gulf crisis began, the Staten Island home port was almost ready to open, or almost ready to close, depending on who was asked. Now, the prospects for the port are even more confused.
The debate over the port, the New York metropolitan region's largest military project, has been given a new wind by the largest and costliest troop deployment since the Vietnam War.
The port is now more than 90 percent complete. More than $150 million has been committed to building the pier, the maintenance building and other parts of the base. The families of more than 100 crewmen for the Normandy, the new ship that is the center of the naval task force that is the center of the plan, have already settled into new apartments at Fort Wadsworth near the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge. 
Before the current crisis, the scramble to cut military costs had landed the port project on the list of possible cuts in the military budget.
 
'Everything Is Up in the Air'
Now, no one is certain what will happen. ''A few days ago we thought we would probably be announcing more base closures,'' said Glenn E. Flood, a Defense Department spokesman. ''Now everything is up in the air.'' Mr. Flood said no decision was likely on the port until the fall, when a new budget is adopted.
In the meantime, the base's supporters and opponents are pushing in opposite directions. Officially, at least, Staten Island is the designated port for the Normandy and its support group.
The 567-foot missile-carrying cruiser is being checked at a shipyard in Maine. Navy officials expect it to arrive in New York in October.
Chief Petty Officer Lawrence A. Jones, an engineer on the Normandy, and his wife, Diane, recently moved into a new garden apartment at Fort Wadsworth. Mr. Jones has no doubt that the Normandy will sail into New York harbor in a few weeks. ''That's why I'm moving my whole house here,'' he said.
 
Private Users Sought
But more than $100 million in additional construction for the base and personnel support installations has been stalled for months.
Moreover, Mayor David N. Dinkins, who opposes the base, is so certain the project will be killed that a few weeks ago he sought plans for alternative uses for the installation. A report is due in early September.
''The Mayor's intent is the same as it's always been, to find private industrial uses of that site,'' said Albert Scardino, the Mayor's press secretary.
Staten Island and five other new ports across the country were proposed in 1983, when the United States was working to build a 600-ship Navy and needed more berthing space. Opponents said the dispersal was intended to win political support for the buildup.
The Navy is now reviewing its system of bases, including all six home ports, which face different levels of opposition. Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney has imposed a spending moratorium on military construction projects, including ports, and has placed four of six home port projects, including Staten Island, on a list of possible cuts. A Nuclear Danger? The port was initially embraced by New York City officials, led by Mayor Edward I. Koch and Representative Guy V. Molinari, now the Staten Island Borough President. Many believed that the Navy would pump $387 million a year into the city's economy. But in the mayoral campaign last year, Mr. Dinkins said he would fight the project because the ships to be berthed on Staten Island could carry nuclear weapons that would endanger the region.
A tour of the two areas within the port - Fort Wadsworth, beneath the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, and the new pier and 200,000-square-foot maintenance building in Stapleton, about two miles away - indicates that the base is close to operating capacity and Navy officials say it is ready to handle the Normandy.
The pier, on which the Normandy and 10 other ships can be docked, was dedicated in 1989. In June, the Navy officially moved its local headquarters from the Brooklyn Navy Yard, which is to be closed by 1992, to Staten Island.
According to the General Accounting Office, $193 million has been appropriated for the Staten Island port. Of that, $152 million had already been obligated as of May 31, and $136 million had been spent.
 
To Build or Not to Build
Before Congress recessed a few weeks ago, a proposed budget amendment to cut off financing for the ports was defeated in the Subcommittee on Seapower and Strategic and Critical Materials and the full Armed Services Committee. A similar amendment could be introduced when a budget bill is debated on the floor of the House of Representatives in the fall.
Mr. Dinkins has asked Defense Department officials and a Congressional committee to force the Navy to stop building on Staten Island until the project's future is decided. He vetoed a city budget expenditure of $22.7 million this year for the reconstruction of Front Street and city bulkheads near the Stapleton pier.
If the Navy were to ship out, Mr. Dinkins has supported the idea of buying back the property and using the new Navy pier to dock a 200-foot-long oil spill recovery ship operated by the oil industry.
 
'I'll Carry the Ball'
Capt. Charles H. Gnerlich, commanding officer of Naval Station, New York, which encompasses Fort Wadsworth, the Brooklyn Navy Yards and several other military installations in the area, has said he is willing to allow an oil spill recovery team to berth at the port even after the Normandy arrives, if that is what the city wants.
''I'll carry the ball for the city to make such an agreement happen,'' Captain Gnerlich said. ''The Mayor doesn't have to buy the facility from me to get what he wants.''
Supporters of the base say it is needed now more than ever. Joseph F. Callo, executive director of Homeport Information Task Force, which represents businesses and officials supporting the project, said that if Navy ships had sailed to the Gulf from New York instead of Newport News, Va., they would have arrived one or two days earlier.
But Representative Ted Weiss, a New York Democrat, said the Persian Gulf crisis has not changed his view that completing the port would be a waste of taxpayer money. ''I don't doubt at all that some people are going to use the crisis as an excuse for keeping home port alive,'' he said, ''but I don't think the argument is going to sell.''

HEADLINE: Oil Prices Fall Back $1 a Barrel

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES

 BODY:
Prices of crude oil fell $1.02 a barrel in the futures market yesterday, and prices for gasoline and home heating oil eased slightly. Analysts and brokers said jittery commodity traders cashed in some profits before the close of a landmark week in the oil markets.
The contract for October delivery settled yesterday at $30.91, a gain of $2.28 on the week. Alarmed by American military maneuvers and fear of fighting near the giant Middle East oilfields, traders had pushed oil prices to $31.93 on Thursday, and at one point during the day to $32.35, which equalled the highest level in the seven-year history of the New York Mercantile Exchange. 
 
Gasoline Prices Ease
Gasoline prices ended the week at $1.05 a gallon, off 4 cents from a record close on Thursday at $1.09 a gallon on the New York Merc. Home heating oil finished the week at 91 cents a gallon, losing 5 cents yesterday, but up 10 cents for the week.
Albert Helmig, a principal with Energex, a commodity brokerage firm, said that although traders remained nervous about events in the Persian Gulf, many reduced their holdings of October contracts because of the uncertain impact of military and diplomatic activity over the weekend, as well as the unofficial meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries set for tomorrow in Vienna.
If Saudi Arabian oilfields are damaged, it will likely cause crude prices to soar when trading resumes Monday. But if tensions between Baghdad and the West ease, or if OPEC members agree to raise production to replace the estimated four million barrels lost from Iraq and Kuwait, prices will fall, analysts said.
 
Reason for Caution
''If something good happens, it would put a lot of pressure on the October contract price,'' Mr. Helmig said, explaining why traders are cautious, even though most continue to bet on an outbreak of war and disruption of supplies. Many European traders closed their positions yesterday since the London commodity market will be closed Monday, ''Most people in the market think this is a crucial weekend,'' said Robert S. Jonke, a trading manager and analyst at Cargill Investors Services, a commodity brokerage firm in New York.
''There has been no lessening of tensions, but some people wanted to take their profit and get out,'' said James R. Fiedlerat E.D.&F. Man Inc., in New York, despite a very dangerous situation in the Persian Gulf.
Ministers from as many as 10 OPEC nations are to meet tomorrow in Vienna to discuss raising output quotas, although the role of Saudi Arabia, the group's largest producer, was unclear. Some analysts said little of consequence was expected from the meeting.
The Saudis indicated last week that they would increase output by nearly two million barrels a day next month, and other OPEC members, including Venezuela, Nigeria and the United Arab Emirates, were expected to add one million barrels to help cover the shortfall from Iraq and Kuwait.
Global demand for OPEC oil was estimated at 22 million barrels a day before the Iraqi invasion on Aug. 2. Fareed Mohamedi, senior economist at the Petroleum Finance Company in Washington, said OPEC output would rise to 22.5 million barrels a day next month if the Saudis, Venezuela, the United Arab Emirates and Nigeria succeed in raising output to their recently voiced objectives.
 
Doubt About Output
But many analysts doubt that those production levels will be achieved in the coming months. In that case, oil prices could resume their climb even if war is avoided.
Also, some analysts said, little of the Saudis' additional production would be available for export, since much would be diverted for Saudi and American military use.
Adam E. Sieminski of the Washington Analysis Corporation, a Washington consulting firm, said a worldwide crude oil shortage would probably would be evident as early as mid-September. He predicted heating oil shortages by November.
''Prices are going to go higher,'' he said. ''How much higher depends on whether we have a shooting war, whether the Administration taps the Strategic Petroleum Reserve and how effective the embargo of Iraq is. The odds that we could have $35 oil, at least for a while, are pretty good.''
A war would drive prices to $50 or higher, he added.
 
Increases by Refiners
Domestic refineries in the United States continued to increase the cash prices paid for oil delivered this week. The Mobil Corporation said yesterday that it increased its posted price at its Texas refineries by $3.25 a barrel, to $30.25 a barrel, on Thursday. The Texas Railroad Commission, which regulates the state's oil industry, estimated that posted prices at refineries would average more than $29 a barrel for the week.
Oil prices have doubled from a close of $15.30 in the futures market on June 20, and are up nearly $10 a barrel since the day before the Iraqi invasion. The Middle East events have also sent gasoline prices surging, and consumers face further increases in coming weeks, even though supplies were reported adequate as the end of the summer driving season neared.
The average price of unleaded regular gasoline at self-service pumps rose 3.7 cents since Monday, to an eight-year high of $1.27 across the nation, the American Automobile Association said yesterday.
Higher oil prices are also expected to extract a heavy toll on the nation's work force. Stephen P. A. Brown, an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas, said that if oil prices held at $31 a barrel through 1991, the economy would lose 1.2 million jobs.
An analysis of 1989 economic data indicates the nation loses 90,000 jobs for every $1 rise in oil prices, Mr. Brown said, although the effects vary by region. For instance, in Texas 15,000 jobs are added for every $1 rise in oil prices, as the domestic oil industry increases drilling activity.

HEADLINE: G.N.P. Rate For 2d Period A Weak 1.2%

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24

 BODY:
In what many analysts see as a further sign of a weakened economy, the Government confirmed today that growth was listless even before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait jolted oil prices.
Figures released by the Commerce Department confirmed an earlier estimate that the nation's output of goods and services had risen at an anemic 1.2 percent, or $12.2 billion, for the second quarter of 1990. That followed a 1.7 percent growth rate in the first quarter and a rate of three-tenths of 1 percent in the fourth quarter last year.
The latest figures are far below earlier expectations by the Bush Administration of a growth rate of at least 2 percent for the year. 
 
Drop in Business Inventories
Economists had hoped that increased exports and consumer spending would lead to an upward revision of the gross national product for April, May and June. But those advances were more than offset by a sharp downward revision in business inventories from the first estimate released July 27.
''The economy is headed toward a recession,'' said H. Erich Heinemann, chief economist at Ladenburg, Thalmann & Company. ''The imposition of the 1990 oil shock on top of extremely tight monetary policy will push consumption and, thus, the economy into a somewhat lower position than we had expected.''
Economists have traditionally defined recession as two or more consecutive quarters of negative growth.
The new figures appear to make even more delicate both the economic and the political situation of the Federal Reserve Board, which sets monetary policy. Any immediate move to infuse money into the system and encourage industrial growth could add to the already-rising rate of inflation. On the other hand, a failure to provide some relief could cause a further drop in production and increase the number of people unemployed, leading to a recession.
Since July, the price of crude oil has risen more than 75 percent. Economists say that each 1 percent rise in the crude oil price could cut the gross national product by about a tenth of a percent. The Bush Administration, insisting a recession is avoidable, has been pressing the Fed to lower interest rates. A New York Times/CBS Poll conducted this month showed that more than 60 percent of the people surveyed believed the nation was already in recession, and 55 percent said the economy was getting worse.
''It's not a great choice for the Fed,'' said Allen Sinai, an economist at the Boston Company. ''There isn't enough data yet for the central bank to call it a recession by the traditional definition and to ease monetary policy. But from the data, it is easy to read that the momentum of the economy was sliding in the second quarter and it is not hard to forecast that we are heading toward a recession.'' Members 'Remained Confident'
The minutes of the July meeting of the Fed's Open Market Committee, released today, reflected the view that inflation would not pose a significant problem for the economy. ''The members generally remained confident,'' the minutes said, ''that some progress would begin to be made in reducing the underlying rate of inflation during the period ahead, given their expectations of diminished pressures on labor and capital resources.'' Their view was formed, however, before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait pushed oil prices up sharply.
The Open Market Committee met again on Tuesday and, although the committee does not immediately announce what happens at each meeting, there were indications that it has decided not to make any change in monetary policy until the Persian Gulf crisis has subsided.
Briefing reporters in Kennebunkport, Me., the White House press spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said the Commerce Department report showed that the economy ''was indeed still growing,'' but he emphasized the need for a quick agreement with Congress on controlling the budget deficit to offset any negative impact the Persian Gulf crisis might have on the economy.
The growth reported today for the second quarter, combined with the 1.7 percent increase for the first quarter, put the nation's annual rate of growth at 1.5 percent for the first half of 1990.
The report reduced earlier figures on the growth of business inventories by $14.6 billion, to $11.6 billion. After-tax profits of American corporations also slipped, by two-tenths of 1 percent, to $166.7 billion, their worst decline since a 5.9 percent drop in the third quarter last year.
 
No Change on Inflation
The Government's reading of inflation was unchanged in the Commerce Department's report, which said that the price index tied to the gross national product rose at an annual rate of 3.9 percent in the second quarter. Government officials expect inflation to worsen in the third quarter because of higher fuel prices.
Consumer spending, which accounts for about two-thirds of economic activity, increased three-tenths of 1 percent in the quarter, a modest increase from the earlier estimates but substantially down from the 1.1 percent increase for the first quarter. Business investment spending fell 5.2 percent, and housing construction dropped 10.8 percent.

HEADLINE: Going Private Is a Public Affair

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 23

 BODY:
Under the plan of the Mexican Government to privatize its huge national telephone company, the winning bidder will have to agree to increase the number of household phone lines from 5 million to 10 million over the next four years; reduce installation time from 18 months to 6, and shrink the wait for a dial tone from 30 seconds to under 10.
Short of cash to pay off debt and also to support education, health care and other social programs, the administration of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari is plunging into privatization. But in Mexico, privatization comes with a great deal of regulation for the new owners, and that might rule out sales at full market value, in the opinion of some economists and businessmen.
''There is a trade-off between price and regulation, and the Government might have to adjust the price downward,'' said Federico Reyes Heroles, an economist at the University of Mexico. $20 Billion Is the Goal Two tendencies are emerging among the European and Latin American nations caught up in the privatization trend. Britain and Argentina, for example, impose few rules, trusting that the growth potential of their markets will prompt the new owners to invest billions of dollars voluntarily. But countries like Hungary and Mexico, with less confidence in free market incentives, are trying to hold the new owners to detailed annual growth rates. 
''We have a Mexican model: You privatize but you regulate,'' said Jacques Rogozinski, chief of the Mexican Government's Office for Privatization. ''We do not believe that the Government has to own things to direct the economy.''
Whatever the dampening effect of regulation, the Government is hoping to raise more than $20 billion -roughly 30 percent of what it spends in a single year -from the sale not only of the phone company and 18 major banks, but also of a copper mine, steel mills and dozens of other enterprises. More than half of the hoped-for revenue is to come from the phone company and the banks.
The regulations concerning the sale of the telephone company, Telefonos de Mexico, are probably the most demanding. And although the sale is to be completed by Christmas, many criteria are just now being published. Potential bidders include three United States companies, the GTE Corporation, Southwestern Bell and U S West.
By all estimates, the cost of meeting the Government's and other goals will be roughly $8 billion over 8 to 10 years for a company whose market value is about $8 billion, based on the price of publicly traded Telefonos stock. The Government owns 51 percent of the company and it would receive more than $4 billion from the sale, Mr. Rogozinski said, but only if the company is sold for its full market value.
The Salinas Government does not want to give ground on price in these transactions. In one case, however, it has had to. The Cananaea copper mine, which accounts for 3 percent of the world's copper production, was put up for sale last year at nearly $1 billion. After three attempts to sell the mine, 25 miles from the Arizona border, the high bid in an auction this week was $475 million, from a Mexican group. The price tag came down in part because the new owners will be under pressure from the Government to invest $250 million in the next few months to upgrade equipment, and $1 billion over a five-year period.
In theory, at least, the Telefonos sale is structured to encourage this sort of big investment, without at the same time making sacrifices on price. The operating group will be able to gain voting control of the company through a payment of only $2 billion, Mr. Rogozinski said. Most of the limited voting stock will be sold to the public, and traded on stock exchanges here and abroad.
But however low the initial payment from the controlling group might be, Telefonos's average net income in recent years has been only about half of the $1 billion a year that will probably have to be invested to comply with the goals that Mr. Rogozinski's office is putting together.
That means the controlling group, and perhaps the public investors, will have to ante up hundreds of millions of additional dollars before the investment in Telefonos begins to pay a dividend, toward the end of the decade. Mr. Rogozinski estimates that reinvested profits might supply up to 70 percent of the capital requirements of the telephone company.
 
Taking the Long View
Nevertheless, plowing new money into Telefonos and waiting years for the first dividends might turn out to be acceptable to some of the private groups considering a bid, given the growth potential of a country whose industrial output is expanding while telephones are limited to one for every 17 people. Although U S West, one of the potential bidders, has not commented on the Mexican deal, the company has made a similar investment in a television cable concession in Hong Kong. That investment is not expected to begin to pay off until just before China takes control of the British colony, in the late 1990's.
Some critics of privatization in Mexico, among them Albert Barranco Chavarria, an economics columnist for the daily newspaper La Jornada, argue that if private investors are willing to upgrade the telephone company and wait for a payoff, then the Mexican Government should also take this long-term approach. Unlike state-owned companies in Eastern Europe and some other Latin American countries, major Mexican companies held by the state - among them the oil and telephone companies and the banks - have been profitable in recent years.
Rather than invest these profits in the companies, however, the Salinas administration has used the money to pay foreign and domestic debt, finance social services and reduce the budget deficit. The administration argues that these outlays remain the top priority and in addition the Government cannot, over the long run, operate a company as efficiently as the private sector.
The private sector, however, faces problems under the privatization rules in Mexico. Because foreign ownership is limited or prohibited for some major state enterprises, companies are being sold to consortiums of Mexican businessmen, raising the possibility of disagreements.
This has been the case with the Mexican groups that purchased the two state airlines last year. In one case, Aeromexico, one group is buying out another. And in the case of Mexicana de Aviacion, one partner has put his share up for sale.
Mexicans will hold a majority stake in the group that will gain control of Telefonos de Mexico, and the minority partner will be a foreign phone company that will provide technology and operating expertise. To prevent one partner or another from pulling out, the Government has specified that the controlling shares must go into a trust that cannot be touched for five years.
The banks, which were nationalized in 1982 and are now being resold, are also subject to numerous regulations. Industrial companies, for example, cannot be buyers. A new Government agency will monitor bank practices, in part to prevent new owners from making risky loans to themselves or their friends at preferential rates. And foreign ownership will be limited to 30 percent. Among American banks, Bank of America and Morgan Guaranty have made inquiries, published reports have said.
 
The Old and the New
Still, the resale of the banks, which account for 90 percent of the nation's commercial banking industry, is likely to go more smoothly than other privatization projects. The new owners are expected to be mostly the same Mexican business groups that owned the banks when they were nationalized. Having received $400 million when the banks were seized, they are being asked for $8 billion to buy them back.
But in the intervening years, the Government has increased the banks' profits threefold. It has invested millions of dollars in new computer equipment and it has closed weak banks or merged them with stronger ones.
That should make them attractive as investments to foreign banks. But so far most of the foreign interest is coming from Europeans, particularly the French and the Spanish. ''More than the Americans, Europeans don't mind not having control,'' said Guillermo Ortiz, Under Secretary of the Finance Ministry. ''They are accustomed to minority stakes.''
