HEADLINE: Oil? Nation's Utilities Are Not So Worried

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Whatever damage the run-up in oil prices inflicts on the economy as a whole, the effect on electricity bills is likely to be relatively modest. Of the fuel-consuming industries, the electric utilities have been the most successful in learning the lessons of the first two oil shocks, in the 1970's, and finding other sources.
Oil accounted for about 16 percent of the fuel used by utilities at the time of the Iranian revolution in 1979, but amounted to only an average of 5.7 percent last year, despite a vast increase in the amount of electricity generated over the last decade. Moving the electric system off oil is important because a growing share of the energy used in this country - almost 36 percent last year - is turned into electricity before it is consumed.
 
Variations Among Companies
But the amount of oil used by utilities still varies widely from company to company, so the effect of rising oil prices on consumer bills will also vary. The Hawaiian Electric Company, for example, is nearly all oil-powered. The Long Island Lighting Company is still 63 percent oil-dependent, while the Consolidated Edison Company of New York depends on oil to generate 41 percent of its power. 
A barrel of oil produces about 500 kilowatt-hours when burned. The average household uses about 500 kilowatt-hours a month. If a utility was 100 percent oil-dependent, a $20 increase in the price of a barrel of oil would raise the monthly electric bill by the same amount.
But most utilities that were heavily dependent on oil in the 1970's have weaned themselves away by converting to coal or natural gas and by purchasing or building hydroelectric capacity or nuclear reactors. In addition, experts say, few plants built in the last few years use oil.
''As the utilities began to see themselves as competitors, and wanted to portray themselves as low-cost producers, the incentives were for them to switch away from oil,'' said Marie Corio, president of Applied Economic Research in New York.
They accomplished this first by running their own plants in a different pattern. They used gas- or coal-fired generation first, bought power from utilities with extra coal-fired capacity next, and then rebuilt their hardware to burn fuels other than oil. This required adding anti-pollution equipment in many cases, although the biggest technical difficulty was often finding a place to store the additional coal, some experts said.
As various users now substitute gas for oil, the price of gas will rise, Dr. Corio said. This may discourage the plans of some utilities and independent power producers to build new natural gas-fired power stations.
Others are not sure the price of gas will rise. ''We don't see a very direct linkage,'' said I. C. Bupp, a managing director of Cambridge Energy Research Associates. Even if oil gives up part of the market to gas, ''there will still be gas-on-gas competition,'' he said.
Coal prices will not rise, because ''there is so much spare capacity, nobody has to dig a new mine,'' said Standley H. Hoch, chairman and chief executive of General Public Utilities in New Jersey. It gets about 45 percent of its energy from coal.
Companies with excess capacity to burn coal will be in a strong position to sell power to those that use oil, said Charles B. Earle and Gary R. Licht, utility analysts at Mabon, Nugent & Company, the securities firm. They add that companies that still use oil heavily may find that after they have passed increased fuel costs to their customers, they will run into political resistance to unrelated increases. Eastern Utilities Associates, which wholesales power in New England, is in the former category, they said. Central Maine Power and Con Edison are among the latter. Still, the public's resistance to nuclear power and the emissions problems that arise from burning coal make it doubtful that oil will disappear in electric generation.
 
Gas or Light Oil Burned
In addition, many utilities and independent power producers have added turbines that burn natural gas when it is available and light oil when it is not. In the Northeast, these generators have been blamed for increasing the demand for heating oil on the coldest winter days, when natural gas is in short supply, as happened last December.
Over all, however, the conversion away from oil has been dramatic.
United Illuminating, which serves the New Haven and Bridgeport areas of Connecticut, is now about 22 percent oil-dependent, down from 92 percent at the time of the Iranian revolution. That figure will fall to 11 percent by 1991, the company says, at which point, even if oil prices doubled, electric costs would go up only 9 percent.
The reasons for the switch by utilities around the country are illustrated by United Illuminating's cost structure. The fuel and operating cost per kilowatt-hour at the plant gate is 2.176 cents for Bridgeport Harbor 3, a 25-year-old plant that was converted from oil to coal in 1985. A less-efficient oil-fired plant, which was used only about 7 percent of the time last year, has a price of 5.3 cents per kilowatt-hour.
 
Nuclear Power Increased
United Illuminating and many other utilities also substituted uranium for oil by building nuclear plants, which last year generated 19 percent of the domestically produced electricity, up from 4.5 percent in 1973, at the time of the first oil shock. The Seabrook nuclear plant, which went into commercial operation earlier this week and of which United Illuminating owns 17.5 percent, costs the company 1.792 cents a kilowatt-hour, the utility said.
But building new nuclear plants is an option now closed, for all practical purposes, because of waste disposal problems, safety and regulatory questions, and especially cost overruns. Building Seabrook bankrupted the biggest investor, the Public Service Company of New Hampshire and required United Illuminating to seek several emergency rate increases.
The New England Electric System, another Seabrook partner, which was 78 percent oil-dependent in 1979, has since reduced its reliance. John Rowe, the chairman, said the company had adopted ''a general strategy of not being caught that dependent again.''
Even when oil bottomed out at around $10 a barrel in 1986, he said, the coal the company was burning in converted plants was cheaper.
''In 1990, people understand the need to burn coal, with troops in the Middle East,'' Mr. Rowe said. ''But it isn't always obvious at other times.''
 
Changes in Florida
Florida Power and Light, which was 53 percent dependent on oil in 1979, completed two new nuclear plants and is now seeking other ways to curtail its oil use. It has signed long-term contracts for natural gas, and recently signed a letter of intent to buy a minority interest in a coal-fired plant in Georgia. This year, oil will make up 22 percent of its fuel, said Michael R. Bumgardner, a spokesman.
Southern California Edison was more than 40 percent dependent on oil at the time of the 1973 oil shock, said Larry Papay, a senior vice president. Now it is 4 to 5 percent dependent on the fuel. In the last 10 years, nuclear power has grown to 17 percent, from 4 percent, he said. The company also burns more coal and natural gas, and buys or generates power from solar plants, geothermal plants and windmills.
The company's focus is on improving efficiency, he said. ''Although conservation lost some of its glamour after 1985, we have continued spending $44 million or $45 million a year'' to help customers use electricity more efficiently, he said. Earlier this year, after negotiations with environmental groups and others, it raised the sum to $75 million, and will increase it again to $100 million.
 
Long Island Abandonment
Less successful in reducing imported oil is Long Island Lighting, which built a nuclear plant that would have displaced more than eight million barrels of oil a year if it had operated as its designers said it would. But the plant was abandoned by agreement with New York State because of safety concerns.
In the last 12 months, the company has been 62.5 percent dependent on oil, 13.5 percent on natural gas, 5.5 percent on nuclear power from a plant upstate and 18.5 percent on purchased power - a mix of natural gas, coal, hydroelectric power and even garbage, which is burned in a power-generating incinerator.
In July, Lilco paid an average of $15.19 a barrel for the heavy oil it uses, up from $14.49 in June. On Monday, it paid $22.50.

HEADLINE: Fed Panel Kept Steady Course in July

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24

 BODY:
Federal Reserve policy makers concluded in July that inflation remained high enough to require that current interest rates be maintained despite a ''relatively slow'' economy, records released today show.
''The staff projection prepared for this meeting suggested that the economy would expand over the remainder of 1990 at around the rate estimated for the first half of the year and at a slightly faster pace in 1991,'' minutes of the July meeting said.
Ten days later, on July 13, the central bank did lower the Federal funds rate - the rate banks charge for overnight loans - from 8.25 percent to 8 percent. But the Fed said that action was intended to offset overly cautious lending practices by the nation's banks and was not carried out because of a weakening economy. 
The Federal Open Market Committee met again Tuesday but decisions made then will not be announced for six weeks.
In testimony before Congress in July, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said the central bank projected a 1990 growth rate of 1.5 percent to 2 percent, slightly slower than the Bush Administration forecast of 2 percent.
Since then, however, the Commerce Department reported the economy slowed from a 1.7 percent annual rate of growth in the first quarter of 1990 to 1.2 percent in the second quarter, and there have been signs of further weakness as the economy entered the second half of the year.
Moreover, the invasion of Kuwait by Iraq on Aug. 2 has driven the price of oil above $30 a barrel, adding to inflationary pressures and concerns that the economy may be pushed into a recession.
 
Juggling Interest Rates
The Federal Open Market Committee, which is made up of the 7 Fed governors and 5 of the 12 presidents of Fed regional banks, had pushed short-term rates up, beginning in 1988, to slow the economy in an attempt to curb inflation. But as economic growth weakened, the policy makers began nudging short-term rates down, starting in June 1989.
The Administration and many economists have been urging the committee to permit interest rates to fall further to stimulate the economy.
''The information reviewed at this meeting suggested that economic activity was continuing to expand but at a relatively slow pace,'' the minutes said.
At the same time, the minutes said that while prices had moderated since earlier in the year, ''there was little evidence of significant change in the trend rate of inflation.''
At the end of the meeting, the members voted, 11 to 0, to maintain current interest rates. Manuel Johnson, the vice chairman, who is resigning, did not attend the meeting.

HEADLINE: Bond Yields Rise in Volatile Trading

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Long-term Treasury bond yields continued to edge higher yesterday in a trading session marked by volatile price swings. The Treasury debt market was buoyed after the opening by weakness in oil prices and the absence of any signifcant worsening of the situation in the Middle East, as well as by the expected slowing in the growth rate of the second-quarter gross national product.
''After some buying after the opening, which included some bargain-hunting, most market participants concentrated on unwinding or hedging positions for the weekend,'' said Kevin M. Flanagan, money market economist at Dean Witter Reynolds. ''But the shorter maturities were spared the volatile price moves and were essentially unchanged for most of the session.'' 
 
Long Bond at 9.15 Percent
In late trading, the Treasury's benchmark long bonds, the 8.75 percent issue maturing in August 2020, were offered at 95 25/32, down 8/32 on the day, while the yield rose to 9.15 percent from 9.11 percent the day before and 8.93 percent a week ago.
Although the long bond's yield is at its highest level since March 1989, the real rates of return on Treasury debt issues are falling well below those on comparable Japanese and German maturities. The real rate of return is the yield, less the rate of inflation. This development has given rise to concern about the Treasury's ability to continue financing the Federal deficit and other needs without increasing interest rates.
Eugene J. Sherman, senior vice president and chief economist at the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York, said that ''German and Japanese bond yields and real rates of return have soared in the past month, despite the fact that their inflation levels were rising faster than ours before the surge in oil prices.''
Using 10-year Treasury maturities as a yardstick, Mr. Sherman found that the real interest rate in Germany was 5.9 percent, roughly the same as in Japan and about 4 percent in the United States.
The Treasury's long notes, the 8.75's of August 2000, fell 6/32 on the day, to 98 6/32, as the yield rose to 9.03 percent, from 8.79 percent a week ago. By comparison, the yield on Japanese Government 10-year bonds, their longest maturity, climbed to 8.29 percent, from 8.05 percent a week ago, while the same German long bonds rose to 8.94 percent from 8.89 percent during the week.
Using 90-day Eurocurrency rates for a measure of real short-term returns, Mr. Sherman found the real interest rates in Germany and Japan at 5.5 percent while those in the United States were roughly at 3 percent.
''Consequently, United States financial markets are more vulnerable at this stage than major foreign markets,'' Mr. Sherman said. ''In short, interest rates here are likely to move up and the dollar lower under almost any reasonable prospective scenario.''
Meanwhile, the discount rate on 90-day Treasury bills fell seven basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 7.46 percent; six-month bills slipped three basis points, to 7.48 percent, but the one-year bills added a basis point, at 7.41 percent.
 
No Fed Intervention
The Federal Reserve refrained from intervention in the credit markets, as was expected, because the central bank had arranged a large infusion of reserves into the banking system on Thursday through four-day repurchase agreements. Partly as a result, the Federal funds rate that banks charge each other for overnight loans held steady at 8 1/16 percent most of the day before closing at 8 percent.
Elsewhere in the credit markets, American Airlines Inc., a subsidiary of the AMR Corporation, priced at par $250 million in equipment trust certificates with maturities ranging from 1992 to 2014 through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The securities yield from 8.75 percent to 10.68 percent and are rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Up From Lows; Gold Higher in New York

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
In what is becoming a usual Friday performance, the dollar rose yesterday ahead of an uncertain weekend in the tense Persian Gulf.
Gold prices advanced after drifting lower overseas. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold settled at $415 an ounce, up $3 from Thursday. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $414, up $2.75 an ounce. 
After falling in the previous session to new lows against the German mark, the Swiss franc and the British pound, the dollar was ripe for a technical rebound. The currency began rising in Asian trading and continued to gain ground when activity shifted to Europe and then the United States.
Traders continued to focus on developments in the Middle East, where a tense standoff got under way at foreign embassies in Kuwait. The United States Embassy and at least seven other missions were encircled by Iraqi troops as diplomats defied an order to close their doors.
 
'Threat of Military Conflict'
''There's a threat of military conflict over the weekend, and despite all the obvious concerns over the economy, the knee-jerk reaction says you buy dollars,'' said Earl Johnson, a vice president at Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago.
Traders agreed that if hostilities do not break in the next few days, the dollar is likely to resume its descent.
''Events are arguing for a higher dollar, but fundamentals are arguing for a lower dollar,'' said Stephen Flanagan, a vice president at the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company.
Indeed, the Commerce Department confirmed its first estimate that the economy grew at a sluggish annual rate of 1.2 percent in the second quarter. Although traders said there was little reaction to the report, they added that the notion of broad economic weakness was not being lost on the market.
In Tokyo the dollar fell to a closing 145.70 Japanese yen, from 145.88 at Thursday's close. But it rose later in London to 146.45 yen and continued to gain ground, settling in New York at 146.75 yen, up from 146.19 yen on Thursday.
In London, the British pound fetched $1.9445, cheaper than $1.9515 late Thursday. In New York, it cost $1.9400 to buy 1, less expensive than Thursday's $1.9570.
Against the German currency, the dollar rose to 1.5605 marks from 1.5445.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.2720 Swiss francs, up from 1.2560; 5.2360 French francs, up from 5.1855; 1,159.50 Italian lire, up from 1,152.00, and 1.1353 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1293.
Gold fell in London to a late bid price of $411.75 an ounce, from $412.75 bid late Thursday. In Zurich, the metal settled at a closing bid of $410.75, down from $411.75. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold fell $2.61 an ounce to close at $410.95.
Silver prices were mixed. On New York's Comex silver bullion for current delivery settled at $5.187 an ounce, up from $5.126 on Thursday. In London the metal fell to a late bid price of $5.14 an ounce from $5.15.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Cattle Prices Are Declining Amid Fears of a Recession

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Cattle futures prices slipped yesterday at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange amid continuing fears of a recession.
Cattle prices are vulnerable on a number of fronts and are now at the mercy of the Middle East energy crisis and the potential for a recession, said Paul Hare, an analyst in Chicago with Linnco Futures Inc.
''There's also some concern about the profitability for cattle prices this fall because of the extremely high prices that were paid for feeders in the early spring and midsummer,'' he said. 
The cash market is not helping, he said, with cash feeders falling $2 to $5 a hundredweight yesterday.
In contrast, pork futures showed some stability after a period of sharp declines in cash prices.
Cattle futures settled 0.25 cent to 0.75 cent lower, with the contract for delivery in October at 76.17 cents a pound; feeder cattle were 0.55 cent to 1.15 cents lower, with August at 88.17 cents a pound; hogs were unchanged to 0.33 cent higher, with October at 48.42 cents a pound, and frozen pork bellies were 1.82 cents lower to 0.30 cent higher, with August at 41.90 cents a pound.
Soybean futures prices advanced on the Chicago Board of Trade.
''After yesterday's strength, nobody wanted to sell,'' said Mickey Luth, an analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. ''The fundamentals were there to drive it higher.''
He said bean prices were benefiting from lower supplies, reduced South American production and smaller amounts of competing crops.
Grain prices, on the other hand, were weak.
''They don't have the dynamics of soybeans,'' Mr. Luth said. ''The corn supply is getting bigger, not smaller. And there's no risk of frost.'' The latest 6-to-10-day forecast calls for warm temperatures in the main corn-growing regions, and Mr. Luth said he felt confident that the crop would make it past Oct. 1 and into the harvest season without severe frost damage.
Wheat was 1 cent lower to 1 3/4 cents higher, with the contract for delivery in September at $2.84 3/4 a bushel; corn was 1 1/4 cents lower to 1/4 cent higher, with September at $2.57 3/4 a bushel; oats were 1 1/4 cents lower to 3/4 cent higher, with September at $1.18 a bushel, and soybeans were 1 1/2 cents lower to 5 cents higher, with September at $6.30 a bushel.

HEADLINE: USAir Plans More Layoffs

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
USAir Group Inc., which had already announced layoffs of more than 1,500 workers this month, said yesterday that it planned to cut another 2,100 jobs by the end of the year. The latest reduction amounts to about 4 percent of the work force of the airline company, which is based in Arlington, Va. 
''These additional personnel cuts take into account the softening of passenger demand, poor economic conditions, escalating fuel costs and the company's need to reduce operating costs,'' said Edwin Colodny, the company's chairman. The nation's seventh-largest airline has had to roll back expansion plans. USAir said it was planning to increase capacity next year by 2 percent, compared with its original plans of 6 percent.
USAir currently has about 54,000 employees. It has hubs in Pittsburgh, Philadelphia and Charlotte, N.C.

HEADLINE: SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
Saratoga's Backyard Success

BYLINE: By Steven Crist

DATELINE: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.

 BODY:
Business at Saratoga this month should have been rotten. The economy is receding. Tourism in the area is down. The racing is indifferent and the weather is as unpredictable as the steeplechasers.
Yet still they come, day after day, the old faithful horseplayers and the newly curious patrons, and they can hardly wait to part with their currency. The usually prosperous tourist business in nearby Lake George is down 30 percent this summer, but the attendance at Saratoga Race Track is holding steady and the betting is up 9 percent. 
No one is coming for the fabled water, oily and overrated stuff. Nor is the climate a draw. Last Saturday, it was 90 degrees and stickier than jam, and the next night the temperatures plunged to the 40's. When it rains, it rains for days. The only thing you can count on rain or shine is being mugged by mosquitoes the size of small children.
When the racing is good, it is very good, but more often, it is peculiar and maddening: steeplechases and grass races on the flat at marathon distances that are impossible to handicap, fields full of first-time starters that are exercises in guesswork and dozens of shippers.
No one comes for superior amenities. Saratoga is a charming old place, but short on comfort. Seats with decent views of the races are scarce, and lines for everything from rest rooms to betting windows are infuriatingly long. Even the swells have to crowd into tiny boxes that sell for $50 a day, and then pay $10.50 for a cheeseburger.
A far more pleasant day at the races can be had any afternoon in the summer or fall at Belmont Park on Long Island, but there, attendance dwindles every season and the box-seat section is a ghost town. So what is everyone doing here? Race tracks usually thrive during recessions, but Saratoga is a phenomenon unto itself. Its continued success over the last decade has not carried over to Aqueduct or Belmont. Saratoga should be New York racing's best marketing tool, but it seems entirely self-contained. Saratoga turns newcomers into Saratoga fans, not into racing fans. The society angle also seems overblown. Everyone talks and writes about the rich people who move into their summer houses here for a month and go racing every day, but there are no gawking masses hungering for a glimpse of the well-heeled. No one pays much attention to the swells but the other swells, and there is no evidence that the throngs in the grandstand are there because they enjoy gambling under the same roof as richer folk.
In fact, the swell in Saratoga's business over the last decade has been decidedly downscale. The largest segment of new racegoers are the group that spends the day picnicking in the expanded backyard area. Clad in tank tops and shorts and toting folding lawn chairs, they stake out a spot for the afternoon and get no closer to a race than the television monitors hung in the trees. They will wander over to the betting windows a few times during the afternoon, but they could just as well be at an offtrack betting parlor, except that there is no such parlor where you can sit on your own lawn chair and eat from a picnic basket.
Perhaps that is the secret of Saratoga's success. For many of the new patrons, a day at Saratoga is like a day in their own backyard, with the added amusement of nine horse races on a television screen. With money tight, people are taking fewer vacations, and a few day trips to Saratoga add up to a cheap vacation.
The other difference from being in your own backyard is that every half hour or so, some horses wander through the picnic area as they are being led to the paddock. The best thing about Saratoga for those who enjoy horses as well as racing is the close-up view of the runners before and after a race. It is too easy at other tracks to relegate these magnificent creatures to numbered specks on a television screen. Saratoga reminds you of the flesh and blood.
Go for Wand, Rhythm and Meadow Star may be remembered as the stars of the meeting, but a less renowned runner turned in two performances that show just how big these horses' hearts really are. Token Dance, a talented 3-year-old sprinting filly, ran in the Test Stakes here Aug. 2 and ran well to be third to the spectacular Go for Wand. Eddie Maple, her jockey, knew she had hit her head on the side of the starting gate when she broke, but only after the race did he and the filly's trainer, Pat Kelly, find that Token Dance had ripped out three teeth and a piece of her jaw.
She did not flinch when a veterinarian went in with a knife that night and cut out the broken piece of her jaw, which will grow back in time. Then three days ago, Token Dance went back to the races. Under firm but gentle handling by Maple, she scored a comfortable victory.
''She's amazing, '' Kelly said. ''She's got a hole in her jaw and a big space where those teeth should be. I guess now she can whistle 'All I Want for Christmas Are My Three Front Teeth.' ''

HEADLINE: CONSUMER'S WORLD;
Oil vs. Gas: A Question of Cost Again

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
The contest between oil and natural gas for supremacy in the home heating market has been long and bitter. Now the confrontation between the United States and Iraq has made it more intense.
Since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 the price of home heating oil, along with prices of gasoline and other petroleum products, has risen sharply. To the gas industry and some Government officials, these increases are typical of price patterns during oil crises and could presage still further rises in oil prices this winter. 
But to the oil industry and at least one consumer group, the price changes accompanying the new turmoil in the Middle East represent little more than a blip on a chart on which both fuels fluctuate and neither has a monopoly on large price advances and declines.
No one questions the fact that prices of home heating oil are up this month. A survey by the New York State Consumer Protection Board found that since the invasion of Kuwait, the average price of heating oil in the state has jumped to $1.07 a gallon from 95 cents, and the average price in New York City to $1.19 from $1.06.
''We have received no indication that there are oil supply problems, yet home heating oil prices are now at their highest August level in six years,'' said Richard M. Kessel, executive director of the board. ''Based on current projections, I wouldn't be surprised if by Labor Day or shortly thereafter you're going to be paying $1.25 for home heating oil. This is going to be a very difficult winter.''
Mr. Kessel's words are music to the ears of natural gas executives. In their marketing efforts they have frequently cited what they perceive as the advantages of gas for heating homes, including ready availability of gas, its clean burning qualities and no storage requirements. Now they are emphasizing the price argument even more.
 
Gas Industry's Warnings
''There is a good potential for higher oil prices, and that makes gas a better buy relative to oil,'' said Paul D. Holtberg, principal economist of the Gas Research Institute, an arm of the natural gas industry. ''In the worst-case scenario with a war in the Middle East, a great deal of productive capacity would be destroyed.''
''The cost of oil varies with demand,'' added Walter F. Wilm Jr., vice president of gas operations for the Long Island Lighting Company. ''Whenever there is a supply disruption or the threat of one, the cost of oil goes up.''
Heating oil specialists, however, believe that such talk is an example of not seeing the forest for the trees. They say that oil prices, as well as gas prices, should be viewed as a continuum rather than as a series of peaks and valleys. Seen that way, they say, there is no clear-cut distinction as to which fuel is less expensive for the homeowner over the long run.
 
Oil Men's View of Prices
''We've had extreme highs and we've had extreme lows,'' said William F. Kenny, president of the Metropolitan Energy Council, a federation of heating oil associations in the New York area. ''But on a long-term basis, the price of oil and gas is the same.''
''Every form of energy has its cycle of crises,'' said Bernard A. Smith, executive vice president of the New England Fuel Institute, which represents oil dealers in that region. ''When you try to come up with a long-term solution to a short-term problem, the consumer usually comes up on the short end of the stick.''
Thus oil people are concentrating their advertising and promotional barrages these days not on the current price, but rather on what they consider to be the superior qualities of their fuel. These, they say, include a higher heating efficiency over gas, the relative ease of improving an oil heating system, and the absence of pipelines that could be damaged and disrupt supplies.
The argument that a long-term view is better than a short-term view is buttressed by the Consumer Energy Council of America Research Foundation, a public interest group. It studied the cost of both fuels in gallon equivalents over the last decade and concluded that there is little to be gained by switching from oil to gas on economic grounds.
''The surest way of saving money is not to gamble over the future differential of fuel prices but to cut consumption,'' said Ellen Berman, executive director of the council. ''Conservation is still one of the best consumer purchases around.''
 
WHEN IT WOULD PAY TO SWITCH TO GAS
For consumers who are considering converting their heating equipment to gas from oil, Charles Guinn, the deputy commissioner of the New York State Energy Office, has this advice.
If your existing furnace is fairly new and operating efficiently, conversion would not be as cost-effective as it might be with old and inefficient furnaces.
Check costs, short-term and long-term. The price of a new gas furnace can range from about $1,500 to $5,000, with the national average at $2,000, according to the American Gas Association. If natural gas is cheaper than oil, as it is today, and that differential continues, figure out how many years of such price savings it would take to cover the price of the furnace.
An example given by the gas association shows $2,300 as the price of a new furnace and installation, a saving in the Northeast of $385 a year from using gas instead of oil, and a payback period of almost six years. Experts say, however, that the history of prices in the past decade suggest that the current price differential is unlikely to continue at exactly the same level for six years.
Before making any calculations, find out whether natural gas is available to you. There are areas, like the north and south forks of Long Island, where supplies are extremely limited.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost;
Watching Interest Rates

 BODY:

International events are now influencing the interest rates that banks pay more than the economy is influencing them. Yields on certificates of deposit have been falling for more than three months, but the Middle East situation could mean higher yields in the near future. Bank rate analysts suggest watching rates on certificates of deposit closely for the next three weeks and holding some money in a federally insured bank money market account to be ready to shift to C.D.'s if interest rates rise. Investors might also want to split money between short-term certificates of deposit and money market accounts. LENGTH: 1354 words

HEADLINE: After a Stray Shot: A Girl's Family Seeks Meaning in a Random Loss

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO

 BODY:
Daisy L. Rasberry lives as if suspended in time. She has not been to work for two months. Nor has she slept a full night since the evening of June 23, when a Saturday shopping trip with two of her daughters ended with her 10-year-old ''baby,'' Shaniqua, bleeding in her arms from a fatal gunshot wound to the chest.
The bullet was not meant for Shaniqua. She was killed when an argument between two men and three clerks at a jewelry store in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn spilled onto the sidewalk where she stood browsing for summer shoes with her mother, her 13-year-old sister, two of her mother's friends and their three children. Another child, an 8-year-old girl, was also shot but survived.
''I do accept it,'' Mrs. Rasberry, 30, said, ''but I can't believe it.'' 
Since the death of Shaniqua Brown, a third-grader from Far Rockaway, Queens, who was known for her warmth, good grades and funny faces, stray bullets have killed at least five more New York City children under the age of 16 and wounded at least another five. The shootings have led to plans to hire more than 1,000 police officers by next spring and calls for tougher gun-control laws.
But while such random violence appears to have become commonplace, its lingering impact on the victims' families, friends and communities is not.
Within Shaniqua's family - her mother, her stepfather, Larry Rasberry, two sisters, Carmalei, 13, and Shayisha, 12, and grandparents - there is anger at the police for not being there when the quarrel outside the jewelry store on Flatbush Avenue erupted into shots, and at the store employees for somehow letting the argument turn deadly.
Mrs. Rasberry said she was considering a lawsuit against both the Police Department and the jewelry store.
It is not rage, though, but numbness, that seems to envelop Shaniqua's family. During interviews, they hardly mention the fact that two men have been arrested in the case.
''It's a lot to deal with,'' Mr. Rasberry, 27, a truck driver and former air cargo specialist with the Air Force, said last week.
Mrs. Rasberry says she finds solace in talking to her minister, Charles Jones, at the Bethel Temple Church of God in Christ in Far Rockaway and in a Bible study group. But she still gropes for a meaning to her daughter's death. ''It's like paying for somebody else's sins.''
Shaniqua's sister Shayisha remembers her as ''the only one in the house that made us laugh.'' ''She'd make funny faces.'' Mr. Rasberry said his stepdaughter was also the only one who could make him ''move'' - go out for pizza, for example - after a hard day of work.
''I was always too tired but she had a way of getting me to do things,'' he said.
 
'Jarring Reality' for Students
At Public School 197 in Far Rockaway, where Shaniqua would have started fourth grade this September, a psychologist, a social worker and an educational evaluator were on hand the Monday after the shooting to help her classmates and other students deal with the news, the principal, George Giberti, said.
Most students, he said, had heard about the shooting by the time they arrived for classes and many were visibly upset.
''There was a jarring reality,'' he said. ''Children sometimes feel that they are immortal. They were now faced with a loss and there was an outpouring of emotion.''
Emotions ran strong too, in the neighborhood where the shooting took place, a bustling strip of stores and markets that is always crowded on Saturday afternoon.
 
Neighbors Cooperated With Police
The police said they were able to arrest the first of two men charged in Shaniqua's killing within 48 hours because the level of cooperation among residents and shopkeepers was unusually high. They provided leads and identified the first suspect, Jamal K. Coley, in a police lineup.
''Normally in a case like this nobody saw nothing,'' said Ed Boyar, the assistant district attorney prosecuting the case.
In a statement to the police, Mr. Coley, 22, who lives in Flatbush, said he had gone to the Taj Mahal Jewelry store to return a gold chain he had bought for several hundred dollars but which another jeweler told him was worth half what he had paid. Mr. Coley told the police that when he confronted the Taj Mahal's clerks, they denied having sold him the chain. He left the store, kicking the door on his way out, and returned a short while later with a neighbor, Brian Reid, 22.
Just as Mr. Coley and Mr. Reid went back to the Taj Mahal, Mrs. Rasberry and her friends, their children in tow, decided to shop for shoes. Feeling June's growing heat, they had gone to Flatbush Avenue to shop for cool clothes and sandals. Mrs. Rasberry often shopped in Brooklyn, somewhat of a trek from her Queens home, because ''it's so cheap out there for the kids.''
 
'It Was So Quick'
She recalled that the stores that evening ''were packed with kids.'' About 7:15 P.M. she, her daughters and her friends stopped by the window of Your Foot, next door to the Taj Mahal. Shaniqua fell for a pair of sandals in black, red and yellow.
The next thing she remembers is hearing someone yell ''Run!''
''It was so quick,'' she said. ''I didn't hear an argument.''
''All we did was bend down for one second and someone said, 'Run!' I went to grab my baby girl and the bullet hit her at the same time. I remember when she said 'Ow.' I said, 'Run, Shaniqua!' ''
Mrs. Rasberry said that she and her daughter ran inside the shoe store for safety, but that Shaniqua, grabbing her stomach, said, ''Mommy, I've already been shot.''
 
Fired a Single Bullet
Shaniqua died later that night at Kings County Hospital Center.
Mr. Coley has told the police that he fired a single shot into the air after he and Mr. Reid argued with a shoe store clerk they believed ''was with'' the jewelry store workers. The police say that is the shot that killed Shaniqua.
Mr. Coley, arrested two days later at his girlfriend's apartment, has been indicted on charges of second-degree murder, attempted murder, assault and criminal possession of a weapon. He has pleaded not guilty and is being held without bail.
Mr. Reid, who turned himself in to the police Aug. 6 and is also being held without bail, has been indicted and is scheduled for arraignment on the same charges tomorrow in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn.
Both men are unemployed and single, and both lived with their families in Flatbush.
 
Suspect Has a Son, 4
Mr. Coley, who dropped out of school after the 10th grade, is the father of a 4-year-old boy.
''He's very concerned about the charges against him, but he and I agree that whatever happened was certainly very tragic,'' Mr. Coley's lawyer, Michael F. Baum, said.
Because killings like that of Shaniqua are so random and unexpected, psychiatrists say, they provoke more shock and fear than other types of violence, and are more difficult to accept.
And because the frequency of such killings has reached new levels, -they are extremely disorienting, said Lawrence W. Sherman, a professor of criminology at the University of Maryland who has researched bystander shootings and reactions to them.
 
'Completely Terrorizing Event'
''It's not something your parents have told you about,'' he said. ''It's not something your friends have experienced. To have a stray bullet come out of nowhere for reasons that have nothing to do with the kind of life you've led, it's a completely terrorizing event.''
Since Shaniqua's shooting, Toufik Kassab, owner of both the Taj Mahal and Your Foot, has hired security guards at both stores. The owner, who was not present during the shooting, said that his employees had called the police at least twice about the argument but that there was no response.
Come September, Mrs. Rasberry said, she may be ready to return to her job as a part-time office clerk in the highway permits division of the city's Department of Transportation, ''just to keep my mind occupied.''
Also in September, when classes resume at P.S. 197, the school plans a food drive, Mr. Giberti said. Donations will be sent to Bethel Temple Church of God in Christ in Shaniqua's name.

HEADLINE: Lead Paint Poisons Children Despite 1971 Law on Removal

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Aug. 25

 BODY:
Nearly 20 years after Congress declared lead-based paint a health hazard and ordered it stripped from the nation's stock of federally subsidized housing, it remains on the walls and woodwork of dwellings across the nation, posing a lasting toxic threat that medical experts say afflicts as many as one in every six children.
By almost any measure, the campaign to eliminate lead-based paint from the apartments and houses where the nation's poorest inner-city families live has produced a legacy of frustration and failure, according to housing specialists, public health experts and Congressional critics.
''The Government's record in dealing with this problem is one of absolute dereliction,'' said Dr. Herbert L. Needleman of the University of Pittsburgh, a researcher who has linked lead poisoning to learning disabilities, higher school dropout rates and lower I.Q.'s among children. ''Unlike almost any other public health threat, the problem of lead paint is eradicable, not just controllable.''
Despite Congressional imperatives, court decisions and a growing consensus among medical experts that more than three million children under the age of 6 have elevated levels of lead in the blood, the national effort to eliminate lead paint from public housing, much less private housing, has been mired in a kind of bureaucratic inertia. 
 
Issue of Financial Resources
By way of a defense, Federal and local housing officials argue that Government does not have the financial resources to remove lead paint from public housing units. The cost is estimated at $3,000 to $8,000 for each dwelling. Yet their critics say that if the Government does not pay now, it will pay later.
In remarks in Congress last May, Senator Barbara A. Mikulski, a Maryland Democrat who heads the subcommittee that oversees appropriations for the Department of Housing and Urban Development, said Federal officials were not taking into account the cost of future medical treatment.
''I'd rather see H.U.D. paying to clean up houses than Medicaid paying to clean up kids,'' Senator Mikulski said this week.
Public health experts and Congressional critics say the failure to deal with the problem partly reflects the absence of public pressure to eradicate a hazard whose principal victims have little political leverage - young, poor, black residents of inner cities.
Although Congress banned residential use of lead paint more than decade ago, studies estimate that nearly 900,000 units of public housing, and some 40 million units of private housing, still have lead-based paint. H.U.D. is now conducting a study on how to deal with the problem in private housing.
 
Odd Impact at White House
Not all the lead paint is in poor neighborhoods. Earlier this month, it was disclosed that Millie, President Bush's dog, became ill with what was described as ''acute lead exposure'' as a result of renovation work being done at the White House.
Critics argue that it is a measure of the Government's hesitant approach to the problem that a 650-page set of new, comprehensive Federal standards for testing and eliminating lead-based paint in public housing units has yet to be distributed to the nation's 3,200 public housing authorities, even though they took effect on April 1.
John C. Weicher, Assistant Secretary for policy development and research at H.U.D., attributed the delay to disputes over certain key sections. Despite the delay, Mr. Weicher said Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp was determined to address the problem of lead-based paint.
 
Growing Scope of Problem
''I'm not going to try to defend 20 years of policy on this issue, by a variety of administrations,'' said Mr. Weicher. But he said that only in recent years had officials come to understand the growing scope of the problem. In response to new medical evidence, the United States Public Health Service has twice since 1971 lowered the limit of acceptable lead exposure and is now considering a further reduction, he said.
Although the lead poisoning has been associated with lead in drinking water and other products, experts argue that the disease most often strikes children who inhale dust tainted by lead-based paint, or ingest paint chips.
In poorer neighborhoods, in both public housing units and private apartments, paint is often peeling. Dr. Needleman said 55 percent of poor, black urban children under the age of 6 have elevated levels of lead in the blood.
So far, state and local programs aimed at private housing, particularly in inner-city buildings, have had little effect, partly because of resistance from landlords.
The State of Massachusetts and the City of Baltimore have adopted strong programs, including mandatory screening for lead exposure in preschool children. Yet for the most part local officials become involved only after a child is already ill and tests show lead poisoning. Critics say that is the public policy equivalent of using children as coal companies once used canaries in mines to detect poison gas.
 
Special Nature of Problem
Don Ryan, a former Congressional aide who is now an organizer of a public interest alliance that will focus on the danger of lead paint in housing, argues that lead exposure poses a public health hazard unlike any other environmental threat.
''When we talk about pesticides or asbestos, we use risk assessment models that discuss some statistical chance - one in a million, say - that someone may be harmed in the future,'' Mr. Ryan said. ''With lead, we know that about one out of every six children is already suffering, that they have too much lead in their bodies. In some places we even have their names and addresses.''
As in some cases of asbestos, some housing officials argue that it may be better to cover lead paint surfaces, rather than try to remove them. Jeff Miller, a spokesman for the Lead Industries Association in New York, said several lead manufacturers had been working with the Environmental Protection Agency on ways to cover lead paint safely, to reduce its hazard.
Public health experts like Dr. Needleman oppose covering, rather than removing, lead paint, saying it only postpones the problem.
Experts agree that many techniques used so far to remove lead paint have often made the problem worse. Sanding lead paint produces dust tainted with lead that residents and workers inhale. Devices that use flame to burn off lead paint produce toxic fumes.
Under the new H.U.D. standards, the agency recommends methods for safely removing the paint, including the temporary relocation of tenants and the use of protective equipment and clothing for workers.
Congress passed the Lead-Based Paint Poisoning Prevention Act in 1971. But 10 years later, the General Accounting Office assailed the housing department, accusing it of ''confusion and noncompliance'' in programs aimed at eliminating lead poisoning in children.
For all its useful properties, lead has been known since biblical times to be toxic. Amid concerns about the public health effects of lead, Congress strongly restricted the use of lead as an additive in gasoline, and banned most use of lead-based paint in 1978.
 
Many Cases Undetected
Dr. Needleman has pointed out that the great majority of cases have never been diagnosed because the effects of lead poisoning, though severe, are not unique or obvious. In a long-term study, published this year in The New England Journal of Medicine, he concluded that teen-agers who had been exposed to relatively high levels of lead as first and second graders were seven times as likely to be school dropouts as classmates who had little or no lead exposure, and six times as likely to suffer reading disabilities.
Despite H.U.D.'s adoption of the new guidelines, public housing advocates argue that the Government has failed to train personnel and will not pay for the complex testing procedures to determine whether an apartment is contaminated with lead paint.
Perhaps more significant, they say that some of the department's field offices are intentionally ignoring the guidelines.
Robert E. McKay, executive director of the Council of Large Public Housing Authorities, wrote to Federal housing officials in July, complaining that field staff members were threatening some local public housing agencies with loss of Federal funds for modernizing housing, because the agencies wanted to delay some current construction work so as to comply with the new lead-paint standards.
 
'Transitional Problem'
Mr. Weicher of H.U.D. said the department was having what he called ''a transitional problem'' in bringing the agency's bureaucracy in line.
Some attitudes within H.U.D. on lead paint were reflected in comments made at a housing seminar in St. Louis earlier this year by Carolyn Newton, who has since left the housing agency. She told a meeting of public housing administrators that there were those in H.U.D. regional offices who believe the lead-paint issue ''has been blown way out of proportion, that there are other more pressing issues.''
Officials who administer public housing developments do not disagree that lead-based paint constitutes a major health hazard. But they also say the Federal Government is asking them to undertake costly and disruptive abatement programs with little more money.
''You may ask, Are we not fully occupied already, having been singled out to solve the nation's drug problem, and its housing problem of mentally handicapped and homeless?'' said Alonzo Watson, the director of the South Bend, Ind., Public Housing Authority, at a recent seminar.
Local housing officials also worry about the soaring cost of insurance for contractors removing lead paint, and the growing specter of lawsuits from tenants and workers whose own blood may show elevated levels of lead, as a result of exposure.
In New York, Boston and New Orleans, tenants have filed lawsuits against city or public housing authorities, alleging health damage. In turn, the Government agencies have sued the lead paint industry.
William P. Quigley, a New Orleans lawyer working on behalf of the tenants there, says that because most of the victims are young, poor and black, the questions involved transcend matter of public health. ''This is a human rights issue,'' he said.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Iraqi Diplomat Vows to Release Kin of Envoys

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25

 BODY:
Iraq promised today to release dependents of American diplomats from Kuwait who are being held in Baghdad, but not the diplomats themselves.
The Iraqis meanwhile acted on their threat to cut off supplies, electricity and water to the American Embassy and several others in Kuwait. Soldiers, some of them armed with machine guns and mortars, continued to encircle many embassies in Kuwait City but made no effort to remove the remaining diplomats by force.
United States officials said the American Embassy was using an electric generator and that supplies were adequate for the Ambassador, W. Nathaniel Howell, and his skeleton staff of about 10 diplomats.
Iraq's Ambassador to Washington, summoned to the State Department for an hourlong discussion of the situation, said the diplomats in Kuwait could not be released ''because they don't have diplomatic status; they are considered ordinary citizens, just like anyone else.'' 
 
Says Embassy Won't Be Attacked
The Ambassador, Mohammed Sadiq al-Mashat, said after the meeting here that Baghdad's troops are ''not going to use force'' against the United States Embassy or its envoys.
''You people should be concerned with the major problem: We are on the brink of catastrophe, unnecessary,'' he said. ''Without any reason American lives are being risked. For no reason whatsoever.''
As many as 60 spouses and children of American diplomats might be allowed to leave the Iraqi capital, where they have been held since they left the embassy in Kuwait on Friday.
It was a day of inconclusive and sometimes confusing diplomatic wrangling, as the United States also moved to enforce the naval blockade approved early today by the United Nations Security Council to enforce trade sanctions against Iraq.
Bush Administration officials said the United States was studying the possibility of offering political asylum to the crews of Iraqi vessels as an enticement for them to cooperate with the blockade.
Other tactics were also being considered, from blocking Iraqi ports to boarding or even attacking merchant vessels attempting to break the embargo. Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser to President Bush, said the United Nations resolution meant that the United States has full authority to enforce the blockade, and he said that the American military intends to use it.
 
Minimum Use of Force
But Mr. Scowcroft also said in an interview with the Cable News Network that allied forces hoped to use ''the minimum amount of interference necessary'' to make the sanctions effective.
Appearing on Iraqi television, President Saddam Hussein dismissed the Security Council as a puppet of the United States. He used a joint appearance with Kurt Waldheim, the Austrian President, to talk vaguely of a solution yet use some of his most bellicose language yet.
''We want peace,'' he told reporters accompanying Mr. Waldheim. ''So, it is the duty of the Americans now to bear in mind that they should resolve to a political solution and not to force.''
But if the United States attacks, ''there will be columns of dead bodies which may have a beginning but will have no end,'' he said through a translator.
After a personal appeal from Mr. Waldheim, President Hussein allowed the Austrian President to board a chartered plane with 95 Austrians who had been trapped in Iraq. The mission drew some criticism abroad, for Mr. Waldheim is the only Western leader to have met with Mr. Hussein since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2.
Offering to meet with other world leaders, President Hussein suggested that Mr. Waldheim could be a mediator in any settlement talks.
Mr. Scowcroft cautioned against making too much of President Hussein's gesture, calling it ''an attempt to get around the universal condemnation.''
 
Kuwait Embassy Situation
As the Middle East crisis continued, it remained unclear whether Iraq intended to seize the embassies of the United States and other countries in Kuwait. A confusing picture emerged as Iraqi troops continued to surround many embassies, preventing people from entering or leaving.
United States officials said that electricity was cut today at the American Embassy, and restored briefly at the British Embassy, only to be cut again. Japanese diplomats said that electricity, water and telephone service had been disconnected at their Embassy.
Confusion also engulfed the other foreign hostages held in the Iraqi capital. About 20 of the 213 Japanese citizens held at a hotel in Baghdad were loaded into a bus with other foreign nationals and taken by Iraqi authorities to an undisclosed location. Diplomats tried to pursue the bus but lost sight of it, the Japanese Foreign Ministry said, and Iraqi officials offered no information on the captives' destination.
Mr. Mashat was summoned to the State Department this afternoon for what an American official called a discussion ''of our views on the American Embassy in Kuwait and American and other foreign nationals in Kuwait.''
 
'No Use of Force'
In Baghdad, an Iraqi spokesman told Reuters, the British news agency, by telephone: ''For the time being there is no use of force and I do not think there will be any use of force.'' Diplomats remaining in Kuwait ''will enjoy no privileges, services, or facilities,'' he said.
About a dozen Iraqi commercial ships, primarily loaded oil tankers, remained under close surveillance by Navy ships and helicopters in the Persian Gulf and Red Sea.
 
Iraqi Vessel in Aden
Although one Iraqi tanker has apparently unloaded its cargo in Aden, a port city in Yemen where Iraq has regularly sent its crude oil for processing, and a second tanker is in port, the Yemenis have said they will abide by the international sanctions and refuse to unload any more oil.
Pentagon officials said that American warships are prepared to disable the Iraqi ships by firing at their rudders, if the vessels attempted to run the blockade.
But Administration officials said they were also reviewing whether to offer asylum to the Iraqi crews and spare the United States a possibly bloody confrontation that could trigger all-out war.
''It's what we'd prefer,'' said one Pentagon official, who said the White House was discussing various options.
 
Crews of Iraqi Tankers
According to American intelligence officials, the Iraqi tanker crews are under strict orders from Baghdad to ignore warnings to halt, even if fired upon. Tanker crews face the death penalty in Iraq if they allow American sailors to board their vessels.
Although Iraq is believed to have warplanes based in Yemen, Pentagon officials said today that Navy ships intercepting Iraqi tankers would be protected by American F-14 fighter jets on aircraft carriers nearby and by F-15's based at Saudi airfields.
Even if the Iraqis accepted asylum, Administration officials said there would be several problems to resolve, including what the United States would do with the Iraqi ships and their cargo.
As the blockade continued to strangle Iraqi's oil-dependent economy, several American military officials bluntly warned Mr. Hussein that if attacked, the United States would respond with force on a large scale.
The American buildup continued today, as the United States said it was sending an unspecified number of F-111 bombers based in Britain to Saudi Arabia to bolster what is called Operation Desert Shield.
The situation at more than 60 foreign embassies in Kuwait, all of which Iraq ordered closed on Friday, varied today from nation to nation.
 
Power Is Cut Off
Iraqi soldiers cut off electrical power to the United States Embassy in Kuwait City today at 11:15 A.M. Kuwait time, or 4:15 A.M. Eastern time, but power was restored using the emergency generator.
Ambassador Howell and the other 10 American diplomats remained in routine contact with Washington, officials here said.
Elsewhere in Kuwait City, Iraqi troops were reported this morning to have breached the wall of the French Embassy, apparently to cut off water lines.
News reports quoted Italy's Foreign Ministry as stating that Iraqi troops surrounding the French Embassy were ''beating down the embassy wall to get to the water unit to cut the water off.''
 
Report by Italian Envoy
The report, which could not be quickly confirmed, came from Italy's Ambassador to Kuwait, Marco Colombo, who said he had talked to French diplomats in Kuwait City early today.
British officials said Iraq had pulled its tanks away from its embassy but that soldiers still surrounded it. Electricity was restored to the mission today after being cut off on Friday, they said.
Iraqi soldiers surrounded Canada's Embassy on Friday but withdrew overnight, leaving power and water in place, Canada's External Affairs Department said.

LENGTH: 342 words

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Hostage Families Tell Their Stories

 BODY:
A decade ago, Arleen Uerling was working in a restaurant in Yakima, Wash., when Mohammed Tayeh walked in, ''and it was love at first sight,'' her mother said. Two years later they were married and headed for Kuwait, where, until the Iraqi invasion Aug. 2, Mr. Tayeh had a catering service and Arleen Tayeh was a homemaker.
Now she is one of 3,000 Americans trapped in Iraq and Kuwait, all of them hostages, many of them moved to important military targets as shields against attack. 
The United States Government and the families of these Americans know almost nothing about their condition now, or even where they are. But some families are willing to tell the stories of their missing relatives. A page of profiles of Mrs. Tayeh and other hostages, by Lisa Belkin with Dennis Hevesi, is on page 14.
BUSH'S BIG TEST: The President, who has successfully stitched together a broad international alliance against Iraq, still faces fragile public support and the possibility of far-reaching damage to the nation's economy as a result of the Middle East crisis. News analysis, page 16.
IRAQ'S SUPERGUN: Before he was slain, Gerald Bull, the world's greatest artillery designer, sold his lethal talent to the highest bidder: Saddam Hussein. Beginning in 1985, Iraq bought hundreds of artillery pieces developed by Mr. Bull that now threaten the multinational force in Saudi Arabia. But Mr. Bull's obsession was building a Supergun able to launch shells thousands of miles. Although a number of Supergun parts were seized in Europe on the way to Iraq, the Hussein Government is believed to have many other components - and the blueprints. Magazine, section 6.
HUSSEIN'S VIEW OF HISTORY: Giant posters in his country liken the President of Iraq to Nebuchadnezzar, the Babylonian king who destroyed Jerusalem, and Saladin, the Muslim warrior who fought back Christian crusaders. The glory his region had as a world power through the centuries is still alive as a force driving Saddam Hussein's yearning for greatness. The Week in Review, section 4.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
U.N. CALLS ON NAVIES TO BLOCK IRAQ'S TRADE; RESOLUTION PERMITS USE OF FORCE, U.S. SAYS

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 25

 BODY:
The Security Council overwhelmingly adopted a resolution early today giving the United States and other nations the right to enforce the economic embargo against Iraq by halting shipping to and from that country.
The vote was 13 to 0, with Yemen and Cuba abstaining.
The resolution endorses ''measures commensurate to the specific circumstances as may be necessary'' to halt shipping; it does not explicitly authorize the use of ''minimum force,'' as the United States had urged. But Thomas R. Pickering, the American representative to the United Nations, said the resolution was ''sufficiently broad to use armed force - indeed, minimum force - depending upon the circumstances.''
 
On Watch in Gulf and Red Sea
The Pentagon has reported that about a dozen Iraqi ships are under surveillance by American or allied warships in the Persian Gulf and Red Sea. 
Brent Scowcroft, the White House national security adviser, said the resolution - the result of several days of negotiations - allows the United States to act as it sees fit to enforce the embargo ordered by the United Nations against Iraq on Aug. 6, four days after the invasion of Kuwait.
''That means no commerce should go in and out by sea, and that means that vessels will be stopped and inspected,'' Mr. Scowcroft said. Other American officials have said the United States and its allies could use force to disable ships, wrecking rudders of vessels that seem determined to break the embargo. This runs the risk of Iraqi air retaliation against American ships.
 
Another Warning From Iraq
The Iraqi delegate to the United Nations, Abdul Amir al-Anbari, warned after the Council's vote, ''This use of force by the United States or any of its allies or puppets will lead inevitably to a number of explosions which will burn all in their path.''
Officials have suggested that Iraqi air attacks on American ships could set off a huge military response by the United States.
The Security Council resolution, the result of compromises with the Soviet Union, was not as clear-cut as Washington had originally intended. Instead of specifically permitting the use of force, the text is more ambiguous.
The Council calls upon nations with naval forces in the area ''to use such measures commensurate to the specific circumstances as may be necessary under the authority of the Security Council to halt all inward and outward maritime shipping in order to inspect and verify their cargoes and destinations and to insure strict implementation of the provisions related to such shipping.''
The United Nations vote was nonetheless widely regarded as a success for the United States because its language seemed to permit the use of force.
The vote also dramatized a shift in the international climate. At an earlier time it would have been unthinkable to envision the Soviet Union and China both voting to enforce an embargo against Iraq, a country that has had friendly military and political relations with both.
Despite qualms earlier in the week about authorizing force, the Soviet delegate joined in the vote after President Mikhail S. Gorbachev ended his silence and warned President Saddam Hussein of Iraq that the Security Council would take additional action if his forces did not withdraw from Kuwait.
To make Soviet agreement possible, the United States eliminated the phrase ''minimum force'' and met a Soviet request that any military actions be coordinated ''as appropriate'' through a moribund United Nations body, the Military Staff Committee.
President Bush's spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said today that the vote ''further strengthens the world resolve to force Iraq out of Kuwait.''
In Kennebunkport, Me., where Mr. Bush is vacationing, Mr. Fitzwater said in a written statement, ''We are encouraged by the progress of events at the United Nations and by President Gorbachev's strong support.''
He called Mr. Gorbachev's actions ''a very important development,'' adding, ''We welcome his voice to the world condemnation of the aggression by Saddam Hussein.''
 
Bush Largely Out of Sight
Mr. Bush stayed largely out of sight today, going boating in the early morning and meeting with Mr. Scowcroft at Walker's Point, the President's family residence.
Mr. Fitzwater did not immediately comment on a remark to reporters Friday by the Soviet delegate, Valentin V. Lozinsky, indicating that the Soviet Union was considering taking part in the multinational naval presence.
The Security Council approved the resolution at 4:10 A.M. after consultations that began late Friday. It was the third time the Council has endorsed the use of force to support United Nations decisions since the organization was founded in 1945.
In 1950, the Council voted to repel North Korea's attack on South Korea, although the Soviet Union did not take part in the resolution. Force was also authorized in 1965 against breakaway Rhodesia, now Zimbabwe, after its declaration of independence from Britain.
Mr. Pickering said in a Council speech after the vote, ''At no time since 1945 has this Council been asked to take on the kind of responsibility we are assuming today.''
 
China's Approval Unexpected
The size of the majority exceeded even some predictions by diplomats who had championed the measure. Only shortly before the balloting - by a show of hands in the hushed Council chamber - did it become widely apparent that China would also vote yes instead of abstaining, as it had earlier said it would.
With that, the measure received the unanimous backing of the Council's five permanent members - the United States, Britain, China, France and the Soviet Union, each of which has veto power. The other 10 members now holding seats on the Council are Cuba, Yemen, Canada, Finland, Colombia, Ethiopia, Malaysia, the Ivory Coast, Zaire and Romania.
The United Nations resolution was the fifth directed at Iraq since it occupied Kuwait.
On Aug. 3, the Security Council voted 14 to 0, with one abstention, to condemn the invasion, demanding the immediate, unconditional withdrawal of all of Baghdad's forces from Kuwait. On Aug. 6, the Council voted 13 to 0, with 2 abstentions, to order the trade and financial boycott of Iraq and occupied Kuwait. On Aug. 9, the Council voted 15 to 0 to declare Iraq's formal annexation of Kuwait null and void under international law. And on Aug. 18, the Council unanimously demanded that Iraq free all detained foreigners and implicitly warned of military action if they were not released.
The United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, said the vote signaled that ''the time has come'' for him to open urgent talks with Iraqi officials on easing the Gulf crisis. He invited the Iraqi Foreign Minister, Tariq Aziz, to join him for discussions in New York or Geneva, but there was no immediate response.
 
Backing of Nonaligned Sought
The final hours before the vote today were marked by efforts by Mr. Pickering and his British counterpart, Sir Crispin Tickell, to get backing from nonaligned nations on the Council. Resentment of the permanent members' veto power is widespread among nonaligned delegates here.
Representatives of the permanent members had spent days trying to agree on a draft resolution. The Soviet Union argued that a clear violation of the boycott should occur before the resolution was passed, while the United States pressed for a swifter vote.
 
Soviets 'Came on Board'
The Soviets ''came on board,'' as some diplomats put it, after telephone conversations between Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze.
The Cuban delegate, Ricardo Alarcon de Quesada, complained in a speech just before the vote of the ''strange and tortuous wording'' of the resolution, which he said violated parts of the United Nations Charter.
But Mr. Pickering, seemingly untired by his marathon diplomatic labors, told his fellow delegates in a speech, ''History will judge us by our resolve in the face of Iraq's threats to international peace and security.''

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1, Page 15, Column 2; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 698 words

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Diplomats' Position in Kuwait: Gray Area in International Law

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25

 BODY:
The Persian Gulf crisis poses questions of international law that appear clear cut in the case of United Nations actions, but murky when it comes to the protection of foreign diplomats in Kuwait.
The United Nations Security Council's approval of military force to promote the economic embargo of Iraq is clearly defined as legal by international conventions. But international law is less clear in defining the options that nations have to defend their embassies and diplomats threatened in Kuwait City, especially since Kuwait is occupied by a foreign power. While governments are required to respect the sovereignty of embassies and the immunity of diplomats, those rights are not clearly established in situations in which those missions come under the authority of occupation forces. 
The Security Council's unanimous resolution today gives the allied forces the right to blockade Iraqi ports and stop, board and even attack merchant vessels attempting to break the embargo. Iraq has claimed that the United Nations action violated international law, but according to American legal scholars the resolution is well within established legal convention.
''There's no question,'' said John Norton Moore, a law professor at the University of Virginia, ''that in the face of aggressive attack, the Security Council can authorize nations to take the measures necessary for an effective embargo.''
Mr. Moore said that within the limits of ''collective defense'' of Kuwait, whose invasion by Iraq the Security Council deemed illegal, force can be used against shipping as long as it is ''necessary and proportional.'' He added, ''There is an obligation to use the minimum force necessary to achieve the lawful objective.''
Minimum force, legal scholars say, would include knocking out a rudder or landing a military force to take over the vessel.
But scholars say President Saddam Hussein's threatened violation of diplomatic immunity moves the crisis into some areas of international law that have become increasingly murky.
Traditionally, a nation's embassy has been considered part of that nation's territory, frequently protected by armed guards belonging to that nation's armed forces. Diplomatic personnel assigned to embassies, and whose credentials are accepted by host countries, are given special legal privileges by which they are immune from most or all prosecution in the countries where they serve.
The rules by which embassies and diplomats function were codified by the 1961 Vienna Convention, which states: ''The agents of the receiving state may not enter except with the consent of the head of the mission.''
The convention goes on to say: ''The receiving state is under special duty to take all appropriate steps to protect the premises of the mission against any intrusion or damage and to prevent any disturbance of the peace of the mission or impairment of its dignity.''
 
Diplomats Told to Leave
Iraq, which signed the convention, would seem to be violating international law when it cuts off electricity and water to a number of embassies in Kuwait. Mr. Hussein has threatened to withdraw diplomatic immunity from embassy personnel that do not comply with his order to leave Kuwait for Baghdad and has implied that the diplomats will become hostages until the United States withdraws its forces from the area and the international community lifts the embargo.
But Iraq claims that the foreign embassies in Kuwait have no rights because Kuwait no longer exists. It was Kuwaiti, not Iraqi, authorities who accepted the credentials of diplomats in Kuwait City, and who granted the embassies their privileges.
 
A Sovereignty Issue
''The problem arises here because this is arising in Kuwait,'' said Abram J. Chayes, a law professor at Harvard University and legal adviser to the State Department during the Kennedy Administration. ''The legality of the whole thing comes down to who is the legal ruler of Kuwait. It's an issue of who has sovereignty.''
Legal scholars say there are no clear modern precedents to define the rights of foreign embassies in countries that have been annexed outright, without the creation of a puppet government.
