PUB-DATE: August 26, 1990

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1, Page 16, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1641 words

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
The Golf Cart Crisis

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., Aug. 25

 BODY:
Even on a day when he savored a hard-won diplomatic triumph at the United Nations, President Bush and his handling of the Persian Gulf crisis encountered irritating criticisms from unexpected quarters.
 
At the same time that
Mr. Bush is basking in beams of approval from Europe and receiving support from the Soviet Union, television comedians and journalistic commentators at home are suggesting that he set an example for the nation by giving his gas-guzzling speedboat a rest.
And he is getting conflicting reviews from American conservatives, with some doubting the worth of the mission and others, including two former Secretaries of State, Henry A. Kissinger and Alexander M. Haig, warning about the dangers of wearing out popular support by waiting too long to act in his effort to control the expansionist ambitions of Saddam Hussein.
This situation reflects the problem that while Mr. Bush has adeptly marshaled foreign support and stitched together a broad alliance, he has had little appetite or time for grappling with the implications of the crisis for the national economy, the impact on the Federal budget deficit of tens of millions of dollars a day in additional military spending and, finally, developing an election-year rationale for the overarching goals of his policy. 
Within the White House and among outside experts, there is a sense of a President launched on a stormy period that will be crucial to the verdicts on an Administration that had begun well but had not yet faced a test of such magnitude.
''I think we're seeing Bush feeling his way into a whole new world,'' said Stephen Ambrose, biographer of Dwight D. Eisenhower and Richard M. Nixon. ''This is the first post-cold war crisis, the first in which none of the givens of his lifetime are there anymore. It's uncharted water for the White House and I don't think they're navigating it entirely successfully yet.''
As the focus of such attention, Mr. Bush has so far avoided the appearance of personal anguish that characterized the presidency of Jimmy Carter. He has tried to project the image of a leader unintimidated by perilous military action and willing to bear the responsibility of military command without being paralyzed by threats to the lives of American hostages.
Mr. Bush has clearly distinguished himself from his predecessors - more decisive than Mr. Carter, more in charge than Ronald Reagan - and yet is haunted and occasionally hobbled by the ghosts of their presidencies.
By holding to his summer vacation plans, Mr. Bush has rejected Mr. Carter's decision to stay in the White House during the Iran hostage crisis. But Mr. Bush's approach has sprung an entirely new trap: while Mr. Bush is hard at work here, the television imagery is of a President blithely speed-boating and golfing through what has become a dangerous summer for tens of thousands of American soldiers and thousands of American civilians.
''He may end up being the first President who's held hostage on a Cigarette boat,'' said Jody Powell, who was Mr. Carter's press secretary. ''He's sort of got himself in a position where he has to go fishing even if he doesn't want to. They made a decision about appearances that's got away from them and is now controlling him.''
 
An Intimate Portrait
Although Mr. Bush fiercely resists close inspection, the last three weeks have provided a intimate portrait of his leadership. They have revealed him at his most temperamental, grousing at reporters who dog his golf cart. They have shown him at his diplomatic best, telephoning around the world to hold together the anti-Iraq alliance.
They have also demonstrated the perils of the personal way Mr. Bush conducts his diplomacy. He has relied on a knowledge of the Middle East that comes from a long association with its oil-rich, conservative royal families and leaves Mr. Bush with a blind spot in assessing the currents of the Arab street and the intentions of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.
In general, the Persian Gulf conflict puts the final focus on a picture that began taking shape in 1989 as the new President began shedding images accrued over the years in which he had been Mr. Reagan's silent and loyal No. 2: ''wimpy,'' ''excessively cautious,'' ''inarticulate,'' ''lacking in vision.'' ''He's had to wipe off eight years of cobwebs,'' said a senior Administration official.
The leader evident in today's crisis began emerging, this official suggested, in a May 1989 meeeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization at which he made a proposal to cut conventional armed forces. ''The idea was to tell the allies clearly that he was going to lead NATO, that he had the personal will and ambition to match the U.S. role as a superpower,'' the official said.
After the Malta summit meeting and the Washington meeting with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev this year, many of Mr. Bush's critics were acknowledging that he had moved effectively on the world stage. But there has been a lingering complaint that while he excelled at shifting gears quickly, Mr. Bush was disinclined to provide a broad vision for his actions.
 
Untested in Adversity
He was also untested in adversity, but in the Panama invasion last year, Mr. Bush demonstrated his willingness to employ military force. Newsweek magazine, which once speculated about ''the wimp factor,'' now calls him the ''WASP warrior.''
Administration officials say Mr. Bush is giving thought to the larger picture, pondering what the Middle East will look like if the military operation drives Mr. Hussein from Iraq. But there are indications here that the Administration is prepared to accept an ending in which Mr. Hussein remains in power in Iraq and it is not clear what its solution for Middle East security would be in that case, apart from an indefinite American military presence.
These internal deliberations have been conducted in a classic Bush fashion, in the smallest circle of advisers. Indeed, the President and his national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, have spent hours together, often with fishing lines trailing in the Atlantic Ocean off Mr. Bush's speedboat.
But whatever the intensity and scope of these discussions, Mr. Bush has had trouble expressing his larger goals to the public. Mr. Scowcroft tried to do some of that for him today in an appearance on Cable News Network, saying the gulf crisis was reflecting ''the emergence of a new world order,'' with the United Nations functioning as originally intended ''to mobilize the civilized world against aggression and against aggressors.''
Turning to the political problem, Mr. Scowcroft said Mr. Bush is actually putting in a full day's work and is so pressed for time that he winds up taking ''a forced march around the golf course instead of a leisurely round.''
For Mr. Bush's part, he has been markedly accessible for a President in the midst of a crisis, giving regular news conferences, which he obviously enjoys, and three major speeches, which equally obviously he does not.
These speeches have summoned patriotic imagery and talked of stopping a Hitler-like aggressor. Mr. Ambrose, the Presidential biographer, argued that these are words more suitable to an older era. ''He's talking about the American way of life being at stake, about freedom being at stake,'' he said. ''That's typical Nixonian rhetoric, typical Vietnam rhetoric.''
One problem Mr. Bush may be having is that the importance of preserving oil supplies is an important part of his Gulf policy, but one that does not play well in public. The other problem is the hostages. Mr. Bush and his advisers have been absorbed in not allowing him to fall into the same patterns that paralyzed Mr. Carter and Mr. Reagan, not only adhering to the famous vacation but also making sure that Mr. Bush does not - as Mr. Reagan did -begin appearing with hostages' families and thus establish a hobbling personal relationship with them.
 
A Central Truth
Implicit in all his decisions is one central truth: If Mr. Bush orders military action, he will do so in full knowledge that it will likely cost the lives of Americans and others held hostage by Mr. Hussein. But Mr. Bush cannot speak that thought directly.
Administration officials have argued with justification that the speed with which Mr. Bush gathered other countries behind him is testimony to his personal diplomacy. Bush.
But what the Persian Gulf crisis has also demonstrated are the hazards of Mr. Bush's penchant for dealing only with the top officials of foreign countries. In this case, Mr. Bush's views are heavily tinted by his friendships with the ruling elites of countries like Jordan and Saudi Arabia.
''During a trip to Saudi Arabia in 1986, Bush met with King Fahd from 4 P.M. to 3 A.M. one day,'' a senior official said. ''He is a longtime friend of the Saudi Ambassador in Washington, Prince Bandar, who gave Bush an enormous party in air-conditioned tents in the desert and took him riding on the dunes in a jeep. They got stuck in the sand together.''
 
Personal Bonding
''But the scene that sticks in my mind the most is Bush on a yacht with King Hussein of Jordan,'' he said. ''They were going out sailing together and there was Bush, this tall, lanky American, rubbing suntan lotion all over the face of the King, who was much shorter.''
This personal bonding is critical to Mr. Bush. He is said to be unable to trust another leader until he has achieved it. But Administration officials acknowledge gaps in his understanding of the Middle East.
''There is an aspect of Arab religion, culture and political life that is not clearly understood by anybody,'' an official said. ''Since that's the card that Saddam is playing right now, this manifests itself not being able to understand Saddam's motivations or predict his next move.''

PUB-DATE: August 26, 1990

LENGTH: 526 words

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
Kuwaiti Exiles Talk of Iraqi Search for Westerners

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
Some Iraqi soldiers in Kuwait are searching for Westerners, Kuwaiti exiles in Saudi Arabia said yesterday in telephone interviews.
The Iraqi troops also appear to have confiscated from Kuwait and shipped home large quantities of food. As a result, the United Nations trade embargo against both countries may cause hunger and other hardship sooner in occupied Kuwait than in Iraq. 
Iraqi troops in Kuwait are said to have visited the large apartment complexes where many Westerners live, asking the guards for help in locating Americans and other foreigners, said a Kuwaiti businessman in Zilfi, a Saudi town about 200 miles from the border.
But a State Department official said the United States had received no recent reports of Iraqi soldiers going door to door in search of foreigners or of local residents being pressed to help find foreigners. The official insisted on anonymity.
Iraqi-controlled television and radio in Kuwait have warned residents against harboring foreigners, said a Kuwaiti Government worker in Zilfi who left his country on Monday. ''They said you will have the strongest punishment, but they didn't say what it was.''
The businessman belongs to a group that is bringing people out from Kuwait. He said he had made six trips, most recently coming out on Thursday, while a teacher said he had made three trips, returning from the last trip on Aug. 19. They spoke on condition that they not be identified.
Their accounts could not be independently confirmed.
 
Perhaps Too Great a Risk
The Iraqis have stepped up their border patrols and begun shooting at people attempting to cross the desert, the businessman said, adding: ''I don't think I will go back. I don't think I can do it again.''
Iraqi troops have obliterated graffiti critical of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, the businessman said. ''The Kuwaitis will write 'Saddam Is Bad,' and the Iraqis will paint over it, 'Saddam Is Good.' ''
Demonstrations by Kuwaiti women holding up pictures of the exiled Emir have been broken up by Iraqi troops, said a Kuwaiti businessman in Riyadh, Nasser Al-Rashed, the chairman and managing director of Kuwait's partially state-owned Public Warehousing Company. He fled Kuwait on Aug. 5.
Bread was still available in some bakeries on Thursday, and some gas stations were still open, Mr. Rashed said. Vegetables were also available, and Kuwaitis have stored food in their homes. But many warehouses stood empty, he said, and concern about the supply of food is increasing.
The United States Department of Agriculture says Kuwait produces some vegetables in greenhouses and has a small shrimp-fishing industry but relies on imports for 96 percent of its food. Kuwait imports much of its food by sea, but Kuwait's ports are now blockaded by the United States Navy.
Iraq relies on imports for 70 to 80 percent of its food, said John P. Parker, an Agriculture Department economist.
The Iraqi Government is more likely to feed its people than the Kuwaitis if the United Nations embargo proves prolonged, said Marvin Zonis, a professor at the University of Chicago Graduate School of Business, who studies Iraqi politics.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
OPEC LEADER URGES HIGHER OIL OUTPUT

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: VIENNA, Aug. 25

 BODY:
The president of OPEC said today that the organization should help alleviate any oil shortages caused by the Persian Gulf crisis.
But his remarks were not accompanied by any signs that informal talks here on Sunday would mend a deep split in the group.
''I hope to God we save OPEC,'' Sadek Boussena, the oil minister of Algeria, told reporters at a Vienna hotel. 
Representatives of most of the 13 members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries are expected to join in the talks here amid what appeared to be a deepening rift between those that want to raise production and those that want even higher oil prices.
 
Nearly a 50 Percent Price Rise
Oil prices have already risen nearly 50 percent since supplies were disrupted after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2.
Mr. Boussena said OPEC should act, at what he called the right time, to help alleviate any oil shortages.
Neither in his remarks at the hotel, nor in an interview with Reuters, did Mr. Boussena elaborate on what he saw as the main threat to the group.
In the interview, he emphasized that his remarks reflected Algeria's position and that he was not speaking in his capacity as OPEC president.
Saudi Arabia's Oil Minister, Hisham M. Nazer, said upon his arrival in Vienna that he would have ''no comment to make at this stage.''
Saudi Arabia and Venezuela have been the main proponents of the talks, which were set after a militant group of oil producers blocked an attempt to hold a more formal emergency meeting to try to stabilize soaring oil prices.
At one point, the Saudis had said they were unlikely to attend any meeting unless it was a formal decision-making conference.
 
Severe Petroleum Shortages
The disagreement has come as the world's oil markets have begun to experience severe shortages of some refined petroleum products. Many oil experts expect the situation to worsen in the coming months as a United Nations-endorsed embargo against Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil sharply diminishes world oil supplies.
Prices have jumped about $10 above OPEC's declared target price of $21 a barrel, threatening to revive the group's negative image of the 1970's and forcing industrial countries to cut back consumption of OPEC oil.
The United States wants OPEC to raise production above the current quotas to help offset the loss of some four million barrels of Iraqi and Kuwaiti exports a day.
Saudi Arabia, which has up to two million barrels of spare production capacity, and Venezuela and the United Arab Emirates, with around 500,000 barrels each of spare capacity, say they will increase production with or without approval from the rest of OPEC.
Iraq, a member of OPEC, will scarcely grant such approval, delegates say.
 
Reason for Consultations
''I am a man of the law; I follow the statute,'' Mr. Boussena said, referring to OPEC's bylaws to explain why he had called only for consultations.
Algeria had not opposed a full conference, but it had thought that in the uncertain political atmosphere preparation was needed so that ''we could act smoothly,'' he said.
Mr. Boussena added that OPEC confronted ''maybe one of the most difficult challenges it has ever had to face.''
''We know that a shortage of oil, if that really occurs, will not help the global economy, of which Algeria is a part,'' he said.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
For an Egyptian Father, The Joy of Sons' Escape

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, Aug. 25

 BODY:
Outside the Mourci cafe on a dusty Cairo back street on Friday, Mohammed Gamal was all smiles. In a telephone call from Nuweiba, a port on the Sinai peninsula, he had learned that his five sons had returned safely to Egypt on a ferry from Jordan, after a grueling 1,200-mile bus journey from Kuwait.
For Mr. Gamal, a 63-year-old driver, the call signaled the end of an ordeal that began on Aug. 2, when Iraqi troops overran Kuwait. His sons were among 250,000 Egyptians working in the Persian Gulf state, many of them as laborers. Like thousands of others, they arrived back in Egypt penniless, looted of their savings, their radios and other valuables along the punishing journey that brought them home through Iraq. 
Across Cairo, and down the Nile River valley, recent days have witnessed many scenes like that at the cafe on Darb el-Qatib Street, where Mr. Gamal stalked from table to table, accepting the congratulations of neighbors drinking sweet Turkish coffee and drawing on water pipes.
Amid the handshakes, Mr. Gamal offered a flurry of comments on the crisis that has made refugees of tens of thousands of Egyptians who were among an estimated two million working in Kuwait and Iraq.
 
Politics by Expletive
''Majnoon!'' Mr. Gamal exclaimed, using the Arabic word for crazy to describe Saddam Hussein, the Iraqi leader. ''Ragal!'' he said, referring to President Bush with a word that Arabs use to refer to a man of resolve.
Three weeks into the Persian Gulf crisis, there is little sign of a shift in the public mood in Egypt, the most populous Arab country and the one whose President, Hosni Mubarak, led a majority of Arab nations in condemning the Iraqi action and approving the dispatch of Egyptian and other Arab forces to Saudi Arabia.
Despite attempts by Mr. Hussein to stir a ferment among Egyptians by accusing Mr. Mubarak of betraying Arab interests, ordinary Egyptians appear to be backing their President to the hilt.
In Western embassies here, the support has been reassuring. Just as Mr. Mubarak's stand was crucial to forging an Arab consensus, any weakening of his position could be the beginning of an unraveling of Arab resolve.
While Mr. Mubarak has survived crises in the nine years since the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat, his position has never been free of a potential challenge from Muslim fundamentalists, Arab socialists and others who distrust Egypt's close ties with the United States.
 
Most Pleas to Left Unavailing
In an ''open letter'' to Mr. Mubarak this week, and in statements against the Egyptian leader read on the Baghdad radio, President Hussein has appealed to these potential opponents. But indications so far have been that the appeals have failed.
Only a handful of leftist journals here have sided with Mr. Hussein, and he has found almost no support, at least in public, among Muslim clerics who constitute a potentially receptive audience for his attacks on Arabs who associate with the ''corrupt'' and ''imperialist'' purposes of Western powers.
Not that Mr. Mubarak has taken his stand without strains. The return of the migrants means a loss of the remittances that have shored up Egypt's foreign-exchange earnings, estimated by some economists at $2.5 billion a year.
While Japan pledged financial aid this week to help cover some of the losses, there will be additional heavy costs in resettling the returning workers. The Government has pledged to employ 100,000 of them in Egypt's already bloated bureaucracy, but others will swell an unemployment rate estimated at 20 percent before the gulf crisis.
Egyptian security officials have been alerted to watch for possible infiltrators placed among the returnees by Mr. Hussein. And while many arriving here have spoken bitterly of the Iraqis, officials here acknowledge that coming home to economic privation that caused many of the workers to leave in the first place could foster political discontent.
 
Egyptians Ignore Attacks
This appears to be the hope of leftist groups like the Socialist Labor Party, whose leader, Ibrahim Shukri, said this week that Egypt had ''committed a vulgar crime'' by condemning Mr. Hussein and supporting the dispatch of American forces.
Despite such statements, Egyptian volunteers continue to line up at the Kuwaiti and Saudi Arabian embassies here, applying to enlist in the Arab forces arrayed against Mr. Hussein. Nor has there been any sign of ferment against President Mubarak at Cairo's principal mosques.
Sermons that followed noon prayers on Friday, such as the one at the Saida Zeineb mosque in the heart of the city, were steadfast in their backing. ''I pray for Saddam to come to his senses,'' said Sheik Ibrahim el-Qahum, senior cleric at the mosque.
Since many mosques and Muslim groups here are at at least partly Government-financed, the support is partly expected. But diplomats were struck this week by a statement drawn up by a group of 50 Muslim scholars led by Fahmi Hoveidi, a leading figure in the Muslim Brotherhood, a fundamentalist grouping that has been no supporter of Mr. Mubarak's.
The statement called the Iraqi invasion ''a crime and an offense against all Arab and Islamic laws,'' and said that it ''must be challenged and reversed by force.''

Tens of thousands of Egyptians who had been working in Kuwait and Iraq are arriving home penniless, their savings, radios and other valuables stolen during the punishing desert journey. HEADLINE: Bush's Trade Offer Gets a Warm Latin Reception

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 24

 BODY:
When President Bush made his offer to open a free-trade partnership with all of Latin America, President Luis Alberto Lacalle of Uruguay jumped to the telephone and said he would accept.
Then he started calling his fellow South American leaders and urging them to do the same before the news got cold. Maybe, he said, they ought to send a delegation of three Presidents to Washington immediately.
''When, after years of our complaining of neglect, the most important man in the world offers his hand, then I think we should grab it - and the arm and the elbow and the shoulder, too,'' Mr. Lacalle said. While the broader Latin American reaction did not come as quickly as the Uruguayan leader wanted, Mr. Bush's June 27 proposal has been very warmly received in an area looking frantically for ways to keep pace with the global movement toward free markets and free trade. 
Although there are doubts in the region about whether Mr. Bush can fully deliver on his free-trade offer, many leaders are excited about the prospect of being able to negotiate seriously on points that concern them. On the continent that once rang with cries against ''Yankee imperialism,'' seemingly everybody of influence now dreams of a special relationship with the man who once headed the Central Intelligence Agency.
''We are passing through the most brilliant moment in our relations with the United States,'' President Carlos Saul Menem of Argentina declared recently. That was said in a country with a long history of testy relations with the United States over such points as economic nationalism, competing trade policies, nuclear programs and human rights violations.
Mr. Bush's proposal coincides with, and seems to have added momentum to, a number of attempts to open up trade within South America after three decades of protectionist and import-substitution policies.
Argentina, Brazil and Uruguay have signed agreements that are supposed to completely open their borders to one anther by the beginning of 1996, although many steps lie ahead to make the agreements work. Paraguay has expressed interest in the pact as well.
On Sunday, Mr. Menem travels to Chile to encourage the Government of President Patricio Aylwin to join the trade zone, which he hopes will expand to all of South America.
Chile has pioneered free trade and economic liberalization in the region for 15 years, finding most of its markets outside Latin America, and looks eagerly to any improvement in trade prospects. But it is leery about tying its hands at this point to Argentina and Brazil until they do more to dismantle their protectionist structures and come out of recessions that severely restrict their import possibilities.
''Today, economic integration is the principal tenet of foreign policy of all of Latin America,'' said Rubens Barbosa, a Brazilian diplomat who presides over the committee of representatives to the Latin American Integration Association, which has its headquarters here. The 11-member group includes Mexico and the South American countries except for Surinam and Guyana.
''The scenario of 1990 in Latin America is completely distinct from that of 1980,'' Mr. Barbosa said. ''Then, the model was substitution of imports with local products and to protect and defend national industry.'' Mr. Bush, saying he was willing to work on a bilateral or multilateral basis, proposed that the free-trade negotiations begin with a series of ''framework agreements'' between the United States and individual Latin American countries or groups of countries.
Mr. Barbosa said he thought the United States would end up facing five different negotiations: with Mexico, already under way; then with the Caribbean countries; Central America; the Andean countries, and the countries here in the southern extreme, including Brazil.
But some South American nations also seem inclined to jump into bilateral negotiations. Bolivia has already done so, and Chile will probably do it if the others do not quickly catch up to its policies.

HEADLINE: Women's Shelter Wants Women Only on Its Board

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Aug. 25

 BODY:
Every day more than 100 women drop in at Rosie's Place because they are homeless and hungry, and in most cases because they have been abused at the hands of men. At Rosie's, the first homeless shelter in the country for females only, women are always welcome.
But men are not so welcome, and a recent decision to ban them from the board of directors has divided the shelter's corps of 250 volunteers, the people often described as the heart of the 16-year-old organization.
Although men have volunteered at Rosie's since the privately financed shelter opened, a male volunteer who wanted to run for the board in July learned he was not qualified because of his sex. 
No man had sought a seat on the 19-member board until January, when Howard Ostar, a longtime volunteer, decided to run in the board election that month. Volunteers who have worked at Rosie's for at least six months are eligible for board seats and can vote in elections.
Although Mr. Ostar lost, Randy Bluffstone, a volunteer for more than two years, decided to run in the July election. But Mr. Bluffstone's bid was thwarted when the board amended its bylaws in March to exclude men.
Today three seats remain vacant because no female candidates have sought them. Agnes Cahill, president of the board, said the directors were considering eliminating the vacant seats or filling them with homeless women.
 
'The Normal Dirty Jobs'
Mr. Bluffstone, a graduate student in economics at Boston University, said he was shocked by what appeared to be deliberate discrimination by people who are keenly aware of bias. ''The male volunteers work in the kitchen and do the normal dirty jobs like all the volunteers, but we're barred from any position of control because of our gender,'' he said.
The board's policy has divided the shelter's 250 volunteers, at least 10 of whom are men. While Mr. Bluffstone continues to volunteer at the shelter, serving meals, washing dishes and socializing with the guests, Mr. Ostar left, saying he was frustrated at being excluded from managerial decisions.
Rosie's officials say the rule is not meant to discriminate, but rather to formalize the shelter's goal of providing female role models for women. About 90 percent of the women who come to Rosie's have been abused by men. Many are chemicallyepepdedent, and nearly 25 percent veve beeininfefected witththAIAI v vusus ililsoso s sltlts s veveununededofof beds, Rosie's has limited its overnight capacity to 20 so it can attend to each woman individually. ''Rosie's has led the way in how to provide a service to people in need without robbing them of their diginity,'' said Sue Marsh, executive director of the Massachusetts Coalition for the Homeless.
 
Not the 'Shelter Industry'
Kip Tiernan, the shelter's founder, who is known for her commitment to the plight of poor women, said Rosie's was determined not to join the ''shelter industry'' by expanding capacity to accommodate a growing homeless population. Instead, the board decided last year to concentrate on helping a limited number of women find permanent homes and steady jobs. To that end, the directors created two managerial positions, which were filled by women. Given the shelter's focus on women, supporters of the board argue that reserving board seats for women is appropriate. ''It is within the spirit of affirmative action that a place whose entire mission is steeped in the conviction to empower women has a policy for board membership that reflects this commitment,'' said Lisa Price, a volunteer for more than two years.
But Mr. Bluffstone argues that men can also provide important role models for the women who come to Rosie's. ''I thought I could make a contribution to the empowerment of poor women by showing them on the spot that I value their ideas and opinions,'' he said. ''But the board members are sending the message that men are not to be trusted. I think they're seriously misguided.''

HEADLINE: Public Dismay on Savings Disaster Grows, Poll Finds

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH

 BODY:
The public has grown increasingly disenchanted with President Bush's handling of the savings and loan crisis, but most Americans still place ultimate blame on the managers and owners in the industry, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.
The high negative ratings for the President on the subject have apparently spilled over to his fellow Republicans. By a margin of more than 2 to 1, Americans said they faulted Republicans more than Democrats for the crisis, which experts now calculate will cost taxpayers at least $500 billion over the next 30 years.
And in a sober warning to regulators as well as politicians, the poll found a gloomy view of the future of the financial system. Fifty-nine percent of the public said they feared the worst of the savings and loans crisis was yet to come, while 62 percent said they worried about the safety of deposits in savings and loans, and 40 percent said they did not think money in commercial banks was absolutely safe. 
The savings disaster did not prevent Mr. Bush's overall approval rating, first reported last week, from matching his highest level so far, buoyed by public support for his handling of the Persian Gulf crisis. Seventy-six percent of the 1,422 adults polled by telephone from Aug. 16 to 19 said they approved of the way he was handling his job as President; only 15 percent disapproved. The margin of sampling error was plus or minus three percentage points.
 
'Noise,' but Nobody Is Punished
But his handling of the savings and loan crisis was approved by only 27 percent; 51 percent disapproved. In May, a Times/CBS News poll found that 32 percent expressed approval and 42 percent disapproval.
''So far it looks like Bush is just letting the taxpayers pay for it,'' said Merlin H. Spading, a 59-year-old retired employee of the International Business Machines Corporation in Rochester, Minn., who participated in the poll, then responded to questions in a later interview. ''We are hearing a lot of noise in Washington, but no one is going to jail, and they're not trying enough to recover the money from the assets that were taken.''
The poll's findings underscore what strategists of both parties have been saying in recent weeks about the Federal effort to bolster collapsing savings and loan industry: that a year after President Bush signed into law the largest Federal rescue in history, the public is becoming increasingly frustrated by the slowness and the cost.
The Government has seized hundreds of insolvent institutions, but top Administration officials concede that the bill for the bailout will be at least double initial projections and millions of taxpayers will have to pay thousands of dollars more in Federal taxes over the next 30 years because of inept regulation, mismanagement and fraud by executives.
 
Overshadowed by Persian Gulf
Until the confrontation began in the Persian Gulf, the savings and loan crisis was considered a major vulnerability for Republicans in this fall's elections. Democratic strategists now say success of the President's Persian Gulf policy could blunt the effect of the scandal, but they still predict that the savings and loan issue will become important in the 1992 Presidential campaign.
Administration officials say such criticism is unfair since Mr. Bush was the first President to confront the issue. But they acknowledge it has been difficult to counter the barrage of criticism in recent months, and cite two turning points.
One was the acknowledgement by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady that the cost of the savings and loan bailout would be more than twice what the Treasury first projected. The second was action by Federal regulators against President Bush's son Neil for his role in the collapse of the Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association in Denver.
Regulators have accused the President's son of violating laws on conflicts of interest when he failed to disclose that he had business relationships with two major borrowers from Silverado. Loans to them ultimately caused huge losses at the institution and contributed to its demise.
''The S.& L. issue is a crystallizing issue,'' said Stanley B. Greenberg, president of Greenberg & Lake, a national Democratic polling firm. ''I think the perception is that Republicans are closer to big businesses and that they are in charge and therefore responsible. People tend to blame the people they think are in power.''
 
Bleak View of the Economy
Democrats also detect public concern about the safety of deposits in savings associations and banks as a potent political issue. The destabilizing effect of the savings and loan crisis on the economy, they say, is perhaps more critical than its links to campaign financing irregularities or its criminal aspects, particularly as voters sense the onset of a recession.
The Times/CBS News Poll found that particularly since trouble erupted in the Persian Gulf, Americans have become bleak about the economy. The poll found more people saying the economy was getting worse, not better, than at any time since January 1981, just before the worst recession in the postwar period. Indeed, 61 percent now say the country is already in a recession.
''I think people look at the S.& L. scandal as confirmation that the economy is in trouble, that it is going to cost taxpayers money and that people's living standards are going to be in trouble,'' Mr. Greenberg said.
The poll found that 61 percent strongly supported the Federal deposit insurance system, saying they would endorse an increase in their taxes if necessary for the Government to ''keep its promise to reimburse all depositors'' for losses in savings associations. Thirty-two percent said they would not favor a tax increase.
That contrasted strongly with a lack of support for higher taxes to protect United States interests in the Persian Gulf or to cut the Government budget deficit. In the poll, 53 percent said they would oppose higher taxes to protect Saudi Arabia against Iraqi aggression and 65 percent said they would disapprove of raising taxes to reduce the deficit.
 
Erosion of Public Confidence
The response echoed growing worry among bankers.
''Consumer confidence has definitely eroded, and it should come as no surprise,'' said Ken Guenther, executive vice president of the Independent Bankers Association, a Washington group representing small banks.
''Most people don't distinguish between banks and S.& L.'s, and until Iraq pushed the topic off the front page all they were hearing was bad news about the banking system,'' he said. ''I hope the people in power take note, because consumer confidence is very important. I bet confidence has gotten significantly worse in the last few months.''
Such uncertainty seems to be reflected in the blame the public places on Republicans for the crisis.
Asked which party was more responsible for the crisis, 35 percent of Americans blamed the Republicans, 17 percent blamed the Democrats and 17 percent said both parties were equally to blame.
On a separate question, only 3 percent held President Bush directly responsible for the crisis, while 18 percent blamed President Reagan and 10 percent blamed Congress.
Fifty-five percent blamed the managers and owners of the savings and loan industry.
 
Congress Seen as Culpable
When those who believed the industry was primarily at fault were pressed on who was to blame ''for allowing the owners and managers to cause'' the crisis, more than half cited Congress.
The poll also inquired about Neil Bush's role. Besides being accused of conflict-of-interest violations, Mr. Bush and other Silverado directors and officers may also soon be the target of a $200 million lawsuit by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, claiming negligence.
But the public was divided on whether the President's son was being singled out unfairly. Forty-seven percent said he was unduly the object of attention because of his relationship to the President, while 42 percent said his case was receiving the attention it deserved.
Describing the willingness of the public to blame industry executives and the President's son, Mr. Guenther said: ''The public has to hang somebody. It's true throughout history. People have to personify evil and wrong.''
Campaign contributions linked to savings institutions have been a source of particular anxiety among elected officials. Some members of Congress have said that not only are they returning all such contributions, but that they will also refuse to accept them in the future.
Attention has focused especially on five Senators who intervened with Federal regulators in 1987 on behalf of Charles H. Keating Jr., after they received very large contributions from the Phoenix developer and owner of the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif.
The poll appeared to underscore those concerns. Asked their voting sentiment if their Congressmen received contributions from the industry, 42 percent of Americans said they would be less likely to vote for the lawmaker again.
 
HOW THE SURVEY WAS CONDUCTED
The New York Times/CBS News Poll was based on telephone interviews conducted from Aug. 16 to Aug. 19 with 1,422 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the country. The exchanges were chosen so as to assure that each region of the country was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. The numbers were then screened so that only residences would be called.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of residential telephone lines and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to region, race, sex, age and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20, the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
The percentages reported are the particular results most likely to match what would be obtained by seeking out all adult Americans. Other possible percentages are progressively less likely the more they differ from the reported results.
The potential sampling error for smaller subgroups is larger. For example, for those who currently have an account in a savings and loan institution, it is plus or minus five percentage points.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll.

HEADLINE: Constance Gelb, Photojournalist, Weds Scott A. Otteman, Editor, in Stamford

 BODY:
Constance Gelb, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce S. Gelb of New York and Washington, was married yesterday at her parents' summer home in Stamford, Conn., to Scott Alan Otteman, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Merlin Otteman of Fort Collins, Colo. The Rev. Clarke K. Oler, an Episcopal minister, officiated. 
Miss Gelb, 30 years old, is a freelance photojournalist. She graduated from Choate Rosemary Hall and Hampshire College and received a master's degree in journalism from Columbia University. Her father is the director of the United States Information Agency. Her mother, Dr. Lueza Gelb, was until recently an adjunct professor of history at Pace University and Marymount Manhattan College. The bride is a granddaughter of Joan Bove of Palm Beach and the late Lawrence M. Gelb of New York; they founded Clairol Inc.
The bridegroom, 30, is an associate editor at Inside U.S. Trade, a magazine published in Crystal City, Va. He is a graduate of Stanford University, and he has master's degrees in journalism and international affairs from Columbia and a master's in developmental economics from Stanford. His father is a surgeon.

HEADLINE: EARLY MUSIC;
Minds and Ears Can't Go Back

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Richard Taruskin lays bare one of the most significant fallacies in the quest for musical authenticity: the tendency to be selective about what is ''authentic.''
There is, however, another, equally telling fallacy: the tendency to ignore the fact that what we hear in music is not simply a performance but a performance as it is experienced by our culturally conditioned ears and minds. 
Minds and ears that have experienced Wagner, Debussy, Stravinsky and Crumb cannot hear Beethoven's music in the same way his contemporaries heard it. For that matter, minds and ears accustomed to the sonic and rhythmic environments of daily life in the 20th century cannot hear Beethoven's music as his contemporaries heard it. Indeed, all the cultural changes - scientific, technological, social, economic, political, esthetic, philosophical, religious - that have occurred since the early 19th century alter the way in which we listen to music from that or any other period.
The quest for authenticity is valid to the extent that it tries to do justice, however imperfectly, to performance practices of the day. It is fallacious to the extent that is selective about what is ''authentic,'' and blind to the role of the listener in co-creating the musical experience.
 
GENE PAUL STRAYER
York, Pa.

HEADLINE: A Drugstore Industry Leader Raises the Level of Its Game

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
Sometimes a cigar is just a cigar. But during a recent crowded lunch hour in downtown Chicago, Jim McCallister's cigar became proof of just how quickly a customer can get in and out of one of Walgreen's drugstores.
Mr. McCallister, a 58-year-old Federal worker, was happily puffing onhis cigar before deciding to dip into a bustling Walgreen drugstore in Chicago's Loop. So he placed it on a ledge before entering the store, and emerged a couple of minutes later with a small bag of first-aid supplies, pausing to retrieve his still-burning stogie.
Mr. McCallister's brief shopping foray may not loom large in the annals of retailing, but it is typical of the experience of many loyal Walgreen customers, who prize convenience and efficiency. And it helps explain why Walgreen, a 1,552-store chain, is the fastest-growing major company in the $58 billion-a-year drugstore business. 
Today, despite a shaky economy that is being depressed further by higher energy costs because of turmoil in the Middle East, Walgreen is embarking on an ambitious and costly program of expansion. Walgreen, long a household name in the Midwest, is now browsing for sites in the Northeast and Northern California as part of its plan to open 600 new stores over the next five years.
Moreover, Walgreen is betting that it can succeed in new markets at a time when competition is stiffening. Supermarkets increasingly are adding sizable drugstore departments, while so-called ''deep discount'' drugstores that cut prices on basic goods like shampoo and toothpaste by up to 40 percent are proliferating.
''There are a lot of people going after their business,'' said Neil Stern, of McMillan Doolittle, a retail consulting firm in Chicago. ''Walgreen's is really the star in this industry right now.'' At the Walgreen headquarters in Deerfield, a suburb of Chicago, the company's management - a cadre of former druggists and drugstore managers, known for being tightfisted and detail-oriented - hopes to maintain its leading position in the industry, and its growth plan is crucial to continuing its momentum.
The Walgreen strategy is based on investing heavily in new stores and cutting-edge retailing technology in an effort to strengthen its already strong franchise.
Walgreen's does not claim to have the lowest prices on drugstore staples. Instead, the company's executives strive to make sure a Walgreen outlet is the store of choice for the harried shopper on a 30-minute lunch break. In fact, the average Walgreen customer buys two items in well under 10 minutes.
''Nothing is more important to Walgreen's long-term success than convenience,'' declared the company's 1989 annual report.
''That is the cornerstone of their strategy,'' said Mr. Stern, the retail consultant.
So far, Walgreen's strategy is working. Last August, the company announced its 15th straight year of record sales and earnings. For the fiscal year ended on Aug. 31, profits increased nearly 20 percent, to $154 million, and sales were up more than 10 percent, to $5.38 billion. Return on shareholder's equity was more than 20 percent for the year.
Although those attending the company's annual meeting are given a bag of vitamins each year, shareholders are in little need of pepping up. After three stock splits, 100 shares of Walgreen's stock bought in 1979 for $3,050, were worth $37,500 ten years later. Dividends, paid every quarter since 1933, have been increased 14 times in the last 12 years.
The company is conservatively financed. Despite a $200 million capital spending budget for store expansion and remodeling this year, Walgreen is paying for it with funds generated internally, not debt.
The company is also investing heavily in technology to cut expenses and improve efficiency.
Walgreen is in the process of becoming the first major drugstore chain to replace cash registers entirely with scanners, speeding up check-out times and eliminating the need for clerks to price items. The company is also introducing an electronic inventory control system that is expected to allow the company to reduce its inventory expense by $200 million, or 25 percent.
''They seem to be at the forefront of retailing technology,'' said Richard G. Elam, a Chicago-based analyst with Blunt Ellis & Loewi Inc.
The company's most significant high-tech edge in wooing the all-important pharmaceutical customers is its nationwide system of satellite dishes that connects more than 1,000 Walgreen stores.
The network allows pharmacists in stores throughout the country to gain instant access to a customer's prescription records. For customers who are traveling, it means a Walgreen store thousands of miles from home can handle prescriptions as easily as the nearby Walgreen outlet. In fact, the cigar-smoking Mr. McCallister was an out-of-town customer visiting Chicago. ''Walgreen's is the only company in the country that I know of where I can have a prescription on file in Florida and I'm here in Chicago and they'll fill it,'' he said.
Walgreen's has won such customer endorsements by concentrating exclusively on the drugstore business in recent years. Ill-conceived diversification attempts and heavy borrowing crippled Revco D.S. Inc., once a formidable competitor, which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in 1988.
For a while in the 1960's and into the early 70's, Walgreen dabbled with its own diversification strategy, trying at one time or another to sell everything from men's suits to restaurant meals.
Yet the company strayed far less than many of its rivals. And by 1975, Charles R. Walgreen 3d, the current chairman and grandson of the founder, decided it was time to begin selling off the unrelated operations.
In 1988, Walgreen sold its 91 Wag's restaurants to the Marriott Corporation. This summer, the streamlining was completed when Walgreen's sold its private label manufacturing operation to an employee group.
L. Daniel Jorndt, Walgreen's president and chief operating officer, is a believer in the perils of diversification. ''If some Harvard M.B.A. pulls out all the data, he will see that the people that got in trouble in this business didn't get into trouble in the drugstore business,'' Mr. Jorndt said.
Today, Walgreen faces its most formidable competition from nontraditional outlets. Deep discounters, like privately held Phar Mor and the Drug Emporium, both of which offer low prices in cavernous no-frills stores, are siphoning off much of the toothpaste and shampoo business. The discounters, which trim suggested retail prices by up to 40 percent, are forcing the entire industry to accept lower margins.
From another direction, the nation's supermarket chains are pouring onto Walgreen's turf, lured by the higher profits available on health and beauty products compared with groceries. There are now 3,700 stores nationally that combine grocery and drugstore operations under one roof, accounting for 13 percent of retail drug prescription sales.
For his part, Mr. Jorndt says he is most concerned about the threat posed by the supermarket-drugstore combos. For example, there is now more shampoo sold in supermarkets than in drugstores - a significant shift from traditional buying habits - and, in fact, supermarkets have become the main source for nearly every health and beauty aid category.
Hence, Walgreen's strong emphasis on prescription drugs and convenience, both in catering to the customer and in selecting high-traffic store sites.
Walgreen's top management is closely involved in the choice of new locations - and, it seems, just about everything else.
Like many of Walgreen's senior officers, Mr. Jorndt and Mr. Walgreen worked as pharmacists in the stores. It has a top management team that for laughs will quiz each other on such details as, say, the daily sales results of the new store in Tempe.
''Our people thrive on details,'' said Mr. Jorndt, quoting Walgreen's founder, Charles R. Walgreen, who said, ''Success is doing a thousand little things the right way . . . over and over again.''
 
PROFITS IN PRESCRIPTIONS
 
CHICAGO
The Walgreen Company's booming prescription drug business has been a key ingredient in its success. Today, the company accounts for more than 6 percent of all prescription sales in the United States.
''Walgreen's pharmacy business is among the most impressive growth businesses in all of retailing,'' according to a report by Stephen F. Mandel Jr., an analyst at Goldman Sachs.
Indeed, Walgreen's drug sales have grown by an average of 25 percent a year during the last decade. And this year, the company's drug sales are expected to account for nearly $2 billion in revenues, or more than a third of the chain's total sales.
The outlook for Walgreen's retail drug business appears bright, now that America's baby boomers are entering middle age, the time when a person's use of prescription drugs typically rises sharply.
''We are in a segment of retailing that has very good demographics going for it,'' said L. Daniel Jorndt, president and chief operating officer of Walgreen's, noting that prescription usage ''really takes off when you hit 45.''
Not surprisingly, Walgreen tracks demographic statistics with a mercenary eye. Its 1989 annual report gleefully notes the number of people between 45 and 54 years old will increase by 46 percent during the 1990's.
Prescription drug customers tend to find a favorite pharmacy and become loyal, steady patrons. And during the wait to get a prescription filled, customers are likely to pick up a box of Kleenex or a tube of toothpaste. And drug retailing is a recession-resistant business, analysts note.
Still, drug retailers are facing pressure on profits. Behind the squeeze is the increased clout of the medical insurance plans, which now pay for roughly a third of all drug purchases and, by 1995, are expected to represent more than half.
Large health maintenance organizations and other third-party providers are able to negotiate price cuts with the large drugstore chains in exchange for the many customers they provide. Several studies by drugstore trade groups have concluded that much of the third-party prescription business is unprofitable for chains, even when factoring in the additional purchases made by customers. Chains are beginning to reject contracts from HMO's when the terms are too unfavorable.
But analysts are confident that Walgreen can remain the low-cost provider of prescriptions to third-party groups, thus gaining market share even though the profitability of that business will almost surely continue to decline.

LENGTH: 1428 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIARY/August 19-24

BYLINE: By ALLEN R.MYERSON

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
More on the Trump Saga
 
For savings and loan bailouts, the Resolution Trust Corporation must approve. For Trump bailouts, it takes the New Jersey Casino Control Commission. On Tuesday, the commission approved Donald J. Trump's package of $65 million in new bank loans, with casinos as collateral. The Trump Shuttle is no longer for sale. So says Mr. Trump, but his creditors keep pressuring him to sell off property to pay down his debts. Mr. Trump swears that he has had many offers, although the $340 million value he assigns to the shuttle is $40 million to $190 million more than his accountants say it would fetch if he had to sell it in a hurry. The shuttle plans to add charter flights and Atlantic City service, and update its fleet. Mr. Trump said that he wants to provide ''a stable environment for our valued customers.'' Stable, but more expensive, that is, with fares rising $10 effective on Monday. 
 
Southland Fights Back
 
A good idea came too late at the Southland Corporation. A Southland executive in the Pacific Northwest found a sure method of shooing teen-agers away from the company's Hoagy's Corner Delis and 7-Eleven stores: Hit them with Mantovani, pour it on them from loudspeakers outside the stores. Others may call it easy listening, but when the strings swoon, the teens scatter. Southland, remember, narrowly avoided bankruptcy last month. Japan's Ito-Yokado Group took over the chain from its founders, the Thompson family, after a leveraged buyout went awry. Who knows but what, if Southland executives had piped in music their creditors couldn't stand, they might still be in charge today.
 
A Stock for Wartime
 
We all know that Wall Street has ways to cash in on every crisis. Hurricanes? Short insurance stocks. Strife in South Africa? Buy gold. Now comes a chemical warfare play. Survival Technology of Bethesda, Md., makes nerve-gas antidotes. The United States is keeping the company busy around the clock, making filled syringes that could become essential in fending off an Iraqi attack. On Aug. 7, Survival stock stood at $9 1/4. While the broader market has tumbled since then, Survival closed on Friday at $10 1/8.
 
Japan Prepares Arab Aid
 
The United States sends troops, Japan sends yen. At the urging of President Bush, Japan is offering Arab nations aid that could run into the billions of dollars to compensate for lost trade with Iraq and Kuwait. Japan's Constitution precludes direct military involvement. But Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan has reportedly discussed sending medical, transportation and communications experts, and possibly some minesweepers, to the region. His nation relies on the Middle East for more than 70 percent of its oil, more than any other industrialized nation. Japan, searching for a role in the world to match the size of its economy, already provides more foreign aid than the United States. President Bush is said to have asked Mr. Kaifu last week to also help pay for the international forces sent to the Persian Gulf. A recovery on Friday was not nearly enough to make up for sharp losses on the Tokyo stock exchange earlier in the week. The Nikkei index fell to 24,165.76 during the week, from 26,786.72 the week before.
 
Looting an S.&L.
 
A Federal judge on Thursday rejected Charles H. Keating Jr.'s suit to regain control of the failed Lincoln Savings and Loan Association. Lincoln's $2 billion bailout has been one of the most costly so far. ''What has emerged is not a pretty picture,'' said Federal District Judge Stanley Sporkin. Mr. Keating and his associates, he said, had ''abused their positions. Bluntly speaking, their actions amounted to a looting of Lincoln.'' Mr. Keating, who has accused regulators of having a vendetta against him, faces several lawsuits and investigations.
 
In Brief
 
Three former Northwest Airlines pilots were convicted on Monday of flying under the influence of alcohol, the first time professional pilots have been found guilty of the crime.
 
Shares of UAL Inc. closed at $93 1/2 on Friday as analysts said they doubted that employees would be able to finance their $201-a-share buyout bid.
 
The Control Data Corporation can sell six mainframe computers for $32 million to the Soviet Union. The United States Government, relaxing its technology export controls, granted a license on Monday. The computers, the fastest the Soviets have bought, are to be used to evaluate the safety of civilian nuclear power plants.
 
THE ECONOMY
 
Trouble in the U.S.
 
Friday's report on the gross national product removed any doubt that the American economy had been staggering even before Iraq invaded Kuwait. The Commerce Department confirmed its earlier estimate of 1.2 percent growth during the second quarter, down from 1.7 percent the quarter before. The Bush Administration had predicted 2 percent growth for the year. On Friday, a White House spokesman noted that the economy was still growing, but emphasized the need to reduce the budget deficit.
 
Profit Sag Drags Stocks Down
 
No, it's not a blind panic on Wall Street. It's a sane response to prospects of sharply lower profits, say some analysts. The Commerce Department reported on Friday that corporate earnings fell two-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter, even before oil prices took off. Economists say the economy is too weak for companies to pass along their higher energy and labor costs. ''A lot of people thought the trough in profits would be the second quarter,'' said William C. Dudley, senior economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company. ''But now, that is not the bottom.'' Investors had pushed the Dow Jones industrial average to within a fraction of 3,000 earlier this year on the prospect of higher earnings. But the Dow closed at 2,532.92 on Friday, down 111.88 for the week.
 
Oil and Recession
 
Oil rose to the highest prices since the early 1980's last week, causing all but the most optimistic economists to predict a recession. Oil for October delivery rose to $30.91 a barrel, up $2.63 for the week. Joseph Carson, senior economist at Chemical Bank, said he had predicted a mild recession even before the Middle East confrontation. Higher energy prices have caused consumers to fear for their jobs and incomes, he said; a decade ago, oil costs caused most to worry only about inflation. ''There's a totally different mindset,'' he said, which is bound to cause a deeper recession. Stephen S. Roach, senior economist at Morgan Stanley, said oil prices accurately reflect the risks. ''People are hunkering down as we move closer and closer to hostilities,'' he said. ''There is a legitimate fear of the destruction of some oil-producing facilities.'' Mr. Roach said recession is no certainty unless oil goes above $35. But among major Wall Street firms, he added, ''We're the only holdout.''
 
The Fed Holds Fast
 
The Federal Reserve apparently decided last week to hold interest rates steady until the effects of the Mideast crisis become more clear. For the time being, the Fed seems more intent on controlling inflation than stimulating the economy.
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Helping Russia to a Better Shoe
 
The M.A.L. Sales Corporation has reached a tentative agreement to help the Russians make 50 million pairs of shoes over the next decade. First will come canvas-and-leather athletic shoes, then work shoes, with a total wholesale value of about $5 billion. Lined up end to end across the vast tundra, mountain ranges, rivers and steppes of the Soviet Union, they would stretch from Moscow to Vladivostok and most of the way back - and, Moscow hopes, last longer than the footwear the Soviets themselves make.
 
Oil Ripples Through U.S. Markets
 
Exactly a century ago, the superintendent of the Census announced the closing of the American frontier. But the myth o nature's limitless bounty persists, with residents of the arid Southwest insisting on lush lawns and Northeasterners shuttling by jet over short distances that other nations travel more often by train. The last decade began with the disposal of gasoline rationing cards, printed but never used. Last week, to secure its oil supplies in the Middle East, the nation was using ecomonic, diplomatic and military means that no other nation can match. Oil prices soared, stocks and bonds plummeted, as analysts saw war becoming more likely each day. But all its preparations for a battle hav served to emphasize the nation's dependency as much as its might.
