HEADLINE: Twin Spotlights on Parsons of the Dime

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
The directors of the Dime Savings Bank of New York had one final misgiving about naming Richard D. Parsons as its president two years ago: whether, as a former aide to Nelson A. Rockefeller and Gerald R. Ford, he could resist returning to politics. ''You know, we're not going to keep that guy,'' one board member told the chairman. ''How many black Republicans are there?''
Mr. Parsons hesitated to give the board a commitment. Politics had been his passion, and he knew that his success in the business world had been built on his record in government. As an outside lawyer, he had become deeply involved in Dime management, winning the board's admiration. He decided that he wanted to run a company himself, and promised to stay out of politics for at least five years.
Mr. Parsons became the Dime's president in July 1988 and its chief executive on July 1 of this year, the first black to manage a lending institution anywhere near the Dime's size. ''It's a statement by and to corporate America that there are no more areas where African Americans haven't succeeded,'' he says. 
Trying to turn around a savings and loan that lost $92.3 million last year would burden anyone. But Mr. Parsons says that his failure also would disappoint blacks who consider him a model and confirm the prejudices of those who believe that blacks can't succeed in top corporate jobs. ''The fact is, in this society, you are going to be held to a higher level of accountability,'' he said.
Mr. Parsons says that more blacks should strive for business success but he recognizes the obstacles. Blacks remain better represented at the upper reaches of politics and government - a Supreme Court justice, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, the Democratic Party chairman - than in business.
Last month, Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole said she was planning a ''glass ceiling initiative'' to speed the promotion of women and minorities. Companies that do not cooperate, she said, risk having their government contracts canceled.
 
A Stress on Business
Mr. Parsons deflects questions about his political prospects, stressing instead his preoccupation with the Dime. ''I'm not in the business of being a political leader at this time,'' he said. ''I'm in the business of running a financial institution. '' Leading the second-largest savings and loan in New York's stagnant economy, even with a salary of $525,000, is no enviable position. The downturn found the Dime owning a junkyard of ''low-documentation'' loans, made without verifying applicants' jobs, credit ratings or incomes. After last year's loss, investors have driven Dime stock down to a quarter of the institution's net worth.
Some analysts say that at least $100 million more of the Dime's loans will sour by the end of next year. But they say the Dime is likely to be among the battered industry's survivors. It has enough capital to satisfy Government requirements, while Crossland Savings, New York's largest savings and loan, falls well below.
One of Mr. Parsons's first missions at the Dime was cutting costs - reducing the staff from 3,600 to 2,600 and closing all loan offices outside the New York area. At a lunch with middle-level managers, he heard complaints about layoffs so abrupt that employees had no time to discuss severance benefits. ''People are quite upset,'' said one woman. ''They come into work not knowing whether they are going to be there at the end of the day.''
Employees took scant comfort from his mention of ''great deals'' on foreclosed homes. They wanted to know why the stock had been a terrible deal, falling from a 1987 high of 27 to less than 6. ''My father bought some of this stock when it was 16,'' Mr. Parsons responded. ''I told him, 'You have to be patient.' '' Investors, he added, have failed to distinguish the Dime - ''the strongest thrift franchise in New York'' - from its weaker sisters.
Some analysts who have criticized the Dime's performance say that Mr. Parsons is the key to recovery. ''He's the right guy for the job despite his short experience,'' said Peter Treadway of Smith Barney. ''He has a clear understanding of what the dimensions of the problems are.''
 
Setting Strategy
The Parsons strategy is to clean up problem loans, continue cutting costs and capitalize on his broad customer base to sell a raft of new services. Too many customers think of the Dimeas just a place for savings accounts and mortgages, he says. Racks in the Dimes's lobbies are stuffed with brochures on insurance, annuities and investment brokerage. Marketing experts hired from commercial banks scheme for ways to grab more consumer business. Mr. Parsons boasts that, with half a million households having accounts, the Dime is fifth in New York behind Citicorp, Chemical, Chase Manhattan and Manufacturers Hanover. ''We have to reposition ourselves, with our customers first, then with our noncustomers,'' he said, sounding much like a commercial. ''The Dime is one-stop banking.''
But Mr. Parsons grants that if the New York real estate market continues to suffer, so will the Dime. The Dime's strategy, said Jonathan E. Gray, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, is ''largely defensive, because it must be.''
Mr. Parsons faces high expectations outside of his job as well. Charities, civic causes and company boards always try to recruit corporate chiefs, but as a black Republican, he has special allure. He is on the boards of Howard University, the New York Zoological Society and Philip Morris Companies Inc. He is a member of the President's Drug Task Force and chairman of the Wildcat Service Corporation, which provides on-the-job instruction for those whose past crimes, drug addiction or poverty might otherwise make them unemployable. ''I don't fool myself that all these opportunities to participate come to me just because I'm a great American,'' he said. ''People in this society are always looking for minorities to be involved.''
Black business people debate just what their responsibilities should be. Andrew F. Brimmer, the first black member of the Federal Reserve Board and now a consultant, resents the obligations heaped on people like Mr. Parsons: ''He's a businessman. That's what he gets paid for. First, he should be expected to run his institution. Second, he should be expected to run his institution.''
But Wilbert A. Tatum, the editor and publisher of The Amsterdam News, New York's black newspaper, says that someone in Mr. Parsons's position can't avoid extra burdens. ''One has a responsibility simply in being black and successful,'' he said. ''Not only in giving back, but also to prove over and over again to suspecting whites that you didn't get there by candlelight, that you got there by pure unadulterated competence.''
Mr. Parsons agrees, but he has no patience with those who hector him about racial responsibilites. ''I don't feel a need to apologize to anybody for being black, or not being black enough,'' he said. ''There are a lot of people who will come and lecture you on your obligations as a successful black man. I remember once, this person asked me to describe myself. I started saying, 'I'm a lawyer, I'm - ' She said, 'Wrong! See, that's the problem with you, you're a black man, and that's the single most significant factor.' Believe it or not, this was a white liberal.''
Mr. Parsons describes his own political philosophy succinctly. ''I am still a Rockefeller Republican,'' he said, ''fiscally conservative, socially liberal.'' The Rockefeller influence permeates his life. His office, which looks out on Rockefeller Center, is decorated with copies of Rockefeller's paintings and sculpture, gifts after Mr. Parsons helped launch a reproduction project. A favorite lunch spot is the Rockefeller Center Club, the dining room atop Rockefeller Center known as the Rainbow Room at night.
In 1986, the family sold him a home in Pocantico Hills, welcoming him as a neighbor where his grandfather had kept the grounds. ''I owe them,'' Mr. Parsons said of the Rockefellers one evening as the Dime's chauffeur took him to Pocantico Hills. ''I didn't go to the right school. I wasn't from the right side of the tracks. But when I was fortunate enough to hook up with Nelson Rockefeller, that's how I developed my own network.''
Now the Parsons influence is beginning to permeate the Rockefellers. Mr. Parsons sits on the board of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund and is consulting on the reorganization of the family's charities and assets.
 
A Political Touch
In last year's New York mayoral contest, Mr. Parsons campaigned first for Ronald Lauder, a friend and former client, then for the Republican nominee, Rudolf W. Giuliani, a former partner in Mr. Parsons's old law firm. Mr. Parsons left the firm at the urging of Harry W. Albright Jr., another former Rockefeller aide who was then the Dime's chief executive. ''You can give advice, but wouldn't you really like to run something?'' Mr. Albright asked him.
Mr. Parsons found the Dime's record in minority hiring and low-income housing especially attractive. ''This is an institution that is committed to having a work force that mirrors the members of the communities it serves,'' he said. Of 400 officers, more than half are women and 30 percent are racial minorities.
Some customers have noticed that the Dime has a black chief executive. His appointment caused a few to close their accounts - and some others to open them. But some messengers haven't noticed the new boss yet. When Mr. Parsons works at a desk by his secretary's, delivery people tend to assume he is from the mailroom. Mr. Parsons signs for packages, and later laughs. ''Hey, life's too short,'' he said.
Self-reliance is Mr. Parsons's personal and political anthem. He talks about the human tendency to blame misfortunes on life's bad turns - a habit ''not unique to the minority community, but it is more prevalent.'' He tells of how one of his teen-age daughters, legally blind and nearly deaf, will go anywhere, try anything. But another daughter - bright, athletic, ''with all the gifts you could want'' - complains of life's unfairness. ''To her, each perceived iniquity is paralyzing.''
Mr. Parsons elaborated on this message before the Pocantico Hills School eighth-grade graduation class in June. He talked about being cheated out of a ride on the Coney Island Cyclone roller-coaster as a child. If he kept his grades up, his parents had promised, the ride would be his 12th birthday present. He made the grades; then, on his birthday in April, it snowed.
''It just wasn't fair,'' he said. ''Somebody had to do something to make it right. You were owed something. I took my case to my mother and she said, 'Son, life isn't fair.'
''Tip No. 1, graduates. Don't let the fact that life isn't always fair stop you from working hard and giving your all in pursuit of your goals.''
He says life has been eminently fair to him. ''I don't have any experience in my life where someone rejected me for race or any other reason,'' he said. Mr. Parsons says that his wife, Laura, a teacher of the handicapped who is white, is quicker to notice racial slights. ''Richard is not looking for racial discrimination, therefore he doesn't see people's prejudices,'' she said.
Mr. Parsons is a native of Bedford-Stuyvesant, the son of an airline technician who installed and repaired electronic navigation systems. He grew up with few ambitions. At the University of Hawaii, he was a varsity basketball jock and social chairman of his fraternity. But he soon encountered a stabilizing influence, a fellow student named Laura Bush. They married in 1968. ''Left to my own devices, I don't feel any compulsion to strive,'' he said. ''My wife became my focus and the person to whom I owed my best.''
He decided to attend Albany Law School in New York. Even while working part-time as a janitor and later as an aide in the State Assembly, he distinguished himself, finishing first in his class and first among the 3,600 lawyers taking the state bar examination in 1971.
 
The Law Practice
He joined Governor Rockefeller's legal staff. ''Nelson always thought he was one of the most able lawyers he had met,'' said David Rockefeller, the late Governor's brother.
When Nelson Rockefeller became Vice President in 1974, he took Mr. Parsons with him to Washington. Then President Ford borrowed Mr. Parsons to serve as general counsel and associate director of the Domestic Council, where he specialized in drug issues.
When Mr. Rockefeller left office in 1977, Mr. Parsons was invited by Harold R. (Ace) Tyler Jr., the departing Deputy Attorney General and a former Federal judge, to join what became Patterson, Belknap, Webb & Tyler, a large, old New York firm.
Judge Tyler became head of the firm, and Mr. Parsons went from associate to partner and management committee member in four years. He had strong prospects of becoming the first black to lead a major law firm. Mr. Parsons handled sticky matters of reorganization and pay.''You have a lot of people who all think they're God's gift to humanity,'' Judge Tyler said. ''Dick had a talent for sitting people down and explaining what needed to be done.''
Among Mr. Parsons's clients were the Rockefeller Brothers Fund and the Dime. Mr. Albright turned to him more and more for advice. ''He wasn't out there like a potted palm,'' lawyerly and aloof, Mr. Albright said. ''He was really involved.''
Now the Dime is in Mr. Parsons's hands. But his job is not necessarily secure. Some analysts say that the Dime's broad base of customers and low stock price have tempted larger, acquisitive institutions. Even at his most relaxed, over lunch at the Rockefeller Club, it's a matter that causes Mr. Parsons to pause, let out a long breath and say, ''That's a sensitive subject.'' The Dime's stock rose on takeover speculation in 1986, some analysts say, but management has shown little interest in striking a deal.
Given another minute to think about it, Mr. Parsons decides that a takeover at the Dime would not rattle him. ''If it ever changed hands, I could find another job. Oh, I could.''
 
PROBLEMS AT THE DIME
At the Dime, Richard D. Parsons entered a venerable institution, in business since 1859, named after the amount it took to open an account. But heritage hasn't helped the Dime cope with soaring interest rates and shaky loans over the last decade.
As rates demanded by depositors rose rapidly in the early 1980's, the Dime's income from low-interest, fixed-rate home mortgages lagged. The Dime's solution was to open offices around the East, offering adjustable-rate mortgages to almost anyone with a 20 percent downpayment.
The Dime's asset base ballooned from less than $7 billion at the beginning of 1987 to more than $12 billion by the end of 1988. Then came the end of the Northeast's boom. Checks from thousands of homeowners stopped coming. Nonperforming assets - banker talk for loans that are way behind - increased to $754.8 million at the end of the second quarter.
Harry W. Albright Jr., the Dime's chief executive before Mr. Parsons, said he had no choice but to pump out adjustable loans to match the bank's income with the cost of its deposits. ''I am entirely unapologetic,'' he said.
Fortunately, the Dime had in some ways remained conservative. Most of its loans are residential, where the underlying property is far more salable than, say, the half-completed shell of some Dallas office building. Still, bad loans left the Dime with a $92.3 million loss last year.
Mr. Parsons can boast that the Dime's income for the first half of 1990, $30.4 million, was almost twice that of a year earlier. But analysts expect more write-offs. Jonathan E. Gray, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, says that problem loans might rise to more than $850 million by the end of 1991. His warning: ''You could see several years of earnings eliminated.''
 
The World of Black-Led Lenders
Until this July, the largest lenders headed by blacks were less than a 13th the size of the Dime. These are institutions started by blacks, some more than 80 years ago, to provide credit for black homes, churches and small businesses when few white banks would. In their markets, the black-owned lenders had virtual monopolies.
Although studies indicate that some discrimination in mortgage lending persists, many large lenders are courting black business. On 125th Street in Harlem, a black bank and a black savings and loan compete with American Savings Bank, Apple Bank and Chemical, and two branches of Manufacturers Hanover. ''There was a time when, because of segregation, black businesses had a corner on the black market,'' said Edward D. Irons, dean of Clark Atlanta University Business School. ''Increasingly, there are going to be no racial barriers behind which minority financial institutions can hide.''
The challenge for black lenders is all the more serious because of their small size. The largest institution traditionally managed by blacks, the Independence Savings Bank, in Washington, had $253 million in assets at the end of last year - less than 3 percent of the Dime's total.
Black institutions are among the most severely afflicted of savings and loans. The business magazine Black Enterprise found that the number of black savings and loans fell by 27 percent, to 24 from 33, in 1989, while the savings and loans overall declined by about 10 percent. Black-owned banks did better, going to 37 from 35 last year.
Black lenders are at odds over whether to reach into white neighborhoods or expand in black ones. Independence has its headquarters not in a mostly black area, but on Connecticut Avenue in downtown Washington. ''We don't look at ourselves as being a Chinese bank, an Eskimo bank or a Greek bank,'' said William B. Fitzgerald, the president. ''We have a fully intergrated staff, a fully integrated board and fully integrated stockholders.''
The second-largest black lender, with $238 million in assets, has taken the opposite approach. Carver Federal Savings Bank has its main office in Harlem, with most of its six branches concentrated in black neighborhoods like Jamaica and Bedford-Stuyvesant. Its president, Richard T. Greene, sounds like an old-time country banker as he speaks of knowing his community intimately, providing church loans (''We haven't had a foreclosure yet'') and awarding college scholarships. ''We are keeping pace - slowly,'' he said, explaining that he introduced an automated teller machine just last year.
Most other black lenders have remained conservative; their size excluded them from lending to Bolivia, say, or Donald J. Trump. Like Carver, with its perpetually crowded lobby, they depend on the little people. ''That's expensive, but that's our clientele,'' said Mr. Greene. ''We cater to them smilingly.''

HEADLINE: All About/Coal;
Will Coal, the Plentiful Old Standby, Pick Up Speed?

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
All it takes to give coal more luster is a crisis in the Middle East. With the embargo against Iraq and Kuwait cutting off about a fifth of the world's oil supplies, coal demand can only increase. But even before the recent jump in oil prices, the United States coal industry was growing enough in both size and efficiency to make healthy profits. And coal reserves are vast: if the nation derived all of its energy from one domestic source, crude oil would last eight years, coal 100 years. The United States now imports as much oil as it produces, but exports about 10 percent of its coal.
United States coal production this year is likely to exceed one billion tons for the first time, the fourth consecutive annual record. Domestic demand has been growing 2 percent annually - about as fast as the economy, but faster than demand for oil or natural gas. Still, coal prices have remained flat, at about $25 a ton, since the early 1980's because companies have plenty of extra capacity. Industry analysts say prices now depend as much on the economy as on events in the gulf. ''As long as the economy continues to grow, I expect prices to go up this fall and winter, for the first time in a long time,'' said Scott Jones, an energy analyst with AUS Consultants of Philadelphia. 
Until the 1940's, coal was the nation's leading industrial fuel, for everything from railroads to home heating. By the 1960's, trains ran on diesel fuel, but the the electric utilities had emerged as major customers. Utilities now use 77 percent of the nation's coal.
One major threat to the industry comes from pending clean-air legislation. Producers are competing to buy mines and mining rights for cleaner-burning, low-sulfur coal.
Coal is classified by hardness, moisture and the amount of energy it produces. Bituminous, the most common, is a soft coal used by electric companies and steelmakers. The metallurgical coal that steel mills turn into coke is a grade of bituminous that contains fewer impurities and produces less ash.
The hardest coal, anthracite, is almost pure carbon. About four million tons a year are consumed in the United States, mostly for heating. Lignite, the softest coal, accounts for a tenth of domestic production.
 
The Producers
Fighting Pollution, Hoping for Exports
The coal industry is far more fragmented than the nation's oil industry. There are more than 1,000 mining companies, some independent, some subsidiaries of large oil companies that entered the market in the late 1970's.
The largest producer, the Peabody Coal Company, a unit of the Peabody Holding Company, was purchased by Hanson P.L.C. of Britain in June for $1.25 billion. Peabody produced 9 percent, or 86.7 million tons, of the nation's coal in 1989, according to the National Coal Association. Next came the Consolidation Coal Company, owned by E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, with 52.5 million tons, and Amax Coal Industries Inc., with 38.1 million tons.
Peabody has been less profitable than many of its major competitors because its mines are less efficient, analysts say. They expect Peabody's modernization - $129 million for capital improvements last year, up 36 percent over 1988 - to improve profits and shift its production toward low-sulfur coal. Low-sulfur coal, which is less polluting, is deeper in the ground and more expensive to mine than coal with higher sulfur, which can be shoveled from open pits. But new technology has enabled coal companies to get 15 to 20 percent more coal out of underground mines each hour with half the workers. Peabody has bought machines that haul coal from underground mines on conveyor belts rather than by trucks.
Exports of coal in 1989 reached 105 million tons, the third-highest total after a 1981 peak of 112.5 million and more than a tenth of domestic production. How much higher exports go this year depends on oil. ''If the price of oil stays higher than $25 a barrel, I would expect that there would be a moderate increase in demand overseas, as Europe and Japan switch back to coal electricity,'' said Daniel Roling, a coal analyst with Merrill Lynch.
The United States, with 35.1 percent of the world's proven, recoverable coal reserves, would be the main beneficiary of higher demand. The Soviet Union has 26.8 percent, followed by South Africa, with 9.1 percent.
 
The Steel Market
New Technologies Promise Efficiency
The United States steel industry buys 4 percent of the nation's coal. But here and abroad, steel mills have been using less. Last year, demand for metallurgical coal amounted to 38 million tons, down from 67 million tons in 1980. Economists predict that environmental legislation and lower steel production will cut the nation's production of metallurgical coal by an additional 4 million to 5 million tons by the end of the decade.
The world's steel companies are working on ways to produce steel with much less coal and less air pollution. Steelmaking is now very energy-intensive. Coal is heated in a tall, narrow oven sealed to keep out oxygen. The heating drives out chemical byproducts, primarily benzene, and produces red-hot coke, nearly all carbon, that burns more efficiently and at a far higher temperature than coal. Pollution comes from gases - primarily benzene and ammonia - that escape during the coke-making process.
The American Iron and Steel Institute, a trade association, is working on so-called direct steelmaking, which requires no coke and less coal, or in some cases none. Some methods burn coal instead of coke, while others rely on electricity. European and Japanese steelmakers also are working on these technologies. ''Over the next 5 to 10 years, steelmakers will need far less coal than they do now,'' said John Jacobson, an analyst with AUS Consultants of Philadelphia.
 
The Unions
Still Wedded to The Wildcat Strike
The coal industry continues to have some of the nation's most bitter, violent strikes. A 10-month strike by 1,600 members of the United Mine Workers against the Pittston Corporation that ended in February touched off wildcat strikes involving 27,000 other miners. More than 3,000 miners were arrested. Pittston, which is based in Greenwich, Conn., had insisted that reduced employee benefits and more flexible work schedules were necessary to survive in an increasingly competitive industry. Members of the United Mine Workers complained that they had been without a contract since February 1988 and said the company's demands would destroy the union and its gains from earlier strikes.
Sympathy strikes cost other coal companies hundreds of thousands of dollars a day. To some, the strike signaled new militancy in a union that once could cripple the nation's coal producers and many other industries. Pittston's new four-year contract provided raises of about $1.20 an hour over three years, to a minimum of $15.12, and full coverage of medical expenses for employees, pensioners and families. In return, Pittston won the right to schedule 24-hour production.
Since the Pittston strike, labor relations have calmed down, with no further strikes. ''This is similar to the thawing out in a turbulent period in a marriage,'' said William H. Miernyk, professor emeritus at West Virginia University School of Business. ''Both sides realize that after the fight you have to live together.''
 
SCRUBBERS AND OTHER DEVICES
Scrubbers have been the power industry's usual answer to pollution from coal. They are small chemical plants, attached to power plants, that reduce sulfur emissions from the burning of coal. The scrubbers include electrically charged filters that trap pollutants. But since the scrubbers cost an average of $100 million, with a 5 percent loss in generating capacity, the search is on for pollution control methods that don't scrub profits as well.
The pressure to adopt new methods is likely to increase with the passage of tougher air-pollution restrictions now before Congress. Better ways of controlling emissions would also allow power plants to use less expensive higher-sulfur coal. Sulfur emissions from the burning of coal create sulfur dioxide, which causes breathing problems and contributes to acid rain. The Government has already committed $1.3 billion in matching funds to 38 clean-coal projects, and industry experts expect Government outlays to reach $2.5 billion by the end of 1992.
The most widely tested alternative to scrubbers costs little more than a few tons of limestone. Fluidized bed combustion, as it is called, requires the limestone to be injected into the boilers where coal is being burned. The limestone acts as a chemical sponge, absorbing nearly all of the sulfur emissions.
But only a few utilities, among them American Electric Power Service of Columbus, Ohio, and the Tennessee Valley Authority, have tested this technique, and only at low levels of power production.
''It is still a technology that is seen as being risky,'' said Robert C. Porter, a spokesman with the Department of Energy. ''The technology has not yet been widely tested on the scale utilities are accustomed to.''
Another promising technology converts coal into synthetic gas. Coal particles are broken down, then burned in a gas turbine. When the coal is converted to gas, processes widely used by chemical manufacturers can remove nearly 99 percent of the sulfur. This method, too, is only experimental, Mr. Porter said, with tests at only two plants.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: August 26, 1990

SECTION: Section 3; Page 27, Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 944 words

HEADLINE: Managing;
Teamwork or Tug of War?

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
Add team dynamics to the lengthening list of strains to come out of the tumultuous 1980's.
As companies try to speed products from concept to market, they are asking engineering, manufacturing, design and other departments that used to indulge in parallel play to work together. That means that managers are being asked to form cohesive groups out of people who don't know the boss or each other, and who often come from different cultures within their companies.
Increasingly, those managers are coming a cropper. For example:
* When Michael H. Sternett became the Eaton Corporation's Chicago area sales manager, he gave his people fairly innocuous orders, like go make 15 sales calls a week, and do not travel in pairs. Within months, his staff complained to his boss. ''They said I was unfocused, and that I had taken the fun out of the job,'' Mr. Sternett said. 
* Everyone at the American Telephone and Telegraph Corporation seemed to agree with the concept of making one group responsible for ordering materials, scheduling work, designing information systems - in general, for keeping the factories humming. Yet the newly formed group was frought with tension. ''Some of the people believed in centralization, some in decentralization. They didn't trust each other, and they certainly didn't trust me,'' said Laurence C. Seifert, the officer who headed the group.
* The Chase Manhattan Bank thought it had the perfect new-products team when it combined a production group and a sales group. The team members were quality conscious and motivated, and the team's new manager was outgoing and helpful. Yet within six months, the team was behind schedule on its goals, and hostility was palpable. ''The new manager did not understand that sales types and production types see things through different lenses,'' said Marie Eiter, vice president of executive development.
Such stories do not surprise management consultants. ''More new managers fail because they cannot turn the staff they inherited into a productive team than because of lack of talent or knowledge,'' said Frank Petrock, president of the General Systems Consulting Group in Ann Arbor, Mich.
There's a lot of research to back that up. John J. Gabarro, a professor of organizational behavior at the Harvard Business School, spent four years studying what differentiated successful management transitions from failures. His conclusion: ''Many of the executives who failed had not considered building a team to be high priority.'' Conversely, the Hewlett-Packard Company studied about 150 of its most successful managers, and found that each was very good at building teams.
Thus, many companies are trying to help executives solve team-building glitches. In the process, they are discovering that seemingly major problems have easy fixes.
For example, after his boss persuaded him to hold a series of air-clearing meetings with his sales staff, Mr. Sternett learned that he needed to establish clear objectives for the group as a whole. He set an office-wide sales goal, and switched from individual commissions to paying salespeople on the basis of how the whole office performed. ''It forced the senior people to make sure that the less experienced people got help,'' Mr. Sternett said. Within a year, the office was meeting its quotas - for the first time in a decade.
At CHASE, Ms. Eiter got the new manager and his warring staff to take ''management inventories'' - pen-and-paper tests used to help managers understand their own styles and orientations - and to discuss their different characteristics and attitudes. Ms. Eiter reports that, armed with this new understanding, they are functioning better as a team.
She now routinely administers the tests to groups going through a management change, and uses the results as fodder for half-day team-building sessions with the groups and their new manager. ''It helps new managers understand why some individuals always seem to fight the current,'' she said.
Sometimes, an outsider finds it easier to spot what is preventing a team from functioning. Frank Petrock, the consultant, interviewed many of Mr. Seifert's subordinates at A.T.& T. He picked up on fears that Mr. Seifert would brook no philosophical differences about decentralization and would be too much of a hands-on manager.
At Mr. Petrock's prodding, Mr. Seifert committed himself to delegating authority, and specified the criteria he would use for promoting people. That helped his subordinates trust him. To help them trust each other, he instituted twice-monthly meetings.
By the time Mr. Seifert moved on to another position last year, the group had cut back to monthly meetings. ''Everyone had grown comfortable with the idea of telling everyone else what they were doing on an informal basis,'' he said.
 
A MODEL FOR TEAM-BUILDING
The Hewlett-Packard Company has codified the steps a new manager must go through to build a successful team. Barbara Baill, management development manager, describes them, using her own job as a source of examples. Establish why the team exists. ''My purpose is to educate managers.''
Build a vision, set values. ''My vision is to build the world's most effective group of managers, and we will stress such values as being honest with each other.''
Create shared plans. ''I will make sure that people who work with senior management and those who train new managers are aiming at the same goals.''
Lead the action. ''I measure people by milestones, ask where they need help and reward them for good work.'' Evaluate results and processes. ''I am constantly checking to see if this model needs to be revised.''

HEADLINE: A California Pension Fund Cuts the New York Umbilical Cord

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
How many people does it take to invest $17 billion? Just one manager and two part-time traders if you are the California Public Employees' Retirement System.
DeWitt F. Bowman, the chief investment officer of Calpers, who is in charge of the fund's total stock and bond portfolio of $58 billion, showed off his organization's state-of-the-art trading operation at a recent industry conference - courtesy of a live, satellite hook-up.
The audience of about 80 people - including public pension fund managers representing about $550 billion in investments - watched the Sacramento-based traders, crammed into a room no bigger than a kitchen, monitoring their gargantuan stock portfolio on 10 color-splashed computer terminals.
The space-age trading system makes it easier for Calpers to manage most of its stock investing internally, without the aid of highly paid outside money managers, Mr. Bowman said. It also minimizes the fund's dependence on Wall Street brokers. Independent studies show that Calpers pays about 50 percent less in commissions on its internally managed funds than do similar large funds. 
''They are the cutting edge,'' said Bob Toigo, president of the Institute for Fiduciary Education, which sponsored the seminar. ''There may be somebody else out there, but in asking other people in the industry, Calpers has one of the most up-to-date back-office trading systems around.''
With a set-up like Calpers's, it is no wonder that Wall Street is feeling uneasy breezes. As the availability and ease of computer-based trading spreads, Wall Street's commission-based revenue, once the mainstay of the industry, is likely to come under even more pressure than it already has.
Competition among the brokerage firms has already driven down commissions, which accounted for 50 percent of the revenues of Wall Street firms 15 years ago, when they were more than 20 cents per share. Today, they comprise just 17 percent of those firms' revenues, and range from 5 to 7 cents a share.
Michael L. Goldstein, who analyzes Wall Street companies for Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, called computer-based trading ''a negative in a business that already has a lot of negatives.'' He estimated that such trading would be economical for any fund that manages $10 billion or more, and some already 34 do.
Officials of Calpers said the cost of installing their new trading system lay essentially with the software, since they already had the staff and personal computers in house. They declined, however, to give figures on that cost, or on maintenance and other factors.
Not many years ago, Calpers, with its limited staff and budget, relied heavily on outside money managers to invest its funds, which represent the retirement future of 800,000 firemen, policemen and other state and local employees. Calpers paid a typical money-management fee for that service - perhaps one-quarter of 1 percent of the total amount being managed. Those fees helped cover the commissions that the money managers, in turn, paid to the Wall Street brokers who facilitated its orders to buy or sell stock.
However, thanks in part to software designed by San Francisco-based Vestek Systems Inc., Calpers since the end of last year has managed 77 percent of its $22 billion portfolio of United States equities using nothing more powerful than several personal computers.
Carl C. Wilberg, who, as principal investment officer, manages the $17 billion in equities no longer hires scores of research analysts to scrutinize corporate profits and spot promising opportunities. Instead, he and his pair of part-time traders seek to create a stock portfolio that exactly replicates the composition of the Standard & Poor's 500, minus the stocks of companies that invest in South Africa, which Calpers is prohibited by state law from buying.
As long as Calpers does as well as the stock market as a whole, which it can insure by buying a near-replica of the S.&P. 500, Mr. Wilberg and Mr. Bowman are happy.
Since installing its new stock-index-based system, Calpers's internally managed portfolio has matched or slightly exceeded its target, the South Africa-free S.&P. 500. And it has outperformed the external money managers it has hired. That is not particularly surprising since about 75 percent of all money managers consistently underperform the market as a whole.
While Calpers's indexed trading system has saved it substantial money-management fees, it has also enabled it to cut back sharply on the commissions it pays to Wall Street brokers.
Previously, if Calpers wanted to buy or sell stocks for its internally managed portfolio, its investment officers would type up the list of its trade requests and transmit that list to a broker who would not necessarily have a ''natural'' buyer or seller standing by. The broker might then have to do a lot of legwork to find sellers of certain stocks that Calpers wanted to buy, increasing the likelihood that the firm would not get the most attractive price. Or, if it could not find buyers for certain stocks, the firm might have to assume the stock position itself, adding it to its own inventory.
Of course, Wall Street charges for those services, particularly when it is required to use its own capital to accommodate a customer's needs.
Today, Calpers' computer-aided trading system gives it several options that allow it to limit brokers' involvement, and fees.
First, Calpers's computer software automatically generates a list of stocks that must be bought or sold for it to remain synchronized with the South Africa-free S.& P. 500. The trader then checks that list against a centralized listing service that brokers, who already have ''natural'' buyers and sellers interested in trading certain stocks, use to communicate with some of their most important customers.
If a broker has sent Calpers an electronic message indicating that it has a buyer for 3,000 shares of the General Motors Corporation, for example, and Calpers's software program indicates that it needs to sell 3,000 G.M. shares immediately, the trading system will indicate that the deal should be done, provided the price is the most competitive one it has received.
A Calpers trader will then send an electronic message to the broker asking that the trade be executed. (Calpers cannot execute the trade itself because securities laws require that all trades of publicly listed securities be displayed on a national market tape, to which only members of the exchange have access.) By trading with a buyer who already has an interested customer and by limiting the amount of work the broker actually must do, Calpers has bought and sold stock at more competitive prices.
''We're now saying we want a lot of the discretion taken away from the broker,'' Mr. Bowman explained.
And Calpers can reduce that commission even further. Its new trading system is also capable of generating and then sending a lengthy list of buy and sell orders instantly to the floor of the New York Stock Exchange via the exchange's electronic-delivery system, called SuperDOT. When it places orders using that method, Calpers pays only 2 cents a share to the brokers who execute the trade.
While other large customers may also have SuperDOT machines in their trading rooms, courtesy of their brokers, they cannot - without sophisticated software - trade long lists of stocks quickly and efficiently.
And Calpers has still another option. Because it has become such a large player in the markets, it can trade directly with other large institutions. Mr. Bowman says that Calpers has done such direct trading with organizations like Alliance Capital, International Business Machines and Wells Fargo. And in such instances, Calpers pays a brokerage commission of just half-a-cent a share.
With all of these options, Calpers has been able to reduce its commission costs on its internally managed funds to an average of 3.8 cents a share, compared with the 6.5 cents a share that it pays for stocks handled by outside money managers. And when an institution trades $9 billion worth of stock, as Calpers did last year, a few cents a share can make quite a difference.
 
DOING DEALS DIRECTLY
 
LOS ANGELES
Although computerized stock trading rules the day at the California Public Employees' Retirement System, there is still room for an innovation that relies on nothing more than old-fashioned personal contacts. At least several times a quarter, a Calpers trader will pick up the telephone and call an official at one of a dozen or so other pension funds and work out a direct, private stock transaction.
''If we have a list of securities we want to trade, we'll call our opposite numbers and see if they're interested in working something out,'' said DeWitt F. Bowman, the chief investment officer of Calpers. ''It's carried out person-to-person.'' This direct trading phenomenon, which Calpers has been involved in for about a year, is a throwback to Wall Street's earliest days, when traders conducted their business without need of intermediary brokers. It is also another example of how large pension funds are no longer satisfied with being passive investors. Just as fund managers are demanding that corporate boards of directors be more accountable to big shareholders, they also are recognizing they can operate more efficiently - and profitably - by taking a more active role in stock trading.
So far, Mr. Bowman said, only a small number of pension funds and other investors are involved in this informal direct-trading circuit. And they are active, typically, only when they have a large list of trades to make at once and when the odds seem strong of finding a suitable trading partner.
''But I think it's an activity that will grow,'' he added, ''as institutions become larger and tend to trade more in blocks, and as indexing becomes more popular.''
A chief advantage of these direct trades is that - like computer-based trading - they save on commissions. To comply with securities law, the trades are run through a brokerage house - but for a fee of only about a half-cent per share, compared with the 6 cents or so paid by the average institutional investor. (The use of the brokerage means the transactions become part of the permanent, public trading record.) But parties involved say an even bigger advantage of this direct trading is that transactions can be completed at the best prices possible.
When large buyers and sellers of securities, like pension funds, wade into the marketplace separately, their trades can cause big ripples in the price of stocks. But trading directly, the pension funds' activities, conducted outside of the market, can be carried out at one firm price.
''This defines the essence of trading: the direct negotiations of transactions between interested counterparties,'' said Donald L. Luskin, executive vice president at Wells Fargo Nikko Investment Advisors, a large index fund manager based in San Francisco.
Not wanting to be frozen out of this growing market, several brokerage houses have started to address the ''Rolodex market,'' as it is sometimes called, pitching ideas for new services, said Hilda Applbaum, an investment officer with Calpers.
Already on the market is a system called Posit, offered by Jefferies & Company, the Los Angeles-based brokerage. Posit has about 200 pension fund subscribers, including Calpers, which list their transaction desires anonymously on an electronic bulletin board.
Despite its use of Posit, Calpers says it prefers to go its own way.
''The whole reason for doing this is the informality of it, and the fact that you don't have another party in the middle,'' said Ms. Applebaum.
MICHAEL LEV

HEADLINE: Technology;
As Oil Prices Rise, the Hydrogen Car Is Looking Better

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
On the surface, the hydrogen-powered car looks as if it were made by a malevolent Rube Goldberg.
It backfires like the cars in the old comic movies. Its engine knocks incessantly. Its fuel tanks are huge and unwieldy, yet it still can't go more than 100 miles, tops, before it needs refueling. And it costs a fortune to run. 
But no one is ready to dismiss the hydrogen car quite yet. In fact, now that Saddam Hussein's march on Kuwait has raised the specter of gasoline shortages and skyrocketing gasoline prices, hydrogen's status as one of the most abundant elements on earth is adding to its luster as a motor fuel.
''The fact that hydrogen can be produced domestically is certainly in its favor,'' said Joan M. Ogden, a physicist at Princeton University. Added Stephen K. Lowe, chief of public affairs at Siemens Solar Industries, ''Another 40 days of war in the Middle East and people may not be talking about fuels just in terms of cost-effectiveness.''
Even before the Iraqi invasion, there was good reason to push for hydrogen-fueled cars. Hydrogen burns squeaky clean, spewing forth little else but water vapor and non-troublesome amounts of nitrogen oxides. ''The payoff in improved environmental quality is so high that hydrogen cars merit more research,'' said Susan J. Hedman, director of policy research at the University of Maryland's Center for Global Change.
Actually, in the early to mid-1970's, most car companies in the United States and abroad experimented heavily with hydrogen-powered cars. They all ran up against the same obstacles: It took more energy to get the hydrogen than the hydrogen itself provided. The processes for deriving that energy were polluting. And no one could figure out how to put enough gaseous or liquid hydrogen into a car to give it a decent cruising range.
According to A. John Appleby, director of Texas A. & M. University's Center for Electrochemical Systems and Hydrogen Research, a cylinder containing the energy equivalent of a gallon of gasoline in compressed hydrogen would weigh between 65 and 200 pounds. To say that it's better than electric - it would take a one-ton lead acid battery to give an electric vehicle the same energy as a gallon of gas - is faint praise.
Liquid hydrogen gives three times as much energy as gasoline by weight, but takes up about three times as much space. And it must be stored at 423 degrees below zero or it will boil away.
These problems have certainly dampened domestic ardor for hydrogen fuels. The Department of Energy spends only about $2.4 million a year on hydrogen research. Detroit, too, is concentrating on other alternative fuels like methanol or reformulated gasoline.
''Hydrogen will just not be available at cost and volume that is appropriate for motor transportation for 20 or 30 years,'' said Nicholas Gallopoulos, who heads the General Motors Corporation's engine research department. The Ford Motor Company is ''looking at it, sure, but it is not on the front burner,'' said Donald R. Buist, director of Ford's automotive emissions and fuel economy office, who guesses that gasoline would have to hit $4 a gallon before hydrogen came close to being cost competitive.
It is in Europe, where gasoline prices already are high, that research into hydrogen cars is proceeding apace.
BMW, for one, has an experimental sedan with a modified 3.5 liter, six-cylinder engine that converts hydrogen liquid to gas in a heat exchanger when the engine is running. Many experts say BMW's research could lead to liquid-hydrogen-powered trucks and buses.
Daimler-Benz has concentrated on hydrides, metal alloys like titanium iron and magnesium nickel that, when powdered, can absorb huge quantities of hydrogen. Heat from the exhaust or cooling system can free the hydrogen and send it to the engine.
Over the last decade Daimler has tested two hydrogen systems. One used hydrogen alone in a 2.3 liter, four-cylinder engine, fitted with a hydrogen distributor instead of a carburetor and a system that injects water to prevent backfiring and to reduce production of oxides of nitrogen.
The second combined gasoline and hydrogen for use in station wagons with fuel-injected, six-cylinder engines. The engine got only hydrogen when the car idled and only gasoline at cruising speeds.
The tests, which were funded by the West German Government, proved that ''the operation of vehicles with hydrogen is possible and controllable,'' said Dr. Hans-Ulrich Hoss, Daimler's head of hydrogen research. He said Daimler has a project scheduled for next year to develop a hydrogen-powered bus with improved storage technology.
Both BMW and Daimler report that hydrogen's reputation as a dangerous fuel is overblown. Unlike gasoline, it has no toxic fumes, and the famous pictures of the Hindenburg blowing up notwithstanding, it is no more explosive than natural gas.
Moreover, it is easy to prevent it from accumulating to explosive densities. Hydrogen molecules are tiny enough to leak through minute cracks in storage containers but are so light they quickly float away. And it is fairly easy to mount hydrogen storage tanks on rear axles or other crash-insulated parts of the car, and to equip cars with electronic sensors that open vents or windows to let out any leaking hydrogen.
The real sticking point is finding economical sources for hydrogen. Here, too, strides are being made. The European Community and Canada are testing the feasibility of using surplus hydroelectric power from rivers in Quebec to produce hydrogen. One of the game plans is to transport the hydrogen by ship to Hamburg, West Germany, where it would be used to run some 150 buses.
In the United States, many researchers are hoping that breakthroughs in nuclear fusion or in solar energy will provide economical ways to fuel electrolysis, the process of making hydrogen by passing an electric current through water to split it into hydrogen and oxygen. In fact, there already have been great improvements in thin-film silicon solar cells, manufactured from silicon derived from sand and capable of cheaply converting sunlight into electricity.
Some researchers suspect that solar hydrogen produced in the American Southwest would be roughly competitive with synthetic fossil fuels by the turn of the century. Mr. Lowe of Siemens could see photovoltaic cells fueling electrolysis near the sea, with the resulting hydrogen shipped to desert areas that would welcome it for its energy value and for the water it would yield.
While everyone still argues about hydrogen in cars, it is already being used in planes, where volume of fuel is not nearly as important as weight. The Russians have developed an airplane that flies on liquefied hydrogen. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration, meanwhile, is studying whether slush hydrogen, a hydrogen slurry that takes up less space than liquid hydrogen, is a good idea for the space shuttle.
The Shuttle already uses hydrogen fuel cells, battery-like devices that, in Dr. Appleby's view, represent the best scenario for using hydrogen in cars.
''Instantly rechargeable electric vehicles equipped with lightweight hydrogen fuel cells would have three times the fuel efficiency of the internal combustion engine under urban conditions,'' he said. ''This is where the future should go.''

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Protecting Creativity in a Global Market

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER J. STEFFEN; Christopher J. Steffen is vice president and chief financial officer at Honeywell Inc.

 BODY:
As this nation ponders its place in world markets, it is increasingly clear that the protection of intellectual property and the upholding of American patent laws are inexorably intertwined with competitiveness.
This view is not based on protectionist sentiments, but on the realities of international trade and patent law: many of the inventions thought to be protected by American patent laws have found their way into foreign products. Eventually they are exported for sale in the United States, with no payment to the inventor. According to International Trade Commission estimates, American companies lose $40 billion to $60 billion annually as a result of inadequate intellectual property protection from foreign manufacturers. 
One unfortunate impediment to the protection of intellectual property rights is the gridlock that has overtaken America's courts. Some foreign companies have successfully exploited it to their advantage. Their strategy has been clear and simple: forgo licensing agreements and sell a product. By the time the court addresses the issue, the patent will probably have expired.
It was only after 25 years of litigation that Texas Instruments Inc. won the payment of extensive royalties from nine foreign companies for a patent covering integrated circuit technology - which is used in basic consumer products like pocket calculators and digital wristwatches. Recently, Honeywell Inc. was more fortunate than many other companies fighting for their intellectual property rights. It was granted a one-year acceleration by the United States District Court in New Jersey in the trial date for a patent-infringement lawsuit against the Minolta Camera Company of Japan.
Positive steps are being taken. In 1988, Congress amended Section 337 of the Tariff Act of 1930. Section 337 provides for a halt in the importing of products that violate American patent law if a company has made either a substantial investment in the development of a technology, or significant effort to license it. The 1988 amendment modified the prior requirement that a company also had to manufacture the product.
Inventiveness, creativity and risk-taking must be nurtured and rewarded in the global marketplace. American business has been the world leader in technological advancement precisely because the United States economy rewards successes and provides incentives to take risks and invest in the development of new and emerging technologies. The same rules must now be made to apply in the global marketplace. To achieve this the General Agreement on Trade and Tariffs must reach an agreement on a strong intellectual property package that provides for timely and effective resolution of patent-law violations.

HEADLINE: Currency;
Pressure on the Dollar

 BODY:
Another week and another milestone for the dollar. First, the dollar set a new low against the German mark on Aug. 14. Then, last Thursday, it fell to a low against the Swiss franc, 1.2560, and set another low aganst the mark, 1.5444. At the same time, the weary dollar fell further against the three popular high-yield currencies that are backed by high interest rates and are also net energy exporters, making them less vulnerable to the Persian Gulf crisis. On Thursday, the pound jumped three cents to $1.9555; the Australian dollar rose to 83.52 cents. And the dollar fell to a 12-year low against the Canadian dollar of 1.1293. The dollar got a little lift from tension in the Middle East on Friday, as the Iraqis surrounded foreign embassies in Kuwait City.

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
Shareholders Get a Say on Salary

BYLINE: By Diana B. Henriques

 BODY:
How much is good corporate management worth? A great deal, no doubt, when markets are in upheaval and economic prospects grow cloudier every day; even in sunny times, nobody expects corporate executives to toil for free.
But an odd chain of events at the Emerson Radio Corporation, the $100 million consumer electronics company based in North Bergen, N.J., is giving that company's shareholders a chance to offer their opinion on the question at their annual meeting, which is scheduled for Sept. 24 in New York. Specifically, shareholders are being asked to ratify last year's $5.3 million buyout of the deferred pay claims of five top executives.
If the independent shareholders do endorse the deal, the executives will give $1.6 million back to the company in the form of future salary cuts; if shareholders balk, the executives will repay the money with interest and retrieve their original rights to deferred pay. Given the amount of money the corporate leaders have collected during a year in which both the company's share price and its financial health have deteriorated sharply, the shareholder debate could well be a lively one. 
The drama that has led to the pending shareholder vote began last summer, at a meeting of the company's six-member board of directors. It consists of William W. Lane, the chairman, and his brother, Stephen L. Lane, president; Donald Dvorkin, vice chairman and executive vice president; Jay M. Haft, a New York lawyer who is also a paid consultant to the corporation; Walter F. Mondale, former United States Vice President and now a lawyer in private practice; and Lyle Gramley, chief economist of the Mortgage Bankers Asociation and a former Federal Reserve Board governor.
On July 29, 1989, these directors approved a plan whereby the company's top executives, including the Lane brothers and Mr. Dvorkin, would give up certain deferred compensation rights in exchange for a single lump-sum payment totaling $5.3 million. Also sharing in the buyout plan were Harold Falik, executive vice president for finance, and Kunio Takei, executive vice president for foreign operations. As a result, the Lane brothers each collected $1.27 million; Mr. Falik got just over $1 million; Mr. Dvorkin got $926,200, and Mr. Takei got $814,00.
The plan, the 1990 proxy statement explained, was deemed ''fair and reasonable under the circumstances.'' The board believed that the company's share price, then about $5.50, would soon increase. That would boost the amount of deferred pay each executive could claim upon termination.
Further reflecting their belief that Emerson's stock was a bargain last year, the directors voted to repurchase $4.5 million worth of the company's shares and redeemed certain executive stock options at prices that ranged from $5.50 to $6.63 a share. The redemptions cost another $6.9 million, of which $5.9 million went to the Lanes, Mr. Dvorkin, Mr. Falik and Mr. Takei.
These same executives also got healthy increases in their base salaries and bonuses. In the 1990 fiscal year, which ended March 31, the Lanes each got just over $1 million, up 20 percent over the prior year. After heftier raises, Mr. Dvorkin's base package was $955,769, Mr. Falik's was $942,308 and Mr. Takei's was $835,000.
Unfortunately, the directors were wrong about the company's prospects. Unsold products piled up in warehouses, margins collapsed, and 1990 profits were scarcely ahead of those for 1989. The stock price has fallen to $3 a share, more than 50 percent below last September's level.
As its business worsened, Emerson experienced a sharp decline in its current ratio, a benchmark financial measurement. At the end of fiscal 1989, it had $2.40 in current assets for each dollar of current liabilities; by last March, it had just $1.60. That put the company in default of the terms of a $33 million note issue, which required a current ratio of at least $1.80 to 1.
Mr. Falik, the company's chief financial officer, said the noteholders have waived their right to immediate repayment until Sept. 30, a week after the annual meeting. By then, he said, the company will have either improved its current ratio, or ''we'll negotiate with the noteholders themselves'' to revise the note terms.
Aside from these financial problems, the company and its top executives are still battling with a shareholder group that has filed a lawsuit charging that executives misled investors about the company's prospects in late 1986 and early 1987 and took advantage of the resulting short-lived rally to unload their own shares. The executives have denied the charges. A second shareholder suit filed last fall complains that the company's 1989 proxy statement did not fully disclose the executives' legal troubles before seeking approval of the stock-option redemptions, a charge the company also denies.
In any case, in June, the board's audit committee - Mr. Mondale, Mr. Gramley and Mr. Haft - began to have second thoughts. The committee decided that the deferred-pay buyout should be submitted to shareholders, and met with the affected executives to negotiate the compromise that will be voted on next month. The audit panel also won approval for the creation of a compensation committee to review such issues in the future.
Bruce Coleman, the attorney with Coleman & Rhine in New York who represents shareholders in both lawsuits, is not mollified. ''If I were an Emerson shareholder, I would be outraged,'' Mr. Coleman said. ''What the situation really needs is a stiff dose of regulatory intervention, and soon.''
As a spokesman for the company, Mr. Falik sees it differently. He said the compromise negotiated with the audit committee is beneficial for Emerson shareholders because it will eliminate the deferred-pay liabilities on the company's books. He and his fellow executives have accepted the deal, he said, because ''we are shareholders, too; our main concern is the company.''

HEADLINE: FORUM;
U.S. Takes Back Seat in Third World

BYLINE: By VICTOR H. PALMIERI; Victor H. Palmieri, chairman of the Overseas Development Council in Washington, was a former Ambassador at Large and coordinator of refugee affairs.

 BODY:
The United States and Japan have already traded places in the global financial hierarchy. Long the world's greatest exporter of capital, the United States over the past decade has become a capital importer on a gigantic scale to finance its chronic deficits. Japan's economic surge has made it the world's pre-eminent international creditor.
Now the same shift has taken place in the arena of third world development assistance. In 1988, Japan pledged to double its aid to $50 billion over the five-year period ending in 1992. In 1989 Japan became the world's largest aid donor in absolute terms. Moreover, Japan's program transferred 0.032 percent of its national wealth to the third world, more than twice the share of the United States. The growth of Japan's aid program will gradually but surely erode American influence in the developing countries. It will also erode the image of the United States as a leader in promoting development as a basis for peace, prosperity and political stability. 
At least as important as aid levels is the the use of aid. The American program has always been driven more by security concerns than by economic development or commercial objectives. Over 60 percent of America's $14.5 billion annual aid budget is targeted on security objectives. The current crisis in the Persian Gulf is likely to intensify this policy focus. By contrast, Japan's priorities have been the reverse. In addition, about 40 percent of America's declining bilateral assistance budget continues to go to Egypt and Israel, with the remainder divided among the rest of the world to promote democracy, stimulate growth and alleviate poverty.
There are already consequences from Japan's growing influence in the governance of the international financial institutions - the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund and the multilateral development banks. Until recently, the United States has been a persistent advocate of what is called ''enlarged burden sharing'' by Japan, which means increased contributions to these organizations. But the United States has also been an equally persistent opponent of greater power sharing with Japan in the governance of these institutions. This policy is now giving way to an acceptance by the United States of Japan's entitlement to more voting power based on its level of capital contributions. As a result, it should not be surprising to see a Japanese as the next president of the World Bank, a position held by Americans since the bank's inception after World War II.
Until recently, Japan seemed willing to accept a subordinate role to the United States in part because of its traditional postwar acceptance of the United States as its mentor in global foreign policy. But, Japan's willingness to accept this ''junior partner'' status is now eroding.
Japan's leadership capacity in the development field is still limited by its lack of institutional and administrative resources. In the Philippines, for example, where Japan's program is larger than America's, Japan has just 28 aid officials, including its embassy staff, to administer its programs. By contrast, the United States Agency for International Development alone has more than 100 officials. In India, the United States has a staff of 25 while Japan has only 4. This lack of staff resources undoubtedly creates problems for the Japanese in the quality of their programs.
Japan's increasingly powerful performance in the aid sphere portends a major transformation over the next decade of America's role from leader to follower in promoting the development of the poorer countries. This transformation mirrors the decline of American economic hegemony worldwide. But the diminishing role of the United States in the third world is not just the result of Japan's commitment to spend more money. It is equally the result of America's failure to develop a new policy.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Detroit: America's Best Source of Oil

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER FALVIN; Christopher Flavin, an energy analyst, is vice president for research at Worldwatch Institute in Washington.

 BODY:
At least one fact has become inescapably clear during the past two weeks. The world cannot afford a continuation of the steady increase in dependence on Persian Gulf oil. Means are available to reverse this trend. We can make our cars, buildings and industry far more fuel-efficient than they are today. The question is whether there is the political will to do so.
Few can deny that the world is recklessly over-dependent on Middle Eastern oil. Indeed, the situation is getting worse all the time. World oil demand has increased more than 2 percent annually since 1985. Meanwhile, the Middle East's share of the world oil market is rising at more than one million barrels per day each year. 
This dangerous trend is hardly a surprise. Experts saw it coming for years. But political leaders studiously ignored the problem, slashing many of the programs that could have reduced oil consumption and thereby vulnerability to the kind of military crisis that now exists.
Automobiles are at the root of American oil dependence. Some 43 percent of the country's oil is now used in automobiles. And 20 percent is used in other forms of transportation like air travel and trucking. Any efforts to reduce oil consumption must start with these transportation systems that together account for nearly two-thirds of oil use.
Ironically, these facts seemed to be better understood in the 1970's when Congress approved fuel economy standards that nearly doubled the fuel economy of American cars during a 10-year period. However, these standards were then allowed to remain at the level achieved in 1986. Indeed, for several years the Reagan Administration provided the auto industry with exemptions to the standards already in place.
As a consequence, cars rolling off Detroit's assembly lines in 1989 were actually less efficient than those of the previous year. This is a tragic reversal. If the average fuel economy was just five miles per gallon higher, we would be importing two million fewer barrels of oil each day, and in a much better position to withstand the effects of the embargo on Iraq.
President Bush finally discovered the words ''energy conservation'' after American troops were on their way to the Persian Gulf. Mr. Bush, however, was Vice President in an Administration that attempted to eliminate virtually every program aimed at reducing oil dependence.
Even in 1990, the country is spending just $411 million on energy conservation, over 50 percent below the levels of the early 1980's and equivalent to a few days' expenditure on the American forces now in the Persian Gulf. The Bush Administration is asking for substantial cuts in these conservation programs next year.
Simply raising new-car fuel economy from the current average of 27 miles per gallon to 40 miles per gallon would reduce American oil consumption by 2.8 million barrels per day by the year 2005. This is nearly 10 times the rate of oil production that the petroleum industry thinks is possible from the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, which it claims is the largest potential source of new oil supply in the United States.
The automotive technologies to accomplish these goals are available. Prototype vehicles that get more than 70 miles per gallon have been developed, though they have not yet reached the marketplace.
The projected additional cost for a 40-mile-per-gallon car is $500. This sum would be more than offset by gasoline savings of more than $2,000 during the life of a typical car. Fortuitously, the Senate is scheduled to vote on a bill mandating fuel economy standards in September.
The folly of relying on the Middle East for most of the Western world's energy supplies has been clearly revealed. Political leaders need to understand the simple fact that the biggest oil field available to the United States is in Detroit. With American lives now on the line, it is time that President Bush got serious about the country's energy efficiency.

LENGTH: 785 words

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
What to Call the Poorest Poor?

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Two weeks ago, Prof. William Julius Wilson stood up before 1,500 colleagues and called into question the usefulness of a term that has become a fixture of the American political vocabulary and one that he, more than anyone, helped legitimize: ''the underclass.''
His influential 1987 book, ''The Truly Disadvantaged,'' championed the term to describe not the poor generally, but a small group who are most likely to become dropouts, teen-age parents, drug addicts or even criminals, and who live among others like themselves. Professor Wilson, a sociologist at the University of Chicago, recognized the politically potent qualities of the word. As a liberal, he accused others on the left of being ''timid'' about discussing the pathologies of the inner city. Calling for more candor, he said that using the term ''underclass'' would enhance liberal credibility in the debate. 
He's now unsure if that's still the case. While Professor Wilson says he's not abandoning his analysis -that cultural factors help restrict inner-city residents - he worries that the phrase ''the underclass'' may have destructive consequences. In his speech to the American Sociological Association, he quoted Herbert Gans, the sociologist, to the effect that it has become an ''increasingly pejorative term,'' one ''hopelessly polluted in meaning.''
Elaborating in a telephone interview last week, he said he feared the term, once useful, is now being used by some journalists and conservatives to argue that the poor have created their own plight. And Professor Wilson, who is black, worries it may take on racist connotations. In his speech, he said he might begin to substitute the term ''ghetto poor.''
 
Assigning Blame
There is more than semantics involved in the debate. At bottom, the sparring is a new round in an old fight about where blame for poverty should reside - with the poor themselves, or with society at large.
In offering his definition of ''underclass,'' a phrase first used by the economist Gunnar Myrdal, Professor Wilson was trying to provide a complicated answer. At its root, he argued, the growth of the underclass is an economic problem, caused by the flight from the inner city of jobs for unskilled workers. That problem has been compounded by the flight of middle-class blacks that followed the end of legal segregation. This weakened institutions like churches and clubs and left people who remained with little in the way of role models. With this isolation of the ghetto, he wrote, ''joblessness as a way of life takes on a different social meaning.'' While the destructive patterns of behavior have economic origins, he contends, they in turn help perpetuate poverty as ghetto culture creates additional obstacles to social and economic advancement.
 
While Professor
Wilson was trying to describe two sides of a coin, economic and cultural, he now worries that ''underclass'' conjures only one: an image of people unwilling to help themselves.
Nicholas Lemann, author of a five-year study of the underclass that will be published in February, notes that Professor Wilson's dilemma is one that liberals have faced at least since Victorian England, when distinctions were made between the ''deserving'' and ''undeserving'' poor. ''To some people, 'underclass' will be taken as just a new way of saying these people don't deserve any special help,'' said Mr. Lemann, who is a liberal. What's unclear is whether in the long run ''ghetto poor'' would fare any better.
Some on the left, like Professor Gans, prefer terms like ''jobless'' to ''underclass,'' arguing that it is the economy, not the people, that needs reforming. The solution, Professor Gans says, lies in more well-paying, low-skilled jobs. But others, including some liberals, say ''underclass'' is more apt, arguing that cycles of welfare dependency are so strong that they inhibit people even when jobs are available. They point to immigrants who have few skills but more success in finding jobs.
This debate calls to mind an earlier and unhappy one, the vitriolic fallout from the 1965 Moynihan report that noted with alarm the increasing number of black families headed by women. The report, now widely admired for its prescience, was attacked as a racist document that ''blamed the victim.'' The effect was to inhibit among liberals a frank discussion of the inner city. One person who doesn't think that chapter will repeat itself is Senator Moynihan, who agrees that the term ''underclass'' has ''lost its explanatory edge.'' In an interview last week, he said that liberals who speak candidly about the poor risk being misunderstood, but that ''not to try to describe reality is the biggest risk of all.''
