PUB-DATE: August 26, 1990

SECTION: Section 4; Page 5, Column 4; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1030 words

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
In the Polls, the Economy Declines, Bush Doesn't

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Saddam Hussein has thrown America's election-year political forces into a strange and unpredictable alignment.
Generally speaking, two factors have greater weight than any others in determining which party will come out ahead in midterm elections, now only 72 days away. The first is the state of the economy and the second is the public standing of the President. They usually move more or less in tandem: a sour economy, for example, understandably sours people on the President and his party. 
But what happens when one indicator, the President's approval rating, is rising, and the other, the health of the economy, appears to be declining?
That is what has happened since Mr. Hussein sent his tanks across the Kuwaiti border. Confidence in the economy, which had been drifting downward, has gone into free fall as oil prices have soared, and most Americans believe the economy is in recession, according to recent polls. But approval of Mr. Bush, which had been drifting downward, has also soared in reponse to his tactics in the Gulf. These opposing forces are creating enormous political torque. ''It's the irresistable force meeting the immovable object,'' said Norman Ornstein, an analyst at the American Enterprise Institute.
In physics, such a collision produces an explosion. In politics, no one is quite sure what will happen. Before the Persian Gulf crisis, office-holders felt this would be an unpleasant year for them as voters acted out both their economic uncertainty and a general disgust toward politicians. The synopsis in political circles was that there was an ''anti-incumbent mood'' in the land.
All the sources of that mood are still palpable in the body politic. It was clear in the latest New York Times/ CBS News poll that Americans are deeply worried about the economy and other domestic concerns, despite their enthusiasm for Mr. Bush's foreign policy. What is far from clear, though, is how the divergent attitudes on foreign and domestic issues will influence the fall elections.
Ed Rollins, co-chairman of the Republian National Congressional Committee, had been advising his party's candidates to save their fire, and money, until the last three weeks of the campaign. Now he says, the situation is changing so quickly, and so unpredictably, that he is advising them to wait until the final 10 days.
The immediate political impact of the Persian Gulf crisis, as Mr. Rollins' advice suggests, has been to freeze most other politics in place. Kate Michelman, head of the National Abortion Rights Action League, worries that David Souter, Mr. Bush's nominee to the Supreme Court, is not getting enough scrutiny. ''The Administration is benefiting from the lack of attention,'' she said.
Similarly, Gerald Celente, director of the Socioeconomic Research Institute, which studies cultural and political trends, said, ''the Persian Gulf crisis has diverted the public's attention away from the nation's many festering ills,'' like the deficit, the collapse of the savings and loan industry and the declining economy.
Mr. Bush himself found it difficult to change the subject from the Persian Gulf the other day when he tried to lambaste the Democrats for what he said was their failure to negotiate on the budget. The little attention he got for his effort was mostly in the form of criticism for injecting partisanship into the patriotic fervor accompanying his dispatch of forces to Saudi Arabia.
On the campaign trail, the situation is somewhat different. Candidates who cannot find something good to say about Mr. Bush's Persian Gulf strategy are tending to say nothing about it. Disagreeing with the President is not likely to produce any political gain while Mr. Bush maintains a 76 percent approval rating, as he does in the latest New York Times/CBS News poll. Instead, candidates are proceeding, as if on auto-pilot, with their pre-crisis campaign themes.
 
Competing for Attention
But it is harder and harder to get attention. ''What Iraq has done is take everything off the radar screen,'' said Mr. Rollins.
Democrats had been hoping for a vigorous debate this fall about the state and direction of the economy, stressing their themes that the rich have gotten richer at the expense of everyone else. They wanted this partly to win elections this year, but they also wanted to test their themes for 1992. ''The public discourse would have been very strong,'' said Paul Tully, political director of the Democratic National Commitee. ''Now, maybe not.''
Some of the themes may still be voiced in campaigns, said Mr. Tully. But without reinforcement by the press, many campaign efforts fall flat.
Thus the most important spot in American politics may in many respects be Baghdad. Eddie Mahe, a Republican consultant who is advising several congressional candidates, said that if he knew what Saddam Hussein was going to do, he could predict how the fall campaigns will come out.
''If nothing happens that appears like George Bush has lost I think the American public will be uninclined to punish the President,'' said Mr. Mahe. Democrats do not argue with that, but insist that domestic concerns will still drive voters in congressional races.
But both Mr. Mahe and Mr. Rollins see the prospect of a special opportunity if, say around October, a widely popular Mr. Bush turns partisan and asks the American people to send him a more cooperative Congress. Mr. Rollins suggests that the President try telling the country that he cannot fight both the Democrats and Saddam Hussein. ''I think he could make a tremendous case,'' said Mr. Rollins. ''It could be a unique opportunity.''
Mr. Mahe concedes he and Mr. Rollins are envisioning a remarkable accomplishment: the party in power holding its own or even gaining seats in a period of economic decline.
A recession without the Persian Gulf crisis would have meant very bad times for Republicans, said Mr. Mahe. But with a successful handling of the gulf crisis as a counter to the economic trouble, it may be, Mr. Mahe said, ''that Republicans would not suffer the normal very adverse consequences that would be anticipated in an off-year election with a recession.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Bush (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: THE REGION;
The City's Rough Past: Frighteningly Familar

BYLINE: By RALPH BLUMENTHAL

 BODY:
Crimes of violence up 30 percent in six years. Arrests up 20 percent. Five police officers killed in a year. Court calendars clogged. Citizens arming themselves. Racial tensions at a boil. Critics bewailing a ''carnival of murder.'' So it went in the New York City of the 1860's. Today's alarming crime rate and fearful populace have clear parallels in earlier eras of city history, although historians say they have to go back to the 19th century and earlier to find them.
As early as the 1750's, New York was already regarded as the most degenerate of the colonial towns, with frequent brawls spilling out of the saloons, gaming places and houses of prostitution, wrote James F. Richardson in ''The New York Police:
Colonial Times to 1901'' (Oxford University Press, 1970).
''Thronged as our city is, men are robbed in the street,'' an investigating city panel lamented in 1842. ''Thousands that are arrested go unpunished, and the defenseless and the beautiful are ravished and murdered in the day time, and no trace of the criminals is found.'' 
The 1850's brought stirrings of vigilantism and press complaints that the city was becoming as deadly as the Kansas badlands.
In a 1910 killing as fresh as today's headlines, a gangster named Johnny Spanish opened fire on a rival, Kid Jigger, on Forsyth Street, missing him but killing an 8-year-old girl playing in the street.
Just where today's metropolis sits on the chart of more than three centuries of criminal violence in New York City is a matter of dispute, one that may never be satisfactorily resolved given the lack of reliable records. ''You're in a fog bank when you get into this question,'' said Richard H. Wade, professor of history at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York.
But Mr. Wade and other specialists say that the level of violence in the city today has no equal since at least the 1920's and invites comparison with benighted periods of mayhem in the 19th century. Some even say that when old accounts are discounted for exaggeration, this era may emerge as the worst ever, although some reported barbarous episodes of the past clearly surpass anything seen today.
''No doubt we've had higher crime rates than now,'' said Mr. Wade, citing a period from 1857 to 1870 when the state-appointed police force clashed regularly with a rival city police force called the Municipals, leaving hapless citizens at the mercy of mobs and gangs.
But the big difference today, he said, is the ubiquity of crime: where once it was largely bottled up in a few notorious districts, it now rages throughout the city.
Marvin Yablon, professor of operations research at the graduate center of the John Jay College of Criminal Justice of the City University, said he would be hard pressed to find a grimmer period than the current one. ''The locomotive driving things is beyond police capability,'' Mr. Yablon said. ''I have a sense now that it's going completely out of control. It has no limit. It seems to multiply.''
Mr. Yablon, a mathematician specializing in creating computer models of problems for scientific analysis, said the contraction of the economy was especially sinister because it reduces the chances of youths escaping the cycle of violence.
In absolute terms, last year's toll of 1,905 homicides was the highest ever recorded, according to the Police Department, and this year's toll looks worse. The figure yields a homicide rate of about 30 per 100,000 - or nearly eight times the rate of 3.8 per 100,000 in 1901 to 1905.
 
A Death Toll Today of Six Nightly
Through the 1940's and 1950's, murders averaged no more than 300 a year. As late as the 1960's, according to the Citizens Crime Commission of New York City, a business-supported watchdog group, three-quarters of all murders in the city were a result of personal disputes -lovers' quarrels, barroom brawls and the like. By the 1980's, however, it said, more than half the murders were a result of drug disputes and terrifying random robberies, with robberies themselves increasing more than tenfold from 8,757 in 1952 to 93,377 last year, despite a small drop in population.
Murder figures are reliable, ''because it's hard to dispose of bodies,'' said Thomas A. Reppetto, president of the crime commission and a former Chicago policeman who insists that crime in New York has never been worse. ''It's way, way more violent today,'' he asserted, scorning as unreliable exaggerations the popular accounts of rioting and gang warfare in the middle-1800's.
Yet Robert D. McCrie, assistant professor for security management at John Jay, said his research into 19th-century New York showed greater panic over crime in 1810 to 1830 and again between 1860 to 1880 than today. ''People wouldn't think of going out after dark without a weapon,'' he said.
James Richardson, in his police history, reported that between 1814 and 1834 the city's population little more than doubled while the number of complaints at the police courts quadrupled to 8,719. The next year, they jumped to 10,168.
In 1845, New York became the first American city to found a police department, modeled after London's.
In one night in November 1857, a contemporary account marveled, six men were shot or stabbed in barroom brawls. Now, with New York's population about 20 times larger, that is an average night's death toll.
Arrests in 1862 far exceeded today's rate. As Herbert Asbury reported in his popular classic of 1927, ''The Gangs of New York,'' the police in 1862 arrested 82,072 people, or 1/10th of the city. Last year, 308,164 people, equal to about 1/20th of the population, were arrested.
In 1864, five police officers were killed. Last year five were also killed; a sixth died in a fall chasing a suspect.
No era was without its cries for more police protection. In 1876, there was one officer per 475 citizens. In 1986, the ratio had dropped to one per 540 citizens. Today it is one per 280.
Scholars are coming to view some of the city's patrimony of violence as exaggerated. ''Every time historians get there, deaths go down,'' said Mr. Wade.
Still, accounts based on contemporary sources portray a New York horrifying even by today's debased standards.
 
Images of Militiamen Firing Howitzers
The Old Brewery, a notorious tenement in the heart of Five Points in Lower Manhattan, may not have housed 1,000 debauched poor, or averaged a murder a night for nearly 15 years before its demolition in 1852, as popular accounts have it. But a story in the Asbury book about one of its denizens, a little girl who lived with 25 others in a small basement room and who was stabbed to death over a penny she had begged, undoubtedly captured the tenor of the times: ''The body lay in a corner for five days before it was finally buried in a shallow grave dug in the floor by the child's mother.''
Similarly, the draft riots of 1863, in which Irish mobs turned on blacks and the police and sacked sections of the city, have been reinvestigated. And historians put the death toll at about 100, far below the hundreds or even thousand or more of early accounts. Yet even crime-hardened New Yorkers can only quail at the images of rioters cutting pieces from the bodies of lynched blacks amid pitched battles with police and militiamen firing howitzers.
Beginning in the 1830's, gangs such as the Plug Uglies, Dead Rabbits and Bowery B'hoys prowled the Five Points and Bowery and later Hell's Kitchen and other districts, thieving, brawling and murdering, undeterred by outnumbered and dismally untrained forces of the law.
For most of the 19th century and into the 20th, the police were abysmally corrupt and brutal, as exemplified by Captain, later Inspector, Alexander (Clubber) Williams, who starting in the 1870's grafted his way to a $300,000 fortune, a Connecticut estate and a steam yacht he attributed to speculation in Japanese building lots. Although he was brought up on charges 358 times and fined 224 times, he was never dismissed. Today Williams is remembered for his dictum: ''There is more law in a policeman's nightstick than the Supreme Court.''
In comparing the violence of bygone New York and today, Joel Rose straddles both worlds. A writer who has immersed himself in the gang culture of the 1840's for his as yet unpublished novel, he lives in a crime-ridden section of the Lower East Side, near Tomkins Square Park.
Mr. Rose says he looks back almost with nostalgia on the last century when thugs ruled his streets with brickbats and cobblestones, and more recently, when heroin addicts lined up peacefully for fixes. Now crack addicts are everywhere, jumpy, heavily armed and vicious. Last month, a crackhead he tried to befriend broke his hand with a lead pipe.
In the 1840's, he said, ''The city had newness and brightness, at least there was hope for a better life. Now I can't see any hope.''

CORRECTION-DATE: September 2, 1990, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about crime waves in New York misstated the year in which the ratio of police officers to citizens dropped to 1 per 540. The year was 1896, not 1986.

HEADLINE: THE REGION;
Cuomo's Green Period

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK

DATELINE: ALBANY

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has been campaigning vigorously across the state. He has political advertisements on the radio. He has spent $300,000 on television commercials, just in August. ''The choice is very clear,'' he says solemnly, staring into the lens.
The choice Mr. Cuomo refers to is not the one between him and Pierre A. Rinfret, the Republican candidate in the Nov. 6 gubernatorial election. It is whether to approve a referendum on the 21st Century Environmental Quality Bond Act, a $1.975 billion measure that Mr. Cuomo contends will ''help make New York's future clean and green.'' 
Mr. Cuomo has campaigned aggressively for bond issues before, but rarely this early before Election Day. While no one questions Mr. Cuomo's sincerity in promoting the bond act, his political opponents believe the timing of his advertising blitz has as much to do with his own political condition as it does with the bond issue.
As a political issue, the environment is hot. As a political candidate, Mr. Cuomo is not, or at least not as sizzling as in past years. As the bond act's most visible spokesman, the Governor can expect to reap the benefits that accrue to politicians who wrap themselves in popular issues.
''I certainly hope so,'' Mr. Cuomo said in an interview. ''Adlai Stevenson said it: the best politics is good government.''
Environmentalists see the tactic somewhat differently. ''He's trying to attach himself to environmental protection, which is an area that people are very concerned about and an area where he has been weak,'' said Larry Shapiro of the New York Public Interest Research Group.
 
The Politics of Planting Trees
Mr. Shapiro and other environmental advocates commend Mr. Cuomo for helping to close the Shoreham nuclear plant, for proposing legislation to reduce acid rain and for backing a $1.45 billion environmental bond act in 1986. But they criticize his administration for permitting the licensing of garbage incinerators, for being slow to finance toxic-waste cleanups and for not declaring a moratorium on development in the Adirondacks, as recommended by a gubernatorial commission.
As Mr. Cuomo runs for his third four-year term, numerous private opinion polls indicate that his approval ratings have dropped. He faces the inevitable antagonism aimed at an incumbent who has been in office for eight years. The state's economy is sliding perilously close to recession. And this year's excruciating budget negotiations ended with the passage of a record $1.4 billion in new taxes.
The Governor is expected to have little trouble disposing of Mr. Rinfret, a largely unknown candidate who has disappointed even the leaders of his own party. But the strength of Mr. Cuomo's showing in November is important to his political future, both to his ability to govern New York and to his status as a potential Presidential candidate in 1992.
Mr. Cuomo has done little to suggest he is planning a race for the White House. But should he run, it would not hurt him to be able to boast of ushering in a bond issue that would dedicate a record amount of money to land acquisition, solid waste management and water quality improvement, among other purposes.
Since mid-June, Mr. Cuomo has made appearances on the measure's behalf in 19 cities, most of them in upstate New York where support for bond issues has usually been weakest.
At 10 of the events he has planted sugar maple saplings, the state tree.
The Governor also has spent his own campaign funds on the television commercial, which features pictures of billowing smokestacks, slimy seas and overflowing landfills.
Mr. Cuomo has declined to use any of his nearly $8 million war chest to help Democratic candidates for the State Senate, saying the funds were not contributed to him for that purpose. His aides said that principle does not apply to spending the money for the bond act commercials because Mr. Cuomo may benefit politically from the ads and because the bond act is crucial to his agenda.
Republicans maintain that the Governor is trying to divert attention from more damaging issues.
''If you had his record on taxes, spending and crime you would want to plant trees too,'' said Assemblyman John A. Faso, Mr. Rinfret's campaign manager.
Mr. Cuomo said he deliberately started the advertising campaign for the bond act early to give voters time to understand its import and to separate it from the noisy clutter of the fall campaign.
He said he also was motivated by fears that the state's financial problems could influence people to vote against the bond act. In the next fiscal year, the bond act would add an estimated $28 million to the state's debt-service payments, a figure that would escalate to $201 million 10 years from now before gradually decreasing.
''Some people, I believe mistakenly, regard the difficulty of these times fiscally and economically as being the reason to vote against the bond issue,'' Mr. Cuomo said. ''I see it as a good reason to vote for the bond issue. Making that case takes an awful lot of argumentation and discussion.''

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
Know Your Allies

BYLINE: By A. M. Rosenthal

 BODY:
Americans have a pretty clear idea why the United States is fighting in the Arab Middle East, what rings true and what clunks like a counterfeit coin.
But when it comes to understanding our new Arab allies, who are supposed to help the United States, we are being fed a lot of political and journalistic hogwash. If we swallow it, the Middle East will wind up a more dangerous place than ever for us all.
Any politically literate American knows we are not fighting for democracy because there is none in the Arab world. We are not fighting for the right of the Kuwaiti royal family because no American would be fool enough to risk his life so that it can go on running the place like a private oil plantation. 
The crack that we are fighting for a few cents on the gallon is a cruelly undeserved accusation that President Bush is willing to sacrifice American lives for a buck.
No, the U.S. moved into war position to stop a psychopathically ruthless killer from controlling a resource that is basic food to industry and can mean the difference between economic life and death. It would have been suicide to do otherwise, the worst crime a free government can commit against its people.
But the new ''allies'' of the U.S. are being treated by Government and press with an unctuous tenderness that is not comical only because it is dangerous.
But almost everything Americans detest and have fought is not only alive but dominant in the Arab world.
Morally it is impossible to distinguish Hussein of Iraq from Assad of Syria. Like Saddam Hussein, Assad has slaughtered his own citizens by the tens of thousands. Like him, he has invaded and occupied a brotherly neighbor - Lebanon. He too is a terrorist leader specializing in killing Americans - remember Pan Am 103?
And like Hussein, he knows the value of hostages to any marauding tyranny.
The other Arab Governments are not quite as terrifying - except to their people, if we still care. In Saudi Arabia political prisoners are arrested without warrant, held indefinitely, tortured routinely. At the next of those elegant Saudi Embassy parties in Washington, some of the guests should bring along the latest Amnesty International report on Saudi Arabia.
Human rights reports from Egypt also are chilling. Political prisoners are subject to electric shock, cigarette burns, rape and sticks inserted in the anus.
All the Arab allies are indeed unified - by common governmental detestation of free speech, press, assembly or elections.
Saudi Arabia and Kuwait poured billions into Saddam Hussein's war treasury before he double-crossed them, and will again if he just lays off them a little. They would be happy to see him turn his attention from their oil derricks to the cities of another Middle Eastern nation, Israel.
Obvious questions: Should Mr. Bush reject help from any country in the fight against Hussein? And, be realistic, can he be expected to talk now about things like torture, Middle East fascism and religious hatred, and the planned extinction of Israel? Answer: Yes to both.
The Arabs joined the struggle against Hussein because he unexpectedly went for their throats. They knew this was their last chance to get the U.S. to rescue them.
Fine - but the U.S. would have strengthened its cause and helped its citizens if it had told Mr. Assad we did not want his flag or token detachments as long as he permitted terrorists to chain Americans to the wall in territory under his jurisdiction. And we can still tell our Arab allies we expect them to give their people a taste of something called human rights.
Already the Arabs are preparing a bill to the U.S. for saving their hides. If Saddam Hussein falls, or if he decides to pull out of any part of Kuwait, the Arabs will demand that the U.S. pressure Israel to leave the West Bank.
A ludicrous, hypocritical quid pro quo. Kuwaitis did not use their territory as Palestinians and other Arabs use the West Bank - a center for infiltration and terrorism and a base for the eventual extermination of the enemy. All Kuwait and the other oil states wanted was to be allowed to give Hussein billions to go fight somebody else.
The Arab coalition is of use now. But it could turn out to be a fatal pressure front, a prelude to a devastating war in the Middle East against Israel. Unlike the Kuwaiti princelings, the Israelis will not helicopter out.
In World War II there was a poster: ''Know your enemy.'' It might not be a bad idea to print up a new one: ''Know your ally.''

HEADLINE: A Week of Tension in the Gulf

 BODY:
Sunday, Aug. 19 - President Saddam Hussein of Iraq says foreigners in Iraq and Kuwait must remain until the United States withdraws from the gulf. Many are transferred to potential targets. American warships decline to use force to stop Iraqi tankers pending United Nations approval of such action. 
Monday - President Bush, shuttling between his vacation in Maine and Washington, uses the word ''hostages'' for the first time to describe the detained foreigners. Iraq says embassies in Kuwait must close by Friday or the diplomats will lose immunity and face arrest. Oil prices, which had risen for a week, fall slightly on Saudi Arabia's promise to increase oil production by two million barrels a day.
Tuesday - Iraqis force one American and eight Britons from their homes in Kuwait. President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt issues an appeal to Mr. Hussein to pull out of Kuwait. Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands and Spain agree to send warships to the growing international force in the Persian Gulf.
Wednesday - President Bush authorizes the use of as many as 50,000 military reservists and says the American Embassy in Kuwait will defy Iraqi orders to close. Japan offers billions in financial aid to Mideast nations hurt by the boycott of Iraq. King Hussein of Jordan says he will travel among Arab nations to seek a diplomatic solution. He orders Jordan's borders closed to the refugees from Iraq.
Thursday - Saddam Hussein appears on Iraqi television with a group of Western hostages, who appear uncomfortable as the Iraqi President explains that they are ''heroes of peace.'' Iraq says any attempt to keep embassies in Kuwait open after a Friday deadline will be taken as an ''act of aggression.'' Most nations say they'll stand pat but evacuate most of their staffs. Jordan, unable to stop the refugees, reopens its borders.
Friday - Iraqi troops surround embassies in Kuwait, including the American Embassy. Diplomats and their families evacuated to Baghdad from Kuwait are not allowed to leave, despite Iraq's promise. Moscow warns Baghdad to pull out of Kuwait and release foreign nationals, and agrees to support the United Nations resolution backing force.
Saturday - The United Nations Security Council, including the Soviet Union, approves the use of force to support the military and economic blockade of Iraq. Mr. Hussein meets with President Kurt Waldheim of Austria, and Mr. Waldheim leaves Baghdad with 80 Austrians.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Saddam Hussein and young hostage on Iraqi TV. (Jack Manning/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Travel Advisory

 BODY:

Sea Theme In Disney Plan For Long Beach
The Walt Disney Company's master plan for a 350-acre oceanside resort and theme park in Long Beach, Calif., boasts everything from the world's largest aquarium to underwater steel cages where tourists can swim with sharks.
The $2 billion project, to be called Port Disney, is the first of two competing plans by the Disney organization for another theme park in Southern California. The second proposal, details of which will be disclosed next year, would add a new attraction near Disneyland, in Anaheim, that would be similar to the Epcot Center in Florida.
The company will decide on the site after studying the attitude of residents and local governments in the two communities. If Port Disney is chosen over the Anaheim project, it would not open for at least 10 years, company officials said, citing the necessary public hearings, environmental impact studies and building permits. The centerpiece of the Port Disney project is DisneySea, a theme park of rides and attractions, revolving around Oceana, a futuristic bubble-shaped complex, and a marine research center. 
Other attractions will include five resort hotels; boats for rental, excursions, shows and dining; 400 new marina slips, and a cruise ship terminal to be operated by the Port of Long Beach. Land shuttles, water ferries and a monorail will link the north and south shores of Queensway Bay in downtown Long Beach to the resort. Long Beach is about 20 miles west of Disneyland.
 
Curfew Still On In Trinidad
The attempted coup by armed radical Black Muslims in Port of Spain, Trinidad, July 27 has crippled tourism in Trinidad and Tobago. Calls by cruise ships have been canceled, airline service is limited and some hotels are empty. The Government has decided that the current state of emergency will continue until Nov. 10. The curfew, from 9 P.M. to 5 A.M., is expected to go on until mid-September.
Hotel reservations for the coming winter are relatively high, the Hotel and Tourism Association says, but cancellations may be heavy as the season approaches. Before the coup attempt, officials had been encouraged that visitor figures for the two islands showed increases for last year and for the first six months of this year.
Many hotels with few or no guests have laid off employees, which, the association points out, is aggravating the already serious unemployment situation. The country's unemployment figure is around 28 percent. Representatives of the association have been told by the Minister of Industry, Enterprise and Tourism, Dr. Bhoe Tewarie, that while tourism is probably the industry hit hardest by recent events, the Government feels that security remains the major priority.
However, government officials say they are eager to win back lost tourism and to encourage reservations for the high season starting in December. Members of the country's Tourism Development Authority have been in the United States this month visiting cruise lines in an attempt to convince them that the attempted coup was ''an aberration'' and that Trinidad and, particularly, Tobago are safe for visitors. In 1989 about 218,000 people visited the two islands, including 29,000 cruise passengers.
 
Kosher Guide, Meal Service
Jews who follow the dietary rules of kashrut need no longer scoop tuna fish from cans or go without cooked food when far from home and a kosher kitchen. The Kosher Club (82-84 Genung Street, Middletown, N.Y. 10940; 914-344-1933) can help members locate the nearest kosher restaurant in the United States or will ship kosher meals directly to a member's hotel.
''I started Kosher Club because I needed it,'' said the founder and president, Stephen Ostrow, a commercial photographer. ''I am kosher and I travel a lot. Last year we visited New Mexico - it's a great state, I loved it - but there was nothing kosher so we lived on tuna fish and boiled eggs.'' With his wife, Monica, and some friends, Mr. Ostrow compiled a guide to 800 kosher restaurants in the United States, Canada and Mexico, complete with descriptions and information on each restaurant's rabbinical certification.
Prepackaged meals shipped overnight in dry ice ''are not airline meals,'' said Mr. Ostrow, ''but they are produced by the same people who make airline meals. They're basically enhanced TV dinners.'' Prices range from $8.95 for a chicken dinner to $17.95 for ribeye steak. Customers also pay shipping costs, approximately $4 a meal. Both guide and meal service are available only to club members; a year's membership costs $49.95, with $5 added for spouses. Members also get a monthly newsletter on kosher restaurants and discounts at about one-third of the kosher restaurants.
 
Historic Homes Open for Tour
A number of Washington's historic homes will be opened to the public on Sunday, Sept. 16, for the sixth annual Kalorama House Tour, which this year will benefit the Woodrow Wilson House Museum, the capital's only Presidential museum.
President Wilson moved into the 1915 Georgian Revival townhouse on Inauguration Day, 1921, the day he left office. After his death in 1924 his widow, Edith, remained in the home, subsequently bequeathing it to the National Trust for Historic Preservation to preserve as a memorial to her husband.
In addition to the Woodrow Wilson House, nine private residences will go on view from noon until 5 P.M., including the 1906 red brick mansion known as the Codman-Davis House, and the Studio House of Edwin Lind Morse, a painter and author whose father was Samuel F. B. Morse, the inventor and artist.
The Sheridan-Kalorama area, known as Embassy Row, has been home to four Presidents as well as diplomats, statesmen, writers and artists.
The tour begins at the Wilson House Museum at 2340 S Street, N.W., where visitors receive a map detailing the architecture and history of each home. Light refreshments will be served. Tickets for $12 may be purchased in advance at the museum or by calling 202-387-4062. Same day tickets are $15.
 
BATTLE OF BRITAIN CELEBRATIONS
Fifty years ago this year the Battle of Britain was fought in the skies over England when fighter pilots of the Royal Air Force turned back the German Luftwaffe. A continuing series of events, from flying displays to exhibitions of 1940 fashions, culminates in London on Sept. 15 with a parade, a flyover and fireworks. A service commemorating the battle, one of the most decisive campaigns of World War II, will be held at Westminster Abbey the following day.
The centerpiece of the anniversary events is an exhibition, ''The Battle of Britain Experience,'' at the three R.A.F. museums in the north London district of Hendon through Oct. 31. One of the world's finest collections of R.A.F., Luftwaffe and Italian planes of World War II is on display, along with a copy of an operations room used during the battle.
Many towns in southeastern England, which bore the brunt of the German daylight attacks, are holding various events. Among them is Folkestone on the south coast, which has a festival from Sept. 8 to 16 that includes an air show, parades, tea dances and a Glenn Miller Band concert. The Kent Battle of Britain Museum in Hawkinge, site of a former front-line airfield south of London, has copies of wartime planes and artifacts of the battle. A six-hour flying display is scheduled Sept. 15 at the R.A.F. base at Abingdon, Oxfordshire, west of London. Information is available at the British Tourist Center on Lower Regent Street in London (730-3400) and at local tourist offices.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 29, Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 4914 words

HEADLINE: Japan's Imperial Present

BYLINE: By Steven R. Weisman; Steven R. Weisman is chief of The Times's Tokyo bureau.

 BODY:
In the 22d day of November this year, if all goes according to plan, an enigmatic and lonely 56-year-old man who has lived almost all his life in the shadow of his father will leave his modest home for the grounds of the Imperial Palace in downtown Tokyo. At 6:30 P.M., Akihito will bathe, put on white ceremonial robes and enter a shrine in a wooded glade. He will eat boiled rice and millet and then commune alone with the spirit of his mythological ancestor, the sun goddess Amaterasu Omikami. Three hours before dawn, he will emerge spiritually transformed as the 125th Emperor of Japan.
Akihito has been Emperor since the death of his father, Hirohito, in January 1989. But he has had to wait until after a long mourning period for his enthronement, for a day decreed as sacred by the Taiho legal code adopted from China nearly 1,300 years ago. Although about a thousand prominent guests are spending the night in buildings near the simple thatched-roof shrine, they will not be allowed to observe this rite.
The ritual was last performed in 1928, when Hirohito ascended to the Chrysanthemum Throne. Now, just as the late Emperor served as a symbol of Japan's dark militarist past and then as a revered totem of its miraculous rebirth, many Japanese see Akihito as an incarnation of a new era. 
Cautious and self-effacing, the new Emperor has been preparing for this accession all his life. He has let it be known that he wants to be a constitutional monarch, one who brings the throne closer to the people. Since becoming Emperor, he has established an informal style, stooping, for example, to shake hands with children and the handicapped, in contrast to his father, who expected everyone to bow to him. He is also the first Emperor to marry a commoner - Empress Michiko has dazzled Japanese with her style and grace - and the first to raise his own children.
But Akihito's modest personal profile is something of a paradox. The public ceremonies that culminate in his ascension will be the most elaborate display of the Emperor's ancient role as a Shinto priest since the end of World War II. For many Japanese, the rites demonstrate the nation's willingness to put on center stage the imperial traditions long sidelined or muted.
Akihito is acutely aware of the ambivalent attitudes that the Japanese have toward him. Most regard the Emperor as irrelevant, but even more than the subjects of Queen Elizabeth, for example, they expect him to behave in an exemplary fashion and maintain the institution as a repository of culture and tradition.
Officially, the Emperor was stripped of his powers in the Japanese Constitution written by the United States after the war. In an age when belief in traditional Japanese institutions is being tested, the survival of the monarchy depends on the faith of the people. Akihito is aware that, with his series of pomp-filled accession events, the Japanese will be watching his efforts to revitalize ancient rituals, establish his own identity and somehow make himself relevant on the threshold of the 21st century.
''I think he's now trying to rebuild the authority of the Japanese imperial system,'' says Akira Hashimoto, general manager of Kyodo News Service and a former schoolmate. ''He is genuinely searching for his own way to be loved by the Japanese people.''
Thousands lined the rain-spattered streets of Nagasaki in southern Japan in May as Akihito smiled and waved from a black Nissan limousine with a gold chrysanthemum crest. Once, Japanese had to prostrate themselves before the Emperor, but on this day people were craning excitedly for a glimpse. ''Now I can live longer!'' an old woman exclaimed as the motorcade sped by.
At a city park dedicated to victims of the atomic bomb attack in 1945, the crowd gasped when the Emperor set aside his umbrella and bowed deeply before the memorial, a gesture of humility that his father would never have made. Later, in front of the Nagasaki government headquarters, a bearded man burst emotionally into the national anthem:
 
Rule on, my lord,
Until the pebbles
Grow to mighty rocks...
''Banzai!'' the crowd shouted three times. ''Ten thousand years!'' Akihito and Empress Michiko nodded, turning into the building for a meeting with the Mayor of Nagasaki, Hitoshi Motoshima, whose relationship with the imperial family is an unusual one.
In the last months of Hirohito's life, Motoshima dared to criticize the ailing Emperor openly, accusing him of being partly responsible for the disaster of World War II. The Mayor was then subjected to death threats and snubbed by Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party. Last January, in front of the city hall, a rightist shot Motoshima in the back.
The Japanese prize subtle gestures, and it was an extraordinary sign for Akihito to meet in this way with a critic of his late father. Motoshima, who has fully recovered from the wound, recalled afterward that the Emperor nodded appreciatively when he described his recovery and his still sleepless nights. ''I think he could understand what I said,'' the mayor told reporters. ''As a human being, I think this man is great.''
Indeed, Akihito seems determined to move past the painful debates that dogged Hirohito until the end of his life. But the new Emperor does so as heir to a history filled with contradictions.
Japan's postwar Constitution defines the Emperor simply as a ''symbol of the state and of the unity of the people.'' He thus presides at banquets, greets foreign dignitaries, signs official documents and undertakes other duties as a head of state who is not actually a head of state.
In a similar paradox, the Emperor is a religious leader who is not a religious leader. Like his predecessors, he functions as the chief priest of Shinto - worshiping his mythical ancestors and other gods of the Shinto pantheon - although since the war, his religious identity is no longer formally recognized by the state.
For most of recorded history, priestly chores were the main job of the Japanese tenno, or heavenly sovereign. Real power in Japan has almost always rested with a succession of warlords and rulers who manipulated the Emperor and kept him up front as a symbol of their legitimacy. Only after the coup of 1868, known as the Meiji Restoration, was the Emperor elevated to the status of ''sacred and inviolable'' head of state. By the 1930's, the new concepts of state Shinto religion and Emperor worship were used to justify Japan's brutal military aggression.
Today, less than 5 percent of Japanese say that they believe the Emperor is divine. About the same number want the Emperor system abolished. Most opinion surveys show Japanese to be benignly indifferent, leaving much of the bitter debate about the role of the monarch to rightist and leftist extremists.
Radical leftists occasionally fire homemade rockets at various imperial homes, for instance, and they recently firebombed several Shinto shrines to protest the coming rite. For their part, rightists no longer engage in widespread assassinations of the kind that opened the way for a military takeover in the 1930's, but Emperor worship and violence - as shown by the attack on the mayor of Nagasaki - are still practiced.
When I visited the National Patriots Conference, a prominent rightist group, at a drab office building in Tokyo, a handful of middle-aged men were bustling around, planning for the enthronement with a large calendar listing all the ceremonies leading up to it. ''Akihito is not just a monarch but a spiritual being,'' says Rikio Kishimoto, the conference director general. ''He is like a father, and the people are his children. He is like the sun, giving everything and not expecting anything in return. He should be above us.''
as a teen-ager, Akihito was once asked if he ever wished he could be an ordinary boy. ''I don't know,'' he replied. ''I've never been an ordinary boy.''
His birth in 1933 was a cause for joy because, after four daughters, Empress Nagako had begun to despair of producing a male heir. Following tradition, Akihito was separated from his parents at the age of 3 and brought up by attendants who so zealously cared for him that he later told friends he was scarcely permitted to walk up the stairs by himself.
By all accounts, Akihito's childhood was painfully lonely. Schoolmates were kept at a distance and even asked to refrain from talking about their trips to the zoo so as not to deepen his unhappiness. A friend once came into Akihito's darkened room in the evening and found him alone by his desk lamp, aimlessly killing moths.
At the height of the war, in 1944, when American B-29's were bombing Tokyo, Akihito moved to a coastal area south of the city, then to the mountains. The next year, he returned, shaken, to find his school and house destroyed, surrounded by a devastated shell of a city, and his schoolmates wondering about their future in the occupation. Gen. Douglas A. MacArthur, rejecting the advice of many, decided not to remove or punish Hirohito on the ground that the Emperor had been powerless to stop the war. MacArthur reasoned that maintaining the Emperor would promote Japanese unity and friendship.
The Americans decreed that it would be dangerous for the 12-year-old Akihito to be further isolated, as tradition required. He was thus educated through high school and college among friends from the old privileged classes. With the enthusiastic support of General MacArthur, the imperial family also decided to recruit an American schoolteacher to tutor Akihito in English and in American customs. The teacher, Elizabeth Gray Vining, a Philadelphia Quaker and pacifist, recalled later that she found a shy, sensitive and friendly boy, frequently bored with his schoolwork, whose chief outside interests were fish and horseback riding. ''Poor little boy!'' she wrote in her memoirs. ''I thought that he led a very dull and restricted life, and I longed to set him free.''
Classmates of Akihito say Mrs. Vining was a strong influence. ''She opened his eyes and helped to instill him with democratic and liberal values,'' one recalls.
Approaching adulthood, Akihito vowed to raise his own children without the restrictions he had experienced. As it happened, the Imperial Household Agency, which runs the daily lives of the royal family, favored strengthening the imperial bloodlines with a bride outside the old aristocacy. An extensive search culminated in 1957 with the choice of Michiko Shoda, the daughter of a prominent industrialist, a brilliant, athletic and attractive student at the University of the Sacred Heart in Tokyo. A meeting was arranged in a game of mixed doubles at a mountain resort, where Akihito was defeated in tennis but immediately fell in love.
The aristocracy was shocked at the selection of someone educated in a Catholic school, albeit an elite one. Michiko's family also opposed the marriage, fearing the burdens that would be placed on their daughter. Akihito persisted, persuading her with a heartfelt declaration of his desire for a family.
His stubborn streak flared in other ways. When his old schoolmate, Hashimoto, then a young reporter, wrote a story quoting the Crown Prince as saying he was in love, Akihito accosted his friend at a reception and shoved him out the door, shouting, ''I don't like you!'' They subsequently reconciled, but Hashimoto is one of several acquaintances who discovered the Emperor has a temper.
''Nothing gets him angrier than an invasion of his privacy,'' says another old friend. Nevertheless, the difficulties that Akihito and Michiko's marriage ran into in 1959 were widely reported.
Friends today confirm reports that the young couple sought without success to dismiss Michiko's chief lady-in-waiting, a member of the old aristocracy viewed by them as a spy for Akihito's mother, Empress Nagako, and others in the family. In a recently published memoir, a senior chamberlain recalls Michiko plaintively asking why her mother-in-law disliked her so.
Although not a Christian, Michiko was also suspected by members of the old nobility of indoctrinating her children with Bible stories. The Crown Princess found herself further criticized for wearing the wrong kinds of gloves and dresses, carrying her baby son openly in public, breast-feeding and cutting a more glamorous figure than others in the family.
The Japanese public became anxious as these pressures took their toll. Michiko lost weight and appeared gaunt, fatigued and depressed. In 1963, four years after the marriage, the Imperial Palace abruptly announced that the Crown Princess, suffering from ''great mental strain,'' was being hospitalized for an abortion of what would have been her second child. Michiko went into seclusion for four months, and a palace spokesman denied widespread reports that she had suffered a nervous breakdown.
Friends say Akihoto has stood by Michiko, who today is admired for her elegance and grace but who is still widely viewed as a shadow of her early vibrant self. As Empress, some associates say, she has come into her own at last, insisting that many domestic matters be done her way and that her two sons, at least, be free to study abroad (at Oxford) and marry when they want. Her three children are said to have independent streaks, and the 30-year-old Crown Prince, Naruhito, has already disappointed ultranationalists by defending the Constitution and denouncing the shooting of Mayor Motoshima of Nagasaki.
Insiders say Michiko, who at 55 is a year younger than her husband, has also lately sought a rapprochement with some family members, but that strains persist with Akihito's sisters and mother, Empress Nagako, who is 87 and ailing. Most members of the imperial family have their own charitable and ceremonial obligations and live much more quietly than, say, the British royal family.
But there is occasional gossip about imperial carryings-on. In 1982, Akihito's bearded young Oxford-educated cousin, Prince Tomohito Mikasa, created a small scandal by boycotting several ceremonial events and letting it be known that he wished to ''secede'' from the family. He later changed his mind. Under postwar Japanese rules, only male descendants of Emperor Hirohito and his siblings keep their official status and draw annual imperial stipends, including about $1.7 million shared by Akihito's immediate family and $1.5 million by 15 others.
Akihito and Michiko live in the secluded Togu Palace outside Tokyo amid the mossy overgrown forests of pines, birches and azaleas on the sprawling grounds of the Renaissance-style state guest house, the Akasaka Detached Palace, with their 21-year-old daughter, Nori. Naruhito, known as Hiro, and his younger brother, 24-year-old Prince Aya, who married earlier this year, do not live with their parents.
Akihito tries to break out of his shell by inviting acquaintances in for tea or for meals. ''He is the first Emperor in Japan's history to have friends, a huge asset his father never had,'' says Yoshinobu Tokugawa, a schoolmate and historian who is a descendant of the last shogun. But another friend adds that he is an essentially lonely man: ''There is a wall between the imperial family and us, so we never know his true feelings.''
As his father did, Akihito writes poetry on important occasions and studies fish at the marine biology laboratory at the Imperial Palace. A couple dozen of his papers have appeared in the Japanese Journal of Ichthyology, and he wrote several entries on tropical gobies in the book, ''Fish of the Japanese Archipelago.'' He commutes each day by limousine to the nearby Imperial Palace grounds, where a new palace is to be built for him, and he is seen in public a few times a week at dedications, concerts, exhibitions and the like.
Declaring that he attaches ''great importance'' to his private religious obligations, the Emperor also performs about 20 major religious ceremonies a year at the three shrines on the palace grounds in his capacity as chief priest of Shinto. Many rites are elaborate and grueling, like the one on New Year's Day when he gets up before dawn and prays alone for several hours in a cold, dark shrine. Friends say they are awed by his discipline at both public and private events. ''Sometimes I feel he's like a doll, not a human being,'' says Hiroshi Matsumoto, another former schoolmate.
The main constraints on Akihito's life are the all-powerful Imperial Household Agency and the requirement that he keep all of his opinions to himself. The agency, whose 1,100-odd employees are famous for a protectiveness toward the imperial family that cannot be breached by politicians or other outsiders, has never felt accountable to the public and has tried to control, even censor, news about the royal family by threatening to cut off access for uncooperative reporters and photographers. The Emperor has a personal staff of several chamberlains and a dozen Shinto ritualists, as well as an informal circle of a advisers that includes professors and former diplomats.
Some around Akihito worry that he is kept uninformed. One person describes him as taken aback recently when he was told about economic tensions with the United States. ''After the war, the chrysanthemum curtain was opened,'' says a former schoolmate. ''But the bureacratic curtain remains shut.''
Behind the scenes, however, associates say that unlike his father, Akihito bridles at being overly dictated to. They say he takes an active interest in what he is told to say on diplomatic occasions, demanding explanations or changes to reflect his feelings. ''He doesn't want to give the impression he's a puppet,'' an official says.
Moreover, Akihito has adopted an informal style, marked by his use of colloquial Japanese - his voice is reedy and he has a slight lisp - a startling contrast to the courtly locutions of his father. He has also cut his retinue of security police, food tasters and the officials required to see him off at airports and train stations, and directed that his motorcade stop at some traffic lights. ''I find it natural that the imperial family should not exist at a distance from the people,'' he said last year.
Emperors of Japan have long been politically manipulated. When Meiji was ''restored'' to power as Emperor in 1868, for instance, he was only 15 years old, with shoulder-length hair, blackened teeth, plucked eyebrows, a powdered face and the flowing robes of a priest. To send the world a message that Japan had a constitutional monarchy, the nation's new rulers dressed Meiji up in a Prussian military uniform and put him on a horse with a sword and a plumed hat.
Meiji's grandson, Emperor Hirohito, lost his military regalia after the war but became a familiar icon in his baggy suits and fedora. Akihito, 5 foot 5 and birdlike with a helmet of graying hair, wears sharply tailored suits and, at certain ceremonies, flowing pleated kimonos that are an example of what one scholar calls ''forced archaism'' - the adaptation of traditions to suggest continuity and majesty.
To maintain the luster of the imperial system, of course, Akihito must do more than wear a number of different uniforms. Surveys show that the overwhelming majority of Japanese have a favorable opinion of him, but that sentiment is not so intense as it was for his father, who was highly respected as the nation's last ''god king,'' even among those who did not believe in his divinity. Some intellectuals and leftists dismiss Akihito as ten-chan, or the ''little emp,'' and make jokes about his being henpecked.
A factor in Akihito's favor is the increasing pride the Japanese take in their traditions. ''When I was growing up, intellectuals and students were all criticizing Japanese culture, including the Emperor system,'' says Shin-ichi Nakazawa, a 39-year-old author of several books on Japanese society. ''Today everyone is fascinated by royalty. In all our magazines and newspapers, you cannot find one harsh word against the Emperor system.''
Or, as a recent youth magazine put it, the imperial family ''saves us from being only a nation of shopkeepers.''
What sort of Japan will emerge from such pride in its heritage? Will the old nationalism of earlier this century be replaced by a new techno-nationalism, or economic imperialism, or a new willingness to participate as a partner in international relations? Japan's friends and rivals will likely be watching Japanese public attitudes toward the imperial system for clues.
Japanese rightists want to restore imperial sovereignty over the Government and armed forces. Most of the more than 800 right-wing groups in Japan limit their activities to sending out sound trucks blaring patriotic music and speeches denouncing the left. Only about 50 groups, with a total of 22,000 members, are believed by the police to practice violence, mostly in mysterious connection with mobsters known as yakuza.
People around the Emperor say he resents being used by this small group of Emperor worshipers, especially the extremists. The rightists, in turn, are said to be less than happy with his stated support for the Japanese Constitution, calling him a ''closet pacifist'' and leftist tainted by Christian influence.
Akihito's opinion about such matters has never been stated explicitly but gleaned from reading between the lines of his statements, and from keeping track of such gestures as the visit to Nagasaki. ''The position of the Emperor is to perform his duties according to the Constitution,'' he once told reporters, ''and I believe I should refrain from making remarks involving arguments relating to the Constitution.''
But there is little doubt among the people who know the Emperor best about where he stands. ''He is very much a member of his generation, a very strong pacifist, a strong liberal and a believer in democracy,'' says Edwin O. Reischauer, the former United States Ambassador to Japan and a longtime acquaintance.
As evidence of Akihito's pacifism, for example, an insider at the palace recalled a conversation in which someone described nuclear weapons as a ''necessary evil,'' only to be lectured curtly by the Emperor about the devastation they cause.
In rare instances, what appear to be the Emperor's own misgivings about Japan's past have surfaced. Earlier this year, he went along with a strong apology to South Korea for Japan's 35-year subjugation of the Korean peninsula - a much stronger act of repentance than Hirohito ever made. Asked last year at a news conference about his country's record of military aggression, Akihito said, ''My heart aches when I think of the great many people at home and abroad who lost their lives or suffered pains in the last war.''
If anything, Akihito's well-known distrust of ultranationalists is seen as a kind of guarantee against their ever trying to overthrow the Government in his name. More troublesome politically, then, is not the right wing's embrace of the Emperor but the way his status is used and supported by the Liberal Democratic Party, which has controlled the Government since 1955 and has always faithfully served conservative and right-wing interests.
In recent years, the ruling party has turned increasingly to the right, moving to restore patriotism and traditional values in a way that has struck some as a reminder that Japan has yet to digest its past. For example, the ruling party supports the whitewashed versions in Japanese school textbooks of the World War II offensive against China, Korea and other victims of Japanese aggression. And many Asian leaders were shocked at the time of Hirohito's death when then Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita declared that it was up to future historians to decide whether Japan was the aggressor in the war.
Former Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, who created a stir in 1987 when he visited a Tokyo shrine to Japanese military heroes of World War II, is a favorite of the right in Japan. But a longtime acquaintance of Akihito said that the Emperor had once expressed disapproval of him.
A year and a half ago, Japan went through what was called a period of self-restraint while Hirohito lay dying, with businesses canceling New Year's parties and stores forgoing holiday window displays. But some Japanese accused the Government of encouraging an atmosphere of coercion that led to such actions. Other critics claimed that the ruling party took a reactionary step toward establishing Shinto as a state religion by holding a Shinto funeral for the Emperor in front of foreign dignitaries, although behind a screen.
By far the most controversial action by the Liberal Democratic Party has been its decision to spend $15 million in public funds for the religious part of Akihito's enthronement. (A secular ritual is to occur on Nov. 12 with 2,500 people attending, including Vice President Dan Quayle, the Prince and Princess of Wales and many heads of state.) The dispute revolves around the quasi-religious ceremony on Nov. 22, when the Emperor engages in purification rites and spends the night alone, eating specially prepared rice, praying for a bountiful harvest and communing with the gods.
Critics say the ceremony - known as a daijosai, roughly translated as ''great food-offering festival'' - should be dispensed with because its traditional function was to create a living god. Some Shinto specialists claim there are secret parts of the ceremony in which the Emperor simulates sex with the sun goddess.
The Government denies these contentions, and Akihito's friends say he himself has no illusions about being a deity. But many people still see the entire ceremony - not to mention the public financing of it - as an affront to the Constitution. At the very least, critics say, it signifies the ruling party's embrace of conservative forces in Japan. Indeed, a senior adviser at the Imperial Palace acknowledged in an interview that the decision to make the daijosai a public event was influenced by ''the strong conservative politicians and lobbyists who pull the strings from behind the scenes in this Government.''
A group of lawyers has announced a lawsuit to block the ceremony, and leftists and Christian organizations are also lobbying against it. In a powerful plea, four presidents of Christian colleges warned that the ceremony would be seen ''as a movement toward a return to imperial divine sovereignty'' in Japan. After their statement, right-wingers fired bullets into the house of one college president.
Few people in Japan think there is even a slight chance of Japan returning to militarism, even with the nationalist leanings of its political leadership. But some worry that with its rising economic power, Japan could adopt a more nationalist, and perhaps confrontational, approach on trade and other issues. The Government dismisses the fears about Japanese arrogance and the establishment of a state religion as baseless, asserting that most Japanese see the daijosai as a mere harvest festival of thanksgiving. ''Even if the Government is spending money for the ceremony, it does not mean it is supporting religion,'' Nobuo Ishihara, deputy chief secretary of the Cabinet, told me. ''Besides, the majority of the Japanese people feel the Government should spend as much as needed for the ceremony.''
Although no one thinks the Emperor will be vested with real political power in the foreseeable future, some experts do not rule out such a possibility in another generation or two, if only to make him a real, rather than symbolic, head of state to guarantee stability, like some Western monarchs.
Akihito, like all monarchs, is being constantly challenged to adjust public obligations to private pressures. The Imperial Household Agency, for example, is stumbling now to find a bride for Crown Prince Naruhito, a search that insiders say is difficult because of the horror stories about the treatment of Empress Michiko. Popular magazines are having a field day publishing profiles of possible candidates, along with their supposed defects and assets. The search for an appropriate bride for the Crown Prince is vital to the survival of the imperial system, which can only renew itself through such events as the wedding last June of Aya, the younger son, to the popular Kiko Kawashima, the daughter of an economics professor.
Given the dark legacy of war, the Japanese Emperor is always likely to be shadowed by history in ways that the other monarchs of the world are not, but he also draws on Japan's unusual cultural affinities.
The long sense of their own uniqueness - a quality of the Japanese many outsiders find both seductive and dangerous - seems to rest on the tremendous sense of gratitude the Japanese feel toward their parents and ancestors. I know many people who in one breath say that the Emperor is irrelevant to their lives and that Akihito is not especially impressive, but in the next say that he reminds them of their amazingly strong bond to history and their distinctive character.
Perhaps the mystery was summed up best when I was watching the Emperor create an undeniable emotional effect on crowds in Nagasaki.
''From his face, you can see that the Emperor loves peace,'' says Hideoki Ogawa, a 44-year-old electrician. ''He represents something precious but fragile, the fact that our blood has continued for 2,000 years in this one man, that we are Japanese and this is our homeland. If we deny him, we deny ourselves.''

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: August 26, 1990

SECTION: Section 6; Page 67, Column 3; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 1146 words

HEADLINE: Men's Style;
A STORE IS BORN

BYLINE: BY RUTH LA FERLA

 BODY:
You don't have to be a romantic to sell men's clothing in Manhattan. But it helps. Consider Alan Flusser, whose recently opened Wall Street-area tailor shop is a florid evocation of old England. There are trellis-patterned carpets, chintz-covered chairs and an old-fashioned sofa in which customers can wallow as they ponder the distinction between a chalk and a pin stripe.
Or take Ermenegildo Zegna. When this scion of the family-owned Italian men's-wear business opened his first American store in July, he chose as its site a regal town house on Fifth Avenue. ''We wanted the store to look residential,'' says Randall Iserman, Zegna's manager. Clients can sip San Pellegrino and try on suits amid overstuffed furniture and walnut cabinetry. 
But retailing's ultimate romantic may well be Ira Neimark, Bergdorf Goodman's dapper chairman, a man with a very particular vision. Bergdorf Goodman Men, which opens this week at 745 Fifth Avenue, just across the street from its long-established sister, is a sumptuously appointed amalgam of shop, men's club and Old World hotel.
Not just any Old World hotel. Neimark has carefully tutored the store's designers, retail-space specialists James and Christine Nakaoka, in the distinction between garishness and graciousness. It is the difference, he likes to point out, between certain Paris hotels, where the clatter of heels on marble floors heralds one's arrival, and those where every footfall is absorbed by spongy carpeting.
Working with Angela Patterson, Bergdorf's vice president and director of store design, the California-based design team seemed to anticipate Neimark's subtlest whims. For the most part, they dispensed with mahogany paneling - a design cliche in men's retailing - and substituted gray limousine-cloth walls, vaulted ceilings and woodwork that varies in hue from ash to eggplant. The results - simultaneously soothing and intimidating - echo the main store's most distinctive features.
''We tried to create a mood of height and hush,'' says James Nakaoka - no negligible feat in a store with only three floors and 40,000 square feet of selling space. The centerpiece is a two-story rotunda, which lends Bergdorf's men's store its grandeur and defines its spirit as eminently classical.
This suits Neimark perfectly. ''We are not just expanding,'' he declares. ''We are adding a major traditional business.'' Indeed, Bergorf's men's-wear business, once perceived by some industry experts as catering chiefly to an avant-garde clientele, has now widened its reach. Cutting-edge designers like Giorgio Armani, Gianfranco Ferre, Dolce & Gabbana, Luciano Barbera and Dries van Noten have been assigned to the new store's top floor. In true haberdasher's style, the main-floor rotunda and surrounding alcoves house accessories by prestigious traditional makers like Charvet, W. H. Giddin, Ferragamo, Hermes and Chanel. Turnbull & Asser, the venerable London shirtmaker, has moved from its old nesting place in Bergdorf's main store to its two-story, Edwardian-flavored headquarters at Bergdorf Goodman Men. The rest of the store has been subdivided into individual showcases for suits, coats and sportswear by Ralph Lauren, Alan Flusser, Willis & Geiger, Etro and others who tread the fine line between fashion and tradition.
Custom clothing represents a minor portion of what Neimark projects will be a $40 million business. The store also carries top-quality handmade suits from Oxxford, St. Andrews and such relatively unsung makers as Kiton. A cashmere Kiton suit carries a $2,000 price tag - high, but not scandalously so in a store where a $650 suit is a bargain.
For this, Neimark makes no apology. The men's store, a monument to opulence, is, as he is fond of saying, ''geared to those people who go to the best hotels, the best restaurants, the best clubs and the best resorts.'' Amenities proliferate, some practical, some shamelessly pretentious. The store maintains a shoeshine parlor, 20 cordless telephones, a clothing repair service and a barber shop, and it will open its doors at 8 A.M. if a customer requests it.
Bergdorf Goodman Men also boasts its own concierge, but retailing old-timers are not impressed. ''Every guy that works for me is a concierge, a personal shopper,'' insists Murray Pearlstein, the president of Louis, Boston, on East 57th Street, one of Bergdorf's chief competitors. Clifford Grodd, the president of Paul Stuart, points out that his Madison Avenue store always opens its doors at 8 A.M. ''That's our shoeshine,'' he says. ''The idea that you can charge anything in your store, as long as you package it well, doesn't work anymore,'' he adds ominously. Still, retailing experts acknowledge that as more stores compete for upscale customers, men's retailing will inevitably become a ritual of seduction. Like the decor, which customarily includes well-worn Oriental rugs, brass fixtures and, in Bergdorf's case, waxy marble fireplaces, the service level at these stores tends to emulate that of an old-fashioned gentleman's outfitter. Alan Flusser, who pioneered the concept of the men's store as an exclusive club in New York, believes in the intuitive sell. To Flusser, the ideal salesman has been educated to look a man over, speak to him briefly without mentioning clothes and, based on this fleeting encounter, pick out the perfect swatch or suit.
There's a lot to be said for such cosseting, maintains Kurt Barnard, the publisher of Barnard's Retail Marketing Report. He points out that even in today's uncertain economy, there are more men willing and able to buy a $1,500 suit than there were 10 years ago. ''They want to be elegant, and they want to be catered to,'' he says.
All this bodes well for the luxury retailer - and for Bergdorf Goodman in particular. William J. Flatley, a retail analyst with the consulting firm Kurt Salmon Associates, which monitors the apparel industry, maintains that although suit prices have jumped in recent years, the man being wooed by Bergdorf's won't feel the pinch. ''Clothing is an integral part of his personality and life style,'' Flatley says. ''He doesn't settle for second best. He's looking for design leaders and trend setters. And he's willing to pay for that.''
And to be entertained in the process. Bergdorf's identifies its customer as one who views dressing well as something akin to a moral obligation, yet wants to look conspicuously relaxed in the act of consumption. Perhaps that's why Neimark furnished Bergdorf's pro shop with a putting green, where customers can practice between dressing-room visits. ''I was always impressed with the kind of man who plays golf,'' Neimark explains, recalling his first visits in the 1940's to Westchester's exclusive golf clubs. ''As we used to say in those days, 'He is diligent to his family, diligent to his God and diligent to his game.' ''

Randall Iserman, the manager of Zegna's first American store, is a model of Milanese style, from his peaked lapels to his suede shoes. Alan Flusser ''at home'' in his shop, where a sofa, flowered carpets and chintz-covered chairs suggest a British sitting room. (Photographs by Burk Uzzle/Lee Gross Associates for The New York Times)
