The New York Times

PUB-DATE: August 26, 1990

SECTION: Section 7; Page 1, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1836 words

HEADLINE: Give Law a Chance

BYLINE: By ROGER ROSENBLATT; Roger Rosenblatt, the author of ''Children of War,'' is a columnist for Life magazine and an essayist for ''The MacNeil/Lehrer Newshour.''

 BODY:

ON THE LAW OF NATIONS
By Daniel Patrick Moynihan.
211 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:
Harvard University Press.
$22.50.
Once I'd made up my mind about ''On the Law of Nations,'' an elegant and persuasive history-cum-argument about international law, I decided to break an international law of book reviewing, the one that says the reviewer must keep his distance from the author at all times. With the Persian Gulf about to go haywire, I called Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York to ask how the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait fit into his thoughts. This was Monday, Aug. 6, the day after the Foreign Minister of Iraq's proxy government in Kuwait responded to the growing world outrage by warning that ''these countries should . . . not expect us to act honorably at a time when they are conspiring against us and other brothers in Iraq in an aggressive way.'' It was also the day after President Bush vowed: ''This will not stand. This will not stand, this aggression against Kuwait.'' 
By the end of that Monday, the United Nations Security Council would have voted military and economic sanctions against Iraq, presenting the rare and satisfying televised sight of the United States and the Soviet Union joined against an enemy in common. By Wednesday, America would be sending troops to protect Saudi Arabia, and Iraq would announce the annexation of Kuwait. By Friday, the Arab states would have met in Cairo to tell Iraq to get out of Kuwait and to vote to send combined Arab forces to join Western forces.
Before most of this happened, Senator Moynihan said: ''Know what I'd do? First, cut off the pipelines. Second, stop all imports of food. Iraq is the largest importer of U.S. rice, you know. Third, ask the Saudis if they are prepared to call for a collective response. Fourth, use military force but sparingly, in a naval blockade. We can influence the world through the U.N. If there were ever a time to use international law, here it is.''
As for President Bush's appeal for international law, made at Aspen, Colo., the week before, Senator Moynihan approved wholeheartedly, adding, ''I'm glad he's heard of it.''
Since many more people have heard of international law than know what it is, here's one definition, from David Scheffer, an international lawyer and senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace in Washington: ''International law is the body of binding rules of conduct among nations, expressed in treaties, in consistent and established behavior by nations, in the writings of distinguished scholars and in the rulings of judicial bodies.'' A sort of floating court, but a real one.
The Senator's responses to my questions, including his poke at the President, were what one would expect of the author of ''On the Law of Nations.'' Senator Moynihan demonstrates convincingly that since the 18th century, American leaders and thinkers have honored the ideals of international law, conduct to the contrary notwithstanding. In the modern Presidential era, however, even the pretense of reverence has been dropped. ''What happened?'' asks Senator Moynihan. ''How did a subject once so central to our thinking about world affairs become seemingly so peripheral?'' The paradox he explores, and regrets, is that after Woodrow Wilson ''governments became legitimate only as they could show that they were democratic,'' yet once the world did grow more democratic, international law lost its urgency and attractiveness.
His history creates his thesis: ''The United States is moving away from its long-established concern for and advocacy of international legal norms of state behavior.'' His thesis creates his argument: adherence to international law is the way to insure safe, civilized and intellectually proper behavior as we approach the next century. I add ''intellectually proper'' because one hears a sardonic, righteous anger in the book's voice, which, like the Senator's public-speaking voice, has the tentative assertiveness of the impassioned professor who suspects no one's listening.
Between the lines, Senator Moynihan is clearly fuming that an idea as morally impeccable as international law is routinely regarded as disposable and naive. His book is not only a forceful elucidation of the subject; it is a cri de tete of a man who often sees things more accurately than others, while others snigger at his frustrations or hurl impertinent accusations.
So it was in 1965 when Mr. Moynihan wrote in his report on the disintegration of the black American family, ''The children of our slums are being savagely cheated by a society which thinks it is too sophisticated to care about whether children have fathers and mothers have husbands.'' For that he was called racist. Before anyone else he (and his former Harvard colleague Nathan Glazer) understood how certain well-intentioned liberal social programs, such as busing, were hurting those they were invented to help. For that he was called reactionary. Small wonder the Senator always bears the dazed look of a sleepy baby. For his espousal of the principles of international law he will probably be called a mush-head - but not at the Iraqi moment, of course, not when the principles of international law are useful and convenient to the United States and much of the world community.
The whole argument over the efficacy of international law is in fact illuminated at moments like the Iraqi conflict. Why, say those who oppose the idea, should we accept international restraints when the other side won't abide by them? Mr. Moynihan quotes John Norton Moore writing in Foreign Affairs 10 years before the United States invasion of Grenada: ''International law is thought of as saying what cannot be done,'' that is, as an impediment to national security decisions. International law ''is an ass,'' wrote the columnist Charles Krauthammer in The New Republic, echoing Dickens's Mr. Bumble, because ''it cannot imagine the infinite capacity of nation-states for duplicity, mendacity and malice.''
Mr. Moynihan counters that one nation-state's malice is another's foreign policy, and law offers the best way to deal with the difference. He condemns as self-defeating and plain wrong the United States mining of the Nicaraguan harbors in March 1984, over which he resigned in protest from the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence, claiming the group was not consulted by the Reagan Administration. Similarly, he disapproves of the Grenada invasion and, most recently, of the assault on Panama and the arrest of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. Going to the trouble of amassing world opprobrium legally through the United Nations, he told me on the phone, may not give as much immediate ''pleasure as a weekend in Panama,'' but in the long run it works better for a stabilized world.
Unfortunately, one of the customs of international law forbids crossing a nation's borders to apprehend a criminal without the consent of his Government. That consent would have been a diplomatic feat in the case of General Noriega, who was his Government. One assumes Senator Moynihan would still stand by the principle.
Here's the anomaly, as well as the end point of his history lesson. Mr. Moynihan writes of those earlier American violations: ''As the United States became more committed to the advancement of democratic values in the world at large, it came more and more to do so by means of covert strategies. . . . This is not difficult to explain; it is difficult to defend. It costs too much, it achieves too little; and it gives power to presidents to do things that come to seem merely extralegal, rather than illegal. Not lawless, simply above the law. The intelligence community cannot help but make presidents feel this is what they are there for.''
The advancement of democratic values is the gut motive of this book. If the Senator appears a zealot for his cause (he has pushed it before, in a 1984 book, ''Loyalties,'' and recently in advocating that Lithuania's claims for independence be taken up by the World Court), it is because he believes that if America wants to show the rest of the world how to live, it must - as we are doing with Iraq - take advantage of the law at the same time it exercises its power.
He admires Presidents Wilson and Franklin D. Roosevelt, who, while frequently breaking the rules of international law themselves, nonetheless envisioned the world's eventual compliance. He admires considerably less President Ronald Reagan, who also broke international law but seemed to disdain it as a hindrance to beating up on evil empires wherever they were found, or were thought to be found - in freedom's name. Senator Moynihan may be suspending judgment on President Bush after Iraq. With dreams go responsibilities. The best way to promote democracy, implies the Senator, is to act lawfully.
That said, ''On the Law of Nations'' does not answer a question that the less expert among us find a lot more troubling than accepting Mr. Moynihan's argument. I have no difficulty understanding why it is good and right for the United States to confer with other nations and proceed through the United Nations Security Council before it moves against Iraq. I do have a problem understanding why the same moral recourse to international standards is not applied to situations such as Pol Pot's Cambodia or to the murderous civil war in Liberia this summer.
Why do we leap so furiously into the fray when money is at issue, as it is in Kuwait, and not when the matter is human life? A little irony of the Liberian situation is that while international law recognizes the right to rescue a few stranded internationals caught in the slaughterhouse, as we did in Monrovia, it does not recognize the right to stop the interior slaughter.
International lawyers see a logical collision between the principle of humanitarian intervention and the inviolability of national borders. The Nuremberg trials may have established the right to act against international criminals, but the world never used the Nuremberg precedent to create an international criminal court. It is hard to imagine nations signing a pact permitting external intervention - the United States certainly would not allow any world body to interfere with the prerogatives of Congress and the supreme law of the Constitution. Still, the question, when it arises, is urgent: will international law find an acceptable rationale to protect human rights when the lives of millions are at stake?
Mr. Bumble called the law ''a ass.'' Dr. Johnson called it ''the last result of human wisdom acting upon human experience for the benefit of the public.'' Senator Moynihan sides with Dr. Johnson. To the Senator the emphasis on Dr. Johnson's definition ought to be on ''last,'' since in the end Mr. Moynihan is calling for patience on the part of power, the exertion of wisdom over frustration. Not that such conduct on our part will ever rid the world of scoundrels. But it will make it easier to tell them from us.

HEADLINE: Middle-Class Radical

BYLINE: By DIANE McWHORTER; Diane McWhorter is writing a history of the civil rights movement in Birmingham, Ala.

 BODY:

BLACK IN SELMA
The Uncommon Life of J. L. Chestnut Jr.
By J. L. Chestnut Jr. and Julia Cass.
Illustrated. 432 pp. New York:
Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $22.95.
In the landmark towns of the movement, civil rights history is being rewritten. Unsung local heroes in Montgomery, Birmingham and Selma - where the bloody marches of 1965 inspired the Federal Voting Rights Act - have abandoned the heraldic story of Martin Luther King Jr. for the equally extraordinary day-in-and-day-out record of hometown life. The autobiography of J. L. Chestnut Jr., now 60 years old (a year younger than Dr. King would have been), is the story of Selma's first black lawyer and prodigal son, but it is also part of the history of the race, sweeping biblically from enslavement by segregation to freedom to the ambiguous aftermath of redemption. 
Mr. Chestnut grew up as a saxophone-playing cardsharp son of Alabama's schizoid black middle class. Branded early as a radical ''race man,'' in high school he wrote a paper slamming Selma's most powerful black, a shiny-suited Baptist minister, as a lackey of the white establishment. Coming home from Howard University Law School in the segregationist gloom of the late 1950's, Mr. Chestnut was like a rogue elephant in eerily placid Selma, where no one found it weird that a local black sleeping car porter returning from an out-of-town run had to check and see if a police car was parked in front of his house and then kill time till the white cop concluded his social call inside.
The first third of ''Black in Selma'' is a wicked, anecdotal diagnosis of segregation's sadomasochistic pathology. As the paradoxical ''nigger lawyer,'' Mr. Chestnut was in a privileged position to see into the souls of white folk, notably the soon-to-be-legendary, cattle-prod-happy Sheriff Jim Clark and his fabulously warped, blue-blooded handler, Circuit Judge James Hare. An amateur student of African history, Judge Hare lamented to Mr. Chestnut - whom he cordially considered a fellow, if lesser, intellectual - that Selma's blacks were descended from the most ''backward'' of the jungle tribes, the Ibos and the Congolese. When Mr. Chestnut laughed during one of his speeches on the telltale color of the gums or jut of the heel, Judge Hare pouted: ''Nothing is sacred to you, James.'' (J.L., not James, is Mr. Chestnut's given name, his father, J.L. Sr., having been named after a white banker his mother admired.) Mr. Chestnut's portrait of the sacred local customs would seem to be building inevitably to black Selma's rendezvous with destiny and Sheriff Clark's mounted posse on the Edmund Pettus Bridge. But ironically the narrative loses some of its authority at what ought to be its peak, the ''Bloody Sunday'' assaults on voting rights demonstrators at the bridge and the ensuing march to Montgomery. At the time, Mr. Chestnut tells us, he was hostage to a whisky habit, to the point of voluntarily sleeping off his benders at the city jail and then hollering about his constitutional rights the morning after. More significant, perhaps, he was on the wrong side of a major strategic split in the evolution of the movement. As a lawyer, and partisan of the N.A.A.C.P.'s glacial tactics of battling injustice in the courts, he only passively supported the massive civil disobedience pioneered by Dr. King - whose treatment here is almost absurdly anticlimactic. (''In the meantime, up popped Martin Luther King, Jr.'') In this crucial middle section, Mr. Chestnut's co-author, Julia Cass, a reporter for The Philadelphia Inquirer, misses the opportunity to dramatize and globalize his story. She has done a worthy job of shaping his vivid raw material into a life that moves between autobiography and oral history, elegant prose and colloquial outburst. But Ms. Cass's journeymanlike introductions to the book's chronologically arranged sections refuse to capitalize on Selma's sublime place in the history of the movement - curious for a book trading on that connection. (''Black in Tuscaloosa'' would not quite do the trick.) So the fascinating Hare-Clark-Chestnut relationship, for example, never transcends insider tidbit to become historical revelation.
Mr. Chestnut went on the wagon in time to be a real player in the next phase of the movement: translating the right to vote into political power. After joining forces in the early 1970's with two committed young black Harvard Law graduates, Hank and Rose Sanders, he became one of Alabama's leading civil rights lawyers, shepherding rural blacks into elective office. The difficulties he faced, though they may not be glamorously tragic enough for the general reader, confirm Alabama's role as America's crucible for race relations. In Mr. Chestnut's view, one goal is to forge a working relationship between black political power and white economic power, yet he reminds us of the quotation from the 19th-century abolitionist Frederick Douglass: ''Power concedes nothing without a demand.''
In the continuing absence of black economic progress, can black leaders keep their constituents motivated without turning to demagogy? The diminishing returns of the longstanding protest over the dismissal this year of Selma's first black school superintendent imply a stalemate in the win-lose dynamic that has characterized past civil rights struggles. As the Mississippi gentleman poet William Alexander Percy said of Southern politics long ago, ''Nothing is so sad as defeat, except victory.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: J. L. Chestnut Jr. and the Rev.Jesse Jackson in 1984. (From ''Black in Selma'')

HEADLINE: VIEWS OF SPORT;
A Fond Look at 'a Sport for Everyone'

BYLINE: By DAVID N. DINKINS; David N. Dinkins, the Mayor of New York City, is an avid tennis player.

 BODY:
MOST people who know me are aware of my fondness for the sport of tennis. I was first introduced to the game more than 40 years ago in Trenton by my good friend Dr. Bill Hayling.
Bill, who also has the distinction of having delivered my two children, taught me how to hold a tennis racquet properly, and from that moment on, I became a die-hard fan of the sport.
In those days, tennis wasn't a very popular sport among African-Americans. Tennis courts, after all, weren't very accessible to us at that time. There was also a perception that African-Americans couldn't excel in tennis. In convincing form, Althea Gibson dispelled that myth by winning the United States national amateur singles title and the Wimbledon championships in 1957 and 1958. 
Ten years later, in 1968, my good friend Arthur Ashe won the first United States Open singles title, and he went on to win Wimbledon in 1975. What made Arthur's Open victory so remarkable was that 1968 marked the first year that the Open allowed amateur players to compete against professionals.
At that time, Arthur was an amateur. Few people believed that amateurs had a realistic chance of beating the professionals. Arthur stunned the sports world and won the tournament. It was tennis's version of David versus Goliath.
It was also a momentous occasion for African-Americans everywhere. Arthur's victories sent message to millions of Americans that tennis was a sport for everyone. His victory caught the attention of many African-American youths, inspiring them to learn more about the sport.
In 1969, one year after his Open victory, Arthur came up with Charlie Pasarell, one of the top-ranked Puerto Rican players in the world, to form the National Junior Tennis League to introduce tennis to millions of inner-city youths.
As a result of their efforts and the efforts of others such as Skip Hartman, Jim O'Neill, Bill Davis, and Brother George Roth, who formed the New York Junior Tennis League in 1970, today more than 150,000 New York City schoolchildren, many of them members of minority groups, in 340 public elementary and middle schools are introduced to tennis each year. This success is attributable, in part, to the generous contribution of the United States Tennis Association, headed by David Markin.
In addition to the schools tennis program, the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation provides free tennis programs each summer to more than 8,000 young people at 40 sites.
These programs teach our young people more than just tennis. They reinforce values such as discipline, courteousness, good sportsmanship, team spirit and responsibility. And they provide our young people with an alternative to the streets and allow them to release creative energy in a positive way.
And because many of these programs are held within our schools, they teach our children the importance of a good education and encourage them to stay in school.
Of course, these programs also teach inner-city youths, especially those who are members of minority groups, about the wonderful game of tennis. And they are proving themselves to be quick studies. The national junior rankings indicate that players from minority groups are emerging as a force to be reckoned with in the tennis world.
In fact, the top-ranked players in the under-age-14 category in the boys' and girls' divisions are African-American. And 4 of the top 10 juniors in the boys 14's category and 2 of the top 10 juniors in the girls 14's category are members of minority groups.
I am encouraged by these developments and look forward to seeing these youngsters display their talents on the professional scene and make their mark on the record books.
This week, the United States Open tennis championships will be held at the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows, Queens. The Open has been a tremendous boon to New York City's economy, generating more than $100 million in revenues to our hotels, restaurants, shops and places of entertainment annually.
Moreover, the quality of its competitors and the 450,000 tennis fans it draws each summer from here and abroad reaffirm New York's status as a world capital. Millions of tennis fans will see one of the most thrilling competitions in sports history. More than 250 of the world's best players will compete in this international tournament.
This year, Open fans have one more reason to cheer. The Federal Aviation Administration has graciously agreed to alter its flight patterns. This means there will be less noise and fewer distractions during the tournament.
I am pleased that my administration was able to assist the United States Tennis Association on this sensitive but very important problem. I supported this because the Open and the U.S.T.A. are an integral part of New York City.
The tournament has been held in New York City for the last 60 years, and it has grown and prospered here. Our city has contributed a superb mass-transportation infrastructure to the tournament, offering railroads, subways, and bus service directly to a major stadium. We are also the sports, entertainment and media capital of the world, thus enabling tens of millions of people to view the games both here and abroad.
Moreover, New Yorkers have a rich history of involvement in making the Open tournament the finest in the world today. Many New York leaders have made enormous contributions to the tournament.
As Mayor, and as a dedicated fan of the game, I am committed to working with the U.S.T.A. to insure that the United States Open tournament remains in New York City and retains its status as the most prestigious and exciting sporting event in the world.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Outdoors;
Prices Ebb at Tackle Auction

BYLINE: By Nelson Bryant

 BODY:
ANTIQUE fishing tackle and related paraphernalia, including fish decoys, continue to capture the fancy of collectors, but record-breaking prices are apparently a thing of the past, at least for the time being.
At the recent R. W. Oliver's summer auction in Kennebunk, Me., 1,028 auction lots fell only a few thousand dollars short of the presale low estimate of $488,000, but that was largely a result of the good showing made by gear in the middle-to-lower price ranges.
Big-ticket items, among them handcrafted split-bamboo trout rods, did not do as well as anticipated, and the 51 fish decoys in the auction went for 10 percent less than the presale estimate, averaging $850 each. (All prices mentioned in this article include a 10 percent buyer's premium.) Fish decoys, which are dangled through holes cut in ice on lake or river to lure larger predatory species within spearing range, had been fetching fancy prices over the last few years. That, plus the interest shown in them by those who attended this year's eight-week fish decoy exhibition at the Museum of American Folk Art in New York City, had led auction officials to anticipate more spirited bidding. 
There was, however continued lively interest in early Lake Chautaqua, N.Y., decoys. A nine-inch perch of that genre, the first item on the block, went for $4,125. It was in near-mint condition and was probably fashioned just after the Civil War. Eleven of the 21 New York State decoys went for more than $1,000 each.
As might be expected, fish decoys made by Oscar Peterson did well, with only one, which was damaged, being bought for less than $1,000. The highest price paid for a Peterson fish in the auction was $2,530. Peterson (1887-1951) grew up hunting and fishing on the Lower Peninsula of Michigan,and he spent more than half a century carving and painting decoys. He may have created more than 10,000 decoys in his lifetime, of which perhaps 2,000 are still in existence. His work is assessed in Ron Fritz's color-illustrated book, ''Michigan's Master Carver'' (Aardvark Publications Inc., 104 pages, hardcover, $60).
Aardvark has published other books on antique fish decoys and antique lures. Its address is P.O. Box 252, Boulder Junction, Wis. 54512. The telephone number is (715) 385-2862.
There were 287 reels in the auction. They averaged $608 each, exceeding the lower range of their presale estimates.
Fly reels and bait-casting reels are the reels that interest collectors the most. Some early spinning reels do appear in auctions, but they have not, as yet, been major items. Early versions of the spinning reels that are in use today didn't appear in this country until after World War II.
As was expected, fly reels did best, averaging $750 each. The top fly reel, for salmon, went for $7,150, making it the most expensive item in the auction. It was a Hardy ''Cascapedia,'' size 3/0, in near-perfect condition.
Only about 100 of these reels were made. They date to the 1930's. A Vom Hofe Model 360 ''Perfection'' fly reel, for trout, fetched $6,050, and 11 fly reels by the contemporary maker Stan Bogdan ranged from $990 to $1,870. Bogdan, who lives in Nashua, N.H., is often in the strange situation of seeing his reels auctioned off at twice, thrice, or more, than he charged for them.
The highest-priced bait-casting reel in the Oliver auction was a J. F. & B. F. Meek that went for $5,500.
Lures also exceeded their presale low estimates, going for an average of about $180 each. The highest-priced lure was a 1916 Miller's Reversible Minnow at $1,650.
The top fly rod was a profusely engraved H. L. Leonard eight-foot Hunt 50-4 Model that sold for $5,500. Even so, the catalogue estimate of its value was $6,000 to $7000, and the large selection - 53 in all -of Leonard rods in the sale ran, as a group, 15 percent below their presale low estimate.
In all, there were about 200 rods in the auction, many more than in any previous Oliver's auction, and that may have contributed to the depressed bidding.
Offbeat angling items often appeal to collectors. As an example, the catalogue value of an Ideal Float & Tackle Company salesman's sample case containing lines, sinkers and bobbers was set at $275 to $375. It went for $1,320.
Until a year or so ago, record prices for rods, reels and lures were commonplace at auctions. In assessing the results of the Oliver's auction, Bob Lang, the company's tackle consultant, said the trend had been broken. He said this might be a ''result of a worsening economic environment and maturing collections.''
Oliver's conducts the only major fishing-tackle auctions in the country, having begun them in 1985. Serious collector interest in antique tackle began about 20 years ago. The company's next major tackle auction will be its annual ''High Rollers'' affair in February, held in conjunction with Ben Clark's Northeast Antique Angler's Show.

STATE: MICHIGAN, USA (90%); NEW YORK, USA (70%); 

CITY: NEW YORK, NY, USA (55%);

LENGTH: 1958 words

HEADLINE: College '90;
Headed in New Directions

BYLINE: By MALCOLM MORAN

 BODY:
Back in those carefree days when we could count on the college football season starting some time after the beginning of the fall semester, when we could make our tailgating plans based on 1:30 kickoffs that had been chiseled in stone months before, and when we didn't need an announcement to know who would be in the Southwest Conference for the foreseeable future, even back then, there was this problem.
The problem was that unless we had spent four years of our lives in those quaint, romantic, leafy, hidden towns where many of these games are played, we often needed a map to find our way or we would wind up at a gas station, trying to remember directions to College Ave.
And now? Now that the college football landscape seems to undergo a fundamental change every other week, we need maps and directions just to get through a season. From the inaugural Disneyland Pigskin Classic between Tennessee and Colorado today at Anaheim, Calif., until the Army-Navy game Dec. 8, the 122d season can be expected to reflect the upheaval and uncertainty that preceded it.
Some obvious stops can be reached with simple directions. Major conference championships and nationalpoll implications could depend on the outcomes of games between Clemson and Virginia on Sept. 8, Tennessee and Auburn on Sept. 29, Colorado and Nebraska on Nov. 3, and Michigan and Illinois on Nov. 10. 
Texas and Oklahoma will struggle over their badly devalued bragging rights in Dallas on Oct. 13, if for no other reason than to provide an excuse for the mob that will insist on stumbling along Commerce St. the night before. That same afternoon, Penn State and Syracuse, which have met every year but one since 1922, will play for the final time in a series that became a victim of differing agendas.
But with the future of television deals uncertain, with underclassmen now free to leave when they decide the economic time is right, and with apparently imminent breaks in conference ties about to sever the emotional binds of decades, there may never have been so many questions:
Is the Arkansas outlook now directed toward the southwest, or the southeast? When Penn State joins the Big 10, how does one get from State College, Pa. to Iowa City? When will the Army-Navy game get a corporate sponsor? Does Notre Dame have enough money?
Since Southern Cal opens its season with Syracuse and Penn State, could the Trojans qualify for the Lambert Trophy as the outstanding team in the east? Is Traveler IV, the great, white Trojan horse, prepared for an appearance at East Rutherford, N.J.?
Do we really need 19 bowl games? And does anybody know how to get to College Ave.?
As we search for it, a road map though the season would include these stops along the way:
 
Sept. 8: A Ty For the Champions
The afternoon following Miami's Sugar Bowl victory last Jan. 1, just hours after the release of the news-service polls secured a third national championship in seven seasons, the date jumped off the Hurricane calendar: Sept. 8 - at Brigham Young.
For the third time, the Hurricanes would begin the defense of a championship with a high-profile game. (Miami defeated Auburn, with Bo Jackson, in 1984, and humiliated Florida State, with Deion Sanders, in 1988.) But most of all, the matchup provides a look at Brigham Young's Ty Detmer and Miami's Craig Erickson, the latest in parallel lines of outstanding passing quarterbacks at the two schools. Detmer's pass efficiency rating of 175.6 as a sophomore barely missed the National Collegiate Athletic Association record set by Jim McMahon of B.Y.U. in 1980.
 
Sept. 29: A Milestone for Tubby...
Not long before the start of his 25th season as the coach at Delaware, Tubby Raymond remembered his second season, a 2-7 year in 1967 during which someone mentioned something about winning 100 games. ''I said, 'A hundred wins? It'll take me 80 years to do that,' '' Raymond said. When the Blue Hens meet Rhode Island at Delaware Stadium on Sept. 29, a fourth straight victory would make Raymond the 21st coach, at any college level, with 200 victories, and the 12th to win that many at one school. ''I've always said I never won a game,'' he said. ''I never lost one, either. I'm along for the ride.''
The only imperfection in the coach's ride to No. 200, whenever it comes, is that his wife Sue will not be along. She died last April, after they had been married 38 years.
For 10 years, Sue Raymond taught English sign language at Delaware. She was 29 when she lost her hearing and made a discovery any coach's wife could understand. ''I could never appreciate how enjoyable a football game at Delaware Stadium could be until I lost my hearing,'' she once said. ''Now I can't hear the fans boo every week.''
 
Oct. 6: ... and Bowden, Too?
If Florida State is to produce the 200th victory of Bobby Bowden's 25-year career as a coach at Miami Oct. 6, the Seminoles will have to do it without Renegade. Renegade doesn't do road games.
Renegade III, an Appaloosa horse, will continue to create advantages in Tallahassee when he brings Chief Osceola to midfield to deposit a 10-foot flaming spear. His gallop last October, before the victory over Miami, seemed to be delayed when several Miami players appeared to block the horse's path.
But Bill Durham, a financial planner who conceived the idea and oversees the display, said both teams were in the way. ''Nobody wanted to leave the middle of the field,'' he said. ''If they don't leave the middle of the field, the horse won't come up in there.''
 
Oct. 20: Last Hurricane Warning?
The schedule says that Miami and Notre Dame will meet for the absolutely, positively last time on the afternoon of Oct. 20 at South Bend, when the inventive minds that introduced the concept of ''Catholics vs. Convicts'' will be given the opportunity to bid Miami farewell.
But before the young Domers say too many goodbyes, they should consider one reminder. This matchup, which prevented Notre Dame from winning a national championship last year and Miami the year before, will be automatically transferred into the marketplace, available to the most aggressive, highest-paying bidder of a bowl game without a conference affiliation. Like, say, the Fiesta? Maybe we should just pencil in a date in Tempe, Ariz., some prime-time evening in the first week of January, 1992.
 
Nov. 10: Making a Warmer Winter
When the sun begins to disappear before evening arrives and the leaves just disappear, before the big-time programs get around to the expensive business of defining their seasons, two games on Nov. 10 could carry a significance that is just as intense, if not as financially significant.
The game between Princeton and Yale could determine an Ivy League championship. Williams, which opens its season with a 13-game winning streak, will play at Amherst in a game that some of the alumni have been known to anticipate for months.
''They sometimes wonder how Amherst is going to be in the summer time,'' said Dick Farley, near the start of his fourth year as the coach at Williams and his 19th on the Williams staff. ''They ask at alumni reunions and golf outings. 'Who do they have coming back?' They don't seem to question too much the previous seven games.''
Last year Williams had to rally to preserve a perfect season. There was no championship, no league title, and no bowl game. No matter. ''You play seven other games,'' Farley said. ''You might not feel good about things. And if you win that, you can carry it through the winter.''
 
Nov. 24: The Last Bowl Charade
For the last time, invitations to bowl games will allegedly remain withheld until 6 P.M. on the third Saturday following the first Monday of November. After years of thinly-veiled arrangements and semantics games, a new, more realistic set of rules will be established for 1991.
The final zero hour, on Nov. 24, will be the end of an era. (One last complication: Notre Dame will play at U.S.C., after the deadline.) ''There's always been a question of what constitutes an invitation and what doesn't,'' said Don Meyers, the team selection chairman of the Sunkist Fiesta Bowl. ''We'd say, 'If we were to invite you to play in our game, and if we were to tell you your opponent would be Notre Dame, what would your position be?' It gets a lot more blunt than that.''
While coaches and athletic directors solicited invitations weeks ahead of time, the deadline became one of the most violated rules in collegiate sports. Faced with mounting pressures to establish a championship playoff, the bowls will remove the semantics from the process.
Meyers, for one, does not look forward to the passing of all the intrigue. ''It ran up everybody's phone bills,'' he said, ''but it's been a lot of fun.''
 
Dec. 1: Breaking Down a Wall
Auburn and Alabama will return to Legion Field in Birmingham on Dec. 1 for the 55th meeting in a long and often hateful series that began 98 years ago and changed forever last year. That was when Alabama played at Auburn for the first time, and lost a chance to compete for a national championship all in the same afternoon.
After the game, Bill Curry, following what became his next-to-last game as the Alabama coach, said that the deep disappointment his players felt at that moment might serve them one day should something truly significant go wrong.
Next up was Auburn Coach Pat Dye. The Auburn coach then went on to speak of the emotional significance of the Tiger Walk, the ritual that has the team stroll from its athletic dorm through its adoring crowds to Jordan-Hare Stadium.
''I'm sure that it must have resembled what went on the night the wall came down in Berlin,'' Dye said.
Little more than three weeks after young people had been drinking champagne atop the Berlin Wall, an audience of questioners stared at Dye, and then at each other. Is he really saying this? ''I mean, it was like they had been freed, and let out of bondage, just having this game at Auburn,'' Dye said. ''I can't imagine what it must have done to our players, and the effect it must have had on their emotion.''
Nearly nine months later, no one at Auburn or Alabama has been heard discussing the concept of unification.
 
Dec. 8 The Game Of His Life
After a one-year trip to the Meadowlands, the Army-Navy game will complete the season back home at Philadelphia, the traditional focal point of the armed services around the world for three hours on a cold Saturday afternoon.
This year, when the Cadets and Midshipmen meet in the 100th anniversary game at Veterans Stadium, Mike Burns will be able to look back at the day when the final football game of a painful, frustrating career became the game of his life.
After entering the Naval Academy as an enlisted man, Burns became a special teams player who suffered a broken leg on the opening kickoff of the 1988 Army game. Burns had gained 37 yards in his career before the game last season, with just 4 yards on 1 carry in 1989.
But as a starter for the first time in his career, Burns gained 57 yards on 8 carries against Army, including 20 yards in the drive that led to the game-winning field goal with 11 seconds to play.
A day later, his room in Bancroft Hall was lined with balloons and newspaper stories that included his name. After years of effort, watching football is not so painful for Burns anymore. ''I can come to grips a lot better after that game,'' he said from San Diego, where he attends surface-warfare school.
For the most important three hours of a Navy season, Burns was a hero, and he has the videotape to prove it. ''Although it has hit me, and I realize it's a great thing,'' he said, ''I think the actual cherishing moments are yet to come.''

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Vacancy Rates;
Black Monday's Fallout: An Emptiness Downtown

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
The shadow cast by Black Monday is growing longer and longer through the canyons of lower Manhattan, where commercial vacancy rates continue to climb higher than they have in years.
Meanwhile, the fresh crop of skyscrapers in west midtown continues to stand strikingly untenanted, with leasing at a snail's pace.
Almost three years after the stock market collapse of Oct. 19, vacancy rates in the heart of the Financial District - Broadway to the East River, the Battery to Liberty Street - have hit 23 percent for primary office buildings and 30.3 percent for secondary buildings, according to the Cushman & Wakefield brokerage. Throughout downtown, including the Financial District and other areas, the overall rate for both building classes was 18.5 percent in the second quarter.
The Edward S. Gordon Company reported an availability rate of 23.4 percent in the Financial District, which it defines as virtually everything south of Liberty Street. 
The vacancy rate for primary office buildings in west midtown is 19.2 percent, Cushman & Wakefield figures show. Gordon said the availability rate was 26.8 percent on the west side, in contrast to a 15.1 percent figure for mid-Manhattan as a whole.
New York is scarcely alone in the disarray of its commercial market. Many central business districts in the South and West have vacancy rates greater than Manhattan's, including Dallas, Denver, Houston, Memphis, Miami, Nashville and San Antonio.
Phoenix leads one list, with a rate of 29.3 percent. ''Phoenix has no zoning to speak of, so they just built much more than they could use,'' said Barbara Bennett, director of real-estate research at Cushman & Wakefield. (Other brokers, measuring different markets with different methods, come up with different rankings. The Grubb & Ellis Company, for example, puts Dallas at the top, with 22.3 percent, followed by Miami, Phoenix, San Diego and downtown Manhattan.) Although New York is not at the top in rates, the sheer amount of its vacant space dwarfs that of other cities. Depending on how one measures it, there may be from 45 million to 60 million square feet available in New York City. To picture 50 million square feet, imagine 22 Empire State Buildings, plus two Lever Houses. That is as much as the entire commercial real-estate inventory of the Seattle-Bellevue metropolitan area.
''Right now, the bottom is not in sight,'' said Stuart Lilien, executive vice president of the Lansco Corporation. ''There isn't any factor that's going to turn this market around in the near term.''
Lansco, a brokerage and consulting concern, has studied segments of the commercial market and found little in the way of growth potential. ''It seems like every company is undergoing a study on how they can eliminate employees or cut down overhead,'' Mr. Lilien said.
Even in the generally tattered economy, however, the ruins of the investment banking business stand out, together with the implications for downtown real estate.
Vacancies along Broad Street, where Drexel Burnham Lambert occupied hundreds of thousands of square feet before its collapse earlier this year, now exceed 30 percent, according to the Williams Real Estate Company. All told, more than 5 million square feet of space downtown has been vacated in the last year, Williams found.
''The Wall Street market has been devastated,'' Mr. Lilien said. ''People down there are shrinking, moving to New Jersey, moving to Brooklyn, moving up to midtown.''
The average asking rent downtown has dropped to $31.12 a square foot, from $32.76 in June 1989, according to figures from Gordon, which found that downtown space is almost $8 cheaper a square foot than midtown.
That might presage some fresh tenancies in lower Manhattan, although the commercial market there is rather ''inbred,'' in the words of Maurice H. Solomon, vice chairman of the Julien J. Studley real estate concern. Businesses from mid-Manhattan do not tend to migrate to the Wall Street area.
''I wouldn't be surprised if you saw some service companies or organizations going downtown - the deals are too good,'' Mr. Solomon said. ''Other than that, I don't see much hope for downtown. I think there's going to be more attrition in the financial markets. For the most part, you're going to see lean operations.''
''The only silver lining is that virtually no new office construction is coming on line'' to exacerbate downtown vacancies, said Brian Given, managing director of Williams. ''So hopefully the current supply will be absorbed over the next two to three years.''
Some of the hardest hit commercial properties are the older, smaller, secondary office buildings. In such structures downtown, the vacancy rate is 23.9 percent, according to Cushman & Wakefield.
Downtown is not alone in its woes. Nor are older buildings the only ones suffering.
Following is a list of new buildings, completed or under construction, in which more than half the space was reported available from July 30 to Aug. 3, according to a canvass by the Studley organization of leasing agents and owners. The names of developers, principals or owners are also given.
Discrepancies may exist, depending on the source. For example, Studley reported, from the leasing agent, that 505,300 square feet were available in Carnegie Hall Tower in early August. But the developers said a lease signed in June would have reduced the figure to 480,200. Last week, the developers said 460,200 square feet were available; the leasing agent reported 478,459 to Studley.

HEADLINE: Drawing Developers Into Day Care

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:
On weekday mornings, 3-year-old Carolyn Keen, sometimes with a cherished toy in tow, heads with her father, Robert, for the Heller Industrial Park in Edison, N.J., where he is a forklift operator at Linden Motor Freight Company.
She spends the day with 100 other children at the John F. Kenney Childcare Center in Heller Park while her mother, Diana, works as a medical receptionist.
The three-year-old center, built by the park's developer, Isaac Heller, is a bright, cheery school-like building whose colorful playground climbing equipment seems mirage-like next to buildings where companies like Emerson Quiet Kool, Baxter Travenol Laboratories and Polygram Records assemble and pack their products for distribution.
The $1 million day-care center is one of the small but growing number that have been built or paid for by developers at workplaces throughout the country. The need for such centers has become more critical as more women join the workforce and dual-career families become the norm. 
In New York City, the City Council and the leading real-estate trade group have recently offered proposals to encourage developers to join the effort to expand day-care options. If they are successful, there may one day be centers like the one Carolyn Keen attends in the city's office towers and industrial parks.
There is a model for successful workplace day care in Manhattan, although it was not built by a developer. Called Fed Kids, it was created for the children of Federal employees at 26 Federal Plaza in lower Manhattan. It is one of 50 centers set up around the country with money from the Government's General Services Administration. The 4,000-square-foot center has been carved out of space at 26 Federal Plaza that had been the building manager's office - he moved to the second floor - and ground-floor retail space.
One of the City Council proposals - a bill offered by Councilwoman Carolyn B. Maloney of Manhattan - would amend the city's Administrative Code to exempt from some real estate taxes most existing office and hotel buildings that add day-care centers.
Another bill, also introduced by Councilwoman Maloney, would require builders of new hotels and office space to provide day care on the premises or nearby, or to pay the city a fee. The bill would apply to most new buildings of more than 50,000 square feet and to older buildings that add that much space. The measure also specifies that the day-care centers be at least 3,000 square feet or .01 percent of the new or additional square footage, whichever is greater. Builders would have the option of paying a fee of $1 for each square foot of commercial space built or added.
In June the Real Estate Board of New York, the trade group representing most of the city's owners and builders, put forth its own plan for developing day care. Private builders, the board suggested, should be allowed to build six extra feet of commercial space beyond the zoning limit for each foot they set aside for a child-care center. The board's proposals were part of a package of suggestions intended to jump-start New York's sluggish economy.
There is no argument that the city has a pressing need for day-care centers. According to Child Care Inc., a nonprofit organization in Manhattan that helps private and public groups develop day-care programs, a 1987 survey showed there are 146,300 children under the age of five in New York City who are believed to need day care but only 46,300 places for them in licensed centers.
Yet even if one of the current proposals is adopted, it could be years before a single center is built. Not the least of the barriers to developer-led day care is the dramatic slowdown in construction projects in the city over the last year or so. Because the proposals are tied to new commerical development or expansion, a rising real estate market is crucial to any measurable success for the initiatives.
A day-care center is not as easy or as cheap to build as such other popular tenant amenities as health clubs and cafeterias. The most basic center must meet tough construction, health and safety standards, and there is the additional cost of operating and maintaining it. It costs about $10,000 a week, for example, to operate the center in Heller Industrial Park. This includes maintenance, equipment replacement and staff salaries. Half the costs are paid by Mr. Heller and monthly tuition, $260 for each child, pays the rest.
Still, a recent study by the Child Care Action Campaign shows that some communities have used real estate development projects to expand the number of day-care centers. Founded in 1983 by Elinor Guggenheimer, the former New York City Consumer Affairs Commissioner, the campaign is a national nonprofit organization that lobbies on behalf of children. Its report was researched and written by Caroline Eichman, Barbara Reisman and Donna Euben.
''So far, the impact of these types of programs seems to be relatively small,'' said Ms. Reisman, the group's executive director. ''But what we also saw is that there is a tremendous interest in many, many communities that are struggling for ways to fill the gap as state and local governments see their budgets shrink. And in some places people are looking to the private sector to help out with child-care financing.''
The campaign's tally found that requirements or rewards have led developers to build 35 day-care centers across the nation in the last five years, with space for an total of about 1,355 children.
More than 100 government officials, legislators, public and private planners, child-care providers and developers were interviewed for the report, entitled ''Building Links: Developer Initiatives for Financing Day Care.'' It is an inventory of the projects and an evaluation of their impact.
In some places, including the New York metropolitan area, the development of day-care centers in workplaces has been voluntary. Mr. Heller is one of several real-estate entreprenuers who have created these centers as amenities to attract commercial tenants.
But the authors also found other ways in which developers are being drawn into the effort to expand day-care options.
Some centers have been built as a result of legislative mandate. Dubbed ''linkage'' by planners, this method requires developers to build or provide space for day-care centers or to contribute to a child-care fund.
In 1985 San Francisco became the first major United States city to adopt a linkage law. It was part of the city's broad zoning changes, intended to control rapid growth downtown. Since then seven other cities or counties - six of them in California - have adopted forms of linkage.
Zoning incentives have also fostered day-care development. The most common reward for developers who provide day-care space or funds is letting them put up larger structures than zoning laws allow. Portland, Cincinnati, Seattle and Hartford are among the cities using such bonuses. Currently, the campaign report says, 14 cities are considering bonus or linkage initiatives and statewide bonus measures are being considered in Massachusetts and New Jersey.
Not surprisingly, the group found that developers are more inclined to support day-care initiatives when the instrument of encouragement is a carrot - like tax breaks or building bonuses - rather than a stick - space set-aside requirements or contributions to a day-care fund.
Some question, for example, the prudence of establishing day-care centers in office buildings because it often forces parents to take young children on buses or subways during rush hour.
Mrs. Guggenheimer, the 78-year-old campaign president, who often travels on New York's subways, agrees that the workplace is just one option.
''There are other places that would be suitable, like schools,'' she said. ''But when parents have no suitable day-care alternative near home, and there is a day-care center where they work, for many the question of taking children on trains or buses is not important.''
Critics of linkage say that developers alone should not have to pay for a social service that is universally needed and used.
''I think that most resistance is dissolving,'' said Steven Trainer, a senior vice president of Wright-Rumstad Development Company in Seattle, which put a day-care center in the base of one of its downtown office buildings, Washington Mutual Tower, two years ago. ''Developers are begining to see the advantages from both a maketing and public relations perspective.''
Mr. Trainer said his company had thought about including such a center in the million-square-foot building even before Seattle adopted a building bonus day-care ordinance in 1985. The ground-floor center in the Wright-Rumstad building is just under 2,000 square feet and cares for 50 children 6 months to 2 1/2 years old.
To qualify for the bonus, which in Seattle allows an extra 3 1/2 to 16 square feet for each square foot of day-care space, the company paid to build the center and pays to maintain it. The city's bonus ratios are based on the size of the day-care center and where in downtown it is.
But it takes more than a change in zoning ordinances and support from the private sector to foster day-care development, as Hartford officials learned.
Hartford, which has had a building bonus for development of day-care and other amenities since 1984, has seen the construction of more than six million square feet of new office space. But not one developer has built a day-care center. The barrier, officials say, is not a lack of interest but a state requirement that conflicts with the city's ordinance.
''The state requires that all day-care centers have outdoor play spaces,'' said Patricia Williams, Hartford's Planning Director, who helped draft the city's bonus ordinance. ''So far, none of the builders have been able to find ways to meet that requirement because of site configuration or building design. It is frustrating but it shows that good intentions do not build day-care centers.''
There is hope, Ms. Williams said, that the intent of the ordinance will soon be realized. A site owned by one company, Oakleaf Development, is next to a church that sits on a large piece of property. Ms. Williams said the company is negotiating with the church to use part of its property for a playground for a child-care center Oakleaf hopes to build.
Outdoor play space is a vexing problem. At Fed Kids, in the heart of the cramped City Hall area in lower Manhattan, a portion of a public plaza was turned into a playground.
The G.S.A.'s startup cost for Fed Kids was just over $150,000. The agency expects the new annual operating budget for the center, which was recently expanded, to be about $26,755. Fed Kids serves 55 children from 16 months to 4 1/2 years; about two-thirds are children of Federal employees and the rest live in the community.
The McBurney Y.M.C.A., which holds the contract with Fed Kids Inc. to operate the center, keeps it open from 7:30 A.M. to 5:30 P.M. The charge for each child is $142.50 a week for Federal workers and $150 a week for parents who do not have Government jobs.
''When people talk about why the city does not have more centers like this one, they talk about the lack of space and high rents,'' said Susan Kossin, the first board chairman of Fed Kids, which has the G.S.A. permit to operate the center. ''But we started with about 3,000 square feet. You can do a lot with that. You don't have to wait for new construction to develop on-site day care. What you do need are people who want to see it happen.''
Councilwoman Maloney agrees and says that despite the troubled real estate market, support is growing for her bill to reward with tax exemptions developers who include day-care centers in their projects.
''I first proposed a bill like this 10 years ago,'' Mrs. Maloney said. ''We got nowhere with it. The Koch administration was not supportive and at the time, neither was the real estate industry.''
But Mrs. Maloney said she was encouraged by a meeting late last year with a group of developers and others in the industry.
''They support the tax-exemption bill,'' she said, ''and while many are firm in their opposition to any measure that would require developers to provide or fund day care, some agree that day care in the workplace makes sense.''
''I think that the real estate industry and other industries see that the city can be competitive only if we figure out ways to make working and living in New York possible,'' she went on. ''If we do not, we will lose to communities that have done it.''

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;
Shops and Housing May Soon Join Yachts

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
Since the early 1900's a 14-acre peninsula in the west branch of Stamford Harbor has been a boat yard, a boat-building site and a marina, where forests of sailboat masts tower over yachts, speed boats and catamarans.
The North Atlantic In-Water Boat Show is held there each September, and United States Navy vessels were built there and launched from its docks during two world wars. Today it is known along the New York-New England coast as Yacht Haven, the last working boat yard of its size in the region.
Now the Stamford Planning Commission has approved a $90 million residential, commercial and marina complex for the site, and in a vote on July 31 it recommended a zoning change that would permit non-water-related uses for the first time.
The Strand, as the project is called, will go before the Zoning Commission in the fall, and it must also be approved by state and Federal environmental agencies, a process that could take up to a year. 
The Collins Development Corporation of Stamford has spent three years and $2.5 million for engineering, architectural and legal fees, land options and environmental-impact studies in preparing the plans.
''It has been quite a bit more complicated than anything else we've done,'' said Arthur Collins, the president of the firm, ''because of all the new government regulations, and because of its size and variety.''
The Strand would be the first major development in the South End. For 10 years the city has sought a savior for the area's patchwork of black, Italian and Polish neighborhoods. They are sandwiched between decaying industrial plants and oil tanks, cut off from the rest of the city by the parallel swaths of Interstate 95 and the Metro-North Commuter Railroad.
In many quarters the Strand is seen as a golden door through which people and commerce will finally flow and mingle, while less sanguine shop owners, restaurateurs and small-business owners downtown worry about a competing second city emerging on the other side of the tracks.
''The Mayor feels that the Strand will have a very positive impact,'' said Charles Morton, executive aide to Mayor Thom Serrani. ''A great portion of the waterfront is privately owned. As sites come up, Stamford wants projects with provisions for public access that will attract people from all over the city.''
A four-story Residential Village is planned for the seaward end of the complex, with 200 condominium units, shops, restaurants, a fish market, boardwalks, landscaped plazas and a wave barrier doubling as a fishing pier attached to Kosciusko Park, east of the project.
A Maritime Village on the upland sector is to house Yacht Haven's boat services in new quarters, a commercial fishing dock, more shops and restaurants, and a 20-room boatel. Commercial space in both sections totals 85,000 square feet.
The project, designed in Georgian-colonial style by Do H. Chung and Partners of Stamford, will be surrounded by 500 boat slips, almost double the current number.
Some 1,000 parking slots will be distributed underground and on the surface, and a public dock will serve excursion boats and a ferry service to La Guardia Airport.
Because the peninsula is in a flood plain, roads and buildings will be elevated 13 feet above the mean high-water mark, with buildings anchored in bedrock. And to stabilize the boat basin during storms, the developer must build a 60,000-square-foot floating concrete breakwater offshore.
Clam beds under the breakwater site are a concern of the state and Federal environmental agencies, as are water quality and flow and maintaining a viable channel and a viable marina.
''It's the only boat yard on the East Coast that can handle vessels up to 80 feet,'' said Arthur Rocque, director of the Coastal Management Division of the Connecticut Department of Environmental Protection, which will hold hearings on the project this fall.
Mr. Collins was recommended to Mayor Serrani as the developer by the Stamford Partnership, a 10-year-old economic development agency, on the basis of three residential-marine complexes he built in Stamford during the 1980's. The partnership secured citywide acceptance for the project by negotiating some unusual trade-offs.
Mr. Collins agreed to donate up to $2 million, in cash or construction, for low-cost housing in the South End. The partnership, made up of city officials, members of the business community and people representing South End neighborhood factions, will administer the funds.
Units, priced from $80,000 to $100,000, would be earmarked for South End families earning less than $36,000 a year.
The developer's donations will be proportionate to the density of construction that he is allowed at the Strand. In addition, he agreed to help stimulate local employment by using some neighborhood workers enrolled in apprenticeship programs run by Local 210 of the carpenters' union.
Complicated as it is, the Strand ''is much scaled back from a proposal by Northeast Utilities eight years ago,'' said Jon Smith, the Stamford planning director. ''They wanted 1,200 condominium units in 8-and 10-story buildings.''
Northeast bought the property from Yacht Haven for $4 million in 1970, citing the need for a power station that never materialized. When development proved too bothersome, Northeast offered Mr. Collins an option on a $20 million sale price. Yacht Haven, now a Northeast tenant, will have Mr. Collins as its new landlord.
Northeast retained a seven-acre parcel north of the Strand that is contaminated with old coal-tar deposits dumped by its subsidiary, Connecticut Light & Power Company, located next door. It will be leased to Yacht Haven for excess boat storage and parking.
''Northeast can't develop it as is, and doesn't want to set a precedent for its other sites by digging it up,'' said Michael Sinacori, real-estate operations manager for the utility.
The marina is to be built as soon as approvals are in place and financing can be arranged, probably next spring, but work on the residential units will not begin until the market improves. The condominium units will be priced from $200,000 for 700-square-foot studios to $400,000 for 1,800-square-foot, two-bedroom apartments. These are smaller and cheaper than other Collins projects. ''We cannot risk competing with single-family homes,'' said Arthur Collins Jr., senior vice president. ''We've got to go back to the basic rule that condos must be priced 25 percent below single-family houses to maintain market viability.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Arthur Collins Sr., and Arthur Jr. at the site of the Strand, waterfront project, Stamford. (Suzanne DeChillo for The New York Times)

LENGTH: 598 words

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:

Right to Co-op Documents
 
Question: I am a real estate broker specializing in residential loft sales. The lawyer of a client who is interested in a co-op requested access to the financial records but the board refused to comply. Doesn't Section 624 of the New York Business Corporation Law gives prospective buyers the right to see these documents? If I lose a sale because of the problem, would the board be liable? . . . M. A., Manhattan
 
Answer: The answer to both questions is no. According to Stuart Saft, a lawyer and vice president of the Council of New York Cooperatives, the section of the law you cite gives shareholders the right to review corporation records. 
''The request should have come from the seller, as shareholder,'' rather than the buyer, said Mr. Saft. ''They don't have a right to access.''
As for a suit, Mr. Saft said: ''The broker would not have a case because the buyer would not. If anyone would have a case, it would be the seller.''
 
Ban on Weekend Work
 
Question: My husband and I live in a rent-stabilized apartment in a cooperative building. Because we both work, the only time we can have work done is weekends. I arranged to have my carpeting cleaned on Saturday morning, but the superintendent refused to let the man in to do the job, saying no work is allowed to be done on weekends. Can he do this? . . . P. F., Manhattan
 
Answer: Maybe. Cooperatives have the right to set house rules regarding such things as when renovation work or moving can be done. These usually apply to all residents, shareholders or renters. However, if you had been allowed to have cleaning work done on Saturdays in the past, it may be that the Division of Housing and Community Renewal would consider any new restrictions a reduction in your services. You could file a complaint with the agency, but a decision probably would take months. The division has a form for reduction-in-service complaints, available at its Manhattan offices at 156 Williams Street, N.Y. 10038 or 163 West 125th Street, N.Y. 10027.
Meantime, you might approach the superintendent again. Maybe he associates carpet cleaning with very loud equipment when it may make no more noise than a vacuum cleaner.
 
Rent-Stabilized Sublet
 
Question: I am a rent-stabilized tenant and am trying to sublet my apartment. I pay a very low rent so my landlord would like me to move. He has informed me that he will use any legal means to try to keep me from subletting. What are my rights? . . . C. G., Manhattan
 
Answer: An owner may not unreasonably refuse a rent-stabilized tenant the right to sublet for two years out of a four-year period, as long as certain procedures are followed. They include informing the landlord of intention to sublet by certified mail no less than 30 days before the start of the sublet in a letter that describes the terms of the sublet and gives the name and home and business addresses of the prospective subtenant.
Within 10 days of this mailing the landlord must respond, either asking for additional information, granting consent or providing a justifiable reason for denying the request. Moreover, according to Thomas R. Viola, a spokesman for the Division of Housing and Community Renewal, unless your landlord could show that the subtenant could not keep up with the rent or would be disruptive, he would probably have no legitimate reason to turn you down.
Mr. Viola also said that if it takes court action to get a sublease, your landlord might be liable for your legal fees if the agency determined he acted improperly.

HEADLINE: HOME CLINIC;
How to Install a Dimmer Switch

BYLINE: By JOHN WARDE

 BODY:
DIMMER switches allow adjusting lighting levels; they also save energy and extend the lives of light bulbs. Most often, dimmer switches are used for controlling incandescent ceiling lights. Installing one is easy. The job involves simply replacing the conventional wall switch with the dimmer.
Two types of dimmer switches are common. The more expensive is the full-range dimmer, or rheostat. It has a rotating knob and can provide completely variable control from a dim glow to full brightness. Usually it has a 600-watt capacity (the amount is stamped on the device), which is more than enough for a typical living room lighting circuit. 
The other type is the high/low dimmer. It is less expensive and, unlike a conventional wall switch, has a toggle instead of a knob.
High/low dimmers usually have a capacity of only 300 watts and provide only two levels of brightness: full and about 30 percent of full. Nevertheless, where a full-range dimmer is not required, a high/low dimmer is an economical substitute.
Both types are available with a single-pole design, the kind to choose when only one switch controls a fixture. Full-range dimmers are also available with a three-way design, for use with fixtures controlled by two switches. Three-way dimmers are made so that only one of the two existing switches is replaced; thus, a light controlled by such a switch circuit can be operated from two locations but dimmed from only one.
To install a dimmer by replacing an existing wall switch, all you will need in most cases are a screwdriver, long-nosed pliers and a voltage tester (an inexpensive device consisting of a small light bulb with two wire probes attached, available at hardware stores).
Begin by making sure the tester works. To do this, simply insert the probes into the slots of a wall outlet that you know works; if the tester is working, the bulb will light.
Next, shut off the power to the electrical circuit containing the switch, by tripping the circuit breaker or removing the fuse controlling it. Afterward, try operating the switch to make sure the light does not function (which would indicate that the power is still on).
Then unscrew the switch's cover plate from the wall. Avoid touching any metal, either on the switch itself or the outlet box in the wall, until you can use the voltage tester, as described further on.
Beneath the plate, find and loosen the two screws that fasten the switch to the outlet box. Gently pull the switch out of the box to expose the wires connected to it; avoid touching the wiring or the terminal screws on the sides.
Single-pole switches contain two brass terminal screws; three-way switches contain three screws. Newer models of both also have a small green terminal screw for a ground wire.
If there are four screws, the switch is a four-way design, used with two three-way switches to provide an additional point of control. Dimmers are not made for these; replace one of the three-way switches instead.
Other switches contain no terminal screws. The wiring enters the switch body through holes in the rear. Most switches contain both holes and screws, but the wiring is attached by means of only one or the other.
Touch one of the tester's probes to the metal outlet box and the other, in turn, to each of the terminal screws or holes. If the outlet box is plastic instead of metal, touch one probe to any of the bare copper wires (these are ground wires) inside the box while touching the other probe, in turn, to the terminals. If the tester bulb lights, power is still flowing to the switch. Proceed no further until you can turn it off.
When you are sure the switch is safe, remove it. If the switch is a single-pole, simply loosen the terminal screws and remove the wires; or, if the wires enter terminal holes, insert the tip of a screwdriver into the slot near each hole, which will allow the wire to be pulled out.
If the switch is a three-way, put masking tape on the wire connected to the dark-colored terminal screw or to the screw or hole marked ''common.''
To install most dimmers, reconnect the wires to the terminal screws or slots matching those of the original switch. With single-pole switches, it makes no difference which wire is connected to which terminal. On a three-way switch, replace the wiring exactly as it was on the old switch, using your masking-tape marking as a guide.
Connect a short length of bare copper wire or green insulated ground wire to the green terminal screw on the new switch, if there is one. If similar wires are present in the outlet box, add the new wire to them by unscrewing the plastic cap (called a wire nut) that links them, twisting the end of the new wire around those already joined, then replacing the cap. If no bare or green-insulated wires are present, attach the end of the new wire firmly to any metal part of the outlet box.
Some full-range dimmers have short wires already attached to them. To install this type, simply join the short wires to those of the same color in the outlet box, using wire nuts.
Press the connected switch into the outlet box and fasten it, being careful not to disturb the wiring. Restore the power and test the switch. If it works, attach the cover plate.
Although most dimmers have a built-in electrical filter, they sometimes cause interference on television sets and radios plugged into the same circuit or operated nearby. To remedy the problem, move the TV or radio to another circuit and as far away from the dimmer as is practical. If that does not work, obtain a power-line filter for the appliance from an electronics store.
