LENGTH: 1336 words

HEADLINE: ABOUT NEW JERSEY

BYLINE: By Anthony DePalma

 BODY:
VACANT city lots are powerful symbols. Betrayal, despair, mistrust - name it, and for someone the weedy blocks that dot every city represent a modern age that has all but said cities are worthless.
Each lot bears its own history. Right now, one of the most intriguing tales rises, along with a powerful stand of city weeds, at the corner of Johnston and Pacific Avenues in Jersey City, in the shadow of the New Jersey Turnpike extension. Once immigrant families lived here, and shopkeepers did good business along Pacific Avenue.
How that changed no one knows for sure but it did, and today that sector of Jersey City, not far from the waterfront and the northern entrance to Liberty State Park, has been all but deserted. Oh, there is a husk of a house here and there, and on the corner a liquor store appears to have a steady stream of customers. But all else has been swept away. 
Strange as it sounds, that barrenness is the very thing that attracts people like Stephen Roberson, a veteran community organizer who has seen more than his share of despair. On these empty blocks Mr. Roberson sees the chance to rebuild, from scratch, a community that truly has a stake in the future of the city.
This is no pipe dream. Mr. Roberson and the organization he represents, the Industrial Areas Foundation, have an enviable track record of having done the same thing in the worst parts of the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, in a project called Nehemiah, after the biblical figure sent to rebuild the walls of Jerusalem.
More than 2,000 Nehemiah houses have been built in New York. More important, the new owners of the houses have a stake in the city and they have brought the moribund neighborhood back to life.
The foundation had wanted to do more in New York City, but officials there would not provide enough land. Frustrated by the city's reticence, the foundation has now turned to Jersey City, where it is willing to help build hundreds of houses at improbable low prices. Except that Jersey City leaders cannot get around to giving up the empty lots.
''It's one of the things that's most perplexing,'' Mr. Roberson said recently. ''It's almost as if the bureaucracy takes on a life of its own.''
Mayor Gerald McCann and other city officials say they believe in Nehemiah, and eight months ago they pledged to provide enough land for the construction of 600 Nehemiah houses, which would sell for $45,000 each. But so far they have not met that pledge.
So now instead of building houses, the organizers and the city are bickering. Jersey City officials say the Nehemiah people are too demanding and unreasonable. The advocates say the city lacks the will to deliver on its promise. And the empty lots stay empty.
Not one to just wait for the stalemate to break, Mr. Roberson is out seeking new allies in Trenton, knowing from experience how pressure can be brought to bear in useful ways. He came to Jersey City two years ago, after a seven-year struggle to build Nehemiah housing in Brooklyn.
Mr. Roberson, who was raised in Westwood, Bergen County, before beginning his nearly 20 years of activism, was invited to come to Jersey City by the Interfaith Community Organization, a group of clergymen concerned that despite the new office buildings on the waterfront, Jersey City was losing ground to some intractable urban problems - namely, failing schools, a withering stock of affordable housing and a plague of drug abuse.
''These were real solid issues that, on our own, we had a limited capability of addressing let alone solving,'' said the Rev. James V. Pagnotta, pastor of St. Joseph's Roman Catholic parish and co-chairman of the housing team for the Interfaith Community Organization.
Recently, the organization got the Jersey City Police Department to try community-based policing, a way of getting the police out of their squad cars and back on the beat, where they could meet people and get involved in neighborhood affairs before problems arise. The group has also worked to clean up Lincoln Park.
But the most visible and tangible project would be the Nehemiah housing.
In Brooklyn, the Nehemiah houses were built near a forest of public housing projects in one of New York City's most hopeless areas. Now the modest little two-story masonry buildings are filled with working families - 40 percent of them came from the projects - who plant flowers, trim bushes and show off the pride they feel about owning houses they never thought they could afford.
The Nehemiah method is fairly simple: the religious congregations put together a revolving loan fund to get the construction going. Architectural design and legal matters are kept straightforward and inexpensive. Construction crews make a small profit, the city contributes the land and the state provides mortgage guarantees and writedowns that keep the houses affordable to families earning as little as $20,000.
Simple, but successful. So successful that a few years back legislation was passed in Washington establishing a national Nehemiah housing program.
But it seems Nehemiah has won more support in other parts of the country than right here. The 2,000 units in New York were supposed to be just the start. More would have been built, but the city never delivered the land.
Mark T. Munley, director of the Jersey City Department of Housing and Economic Development, said Jersey City was willing to work with Nehemiah, but could not find the land. Vacant lots might appear to be everywhere, but many are polluted. Other nearly vacant blocks contain just two or three houses, but relocating residents is, even in the best of conditions, politically dangerous.
''We believe in the concept, and we want them to build,'' Mr. Munley said. ''But it's just impossible to give them what they want right now.''
The originator of the Nehemiah concept, a retired builder, I. D. Robbins, has said that to work as intended, and to keep prices affordable, Nehemiah must be able to build a large number of single-family houses on cleared, unencumbered lots. In that way, enough people with real stakes in the community will be available to support the rebuilding of schools, stores and other services.
After the first houses were built in New York City, officials there became reluctant to provide any more large parcels of land. Jersey City now, too, seems to be backing off its promise of last December.
Paul W. Hamilton, assistant director of the Housing Department, said Jersey City was ready to offer enough land to build 200 houses near Johnston and Pacific Avenues but not until next spring, after chromium contamination has been cleaned up. He also said that assembling the land for the remaining 400 residences would be difficult, and that it might be necessary to ask the Nehemiah program organizers to increase density and build garden apartments.
As of the middle of this month, Father Pagnotta said he had not received any word from the city about the chromium cleanup and therefore he could not say whether a spring start was acceptable. But he did say that some of the $4 million pledged to the construction loan fund could be lost if nothing happens by the end of this year.
He also ruled out building anything other than single-family houses. ''At one point they asked us to do garden apartments,'' Father Pagnotta said. ''We said no.''
Father Pagnotta, Mr. Roberson and other Nehemiah supporters went to Trenton last month to find a way to get Jersey City moving. They got in to see Gov. Jim Florio.
Like the local officials, the Governor initially embraced the Nehemiah program and set up meetings between the Jersey City contingent and several of his department heads. One of them, Randy Primas, Commissioner of the Department of Community Affairs, has agreed to visit Brooklyn's Nehemiah neighborhood on Sept. 25.
Father Pagnotta and Mr. Roberson are certain to be there with Mr. Primas, hoping he sees that Nehemiah means more than housing, and that rebuilding a community takes more than promises.

GRAPHIC: Photo; Lot, once the home of shopkeepers and immigrant families, at the corner of Johnston and Pacific Avenues in Jersey City. (Frank N. Kinney for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 12WC; Page 1, Column 5; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1432 words

HEADLINE: Board Sends a Message For the Budget Season

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
AMID growing evidence that the county will have to lean more heavily on its property tax in difficult economic times, the Board of Legislators last week approved its first departmental budget of the new fiscal season and considered some unusual new sources of revenue.
After a public hearing on Monday, the Board unanimously adopted a budget of $35.85 million for Westchester Community College, including a county contribution of $12.8 million. The county's share represents an increase of $97,000, or less than 1 percent, over last year's allocation. The college had asked for $532,000 from the county.
Earlier, the Board had trimmed $185,000 from the college's proposed budget. In its final form, the spending plan represents a 7.7 percent increase over last year, but nearly all of that is coming from increased state aid. 
 
'Deep Concerns About 1991'
''This budget reflects our best attempt to reconcile the needs of Westchester Community College with our deep concerns about 1991,'' Katherine S. Carsky, Republican of Yonkers and chairwoman of the Budget and Appropriations Committee, told her colleagues at last Monday's Board meeting.
Diane A. Keane of Rye, the Board's majority leader, called the reductions made by the Board ''fair and sensible'' and said that its members had sent a message to other county departments about the future of their operating budgets. ''Every department has to cut tremendously,'' Mrs. Keane warned. ''If they don't, we'll do it for them.''
Without a sales tax to soften the blow, and with costs mandated by Federal and state programs rising while subsidies and local revenues shrink, county government officials have started searching beyond their traditional boundries for ways to balance the budget. A goal is to avoid a politically disastrous property-tax increase.
 
'To Think the Unthinkable'
A legislative commission has been formed to seek additional county revenues, or ''to think the unthinkable,'' as its co-chairman, Timothy S. Carey, Republican of Montrose, described its mandate.
The bipartisan group of legislators, local government officals and business leaders has asked the full Board to review the rents and fees charged by various departments and also to consider a method for levying a motor-vehicle-use fee. But Mr. Carey described those measures as ''saving a few dimes at a time when the state continues to demand more dollars.''
Earlier this month, his group, the Special Commission on Additional Revenues and Capital Enhancements - or Scarce, as it calls itself - reached considerably farther afield. It agreed to study the idea of selling such government assets as Playland and the County Airport.
 
A Proposal by Lauder
The commission approved a proposal by Ronald S. Lauder, the businessman, former United States Ambassador to Austria and New York City Republican mayoral candidate, to study ''privatizing'' the two operations.
''No one has come and said, ''I want to buy the airport or Playland,'' Mr. Carey said. ''But we must consider, long range, what is the best posture for Westchester.''
Selling the airport and thereby putting the operation on the tax rolls would have ''simply enormous'' economic benefits, Mr. Carey said. In addition, the one-time windfall from the sale itself was estimated at $60 million.
Mr. Lauder, the newly appointed chairman of the New York State Senate Advisory Commission on Privatization, appeared before the Westchester group to describe his state-wide effort to promote private enterprise in goverment as an alternative to higher taxes.
 
Profits and Yearly Revenue
Selling government assets like airports and amusement parks, Mr. Lauder said, can generate substantial one-time profits and put businesses on the tax rolls producing yearly income. ''We can have efficient, privately provided services and benefit from increased revenues without new taxes,'' Mr. Lauder said. There are a number of opportunities in the county, he suggested. ''Government just has no business running a business like an amusement park,'' Mr. Lauder, who is also chairman of the Central European Development Corporation, a private investment group, told the members of the local commission. He urged the county to ''get government off this roller coaster'' and sell Playland.
''You risk nothing by letting private enterprise work,'' he said.
 
Does Public Ownership Pay?
Promoting one of his favorite themes, Mr. Lauder said he would urge the state commission to study the consequences of a sale of the County Airport and to determine ''if the county taxpayers are getting their money's worth with public ownership.''
Last year, Mr. Lauder underwrote a study showing that the sale of the Kennedy and La Guardia Airports would produce a one-time payment to New York City of at least $2.2 billion and generate $212 million in general fund revenues yearly. While the County Airport is ''not exactly J.F.K. or La Guardia,'' Mr. Lauder said, ''privatization works as well for small projects as for big ones.''
Airport privatization has been carried out successfully in a number of European countries, including England. The British sold their airports, including London's Heathrow Airport, for $2.5 billion three years ago.
 
Reviews on Federal Level
But the concept so far has lacked political and governmntal support in this country. The Federal Aviation Administration and the Department of Transportation are reviewing airport privatization, and the two agencies are expected to release their conclusions shortly.
Some Westchester officials are skeptical and several have argued that the county government has already developed a number of public-private partnerships. The county, for example, contracts with private businesses for airport management, bus transportation and garbage-transfer stations.
 
'People Feel Safer'
There are few unexplored areas, said the county's deputy budget director, Kathleen M. Tooher.
''We've taken the best of privatization,'' she said. ''The fact is people feel safer with government. You can yell at your legislator or your government official when something goes wrong at the airport. We are here, and that means public accountability and accessibility.''
County Legislator Martin L. Rogowsky, Democrat of Harrison, agreed. ''Government has accountability, and my election is a direct example of that. They voted my predecessor out because they didn't like his views on the airport,'' he said, referring to his victory last year over a Republican incumbent, Dominick D. Pierro. ''People wouldn't have that opportunity if a private operator ran the airport.''
Saying he favored further study of the possibility of privatization of county assets, Mr. Rogowsky added, ''the airport is the wrong place to start.''
 
The Issue of Control
The commission's cochairwoman, Audrey G. Hochberg, Democrat of Scarsdale, also expressed doubts about whether extensive additional privatization would help the county.
''The idea isn't any panacea,'' Mrs. Hochberg said. ''Public-private partnerships can be useful - and we have several - but I don't see selling Playland or the airport as worthwhile.''
The partnership concept works especially well at the airport, Mrs. Hochberg conceded. But she added, ''I wouldn't want to give up control.''
Privatization is ''worth looking at,'' County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke said last week, but he warned that private, profit-making industries often produced costs higher than those of government, especially for the ''big-ticket'' items like prisons and welfare.
He said he was not interested in having the County Airport become private. ''The airport is one of the few in the country that runs in the black,'' Mr. O'Rourke said. ''Why would we tamper with something that is kicking in $4 million or $5 million a year?''
 
Lauder Finances Commission
Mr. Lauder is the only member of the Senate advisory commission to be named so far, and is also its only source of funds. Additional members are expected to be named shortly, a spokesman for the State Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, said last week.
Mr. Lauder, whose family owns the Estee Lauder cosmetic business, has expended time and money on both sides of the Atlantic promoting the idea that a free-market economy would be more beneficial than government bureaucracy.
Private enterprise can do a lot of things better than government can, Mr. Lauder has argued in speeches, whether that means a ''new beginning'' in Eastern Europe or ''jump-starting'' old projects under new management in New York.

HEADLINE: PREPARING FOR THE WORST;
The Stuff Wars Are Made Of

 BODY:
In the last week the United States crossed a threshold in confronting Iraq over its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. It became more than a nation responding firmly to an international crisis; in its collective consciousness and in cold fact, it began preparing for war.
The signs were numerous. In characterizing the Americans and other foreigners held by Iraq as hostages, President Bush in effect accused President Saddam Hussein of direct hostile action against the United States. While declaring peaceful and defensive intentions, Mr. Bush repeatedly evoked memories of America and its allies justly confronting threats in the past as he argued for resolve now.
The American and foreign military buildup in Saudi Arabia and the Persian Gulf hit full stride, and Mr. Bush called up the reserves, the first time they have been called since the Vietnam war. 
The costs of this effort, many billions of dollars even without the mammoth expenditures that would be required in a war, will weigh heavily on a Federal Treasury already battered by seemingly uncontainable deficits and on a national economy tilted toward recession. The Dow Jones industrial average lost nearly 4.5 percent of its value in one week as investors feared the worst.
The charts and pictures on this page and on page 3 illustrate the magnitude and complexity of the mobilization, and give some hint of its costs. Experts caution that even the best cost estimates are speculative, in large part a reflection of the uncertainty of the days, weeks and months ahead.
 
ALIGNED AGAINST IRAQ
The United States has been joined in the operation against Iraq by many counries from the West, Middle East and Asia. Full data on troop strength, equipment and deployments have not been released but many details are known. Iraq has about 170,000 troops in Kuwait and on the border with Saudi Arabia, of a force that has been estimated as high as 1 million but is probably less. Iraq also has 500 planes and 5,500 tanks but a weak navy.)

MOVING MOUNTAINS
The American military's principal action in the Persian Gulf crisis so far has been transporting thousands of troops and huge amounts of materiel from many points in the United States and elsewhere. Some highlights:
By rail. The Association of American Railroads says that rail companies hired by the Pentagon have transported to ports more than 2,000 flatbed and boxcar loads of equipment, including everything from M-1 tanks to ammunition.
By truck. The American Trucking Association said the Pentagon could call on thousands of truckers nationwide. For example, Landstar System Inc. of Stamford, Conn., ran 327 truckloads from Fort Campbell, Ky., to port at Jacksonville, Fla., 780 miles away. Cost to the Pentagon: from $1.05 to $1.30 a mile per truckload.
By sea. The Military Sealift Command says that as of late last week it cost $93 million to move equipment by sea. Much of the 447,000 short tons was sent on eight fast sealift ships, which carried the equivalent of enough fully loaded semi-trailer trucks parked side by side to cover 76 football fields, including end zones.
Forty cargo ships from the 96-ship Ready Reserve Force have been activated, and three commercial cargo ships have been chartered so far.
By air. The Center for Defense Information says 286 military transport aircraft are being used: 174 C-141's, each capable of carrying 200 troops and 34 tons of equipment; 32 C-130's and 80 C-5's. Both the C-130 and the C-5 can carry 340 troops and 130 tons of equipment.
Thirty-eight commercial aircraft also are being used.
 
COSTS OF DEPLOYMENT: AN EDUCATED GUESS
The Pentagon on Aug. 15 gave a preliminary estimate of $1.2 billion for the cost of Operation Desert Shield through Sept. 30. But that did not take into account subsequent developments like the call-up of reserves, and in any case military officials for strategic reasons are reluctant to provide many specifics about deployments. The estimates here were developed by the Center for Defense Information, an independent organization of retired senior officers that analyzes military policy. The number show how much it might cost, above and beyond normal military operations, to keep 100,000 American troopsin Saudi Arabia with other forces aboard ships in the region. There is no way to calculate the costs should war break out, the center says.

OIL'S POWER OVER THE ECONOMY
The economic consequences of the gulf crisis are uncertain to say the least, but econometric models can show some likely effects of a specific disruption like a sharp rise in the price of oil. These figures compare forecasts of United States economic performance by DRI/McGraw Hill, a forecasting firm. The first, issued on Aug. 2, before Iraq invaded Kuwait, assumed that the price of oil would not go above $22 a barrel. The second, issued after the invasion, forecasts what might happen if oil purchased on contract goes as high as $27 a barrel. Contract oil generally costs less than oil bought on the spot market, where it has risen above $30 a barrel.

HEADLINE: FOCUS;
Developers in Southeast Florida Dangle Incentives

BYLINE: By PAUL BLYTH

DATELINE: BOCA RATON, FLA.

 BODY:
 From Fort Lauderdale to Stuart, home builders in Southeast Florida are offering all types of deals these days. Not only are they reducing prices, but they are also paying buyers' closing costs, buying down mortgage interest rates, supplying free amenities such as microwave ovens or electronic security systems, and offering combinations of all of the above.
They must do these things if they want to sell homes at a rate remotely similar to that of the boom period of the last few years. Although Southeast Florida is still considered a growth area compared to other regions of the country, sales of new homes have slacked off here since peaking in 1988. 
In the Greater West Palm Beach area, for example, which extends from Boca Raton to Jupiter, new-home sales boomed in the mid-80's: 6,961 in 1985, 9,619 in 1986 and, in 1988, the peak year, 11,114.
That number dropped to 9,749 in 1989; for the first five months this year sales were off 29.7 percent from the same period of 1989, according to a study by Appraisal and Real Estate Economics Associates, a Miami research company.
"I've seen developers resort to these types of sales gimmicks in past cycles," said Michael Cannon, president of the research company. "It usually comes about when a developer is not getting his projected sales volume and is straining to sell his inventory."
Karl Preusse, president of K. Hovnanian Companies of Florida and of the Palm Beach County Home Builders and Contractors Association, said most cash discounts range from $5,000 to $8,000.
However, his company, which has built more than 12,000 homes in Southeast Florida in the last 20 years, does not offer discounts; its principal incentive package for about a year has been to pay all or part of the buyers' closing costs, depending on the type of home and buyer.
For second-home buyers, Hovnanian usually will pay some closing costs, equaling about 2.5 percent to 3 percent of the mortgage. This deal is offered in Hovnanian's 500-unit Pine Ridge development in Delray Beach, which is primarily an adult community with three-bedroom single-family detached homes costing $110,000 to $125,000 and two-bedroom condominiums costing $60,000 to $80,000.

 For a first-time buyer -- meaning someone who has not owned a house in three years -- Hovnanian will pay all closing costs and a portion of the points lenders usually require to inititate a home loan. A point is one percent of the loan amount. This essentially means that Hovnania will pay up-front costs equaling as much as 5.5 percent to 6 percent of the mortgage.
If, for example, someone were to make a $20,000 down payment on a $120,000, three-bedroom home in Hovnanian's family development of Lawrence Grove in Boynton Beach, the company would pay about $6,000 in up-front closing costs, Mr. Preusse said. This deal is offered to first-time buyers, he said, because they usually have a harder time amassing the money needed for up-front costs.
"But 6 percent is about the maximum anyone here can do, because that is essentially the maximum Fannie Mae or Freddie Mac will allow," Mr. Preusse said, referring to the Federal National Mortgage Association and Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, respectively. "If you go any higher on discounts, then the folks at those Federal associations will reduce the appraisal value of the home."
Centex Real Estate Corporation, a Dallas home builder that entered the Southeast Florida market about a year ago, learned almost immediately that it also had to pay closing costs.
"It is a market-determined situation," said Centex's division manager, David Barclay. "Other builders use this as an incentive, buyers expect it here now as a common part of the purchase of a house, and so we have to do the same thing to be competitive."
Nevertheless, Centex, which closed on about 80 homes in its first year here, is more selective in its offerings. In its Boca Raton community of Hampton Park, where homes on quarter-acre lots cost $140,000 to $175,000, the company will pay for about 1.5 points to bring down the interest rate and an additional $2,500 toward closing costs.
But in a similar development farther north, where the market is not as built out, Centex offers no deals, Mr. Barclay said. Its Danforth Community near Stuart includes three- and four-bedroom homes on quarter-acre lots and in the same price range as the Hampton Park homes.
Yet offering as many incentive deals as possible seems to be more profitable than not. One of the first companies to pay buyers' closing costs in the greater West Palm Beach area also has been the area's leading home builder in the last few years.
DiVosta and Company, a builder based in the small town of Palm Beach Gardens just north of West Palm Beach, has paid for closing costs such as appraisal fees, credit reports and deed recordings for five years. Company officers say that amount usually equals about 4.5 percent of a mortgage.
DiVosta also includes several extra amenities in its base package -- items such as electrical security systems, microwave ovens, window treatments and automatic grass sprinkler systems. Those types of extras were part of what made DiVosta the leading builder in the Greater West Palm Beach area in 1989, with 764 closings and a dollar volume of $79.8 million, said its executive vice president, Robert S. Kairalla.
DiVosta's unit sales for the first half of 1990 are 18 percent above the same period of 1989, Mr. Kairalla said, despite an industry-wide decline of 29.7 percent.

 "We selfishly need the volume, and we do extra deals to get that volume because high volume helps us purchase truckloads of supplies at less cost," Mr. Kairalla said.
DiVosta's projects are big, but its home prices are comparable to those of other affordable housing in the area. Its newest project, the Oaks in Palm Beach Gardens, involves a plan for about 1,200 units on 320 acres.
Starting at $79,900 are patio homes -- four units to a building, each with its own enclosed patio. Single-family detached homes start at $155,000 and have three bedrooms, two bathrooms and a two-car garage.
Garden Oaks, another new DiVosta project also in Palm Beach Gardens, is completely made up of detached homes similar to those in the Oaks, but they start at $137,900. With DiVosta paying the closing costs, a buyer's initial investment would be about $13,800, and a monthly outlay of $1,390 that includes payment on a 10 percent, 30-year mortgage, a monthly maintenance fee and taxes.
As common as incentive deals are among the 40 or so major developers in Southeast Florida right now, they still do not match some offerings of past down markets, said Mr. Cannon of the Miami rsearch company.
"A few things I've seen in the past but haven't seen recently are free cars, the pre-payment of condo maintenance fees for a year, and payment of brokerage fees," he said.
But just about everything else goes.
"We will do practically any combination of things," said Mr. Wiener of Levitt Homes. "We've given free appliances, closing costs, price reductions. It all depends on what the customer will take."

HEADLINE: In Big Factory, Small Businesses Prosper

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

DATELINE: YONKERS

 BODY:
It is now 36 years since the mills of the Alexander Smith & Sons Carpet Company in Yonkers shut down. The factory, founded in 1845, was at its zenith during World War II, when with a work force of 7,000 people, it operated around the clock producing blankets and tents for the United States armed services.
Yet after the war, hampered by cheaper imports, outmoded equipment, higher wages and production costs, business began to decline. When the carpet company, Yonkers's largest employer, closed its doors in June 1954, 2,400 people lost their jobs. 
Now the two Nepperhan Avenue factory buildings are busy again - but with the buzz of many small workshops instead of one big one. The 34 tenants, employing about 300 people, include artists, cabinetmakers, hosiery manufacturers, meat spice manufacturers and a restaurant.
This revitalization is part of a trend that a city official says has brought a number of small firms into formerly empty space around Yonkers in recent years - years in which the city added a small number of manufacturing jobs while other cities in the region have continued to lose them.
 
Healthy Diversity
With diversity comes strength, said John Zakian, the executive director of the Yonkers Industrial Development Agency. ''Diversity helps keep the economy of Yonkers healthy,'' Mr. Zakian said. ''When you have a lot of different types of businesses operating, jobs are spread out, lessening the dependence on one employer. And if a recession hits one industry, others will still function.''
The rebirth of the carpet factory began in 1978, when the two factory buildings on Nepperhan Avenue, totalling 150,000 square feet, were bought by Allan Eisenkraft, president of the Yonkers Industrial Development Corporation. His original idea was to rent whole floors to a few tenants after completing the necessary rehabilitation work.
''Over the years after the carpet factory closed, the buildings had had a number of small companies as tenants,'' Mr. Eisenkraft said. ''But they were always half vacant and very dilapidated. The windows were a mess, for example. I had to replace about 6,000 panes of glass in 600 windows alone. When I began the project, a lot of people in the construction industry thought I was crazy.''
With the help of officials of the Yonkers Community Development Agency, which encourages developers efforts to rehabilitate vacant buildings, Mr. Eisenkraft said he was able to get two $100,000 long-term low-interest Federal loans.
''The rehab was a big job,'' Mr. Eisenkraft said. ''It took from 1978 to 1983 and cost several million dollars, yet I never lost sight of the light at the end of the tunnel because I was so certain there was a demand for what I was doing. I thought there were businesses out there who would need entire large floors for manufacturing, warehouse or distribution operations.''
Yet, to his chagrin, Mr. Eisenkraft said, ''when the time finally came, I found I couldn't rent full floors.''
 
'Nobody Was Interested'
''Nobody was interested,'' he said. ''Here I was sitting with one of the largest blocks of industrial space in the county and I had no tenants. But at the same time I started getting inquiries from people in light industry who wanted smaller space, so I thought I had nothing to lose and I tried subdividing one of the floors.''
The first tenant who signed a lease for 3,000 square feet of space in the factory building was a two-man architectural woodworking concern, Joseph Kenyson Ltd.
''And they're still tenants,'' Mr. Eisenkraft said, ''but they moved into 12,000 feet now and they have over 20 employees.''
So Mr. Eisenkraft continued to subdivide floors until he collected the diverse range of tenants he has now.
 
Top-Floor Community
The largest tenant, Hoisery Concepts, now occupies one-and-a-half floors, a total of 22,500 feet.
''Jay Kwon, the president of Hosiery Concepts came to the United States from Korea only four years ago,'' Mr. Eisenkraft said, ''and in that very short period of time he has built up a tremendously successful business.''
Artists studios are housed on the top floor. With its 12-foot windows and 16-foot ceiling, it is ideal for artists who need large, naturally lighted work spaces, Mr. Eisenkraft said.
One of the artist complexes on the top floor is run by Debra Sherwood, a sculptor from Seattle, who opened YoHo Studios two-and-a-half years ago.
Ms. Sherwood, who leases 7,500 square feet of space, sublets studio space to eight other artists. Ms. Sherwood, who managed a similar loft in Seattle, said she came to New York, ''because for an artist New York is Mecca.''
''But I knew enough not to look for studio space in Manhattan. My work is life-sized, and when I saw this converted factory, with its strong wooden floors, huge east and west windows and freight elevator, I was thrilled. It was what I needed for myself, and I knew I would find other artists it would attract and it had the added advantage of being so close to Manhattan.''
Subletting studio space, Ms. Sherwood said, ''is not only feasible as a business venture, it also allows interaction with other artists that is valuable.''
''Although, there is some risk attached: if you don't rent the space immediately you have to carry the rent yourself. But I have managed to fill this up in about nine months.''
The mill buildings generate new revenues for the city and attract other businesses to the area, Mr. Zakian said. ''Allan Eisenkraft is a risk-taker and we need risk-takers,'' he continued. ''In 1978 when he started renovating the mill buildings, it wasn't a popular concept. He took a tremendous risk. A lot of people are doing it now, but he ran way ahead of the pack.''
 
'A Microcosm'
The Eisenkraft buildings, Mr. Zakian said, ''are a microcosm of what is happening all over Yonkers.''
''We have more industrial space here than any place in the county,'' he said. ''And we have not lost manufacturers. In the last five years we've actually shown a slight gain in manufacturing in Yonkers.''
Mr. Eisenkraft, who recently received an award from the Yonkers Historical Society for the renovation of the mill buildings, is also involved with new development in the area. His project, the Nepperhan Mall, a 15,000-square-foot, two-story structure, housing six retail stores and five professional office suites was completed in March.
''Four of the stores are rented and the lease for the fifth is in the works,'' Mr. Eisenkraft said. ''My daughter, Sharon Rappaport, and her husband, Paul, are working with me now. The mall is largely in their hands. And despite the negative publicity Yonkers has had recently, we find once we can get a tenant to look at space, the chances are good that he'll sign a lease.''
Mr. Zakian said tenants used negative publicity surrounding Yonkers -mostly concerning the housing desegregation fight - as a negotiating ploy.
''The truth is that the external factors generating that kind of publicity, have nothing to do with the economic pluses of doing business in Yonkers and business people know that,'' he said.

LENGTH: 1370 words

HEADLINE: Tourism At Shore: Changing Patterns

BYLINE: By LEO H. CARNEY

 BODY:
ALTHOUGH state and local tourism officials say that the crowds have begun returning to the Jersey Shore after three years of being repelled by reports of coastal pollution, business somehow is just not the same, they say. The officials add that Shore tourism may never be what it once was.
Dozens of Shore communities along the coasts of Atlantic, Monmouth, Ocean and Cape May Counties that make up what used to be reported as New Jersey's $7.7 billion Shore tourism economy have been experiencing a less than expected increase in business.
When pressed these days, state and county tourism officials shy away from the once admittedly grandiose accounts of Shore tourism revenue and visitors, acknowledging, instead, that there never was a genuine study of Shore tourism, only unscientific ''surveys,'' and that an accurate monitoring mechanism to evaluate this economy will not exist any time soon.
Eugene Dilbeck, the new director of the State Division of Travel and Tourism, who assumed office only a few days before the summer season officially started, said many Shore businesses did better this summer than during the last three, either equaling last year's revenue or increasing it ''one or two points.'' 
Nevertheless, Mr. Dilbeck said, the increase in Shore resort rentals this year, which the division early last spring predicted would be 30 percent over the 1989 figure, turned out to be about 10 percent over all.
The decline in Shore tourism was so serious, Mr. Dilbeck said, that it would require a major marketing effort soon, one that would go beyond New York, Pennsylvania and New Jersey and attempt to attract new visitors from states like Michigan, Illinois, Indiana and Ohio.
 
Seeking Visitors From Other Areas
''We can't sit here and expect vacationers from New York and Philadelphia to come in record numbers anymore,'' Mr. Dilbeck said. ''We have to supplement tourism with more visitors from out of the region.''
Patricia Padula, a spokeswoman for the Monmouth County Office of Public Information and Tourism, said, ''The beach in New Jersey doesn't sell itself anymore.''
What Mr. Dilbeck and others said was that a sharp decline in tourism began to appear in 1987 with reports of medical wastes washing up on the beaches and other forms of coastal pollution. The pollution actually closed a total of only six or seven miles of ocean beachfront along the state's 127-mile coastline.
But the decline in tourism has continued, and most tourism officials agree this year that the slide has been indicative not merely of the vacationers' distrust of ocean quality, but also of longer-term socioeconomic changes. These include smaller families, working couples unable to coordinate vacation times, single parents and, most recently, a further tightening of the national economy.
In 1987 and 1988, Shore retailers and other businesses reported losses for those years of 60 percent or more as pollution incidents persisted and vacationers stayed away in droves.
Although even an official best estimate of how the Shore fared this summer will not be completed until next spring, officials said, interviews with Mr. Dilbeck and other tourism experts, merchants and beach managers showed that the regular yearly increases of 20 percent or more for many businesses, which were common during a good summer in the 1960's and 70's, had generally become a thing of the past.
As for this year, measuring business success at the Shore, Mr. Dilbeck said, has been ''a very subjective thing, depending on where you are and to whom you are talking.''
John F. Tesauro Jr., an owner with his family of Tesauro's Restaurant in Point Pleasant Beach, Ocean County, said he was doing ''an amount of business equal to last year's but with noticeably more families, mostly local residents and owners of second homes in the area, and we are selling less liquor.''
''Our bar business was down 15 percent in June from last June because these people are just not drinking as much at dinner,'' Mr. Tesauro said.
 
'They Just Keep On Going'
When traffic in the street backs up outside at 4 P.M., Mr. Tesauro said, ''it's day trippers coming from the beach, and they just keep on going.''
Dorcas Beatty, an owner with her mother, Dorcas Cotsworth, of a restaurant and outdoor cafe in Bay Head, said that business was on a par with last year's, but that an increase in menu prices this year had helped keep things equal with last year's income. ''We got a good crowd this summer, but people are not coming to Bay Head like they used to,'' Mrs. Beatty said.
''We own our building,'' she said. ''The reason you hear of so many restaurants going out of business at the Shore is that you can't turn a profit because of the high rents.''
As one other sign of a weakening economy, the Atlantic City casino industry posted a loss in the busy April through June period for the first time in the industry's 12 years of operation.
 
Decline in Beach Badges
In Ventnor, Capt. Billy Howarth, who has been a member of the community's beach patrol for 22 years, said he had witnessed a steady decline in beach badge revenues since 1985.
Five years ago, Captain Howarth said, the seaside municipality adjacent to Atlantic City took in $201,000 in beach badge revenue. When the final count for this year is in after Labor Day, he predicted that the total would be about $162,000, representing a $7,000 loss from last summer.
Captain Howarth's supervisor, Stan Bergman, the Chief of the patrol, described this summer as a good one, better than last year's as far as the size of crowds go. ''But the crowds these days are mostly on weekends,'' Chief Bergman said, ''and the weekdays are off from what they used to be. So is business.''
These losses have continued, the two men said, despite mostly clean bathing waters and, until last week, a hot, dry and inviting tourist season.
 
Tourism in Cape May
Established in 1781, Cape May has prided itself over the years in being the nation's oldest seaside resort. Because of that, Pamela Karwasinski, the manager of the Sevilla bed and breakfast inn, said the city was ''more laid back and people who come here are into the history and the reputation of Cape May.''
But Ms. Karwasinski said the trade at the 1879 inn, unlike that in previous years, ''was mostly weekend guests'' with repeat visitors who stayed for a weekend or a week two or three times over the summer.
''Our weekday business is down, and the Fourth of July holiday was a disaster because it came in the middle of the week and people were not sure what to do,'' she said. ''One of the first things people ask me when they call for reservations is how is the water, is there anything floating in it?''
 
Shorter Stays Noticed
Whatever the reasons, the changing trend in Shore tourism, which finally began to be accepted last year as the economic decline continued, has now become part of the fabric of doing business at the Shore. Ms. Padula said the trend was that young couples or families were either staying for regular weekends or long weekends or coming only for the day.
''It seems when they have a week or two to vacation together, they are flying off somewhere,'' she said.
Ms. Padula said the tourism industry ''has finally realized that this trend is now our trade and that we are marketing to it and trying to extend it to more of the year by promoting short travel packages and things like murder mystery weekends in the fall at the bed and breakfast inns, or Victorian Christmas weekends.''
In Wildwood, Cape May County, Jane Phillips, the tourism director, said business was good this summer, but ''slow on lodging, not as strong on room reservations and more spontaneous as far as finding a place to stay.''
Along the Monmouth County coast, many large old hotels have failed to bring in enough visitors in the last decade, Ms. Padula and others said, and have converted to condominiums, filling their dining rooms with catered affairs instead of hotel dinner guests. Others have gone out of business.
''In some areas, such as Asbury Park,'' Ms. Padula said, ''we don't know what the next two or three years will be like. But we hope the water stays clean.''

HEADLINE: Affordability in the Dearest U.S. Market

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN SHARP

 BODY:
When Casa Guadalupe, with its 22 apartments, opened recently in a rough East Los Angeles neighborhood, nearly 300 families applied. Small wonder; the two- and three-bedroom units had dishwashers, air-conditioning, balconies and enclosed patios - unusual upscale amenities in a low-income housing project bordering a major freeway.
''Most of the applicants were too poor to qualify,'' said Carmela G. Lacayo, president of El Pueblo Community Development Corporation, which developed the project; only 35 families could afford the $300 to $500 a month rent.
This experience underscores the disparity between incomes and housing costs in California, where home prices soared to the highest levels in the country before beginning to turn downward last year. Speaking of the strong demand for more affordable housing in the state, Jim Wilson, a financial analyst at Montgomery Securities in San Francisco who follows the building industry, said: ''It's a huge, effectively untapped market.'' 
In the last year, goaded by government regulators and community activists, private lending institutions have flooded into this market by committing billions of dollars to finance low-income rental projects and affordable housing developments.
* In December, the Bank of America, based in San Francisco, announced a $50 million commitment that it said it would make every year to finance primarily low-income rental projects in the state. The bank lends to nonprofit developers at interest rates one point below the market rate.
* First Interstate Bank, based in Los Angeles, recently set aside $20 million in below-market-rate loans for low-income housing projects.
* In March, Wells Fargo Bank, based in San Francisco, increased its commitment with a seven-year, $1 billion lending program for affordable and low-income housing projects; since 1986 it has spent $137 million on similar projects.
* In April, Security Pacific, based in Los Angeles, pledged $2.4 billion for a program over the next 10 years; it is believed to be the largest such program of its kind.
One of the main reasons for the recent surge of such loan programs is criticism of lenders' performance under the Community Reinvestment Act of 1977. The Federal law, meant to prevent redlining - limiting credit in poor neighborhoods - requires federally insured banks and thrifts to meet their communities' credit needs. But it was rarely enforced, said Jim Yacenda, community investment officer of the Federal Home Loan Bank of San Francisco.
Under the law, bank mergers and acquisitions could be challenged at hearings. Last year, community activists challenged Security Pacific's proposal to acquire 20 percent of Mitsui Manufacturers Bank on the ground that the former's Community Reinvestment Act lending was insufficient. In November, the bank met with representatives of 16 California community groups and in April it announced its $2.4 billion program.
''After the success of some advocacy groups, regulators started putting a lot more emphasis on the act,'' said Mr. Yacenda. They set up a system to rate an institution on its community record, though the ratings were not made public.
Under Federal rules adopted last year as part of the law budgeting money to close ailing thrift institutions, the Federal Reserve and other regulatory agencies last month began reviewing - with ratings to be made public - the performance of lenders in providing services in and to poor neighborhoods.
''That was the wake-up call,'' said Donald A. Mullane, executive vice president of corporate community development for Bank of America.
''From a pure business standpoint,'' said one banker, ''it's become necessary for institutions to develop some type of program if they want to remain competitive.''
The competition to help less affluent home buyers as well as the working poor comes when fewer residents can afford to rent or buy. In the last decade, the median price of a home in California has doubled, to $196,521 last year, more than twice the national median of $93,100.
In that same decade, the real personal income of a California worker grew by only 9 percent, to $14,786, according to the Graduate School of Management, University of California, Los Angeles. The California Data Center, a state agency, said the median household income in 1988 - the latest available figure - was $30,200.
Because of the growing gap between earnings and home prices, only 18 percent of Californians can afford to buy a median-priced house, according to the California Association of Realtors (nationally, says the National Association of Realtors, it is 48 percent). As a result, 46 percent of Californians rent.
In the last decade, rents have risen as much as 110 percent in Los Angeles, which has a rent-controlled market. In its metropolitan area the median rent is currently $615 a month.
''The lower middle class and working poor are squeezed tighter than ever before,'' said Anita Landecker, director of California programs for the Local Initiative Support Corporation, a nationwide nonprofit group that provides or arranges financing for low-income housing.
The management of low-income projects, such as the one in East Los Angeles, requires that renters earn at least $14,600 a year, which is 50 percent of the median income in Los Angeles and considered very low-income. According to Federal Housing and Urban Development statistics, low-income applicants must earn at least $21,500 a year.
Based on the Los Angeles figures, very-low-income earners should spend no more than $365 a month for rent and utilities, according to HUD guidelines. However, the cost of building low-income units would make unsubsidized rents about twice what very-low-income renters can afford. Thus below-market-rate bank loans often complement state or Federal agencies that specialize in such projects. Government-assisted low-interest loans, deferred loans and tax credits make up the balance of the funds needed to build a low-income project.
Because the projects tend to be developed by nonprofit community groups, a developer's share does not have to be factored in, so such ventures can be profitable for lenders who invest in them.
''In most cases,'' said Mr. Yacenda, ''it is some of the best stuff in an institutions's portfolio.''
Traditionally, low-income housing projects have been viewed as high-risk propositions. But, said Gretchen Schaffner, senior loan officer for Low Income Housing Fund in San Francisco, although such projects tend to draw tenants who live on the edge of poverty, ''these are performing loans.''
Bankers and other lenders have realized that financing lower-income projects provides not just profits, but also improved public images.
Other factors play a role. The nation's savings and loan crisis has withdrawn a substantial amount of money from California's building and land acquisition activities and the commercial and higher-priced residential sectors of the state's real estate market have cooled considerably in the last nine months. With financing scarce for higher-priced developments, builders and lenders are discovering strong demand in the previously overlooked low-income sector.
Lending institutions that do not have large pools of capital or staff experienced in low-income projects often invest in financial pools, such as the California Equity Fund. In June, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation - Freddie Mac - pledged $10 million to build dwellings for very-low-income Californians. It challenged corporations to match that investment by contributing to the California Equity Fund, designed by the Local Initiative Support Corporation. For every $2 million raised in California, Freddie Mac has pledged $1 million. The Local Initiative Support Corporation hopes that its model will become the foundation for a new national housing policy.
Some California thrifts have long financed low-income rental projects through the Savings Associations Mortgage Company, a lending consortium formed by 11 thrifts in 1971. Since then, it has pooled $215 million in loans that have built 7,600 housing units in the state, including shelters for the elderly, troubled teen-agers, AIDS victims, developmentally disabled and the homeless.
Consortium staff members find low-income housing projects to finance, then invite member institutions to finance all or part of the loans. The consortium gets a fee from participating institutions for lending and servicing the loans. In the last 10 years it has had no foreclosures or deliquent loans - a better record than most of its thrift members, said Mr. Yacenda.
In the last nine months, the group's membership has increased 55 percent, to 75 financial institutions.
''We expect 1990 to be our best year ever, because of the increased interest,'' said Doris Schinder, president of SAMCO.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
SANCTIONS STARTING TO PINCH IRAQ ECONOMY, U.S. AIDES SAY; U.N.'S DIPLOMACY WELCOMED

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26

 BODY:
Amid tentative new stirrings of diplomatic activity in the Middle East crisis, American officials said today that economic sanctions against Iraq, while already starting to have some effect, will probably not have a decisive impact for months.
President Bush is counting on the sanctions, imposed by the United Nations three weeks ago and backed in the last 24 hours by a full naval blockade imposed with the Security Council's approval, to force President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to pull back from his conquest of Kuwait and to release foreign hostages.
Brent Scowcroft, Mr. Bush's national security adviser, insisted that those demands were non-negotiable. But he described as ''clearly acceptable'' plans by Javier Perez de Cuellar, the United Nations Secretary General, to attempt to negotiate a peace settlement. #3 Dependents Held Back American, French and British warships shadowed Iraqi vessels in the waters of the Middle East today but took no action to halt them. 
In Baghdad, the Iraqi authorities freed 55 dependents of staff members assigned to the United States Embassy in Kuwait, and all but 3 of them crossed the border into Turkey, the State Department said tonight.
A department official said she did not know why the three dependents, all young men, were held back by the Iraqis. She said the young men were on their way back to the Iraqi capital. Baghdad refused earlier in the day to free 54 staff members along with the dependents.
Iraqi troops tightened the pressure on American and other embassies in Kuwait, which are defying orders from Baghdad to close, but took no direct action to capture them.
 
'There Are Bread Lines'
With the situation relatively calm at the embassies and at shipping points, the situation in the Persian Gulf took on a slightly less ominous tone.
John H. Kelly, Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs, said on the NBC News program ''Meet the Press'' about the trade embargo against Iraq: ''We know that internal food prices are going through the roof for certain commodities like rice, sugar and so on. We know that there are bread lines.''
But other officials at the State Department and at the Pentagon, who insisted on not being identified, warned it could take from four months to a year before Iraq would experience widespread hunger or other distress of an intensity that would force President Hussein to reconsider his basic policies. #4 More Britons Seized ''It would be a serious mistake to give the American people the idea that this technique will bring fast results,'' an Administration specialist said. ''It won't do that.''
The United Nations announced that Secretary General Perez de Cuellar planned to meet Tariq Aziz, Iraq's Foreign Minister, in Amman, Jordan, on Thursday ''in order to engage in a full exchange of views on the crisis.''
A spokeswoman for the world organization, Nadia Younes, declined to comment about the possibility of a trip to Baghdad by Mr. Perez de Cuellar. President Saddam Hussein of Iraq was quoted on Saturday as saying that the Secretary General was ''always welcome'' to visit the Iraqi capital.
More Westerners were removed from their homes in Kuwait and Iraq by the Iraqi Army, perhaps for use as human shields. The Foreign Office in London said four more Britons had been seized on Saturday, including a woman expected to give birth in two or three weeks, bringing the total to 147. Eight more French citizens were also seized.
The Soviet Union, which voted at the United Nations early Saturday to allow members' warships to use force to uphold sanctions against Iraq, said it would not do so itself. Eduard A. Shevardnadze, the Foreign Minister, said Moscow would ''assume its share of responsibility'' but had ''no plans to use force or to take part in such operations.''
 
Blowing Off Propellers
In a joint statement with Roland Dumas, the French Foreign Minister, who is visiting the Soviet Union, Mr. Shevardnadze called on Iraq to pull its troops out of Kuwait.
British, French and United States warships are already challenging scores of merchant ships each day. Now they are under orders to stop any suspicious Iraqi tanker. But some naval experts think that could be easier said than done, unless the blockaders are willing to contemplate sinking the vessels.
''Ideas like blowing off their propellers are just not practical,'' said a merchant captain docked at the Persian Gulf port of Dubai.
For the moment, said a Navy spokesman in Washington, Chris Bauman, ''There is no action.''
 
Power and Water Cut Off
In Kuwait, Iraqi troops continued to ring several embassies, including that of the United States. Iraqi authorities reportedly entered the Chinese Embassy in Kuwait today, Administration officials said.
Ambassador W. Nathaniel Howell and his skeleton crew of fewer than 10 aides were without electricity, running water or local telephone service, as were several of the other missions.
But Mr. Kelly, who spoke with him by satellite telephone link this morning, said Mr. Howell was in good spirits and predicted that the embassy could hold out for weeks, using an emergency generator and stores of water and groceries.
Britain, France, West Germany, Canada, Japan, Norway and Denmark are among the countries whose embassies are attempting to resist Baghdad's order to close.
 
Diplomats' Immunity Stripped
William Waldegrave, a Minister at the Foreign Office, told the British Broadcasting Corporation that the British mission had enough supplies of food and fuel to withstand a long siege. ''They are staying on,'' he said. Iraq, which invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 and subsequently annexed it, says that Kuwait no longer exists and thus is not entitled to embassies. It has stripped the remaining diplomats of their immunity.
There was more talk about diplomatic maneuvering today, especially on the Sunday morning television interview shows, than in some time.
Speaking on the ABC News program ''This Week,'' former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said he thought President Hussein was seeking a way out of the impasse. He said, ''If we remain firm and if we keep open the prospect that we will not stop, he will settle.''
 
'Despot and a Tyrant'
Zbigniew Brzezinski, who was national security adviser in the Carter White House, predicted that ''some form of an intermediary regional solution'' would be found and agreed with Mr. Kissinger that military action in the region was unlikely.
But Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said after church services near her country retreat at Chequers, northwest of London, that there could be ''no negotiation with a person who by force has taken someone else's country.'' Mrs. Thatcher, Mr. Bush's vocal ally in the Persian Gulf crisis, described Mr. Hussein as ''a despot and a tyrant'' who ''must be stopped.''
Asked to assess the chances for a negotiated settlement, Mr. Scowcroft said in Kennebunkport, Me., where President Bush is on vacation: ''I think the chances are good that our strategy will succeed. Just wait and see.''
The Iraqi press agency said the country was facing severe shortages of food and medicine and accused the United States of committing a ''crime against humanity'' by organizing the blockade. The agency said the Iraqi Red Crescent Society had appealed to the International Committee of the Red Cross in Geneva for assistance, on the ground that medical supplies and food for humanitarian purposes had been excluded from the sanctions.
 
Iraqi Food Imports
But the international committee said that as of late this evening in Geneva, it had not received any request for assistance from Iraq.
A spokeswoman, Karen S. Saddler, said in a telephone interview that the international committee had been unsuccessfully seeking Baghdad's permission to send teams to Iraq and Kuwait ever since the invasion. The committee's delegate general for Middle Eastern affairs, Angelo Gnaedinger, flew to Baghdad to appeal for permission to send Red Cross personnel to both countries, Ms. Saddler said tonight, and is still negotiating with Iraqi officials.
A State Department official said that according to information available here, no Iraqis appeared to be starving and that therefore no humanitarian food shipments were justified now. ''This is not a famine situation,'' he said.
Iraq depends on imports for about three-quarters of its food, including poultry raised with imported feed grain. As of July 25, the Iraqi Government's stockpiles held enough rice for three months of normal consumption, enough wheat for two months, enough beans and barley for a month and less than two weeks of corn, according to John P. Parker, an economist at the United States Department of Agriculture who specializes in Middle Eastern food supplies.
 
Shipments Through Jordan
The corn crop in Iraq is due for harvest next month, and should provide enough for a month and a half of normal consumption, he said.
Iraq is also expecting a bumper crop of fruits and vegetables this autumn from its northern region of Kurdistan, said another American official who insisted on not being identified. After many years of civil unrest, the region was quiet this year and agriculture prospered.
Some food has reached Iraq by truck across Jordan and by air, and it is widely anticipated that traditional local trade will continue with Iran and Turkey. Even when Iran and Iraq were at war, such commercial activity never completely stopped.
All of those resources could be considerably extended, of course, by the type of rationing that Iraq has already imposed, with troops enforcing regulations and black market activity punishable by summary execution.
Kuwait is even more dependent than Iraq on imported food, and Kuwait's warehouses, once full of canned goods, appear to have been looted by the Iraqi Army, said Nasser al-Rashed, chairman and managing director of Kuwait's partially state-owned Public Warehousing Company. He fled to Saudi Arabia on Aug. 5 and spoke in a telephone interview.

More than 80 Austrians were allowed to leave Iraq after Mr. Waldheim met with President Saddam Hussein to negotiate their release. (Agence France-Presse) (pg. A8)

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 2; National Desk

LENGTH: 1681 words

HEADLINE: In the Drive to Revive Schools, Better Teachers but Too Few

SERIES: TOMORROW'S TEACHERS: FIRST OF THREE ARTICLES.

BYLINE: By SUSAN CHIRA

 BODY:
In the struggle to revive America's schools, the news is bittersweet. Despite growing evidence that more and better qualified people are choosing teaching, educators say there are nowhere near enough of them.
The nation still suffers from an acute shortage of academically talented teachers, minority teachers and math and science teachers. These teachers are needed more than ever, given an economy with less room for dropouts, a growing demand for sophisticated technical knowledge and soaring enrollments of minority children.
Yet teachers face a cruel paradox: Americans tell them the profession is vitally important yet continue to discount it. Before and after entering the classroom, teachers are confronted with the evidence that teaching remains a second-class profession of low pay, stifling regulations and restricted mobility. 
Take Amy Hanson, a B-plus student at Illinois State University at Normal. She wants to be a teacher and her parents approve. But Amy's sister, the ''brain'' in the family, wants to be a teacher, too.
''My parents say, 'Amy's going to be a teacher and that's nice,' '' she said. ''My parents say my sister's smart, she should do something else.''
 
A Trend Gradually Reverses
After more than a decade of decline in the numbers and quality of new teachers, experts say that more, different and smarter teachers are now flocking to America's schools. Nationwide alarm about education has spurred states to raise salaries and toughen standards for teachers. The widespread publicity has tapped a vein of idealism, attracting teachers from nontraditional backgrounds.
Students from elite colleges are volunteering for teaching programs modeled on the Peace Corps, like Teach for America, and enrollment in teacher education programs has been rising.
The annual number of new teachers climbed 20 percent from 1984 to 1986, rising to 126,000 from 105,000, the National Center for Education Statistics says. Many experts say that trend has continued, although national figures reflecting it are still being compiled.
The increases reversed 10 straight years of decline, from 216,000 new teachers in 1975, the first year the center began keeping such statistics. There are more than 2.3 million teachers in the country's public schools.
The recruits tend to brush aside the considerable deterrents to teaching. In dozens of interviews across the country, prospective teachers echoed the sentiments of Dana Wollenberg, a 21-year-old education major at Illinois State.
 
Good Intentions Not Enough
''I've always done very well in school, so my father wanted me to go to law school or be a doctor or go into computers,'' she said. ''For me, when I look into the future, I don't necessarily see computers but children, the best future that we have.''
These new teachers must meet higher standards imposed in the last five years by nearly every state.
The states acted after years of indications that the quality of new teachers, as well as their numbers, had declined from the mid-1970's to mid-1980's. Several studies concluded that in those years a higher proportion of academically weak students enrolled in teacher education programs.
Now 46 states are using or developing tests that students must pass before they can enter a teacher education program or get a teaching certificate, according to the Rand Corporation's Center for the Study of the Teaching Profession. At least 27 states require a minimum grade average or a minimum score on standardized tests before students can be admitted to teacher education.
Although few of these tests actually measure teaching ability, there is evidence that the new standards have helped weed out the least qualified. The American Association of Colleges for Teacher Education reports that in 1988 teacher education students typically ranked at the 70th percentile in their high school classes, maintained a B or better grade average in college and had a combined score on the S.A.T. test of 950, slightly above the national average. Less objectively, the reports accumulating from teacher education colleges around the country indicate that better students are signing up for teaching.
 
Numbers Up, but Not Prestige
But many teacher education experts and several recent reports conclude there is still a long way to go. Although standards have risen, many argue that they must go higher.
''We must expect higher-order learning from a greater number of kids than ever in the past,'' said Judith Lanier, on leave from her post as Michigan State University's dean of education to lead a statewide project to improve public schools and teacher training. ''That requires ambitious teaching, and we have to be more selective in choosing which teachers get in.''
An annual nationwide survey of college freshmen by researchers at the University of California at Los Angeles found that more students want to become teachers, but more aspiring teachers also come from the colleges that are least prestigious and academically selective. Although states set a minimum standard for entrance to teacher education programs, that standard is not exceptionally high: between a C-plus and B-minus grade average.
Moreover, too few members of minority groups and too few people with math and science backgrounds want to become teachers. Last year, 81 percent of teacher education students were female and 92 percent were white. Only 4.7 percent were black, 1.6 percent were Hispanic and 1.5 percent were Asian.
Two-thirds of schools surveyed in the past several years reported shortages of math and science teachers, said Linda Darling-Hammond of Columbia University's Teachers College. And the National Center for Education Statistics found that substantial numbers of teachers who did not major in math or science in college are nonetheless teaching math and science, pressed into service by the shortage.
The need for teachers becomes even more urgent as policy makers anticipate a wave of retirements. Half of those teaching in 1987-88 were age 40 or older, the National Center for Education Statistics says. Many will be leaving within the next decade, and a disproportionate number of those will be the most experienced and skillful teachers, primarily talented women who had few other career choices when they entered the field.
 
Education? Professor Laughs
Perhaps the most formidable barrier to finding more and better teachers is reflected in the experience of Cynthia Olson, a 21-year-old Illinois State student. She said her philosophy professor laughed out loud when she said she was majoring in elementary education.
Society continues to look down on teachers, and partly as a result of that attitude, the working conditions insure that many teachers give up the profession.
Discouraging tales of ridicule and derision can be found, both from idealistic college students and from those who have switched to teaching in mid-career. Friends of Lynn Klenk, an Illinois State education student, tell her that she is really majoring in fingerpainting.
Robin Jackson always wanted to be a teacher but let her family and friends talk her out of it. ''Everyone told me, 'You don't want to go into teaching; there's no money in it,' '' said Ms. Jackson, who at the age of 31 is just now leaving her job as an administrative assistant at the World Bank to become a teacher. ''All my friends looked down at the profession.''
One obvious measure of teaching's status is its continuing low pay. Teachers' salaries have risen across the country in the last decade after years of stagnation. The National Center for Education Statistics calculates that they have risen 19 percent since 1981, after a 14 percent decline, when adjusted for inflation, from 1973 to 1981. At least 30 states have set minimum starting salaries, and public school teachers earned an average of $30,788 in 1988, the National Center for Education Statistics says.
Yet that is still below what comparably educated people can earn in many other careers. And for many talented people who could become lawyers, doctors or scientists, a teacher's salary and a long summer vacation are not enough to compensate for the lack of autonomy or career mobility.
 
Frustrated After 6 Months
JoAnn Smith is the kind of teacher recruiters are searching for: smart, black and eager to teach inner-city children. But after her first six months as a fourth-grade teacher in Washington, D.C., she is already talking about leaving the classroom.
She is not daunted by the horrors she sees every day, from crack babies to victims of child abuse. What frustrates her is a common complaint of conscientious teachers: rules she cannot change that seem to work against her students' educational interests. For example, she found that because of space limitations the only way she could get students who needed extra help into summer school was to fail them.
''I'd rather be a consultant and be able to give my opinion freely or design curriculum,'' she said. Although the 23-year-old Howard University graduate knows that improvements are in the works, she doubts they will come in time to give her the power to make changes at her own school. ''Something is going to be done, but I doubt I'll be around to see it done successfully.''
Most teachers spend their days teaching material they did not choose and trying to conform to rules or educational requirements they had no hand in shaping. Unlike many other professionals, teachers often have the same duties 30 years into their jobs that they had the first year they entered the classroom. Although some districts are adopting ''master teacher'' programs for the most skillful teachers, for most the main route to promotion and higher pay remains leaving the classroom to become a principal or bureaucrat.
''We built the job of teaching for young, energetic women who were going to teach for only a few years'' before getting married, Professor Lanier said. ''The working conditions are geared for a different era.''
