LENGTH: 1438 words

HEADLINE: Already Weak, New York Area Is Spending Less

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
Confronted with a fragile economy and haunted perhaps by the slide of the 1970's, consumers in the New York region are cutting spending and delaying purchases in a display of frugality that seems likely to make the slump worse.
''We're talking about net declines of a magnitude that we have not seen since the last recession,'' said Isaac Lagnado, director of research for the International Council of Shopping Centers, a trade group.
According to the council, general merchandise sales declined by 2.7 percent in New York City and the northern suburbs, 8.2 percent on Long Island, 5.3 percent in Newark, 1.8 percent in Bergen and Passaic Counties in New Jersey and 0.1 percent in southwest Connecticut in the first five months of 1990 from a similar period last year.
 
Cutting a Costly Swath
The decline's severity would be even clearer if the figures were adjusted for inflation, which was about 3 percent for such goods, Mr. Lagnado said.
The spending falloff, which began last year in the city and spread to the suburbs, is cutting a costly swath. It is compelling department stores to hold seemingly constant sales, causing restaurants to adopt downscale menus and eroding demand for a broad range of service businesses, from advertising agencies and law firms to dry cleaners and hair cutters. 
It is also taking a toll on state and local governments, which have had to cope with fallen sales-tax revenues.
Retail sales, which are growing sluggishly nationally, are far weaker in some regions of the country, including New York. Economists attribute the local weakness in spending partly to continuing job losses on Wall Street since the stock market plunge of October 1987 and a slowing of wage increases and rising prices, which have left many people with less purchasing power. But they say it is also a consequence of the psychological response to the prospect of prolonged bad times.
''A great deal of this has to do with expectations,'' said Robert A. Dye, director of state forecasting for the WEFA Group, a forecasting service in Bala Cynwyd, Pa. ''Consumers have the expectation of a weak economy, they start to cut back and that can lead to a self-fulfilling prophecy.''
At the Bally store at the World Financial Center in Battery Park City recently, a salesman, Ray Vera, was surrounded by $1,400 leather coats and $240 shoes but no customers. ''We're being hit hard,'' he said. ''It's devastating.''
Last August, the store took in about $9,000, he said. This month he hopes it will gross $6,000.
Mr. Vera attributed sluggish sales to a decrease in customer traffic and a new sense of frugality. ''Where they used to buy the $240 shoes, now they want the $170 pair,'' he said. ''Everybody's worried.''
A few doors away at Cignal, which sells European-style casual clothing, an employee who spoke only on the condition of anonymity said, ''people are buying a lot more conservatively.''
 
Reasons for Consumer Caution
''Right now should be a hot period -the back-to-school, back-to-fall shoppers,'' she said. ''But it hasn't happened yet. Maybe it will in September.'' There is ample reason for consumer caution. The region lost 13,000 jobs in the first five months of 1990, the first regional employment decline since 1982. Wages, which had increased 6.4 percent in 1988, rose only 4.8 percent last year. And the average annual pay in financial services jobs, which tripled from 1979 to 1988, dropped by more than $3,000 last year, to $75,243.
Personal bankruptcies rose 23 percent in New Jersey, 27 percent in New York and 38 percent in Connecticut in 1989 from the previous year. Mortgage deliquencies and foreclosures are up.
Unemployment, though edging higher, has remained relatively low. But that does not seem to be enough to stop many people from recalling the economic difficulties of a decade ago.
 
Scary Memories of the 70's
''People do remember that long downturn in the 70's,'' said Rae D. Rosen, regional economist for the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York.
Over the last three and a half years, the consumer confidence index of the Conference Board, a business research organization, has moved within a relatively narrow range for the nation. In contrast, during that time the index dropped to 64.6 from a high of 160 for New England and to 95.1 from 126.3 for the Middle Atlantic states. Below 90 is considered a sign of a greatly weakened economy.
Retail sales grew by 4.6 percent in the nation in the first five months of this year over the same period last year, unadjusted for inflation, according to the Commerce Department. While they increased in New Jersey by 5.1 percent, New York State showed only a 2.2 percent gain and New York City and Long Island had only a 0.9 percent gain, well below the inflation rate.
In May, national retail sales grew by 2.1 percent over the previous May, according to the WEFA Group. New Jersey posted a 4.3 percent increase, but New York State and Connecticut declined by 2 percent and 3.1 percent respectively. Of the states reporting monthly figures, only Kansas, Massachusetts and Indiana were worse.
 
Specter of Higher Energy Costs
Mr. Lagnado said that the shopping center council's statistics, which are based on a survey of large department stores and include purchases of items like clothing and appliances but not gasoline or food, are a more sensitive indicator of discretionary spending than broader measures of sales. He said the organization's figures showed much greater weakness locally.
One of the few areas in the region to register gains, according to the council, was Jersey City, which had a 23.1 percent increase in merchandise sales in the first five months of 1990, on top of a 16.3 percent gain last year. Mr. Lagnado attributed it to new retail and residential development there.
Economists say the region's problems are compounded by the prospect of higher energy prices, which would cut even further into disposable income, and a mixed tourist season.
Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, said he believed some of the weakness in New York City was due to the popularity of warehouse discount stores and catalogue shopping.
 
Sales at Macy's
He said he thought the city would continue to be a center for high-value goods, particularly clothing.
Even so, the Mideast group that bought Saks Fifth Avenue recently told bankers that it expected flat sales at the Manhattan store for several years.
Garrick-Aug Associates, a store-leasing firm, reports that average rents in Manhattan have dropped from more than $65 a square foot in 1988 to less than $55 a square foot now.
At Macy's last week, Delysia Barnett was buying a dining room set. She had already been shopping for a year, she said, and was drawn to the store by the sale. ''See that? Half off,'' she said.
 
Big-Ticket Items Suffer
Sales of automobiles and big-ticket items like electronics, appliances and furniture soon suffer when the economy weakens. So do expenditures for services, which could hurt New York City especially hard.
The city's once-thriving restaurant industry has been pinched for months. Clark Wolf, a restaurant consultant, said he believed people were eating out as much as ever, but ordering simpler food in restaurants closer to home.
Bruce Schaller, director of policy development for the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission, said nine of the the city's 50 black-car companies had either gone out of business or merged with other car companies. He attributed the shakeout to sagging profits among the corporate clients who hire black-car companies to provide large sedans on request.
Sitting in a barber's chair flipping through a magazine, the assistant manager of Great Expectations hair cutters in the World Trade Center, Elizabeth Fonseca, said business was not what it used to be.
 
'It Has Just Kept Geting Worse'
''After that first crash,'' she said, ''it slowed down and since then it has just kept getting worse.''
As a result, sales-tax revenue in New York City has also slowed. Allen Proctor, executive director of the New York State Financial Control Board, said that in the 1988 fiscal year, sales-tax revenue in New York City grew by 2.2 percent after adjustment for inflation. The next year, he said, there was no growth. And in 1990, it is likely to have declined by 1.5 percent.
Other parts of the region felt sales tax falloffs last fall and winter.
As governments struggle to close the budget gaps, taxes have gone up, which will further diminish spending power at a time it is already weakening.

SECTION: Section A; Page 9, Column 1; National Desk

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
With Embargo, U.S. Farmers Lose One of Their Best Clients

BYLINE: By WILLIAM ROBBINS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 26

 BODY:
The Middle East crisis is confronting farmers, the United States Treasury and taxpayers with costs that go far beyond the rising price of oil.
For farmers, higher oil prices take a heavy toll because petroleum is not only their fuel but also the basic ingredient in many agricultural chemicals.
And the American actions after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait have prompted Iraq to stop payment on nearly $2 billion it owes the United States Treasury for previous agricultural shipments.
For many farmers, the embargo on exports to Iraq means they are cut off from one of their better grain customers at a time when good clients are sorely needed. Baghdad had become a $1-billion-a-year buyer of American agricultural products. 
 
Rice Growers Are Hit Hardest
The loss of the Iraqi market will be hardest for rice growers and the states where rice is grown, principally Arkansas, California, Louisiana, Mississippi and Texas. Iraq had become one of the world's largest importers of rice, buying most of it from the United States.
Last year Iraq bought 538,000 tons of American rice, worth about $180 million. That represented nearly 18 percent of all United States rice exports.
One reason the Iraqis bought so much American rice apparently was the United States' willingness to sell it on credit. But that credit was jeopardized in September 1989 by the discovery of irregularities at an Atlanta branch of an Italian bank that had lent money to Iraq.
This year Baghdad had bought 269,000 tons of rice, worth about $93 million, when the loan problems surfaced at the Atlanta branch of the Banca Nazionale del Lavoro. The Agriculture Department's Commodity Credit Corporation had already granted $500 million of a requested total of $1 billion in 1990 loan guarantees. Consideration of the remaining $500 million has been suspended while an investigation of the bank continues.
 
Lending Authority Exceeded
Several of the bank's Atlanta executives were dismissed when it was learned that they had advanced letters of credit totaling $2.6 billion over several years, far beyond their lending authority, to cover Iraqi imports. Some of the loans had been guaranteed by the Commodity Credit Corporation.
Investigators from the Agriculture Department looked into several deals involving the bank and covered by Government guarantees. They found several irregularities, focusing on the fact that Iraq always seemed to pay substantially higher prices for its purchases than anyone else. Iraq also demanded ''after-sales services,'' which often included demands that sellers provide non-agricultural products like truck parts and tires free.
''If that also covered cash payments and kickbacks, it would be a serious matter,'' said an Agriculture Department official, speaking on the condition of anonymity. ''We have no indication yet what happened. But we felt there were enough indications of irregularities that they needed further checking.''
 
Big Crops, Shrinking Profits
The break with Iraq could hardly have come at a worse time for American rice growers, said Andrew Aaronson, rice specialist with the department's World Agricultural Outlook Board.
''Prices are down,'' he noted. ''We've seen good crops around the world, among all major suppliers and even among many major importers.'' The price of long-grain rice from Thailand, for example, at about $265 a metric ton, has fallen more than 22 percent from last year's level of about $340.
Iraq's American purchases of wheat did not loom as large, but they were still important, particularly to Kansas, Oklahoma, Texas, Colorado and Nebraska, where most of the hard red winter wheat favored by the Iraqis is produced.
Last year the Iraqis bought about one million metric tons of wheat, worth $164 million, and this year had bought about 500,000 tons, worth $89 million, when their credit was suspended.
 
'One of Our Better Markets'
''They bought only a little over 3 percent of our wheat exports,'' said Edward Allen, a wheat specialist, ''but even so Iraq was one of our better markets. Losing it was not as bad as it would be to lose the Soviet Union, but it's not insignificant.''
Farmers and exporters are especially sensitive to the loss of a customer this year, when the United States is producing its third-largest wheat crop ever and when world wheat production is setting a record, expected to reach 384 million metric tons and exceed last year's crop by nearly 50 million metric tons.
With supplies rising, prices have fallen. Export prices at Gulf of Mexico ports, for example, are running at about $125 a ton, down 26 percent from last year. #3-Country Deal Shaken A further uncertainty for the Treasury involves an unusual three-way deal made before the Iraqi invasion, in which Kuwait promised to pay for 200,000 tons of American wheat for Egypt.
Government credit guarantees had been temporarily suspended because of a lag in Egyptian payments. Kuwait then came to Egypt's aid, agreeing to lend it the money to pay for the wheat.
Some of that wheat was still on the high seas when Iraq invaded Kuwait, an Agriculture Department official said. ''We are still hopeful that the transaction will go on as planned,'' with the Kuwait Government in exile making good on the promised payments, he said.

HEADLINE: CONFRONTATION IN THE GULF;
U.N. Leader to Meet With Iraqi Minister

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 26

 BODY:
The United Nations Secretary General, who said this weekend that he would personally intervene in the Persian Gulf crisis, is to meet with the Iraqi Foreign Minister on Thursday in Amman, the Jordanian capital, a spokeswoman said today.
The Arab League's representative to the United Nations, Clovis Maksoud, greeted the initiative by Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar as ''something that definitely reduces our level of anxiety.''
Mr. Perez de Cuellar ''inspires a great deal of confidence among the Iraqis in view of the long-established relations that he made during the Iran-Iraq conflict,'' Mr. Maksoud said in Washington. ''I am sure that he will be able to elicit a positive response'' from Tariq Aziz, the Iraqi Foreign Minister. 
In Washington, Brent Scowcroft, the White House national security adviser, said the Bush Administration would have ''no problem'' with an attempt by the Secretary General to mediate in the crisis.
 
U.S. Insisting on Pullout
But Mr. Scowcroft observed that the United States is demanding an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, a condition that Baghdad has been unwilling to meet even as it has signaled a possible willingness to negotiate with Washington.
Once an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait is accomplished, the United States is ready to ''talk about anything,'' he said.
The United Nations spokeswoman, Nadia Younes, said Mr. Perez de Cuellar was planning ''a full exchange of views on the crisis'' in the gulf with Mr. Aziz. Mr. Perez de Cuellar announced on Saturday that he would seek a meeting with Mr. Aziz as he ended a visit to Bogota, Colombia, before returning to New York.
The Secretary General said ''that the time had arrived for him to start a diplomatic process aimed at solving the critical situation in the gulf area,'' Ms. Younes said. She said Mr. Perez de Cuellar had been in touch with the United Nations representatives of several countries since he returned to New York.
 
No U.N. Comment on Hussein
Ms. Younes did not say when the Secretary General would leave for Amman. And the United Nations Secretariat issued no response to a remark on Saturday by Iraq's President, Saddam Hussein, that the Secretary General was welcome in Baghdad.
Mr. Perez de Cuellar announced that hoped to meet with Mr. Aziz on Saturday, hours after the Security Council adopted a resolution giving countries the right to enforce the economic embargo against Iraq by halting shipping to and from the country.
It was the fifth measure on the Gulf crisis voted by the Council since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2.
At his news conference in Bogota, Mr. Perez de Cuellar said: ''After the adoption by the Security Council of five very important resolutions, the moment has arrived for the Secretary General of the United Nations to start diplomatic efforts aimed to solve in all its aspects the critical situation in the gulf area.
''Therefore, I have invited today the Minister of Foreign Affairs of Iraq, Mr. Tariq Aziz, to urgently meet with me, preferably next week, in New York or Geneva, in order to engage with me without dela, in a full exchange of views on the crisis.''
 
Relying on Ties With Iraqi
Mr. Perez de Cuellar said he felt obliged to make use of the personal ties that he forged with Mr. Aziz during more than five years of negotiations on the war between Iran and Iraq. The eight-year conflict ended in a cease-fire in 1988.
The Secretary General suggested that the Iraqi Government was considering ways of seeking a nonmilitary resolution of the gulf standoff.
He said he would discuss all of the issues in the crisis with Mr. Aziz, including the Iraqi Government's refusal to let many foreigners depart from occupied Kuwait and Iraq.
The Secretary General said that he was acting on his own initiative, not at the behest of the 15-member Security Council. He said he felt he could intervene in the standoff without hampering efforts by the Council, which has also condemned the Iraqi annexation of Kuwait as null and void, called for the withdrawal of Iraqi forces and demanded that all foreigners be freed.
Mr. Perez de Cuellar expressed a hope that nations with a military presence in the gulf region would show prudence in the days to come, saying it would ease his task.
Mr. Aziz confirmed today that he intends to confer with the Secretary General this week.
Interviewed by Cable News Network in Baghdad, he said, ''We are open to listen to suggestions.'' He would not comment on whether his country was prepared to make concessions on its takeover of Kuwait.
Telephone calls to the Kuwaiti Mission to the United Nations late today went unanswered.
 
Secretary General's Role
Mr. Maksoud of the Arab League said that as ''the institutional personification of the United Nations,'' Mr. Perez de Cuellar ''has a stake in bringing about a diffusion of the level of tension, and restoring rational discourse as a prelude to a consequential negotiated settlement.''
He said the Secretary General faced the challenge of reconciling ''the requirements of legitimacy - that is, the Iraqi withdrawal and the restoration of the legitimate Government of Kuwait,'' without jeopardizing the chances for peace.
''It's a very difficult task,'' Mr. Maksoud said. But he said Mr. Perez de Cuellar had already helped to alter a ''collision course'' in the gulf crisis by seeking talks with Mr. Aziz.

HEADLINE: Church Poses No Threat To Park, Lujan Asserts

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GARDINER, Mont., Aug. 26

 BODY:
For nearly a decade, followers of Elizabeth Clare Prophet have come to the spectacular Upper Yellowstone Valley, drawn by the woman they call Guru Ma. Hundreds of members of her Church Universal and Triumphant settled here, near huge bomb shelters they have cut into the mountainside and stocked with radiation suits, food and automatic weapons.
Superintendent Robert D. Barbee of Yellowstone National Park and his assistant, Joseph Allston, have called development of the church land the single greatest environmental threat to the 2.4-million-acre park, with its geysers, hot springs, mud pots, bears and elk. With tensions growing, President Bush's Secretary of the Interior, Manuel Lujan Jr. asked to meet the spiritual leader to see if he could help work out a solution. 
Over coffee at the church-owned Ranch Kitchen restaurant on Wednesday, they talked amiably about bison, wolves, grizzlies, fences, geothermal wells, cattle and water. When it was over, Mr. Lujan was asked if he thought the church represented a threat to Yellowstone or its wildlife.
 
'We Can Work Things Out'
''I don't think so,'' he replied. ''I've always thought we can work things out. Our conversations were very pleasant. I came away with the feeling that we can be, in the final analysis, good neighbors by sitting around and discussing the issue and try to come up with some solution.''
Officials at Yellowstone were astounded, although they would not publicly contradict their boss. ''We could not believe it,'' one official said, speaking on the condition of anonymity.
During his four-hour visit to the park, Mr. Lujan also said the fires two years ago had ''devastated a lot of it.'' Many local officials and merchants said they were disturbed by the comment, which they said was overstated and undermined efforts by park officials and private agencies, which have spent millions promoting the ''rebirth'' of Yellowstone.
Mr. Lujan's staff soon found itself scrambling once again to explain his sometimes unpredictable comments. He had ignited similar exchanges of criticism and explanation in March when he said the Endangered Species Act had sometimes been used to stop economic progress.
 
No Endorsement of Church
His chief spokesman in Washington, Steve Goldstein, said then that the Secretary wanted only to make the law more flexible, not weaken it. This weekend Mr. Goldstein said Mr. Lujan's comment about Mrs. Prophet was not meant as an endorsement of the church's activities but only as an offer of conciliation. ''In no way does the Secretary support the activities of the church,'' Mr. Goldstein said, adding, ''Just because they practice a religion you might not agree with does not mean you can pretend they don't exist. They are the major landowner next to Yellowstone.''
Asked about the Secretary's description of the park as devastated, Mr. Goldstein said Mr. Lujan had been referring only to the worst parts of the park that he had seen in a helicopter tour. Mr. Lujan did not mean that description to apply to the whole park, Mr. Goldstein said.
In Nevada today, Mr. Lujan said a plan to protect the spotted owl in the Pacific Northwest would result in fewer jobs lost than originally thought and would probably protect fewer old stands of timber than environmentalists would like. In support of the plan, he said he had seen a spotted owl last week in Oregon ''and it wasn't in old-growth timber, so it showed me that the owls can live outside the old-growth areas,'' The Associated Press reported. He was not asked about his comments on Yellowstone.
Such comments from the man who is the custodian for the nation's national parks, have incensed political critics and environmentalists. George T. Frampton Jr., president of the Wilderness Society said the comment was ''on the par with a number of other goofy things he has said.''
 
Caution From Senator
''We probably know more about the Northern spotted owl than any species on the endangered species list, and scientists are unanimous in saying that it needs old-growth forest for nesting and reproduction in order to keep the species viable.''
In a letter to Mr. Lujan on Thursday, Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, said that after nearly a decade of controversy and a leak of 31,000 gallons of diesel fuel from a bomb shelter at Mrs. Prophet's ranch, state officials must monitor the church closely. ''I hope your remarks do not reflect a lack of commitment to such monitoring,'' he wrote.
The church began buying land here in 1981 and now owns about 33,000 acres in four parcels just north of the northwest corner of the park. They are building a self-sufficient community that can live sealed off from the world.
The church has built a six-foot high wooden fence along 2.5 miles of the park's boundary, a fence that park officials say impedes animal movement.
In addition, the church plans to use geothermal energy to heat greenhouses by tapping underground sources at LaDuke Hot Spring. The park service has said it believes the hot spring is connected by a geological fault to the famed Norris Geyser Basin about 20 miles away in the park and such drilling could disrupt the natural water flow that causes the geysers. Congress has placed a moratorium on such projects in the area pending completion of a study on their possible effect.
A state court had halted work on the bomb shelter until an environmental impact statement is amended.
After Mr. Lujan's visit, church officials said they were pleased with what a spokesman, Murray Steinman, called a ''good exchange'' with Mr. Lujan.
Edward L. Francis, Mrs. Prophet's husband and chief spokesman, said in a written statement, ''We look forward to maintaining a positive dialogue with Yellowstone Park and the Department of the Interior in the future.''
In Washington, Representative Bruce F. Vento, a Minnesota Democrat who is chairman of the House Subcommittee on National Parks and Public Lands, said that Mr. Lujan may have had good intentions in meeting with Mrs. Prophet but that he undermined park service professionals. ''This coffee and cookie meeting only trivializes the serious issues of public interface with public lands,'' he said. ''These people are threatening public lands.''
After his meeting with the church leaders, Mr. Lujan said he was just trying to find solutions.
''They were concerned about the bison getting with their cattle, as are all other ranchers. We discussed the question of the geothermal well. Perhaps there may be some solutions there. We'll keep talking to see if we come to some kind of, something we can agree.''

CORRECTION-DATE: August 31, 1990, Friday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article on Monday about Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr.'s comments on the Church Universal and Triumphant referred incorrectly to its bomb shelters in a mountainside in Montana. The shelters are not known to be stocked with automatic weapons.

HEADLINE: 2d-Largest Philanthropy Widens Role

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA

 BODY:
Even here in Philadelphia, where the Pew family amassed a fortune from Sun Oil Company profits, the Pew Charitable Trusts are hardly a household name. But they are the country's second-most generous philanthropy, behind only the Ford Foundation and comfortably ahead of better-known giants like the Rockefeller, Carnegie and Mellon foundations.
For years Pew shrouded its charitable activities, citing the family's religious conviction that charity needed no rewards. There are no museums, universities or other landmarks bearing the Pew name. But now the charity, which has $3.3 billion in assets and gave away $145 million last year, is moving through a period of intense change as it seeks to become a major figure in national philanthropy. 
In a two-year overhaul, it replaced 95 percent of its staff and hired a team of specialists with impressive academic credentials to oversee its programs. And it is broadening its focus. Where once it concentrated largely on universities, parks and the arts, especially in the Delaware Valley, it is now moving into new areas like energy conservation and an ambitious program to help thousands of poor urban children by providing comprehensive health and social services to their families.
 
Some May Be Surprised
''Pew intends to make a major effort to help our disadvantaged population,'' said Dr. Thomas W. Langfitt, a 62-year-old neurosurgeon who has been its president since 1986. That, he added, ''might surprise some people accustomed to think of the old Pew as reactionary and secretive in its early years.''
The changes at Pew reflect a significant evolution of the family philanthropy. Until 1987, seven separate family charities operated under the Glenmede Trust Company, a banking entity widely seen as a shield for some members' financial support for conservative politics. The charity did not even publish a philanthropy report until 1980. Asked about gifts, J. Howard Pew, the Sun Oil chairman who died in 1971, is said to have shouted: ''I'm not telling anybody anything. It's my money, isn't it?''
Pew's program for the next three to five years is being developed by an almost totally new staff, mainly recruited from outside Philadelphia. The new executive director is Rebecca W. Rimel, a 39-year-old nurse who was engaged in research on head injuries when Dr. Langfitt met her at the University of Virginia and brought her to Pew to direct health activities. Her deputy, Michael Rubinger, is a New Yorker with 20 years' experience in neighborhood development programs.
The new Pew team leaders are widely recognized for previous accomplishments. But they are still strangers to their peers at other philanthropies and Pew's grant-seeking clients. For months they have been drafting white papers, outlining Pew's future interests in education, culture, religion, health and human services, and even global issues. (One, Drew E. Altman, a former Human Services Commissioner in New Jersey who directed Pew's $48 million program for health and human services, has left to become president of the Kaiser Family Foundation in California.) 'One Stop' Family Services Pew will continue to devote 30 percent of its budget to work in the Delaware Valley. But some local activities will be cut out, including an eight-year-old summer program to help thousands of high school students explore careers in business. The decision to leave that program drew criticism from some supporters and led to worries about other projects.
R. Anderson Pew, chairman of the charity's nine-member board, which has five family members, said Pew's activities generally evoked an ''unwarranted degree of fear, which only time will cure.''
''While Pew's resources are growing,'' he went on, ''competition for the charitable dollar also is growing. Organizations can no longer expect grants to be continued automatically and will have to demonstrate competence or get bumped by others that are better.''
Pew's most ambitious new activity is the Philadelphia Schools Collaborative, a $9 million effort to improve education at 22 local high schools. That program, said to be the nation's largest private donation to a public school system, is reported to have contributed to significant progress in reducing dropout rates.
The charity is trying to create another national model in Philadelphia: a service for children from birth to the age of 6. The aim is to coordinate more than 40 fragmented government-financed aid programs into a single ''one stop'' family service that would cover a whole section of a city. At one site, children, pregnant teen-agers and their family members would be able to get health care, counseling, training and other assistance.
 
Apprentices to the Future
Pew is also supporting Jobs for the Future, an effort to move high school students into apprenticeships that will train them for highly skilled jobs. This will be done at 15 sites around the country, and Pew is looking for other foundations to join the program.
''We are the only industrialized country without an organized way to help youth make a transition to work,'' said Robert B. Schwartz, a former special assistant to Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts, who directs Pew's $35-million-a-year education program.
Pew is promoting an energy efficiency program in New England, initiated by the Conservation Law Foundation of Boston in cooperation with local utilities. It involves designing and installing energy-saving devices in homes, businesses and commercial buldings.
The charity's longstanding support for religious institutions will be augmented by fellowships and research, including studies of religion's impact on politics and on creating and resolving conflicts. And Pew will work with other philanthropies to encourage economic reforms and democratic institutions in Eastern Europe.
Pew, which spends $22 million a year on the arts, helped develop a consortium of major museums to use video programs to enhance visitors' appreciation of the arts. It provided $1.5 million for a museum loan program, to encourage institutions to lend other museums artwork that would otherwise languish in storage.
 
Beyond Philadelphia, and Back
The charity's housing efforts were once concentrated in Philadelphia; now it plans to promote low-income housing on a national scale and to consider special needs, like housing for the mentally ill.
''We see Philadelphia as a place to build models that can be replicated in other cities,'' said Ms. Rimel. ''But we'll also be searching nationally for innovations we can bring home to Philadelphia.''
Looking at the directions the philanthropy is taking, Mr. Pew said, he is mystified that some still consider the Pews (and there are now 1,000 descendants) ultra-conservatives.
''Our Aunt Harriet Pew in Civil War days ran an underground railroad helping slaves from Parker's Landing in Virginia,'' he said. ''You can't get much more liberal than that.''

HEADLINE: Give Me, Also, Your Skilled

 BODY:
America is about to enhance its reputation as a nation of immigrants, and not just for tired, huddled masses. Legislation moving through Congress would increase the number of immigrants, making it easier for families to unite and for businesses to recruit skilled workers. This first major overhaul of legal immigration in 25 years would be as welcome as it is overdue. 
America's willingness to admit foreigners has always been influenced by economic conditions and occasional xenophobia. From the 1920's to 1965, a national-origins quota system favored immigrants from northwestern Europe. In a 1965 reform, Congress gave more favorable treatment to immigrants from Asia and the Western Hemisphere.
Still, the vast majority of immigrants could qualify for admission only on the basis of their relationship to people already resident in the United States. Potential immigrants with needed skills had a hard time competing for entry with sons, daughters, brothers and sisters.
Now, America realizes how much it needs such skills, let alone the ambition and energy of the immigrants who possess them. Global competition and a decline in American work-force skills have prompted Congress to pay more attention to the needs of the economy.
A bill passed by the Senate last year would establish one immigration category for family members and one for independents, mostly workers. Under this bill, sponsored by Edward Kennedy of Massachusetts and Alan Simpson of Wyoming, about 630,000 immigrants would be allowed to enter each year, about 136,000 more than entered in 1988. Of the total, 480,000 would qualify under various family preferences; 150,000 would be admitted as independents.
For the first time, about a third of these work-based immigrants would be admitted without specific jobs but with specific skills needed in the U.S. That would be the same number of immigrants -54,000 - now admitted under sponsorship by specific employers.
In the House, a bill sponsored by Bruce Morrison of Connecticut is likely to reach the floor soon. It would allow up to 775,000 legal immigrants each year, including 520,000 for family members and 75,000 for skilled workers. The House bill also would admit about 55,000 ''diversity'' immigrants a year from areas that have not obtained many visas in recent years, like Ireland and Africa.
The House bill also contains a more troublesome provision that smacks of the old-time fear of foreigners. The bill would impose a fee, $500 to $1,000, on companies with 50 or more employees, for each foreign worker they hired. The money would be placed in a trust fund to retrain American workers. Unions defend the fund as reasonable social policy, particularly if a portion is targeted for women and minorities.
But there is little logic and no justice in imposing such a fee only on companies that can efficiently use new workers. There may be good reason for America to retrain workers, whether displaced by new machines, new products or new workers. If so, the retraining cost ought fairly to be borne by all. To load it all on a few industries with a $500 head tax is unfair, even punitive.
There will be time to iron out such differences. For the moment, it's enough to celebrate the recognition by Congress that skilled immigrants offer the economy new energy and hope.

HEADLINE: Protecting Democracy in Pakistan

 BODY:
Pakistan's President, Ghulam Ishaq Khan, carefully observed constitutional formalities when he ousted the elected Government of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto earlier this month. Ms. Bhutto was nevertheless the victim of a coup in constitutional clothing, sponsored from behind the scenes by military leaders.
Subsequent events have heightened concern that Pakistan's brief democratic interlude could now be ending. A return to military rule in this strategically located country of 100 million would be a severe setback for U.S. policies and could disrupt a relationship that currently provides Pakistan with some $600 million a year in economic and military assistance. 
President Ishaq Khan cited corruption and incompetence as his reasons for removing Ms. Bhutto's Government. There's plausibility to both charges. But democratic practice calls for resolving them in less arbitrary ways. Incompetent governments can be voted out of office. Corrupt officials can be exposed and prosecuted.
Pakistan's present Constitution incorporates changes made during the rule of the military strongman Gen. Mohammad Zia ul-Haq. These subordinated the elected Prime Minister to a President presumed closer to military thinking. Pakistan has been ruled by military governments for more than half its 43-year history. President Ishaq Khan used his constitutional powers to decree a state of emergency and install an interim Government led by a minority party the military likes better than Ms. Bhutto's Pakistan Peoples Party. This new Government, led by Ghulam Mustafa Jatoi, has created special tribunals to try officials of the Bhutto regime.
New elections are still promised for Oct. 24, but such promises have been broken too many times in the recent past to inspire great confidence. An election that excluded Ms. Bhutto or key members of her party could scarcely be considered democratic.
Because Washington winked at anti-democratic practices during the Zia years, Pakistan's generals may be wagering that the U.S. will be indulgent again this time. That's a foolish bet. General Zia was treated with kid gloves because Washington valued his commitment to expelling Soviet troops from Afghanistan.
Those troops are now out. With Washington and Moscow talking compromise, a new military-backed regime in Islamabad could become an obstacle to an Afghanistan settlement. A new government also increases tensions in the still dangerous confrontation with India over Kashmir. Heavy artillery fire broke out along the Kashmir frontier last week. And Washington continues to worry about Pakistan's efforts to develop nuclear weapons.
Neither the Bush Administration nor Congress is likely to wink again should Pakistan abandon its hard-won democratic rule.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (95%); PAKISTAN (94%); ASIA (92%); AFGHANISTAN (92%); INDIA (79%); RUSSIAN FEDERATION (51%); 

STATE: KASHMIR (92%);

SECTION: Section A; Page 16, Column 5; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 213 words

HEADLINE: Political Influence Corrodes the Civil Service;
Foxes in Chicken Coop

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Paul Volcker's discussion of the quality of Government personnel (Op-Ed, Aug. 5) omits salient facts. Mr. Volcker fails to mention that in 1979-80 Ronald Reagan ran against ''Washington,'' to get Government off our backs, and that the derision of bureaucrats was central in his arsenal of anecdotes and cliches.
What Mr. Volcker ignores is that Mr. Reagan made numerous appointments to head major Government entities of people with conflicts of interest who opposed the very missions of their agencies and who presided over their defunding, demoralization and the exit of quality personnel. These attacks on the Government service were warmly supported by the business community, which invested heavily and enthusiastically in Mr. Reagan's election and re-election.
This process of undermining Government, frequently associated with Republican party rule, goes back a long way and seems to be related to a market economy, the demands of its important constituencies and American cultural characteristics. In appealing for reform to educators and the public at large, Mr. Volcker misses both the agents and process whereby the quality of Government service is kept at a low level in this country.
 
EDWARD S. HERMAN
 Penn Valley, Pa., Aug. 11, 1990

HEADLINE: To Cut the S.& L. Losses . . .

BYLINE: By Bob Kasten; Bob Kasten, Republican of Wisconsin, is a member of the Senate Appropriations and Budget Committees.

DATELINE: MILWAUKEE, Wis.

 BODY:
Washington budget summit negotiators have been engaged in a political tug of war over which taxes to raise to pay for the savings and loan bailout. What they should be addressing is the more important question of how to keep the tab from rising. Policy-makers have ignored one of the most effective steps we can take to stem further S.& L. losses: A cut in the capital gains tax.
When we in Congress return from the August recess, we will have to deal quickly with the escalating costs of the bailout, currently estimated at $150 billion. Our task is now complicated by another economic problem precipitated by the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and rising oil prices. 
A recession could trigger a new round of S.& L. failures, requiring taxpayers in the Northeast and Midwest to send even more of their hard-earned tax dollars to bailout the depositors at failed savings and loans in Western states.
The final cost for the cleanup depends on how many more savings institutions will have to be rescued -and how much money the Federal Government can recover from selling the seized assets.
A new U.S. Chamber of Commerce study has estimated that my bill to cut the capital gains tax from 33 to 15 percent would raise the value of the real estate assets held by the Government by 13.7 precent, and lower the cost of the bailout by $19.8 billion.
Since the 65 percent capital gains tax increase in 1986 - the greatest in U.S. history - the value of all capital assets, including commercial real estate and junk bonds held by banks and thrifts as collateral, has steadily declined.
The logic behind this is simple: The value of an asset is determined by the income you can expect to earn from it. The higher the capital gains tax, the lower the expected future income and, hence, the lower the value of the asset.
Because of the high capital gains tax, the Resolution Trust Corporation - the agency created to sell the assets of failed thrifts - has inherited a portfolio of devalued property. Furthermore, declining real estate prices have pushed more thrifts into insolvency, doubling the cost estimates for the cleanup over the last 12 months.
By increasing potential income, a capital gains tax cut would boost the value of all capital assets overnight. The Government's portfolio of foreclosed assets would command higher prices at auction. Savings institutions on the brink of insolvency could be given a new lease on life as the value of their capital assets rises, thus avoiding higher bailout costs.
On Aug. 2, L. William Seidman, the chairman of the bailout agency, told the Senate Banking Committee: ''There is no question in my mind that a great many people who are purchasers are buying these assets for the purpose of seeing them appreciate and selling them, and clearly if the [capital gains] tax was lower, they would be more interested.''
The less the Government has to pay to hold on to these assets, and the more revenue we get for them, the less taxpayers will have to pay.
In addition, the higher real estate values will strengthen the financial condition of institutions like the Federal Housing Authority and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, helping prevent similar kinds of taxpayer bailouts in the future.
Aside from easing the burden of the bailout, a 15 percent capital gains tax would spark the kind of investment and entrepreneurial capitalism that our economy needs to get back on track. And according to economist Allen Sinai, the cut would generate $30 to $40 billion in new tax revenue for the U.S. Treasury over five years and create 2.5 million new jobs.
Capital gains tax cuts aren't a ''give-away to the rich.'' By reducing the cost of the savings and loan bailout, this pro-growth tax cut will eliminate the need to raise taxes on working Americans.

SECTION: Section B; Page 1, Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1303 words

HEADLINE: Welfare Chief Battles Crises and Critics

BYLINE: By THOMAS MORGAN

 BODY:
The job is daunting and she knows it. Barbara J. Sabol, New York City's new Human Resources Administrator, is struggling -some say without success - to nudge a mammoth bureaucracy not known for compassion into being more responsive to the city's most vulnerable citizens.
When Mrs. Sabol took office on April 4, one of the last major appointees of the Dinkins administration, the nurse and veteran social-welfare administrator promised a new management team and a new focus on preventive measures, rather than crisis intervention in foster care, child welfare and homelessness.
''We have an agency of last resort, and what we want to do is find ways to keep families together,'' Mrs. Sabol said in an interview earlier this month.
Community leaders, union officials and child-welfare advocates praise Mrs. Sabol's enthusiasm and openness to changing agency policies and to seeking advice from outsiders. 
But five months since she took office, while they like her plans for change, they say they see little of it. Homeless families continue to be housed in decrepit, unsavory welfare hotels. Child-welfare advocates say that the city's growing foster-care program is poorly run and that several thousand families each month who depend on public-assistance checks for food and shelter are still at risk of being dumped from the rolls for purely administrative reasons.
While Mrs. Sabol shares Mayor David N. Dinkins's philosophy that the best way to deliver social services is at the neighborhood level rather than in citywide centers, a concept that has been debated for years, her agency has not come forward with plans to accomplish that goal. How Many Are Minding the Store? And Mrs. Sabol's critics and some admirers are concerned that as she begins to revamp the agency, few are minding the store. She asked for and got resignations from more than a dozen top deputy or assistant commissioners, directors of borough welfare offices and scores of middle-level supervisors.
Some remain as acting supervisors until replacements are found, but advocates for the homeless and those on welfare say it is often hard to get decisions on policy issues and definitive answers from agency officials, particularly in the troubled Child Welfare Administration, which is without a permanent administrator, and from the Human Resources Administration's legal staff.
''When positions are not filled, that's a problem for our clients,'' said Jane Sufian, a lawyer with the Legal Aid Society who monitors the foster-care program. ''When people are in acting positions, they are caretakers. You don't have someone to talk to about problems, who are going to be there on a long-term basis.''
 
'Vacuum in Decision Making'
David Tobis, a senior research scientist at Hunter College's Center for the Study of Family Policy, said, ''There is a vacuum in decision making, especially in the Child Welfare Administration.''
''They've gotten rid of the old management, which is positive,'' Mr. Tobis said. ''But the agency now has no clear direction. The management staff below does not know what is going on above. Sabol is a breath of fresh air and people hope things will improve, but the hammer has yet to hit the anvil.''
Mrs. Sabol, in the interview, countered those charges by saying that significant change takes time.
She said she is conducting searches to find the best qualified managers to head the agency's troubled divisions. She said her staff members have begun evaluating welfare guidelines, seeking ways to improve the system. And she has asked New York State's social-service experts to help the city improve training for caseworkers.
 
Impromptu Shelter Visits
Her years as deputy executive commissioner of state social services meant that she was no stranger within the agency when she arrived. She is known for detail, a deliberate personal style, 15-hour workdays and an inability to keep the plants in her office alive.
Often, without notice, the 52-year-old Mrs. Sabol drops in on social-service centers and homeless shelters and asks what caseworkers need to do their jobs better.
Mrs. Sabol has two powerful allies: Mayor Dinkins and her boss for the last six years, Cesar A. Perales, the New York State Commissioner of Social Services, who in the past has often been at odds with New York City officials.
At her urging, the Mayor, at a time of budget belt-tightening, has increased the H.R.A. budget to $6.1 billion from $5.4 billion to address a growing public assistance caseload and to start preventive drug-treatment programs.
Mr. Perales expects to work more closely with H.R.A. than in the past.
''I know how Barbara thinks,'' he said. ''She feels strongly about the responsibility of government to disadvantaged people, especially children. When she worked for me as executive deputy commissioner, she was very effective at running the day-to-day activities of this agency and was good at follow-up and details.''
She has put some new programs in place. Under Mrs. Sabol's guidance, H.R.A. has opened Medicaid offices at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center and Bronx-Lebanon Hospital to help welfare clients get timely medical assistance.
In addition, the agency has expanded its drug-treatment programs by awarding contracts totaling $23.9 million to 29 private and nonprofit agencies for drug treatment and related counseling services for 1,000 families.
 
Critics Want More
''Substance abuse is one of the major problems facing families,'' Mrs. Sabol said, ''and we want to match preventive services with drug treatment to help keep them together.''
Her critics say all this is good, but not enough, particularly as the number of people in need rises as the local economy weakens.
In roughly 700 sites around the city, the agency's 35,000 employees serve more than 1.4 million poor people whose needs are legion.
The agency's public-assistance caseload has already risen 10 percent over last year's level, to almost 400,000 cases. One agency official said the caseload is increasing by 12,000 to 16,000 new cases each month.
Nearly 50,000 children are in the city's foster-care system, the casualties of parents in the throes of drug abuse, homelessness and AIDS.
While the city has moved almost 3,000 families out of scandal-ridden welfare hotels during the year, several hundred remain there. City officials said they have failed to meet their own goal of closing welfare hotels because more people need assistance than was forecast last year, and projects to build or renovate more permanent housing are behind schedule.
''The issue isn't that there are families in welfare hotels but how to reduce the numbers of families seeking shelter that continue to drive the welfare crisis,'' said Steven Banks, a lawyer with the Legal Aid Society's Homeless Family Rights project.
''With hundreds of families entering the shelter system each month, which is becoming the only way to get city-sponsored housing,'' Mr. Banks said, ''it's incumbent on the city to implement a comprehensive homeless prevention program rather than simply scramble and deal with families in welfare hotels.
''More than 400 families live in barracks-style congregate homeless shelters where there have been outbreaks of chicken pox and measles. We've not seen any plan by which the city will get all of the families out of such shelters by September 30, 1991, the court-ordered deadline.''
Mrs. Sabol said that her agency cannot do everything at once, or alone.
''H.R.A. has got to be working with community organizations in a partnership to solve these problems,'' she said. ''We can improve life chances for poor children. I know this. I tell our staff that if you are making decisions and want to know what to do, ask the question, 'Is this best for children and families?' ''
